description:
I came here for lunch with my gf and her daughter a few days ago while visiting SF, and we had a great experience.

Being Peruvian myself, I'm familiar with both Peruvian cuisine and with this franchise, which also has locations i. Lima and Miami. When I knew they also had a location in SF, I knew I had to try it, and it did not disappoint. 

We started off with a mixed ceviche in spicy red pepper cream, which was great. The seafood was fresh, and the entire dish was flavorful, refreshing, and actually spicy. Then my gf had the seafood cilantro fried rice w/ onion, ceviche juice & yellow pepper sauce; this dish was excellent. I had the sautéed beef tenderloin, which was also excellent. The been was tender, juicy, and the rest of the dish complimented it well. My gf's daughter had the burger w/ egg & huacatay pepper cream, which was also very good; fresh and flavorful. We also had pisco punch & chicharita cocktails, which were both tasty and refreshing. We finished with a tres leches cake, which was the perfect way to end our meal.

One thing to note, this place is pricey, but I'm sure anyone considering coming here probably knows that already. Overall, I had a great lunch here. I would recommend it to anyone lookout for great Peruvian/fusion food in the bay area.
author: Renzo I.

description:
My husband took me here to celebrate my birthday tonight (Side note: He made reservations on Open Table where he mentioned the special occasion, but the message never got to our waitress, so I was a little disappointed. I'll get over it...I think...), but the food, service, and ambiance was still amazing!

We started off with the Empanada Tasting Sampler, which included: Mushroom, Chicken, Beef, and Choclo (Sweet Corn) and the Nikei Cebiche, which had Tuna, Avocado, Cucumber, Daikon, Onions, and Nori. The Empanadas were delicious, flaky, and perfectly cooked (not oily like some places). It was the perfect size for 2 hungry diners. My tastebuds were incredibly happy. My husband ate ALL of the Cebiche by himself, so that should tell you about how yummy that was! 

For my entree, I ordered the Arroz La Mar with all kinds of melt in your mouth seafood on top of arborio rice. The flavors were balanced and the portion size was larger than I thought it would be, so it was filling. My husband ordered the Arroz Negro that came with Halibut (catch of the day) on top of a black rice stew and it was presented beautifully. I had to try it and loved it as much as my dish with its meatiness and creaminess. 

On to the dessert (with no candle...), we shared the Choco Maracuya with chocolate and passion fruit mousse on top of an almond praline. This was a bit too rich and decadent for me, but I was having a YOLO moment, so it was all good.
author: Lori C.

description:
This was my second favorite restaurant in San Francisco. The whole experience here was just excellent. 

Every single items we got here was simply delicious and is on par with La Mar standards. 

Looking forward to checking out the one in Peru since the one in Miami is just as good. 

I highly recommend trying their cocktails...they are always so good and refreshing here.
author: Sheila P.

description:
After a 3 month long project with unimaginable pain and agony, our generous leader decided to take the entire team out for a fancy night out. It was a 'Thank You' for our efforts, and he even allowed us to choose a nice restaurant. After much menu browsing, careful deliberating, and painful eliminations, La Mar Cebicheria was crowned winner for our restaurant of choice.

The place is absolutely gorgeous. It's the kind of place that makes me feel like I'm on vacation, even with my work laptop humming in my backpack. We were very lucky to be seated at a table with a spectacular view of the San Francisco Bay, and the waters in the golden hour was simply too beautiful. But still, we were hesitant. With so many other restaurants on the Embarcadero, how were we to be sure that we had made the best choice of a restaurant? A restaurant that we expect to be SO good that it should alleviate our PTSD of sending 2358208 emails for that one single project. 

It was at this moment of indecisiveness that a musically talented crab hopped onto our table. It was assumed that this creature must be part of the restaurant staff since he was wearing a tiny name tag that read - 'Sebastian'. Sebastian tapped his pincers onto my glass of Whiskey Smash and fashioned a lovely melody. As he prepared his vocals for the song, I began to recognize that the melody sounded a bit like... like.. 'Under the Sea'.

(please sing along to the tune of Under the Sea, from The Little Mermaid)

The food always look so much better
In some other restaurant's plate
You talk about going elsewhere
But that is a big mistake
Just look at La Mar around you
Right here on the Waterfront!
Such wonderful things on the menu
What more are you craving for? 

Under the seaaaa
Under the seaaa
Ceviches are better
For appetizers 
Peruvian gleeee
This is an adventure for your taste
Oxtail and sauce in the croquette
Focus on eating
In your work meeting
Under the sea!

The hour here is always happy
Our love for the sour Piscos
Tuna, Veggie, and Calamari
All pretty in Ceviche bowl 
The Prawn here thinks he a lucky fellow
But he in for a spicier fate
Served with Aji Amarillo 
And rice on the Entrée plate! 

Under the sea
Under the sea
Enjoy it with beer
Cebicheria 
Seafooood is meee!
A glass of our local Chardonnay
Sourced from here, the beautiful Bay!
We got no trouble
Rose and Bubbles
Under the sea!

**Sebastian points his pincer to our view of the Bay. A band of sea creatures shot out of the waters spinning, and suspended themselves in mid-air. There were clams, crustaceans, fishes, you name it! They, too began to hum along to the melody, producing a booming chorus for what was to be the final verse. Sebastian began once again **

(Sing to a higher volume of the Under the Sea tune)

Yeah, under the sea (under the sea!)
Under the sea (under the sea!)
The taste makes you gallop 
Just try the scallop
It's such a treeeeat! (tre-tre-tre-ee-eat-eat!)
What do they got? (some food from land!)
WE GOT THE WHOLE MARISCO BAND
Nothing is better
La Mar Cebicheria
UNDER THE SEA!

...
..
.
Okay, La Mar was definitely the right choice.
author: Ringo M.

description:
Craving some Peruvian food? This is the place to go in SF. But, just a heads up, it's not cheap! Excluding drinks, we spent $70/person. This is a great restaurant to go to with a big group and order family style.

We ordered the Ceviche tasting & the Causa tasting & the classic Lomo Saltado. For dessert we also got the peruvian classic Tres Leches cake. They were all delicious but I especially liked the Lomo Saltado. Can't go wrong with a classic! Next time I'd love to try more dishes and go with more people.
author: Rohenne L.

description:
Almost as good as it's Lima location, but with the San Francisco price tag. Some friends and I were here the other day and the food and drinks were delicious. My friend ordered us a round of their tamarindo (?) margaritas and they were AMAZING! Seriously though, I'm still thinking about them. 

I'm taking off a star because our server was really rude and not friendly at all. I don't think he liked one of my friends for asking about happy hour. It doesn't hurt to ask ‍ and we're still staying and ordering several rounds of drinks and food.
author: Mikala W.

description:
Friday night dinner for two at 7PM.  Online reservations, we were immediatly seated (in general area, not in the patio section which has a direct view of the bay and Ferries and partial Bay Bridge view (if you sit in the far left back part of the patio...))

Ambiance was very fun, interesting artwork, high ceilings, very open, music, great conversation levels and all manner of folks having dinner there (romantic dinners, business dinners, single diners, family meals, large parties).

We ordered the Volcan and Chilito cocktails (very colorful, each with a 3" spiced ice-ball in the middle).   These were fun to sip and we never got around to ordering wine with dinner.

We decided to sample things rather than to order entrees.  The Cibiche 4 Estacioned tasting was 5 star - large portions, very bright sauce, beautiful tasting and fresh fish.   The empanada tasting (we ordered 4  and cut them in half) was very filling and hearty with a creamy sauce.   Also tried two fish skewers (the fish was a light dense and overcooked) - will try some other side next time.  

The server was super friendly and helpful on what initially looks like a daunting menu - and the only complaint was that all of out plates came out at once - and it seemed like we were a bit rushed to eat (don't want to let the skewers and empanadas sit too long.)
author: Bill H.

description:
We came here for a date night and both had a really good time with satisfied tummies!

Waterfront view, check. 
Delicious food, check. 
Romantic vibe, check. 
Great service, check. 
Yummy drinks, check. 
Convenient location, check. 
Outdoory seatings (with heater and balcony  wind cover), check. 

Highly recommend the verde (salmon Peruvian sashimi), arroz norteno (shrimps lovers' heaven!!!), and Lomo Saltado. 

Guess who are in love with Peruvian food now! Make sure to make reservation before you come. It's worth it!
author: Nancy H.

description:
Came here with a buddy, sat at the bar. 

Bartender girl was friendly. I have a major mollusk allergy, so she made sure to ask the chef if the California Cebiche had any mollusk ingredients. Thankfully, no! So we went ahead and ordered it. 

I had the Whiskey Smash (light fruity taste, subtly sweet...just what I wanted!) and friend had the El Clásico (he said it was good, nothing extraordinary). 

The cebiche was refreshing and light, nice flavors. Vibrant, attractive colors! Wouldn't necessarily come back for it though. 

Overall it was a nice experience, but I'm not drawn to go back any time soon.
author: Peds P.

description:
I had the gift of taking one of the most special people in my life out for her birthday, so for several months I brainstormed "most epic dinner ever" and booked a reservation at La Mar Cebichería Peruana. The result?

Gaston Acurio's San Francisco love child gave us one of my top dining experiences ever. And La Mar will give that to you, too. 
*****
I. FIRST IMPRESSIONS: Upon entering, you'll notice the two-story high ceilings that fill with lively leg-shuffling music and decorated with vibrant colors reflective of the colors worn by Peru's mountain peoples. Chef Acurio's "Peru: The Cookbook" lines the wall on the right next to the host table. Get excited.

II. ROOM SETUP: After you pass the host room, where the pristine bathrooms reside, you'll see the main dining room and then the kitchen to the left. They have a patio outside, which they often reserve for private parties. They dim the lights, making it a very intimate restaurant. 

We sat next to the wall directly across from the kitchen. 

III. FOOD & DRINK: In traditional Peruvian fashion, they offer salads, ceviche (basically Peruvian style hamachi, sashimi), and different large seafood plates and land animal & potato/ starch entrees. What we tried:

*Cebiche 4 Estaciones: As the name implies, the appetizer arrived with four different ceviches.: 
- Halibut in artichoke leche de tigre.
- Salmon in avocado leche de tigre.
- Tombo tuna in aji Amarillo leche de tigre.
- Ahi tuna in rocoto leche de tigre. 

What's not to like? Fresh fish, balanced out with different acid, spice, and textures. All delicious. 

*Pulpo Anticucho: We received this beautifully charred and thick octopus, which the chef paired placed on top of blanched piquillo pepper, a bed of potato, garlic, olive aioli, and arugula salad. The dish sits on the heartier side, despite the octopus being incredibly soft. 

*Chicken Empanada: Absolutely flaky with a fantastic meat to dough ratio. I dug the sauce, but it didn't serve as a highlight of the meal. Get it if you love empanadas. Peruvian empanadas are baked and delicate and these were solid. This wasn't the best dish of the night, but the sauce on the bottom helped add creaminess to the chicken inside the empanada. 

*Lomo Saltado: Imagine a Japanese marinated meat with fries. It works. And so does their rendition of Lomo Saltado. I admit, I thought they overcooked the beef a bit, but the sauce brought everything together. 

*Tres Leches: Best course of the night. Perfectly soaked with condensed milk. It's soft and luscious with each bite. It's okay to cry. Honestly, though, I haven't eaten a better one in my life.

All dishes came out immaculately plated. I also thought that despite the higher price point -- come on, it's SF and you're on the docks -- the amount of food one receives is generous. 

IV. SERVICE: Daniel served us. Despite a small blip, he immediately corrected it. I also thought they did well with the timing of each course. 

V. PRICES: Pricey. Definitely a business or special occasion type of place. 

VI. OVERALL: I've traveled to SFO many times in my life, and I have to say that La Mar ranks as the best dining experience I've ever had. But more importantly, as a person unfamiliar with Peru and its culture, I immediately fell in love with the cuisine and the country. 

Thanks, Chef Acurio, for opening up my world view.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Definitely make a reservation as it can get very crowded. Though I was initially very disappointed to hear that they didn't have a table for us when we arrived for the reservation. Luckily, they had this tall table near the entrance that was open and we didn't mind having lunch there.

The food here is amazing and made up for that initial disappointment. Definitely be wary of prices though. We spent a small portion on octopus thinking that the market price of the dish wouldn't be more than $40. Boy were we wrong. 

Everything was so flavorful. We ordered this crab sashimi and octopus from the recommendation card and a ceviche. 

The chicha morado was refreshing especially since the octopus was a little spicy but a little too sweet for my taste.

I will definitely be back.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Food is so yummy, the wine tastes great.
It's located right next to the pier and it's ideal for date night.
Service was quick and great.
Haven't had such a great food in a long time.
Highly recommend this place.
author: Citizen D.

description:
Came in for a work dinner and was not impressed.

Ambiance: 3/5: huge dining area that looks like a warehouse. Loud, packed with people (mostly corporate dinners) and classic rock blaring through the speakers (at a Peruvian place I would prefer music to match the cuisine). It was nighttime so not much to see on the water and we couldn't sit outside because it was reserved for a private event, but that wasn't the restaurant's fault.

Food: 3/5 Some things were delicious, some were a disappointment. Everything was expensive. Presentation was lovely. Here's what we ordered.

- tiradito verde (salmon): this was bad. I love raw salmon and this tasted like the farm-raised lox slices you get at Safeway. Skip.
- oxtail croquettes: SO GOOD. This was one of our favorite dishes of the whole meal. definitely order. crispy croquette exterior with tons of oxtail meat inside. pro tip: goes great with the green sauce you get with the taro chips!
- empanadas: we got the 4 empanada tasting for $26. Wayyy overpriced. The beef was really good but the others were not worth the price. I know I shouldn't be expecting south american prices but these things were tiny. skip. 
- pork shank entree: DELICIOUS. get this. the meat falls off the bone and is melt-in-your-mouth tasty. Also goes great with that green sauce.
- lomo saltado: we got this because it's a traditional dish. great flavors but not nearly enough beef. More potatoes than anything, so keep that in mind when you order.
- Prawn special: I wanted to like this dish of 5 huge prawns served in a squash but it fell short. It came out cold and the prawns were undercooked and we had to send it back. Instead of making a new dish for us, they reheated the one we had already taken bites out of (which I always find to be a tacky means of resolution). When it finally came back the prawns were overcooked this time and the squash was a bit bland. Wouldn't order a special like this again.

Between the apps and the entrees, our server disappeared and forgot to take our order. We waited for over 20 minutes until we were able to flag him down. He tried to make up for it with complimentary tres leches at the end, which was dry but appreciated.

Don't think I'll be back.
author: Priyanka C.

description:
5 Stars for one of the best dinners of this Peruana's life. Sin exagerar. 

I've had La Mar on my radar for some time now. My family is Peruvian and we are big fans of Gaston Acurio- the chef who, quite simply, put Peruvian cuisine on the map. We own his cookbooks, and I've eaten at two of his restaurants in Peru (Cuzco and Lima). So, to say I was thrilled to be dining at La Mar as a surprise to celebrate my birthday while in SF would be a pretty substantial understatement. Someone knew me well when they planned this. *smile*

Our server, Daniel, started the meal off with outgoing friendliness and recommendations that reminded me of the service standards offered at the top restaurants in the country. At some point we got served the wrong dish and he handled it swiftly and with grace. (Apologetic even though we were not bothered by it.)

Dishes:
Cebiche 4 Estaciones: side by side servings of Halibut in artichoke leche de tigre; Tombo tuna in aji Amarillo leche de tigre; Salmon in avocado leche de tigre; Ahi tuna in rocoto leche de tigre. Of all of these, the two of us had different favorites. It was really based on personal preference because each one was unique in flavor profile and the seafood was as fresh as it could be.

Pulpo Anticucho: Anticucho is a Peruvian skewered meat, but when this came out, it surprised me as there was no skewer. Regardless, the pulpo was thick, charred, and a great consistency that you always hope for with octopus. Besides the protein, the dish included piquillo pepper beautifully blanched and placed atop small dollops of potato, garlic, and olive aioli, and an arugula salad in the middle. The pepper was so luscious and delicate that it could have been a beautiful slice of fresh fish for all I knew looking at it. The potato was not quite mashed consistency, but instead textured with a graininess that somehow made it irresistible. Not a drop was left over.

Chicken Empanada: Peruvian empanadas are baked and delicate and these were solid. This wasn't the best dish of the night, but the sauce on the bottom helped add creaminess to the chicken inside the empanada. 

Lomo Saltado: Traditional Peruvian style beef tenderloin, tomatoes, cilantro, garlic, soy and oyster sauce, potatoes, and rice. This is historically my favorite Peruvian dish just for the explosion of flavors. The rice was served separately and the lomo sitting on a bed of the thick-cut fires and tomato/onion deliciousness. The beef was incredibly tender-- always a quick way to tell a good lomo saltado from a cheap one. I liked the dish a lot, but would have enjoyed a bit more sauce on the plate to soak up with the fries and rice. Still, one of the best I've had.

TRES LECHES: Ok guys. Dessert is not usually the highlight of my meals, and I had some pretty outrageous dishes this night that blew me away. With that being said, I am a tres leches connoisseur and this is without a doubt the best tres leches slice I've ever had. It was rich, sweet, and moist all the way through. I don't know how I didn't get a picture of it, but I'm pretty sure I was in a sugar-anticipation trance. I highly recommend this dessert to finish off a fabulous Peruvian dinner.

The location is right on the water, with seating both inside and outside (with heaters) and you can see into the kitchen. It boasts a beautiful and clean aesthetic and the servers change your cutlery with every dish. 

Overall, this is the type of place that will end up on my list of top restaurants I've been to. A true love letter to Peru.
author: Andi P.

description:
Holy moly, some of the reviews for this place are the length of novels. Well, I can't top them so I'll just say that my husband and I were happy with our experience here. It's just ex-pen-sive.

The ceviche 'sampler' was awesome. Complimentary taro chips went really well with it. We ordered the duck paella for our shared entree and it was superb!

We did not order drinks, but our neighbors at the bar did. They were unfortunately not impressed with their prickly pear martini.

The service is professional, but can be slow. We had a difficult time trying to find our server when we were ready for the check.

3.5 stars, rounded up because of the food and vibe.
author: Gracie J.

description:
I can't give it more than 3 starts based on my only experience.
1. Service was average, server only checked back with us twice and didn't even come over when I waved.
2. While the ceviche mixto was very good, the entre   la Mar Plancha was average, not enough spices nor sauce of any kind. Good enough sized to share.
3. Dessert - one was very good, the chocolate with passion fruit. The other one with chocolate mousse, ice cream and crunchy quinoa was a mess, with a taste of everything but not much of anything.
author: Magda C.

description: Stunning restaurant on the waterfront with beautiful unobstructed views of the Bay Bridge. Peruvian cuisine at its finest. The ambiance is elegant with nice tones of blue throughout. Reservations are recommended but if you do have to wait they have a beautiful full service bar with lots of character. They have both indoor and outdoor dining areas, along with two bars and a sushi bar. We of course chose to sit outside, weather wasn't too chilly and they have ample heat lamps. Our server was very profane friendly and was happy to give you any suggestions. Unfortunately they no longer have plantain chips, but they did replace them with fresh taro chips.... which I like better lol We tried to get a second order but they sold out. Now I know to order two. I had the Dungeness crab and avocado entree served over a potato purée. Delicious, there was so much crab. Next we have a steak dish (I unfortunately forgot the name) that they are known for. It was delicious! Seasoned so perfectly, along with roasted vegetables. I would definitely order that again. We also had some beef skewers. Their desserts were delicious. Their tres leches is better than any of the ones I've eaten in Central America. My dessert was more like a parfait with cotton candy on top. From the side you can see all the layers and actually looks like a piece of art too pretty to eat.... but I did, and I would definitely order that again also. Cocktails were fresh tasting and interesting. I would highly recommended.
author: Fiona G.

description:
Yep! 1 hour ago i was in another restaurant and now eating again! 
Every trip my belly gets greedy and i try to eat in as many places as i can!! 
Forget about sightseeing! Its all about pleasing this belly!

I've been coming to La Mar for years and have tried them for lunch and dinner but this is my first time trying them for happy hour and it was pretty good!

Here the reviews:

-Ambience: not as nice s their restaurant area but cute and clean still!

-Service: they were crazy busy but service was good still.

-Food:
-ceviche mixto ($9)
Delicious! 

-Jalea ($18)
Super fresh

-Pisco sour ($7)
the best!! 
am on my 4th one now so i am not sure how this review is coming out! 

Overall i would definitely recommend their happy hour, good price, Ambience, and prices! But more than anything i loved their pisco sour!!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
So I had a few coworkers suggest the ever most popular La Mar Cebicheria Peruana on the pier, so naturally I had to check this spot out. Sadly in the end I left very disappointed, with a large bill to match. 

So I will give the restaurant kudo's for aesthetics, nice open air feel with views of the bay (Sit outback if possible), the kitchen, and plenty of natural air to keep you cool. The staff was quite nice and helpful, but missing at times when needed even when it was not particularly that busy. The menu is pretty straightforward and easy to navigate with some tasty treats on it that could entice even the little ones if you happen to bring them along. They did offer some weekday specials that looked good, but I was ready for my favorite Peruvian dish (Lomo Saltado). The dish itself was not cheap, teetering on the $40 dollar range, but you should know this due to its location and being in SF anyways. The free plantains with a green chimichurri sauce was absolutely to die for, wish I could of just eaten that the whole time to tell you the truth. Once the main dish arrived, I was a tad confused as most of the veggies look barely cooked and more so on the underside of being cooked. Not much meat to go along with it as well, so you are basically paying for a limited amount of meat and more so of the grilled/cooked veggies. The whole plate was very bland, I am no expert of course, but have had my fair share of saltado's in my lifetime. I just really expected more for what I had paid for, but honestly I cheated myself as this restaurant as it prides itself in seafood hence "La Mar". I think next time if I revisit, I will give the seafood a shot to see if it was an indeed a better choice. 

For the time being though, I am leaving it at a two star sadly.
author: Ryan A.

description:
I didn't know how much I could love Peruvian food. My coworker picked La Mar as her "homecoming" dinner after returning from Atlanta. This is such a fantastic spot for a group hangout or fun date. Bright colors and a beautiful view of the water. Definitely make a reservation because it'll get super crowded.

While waiting for the rest of our friends to arrive, I started with a prickly pear margarita because that sounded unique. Turned out to be quite sweet but still tasty. Later I split a pitcher of regular margarita and finished with an El Cholito cocktail. Dangerously strong. Wonderfully spicy.

For food, we ordered family-style, of course. I love that there are tons of options for "tastings" on the menu, which is just a little of everything. We did that for the tiradito, ceviche, causa, and anticucho. So much food. So fresh, like all the fish was caught right from the ocean. 

We also had the scallop and beef dish which were delicious, too. La Mar is on the pricier side, but it's a worthwhile splurge for a special occasion. If you can make it over to this side of the Embaradero, give this a try, especially for happy hour! It's one of my most recommended spots for others now.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
My husband and I love this place. It was our second time here and I ordered the Conchitas Picantes dish. It's made with diver scallops, ajies and coconut milk sauce, served on black lentil tacu-tacu, and sautéed garlic leaf. It was yummy! 

For my drink, I ordered the Whiskey Smash. It's made with Templeton Ryo, grapefruit juice, lemon, orange, cinnamon, clove, Lico 43, and Blood Orange IPA. The drink was delicious and I'd definitely order it again.

The atmosphere to this place was really nice. I liked seeing the different number of vases with pretty yellow orchids. The servers were professional and gave us good service. 

The prices here are a bit high, but it's due to the location it's in. So far, I've really enjoyed my experience at La Mar, and I recommend this place!
author: Suki K.

description:
This is the second La Mar location I've been to. I went to the one in Peru a couple of years ago and also enjoyed my experience. I got the Experincia La Mar (tasting menu). I definitely had my favorites and one or two things I didn't love. The first course everything was amazing.
1st course: Classico Cebiche-great, causa limeña - great, ahi tuna nigiri - GREAT, tiradito la mar - good.
2nd course: octopus anticucho - great, jumbo shrimp anticucho - good, beef heart anticucho - my favorite thing tonight.
3rd course: arroz con pato- GREAT, lomo saltado- not so good. This was the dish I was looking forward the most and it was so salty. Couldn't eat much of it. And it didn't come with rice. Halibut sudado with black rice - meh. Also very salty
4th course - raspberry passion cruise mouse- was good 
If I were to come here next time I would probably eat the none entree menu items. Most places seem to do those better. With that being said the food overall was very good.
Ambience was absolutely beautiful. They have gorgeous floral decor and plants all over. Good music at a reasonable level. I met the chef and he was SO nice. All the staff was very helpful and pleasant. 
It's a bit pricy in my opinion since most of it is considered "street food" but the experience was great.
author: Sam P.

description:
Located inside the Ferry building in Embarcadero. It is an Impressive and amazing place Peruvian restaurant. Huge, nice ambiance, great view and nice staff. We ordered El Adobo Atamalado (Pork bone-in hindsh ank), Lomo Saltado(Beef w potato), Los Croquettas ( Crispy beef oxtail croquettes) w coconut rice. All tasted fantastic!
It is pricey so I think we will only come back for special occasion. Lol! But it's all worth it though. 
After dining, you can stroll around the area w great ocean view over-looking the bay bridge so that is already a BONUS!!
Service - 5  
Food - 4 
Price - 4  its a bit expensive. So be prepared to spend at least $50-60/pp
Parking - 3   parking is either difficult or expensive. So Caltrain/Bart/muni/uber/lyft is advisable
Bathroom - 3  For such a huge place, this is the only turn-off. They need to have more stalls and clean more often
author: Theresa M.

description:
Service and ambiance were a definite 5/5. Food was good but the pricing was rather high for the amount that was served. Overall, a decent place to grab a nicer sit-down lunch. 

La Mar faces out towards the water so if you get window seating you'll get a gorgeous view. I came around 12pm on a weekday to meet with a friend. Granted we had reservations but even without, I think we wouldn't have had to wait too long as restaurant wasn't overcrowded.

We ordered the choclo empanadas ($14), crab sanguche ($19.5), and the anticucho tasting *add pulpo ($49). Between the two of us, this was definitely more than enough food but even so, the portions seemed rather small for the price point. If you value freshness of the catch though, La Mar won't disappoint! All the seafood we tried was delicious. 

Ultimately, I'd come back for a special occasion but probably not for a quick lunch. I felt a bit rushed this time, but La Mar is definitely a restaurant where you want to take your time and enjoy all the flavors that are presented to your table.
author: Christine W.

description:
What a charming place! Btw, we traveled to Peru 4 years ago and we did not have any food as delicious as it was here.

My husband and I went on a tour of Alcatraz, and we were done by 4pm. Our dinner reservations at La Mar were at 5:30, so we went to their bar and because we were hungry we also ordered some happy hour items. We ordered the classic ceviche, and a dish that had fried calamari, fish, and plantain chips. We so regret ordering this much because we wanted EVERYTHING on the dinner menu. Oh we also had the pisco sour and the mule. They tasted great! Be careful though, the pisco sour is super strong.

For dinner, we had a table outside by the water at the perfect time - just as the color in the skies change while the sun sets. They provide plantain chips and a spicy dip that's yummy. I had the Arroz La Mar, which is like Peruvian paella, and my husband, who was still full from happy hour, only got the cause tasting. Everything was SO DELICIOUS....We CAN'T wait to come back hungry AF and order so much more. Love the ambiance here, food is flavorful, interesting, and colorful, and the service was impeccable. Love!
author: Diana F.

description:
First time dining here and we loved it. Being that we used to live on the east coast, there's a lot to compare with. 

We started w a dozen of the oysters. It had a delightful sauce and minced red onion topped. Tip: add a dollop of the green sauce to the oyster. 

Since we couldn't decide on which entrees we wanted, we went with the "Experience" menu. Basically, your tasting menu. A lil bit of everything! Loll! The Cebiche tasters were great!! The fish were so fresh!

The hot appetizer bites/portion of the menu were also good. We went with the beef heart & decided not to swap it out with the tenderloin. I mean, if you want to try new things, don't play it safe right?!  the grilled octopus was on point. The grilled shrimp was good. 

The entree portions were ok. The halibut with the black rice was the best!! So good!! The halibut was perfectly cooked and juicy inside. We were not as impressed with the Lomo Saltado (beef sautéed w onions, tomatoes, and French fries). I was actually looking forward to this as this was always my fave of all Peruvian dishes. This came a bit too salty. 

The passion fruit- chocolate mouse dessert was delightful and not heavy at all. 

Will definitely come back to try other items on menu.
author: Helen W.

description:
First time here ever, but it came highly recommended by locals and many of our Uber/Lyft drivers during our previous trips. Full disclosure, my wife and I absolutely love Peruvian food and are always looking to enjoy new restaurants that provide Peruvian cuisine.

When we arrived, we had hoped to be seated outside, but that is reserved for for guests who had made reservations previously. We were promptly seated and the restaurant wasn't quite busy for a Sunday night. I did get a chance to go on the outside area and although it was pretty chilly, they have heaters to keep guests warm.

When we were seated and provided the menu. We were eager to try the ceviche, so went with the classic and although the portion appears small, it was shared and went good with the provided chips. The chips with the green sauce was amazing! For drinks, we had the Inka cola, which is a Peruvian soda that is extremely tasteful.

I am a pretty huge Lomo Saltado fan, so I had to try it and boy was in it disappointed. The steak was delicious and the mixture of the sauce and vegetables truly made it savory! My wife opted for the shrimp dish pictured, cannot remember the name, but it was extremely bland and not as rich as we would've expected. She ended up notifying the waitress and ordered the Lomo Saltado instead and she was extremely pleased.

Overall, this is the most we have paid for a Peruvian restaurant, but it was worth the visit. The proportions are definitely not as plentiful, but still filling. Unsure if we will be returning, but I do recommend visiting if you have yet, but be prepared to spend more than average.
author: Kareem G.

description:
I have been in this place twice and the service is amazing! 
My first time was for happy hour which was awesome! Our bartender was Miguel and he made us the most delicious cocktails and recommended us very good snacks and desert!!!!!! Loved it! 

Then I went on Saturday night for dinner, we had a reservation and we wanted to be seated outside, this beautiful woman took us to our outside table and she just looked sooo happy that we were there, while she was walking (which she looked like she was floating I don't know why) she was smiling the hole time... then she gave us this table just outside where she explained us about the menu for a second.
Then our server who looked that was very busy stopped and told us: I'll be right back with you! ( super polite) she had glasses and I wish I could remember her name but she was absolutely impeccable with us! She responded all our questions which of course made total sense, she gave us the best recommendations and she checked with us several times, without interrupting our conversation. 

The food is soo amazing that it's impossible for me to describe how great it is. Also desert was incredible. 
I honestly think that he quality of this place overall worth how pricey everything was which for sure you should be prepared to pay when you are planning to dine in San Francisco... ;) 
I can't wait to go back!
author: Daniela T.

description: This is one of my favorite top five places to dine in the world. The samples of ceviche, potato, and empanada dishes are incredible. Dishes are colorfully prepared. Grab a table outside on the dock on a warmer day. Its ambience is world class. Service is excellent.
author: Chris L.

description:
Amazing culinary experience in a gorgeous San Francisco setting! If you haven't tried Peruvian food, you're missing out. LOVED the ceviche sampler and the nigiri plate. Incredibly fresh seafood balanced with acid. Every bite was better than the last. Paired beautifully with a dry Reising that the Sommelier suggested. 

I can't WAIT to return!
author: Leonie S.

description:
Came here for a business dinner and was surrounded by a sea of consultants and investment bankers in vests and button-ups. 

Crowd aside, this is a lovely place for a dinner, especially with the location along the pier. There were a few dates going on amid all the business deals and schmoozing. We ordered the tasting menu for everyone since figuring out how to order and share plates among 8 people would've been a challenge. While the presentation was beautiful, I was only truly impressed by the scallops, octopus, and seafood rice. Some of the fish, despite being fresh, was too salty because of the sauces. As a result, I wasn't getting the full flavor.

The scallops and octopus are musts! The scallops are so buttery and soft, and the octopus is smoky and chewy. I also got a kick out of the giant corn kernels they garnish their plates with.
author: Sophie W.

description:
I had been dying to try this place out, after sadly missing our Valentines reservations. We stopped in a Sunday afternoon, just recently. It was an early dinner. 

   We made a reservation for 5:30pm. We arrived a bit early and sat at the bar, until our table was ready. We were sat right at 5:30, at a wonderful patio table, bayside. 

   I wish I knew our server's name because she was phenomenal. She was an attentive and all around lady. She made our experience very pleasant. 

   The atmosphere is causal business/trendy. It's a very spacious place. It's modern decor with just a hit of Spanish/Latin flavor. As I mentioned, we dined on the patio, which I highly recommend. 

   Our food was very good. My Spanish octopus, Casuela De Pulpo, was perfection in preparation and texture. It was some of the better Spanish octopus I've had. It compares to one of my fave spots in Miami. 

  I also ordered the Nikei, ahi sashimi appetizer, which was fabulous. It was so fresh and that honey sauce!

  The hubs ordered the Plancha Marina, which he enjoyed. 

   I will say their Tres Leches cake is like heaven! It is amaze. It's not too heavy or rich, but it's so moist with the perfect touch of berries and cream. What a perfect dessert. 

   This is a great spot with Japanese inspired Peruvian cuisine and so many fresh fish & seafood selections.
author: Krista B.

description: They had some things that look like empanadas that were absolutely amazing. Seriously some of the most amazing things I've eaten. Didn't get a try much of the other food but it has a very scenic view in the back private patio.
author: Daniel C.

description: Nice ambiance and beautiful interior. Food is good quality. Drinks are okay. Before choosing the tip, check whether the restaurant applied an automatic 5% surcharge to cover SF employer mandates.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Came here for happy hour one night- the Pisco sour is really great, and the prickly pear is a cute purple drink with really nice salt on the rim- almost tastes like some worm salt from Mexico! The beers during happy hour are both lagers and taste really similar. Would come again and try the food!!
author: Kulmeher D.

description:
I was in Lima, Peru few months back and i fell in love with Peruvian cuisine. I was lucky to dine at Chef Gaston Acurio's flagship Astrid & Gaston. Then i learned that he actually has one of his restaurants, La Mar in SF, and the Chef Victoriano Lopez at La Mar SF had actually worked at the Astrid & Gaston before and later came to La Mar NYC and now in SF. I had to come here, just to reminisce my days in Peru. 

The cocktail menu only mentioned classic pisco sour but i was delighted when our server mentioned that they have Passion Fruit Sour too. That was my magic potion. We wanted to get dungenese crab cebiche special but they were out of it so we went with classic cebiche. It was very fresh and very tasty. I got Arroz Noteña for entree, which i think is inspired from spanish paella. It was awesome, especially the grilled shrimps on it. My friend got scallop dish. That was great too. When it came to dessert course, i had to get Peruvian chocolate mousse. First couple of bites into it, i felt it was too sweet but then i realized that the qinoa meringue on the surface was too sweet so i set the top surface aside and dug into the mousse underneath. It was great. Not as great as the ones i had in Peru but still it was great. Check out the pictures.
author: Ashutosh K.

description:
La Mar is one of those places that I always HAVE to go when I visit San Francisco. The restaurant has a nice bar and a lot of people hang out there for the Happy Hour. The restaurant is big with a nice view of the pier. The decoration is contemporary and I love they have Latin music in the background. 
The menu has ceviche, appetizers, anticuchos (small plates with skewers), desserts and delicious cocktails. 
I always start with a "pisco sour" a Typical peruvian drink, they make it delicious! They even offer flavored pisco sours, if you like citric you should try Maracuyá (passion fruit) pisco sour. 
Something I really like is that they bring you plantain and potatoes chips with a special home sauce to start. Yumm!!! I'm a big fan of plantains. 

For appetizers you must have empanadas!! They make delicious empanadas! My favorite are the beef empanadas yummm!! 
I also like to start with some ceviche. You can't go wrong with any ceviche in this place. The fish is so refreshing I just love it! They make it with something they call tiger milk... yummmm 

For main courses, I had the lomo saltado. If you feel on the mood for steak you can't go wrong with this plate! The steak is cooked on the most delicious and flavorful sauce. It comes with tomatoes, onions and fingerling potatoes. The plate also comes with a side of white rice.  This plate is delicious. 

If you want to have something smaller and save room for dessert, you can always have an anticucho. I had the pescado anticucho and OMG!!! Delicious! They grill the catch of the day fish on a skewer. Mmmmm they put a sauce on it and it tastes so good! This plate comes with fried yuca and Peruvian corn... mmmmmm you can't get any better than that! 

It took me 3 years to not over eat so that I could try their "Tres Leches" and it was so good! It was puffy, it had some strawberries and raspberries. Yummm delicious! I personally like it more wet but it was delicious. I had a bit of the apple quinoa dessert yumm!! Delicious. 
Definitely an explore of flavors in this place. The service was great. Our waiter Erasmo, explain us differences in pisco and told us about the homemade sauces for the empanadas. He knew what he was doing and was amicable.
author: Salma A.

description:
My husband and I came here to celebrate a special occasion on a Saturday evening. We were lucky enough to come relatively early and managed to get a last minute reservation. The servers were very accommodating in being able to move us from indoor seating to outdoor seating and that too twice till we found a table we were okay with.
To start off we ordered a portion of the antichuco tasting - the meat was tender and flavourful and we enjoyed it. This was paired with the spiked punch which was absolutely yummy.
For the entree we had our hearts set on day weekly special which was a whole fish fresh catch of the day but we're informed that the smaller portion size had sold out and only the larger one was available, which was a bit too much for 2 people.
We ended up going for the Arroz Negro- the halibut fillet was cooked well and paired well with the black rice in broth, however, I expected something with a little more zing to it. It was a little bland for me.
The service also was extremely slow - my husband ordered a second drink and it came close to when we were almost done with our mains - a good half hour later.
They do serve a portion of taro chips with housemade sauce which was good and keeps you munching away while you wait for the food to come.
The views of the bay bridge are great and it is a nice spot for date night or of you're in the mood to splurge a bit.  However, I expected a little bit more from a restaurant of this caliber.
author: Mehak C.

description:
12 October 2018 (maggiesfoodjournal)
The rare visit to restaurants in San Francisco brings us to La Mar for Happy Hour. When we got there, the place was quite deserted. We found seating quite easily - and ordered our drinks. I had Piña Punch - a tropical drink jam-packed with tropical flavours of pineapple, lemon, orange juice, pineapple juice with several leaves of mint floating around. The drink reminds me of home - Penang Island - bringing that warm beach vibe to chilly San Francisco.

For a light appetizer before dinner, we had Empanadas - beef, chicken and mushrooms. Mushrooms on their own - have very little flavour - but this was well-cooked and tasty - however, the chicken empanada was dry and the beef was nothing to cheer about.

Location: 4 of 5
Service: 4 of 5
Food: 3 of 5
Drinks: 4 of 5
Price: 3 of 5
Overall: 3.5 of 5
author: Maggie T.

description:
Very nice Peruvian restaurant. The appetizers are fabulous so try and save room for the equally fabulous entrees.

I started with a perfect Pisco Sour followed by a selection of empanadas and cebiche fish. The corn and mushroom empanadas were fabulous and all of the cebiche (that is the Peruvian spelling of ceviche) we're done really nice. 

The duck fried rice and slow posted pork shank were done perfectly and are quite a filling dish. My quibble is there were not as many potato based dishes as you get in the birth place of the potato- Peru.

A nice surprise at the end was the Peruvian chocolate mouse desert. Different than most and surprisingly nice that they pair with a Sauvignon Blanc - I know but, it works!
author: Edward F.

description: Horrification! Servers ignored us heavily and they did not provide anything to us. When called they just turned away as if we were invisible. Not sure why they did that but I'm never coming back. -Check please
author: Carlos J.

description: Only tried the bar. Great cocktails and fabulous service. Reasonable prices and very busy. Really want to go back for food....not enough time! Maybe next time
author: Madison S.

description:
Let me start off by saying that the food itself deserves 4 stars. I was very nice by not docking more stars after my experience here. I gave it 24 hours since I ate here just so I could cool off.

1. I came here with a girl friend so that we could enjoy restaurant week and feel fancy on a budget. One of the guys who fills your water kept speaking to my friend in Spanish and made us so uncomfortable with how much he was trying to flirt with her. There's a time and place for everything buddy and hitting on a girl while you're working is not one of them. He continued to interrupt our conversation throughout our entire meal at his failed attempt at being Rico Suave. Not that it is relevant, but my friend is Indian and didn't understand a single word he said.

2. The restroom was so disgusting that I could not get out of there fast enough. There was a brown ring around the toilet and the floor looked like it hasn't been mopped since opening day. The toilet seat covers were in the floor! I'm just grateful that I ate first then used the restroom afterwards. 

Now let's get to the food...

The Cebiche Clasico was my favorite amongst the 3 dishes I tried. It is very citrusy but it didn't bother me. The different textures definitely complimented each other. My second was the Arroz Norteno. The rice is very heavy but the flavor was on point. The Salmon was only okay. For the price you pay, I would expect either quantity or quality and I didn't get either. The lentils were poorly seasoned and the salmon itself was not only tiny, but it was also on the drier side.

Overall, I'm glad that I tried this place but I probably won't be coming back
author: Denise I.

description:
We were in  a large group. Everyone had been there before. For me it was first time. We ordered a lot of food to share.
The food was great. The drinks were good. Definitely a place to visit again for celebrations.
author: Amit K.

description:
My boyfriend and I love coming to this place. The ambiance is perfect for a date or family gathering. The food is excellent and servers are extremely friendly and professional. 

The chicken empanadas are so good each time I get them I wonder why I didn't double the order. Do not plan on getting two chicken empanadas and sharing them with 4 people. You will regret it! 

Outdoor seating is gorgeous with ample heat lamps. Easy to book online. Highly recommend.
author: Stacey V.

description:
This of most favorite places to eat now, especially seafood. I love their food presentation, which makes their dishes so inviting.

Started off with Dungeness crab appetizer. Comes with purple mashed potato. It has a mild citrusy taste. We ordered another without the potato (trying to avoid too much carbs).

We had the Cerviche sampler (3). I think this is my first to eat cerviche so I'm not sure what to say, but I still liked them especially the one with shrimp and squid mixed in (orangey color sauce). 

Love, love the Marina Plancha! Grilled seafood on hot sizzling plate. So delicious! Love the combination with cauliflower and mushroom. My favorite were the squid in it. So tender and tasty. I had side order of their rice, which tastes good, too. I would have ate all but had to watch my carb to save room for dessert.

I can't wait to come back and order it again and try other dishes, especially octopus or squid. 

I'm glad I saved space for dessert. The chocolate mousse was awesome!!! Just the right amount of chocolate taste and I love the round stuff that adds a crunch to the soft texture.

I can't wait to visit this place again!
author: Ariene S.

description:
This is the place where you bring your family and good friends to have an amazing Peruvian dinner. Our party started with cocktails because we were in that "treat yourself" kind of mood. I recommend the prickly pear margarita (how cute is that name?), pisco punch, or spiked punch. Every table gets an order of plaintain chips. Beware, you won't be able to stop munching after the first chip.

We also started with the cebiche tasting, which gives you a taste of their famous cebiches. It's a good starter though small. We moved on to the empanada tasting with 4 different empanadas, which was delicious and also a great way to start the meal. 

For main dishes, we ordered the arroz la mar, lomo saltado, and pescado. All the dishes were exquisite and delicious. If I were to pick, I highly recommend the arroz la mar and lomo saltado. For me, the lomo saltado with the potato wedges was good though too salty. If the chef eased up on the salt, I think it would be the perfect dish. Overall, I had quite a wonderful dinner experience here. The dishes are the size of your usual tapas, so be open to trying everything!
author: Joanne K.

description:
Mario. 

This amazing server is the best server I have ever had in my 27 years on this earth. The food was superb.. but the service we received was beyond expectation. If any managers or owners read this.. he deserves brownie points!
author: Mariam J.

description:
Incredible Peruvian food located next to the ferry building in San Francisco.  The restaurant is modern and sleek with beautiful views of the bay.  I came here on a Thursday night and the place was poppin.  We were seated right away at a table near the front entrance.  Unfortunately, due to how crowded it was our server appeared to be stretched thin. 

They have complementary plantain chips with herbed aoli.  I ordered the empanada sampler which was enough for a meal for me.  The types were chicken, mushrooms, corn, and beef. The chicken and corn were my favorites.  My boyfriend ordered the Al Mar seafood dish and it was a decent size, loaded with seafood.  The food here was excellent and the price point matches that of what you'd expect in San Francisco.
author: Stacey C.

description:
Service: Moises was our server and he was awesome. We just told him we want to eat a lot because it's our anniversary so he got us 2 glasses of champagne. He was such a fun, nice and happy server who loves what he do and that's to give us a great experience. So thank you Moises! 

We went to La Mar to celebrate our 8th year anniversary and the experience was on point!

The food was delicious. Yes, it's very expensive and the amount is just right for 2-3 people so small portion of you have a big party. We ordered the 4 samplers, nigiri sampler, cebiche sampler, causa sampler and empanadas sampler, one cocktail and the ginger passion fruit soda. The ginger passion fruit soda was so delicious! I want to have a pitcher! I loved the nigiri sampler, it was delicious. You'll get 2 pieces of Alaskan king crab, wagyu beef and salmon. My favorite empanada was the vegetarian one, chicken was dry, beef was pretty good and the mushroom one was just okay. The vegetarian one tasted like sweet corn. Cebiche sampler was all delicious! Causa sampler was yummmmm. You can take a look at my photos. 

Thank you La Mar for making it such a special experience for my husband and I! We will be coming back!
author: Susan H.

description:
My friend came here for dinner for restaurant week. The interior is huge. They have a bar space, an indoor seating section, and an outdoor enclosed seating area with heating spacers. Basically - you could get lost in here. The space is beautiful and they decorated it beautifully. 

There were hosts right at the front who greeted us, and we got seated immediately. Our server was awesome. He was kind and patient explaining what dishes were popular during restaurant week, and was always quick to check in on us.

For the appetizer, I ordered the nigiri, which is ahi tuna, quail egg, and aji amarillo cream. This was by far my favorite dish! The ahi tuna literally melted in my mouth. And the quail egg was actually a really great combo! All that to say, I would come back just for the appetizer :) For the main dish, I ordered the salmon. It came with grilled seasonal vegetables and aji panca-coconut milk sauce. The sauce..so delicious! And I loved how there were tons of veggies :) The dessert was a tres leches cake, with strawberries, and whipped cream. The cake was delicious! It wasn't overly soggy, and was a good touch with the strawberries. All that to say, everything was so good and would def come back!

For price, it was a bit on the more expensive end for restaurant week ($65). But good food is worth it :) Oh, and it's located near Embarcadero..so lots to do if you want to take a walk around afterwards :)
author: Jackie C.

description:
If you really wanna impress someone.. La Mar. Say no more fam. 

La Mar is located on the Embarcadero, can you say dinner with a view? We were lucky enough to get seated in the enclosed heated outdoor area, right by the water. 

It was one of those days where we enjoyed every single thing we ordered: 

- Cebiche: Glad we got full sizes of the mixto and nikei. I recommend the mixto if you want seafood other than fish, and the nikei if you want something a bit fushion-y. 
- Empanada tasting: I only tried the mushroom and choclo (corn), the corn was amazing. 
- Arroz con calamares: SO FLAVORFUL. Grilled salmon-stuffed squid over squid ink infused rice. One of those dishes where the first bite was just as good as the last. Highly recommend. 
- Tres Leches: Complimentary dessert for our birthday girl. So light, airy, fluffy, heavenly.. like pillows on my tongue. 

Definitely need to watch out when you're here because it will add up reaaaal quick $$$, but the food was oh so good.
author: Laverne N.

description: Have nice inside and ocean side seating. We had  the ceviche sampler and the crab sandwich. Ceviche had a spicy, soy based and then the traditional citrus with cilantro..very nice with a glass of wine. Crab creamy and fresh. Great for a lighter lunch option.  Nice for families and lots of couples there too.
author: Danielle K.

description:
The food is good but not authentic Peruvian food. It's like gourmet food with a hint of Peruvian vibe. The atmosphere and decors were nice, perfect for dates ;). 

The food portion was reasonable, and the customer service is good.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Overall the food was mediocre and high priced.  The ceviche sampler of 4 fishes was good but quite expensive at $43. I had the grilled octopus which was nice at $29 but my two employee ordered the Lomo Saltado which is a Peruvian dish of beef tenderloin and the waiter said it's very tender and delicious.  

I was surprised the food came out so quick that it appeared that the meat was pre cooked and probably sitting in a steamer as it was not that hot and not as tender and delicious as waiter described esp at $36 a plate.

The desserts were good but not enough to make up for the overall disappointment with the food.  I only had one drink of El Cholito which wasn't great and looked pre-made. 

The total bill for 3 person lunch came out to $230 before tip.  I really felt ripped off but it was a birthday luncheon for my Peruvian manager and she wasn't wowed by the food.

Definitely won't be coming here again for lunch truck quality food!
author: James H.

description:
This is a great spot for delicious Peruvian and nice cocktails! It's on a cute location on the Embarcadero with plenty of seating. I believe they have a daily Happy Hour that ends around 6 or 7pm. 

You don't actually need to make a reservation in advance. There is a "public space" in the front that is rarely full and I've been able to walk in on about three separate occasions and get seated there immediately. I think they try to reserve those spots last since it's not technically connected to the main restaurant and there are passerby walking by as it's part or a public walkway/path. 

They have a great assortment of ceviches, lomo saltado, one delicious rice/sausage dish (can't remember what it's called) and great cocktails like pisco sours and the like. 

Definitely recommend stopping by if you're in the area!
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Service: 5 stars
Food: 4 stars

We had the:
-complimentary taro chips/dip (yum!)
-Basil cocktail (refreshing)
-Chicha Morada mocktail (delicious, had hints of nutmeg)
-Pobre appetizer (fantastic, a must-get)
-Mixto (meh)

Our waiter, who had been there for 3 years, was fantastic with his service and recommendations. Nice ambiance if you can get a table outside or in the back.
author: Cece Y.

description:
Best restaurant in SF!

Went in without reservations a 4th of July. Very pleased to find a crowd less restaurant since verything else was completely packed.

Elegant enough but very inviting, it is located on the pier. The outdoor patio overlooks the bay and it's beautiful. 

Menu- very diverse, a lot of Peruvian slang that is very well explained by the waiters. If you can get the tasting ceviche platter as well as the tiraditos. 
              -A few options for vegans and vegetarians, not just salads (but the salads are KILLERS, don't skip)
            -The absolute star of the lunch was the Nikkei ceviche, a Japanese inspired tuna ceviche with just the right amount of sweetness. Some dishes come with a Peruvian corn called chocloy, it is amazing too. 
               -Prices are little on the heavier side by we did order a bottle of wine


Overall, very pleased to find a well-thought out restaurant with no touristy vibe, if you're in SF and like Peruvian food, it's a not-to-miss.
author: Maria D.

description:
I picked this place to try for my birthday.  We were not disappointed with the taste of the food compared to other reviews. The portions can be small and the prices are higher. 
We ordered a pitcher of cocktail for the 4 and it was good but $52.  I liked the beef empanadas but wished they were larger than the 2 small ones. 

BFF ordered a nice tasting appetizer. Hubby's paella was very tasty and good amount of food. They were very nice and gave me a tres leches dessert for my BD. It was delicious.  

Staff was nice. The only complaint by Hubby was that they brought the bill while we were still eating dessert. He thought that was rude to bring the check before you asked for it and in the middle of dessert.
author: Ry T.

description:
I'm going to keep this simple: This place is WAY too expensive for the quality of food, interior ambiance, and lackluster service. 

First off, this is only sort of Peruvian food, very much fusion. I had the Empanada ($15), Arroz Nortena ($45), a beer ($8), a dessert ($14), and passion fruit juice ($8) -- I'm all for paying for quality but at that price I basically expect perfection. Here are the issues:

- The Arroz Nortena is just paella but very mushy with overcooked veggies. If you want something like this, go one block down to Coqueta

- The service was terrible. Literally the guy said he would come back and explain the menu then he comes back and urgently asks what we want to order. Meanwhile I have no clue what the 6 sections on the menu even mean. That would have been tolerable but then after dinner they literally forgot we existed. We had to call him over 3 times post-dinner and this was on a Tuesday (many empty tables and free wait staff)

- For a place that has a menu full of passion fruit stuff these were not real passion fruits in use. I'm from Tanzania and know what it tastes like. If this wasn't some kind of concentrate then they're sourcing some horrible passion fruits and should just stop

- The best part was the dessert but at $14-17 they're all just as overpriced as the rest of the menu

If you want Peruvian food I would say skip this place that was full of jersey shore lookalikes and head to the much more reasonable and tasty Limon Rotisserie or Mochica. If you just want to be on Embarcadero then go to Coqueta. There are too many good restaurants in this city for this place to be as highly rated as it is
author: Neechi M.

description:
3.5 stars in my book, but I'll gladly round up (because it's the holiday season!) and because the appetizers and dessert were really bomb.

My first experience at a Peruvian restaurant, and I can confidently say it won't be my last (I hope).

My team and I came here on a weekday (in December) and first of all, loved the decorations! Really, all of the holiday lights in all of downtown is superb but we definitely appreciated the decorations walking in. I also loved the lighting at the bar area next to the kitchen when you walk in as well. And lastly, we sat outside (plenty of heat lamps...we were actually too hot, even) and you can't beat the view of the water. Great ambiance. 

Appetizers we ordered: cebiche tasting, all three of the causas (limena, nikei, vegetariana) and empanada tasting. I think most of the reviews rave about the cebiche, and I second that. Ahi tuna was by far the best, although $34 is super pricey for such small portions. The causas were super interesting: essentially it's that topping (crab, tuna, or veggies) on top of potatoes (almost like a mashed potato consistency). I absolutely loved all of the colors of the plate though. I think it's a dish to try, but I wouldn't care to order it again. And lastly, the empanadas. Think of a Peruvian hot pocket! Really can't go wrong here, unless you don't like hot pockets. But the beef was my favorite. So flavorful...mmmm.

Four of us ordered the arroz norteno, a fried rice dish with huuuge portion. Unfortunately, none of us loved it. I didn't care for the flavor of the rice (and I think there was just so...much...rice...), although there's quite a lot going on in this dish with how many ingredients they add. We appreciated them not skimping out on the amount of shrimp in this dish.

And one of my favorite parts of the meal, the dessert. I would definitely recommend the choco-maracuya if you like some chocolate and something fruity in the middle. The mousse texture......oh my. I'm drooling on my keyboard. 

I would come back just to get full off of their appetizers and dessert. Entree-wise though....I'd have to try something different.
author: Cathy C.

description: Great food and location!  You can take the ferry or water taxi to pier 1 1/2 dock and stroll right into this waterfront restaurant
author: Jack N.

description:
This is a review of the happy hour, so the full dining experience may be significantly different. With that caveat aside:

Having eaten at several Gaston Acurio restaurants, I have to say that this one left me wanting. It definitely didn't live up to the standards I have come to expect from Peru's top celebrity chef. 

The pisco sours were good, and a decent price. If that's what you're after, then this is a reasonable option. 

The ceviche on the other hand, was mediocre. Good ceviche should be made upon ordering. If not, it sits in the lime juice for too long and the texture is all wrong. The ceviche we had bore all the hallmarks of ceviche that was made in advance. 

The bar area itself was also poorly presented. The counter behind the bar was cluttered with items that were obviously out of place. Boxes, Styrofoam containers, etc. I expect a Gaston Acurio restaurant to be a tight ship. This one wasn't. Or it least didn't give that outward impression.
author: Sam P.

description:
I wish I could give it 10 stars. I've eaten Peruvian Food in Lima, New York, Chicago, Barcelona, Madrid and even Chattanooga and this is the best I've ever had. 

I won't waste my time recommending anything because it was all wonderful.....but get the Causa ! The service was spot on and the view and restaurant are beautiful.
author: Tim H.

description:
Super great food and stunning ambiance right by the water front. 

We came here on a Saturday night for a birthday and made reservations in advance. We were seated immediately and the staff attended to our needs at al times (refilling water constantly, checking in on us, offering to replenish the appetizer supply). 

We ordered three main dishes: 
1. Lomo Solato - would highly recommend this dish. The steak is what makes it so much more expensive (but better) than your normal Peruvian Lomo Solato dishes. The steak will melt in your mouth and is seasoned with the right amount of savory sauce. 
2.Arroz de Mar: seafood rice paella. Absolutely enjoyed this as well (though didn't have be same "wow!" Effect as the steak melting in your mouth)
3. Pulpa: octopus arms garnished with seasonings. This was probably my favorite dish despite not getting that much and the price it's still worth it for it's novel taste.
author: Christina G.

description:
Recommended:

This place offers a nice range of classical Peruvian dishes with a small twist, rich flavor, nice presentation with a very nice ambiance..
author: Head Chef F.

description: Really great experience and view. You will pay for the quality and ambiance, so be ready to spend about $50-60 per person with a drink. I would have given another star if there was added value.  Overall, try it at least once on a special occasion.
author: Ben C.

description: The best Peruvian food ever and better than the one that had a Michelin star off Highway 1.  We had fresh ahi, tombo tuna, halibut, salmon and other seafood served raw with fancy sauces.  My cooked seafood stew was excellent with fried calamari and fish.  Place has excellent ambience and is very upbeat.  View is out on the bay and next door to the Ferry Building.  Can't wait to come back.
author: Steve T.

description:
I was so excited about this restaurant. I had organized a work lunch, the weather was perfect, we got there right on time (1pm-- after peak lunch hours), walked in and the place was stunning. But as soon as our overly pretentious server came to our table I knew it was bad news. He couldn't even wait long enough to answer our questions as we were sifting through the options, had to leave (no apologies) to check on other tables while WE waited for him to come back. Please. Sorry your time is more precious than ours. 

The food was fine, small portions for a premium $$$ (yelp doesn't lie) which I could have gotten over if everything else was fine-- but the attitude with a side of service completely ruined my experience. I understand everyone has a story and generally try to give people the benefit of the doubt but everyone also has a job-- shouldn't you at least try to be good at it? 

There are plenty of other pretentious restaurants in the city to try with better food. 

Will never return.
author: Katherine B.

description:
At the bar, cocktails are not as I liked and I thought that they did with no kindness and glass after glass, shaker are not washing clean.
Coca Cola with lemon is just good but not difficult ! 
The margarita they had a special, pickly pear is awful! I can't drink, I let it but if I was more angry I fill the table of the bar.
author: Marie-Claire L.

description:
Here for a casual Friday dinner date.

Nice ambiance, a little loud and excellent service (our server took time to explain the menu and helped us with our decision).

Our favorite is prob the ceviche tasting (4 stars), which had a variety of fish and flavor, particularly good with the complimentary plantains. Conchitas Picantes(4 stars), grilled scallops, was excellent as well - 6 seared juicy scallops with strong coconut scent from the sauce. Our biggest disappointment was the Lomo Saltado beef tenderloin (3 stars) - the taste wasn't bad but nothing special, perhaps even too heavy of sauces. The portion was incredibly small with stingy pieces of beef. Overall, tasty dishes but remarkably overpriced and egregious value, even for sf fidi standard.

TLDR: nice ambiance and service, good food but incredibly overpriced.
author: Nancy Z.

description: This is an interesting place for sure.  The service here is random.  I was there today for an event.  The bartenders could not be more rude.  I have  never seen anything like the service (or lack of service thereof) from the bartenders from the event and also at the front bar area.  The service in the restaurant area, however, when I dined there a couple of times was very good.  I would come back to the restaurant part but I am not ever going back to their front bar area.  I saw one male bartender bending backwards over for some guy as others were waiting just to be served.  There are plenty of other restaurants around here that offer far superior service than this place.
author: Linda K.

description:
When you're feeling a treat yourself type of meal this restaurant on the water is the perfect place. La Mar is a Peruvian restaurant with both small plates for sharing and entrees if you're feeling hungry.

The layout of the place offers the option to dine in their main room which is HUGE or the outside area that is covered and has heaters. Service here is attentive from the moment you walk in to check in to when they give you the check. They have their normal lunch and dinner options but be sure to as your server about the specials of the day.

For lunch we opted for: 

+ California Cebiche ($19) - This was probably my favorite part of the meal. I'm a huge salmon and avocado fan so each bite was delicious! It's a great starter to share since it's light and refreshing.

+Limena ($16) - This was also just as delicious! This is on the smaller side of portions so a couple of egg bites to share. The bites were coated with the right amount of sauce to ensure everything was mixed together without being too creamy. The salmon caviar was a nice touch and added a kick to each bite!

+ Jalea ($24) - Although the Jalea is an entree it's definitely another dish that you should share. The dish comes with a mix of fried salmon, calamari, shrimp paired with plantain chips and avocado bites. If you're taking it on by yourself I would recommend ordering something to offset the oily-ness of this one because it is all fried. 

Overall, La Mar is a great place to try that's central to a lot of the tourist spots near the Embarcadero. If you've never had Peruvian food this isn't a bad place to start. I do think it is on a pricier side of things so I would come here more for special occasions vs. a normal week lunch or dinner.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
The ceviche here is amazing.  The different options that are available is anyone else.  The only downside sides is that it great crazy busy for dinner and even at lunch.  The cost for two people for lunch was $72 pre-tip and we did not drink alcohol.  

What did I learn today?  They have some amazing events, just get ready to open your wallet.
author: Ryan C.

description: Today was a perfect as to why i stopped coming here , The worst Bartenders an lead bartender is the mos5 disrespectful , obviously this establishment chooses to employee disrespectful emlloyees so i wont be back , an will encourage others to do the same , Coupdnt even order , they begun speaking in spanish to each other only thing is i understand  Horrible experience
author: Robert G.

description:
Our experience here was phenomenal. We were able to secure a table for 5 on Saturday. Located off Embarcadero, the restaurant has a great atmosphere inside and out. We were fortunate to get seated in the patio where we had a great view of the bay.  It was all of our first times so the staff were extremely patient with us, they save us great recommendations on wine and food items, and the service was just outstanding.  They came around regularly to check in with us, poured more wine and water if our glasses were near empty, promptly clean out the plates, and best of all, refilled our chip bowl.

This is a perfect place for any occasion. Date, family dinner, business dinner, our casual outing with friends. It was a little difficult to understand the menu, but don't get too intimidated, good ole Yelp! saved the day. Thanks to others who posted useful pictures, I was able to find what I want.  We let our guest of honor (sister the bachelorette) pick out a very good Spanish Chard recommended by our host. 

We started with the Cebiche 4 estaciones:
     -Halibut in artichoke leche de tigre
    -Tombo tuna in aji Amarillo leche de tigre
    -Salmon in avocado lech de tigre
    -Ahi tuna in rocoto leche de tigre
So the fish in these dishes were super fresh and tasted amazing. The different sauces just really woke up my tastebuds. Highly recommend if you are looking for flavorful, yet not too heavy or filling starter. 

Second appetizer was the Fritter Tasting.
    -This came with a selection of empanadas and yuquitas. I have no idea what a yuquitas is but it was so good creamy. This is a perfect dish to sample a little bit of each. 

Main dishes:
lomo saltado, traditional Peruvian style beef tenderloin with potatoes and rice.  Small portion of rice and meat. Was a bit disappointed with the portion, however the taste made up for it. It was good but I didn't get that "wow" factor. 

Arroz la mar, basically your seafood paella with shrimp, clams, mussels, calamari and catch of the day. So this one blew all paellas out of the water. This was simply one of the best tasting dish I've had in a long time. There was that perfect blend of spices and the arroz was cooked to a perfect texture.

Since we were celebrating my sister's bachelorette, I secretly asked our server if he was able to make a special dessert or write a message for her.  He sure delivered! He presented a very good dessert dish with a candle and the plate said "happy bachelorette". Thank you to all of the staff at La Mar for providing delicious food and the great dining experience.
author: Erica C.

description:
La Mar on the water is a nice place for a lot of small plates and sharing. The food was spot on, fresh and creative.

We had assorted ceviche samplers and empanada samplers including beef, chicken and my favorite, the mushroom empanada.

The ceviches were great including a squid dishes that was very unique. I would definitely come back on a regular night as we were there Sunday evening.  I am not sure if the superbowl was an issue but our wait staff did not seem to be that experienced and the bus staff were more helpful than our server who we saw maybe twice the entire evening after our order.

WARNING: Corkage fee insanity exists here.  
Don't get me wrong, as a wine collector I take unique wines not on any menus and have not problem paying 15-20 bucks for corkage. However we had two bottles and we were told 25 bucks for the first bottle and 50 BUCKS FOR THE SECOND!! So 75 bucks for two bottles. Are you guys out of your minds?!  Thus I only opened ine bottle as I am against highway robbery for corkage fees!

STRANGER THINGS: 3/4 through our meal, a server came and took our plates saying he wanted to bring us new ones. You do that AFTER a course, not after. 3 dishes in and 3/4 through dish 3.  Then we waited probably 15 minutes until the plates arrived... but then we had to wait another few minutes for the utensils. Argh!!

So here is my breakdown:

Service 3 stars
Food 5 stars
75.00 corkage for two bottles of wine 1 star

4 stars
author: Jay G.

description:
Great ambience! We're able to walk-in on a Friday night and get seated (and served) right away! Great service from all staff, from host to server to bussers. Loved the margaritas, especially the patron margarita!

Really recommend the Arroz La Mar, it's a Peruvian paella and it's so delicious! Also, ceviche Classico was so good. Catch of the day was super fresh halibut. Sweet potato was the perfect addition in the ceviche, who would have thought! 

Super pricy, but great last minute date spot!
author: Kimia M.

description:
Amazing food and amazing views! La Mar sits right out on San Francisco Bay at the Embarcadero, and on a nice day, the atmosphere is simply perfect, and the dishes are delicious and creative. I came for a business lunch and though the food was pricey, I was impressed by the quality and execution of everything we tasted.

After we ordered, the servers brought to the table a small canister of warm plantain and potato chips with the most delicious spicy dipping sauce! For our appetizers, we shared the clasico cebiche with the catch of the day (halibut), marinated in leche de tigre and paired with red onions, Peruvian corn, and sweet potato. This ceviche wasn't particularly strong in flavor but was refreshing and nicely tart. The nikei tiradito (Japanese sashimi Peruvian style) was made of thin slices of ahi tuna, along with an Asian-inspired passion fruit and honey marinade, sesame seeds, and bean sprouts--this was definitely one of the most delicious things we got!
