Food: From the juicy and citric cebiche to the flaky and warm empanadas, you'll find a range of appetizers to start your dining experience at La Mar. Our more recent outing involved trying the fritter sampler which included a selection of fried apps: empanadas, croquettes and yuquitas. They ranged in flavor, oily-ness and texture, but all were grounded in authenticity and deliciousness! I tend to be traditional when it comes to my main entree and order Arroz la Mar as my entree 99.9% of the time. I love how the bed of rice is always crunchy and evenly, yet lightly fried and how the selection of veggies seems to change each time. It's topped with the freshest seafood medley and I like to believe they stand out on the nearby pier and fish it out and then place it straight onto my plate. If you like seafood, I recommend this dish! My friend is similar in routine and goes for the Lomo Saltado and each time he reacts as if he'd never tried it before. The dish stand out compared to others we've had due to the perfect balance of flavors, adding an even amount of soy and oyster sauce and countering that saltiness with garlic and tomatoes which both cut through the sodium. They tend to cook the meat slightly different so that all of the juices from the meat are preserved, allowing the juices to soak into the potatoes and rice! Cocktails are fairly average, yet fresh and pair well wish dishes!

Service: Always personable, hospitable and friendly staff.

Price: Be ready to pay a pretty penny or two! I love that they maintain their prices, because I truly believe Latin food is stereotyped as needing to be cheap, but La Mar's high quality, authentic and consistently delicious dishes truly deserve their price point. 

Ambiance: Spacious, sophisticated, yet comforting atmosphere. I recommend asking them to seat you on the patio so that you can enjoy the waterfront!

Overall: If my wallet allowed, I'd be here every weekend. Authentic, clean, fresh and flavorful dishes, personable staff and a lively environment. I'd recommend this place to locals and visitors!
author: Astrid Z.

description:
This place is famous for its authentic ceviches. 
But the deserts are above all expectations!
author: Alexey M.

description: The chicken empanadas were so delicious. We ordered a second round for the table.  The  Lomo Saltado we're delicious!!  Don't forget the Pisco Soir.
author: Sherry M.

description:
My wife and I just had our wedding lunch at La Mar.  The service, food, and ambiance were beyond our expectations.

A heartfelt thank you to Andrea (our server, and all the kind/patient staff serving us today) and Jonathan and Andrea who helped organize a smooth and memorable lunch party!

I would highly recommend a big event at La Mar, particularly on the patio.
author: Paul C.

description: Had dinner here with a colleague on a Tuesday evening. The service was fantastic and the food was even better. We shared the ceviche sampler, and then we both ordered the salmon. I was not disappointed at all. Further, we each enjoyed a nice glass of white wine. I regret that I do not remember what type of wine it was, but it was wonderful. Truly an enjoyable evening. Great ambience.
author: Ann J.

description: I have a new favorite restaurant on Embarcadero ! I've never had Peruvian food but I definitely willnow. Reminds me of a tropical take on Mexican/Tapas/South American yums like empanadas. They have fun fantastic cocktails too, some really cute margaritas like my favorite with prickly pear!! Overall so impressed. Great location and outdoor seating on the bay adds to the fantastic experience.
author: Kate P.

description:
La Mar is a staple on the beautiful Embarcadero Waterfront serving delicious Peruvian food.  The plates are all beautifully plated and you can enjoy the amazing waterfront views as well.

Some of the items I was able to devour:
Japanese Sashimi Peruvian Style: Fresh Sashimi with amazing flavors!
Cebiche Tasting: light, fresh and tasty 
Squid Ink Pasta: yummy!
Lomo Saltado: One of my favorite
Pulpo- Octopus: tender and delightful

I've been here a couple of times and the food and service has been on point every time.  I love how they give you the plantain chips and dips to start off your meal.

Will be back! =)
author: Melanie N.

description: Went there for happy hour and tried cebiche and their empanadas. Everything was delicious. Would be better for dinner, I'm sure, since we had to sit in the bar area and didn't get to enjoy the view but the price and the timing were perfect for us.
author: Mary L.

description: The ceviche here is delicious! The cocktails are on point. The staff is great and the ambiance is nice. Good place to wine and dine first time visitors to the city.
author: Val S.

description:
Waterfront views, a convenient Pier 1.5 location (near the Ferry Building), delicious Peruvian food, and tasty drinks...what more could any tourist want?  

Lar Mar Cebicheria Peruana is definitely a welcome stop along the waterfront that houses the famous Ferry Building and the recently renovated and expanded Exploratorium.  With a modest door store front, La Mar hides a gorgeous interior with plentiful indoor seating as well as comfortable outdoor seating with views of the boats along the docks.  

A friend who is a Peruvian food aficionado directed me to La Mar and I'm glad he did.  He lived in Peru for over a year and was the first to introduce me to Limon as well as Mi Lindo Peru.  La Mar was the perfect spot to enjoy a more upscale ambiance yet still enjoy delicious Peruvian food.  Our order:

Fried Plantains - complimentary at every table and served with a mildly spicy dipping sauce.  A easy hit that goes well with the drinks.

Beef Empanada - $15.  Quite simply, the best empanadas I've ever had.  I've had the El Porteno ones from the Ferry Building and also tried the similar Saltena from Nuri's Donut House in Redwood City.  Neither had as great a filling as these.  The price is a bit higher, but it's well reflected in higher beef quality using sliced cuts of beef instead of cheaper ground beef.  The sauce was fantastic and the crust was perfectly crispy on the ends but flaky and soft in the middle.  We got it with the sauce to the side and I enjoyed it even more.

Cerviche Mixto - $19.  One of the two most popular cerviche mixes here.   Plentiful fish, calamari, and shrimp with a creamy orange sauce that went well with the crunchy onions and peanuts.  The resulting mix is more creamy than more traditional cerviche I've had, but I enjoyed it.  Generous portion.

Anticucho Pulpo - $24.  The grilled octopus was a large octopus leg grilled perfectly.  The meat was tender and succulent and the accompanying mashed potatoes and red peppers complimented the octopus meat nicely.  I was expecting small baby octopus but it was nice being served a large leg that was shareable like a good steak.

Anticucho Corazon - $18.  Another winner.  I saw the beef hearts and knew I had to order.  Like the octopus, these are huge beef hearts sliced in half, grilled, and then served with a delicious red sauce that has a hint of spiciness.  Very beefy, flavorful and chewy like beef heart should be.  

Overall, we had a great meal at La Mar Cebicheria.  I've walked by this area a million times and never knew there was a gem of Peruvian cuisine along this area.  The food was tasty and novel and the presentation was top notch.  Are prices a bit higher than your regular Peruvian spot?  Yes, but add the waterfront views, open air building, and the high quality ingredients and I think the value is there as well.

La Mar Cebicheria Peruana accepts credit cards including Amex.
author: Randy F.

description: The food and drinks here are really good.  They've got a great happy hour and their dining area in the patio is awesome.  Try the empanadas and the ceviche samplers.  Definitely worth checking out.
author: Patrick C.

description:
How much better can it get than enjoying lunch on the water, bright blue skies above and amazing fresh seafood?  Went to La Mar and this place is huge, especially for SF.  The inside seating area was spacious, but the outdoor patio area where I got to enjoy lunch had a great view of the Bay.  As you'd expect on a gorgeous SF day, the outdoor patio was packed, but who's complaining?  The restaurant has a good vibe to it and the decor is very nice.  

We were greeted very warmly and seated within seconds upon arriving and I'm sure it helped that we had reservations.  The service was very good and the staff were very attentive.  Our water glasses never had a chance to get half-full, since the staff were refilling our glasses like ninja's.  Our server delivered their plantain chips with salsa, which were highly addicting to start-off our meal.

As we surveyed the menu, I'd heard about the quality Cebiche, so we opted for the Cebiche Tasting, which is three of their top Cebiche's.  The first was their Clasico, which featured Halibut, red onions, habanero, corn, sweet potatoes in their classic leche de tigre.  Next was the Mixto, which featured Salmon, shrimp and calamari in rocoto leche de tigre.  Last was their Nikei, with Ahi Tuna, red onions, Japanese cucumber, daikon, avocado, nori, in a tamarind leche  de tigre.  All the fish were very fresh and paired with the various veggies and spices, these dishes danced inside my mouth.  

My friend had been here before and knew exactly what he wanted, so he asked our server if they had the Ahi Tuna collar.  Our server went to check to make sure the chef could make the dish, since when my friend first came here, it was a special of the day,  however, it wasn't on the menu the day we came.  To my friend's delight, the chef said he could make the dish, so I was even more excited.  As the Ahi Tuna collar was delivered, my first reaction was how HUGE it was.  I was expecting something a lot smaller.  The collar was seasoned with chimichuri spices and served with a quinoa salad and some greens, but I had my sights set on that collar.  If you've never had a collar before, so much of the juicy meat is located here.  It's literally some of the best tasting meat you'll find on a fish.  No knife needed here, as the meat was amazingly tender, flavorful and oh so delicious.  I found myself eating and not wanting to stop.  However,r we weren't able to finish the entire meal, but the server packed our leftovers in a to-go container, so I could enjoy some tasty leftovers.  I had an awesome meal, great service and awesome weather.
author: Lon H.

description:
We stopped in for Sunday lunch during SF Restaurant week. We sat at the bar. 

We had the Cebiche Clasico and Churasquito and the Quinoa Salad and Salmon. The fish in the ceviche was delicious, and almost more like sushi than any ceviche I've experienced. The mozzarella bocconcini made the Quinoa Salad stand out. The tri-tip was perfect and the salmon came on chili coconut lentils that were delicious.

We drank coffee and a very refreshing, extra frothy Pisco Sour.
author: Brett S.

description:
I would highly recommend La Mar for going to the front bar, and grabbing cocktails and appetizers.  All of that is excellent here.

But I have never had a good experience with the main dinner items, so I would skip for dinner.
author: Amjad S.

description:
My now fiance and I were celebrating our 2 anniversary in SF and he found this amazing restaurant. We are always on the hunt for unique cuisines and this Japanese Peruvian restaurant is right up our alley. The restaurant itself is beautiful...right on the water! It was very busy on a Friday night but we were seated right away. Our server took the time to explain the menu to us since we had no idea what we were ordering. He suggested the ceviche tasting and the trio of sashimi. I didn't think it would be enough food but we were stuffed! The fish was so incredibly fresh and the different sauces that accompanied each fish were so unique. Their famous "leche de tigre" sauce is amazing. I've never had anything like it! Be advised that most of the sauces are pretty spicy. For dessert, we had the hazelnut passion fruit mousse. It was sooo good!!! Not too sweet and with a tang. 

Overall, this place is worth the money just because the fish is so fresh. The service is a bit slow, but it is a good way to relax and enjoy the food. We will be back!
author: Tricia G.

description:
This is one of my fav casual dining seafood spot in SF. It's SF restaurant week. I had the Ceviche, churrasquit, and mousse chocolate for dessert 
Great spot at night with a view of Bay Bridge and casual music.
author: Philip T.

description: This was the lunch of a lifetime. A beautiful view of the San Fran bay, a wonderful waiter, and of course the FOOD! It was truly delicious. Every bite was perfectly balanced and cooked. You could tell a lot of thought went into each dish.
author: Jessica H.

description: This place was amazing! We had the ceviche sampler and did the vegetarian one along with Classico and Nikko. All were great. We then did the empanadas and the corn one was THE BEST empanada I have ever had! Beef was good and chicken was a far third. We also had the pulpo (octopus) which was my least favorite. It was dry and just not as flavorful as everything else. For an entree we got the scallops which were excellent. Finally we did the tres leches for dessert which was also yummy. Great service, beautiful ambiance, and the best space heaters ever on a patio. Will be back for sure!
author: Hela M.

description:
Food was delicious and fresh. 

The service was impeccable, especially Jose, the guy who was going around pouring water and refilling chips, picking up our plates. 

This place is a winner.
author: Nance H.

description:
For a number of years, La Mar had been high on my list of restaurants to try.  I really enjoy Peruvian food, so the largely high praise I had heard about La Mar, as well as their mostly positive reviews on Yelp did nothing but stoke my desire to check them out.  Of course, it didn't hurt that they're also one of my friend's favorites spots to take his dates.  Man, if only getting those dates was as easy as coming here for them...

Considering how we didn't have a reservation, as well as how packed nearby Coqueta was (on a Thursday night!), my friend and I were pretty happy we were able to get seated at the bar/counter as soon as we walked in.  True to their name ("the sea", in Spanish), as well as their location on the Embarcadero, the menu leans heavily towards seafood (numerous cebiches are featured).  However, they still have plenty of non-seafood Peruvian staples as well, like Lomo Saltado, empanadas, anticuchos (skewers), and paella-like dishes.

-- PLANTAIN CHIPS WITH DIPS...Free!
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-mar-cebicher%C3%ADa-peruana-san-francisco-4?select=3-IbOwO4EIT37EvG1deJ5g)
Would it be bad to say this might have been the best thing I had here?  The chips weren't dried out, yet still really crispy, and had a good amount of plantain flavor.  Plus, the dips they were served with were great!  I don't know if we were ever told what they were, but both were delicious.

-- MIXTO CEBICHE - Catch of the Day, Shrimp, Calamari, and Octopus in Rocoto Leche de Tigre...$19
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-mar-cebicher%C3%ADa-peruana-san-francisco-4?select=Wh89IZtoL6upuZiwZE40iQ)
Unfortunately, I can't recall what the catch of the day was, but the dish, as a whole, wasn't bad.  All of the seafood was pretty fresh (including whatever fish that was...) and I liked the punch that the leche de tigre (sauce) packed.  That said, for whatever reason, the sheathes on the choclo (Peruvian corn) felt especially hard.

-- LOMO SALTADO - Traditional Peruvian-style Beef Tenderloin, Tomatoes, Cilantro, Garlic, Soy and Oyster Sauces, Potatoes, and Rice....$34
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-mar-cebicher%C3%ADa-peruana-san-francisco-4?select=kbY7QUERVZskaSzp1Wf4JA)
I couldn't resist trying their take on such a classic, but I should've listened to my wallet - not worth the money!  Although the beef was well cooked, it was overwhelmed by all of the veggies, which were cut fairly large (especially the tomatoes).  What really killed the dish though was how salty it was; whoever made this was definitely a little heavy handed with the soy/salt.

Although their food may not have impressed like how I had hoped, La Mar does get high marks for their ambiance and decor.  In that regard, I can definitely see why my friend comes here so often for his dates.  Not only is the space fairly open and airy, but the back area of the dining room offers wonderful views of the bay.  For that reason, as well as the quality of the seafood, La Mar might still be worth a visit, but it comes at a literal price.  Then again, if you're here with an awesome date, who cares?
author: Mike L.

description:
This place is good to go to when you're on a diet cause the food is fresh, many healthy options, and it's really hard to overeat without paying a lot. 

The ceviches and tiraditos here are excellent. The octopus antichucho is super tender yet flavorful because of the smoky paprika based sauce. Really can't go wrong with most of the food and drinks menu although I haven't tried everything yet. 

I'd come here more often if it weren't so pricey. However, given how busy this place is (30 minute wait on a Monday night), it doesn't seem to be a deterrent for most San Franciscans. 

Service is average - we had to ask for water a couple of times.
author: Judy C.

description: Did not like. Sad face.  Food was not particularly good. Went for view but was seated very far away. Disappointed
author: Gillian H.

description: La Mar Cebicheria Peruana is nothing short of spectacular. You get great food with an amazing view to accompany it. I am pretty familiar with Peruvian cuisine so I can tell the difference between authentic versus Americanized Peruvian food.  It's breath-taking and relaxing with the view of the pier. Their food is a delight! I love the plaintain chips and the beef stew. I did have the grilled octopus but I have to say that it just isn't for me. I guess I am not an adventurous eater! The best for me was the beef empanadas though! They were the bomb! I know that I will be back to this place, who wouldn't?! You get great food, a great location and exceptional service all in one place!
author: Allison E.

description: As a second-generation Peruvian, I've had a lot of Peruvian food in my life. This is easily the best meal I've had both in the states or in Peru, and that includes my mom's. The cebiche classico is demonstrably fresh, and if you must have one thing here, make it this. The empanadas are also to die for, and they made my mom who is an Empanada Snob, absolutely stunned. And the causa has some of the best and most authentic use of potatoes you can find in the US. Although pricey, every dish we had was absolutely worth it. If you've ever thought about trying Peruvian food or are a long-term plan, this meal is a must-visit.
author: Drew H.

description:
The pisco sour was on the strong side for us. We tried the summer splash which was refreshing. Given our drinks were strong, we definitely were not able to enjoy our meal to the fullest. 

We ordered the Cebiche Tasting, which provided an excellent selection and variety. The tuna cebiche was much more subtle compared to the other two. We absolutely enjoyed the orange sauce that went with it. 

We also got the arroz la mar. We thought the bell peppers were an excellent texture, and the seafood all tasted so fresh. The shrimp was definitely a highlight as it was cooked to perfection.
author: Nguyen H.

description: My favorite restaurant out of my favorite list!! Indeed the one that I come back the most. First came here in 2013 when I moved to SF and keep coming back. Sometimes come for happy hour when I am craving for the ships (mainly the sauce!) and their EMPANADAS (SOO GOOOOD). Been to the one in Lima, Peru and so glad that there is one in SF for my craving anytime. Great service as well, both bar and the restaurant.
author: Al L.

description: La Mar located at a prime location by the bay and has a catchy name, those are the only pluses of this restaurant. It's a total tourist trap. Foods are just okay, seafoods here aren't fresh at all. And it's completely over-priced. There are much better Peruvian restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Jessica Z.

description: I found a new fave restaurant in S.F.! The food was excellent, ambiance was perfect, and views were amazing! I was skeptical at first about trying this place out, especially since most of the items on the menu include seafood, (not a big seafood lover) but the dishes we ordered, were so fresh and delicious, it left me wanting more! This place definitely exceeded my expectations.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Came here with my boss based on a recommendation I received 2 years ago when I was in the Bay for vacation. I am glad I followed through on that co-sign because the Peruvian food was amazing. Sat by the bar and chatted with the bartender who gave us great explanation of the various menu items and kept passing us drinks. I would highly recommend this restaurant for anyone walking around the pier.
author: Marvin H.

description:
Location and ambiance trump a lot understandably, but I was underwhelmed with the cuisine as well as service at La Mar. 

I came here for a friend's birthday, and we had such a large party that it was recommended we reserve a "private room" for everyone. Just so we're clear, the "room" was not "private," but rather a sectioned off area that was extremely loud and cramped so that our party of twenty people barely had room to turn around in our seats. Additionally, this prior booking required a fixed menu so that the kitchen could (again understandably) prepare for such a large party. But instead of portions for each guest, single-portion dishes were served with the idea that 3-4 people would be sharing. I don't see how this decision was practical or even conceivably understandable. It's San Francisco -- I get it, but the steep amount for a private room, service fees, and then minuscule portions all added up to a woefully disappointing experience. 

I have to give an honorable mention (the negative kind) to the hostess at the front, who could not have been more dismissive and nonchalant when our group walked in and asked about our reservation. She responded with an "Oh" and general wave of her hand for us to walk towards the back before looking straight through us to the next guest. Our servers were warmer and more helpful, although they did mess up the drink orders quite a few times. The busboys, though, were impressively prompt and tactful about swiping away empty glasses and refilling water cups. It was such a small space that I was mystified at how they managed to efficiently clear away plates and neatly place new ones.

The food was unmemorable as far as I remember, and unfortunately I didn't get a chance to snap any pictures. I do remember that the empanadas were mediocre, and I thought that the dough was overly thick and the filling dry. The ceviche was also just okay and I could have used a lot more acidity, although I liked the huge kernels of Peruvian corn mixed in. The sauteed beef with vegetables was overly salty and though the beef was fresh, it was noticeably overcooked and stringy. 

I think the strangest dishes of the night were definitely the Korean-esque bowls of mixed ingredients cooked in hot stone pots. I suppose the goal was to simulate a bibimbap kind of dish, but the tastes were rather bizarre and dissonant. There was a vegetarian version and a meat version, and both were unpalatable. I think I may almost prefer the vegetarian version with its quinoa and arugula mixture, but that in itself just sounds unappetizing. I'm not sure if these options are on the regular menu, but I wouldn't recommend them. 

The other honorable mention (this time a positive one) goes to the desserts. The different kinds of sorbets were refreshing and had a good mixture of tart and sweet, although I really wished that our servers could have let us know a description of the flavors upon serving. There was also a rich chocolate mousse that was a tad sweet for my taste, but the texture was airy and pleasingly light. My favorite was the strawberries and cream dessert with a freshly-made tuile on top. This was the perfect balance of freshness and creaminess for me, and the tuile was fragrant with that just out of the oven freshness. I could have inhaled an entire portion by myself, but of course, these were all shared between 3-4 people. 

The drinks were nice in taste but light on alcohol, which wasn't really an issue since this isn't the kind of venue to drink heavily. They also followed the overall trend of small portions for high prices, even taking the location and ambiance into consideration. I just can't justify it, especially as our per-person price was well above three figures each. 

I'm starting to notice a trend with my opinions of seemingly highly-rated, pricey, upscale restaurants in coveted areas. It might be a while before I try another, but chances are I won't be coming back to La Mar.
author: Maggie X.

description:
I made a last minute reservation (literally a couple hours before, whoops) on OpenTable and indicated that we were celebrating an anniversary. 

We were seated promptly - the space is huge, but still a full house on a Wednesday night at 7:30 - and our waiter, Luis, immediately brought over two flutes of champagne and wished us a happy anniversary. It was really a pleasant surprise.

We ordered two non-alcoholic drinks, the Pina Punch and the Lychee-Nada (I preferred this one), and he ordered the Carne Anticucho and I got the Ceviche Tasting.

The Carne Antichucho was a little on the smaller side, so if you're super hungry it may be too little food, but if you're just normal to kinda hungry, it seemed to be the right amount food. I tried a piece of the beef and I thought it was perfectly chewy and very flavorful.

The Ceviche Tasting seemed like it wasn't going to be enough, as each of the ceviches were in small-ish bowls, but it was plenty. I was definitely stuffed afterwards (the plantain chips helped with that too!). I forgot to ask what the catch of the day was, but it was some kind of white fish, maybe some kind of yellowtail. It was really tasty, with some pieces of roasted corn for some crunch. The Mixto was a little spicier (or maybe it was leftover flavors from the habanero in the Clasico), and was a mix of squid, shrimp, and octopus. Nikei had ahi tuna in it, topped with onions, daikon, and cucumber, with a sauce that tasted like light soy sauce with other citrus-y flavors in it. Overall, I really enjoyed the ceviche sampler, and if you're into raw fish/poke/ceviche, I think you'd really enjoy this.

I thought we would get a dessert menu, but instead, Luis brought out a slice of tres leches cake with a candle, which was extra surprising after the flutes of champagne.

Honestly, I was more inclined to give La Mar four stars because the boyfriend had a little trouble picking out his meal since he wasn't feeling seafood at the moment (there are only a handful of dishes that aren't seafood based), but the treatment we were given was just so fantastic and the food was very good, that I didn't think it would be fair to dock a star. I would definitely go back, especially for happy hour, and try to sit in the (currently covered for warmth) back patio. 

tl;dr La Mar is a fantastic place for a celebration, happy hour, or business meal. Just be aware that options are very seafood heavy, so if you're with someone who has dietary restrictions/preferences that don't lean that way, it may be difficult to accommodate. The menu is online, so be sure to check it out before you go!
author: Tiffany T.

description: Everything is so tasty here! Tried restaurant week lunch menu, good value!!! Weather is perfect today and location is awesome!!! Strongly recommended
author: Meimei H.

description:
The restaurant is beautiful, the service excellent and the food is highly satisfying.  It's hard to believe I've neglected this place all these years. I'm glad I finally made it.  The Lomo Saltado was super duper tender.  It had a nice flavor and was not too salty.  The Jalea, also, was crazy amazing.  I recommend that dish above all.  I didn't care too much for the Yucuintas.  I thought it was too dry.  The empanadas were not amazing either.  I had the shrimp and I didn't find much shrimp in it.  

The positives far outweigh the negatives.  I very much recommend this place. It's a tad more pricey, but the quality is definitely there.
author: Angel S.

description: I loved all the sushi/fish options at this restaurant. Definitely get the nigiri. We got there early and still accommodated us which was very nice. I left my credit card there and they made it easy for me to retrieve two days later.
author: Nick Y.

description: Least memorable restaurant I've not eaten in. Marsha, the hostess finessed passive aggression when we showed up promptly for our reservation and we were apparently so early she felt the need to seat 15 people ahead of us. Still haven't a clue what we did to merit this behavior. Anyhow rushing off to write a 5 star  review for SD down the road who were polite and awesome! Don't waste you time here.
author: Kate P.

description:
Beautiful restaurant on the water!  The inside reminds me of being on a tropical island or something.  

The lunch menu had SO many delicious choices.  I was dying to try some of the ceviche but was trying to keep it light on my stomach.

The plantain chips and dip were great!

I decided to go with the Quinoa with peppers and the fried egg.  Um, seriously one of the best quinoa dishes I've ever had.

Service was a tad slow, as I re-filled my water glass by myself at least 3 times and we had to flag down a bus boy for the check but seriously yummy.
author: Kimberly L.

description: Went here for a Sunday brunch with my friends. Service was great, I was waiting for the plantain chips everyone has posted about, but I guess they were out. They served homemade potato chips instead. They were good, but plantain chips would have been better for our ceviche. Sat outside it was nice, especially with the live music. Also tried the empanadas and the corn was my favorite. Shared the crab sandwich, super yummy, wish I had one to myself. Location is a bit pricey, portions are small, but good.
author: d p.

description:
This restaurant is located at the building next to the Ferry Building on Pier 1 1/2. We came here to celebrate my sister's birthday. I loved the environment and the whole look of the restaurant. The table mats were full of color and the tables were spacious enough for our party of 7. 

To start dinner off, we were given two buckets of plantain chips with a green sauce. The plantain chips tasted like tortilla chips/potato chips and the green sauce had a familiar taste. The green sauce tasted exactly like the sauce they serve at Mexican restaurants for your burritos! It was a nice light snack before our meal.

My sister kept telling us that the portions were large when in fact they were nothing close. It was mostly small plates and quite expensive for what it was.. seriously, we spent probably about $200ish on the following:
- 2x mixto - cebiche that included a mixture of the catch of the day, calamari, octopus, shrimp. This was probably my favorite thing we had! ($19/ea)
- yuquitas - crispy yucca croquettes in a rocoto huancaina sauce. Meh, it just tasted like regular ol' potatoes ($9).
- beef / chicken empanadas - Overpriced for their taste ($14-15).
- arroz la mar - shrimp, clams, mussels, calamari, vegetables, and arborio rice. If you like paella, this is similar. My family liked the flavor. However, I did not ($34)
- 2x lomo saltado - traditional Peruvian style beef tenderloin, tomatoes, cilantro, garlic, soy and oyster sauce, potatoes, and rice. Honestly, there were barely any meat pieces. They seriously skimped out. I felt like there was way too much of the potatoes and onions. It tasted like a dish at a Chinese restaurant, so I wasn't too amazed by the taste. My sister raved about it, having tried it at another restaurant, but I was disappointed ($36/ea).
- some shrimp ball things with a green sauce over it; not sure where this is on the menu

The food is average and not worth the money in my opinion. Portions are small and you can easily rack up a bill on ordering just a couple things!
author: Sydney C.

description:
I went here twice on a recent visit to San Francisco. Once for lunch and once for dinner. I would definitely recommend getting reservations if you plan to eat here as it was busy both times. And, be sure to request the outdoor patio (which was covered when we went) as there are nice views.

For lunch, I had the quinoa salad (quinoa, burrata, greens, tomatoes and a nice dressing) and the beef empanadas (come on a plate of two and server said beef were the best). Fresh, flavorful and filling, I was hooked.

The next day, went back for dinner and shared the quinoa salad, beef empanadas and lomo saltado with Sam C. My colleagues who ordered the lomo saltado the afternoon prior were ready to book their tickets to Peru after one bite, so I knew it had to be good. A lovely mixture of  beef tenderloin, tomatoes, cilantro, garlic, soy and oyster sauce, potatoes, and rice, this was definitely filling and flavorful. Be sure to make sure that you mix all the flavors together and let the potatoes and rice soak up some of the sauce. We didn't have a reservation, but got a spot at the area overlooking the kitchen, which was nice.

Service was friendly both times and clearly I would go back there (since I already did!).
author: Christa S.

description: One of my favorite restaurants. Took my mom and sat outside by the water. We had our waiter select our entire menu, include cocktails and appetizers. Everything was delicious!
author: Nazee M.

description:
The best ceviche ever. This is a large and busy restaurant with excellent 
mostly sea food options from Peru, and the cocktails pisco like are delicious. The wait staff very cordial. We had a beautiful dinner time.
author: Katy E.

description:
First time trying Peruvian food! It was my girl cousins 26th birthday and she chose this place.
At first glance, the restaurant was really nice and has a great view.

Our waiter who was super cute with an accent had to explain to us how the menu worked. We took like fifteen minutes starring at the menu and couldn't figure out what is what.... It was just confusing. Anyways, he was really accommodating and gave us suggestions from each section of the menu.

While we were browsing the menu, our waiter gave us two types of chips and a dip to nibble on. One was potato chip and the other was banana! I LOVED the banana one! So crispy and you can really taste the banana!! Paired with the sauce was nommmm ^__^

Onto the food ! I can't remember the names exactly for each dish. But from what i recall:
- soft shell crab: couldn't try but my cousins said it was crunchy and good
- empanadas sampler: chicken, shrimp, veggie, and beef. I tried all but the shrimp since i'm allergic but the rest were so tasty and delicious. The empanadas were made hot and soft. It was so good we ordered individual empanadas after !
- cebiche la mar: selection of their three most popular; clasico, mixto, jalapeño, and nikei. Very poke-like and interesting but the portion size was small 
- Arroz la mar (I think): fried rice dish with seafood combination of mussels, shrimp, octopus, cilantro, and Huancaina sauce. My cousins said it was filling and had a lot of flavor. 

Drinks wise, us five girls ordered about 2-3 drinks each. Most were good like the prickly pear margarita and daiquiri. But the pisco sour was something else.... 

Overall, service was good.. Ambiance was nice and fancy. Food was tasty but pretty pricy! Empanadas were the best!
author: Anissa D.

description:
Fantastic Spot. Reservation is needed for the dining area but plenty of Bar room available which accommodate walk-ins. The sea food selections are on point as well as all the appetizers. 
Great ambiance.
author: Shadi K.

description:
I have visited La Mar quite a few times, as I work nearby in the area. 

First off, the happy hour is amazing - definitely order the ceviche. They do not skimp on fish, and portions are the same as the regular menu.

I have ordered the following other food:
-Lomo Saltado: A bit salty for my taste (and I love salt..), and a bit oily. Otherwise, it is very good. Meat is cooked well. 3/5
- Pork Fried Rice (can't remember the Peruvian name): This is very good and I'd get it again in a heartbeat. It comes in a sizzling stone bowl topped with egg. The meat and seafood inside are perfectly cooked, not dry at all. The chili sauce is amazing. 5/5
-Scallops Sashimi: Yum! Interesting presentation and accompanying flavors. I would recommend. 4/5
- Ceviche sampler: 3 kinds of ceviche, all very fresh and flavorful, though I feel the ceviche with the orange sauce was a bit overpowered with sauce. 4/5
- Plantain chips: YUMMMMMMM YES .. more please :) 5/5
- Pisco Sour: Strong, flavorful, top notch. 4.5/5

Service was attentive and friendly. 

Atmosphere was a little lackluster, but not horrible. Restaurant could use a little more pizzaz/decoration.
author: Amanda R.

description: This one one of the better places I have ever been to. I love the service and how nice they treated us. This is really a "San Francisco" style restaurant.
author: Gabriel B.

description:
Awesome place for ceviche and seafood in general!! I had a bit of everything by doing a family style lunch with my friends and it was amazing! Definitely a pricey place, but worth a try! :) 

Ceviche, empanadas, octopus, fried rice... all were tasty.
author: Caley Z.

description:
I want to give this place 5 stars, but I'll wait until my next visit.  

Typically I would write about my bad experience, but management has really tried to make things better, so I'm going to write about the good.  

Make a reservation for a seat outside, it's beautiful especially on a nice night.  You are on the water, the view alone is worth the steep price.  

The food is colorful and tasty, a fusion of different cultures including Japanese.  It is a favorite of mine. We ordered Causa Neike, empanadas sampler, lomo Saltado, quinoa caprese, everything tasted great.  We ordered 2 more things, and drinks, it was 
around $350 for four of us.  

The ambiance is fresh and modern.  They have a nice wine list, and large bar that seemed busy.  

We parked across the street, it was luck. 

Hoping to add service, etc after next visit.
author: K M.

description:
Highly recommend the outdoor seating if it's available- really beautiful view of the pier. I love Peruvian food so was well acquainted with most of the classics on the menu. Our table tried a few different things including the ceviche sampler plate, the ahi tuna with whipped potato and the yucca balls for appetizers. I wasn't too crazy about the tuna and the other japanese-esque ceviche but everything else was amazing. Chicha morada tasted great as well. For main course, I tried the octopus skewer and the catch of the day (swordfish)- both were cooked perfectly and went well with the side dishes/garnishes they came with. For dessert, we had the passionfruit chocolate mousse and it was fantastic: not too chocolatey, but a good amount of rich fruity flavor.

La Mar isn't cheap but would definitely come back for a nice dinner or occasion
author: Alka M.

description:
MMM Peruvian ceviche!

Came here for lunch with my friend around noon, we made RVSP incase it was too crowded. Got seated right away, staff was efficient and friendly and environment was beautiful and romantic.

We ordered:
Mixto Ceviche: Pretty good, very fresh, I really liked the creamy sauce
Purple Corn Soda: Interesting taste. It had a strong cinnamon taste, a little sour and sweet. 
Empanada Sampler: Came with chicken, steal, veggie and seafood empanada. Decent.
Fried Calamari: OK, wasn't too crazy for it, kinda dry
Trio: Recommend! Delicious! 3 kinds of raw fish with different sauces!

Overall, great place for seafood and wine and dine. Would come here again to try for dinner. The owner was super nice and gave us a card to come next time and drinks are on him!
author: Natalie L.

description: Amazing drinks, many different selections for ceviche. Their seafood is very fresh. We had the lomo saltado (always great). Parking was available at pier 3, a one minute walk away for good rates. Easily accessible by bart also. Will definitely be coming back here.
author: Meghan P.

description: Ordered the ceviche tasting, empanada tasting, and causa tasting so I feel like we got a pretty decent sampler. Everything was ridiculously overpriced and miniature portions.
author: Ava C.

description:
An average restaurant.

Located right next the Ferry building, this place looked upscale at first, especially when you first walk in. The front lounge area is great for group parties, with wide sitting areas with comfortable open sofas that you usually see in nightclubs. Once you walk inside, you will see a large open area with lots of tables and a chatty atmosphere.

In general, the patrons seem happy to hang out at this place. The decor is certainly amazing. The food is not bad, but as you'd expect is quite pricey, and the portions are small. 

Definitely get the meat rack if you can--the outside is crunchy and the inside is quite soft, which is a great combination.

The service is ok. Not bad, but definitely not superb. There were a few asian jokes that the waiter made that left the table a bit uncomfortable, especially since, well, half the table was asian. Meh.

Overall, come for the decor. The food is average, and not really worth the money.
author: Henry L.

description: My girlfriend took me to La Mar for a surprise birthday lunch! It has a nice location near the water on Pier 1 1/2. The cocktail we ordered was great. It was a punch in a pretty big pineapple cup. The seafood here is awesome. They do a Spanish style sashimi and recommend trying all their different flavors. The complementary plantain chips they provide are sooo good. Probably ate too much of that and didn't save enough room for the dishes we ordered. Definitely a must try for seafood lovers!
author: Alvin T.

description: Three stars for the nice outdoor seating and relaxing tropical decor. Great service from hosts and staff. Unfortunately, only two stars for the food - underwhelming and disappointing from all the great reviews.
author: Eli B.

description: Good food, a bit overpriced but it made up for it with the beautiful patio seating.  We had the ceviche taster, the skewered meat taster, the croquettes, and the shrimp and rice.  It was all delicious.  The low rating is for the service.  While the server was friendly, she was extremely inefficient and a bit inattentive.  I tried to order a cocktail from her and she walked away and didn't hear me.  We got out first round of cocktails halfway through the meal.  She kept picking up empty glasses and not asking if we wanted another.  When they brought our entrees, we had to wait for silverware.  We ordered more chips for our ceviches and it never came.  When we asked about our drinks, she exclaimed "the food looks great!" (??). It seems like the ratings here are by tourists, as in I should have known better than to dine with locals at a restaurant on the pier.
author: Shannon S.

description: We came for my brothers birthday lunch, near the ferry building, good ambience, good service. If you want a $20 small plate of ceviche, this is the place. Do not get the lemon soda, way too sweet. I don't think I'll be back but there you go
author: Sue R.

description: La Mar is a top shelf experience. I must humble myself and admit I did not know Peruvian cuisine has a Japanese influence. If you like raw fish (sushi lovers take note) and you like some spice La Mar is hands down a dining experience. You can dine in either the chic dining room or on the less formal covered patio either is a treat.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
Seriously one of the best squid ink pastas I have ever had...regarding the "pasta" itself.  Incredibly flavorful noddles.  The shrimp and calamari were alright, but the pasta was really the star of the dish.  

Coworker got the crispy lamb shank and I was jealous.  It looked delish.

Great ambiance. Great food.  Would come here again. Definitely worth a visit if you're staying by the embarcadero and have a few hundred dollars to throw down on dinner.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Great food, delicious ceviche, lomo saltado, salads, empanadas, everything cooked and served perfectly. The chocolate mousse with crunchy quinoa caramel on top and lucumu ice cream was amazing!

I was there with a party of about 50 people and noticed the entire staff was just excellent, really on point waiters, never intrusive and helping everyone out. They were like a finely tuned machine working together. Impressive.     And as an added nice thing no one acted strange or annoying about my wheelchair, they were just helpful and gracious. Thanks!
author: Liz H.

description: I love their squid ink pasta  it's tastes amazing and surely it will make you happy
author: Jennifer D.

description:
It had been the better part of five years since the last time I dined at La Mar, and I wanted to see what this new menu was all about so, I hit it up on Monday (3/28) with a group of fun peeps. If you haven't been to this place before, you'd immediately be impressed with the space as the ceiling is vaulted and it sits in between a couple piers. Honestly, the atmosphere is a 10. 

The place is owned by world renowned chef, Gaston Acurio who has more than 18 restaurants to his name spanning all over the globe. It's impressive. Last year, I saw a documentary (Finding Gaston) at the Sonoma Film Festival and was wowed by this man's commitment to his people of Peru and the sustainable approach he takes to sourcing his food for the restaurants. Basically, he's a stud. 

The meal came in multiple courses and was super colorful. Each plate reminded me of spring time (see photos), as the edible flowers were a plenty. My favorites are listed below: 

1. Cebiche Clasico - as it sounds. Classicly delish. 
2. Chicken Empanada - flavorful and not dry. I could crush 10 of these in a single sitting. 
3. Thai Snapper (whole) - deboned, head on, and just heavenly. 
4. Beef Cheek - braised to perfection
5. Mousse de chocolate fortunato - the crispy quinoa made this dish. 

A solid 5 stars. Get in here and try the fare this spring as it's just starting to hit the markets, so you know it's gonna be fresh.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I am so glad that La Mar Cebichería Peruana has been thriving on San Francisco's Embarcadero for six years and counting, with its beautifully prepared and plated Peruvian dishes. Located on Pier 1 1/2, the restaurant boasts a fantastic view of the bay with its thankfully closed-in and heated patio. It has a sleek and modern yet still very comfortable atmosphere. It opened seven years ago with famed Peruvian chef Gastón Acurio at the helm and after all these years, La Mar is still packing them in for those looking for a great Happy Hour with affordable piscos, not to mention tasty bites all at affordable prices. I've been here for lunch on weekdays and weekends and it never disappoints, with its unique style of cooking you can't find anyplace else. 

For those of you looking to come when it is the wait is negligible, may I suggest you come in on a weekend in January as that was clearly the slowest month of the year at La Mar, I was able to come on a Saturday afternoon with my fellow Yelper in crime Christine because she had never been to La Mar before and she's always wanted to come because she's heard such good things about the place (and she's right)! Christine smartly thought we should enjoy a dish on their main patio until we waited for Happy Hour to kick in because at La Mar it is from 3-6pm in the bar area only and it's seven days a week, which for San Francisco is truly rare especially in a tourist haven like the Embarcadero. So we wisely waited it out while we got a great view of the bay and Treasure Island.

We wanted something that truly represented the cooking of Peru, while still not filling us up too much, we went with the Chaufa Aeropurto which was pork fried rice, vegetables, mushrooms, shrimp, egg tortilla topped with a spicy garlic sauce all mixed by our server in a cast iron bowl. We both thought it tasted really good, not too much kick but mixed with a wide variety of ingredients. At 27 dollars a dish, it was the perfect meal for two to share. We thought about getting more but then we realized we planned on getting more food in the bar an hour later, thankfully La Mar provides complimentary deep fried plantain chips with the tangiest aioli (also known as their Cebicheria sauce) that I've ever had and that easily filled me over until 3pm!

Which luckily wasn't too far off, as we easily found a round table in the bar area to sit and charge our phones while we sipped and dined! La Mar is truly one of the largest restaurants in the area. So many rooms, on top of their open kitchen to enjoy their expansive menu. Here's where the real deal at La Mar can be enjoyed. So many fine cocktails from Pisco Sours to Mai Tais at only 6-8 dollars respectively! This is one of the best deals to get your drink on in the city! To drink, Christine went with the Pisco Punch which came with pisco quebranta, house-made pineapple syrup and lemon, while I went with the with Passion Daiquiri which came with white rum, passion fruit and lime juice. Both drinks were meticulously prepared and a real steal at 6 dollars. Christine love mine so much she ordered her own for later. 

The Happy Hour bites menu is filled with six distinctive bites that nicely represent the cuisine of Peru from two types of ceviche, deep fried seafood, yucca fries, various empanadas and their take on a quinoa burger. After careful consideration, we knew we were going with the jaleita, also known as fried seafood, mainly because it consisted of deep fried calamari, which is a must on any menu I come across; the mixed ceviche because like the it had a nice variety of seafood and we could get a nice contrast against the jaleita; and one of their signature empanadas, this time a beef one. We loved the jaleita with its mix of fish, calamari and shrimp alongside that tasty cebicheria sauce which provided that extra kick to it. The ceviche was solid and the empanada was juicy. All three dishes presented affordable deals and was solid against the piscos and sangria we happen to be enjoying on this Saturday afternoon. We were never rushed by the servers, as it was never quite full enough in the bar area again thanks to it being January, where we didn't feel overcrowded once. 

Thankfully La Mar is thriving on San Francisco's main drag so they can share their modern take on Peruvian cuisine with the rest of us. They truly represent the best of the wide range of ethnic backgrounds that are found throughout that country, from Asian fusion to traditional Latin American cuisine, every dish here gives Peruvian food its unique edge and makes for some of the most imaginative dishes from around the world. And it is all found right here on the shores of San Francisco Bay.
author: Jason F.

description:
San Francisco is one of the best cities to dine in. With so many amazing restaurants throughout the city, my fiance chose La Mar to celebrate our 1 year anniversary of the day we met. I'm extremely happy he chose this restaurant as it was an amazing experience from the second we entered, to the very last sip of our champagne!

Out server, Mateo, went above and beyond to ensure that we had an excellent experience. He was super friendly, knowledgeable about the menu and extremely attentive. We were super appreciative of him for taking the extra mile of taking amazing pictures of us outside of the restaurant (near the water, since we sat outside) and bringing us champagne on the house to celebrate our special day! Mateo, thank you so much such a great experience! 

Let's talk about the food. This place is awesome if you love seafood. If you don't, they have plenty of veggie and meat options, as well. Their tuna with avocado as an appetizer was to die for. The sauce... I'm still drooling over it! For our mains, we had the halibut and the sizzling dish with assorted seafood. The cocktails were excellent, as well. I loved the mezcal one. 

Do yourself a favor and sit in the outside area. Enjoy the fresh air and the beautiful view. This restaurant is pricey, but worth it! 

Tip: Ask for their house hot sauce and their house aioli. Mix those two together and thank me later ;)
author: Anastasia N.

description: So good!! The Ahi Tuna, California Cebiche, Chicken empanadas, and croquettes are so delicious!! When ever someone wants a delicious, filling and flavorful meal with a beautiful view of the water, I will always recommend this place.
author: Run.It.Off V.

description:
There are two ways to perceive my experience at La Mar. 

The first is from the perception that I have been to the original La Mar in Mira Flores, Peru. In comparison, the San Francisco location was a complete disappointment. There was nothing that resembled authentic Peru at this location. In fact, I was all together disappointed with the entire experience up until I had the anticuchos (beef heart.) The seasoning on the anticuchos was authentic, delicious, and clearly Peruvian. Those were the highlight of our meal. 

However, from an American perspective, it was an elegant classy restaurant. The service was polite and welcoming. The ambiance was elegant, but a little boring. It lacked theme and direction. 

We ordered a series of cebiches and seafood entrees. None of them were memorable. Not even the pisco sours were memorable, which was very unfortunate. Case and point, my server did not even know what "aji" was, which is a prevalent hot sauce throughout Peru.

Sadly, there are several restaurants in San Francisco that I would recommend before this one.
author: Alecks R.

description: A fave! I stick to the ceviches, croquetas, and drinks. Also, love sitting on the patio and stopping into their bar. Service is always on point.
author: Amy O.

description: Delish lomo Saltado ( meat was very tender) and cebiche tasting was a good surf and turf combo!! The corn inside the cebiche was very unique. Steamed and toasted
author: Jessie C.

description:
What an elegant, fun spot! Came here with the boo last Saturday for dinner and had a lovely time. We ordered the California Cebiche, Sopa Seca, and Lomo Saltado. Oh my gosh, so much yum. Even the free plantain chips and chipotle sauce were delicious. The California Cebiche was amazing. The seafood was hearty and so fresh, and the big corn kernels added a nice touch. It was the perfect amount of tangy. I also loved the Sopa Seca, reminded me of the Fidua I happily ate on a summer day along the Valencia coast. Every bite was packed with seafood and amazing flavor. I'm not a big meat eater so I can't say much about the Lomo Saltado, but the boo enjoyed it.

Also, we were way underdressed but service was still friendly and attentive. We didn't have a reservation, but if you can, make a reservation and sit near the window so you can see the water. Even if you don't, La Mar has a nice trendy, modern feel and is a great date spot. It's on the pricier side, but totally worth it.
author: Joanna C.

description:
We had a lovely Sunday dinner ! No reservations,they were full but had a table.
Have been here before ,  and it was always good , tonight it was excellent.
Had mushroom empenadas, causa with fresh crab - delicious .
Shared the whole halibut which comes grilled with such a tasty rice dish and arugula  . Absolutely delicious and more than enough for 2.
Dessert was the Choco Maracuya - we loved it.
Had a nice bottle of Malbec, Luca from Mendoza .Not too pricey at $ 60.00.
Waiters couldn't have been more attentive . Great dinner !
author: Maria C.

description:
Drop by there around 12:15PM today to have lunch.  Asked for an outdoor table.  There were at least seven or eight empty outdoor tables.  I asked if one of those tables were available and the hostess told me that she can only give me a table that was just outside the perimeter in the outdoor area (walking into the outdoor area, it was the table on the left just outside the metal perimeter) totally under the sun.  There were six or seven outdoor tables totally empty.  I really do not understand the hostess problem.  Maybe she does not want a minority sitting inside the restaurant.  Very rude service.  I felt that your hostess was totally "Ethnic" unfriendly.  Just remember, you are not the only outdoor restaurant on the Embarcadero.  There are many that we can patronize.  

Please Do Not Treat Patrons like dirt.  Remember if you do not have customers patronizing your restaurant, the business will not exist,  you probably will not have a job.  

If you are the owner or manager of the restaurant, you should review your security camera and you will understand how rudely your hostess treated a potential customer.
author: L W.

description: You MUST try this Peruvian/Asian fusion. It is certainly unique and well worth it. BECAUSE it's so unique, I also recommend being ready to spend some money and sharing a bunch of items with the table to get the most of the experience! Everything I had was so great, even some of the dishes I wasn't sure about what I was eating at the time. Don't be afraid to ask the waiter for recommendations here!
author: Alex H.

description: I hosted a client dinner last night at La Mar, we had the chef's table.  The dinner was perfect in every way.   We were 17 people and were able to chat between courses, change seats etc.  The menu we chose was perfect, it goes without saying that the food at La Mar is unique and excellent. Our waiter: Ardjan orchestrated the group of bus staff at our table to perfection. I told our admin to repeat this dinner for our next corporate event, the table, the food, the wine and the waiter.
author: Betsy W.

description:
Expensive, but worth it! I love that this place is like Peruvian-Japanese fusion... Whereby you have several raw seafood options that are seasoned and garnished Peruvian style. 

My coworkers and I tried a variety of ceviches, empanadas, and mashed potato dish, which I forgot the name of. 

The drinks are also great! Several exotic options to choose from. My only disappointment was the apple pie... Didn't really seem to be anything special and the price was ridiculously high for the value.
author: Brittney B.

description:
We went here for dinner with a group. The ceviches to start with were really flavoured and authentic, it actually reminded us of the ceviche we had in Peru. 
Loved the tuna and the calamari one. For mains the octopus was a delight and although a bigger size than any other main, one could not let go of it. The scallops (not as big) were cooked to perfection. The chocolate mousse desert - a little overpowering, not as light and fluffy as one would expect it but definitely chocolaty.  But the downer of the desert was made up by their Pisco Sour, the Pisco Punch and the wonderful seafront views.
author: CatAlina A.

description: Great food and service! Tried the ceviche, loma saltado and empenadas. Everything was amazing and flavourful. The spot is busy all get reservations. Also it is in the tourist district so expect crowds
author: Jasmeet K.

description:
Lovely outdoor seating area overlooking the bay. We weren't too impressed by the lunch dishes though--- dull flavors and pretty pricey for what you receive, IMO. 

We ordered: 
+ Cebiche clasico ( CA halibut in leche de tigre with red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam)
+ Pulpo (Grilled octopus w/ anticuchera sauce, herbed
mashed potatoes, sautéed choclo, Peruvian botija olive
aioli, finished with chalaca chimichurri) 
+ Burger (forgot to take note of what was in it) 
+ Pisco sour

The ceviche's leche de tigre marinade was watered down and too sour. You'll taste better ceviche at Limon. Pulpo and burger were uninteresting. Btw, you get some nice plantain chips to munch on while you wait for your dishes--those were actually pretty interesting. The Pisco Sour was loaded with alcohol, so it was worth the price. 

Kudos to our server for the exceptional service though. He was so vibrant and knowledgeable.

We wouldn't come back unless a friend requested to. In summary, we've tasted better Peruvian cuisine; this restaurant is overrated.
author: Merica S.

description:
Ok, So i'm impressed. i went in there for my 6 year Anniversary with my husband and so glad we chose this over any Restaurant in Napa (which was our original Choice). The food was delicious, flavors were on point. 
I have been trying Peruvian restaurants around the Bay area since i moved here two years ago and have been sorely disappointed.  This place gave me my much needed fill of Peruvian goodness and fancy Anniversary dinner i was craving and dreaming of.  I am Peruvian Born and Raised and grew up in Miami where the standard for Peruvian Cuisine is really high, I really did not want to like this place (it is kind of pricey and thought that i would be paying just for the location) but i was so impressed and fell in love. 
We started our date at the Bar while we waited for our 6:30 pm Reservation, We started with drinks (Pisco Sour and Cholito)  they were really tasty and executed perfectly. We also tried their empanada tasting menu at the bar, the empanadas were done perfectly Peruvian style --i know it sounds odd to rave about empanadas but when everyone  in the area claims to make Peruvian food including empanadas and they are not even close, you lose hope! 

We checked in for our reservation and decided on the tasting menu, i honestly thought i would be left hungry as usually tasting menus are small bites but we were satisfied and super happy with the choice. ALL of the dishes including the variations of comida criolla and the fusions were spectacular and with such a perfect execution of the unique Peruvian taste.  It brought me back to growing up in Peru :)  We sat with a view of the pier and had so much fun as the ambiance and music were just perfect. I cannot say enough things about this restaurant! The only thing i would say that would improve my experience would be valet parking :) 

Gaston Acurio is a Genius Chef and I'm glad he has brought and taught our culture to chefs that can execute this very special cuisine.
author: Delilah R.

description:
Gorgeous space on the water with impeccable service.

My party tried a trio of the cebiches; the ahi one made me swoon. 

The vegetarian empanadas were crispy and slight bit spicy. I really liked them. 

The yucca was fabulous with a delicious sauce to dip them in. Which reminds me, they serve up plantain chips in cones with two awesome dipping sauces, kinda like your chips and salsa in a Mexican restaurant.
The classic Lomo Saltado was okay; I've had better in other Peruvian restaurants and in Peru. 

The dish with quinoa and egg was a definite no for me. I didn't like the flavors or texture. 

I also didn't care for the skewers of meat. Perhaps they weren't cooked enough for me, but the flavor wasn't there for me either. 

I would come back though just for the ahi cebiche and the yucca. Also, service was great. I really enjoyed this place and would come again
author: Cyntia Q.

description: More like a 3.5. Came here with my parents for lunch. We had the la mar burger, the chicken burger, and the fish skewers. Don't come here expecting authentic Peruvian food. You'll be disappointed. BUT, the food was good, just overpriced. Service was really great and the view was amazing.
author: Lexi R.

description:
3.5/5- Rounded up for great service and atmosphere
I could've sworn I wrote a review for this place and my last trip here was more of a 4 star experience but unfortunately neither the food nor the service today were as good as my previous experience. As far as I can tell, this place is authentic compared to what I had while I stayed in Peru but the prices can be steep or reasonable depending on what you get. The service is also generally very nice. Out of the 4 servers/hosts I encountered over my two visits, 3 were absolutely phenomenal and went out of the way to make us feel welcome. I was a bit disappointed they randomly told us they were not offering the restaurant week menu today (despite it being mid-restaurant week) but I was relieved I didn't order it because the prices were ridiculous and basically rivaled getting the entire meal separately.

During my first trip I got the Jalea (didn't see this on the menu this time around) and the Causa Limeña. The Jalea had nice light breading that wasn't too oily. The portion was substantial for the price and the quality of the seafood was above average. The fish were flaky and moist and nothing was overly chewy. Overall the flavors weren't super interesting and it was basically a big bowl of calamari, but it was still tasty. (3.5/5)

The Causa Limeña on my first trip was AMAZING. Everything balanced so so well and getting a evenly distributed bite was heaven. It was pricy for the portion but totally worth it. Unfortunately my friend's causa limeña today was extremely disappointing and resembled a blob of mayo dressed crab over potatoes. The textures of both dishes were great but the second time had far less flavorful potatoes and crab. It was also short on the garnishes that helped balance out the dish like the tomatoes, quail egg, and microgreens. It was still edible but overall nothing special today. (4.5/5- First)(3/5- Second)

During my first trip my friend got the empanada sampler. I only had a bite of each so I don't remember the dish extremely well but out of the four empanadas, two were perfect, one was dry, and one was not very memorable. I think the dry one was the beef but my friend ordered it today and said it was good. Although they look small the empanadas are quite heavy and the sampler can be eaten as a meal. 

On my second trip here I ordered the Tiradito Sampler. This was definitely pricy. Anyone who knows me knows I have no problem dropping money on raw fish but I'm not quite sure the quality of this fish or the taste of the sauces really justified the cost. The cuts of the fish themselves were nice: not to thick or thin. None of the fish was very fatty or flavorful though and overall they acted more like a nicely textured vehicle for the sauce. The sauce also ranged between good and meh. In general they were nicely acidic (though I prefer even more acidity) but the spices/peppers weren't very prominent. I appreciated the maiz chulpe and quinoa they added for texture and the microgreens are always a nice touch. (3.5/5)

Honestly my favorite part about this place besides the atmosphere and the service are the chips. I don't own a fryer and I haven't been able to find a market that sells the chips premade (or at least good ones) but I seriously bought bags and bags of yucca/plantain/cassava/etc. chips while I was in Peru and again when in I was in Guatemala and I swear I could eat the chips here forever. The sauces they come with are also delicious! (5/5)

Overall, La Mar is a bit of a mixed bag when it comes to food quality but the atmosphere and service (and the chips...) are consistently great
author: Vivian C.

description: Terrible pretentious servers. Treated us like out of towners, condescendingly coaching us towards most expensive dishes. Food was okay, but service basically wants to churn tables.
author: Maria T.

description:
Founding chef Gaston Acurio's cuisine is very good. We shared an entire octopus entree between 3 people, enough to satisfy us deliciously. The server quoted it at $69 when providing the specials, but final bill showed $79. 
My biggest critique is for the front bar. The bar staff didn't allow me to order a drink before happy hour ended for a friend who was on her way. Their policy is not to serve more than one drink per person. I find this highly limiting and a turn off to customers. The bar wasn't very busy on Monday evening, what did it hurt to add more drinks to the tab? It is HELPING YOUR BUSINESS. 
Generally, the food is good but this restaurant is overpriced with unnecessary limitations.
author: Patty V.

description: We always love coming in and eating here. Unfortunately this time the service was a bit slow. Albeit we were seated in the bar to eat with a promise to move us over whenever a table opened up. That table never opened up, the food once it was finally delivered to our table was amazing. The price was right on par with what we'd expect here but just the wait made it a long dining experience. A few people left simply because they had waited long enough and still hadn't gotten any food. I would recommend this place to eat just make sure you have a reservation. If ya don't it's still an amazing place to go just beware you might wait a bit to get food or drinks.
author: Anon G.

description: We visited La Mar yesterday, August 11th.  It was our third visit to this restaurant and the food was very good  as usual.  However, the service was very poor with very little personal attention paid to my wife and me.  It seems that they have become understaffed , at least for the weekend crowd.  In addition, this restaurant does not have enough rest room facilities and this seems to have been a problem with them since they opened.
author: David E.

description:
As a fellow Peruvian, La Mar is a restaurant that everyone in Lima knows about. La Mar was opened by renown chef Gaston Acurio, yes the restapreneur that revolutionize Peruvian cuisine.

La Mar offers Gaston's favorite plates:

- Ceviche: raw fish, lemon, chili, salt. You can try it Nikkei style (Japanese-Peruvian)
- Tiradito
- Lomo Saltado
- Fried rice Peruvian style
- Arroz con mariscos
- Empanadas (corn, beef, chicken, etc).
- Drinks - pisco, chilcanos, maracuya sour, etc.
- Anticuchos (beef heart)

We love the chefs in house - Piero, Victoriano, and Danny! Lovely service. Of course, this is an expensive restaurant so every time you pay, your wallet cries.
author: Silvia L.

description:
Came here for dinner on a double date on a Friday night and had a great time! 

We made reservations ahead of time- but only earlier that day- and it was a great decision, when we showed up for a group of 4 others of a similar size had to wait 1-2 hours. The restaurant is split into many sections, more than I was able to explore on this visit, but we were seated in what seemed to be the middle section- between the bar portion at the entrance and the seaside room at the very back. I liked it, the space was very open, full of bustling tables, but not too loud. 

Service was speedy, not very warm but very efficient. The food was delicious!!! We tried all three samples- the cebiche, causas and empanadas. I'm a fresh food fanatic so the ceviche really struck me and I enjoyed this the most. The causes were totally beautiful but a little difficult to dissect the components. The empanadas were definitely the favorite for the rest of our party and I agree that they were delicious. 

The meal opened with Yucca chips and sauces that were good but a little heavy to start with. 

Drinks: we tried the pisco sour and maracuya sour. I am usually an old fashioned drinker and found the pisco sour to be too abrasive but the maracuya to be perfect. 

Overall certainly worth a try, definitely recommend pairing a drink with dinner.
author: Angela D.

description: I wish I would have taken more pictures.  Our server was so helpful with the menu!  Really recommend the Cebiche Taste!  Each one so unique, fresh, light and awesome.  If you have never tried a cebiche/ceviche dish I think this would be a great place to start.  The delicate fish with the contrast of texture was great.  Tried a few dishes.  Enjoyed each one.  The only picture I took was of the Corazon.  Try heart at least once.  Staff awesome.  Our server really made it great answering each and every question regarding the menu food and drink!
author: Spencer J.

description: Amazing Cebiche! Fresh and delicious food, and great Pisco Sour. Can't wait to go back.
author: Mina D.

description:
La Mar is one of my most favorite places in the city. I think they have a fantastic menu and cocktails! I would highly recommend this spot to anyone. They have a nice outdoor patio which is perfect on a nice day. They have these banana chips with a sauce that are absolutely amazing! I highly recommend doing a ceviche sampler. All of them are delicious. Their purple mashed potatoes are also wonderful! 
You can also stop by for a drink too. They have a fun bar scene in the front.
author: Makenzi B.

description: My family and I had an amazing dining experience.  All the seafood was fresh and seasoned well.  My mother who is usually picky, loved it too.  Our server was respectful and made some wonderful recommendations.  We never felt rushed.  Thank you!  We plan to come back!
author: Amar L.

description:
:( asked for more plantain chips and completely got ignored; he clearly acknowledged that we wanted them. We ordered the restaurant week menu and also some other dishes for variety.

Ginger passionfruit soda (?) - mix of Fever Tree's ginger beer with passionfruit as advertised.

Cebiche mercado; tiradito verde - I think I preferred the cebiche mercado over the tiradito, but both were great. Nice balance of texture, freshness, and tinge of acidity.

Pulpo anticuchos - girlfriend got this and enjoyed it.

Lomo saltado - lacking in the soy sauce, but that could be a personal preference.

Sorbets - acai (?) and passionfruit; the acai helped balance the natural sourness of passionfruit; refreshing palate cleanser.
author: James N.

description:
I went here with my bf for sf restaurant week! Firstly, the food was delicious. He and I opted for the set dinners, totalling 6 dishes to try (though I can't remember what they're all called unfortunately.) There was the Quinoa salad and chicken Skewers to start, beef and salmon main dishes, and sorbet and tres leches for dessert. No drinks this time around since I simply couldn't est another bite - it was all so good. There were also chips to start, can't forget those Lol

The restaurant is very touristy looking, but very nice and along the water. We sat outside on the heated patio which was slightly too warm, but comfortable mostly. The service was friendly and attentive. The ambiance was nice, but it was a busy night so it was quite loud.

Overall, great place for dinner or drinks. In the summer, it looks like the patio would have a really nice view when they open the screens :)
author: Bianca C.

description:
Came here for my birthday dinner and it was aweeesomeee. I'm not even that big of a fish person and I thought the Halibut ceviche was so delicious. The corn and chicken empanada were also pretty bomb and flavorful. I thought the lomo saltado was great, perfectly cooked and exceptional as well. The menu is a little confusing at first but after you spend some time with it you get the hang of the layout. 

They also have an amazing pisco sour and prickly pear margarita (it's not sweet at all). Took a while for the drinks to come. Our server was really nice and helpful but kind of disappeared as the meal went on. Still had an awesome experience and I'll definitely be back.
author: Hayley G.

description:
Definitely a fan of La Mar! 5 stars!!! Great service, great food, and love the atmosphere and its located right near embarcadero as you can see the Bay Bridge. You can definitely do family style - I personally do because I love trying different dishes. Most of the dishes I ordered was sea food and I must say, it as FRESH as it can get! 

What to order: 
- Cebiche Nikei:  Tuna, red onion, Japanese Cucumber, daikon, avocado, nori, and sesame in a tamarind leche  de tigre 
- Tiradito Gaston: Peruvian bay scallops, and creamy aji amarillo leche de tigre
- Pulpo Grilled Octopus: skewers with anticuchera sauce, herbed mashed potatoes, sautéed choclo, Peruvian botija olive aioli, finished with chalaca chimichurri (MUST GET)
- Pescado Yellowtail with fried potatoes, Peruvian corn, spicy
panchita and rocoto sauce
author: Jenn L.

description:
I went here with my family, and it was superb.
The food was very good - light and refreshing. The space is beautiful, and above all - the service was perfect. Gilberto treated us like family, and we felt that our every need was treated with care. It was a lovely evening, and we left feeling full and happy.
author: Mina Z.

description: The staff was extremely out focus. Our orders came in, in random order. For example our lunch appetizer (cauliflower) came at the end of the meal and drinks half way through. Staff avoided eye contact and treat us like air. Long wait for food. Food was underwhelming for the price. Heavy on sauce, low on protein. The only memorable part of the lunch was the dessert. Finally the menu is extremely confusing. La Mar is really not worth it. Either adjust prices or work harder to make the experience a lot better.
author: Tytus C.

description: VERY pricey, but good place. We were able to get in here on Father's Day with no wait. We basically had the taster of everything- the ceviches, emapanadas, sashimi, etc. All of it was delicious, but the portions were really small. The sauces, flavors, etc. were fantastic and the service was great. I don't remember our server's name but he was great and provided tons of information. In the end though, the high cost and small portion size take off a star. Go here if you want a fancy Peruvian meal on the water but be prepared for a large bill!
author: Samir K.

description:
Classic Ceviche- awesome. That fish was jello soft and it was damn good.

We got two anticucho's which were also quite good- Corazon and Pulpo. Pulpo was my favorite- octopus cooked to perfection. I'm definitely coming back for that!

Seco de Carillera - Not worth it at all. Wtf $50 for simple beef stew. Sorry but this dish was so extremely disappointing. I could not taste aji amarillo anywhere in that dish.

We asked for a side of aji roccoto and HOLY CAMOLY that was SPICY. In general, I'm a huge fan of spicy anything. Like, spicy cocktails? I'm there. And please make it extra spicy. But oooh wheeeee that aji roccoto was death, lol. I'd totally buy it if they sold it in a jar but I tell ya, it's not to play with. My appetite completely went flat after trying out the hot sauce- I didn't know that was possible? Still, I loved it. It was delicious. Hah!
author: Sara T.

description: Wow!  The food was amazing - and the service was even better!  My husband found this place on Yelp and I told him after dinner that he knocked it out of the park.  The food was really quite amazing and the service was even better!  It has been a LONG time since we have been treated so well by serving staff - especially at a packed restaurant on a Friday evening after the Chinese New Year parade.  The only thing that kept it from being 5 star was the price.  We did have 2 bottles of wine, but dinner for 4 was over $650 with tip - Was it fabulous, yes!  Was it worth it???  I would go back for another special occasion.
author: Phillip A.
