Both the crab and the shrimp were a little past their prime and getting a bit fishy.  And the wine list was less interesting and more overpriced than before (and no half bottles).  Too bad.
author: Stephen G.

description: Yet another delicious delightful time here. I love the pisco punch here with extra nutmeg. The ceviche and the empanadas . Excellent service and great ambience
author: Cecilia D.

description:
We pretty much exhausted the entirety of the menu and loved everything we had. 

To start, the chicken empanadas are the best single bite of food in the city, rivaling only the marina strips from Blackwood on chestnut. 

Secondly, we had so many foods but we're still impressed with the dexterity of the menu and the layering of flavors.  Absolutely incredible and a MUST-try in SF.
author: Jake T.

description:
Awful, loud atmosphere. 
Felt like a tourist trap.
Small portion sizes for too high a price. 
Food came out suspiciously fast...like it was sitting there ready in the kitchen.
Expect chips and salsa with a few plantains sprinkled in there to make it sort of fancy.
The only reason it earned two stars is it's dog friendly.
Not a great place.
author: Eric H.

description:
Excellent ceviche and happy hour. I love their margaritas!!
As an added bonus, the service is excellent, and the bartenders are especially knowledgeable.
author: Janet B.

description:
In San Francisco on business Sept 8th and love cebiche, so what better place to go than a cebicheria? The cebiche sampler was great! Three different kinds of seafood in three different sauces. Main course was the planche de mariscos that was served in a sizzling skillet with calamari, salmon, scallops, and octopus in an anticuchera sauce, drizzled with aji amarillo and chimichurri. Excellent!
   Atmosphere was casual and was not too busy on a Tuesday night at 6pm. Will come back next time I am in San Francisco.
author: Gerald P.

description: My son actually loves ceviche! I never thought I'd see the day. This is a fabulous, creative place for wonderful ceviche's. The only downfall of Lemair, is the noise level is very high. If you are sensitive to noise, which my 19-year-old is, it can be a bit overwhelming. This can be a long drawn out meal, but for us we usually get in and out pretty quickly and the staff is happy to accommodate us. My son thinks the food is worth it for him!
author: Heather D.

description:
La Mar used to be one of my favorite places to go to. I would send every visitor there.
I tried it after a couple of years today and was a disappointed.
We ordered cebiche mixto and it was tasteless..
The lomos saltado came out with literally rare meet we had to send back to get more cooked. Our waiter told us lomos saltado is usually served medium rare but was was more to the rare side.
The Sangria was also meh. 
So sad that the quality has gone down.
author: Nazanin S.

description: Get the ceviche, it's amazing. They also had Japanese food on the menu but it makes sense due to the changes in japanese diaspora in the region.
author: Justin C.

description: Food was delicious! Seviche outstanding My husband took me here for my birthday We even got a free birthday desert
author: Nozima T.

description:
G-N-O!  Girls' night out for me at this lovely place that is by the pier and located near the Ferry Building!

This place was enchanting in terms of the decor at their bar setting, layout and for their delicious, petite-proportioned food as well!

We did some damage to our wallets, but it was well worth the ambiance, entrees and glasses of wines that we ordered up! 

You must get their Ceviche Tasting I can't emphasize that enough!  It was zesty, colorful and full of variety in each small dish.  It tingled the palate and tapped all of my taste buds - especially for an appetizer!  My favorite was their Clasico!

Next up, that you must order, is their Causas Tasting!  The presentation is marvelous. It is basically stuffed potatoes that is served up in 4 different, tasty fillings.  Loved it!

I didn't care for this fried up, seafood dish. Avoid and keep getting wine!  It helps balances out the fried thickness of this dish, if you proceed on ordering it up.  

Get the Empanadas, if you're feeling a craving for them or want something simple.

Service was on point.  

I was loving every moment of this Peruvian-themed restaurant that was down by the pier!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Beautiful place, but lacked service. I waited 20 minutes and finally asked the hostess if she can bring our waiter. The waiter was a bit rushed and annoyed.

I ordered the clasico and it had way too much onion. But overall, it was very good. My friend ordered the pescado. The fish was extremely  dry, but presentation wise was beautiful.
author: Popcorn L.

description:
I took some visitors who are from Bolivia, and knowledgeable "foodies".
We ate at 5:30pm because we had a 9 yr old and 2 year old with us.  Service was fantastic and very welcoming.  Food was delicious and presentation was beautiful.  Thank you for showing my friends such wonderful hospitality.
author: Elaine D.

description:
Used to be a favorite of mine and my family's. The ceviche was always incredible, the rest of the food pretty good (quality was high, then went down a bit,  then improved again the last time I was able to dine here), service great, and fun atmosphere. I've brought plenty of friends here throughout the years. The last two times I've walked in, I've been snubbed. I'm standing there with a smile on my face waiting for a welcome that never comes. The first time, I attributed it to a fluke. I had to initiate the welcome and the hostess just stared at me. I was then told I needed a reservation (which is fine, I get that) but then she just turned away and started talking to another coworker. Recently, my family and I walked in all dressed up as we are waiting to board the Hornblower dinner cruise so we wanted to join in on the happy hour. Zero acknowledgments as we stood there like idiots. Walked out. 

Never going to return. There are plenty of other Peruvian restaurants with much better service. Too bad...but it's probably not a big deal to the restaurant since they get plenty of tourists.
author: Karen G.

description:
A vendor was visiting SF and wanted to take us to lunch. I chose La Mar as I had heard great things and I walk by everyday on my way to the Sausalito Ferry. 

In a nutshell, the Ceviche is elegant, and unlike Mexican style which I make at home, it is bathed in leche de tigre. In fact the sauce is pervasive so it becomes generic and boring. The Empanadas/sampler were moist and tasty! Pisco sours are excellent and I had Pinot which was nice, as it should be at $18 a glass.

But check this out. I asked 3 times for another glass of $18 wine. Our waiter basically disappeared. Another guy showed up with a dish we ordered and I finally got him to bring my vino. We were out on the deck, nice day so the interior was basically empty. It was not swamped with customers by any means. We 3 had all worked as waiters at various stages of our lives and are sympathetic to the profession. So this mystery waiter shows up again and says, "Ya want anymore food?" Nope, just the check, $268 for 3 people and ROTTEN SERVICE! Our hostess mentioned she always tips 20% but gave 18% which was a friggin GIFT!!

Later that day I spoke with a manager at a place I frequent and asked if he had eaten at La Mar. "My wife and I walked out. We went to the bar and ate there, the waiters suck.

Another person overheard us, "I haven't gone in two years. Last time I was there I told the waiter, if I wanted to be ignored I would still be with my husband." LOL

Go to the bar, get a Pisco and a Cebiche ($19) and then go down the road to Fog City happy hour for $4 fish tacos that are killer!
author: Carl K.

description: My partner got a stomach bug after eating at this place. I am very disappointed since we paid $410 for dinner.
author: Daniel L.

description: What a fantastic dining experience! We had the Ceviche sampler, the Causa sampler & the empanada sampler. This is the first place my husband ever tried ceviche several years ago & he's had a thing for it ever since, which I didn't quite understand until I had ceviche at La Mar! So fresh, in bright, flavorful sauces. The Causa were delicious & packed with flavor, served cold. The empanada were not greasy for fried food. The corn & the chicken were the favorites. The mushroom empanada was a little strange as far as flavor. We didn't actually get a mushroom taste at all, and we are both big mushroom fans. We had the tres leches for dessert. It was delicious but small for the price, about $13. Overall a delicious meal in a nice atmosphere. We were seated inside, but the tables outside near the water looked especially enjoyable. The service was good except that our waiter brought us dessert menus & didn't come back for about 15-20 minutes. I would definitely return on a future trip to SF!
author: Andrea R.

description: Came here for a date night with my boyfriend. We were seated in a crappy area near the kitchen ( felt like a sardine being cramped in there) but the food was good. The Tiradito Nikei and La mar were amazzzzing. The causa Limena not soo much, it was like eating baby food. Our cocktails also lacked alcohol, tasted like I was drinking juice ( supposedly a margarita).We opted to order a bunch of small plates and order them over a period of time, waiter seemed annoyed. I agree with other yelpers, that the staff was constantly buzzing around. A bit too much.  Still a cool place in the end if you're looking for a nice date spot.
author: Ashley O.

description:
Hook yourself up for some awesome flavors from Peru.  Get in early book a table for you and your best friends. Start with cerviche samplers, follow it with some drinks from the bar.  Move on to sampler of empanadas.  Everything is flavorful and colorful. Service is great.  Everyone is happy to help give you suggestions and bring you more liquor!

You don't need a big group, 2 is just fine. More the merrier though so you can taste it all. 

Plenty of light indoor seating and out. Open kitchen , feel the heat off the open flame from the stove.  

Background music just subtle enough to hear your party....
author: Brian W.

description: Service is excellent, ambiance is amazing! The food is amazing, but the lomo saltado was a little too salty and would have preferred some more rice with the meal. Don't expect to pay less than $100 for two people. Other than that we had a great time and definitely recommend.
author: Angie F.

description:
Yummy! We stumbled upon this place a couple years ago and have been coming back ever since! They just revamped the menu and it's even better. I recommend the beef empanadas and any of the meats! Everything was tasty and filling. Their sauces are to die for! We have to always get more! 

Highly recommend for a beautiful lunch along the water. Try to sit outside on the terrace if available
author: Shelby L.

description:
You may eat out a lot more than me so let me know what you think.
I had the pleasure of going to La Mar for dinner last night.
It was wonderful!
I arrived a little bit early and the host promptly signaled to a staff member to take me to the table. As I walked through the restaurant, there were a lot of very well dressed men saying "Welcome" to me.
The table had a fine view of the entire restaurant and also looked out to the covered patio (through glass windows).
The table had bright Aqua-colored woven chairs and place settings that looked perfect.
My first instinct told me that this was a good place. The waiter popped over and asked if we wanted to order drinks. Very prompt.
Our table had a tin container with plantain and potato chips and two sauces for dipping. You weren't made to wait for a snack before ordering.
When the rest of the party arrived, the waiter returned to inquire about drinks for them. Once dispatched, we all perished the menu (also in beautiful blue Aqua color) to choose from causas (appetizers with potatoes), ceviches (seafood with citrus or other marinade), empanadas (savory turnovers), the main entrees & sides.
There was so much to choose from everyone could be satisfied. Meat and seafood and vegetarian-food lovers rejoice.
We had delicious beef empanadas to begin the meal. These were very flavorful and slightly crisp.
For mains, I had a grilled seafood with aji sauce that came out on an iron platter. One person had tender short ribs and the other two had arroz la mar (seafood paella).
Everything was wonderful!
Lastly, we decided to share a passion fruit mousse dessert (since we're sharing people).
The waiter surprised us with a dish with an adorable profiterole with drizzled chocolate   sauce and fresh raspberries.
What a nice way to end the meal.
It's been a while since I've experienced fine dining to this level here in San Francisco.
It was a beautiful meal and a beautiful experience. If you haven't had a chance to visit La Mar, go immediately. It made my day and it will certainly make yours too.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Whoa, the food.

After a few hours of flying and a layover, I was ready to chow down and La Mar did not disappoint. They bring you a bucket of chips and dipping sauce which I could have seriously had as a meal but the star was the causas sampler and ceviche platter. Being a novice to Peruvian food, I had no clue what causes was but soon found out its a potato of sorts with whipping meat or topping. Ummm yeah, I was game. The sampler is the way to go! There was Dungeness crab, chicken, tuna and beet, all were flavorful except the beet and the tuna was the winner with the little kick of spice it had. 

Cebiche platter was perfect because it gave you a nice variety to try like halibut, ahi tuna, yellow tail and octopus (my fave) and shrimp and scallops. This was enough for two of us and we left happy and full, glowing after a healthy meal! They close at 10pm even on a Friday night which I found a little odd. Be prepared to get up close and personal with the diners next to you, I felt like I was on a first date with the table to my right, I hope those kids make it!
author: Tiffany N.

description:
La Mar was one of my favorite happy hour spots in San Francisco for the past 5 years. Whenever anyone asked me for happy hour suggestions, La Mar was one of the first ones I spit out. But not anymore, and it truly breaks my heart to say that. I have so many great happy hour memories at La Mar. I'm sad that it won't be my go-to spot any longer. 

I came on a Saturday at about 3:30 PM with my husband about 5 weeks ago (a little late updating this review) and sat down to the only 2 empty seats at the bar. The spot we sat at was dirty, still uncleaned from the previous customers. Empty glasses, crumpled cocktail napkins and wetness. Not a huge deal- bars get busy. But after sitting there for 10 minutes and not being acknowledged, and not having the mess cleaned up, it was a little annoying. I grabbed a happy hour menu from the lady next to me only to see that the prices have really gone up on their happy hour. The little cebiches that used to be $6 are now $9. The pisco sours price went up as well. The causa limena, my favorite item on the HH menu was no longer there, nor was the chicharrón de pollo, another one of my faves. It appeared that the HH menu got smaller and the prices got bigger. Irritated about the new, sad HH menu, I realized we had now sat at the dirty bar for 15 minutes still without acknowledgment. I should mention that the bartenders and bar backs weren't too busy. The bar was full but the staff seemed to be focused on doing the duties that typically take place before a bar opens or when no one is ordering anything, in addition to chatting with the servers at the pick up window. I had become well acquainted over the years with a few of the bartenders at La Mar and didn't see one of them. Maybe they all left for better pastures...
I was pretty mad about my wonderland shitting on me, so I told my husband that I wasn't dealing with it, and we got up and left, still without even a look from the bar staff. I haven't been treated that shitty ANYWHERE in a really long time. I was simultaneously sad and angry. Despite this review, I actually plan on going back to La Mar for happy hour one more time, to see if maybe, MAYBE, I came on a day when the entire bar staff was new, and someone accidentally printed up a small overpriced menu. Because if you check their website, the causa limena and chicharrón de pollo are still on the HH menu. I hope to report back with good news, but I have a hunch that La Mar and I might officially be over.
author: Liz M.

description:
The server was very knowledgeable and explained the dishes well. 

The food was good, presentation was awesome!
author: Shelly C.

description:
Let me get right to it.  The star of the show was the grilled octopus.  I highly recommend.  The texture and flavor were spot on with just the right chewiness and no overwhelming taste from the octopus.  I was so incredibly happy from just this one dish. 

The mushroom empanada had a tomato based sauce that was delicious.  It was like a high end hot pocket, which is a compliment.  Unfortunately, the chicken and beef versions were okay in comparison - the chicken was dry and the sauce with the beef wasn't my favorite.  I also ate those after the octopus, so that could have been a significant source of bias. 

I also tried the chicha morada, a traditional purple corn drink.  It is essentially a juice with an interesting aftertaste; I liked it.  My date ordered a steak with grilled vegetable dish, the lomo saltado if I'm not mistaken.  The meat was well cooked and the dish was all around flavorful.  There was a dessert somewhere too, but I was probably wishing it was octopus.

Ambiance is nice.  The restaurant itself is big and well decorated and with just the right Latin music in the background.  Service was friendly and attentive.

I'd come again, if only for the grilled octopus.
author: Emily Y.

description: I was disappointed mainly because I tried this place a few times and it had been always great. This time everything was different, from the food, lomo Soltado came with half meat and double potatoes. Their cold kitchen got closed before we even ordered food and we weren't notified ahead. Drinks were all sugary and watery.  There were mice running under the tables!! And lastly, it was my friend's birthday and I secretly mentioned to the waitress but she forgot
author: Omid A.

description: Off night dining brought me to this place ... Been wanting to try this place for a few. Friendly atmosphere and set off but busy ... Hardly saw my server ... Maybe cause I'm alone and in the bar . Ordered the yucca croquette and lomo ... The yucca croquette came cold ... But the flavor was spot on perfectly seasoned and the sauce was complimentary . The lomo I could cut with the knife that's how tender it was ! The sauce /gravy is ok . Over all impression : average . Confusing tho that it had Japanese things in the Peruvian menu ... I must be missing something . Must try but don't have high expectations
author: Gretchen J.

description:
So this is where we came for our first day at work. We had been training in San Francisco and they took us to a nice restaurant for lunch. 

The location is excellent, and for the most part the service was pretty good, too. The server however was a bit odd and not necessarily the most attentive or on par-with our interests, despite it being pretty slow. But even then, he was good at what he does, and thats serve. 

We ordered several ceviche appetizers--and wowza, by far my favorite part of the meal. Oh and also the empanadas, the empanadas were on freakin' point! My favorite was the mushroom, total noms. 

I got a fried fish sandwich, which, despite the fact that I speak decent spanish, I did not realize was actually a sandwich nor fried until I received the dish. Overall, it was average at best. 

Honestly, I should give this a 4 stars. And I may decide to change my mind, especially if I visit again. However, that is very unlikely seeing as how expensive this place is. Still, check it out if you're in the area for lunch.
author: Erin J.

description:
When you walk in to Cebicheria la Mar, you think that you are about to eat something delicious in the great tradition of the Muchik civilization in the Noth of Peru, the ones who invented cebiche.  The fish stare at you from displays, everything "looks fresh" and delicious....  But then you look around at the guests....these people do not look Peruvian (well, they look like folks on Peruvian tv). I  ordered razor clams out of nostalgia for my father who grew up eating them on a tiny island in Maine. I asked for a "tiradito," which is a kind of cebiche in yellow causa sauce. They said they could only fry them in butter. Bad sign.  They did not say: these are frozen and cannot work in cebiche.  We ordered a basic cebiche de pescado.  It had that horrible ingredient that destroys your appendix by tenderizing it:  ajinomoto, or monosodium glutimate.  Cebiche only is delicious if the fish is exceptionally fresh.  We mistakenly ordered a jalea.  This is fish that has been breaded and deep fried.  It is where the fish goes that is the least fresh.  AVOID it like the plague.  Puerto Norte or la Choza Nautica--where the Peruvians eat cebiche--are MUCH BETTER. 
 In the end nothing was fresh.  And we paid through the nose.  And we continued to pay all night long as we became sick from eating fish that was not fresh.
author: Loo L.

description:
Very authentic and extremely well presented. 
As a Peruvian I feel proud of this place. The food is very very good and elegant!
author: Augusto R.

description:
I had the pleasure of coming to La Mar last weekend for my boyfriend's mom's birthday dinner and I can honestly say this was one of the top 5 meals I have ever had in my life (and believe me, I've eaten a lot of really good meals, haha).

The location is excellent, right on the water on Embarcadero, easily walkable from BART and the Pier 1.5 building that houses the restaurant is unique and interesting. The waitstaff was fantastic and very knowledgeable--he was able to give us some great suggestions. 

We started with the Mixto Ceviche (yellowtail, calamari and shrimp), Causa Limeña (whipped potato towers with dungeness crab and quail egg), and the Tiradito Passion (salmon sashimi with aji amarillo passion fruit). All of the appetizers were amazing . The ceviche and tiraditos were some of the best I've ever tasted--so fresh and so many different flavors and textures that all came together perfectly.

For my main course, I chose the Salmon La Mar, at our waiter's recommendation (I couldn't decide between that and the Pasta Criollo until he said the Salmon La Mar was his personal favorite dish). This dish was salmon, shrimp, broccoli, bok choi, cauliflower, mushrooms, peruvian red chiles, and coconut milk. It was SO GOOD I can't even describe the full deliciousness of this dish. Everything was cooked to perfection and the flavors were out of this world. I can see why it was our waiter's favorite! Definitely one of the best seafood dishes I have ever eaten and like nothing I'd ever eaten before.

As if we hadn't already eaten enough amazing food, we just had to try some dessert. We chose the Choco-Maracuya (layered passion fruit mousse, raspberry compote, chocolate mousse, and almond praline). It was the perfect dessert, not overly sweet but very satisfying. The passion fruit mousse really added something to it that made it not your typical chocolate dessert. 

Obviously, don't come here if you are looking for a cheap meal. This isn't a place we could eat at all the time, but its great for special occasions or that nice meal everyone once in a while. I hear they have a good Happy Hour which I would love to check out one day for some smaller, lower-priced bites.

If you are considering eating at La Mar, DO IT! You won't be disappointed :)
author: Erica M.

description: I need to stop going into restaurants with such high expectations -- the food was good, but it wasn't great. Did I miss the memo that the food would be Peruvian-inspired? Because it was, at best. Everything I've ever ordered in traditional Peruvian restaurants was just ok (ceviche and lomo saltado), whereas there were some incredibly tasty, non-traditional dishes such as the grilled swordfish with quinoa (wait what?) and the roasted cauliflower. I don't love Fresca or Limon, but I liked them better than La Mar.
author: Jane L.

description: I wandered into this place at 5:30 PM on a Thursday. The bar was super crowded, due to happy hour, so I sat at the sushi bar. I ordered the swordfish dish, which had an egg on it, potatoes and zucchini. The fish, itself, was small, and overcooked. The potatoes were really good, and the egg was an interesting addition. While the service was impeccable, I'd say the food was just okay. But, it's a cool spot, with cool bay views if you can get a window or patio seat.
author: Amanda W.

description:
I had my wedding reception on Saturday here. I'm not 100% happy with how La Mar has so much communication problems within the company but I'm giving 4 stars because they did try to make up for their mistakes. 
They threw away my whole wedding cake that I really wanted to pick up so they said they will send me a check. 
The management didn't give clear instruction to their staff so they were setting up everything wrong so I had to pay extra to my coordinator for setting up the table when he suppose to be there to just give them guidelines. 
They wanted to kick us out ASAP so they asked our guests if they can take the dishes away while they are literally putting food in their mouth. 
Although they did agree that we can pick up our stuff (tablecloth and etc.) tomorrow but their staffs were asking us to take it with us while we are walking out. 
Not to mention, I'm missing several tablecloth. 

But why four stars? 
Again, they did their best to make up for their mistakes and the venue was beautiful. Price was reasonable and food tasted really good.
author: angie s.

description:
I've always been curious about the culinary work of Gastón Acurio, and was delighted when some family friends invited me to eat here. We ordered a good variety from the menu: causa, cebiche clásico, empanada de lomo saltado, and anticucho de carne. To top it off, I also ordered an Inca cola, a kind of banana flavored soda. 

I was not surprised that most of the dishes featured potato and corn, staples of Peruvian cuisine. The corn kernels were very large, about the size of a nickel, and seemed to be imported (I have never seen them in the Bay Area before). They start you off with a mix of house made potato and banana chips with two dipping sauces, which were very rich. The causas were spectacular; the acidity was well-balanced with the creaminess of the crab and avocado. The cebiche was my favorite dish -- the onions and citrus complimenting the halibut tartar. The empanadas were crispy, but not outstanding compared to the previous two dishes. The carne was reverse-seared and was very tender.

This place had a great ambience featuring light blue accents and a view of the SF bay right from the embarcadero. Service was also quick and friendly. Upscale yet casual, and a great spot for celebrating a special occasion.
author: Ishan K.

description:
peruvian zombe,,chicha morada,luca m,causa veggy,empanada k'apchi,cau limena,quinoa salad,choco maracuya,queso helado

2nd time:
Called in ,booked and went in straight in 20 min.
Went just before evening twilight .
Sat along side beautifully rolling SF waters and gorgeous boats.
Ordered Chica morada,mango picoso,mr.bogart 

in main course introduced to quinoa obsessed items lien Verdure nikei,quinoa solterito,quinoa caprese,quinoa chaufa based in friends request.So glad we got them.

Finished off with a nice treat of tres leches.
author: Priyanka L.

description: Located near Ferry Building and you would think it's a touristy place..but no! I'm so glad I chose to dine here and was very impressed. The food our waiter recommended was superb: the crab causa, choclo empanada (sweet corn filling) and the arroz con calamares-which is amazing! Those squid was so tender and the salmon-filled squid was something I've never tasted before. The waiters and managers were all very attentive and friendly, the ambiance was very cozy and fancy at the same time. Definitely coming back to try more.
author: Leslie Y.

description:
My favorite Peruana restaurant. 

Expensive but the food is excellent. The presentation is also excellent. 

The ambiance is upbeat, well lit, and energetic. Great backdrop with piers, Bay Bridge, and Hornblower. 

The service is excellent right down to the chopsticks and service ware.
author: Ish A.

description:
Love the ambiance and the food was incredibly tasty, but I gave this place 3 stars because for the price of the items, you're not receiving a good amount of food!

We ordered the ceviche sampler and I ordered a causa nikei thinking it would hold me over but I had to order their Quinoa entree after because it wasn't enough grub.

As for drinks, their pisco punch is good!
author: Michelle C.

description:
This is a tough review to write because the food was exceptional. We had two kinds of causas, the cebiche clasico, anticucho de carne, salmon tiradito, lomo saltado and the halibut. With the exception of the salmon tiradito which was just about average and the lomo saltado which I found a tad on the small side given the price, the food tasted wonderful. All the flavors came together nicely and were exactly what I'd expect. I've eaten at some very fine Peruvian restaurants both in the states and in Peru and I can safely say that a few of La Mar's dishes ranked up there with the best.

With that said, the rest of the dining experience was a total miss in my book. In the bar which sits adjacent to the dining area, there was an extraordinarily loud party of sorts going on with a mariachi band and dancing. This would have been fine had there been a door between the bar and the restaurant, but there wasn't. I found myself having to yell to communicate with other people sitting at my table. Totally unacceptable and unprofessional in my book.

Second, the bathrooms. There are only two small ones near the entrance and they were absolutely repulsive. Also frankly quite unacceptable both in terms of size and cleanliness.

Third, the wait staff. While the waiters and waitresses were all pleasant enough, nobody came to check in with us as to how the food was during the meal. On top of this, I would expect a bit more professionalism (opening doors for the ladies, letting guests walk through crowded areas first) from a wait staff at a restaurant that purports to be a fine dining establishment.

I'd like to say I'd be coming back, but the experience didn't feel like it was worth the amount of money it costs to eat there.
author: Dev B.

description:
3.5 however I am rounding up. When I knew that I would be in San Francisco on business I made it an absolute must to come here. I'm a huge fan of Gaston Acurio and his cuisine. Being from South Florida my wife and I frequent the La Mar in Miami. 

Walking in I was surprised with how big the restaurant actually was. The one back home is small. The hostess was friendly and got us checked in quickly.

While walking to the table I couldn't help but notice how nicely decorated the restaurant was. The restaurant was also very open which I like.

The menu is a good size with tons of options.

Roberto our server came by quickly to take our drink order. After he took the drink order his service began to get super slow. I actually felt like I was back in Lima again lol.

Yucca chips and sweet potato chips along with two dipping sauces were brought to the table. One of the sauces was huanciana and I can't remember what the other one was. Back home we just get the yucca chips and the huanciana sauce. I always devour them as you can't eat just one. Everyone at the table enjoyed them and couldn't stop eating them.
 

Roberto returned about 10 minutes later with the drinks. He went over a long list of specials and made recommendations. We ordered the empanadas de aji de gallina and the ensalada limena for the table to start with. For entrees two people had the Lomo Saltado and one had the Arroz La Mar.

The empanadas were awesome. They were lightly fried so they were chewy which I like. The sauce was good, however, I didn't find it to be spicy at all. Man the empanadas just melted in your mouth. 

The ensalada limena was good. The produce was super fresh. The vinaigrette had such a great flavor to it.

One of my colleagues and I both needed another drink. Roberto didn't come back by until we finished the salad and the empanadas. He didn't even offer us another drink we had to ask him for one.

The drinks were delivered by someone else this time and was done so quickly. 

As soon as the entrees were placed down on the table everyone got real quiet all of a sudden. The presentations were nice on the Lomo Saltados. The Arroz La Mar's presentation was beautiful though.

My Lomo Saltado was extremely bland and pretty much flavorless. I was disappointed with it.

My colleague loved her Lomo Saltado. I'm happier that hers was better than mine as it was her first experience with La Mar and Peruvian food.

My father absolutely loved the Arroz La Mar. He said that it was probably in the top 3 things that he had ever eaten. My father has been a foodie for a long time so that definitely means something.

For dessert we ordered the Pineapple Coconut ice cream. All I can say is that it was awesome. Each flavor just came together so well. There was also something at the bottom of the cup that was like a happy ending lol. I have absolutely no idea what it was but it was a great way to end the dessert. 

At the conclusion of our meal I had to flag Roberto down to request the check. It took a while for him to come back for the payment after he had dropped it off. In all honesty the service flow that he provided got to me. When I go out I want to enjoy myself and not be rushed, however, I certainly don't appreciate when the service is way too slow. This knocked a star off of my review. I deducted a half star for my entree being bland. I rounded up because the rest of the food was great. 

I found the prices to be very reasonable. We were out the door for under $100.00 a person

I will definitely come back here on my next trip to San Francisco. I just hope that the service will be better. Based on my visit here I definitely prefer Diego Oka's cooking at the La Mar in Miami more. Sorry I couldn't resist throwing that in there!!!!

I suggest that you stop by and try it for yourself.
author: Will G.

description:
Food is delicious but overpriced, as you'd expect from a place right on the Embarcadero. We asked the waiter to recommend the right number of small plates and he took the opportunity to upsell us a $50 special, so that left a bad taste in our mouths. So to speak.

If you want to splurge on waterfront dining with your out of town friends, this is the place. If you're local and just want good Peruvian good, go to Limon instead and save yourself a hundred bucks.
author: Chaney K.

description: The ceviches are the best I had in the Bay Area. The Leche  de Tigre for the different ceviche is the secret sauce that gives the ceviches its unique flavor.  I recommend the California and the Classico ceviche. A great prime location right by the Embarcadero waterfront . I would skip dessert.
author: Juan V.

description:
Yesterday, I had to the opportunity to try La Mar Cebicheria Peruana. It's located next door to the Ferry Building. I was able to garner a great parking space across the street and arrived at 5:40 pm just in time for Happy Hour. Since, we were going to the Giants vs Red Sox at 7 pm we decided to just stay at the bar for Happy Hour. We found seats at the crowded Bar and ordered right away. 

Mixed Seafood Ceviche  3/5 stars It came in a small rice bowl only half way filled. A
                                                             little fishy smelling and taste. a few bits of corn and
                                                             shredded red onions in a yellow sauce

Fish Ceviche (leche Tigre) 4/5 stars much cleaner and fresher taste not fishy. A few
                                                                 kernels of corn and shredded red onion

Chicken Thighs  4/5 stars the largest portion of the night at least filled the small rice
                                               bowl, tasted good but had a lot of gristle. shredded red 
                                               onion

Fried Calamari   3/5 stars run of the mill fried calamari still tiny portion shredded red
                                               onion

Lomo Empenadas 5/5 stars The best dish and only one that does not come in a 
                                                     small rice bowl and shredded red onion

The bar was packed, only a few servers in the bar area, waited for drinks and food. Bill including 1 beer before tip $36.
author: George F.

description:
This restaurant was highly rated as a great Peruvian Restaurant. It was on my list of restaurants to try. I must say I was disappointed. The ambience is enviable, 
the food...not so much. 
The Empanadas were OK, but too small to be considered a true dish. 
The best dish was the Plantain Chips and the delectable dip. Their signature drink
did not delight the palate and was void 
of any punch. I'm glad I tried it, but will
spend my dollars & search for Peruvian fare elsewhere next time.
author: Kae V.

description: I have been here a couple of times now for work dinners and every time has been wonderful.  The drinks are so tasty and the service is great.  The ceviche has always been loved by everyone.  I especially love the short ribs dish.  This past time I tried the lamb dish special which was also very good but the short ribs are definitely a winner.  This place has become one of my favorites in the city.
author: Amanda K.

description: Flavor with a view. They worked some kind of magic on that octopus. I ordered the Pulpo and recommend that you do, too. Marinated and grilled, the skin is smokey and crisp and inside is almost creamy. Seasoned perfectly and served with smashed potatoes and greens. Flavors were fresh and clean with delicious spiciness. Can't wait to go back and work my way through the menu. Sat outside on a stellar day. Excellent attentive and friendly staff.
author: Jen F.

description: This is absolutely the most gorgeous restaurants in SF. Its house cocktail is also amazing. must try pisco sour
author: Nancy W.

description: I was conflicted on what to giving star-wise...I'm giving the biggest knock on the cost vs portions. Do not get me wrong, I'm completely turned off my huge portions but almost equally turned off by minuscule portions with large price tags. I'm specifically speaking on the lomo saltado - I believe it was $34....the flavor of the sauce, the veggies & rice were delish...the beef was 4 pinky-finger-sized pieces of overcooked meat. Flavor was fantastic just over cooked & a laughable portion. We joked it was the most expensive bowl of veggies we've ever had. The quinoa salad was great, great blend of flavors. We also enjoyed the tuna Cebiche. Wines by the glass were fairly limited & pretty pricey. Loved the outdoor space & the indoor dining room had a great vibe. Overall enjoyed the food, but felt it wasn't worth the cost.
author: L M.

description:
Although it is a bit pricey, love this restaurant. Food was amazing! Queso helado as a dessert is delicious. I just removed one start duo to the staff. The waiter was rude all the time and not interested to serve us.

Update 2 months later - I arrived there around 4pm on Sunday asking for a table for 2. The rude staff said that only the bar was open and then she just left without even asking if we would like to have a sit on the bar! Then a couple behind us gave up for the same reason: the woman just ignored them as well. I am really amazed how they are so impolite. 

Update 4 months later - we finally got a nice waiter. We got causa limeña, empanada sampler, salmón fusión and lomo saltado. Everything was amazing.
author: Roberta T.

description: We really liked this place for several reasons. Been here before and the food was good. Drinks are very tasty and the cocktail menu is very inventive. Small plates and empanadas are fantastic. So are the ceviches, really good. But sadly on the last trip there were a few fails. You can usually tell the sign of a bad server when he or she immediately try to up sell you on everything. Straight to the most expensive ceviche sampler for $69. Then the two most expensive entrees each at $36 and $49. Unfortunately on this trip I fell for the up sell with the Plancha Marina dish with Prawns, calamari, catch of the day, seasonal vegetables, aji pancaand lime for $36. It tasted like a whole lot of veggies quickly stir fried in a mediocre and simple red sauce with two prawns, one small piece of fish and a LOT of super rubbery calamari. So rubbery that after the first two bites I ate the prawns, the veggies and the fish and pushed the rubbery calamari aside. The sauce was very plain with very little layering of flavors at all. Next time I'll go back and order ceviche and empanadas at the bar with a tasty cocktail and I'll be much happier. And you will like this place too by avoiding the main dining room up sell servers and overpriced chewy seafood entrees. Stick with what they know best, cocktails and small plates.
author: SFCAFOX S.

description: Omg ceviche! The classic ceviche is by far the best! I had the tasting platter, but wish I'd had more of the classic. I love the giant Peruvian corn kernels that appear in almost every dish. The norteño rice dish was unbelievable! So good. Don't eat shrimpface. We had tres leches for dessert but i wish is was wetter. Free glass of champagne for our anniversary, and great staff. Definitely worth a visit here if you like seafood and Peruvian cuisine. We ate outside and asked for a blanket as it got chilly. Beautiful view of the harbour.
author: Mimi M.

description:
This restaurant made my trip in San Francisco!  My BF and I are 1st-timer in SF and my BF said he heard about this restaurant as we walked pass by, so we decided to give it a try.  Boy did we know little about this restaurant!  It's got airy and spacious environment; I like it's high ceiling!  There are indoor eating area and out door--the outdoor area is covered and heated so it's pretty comfy despite the cold wind from the sea.

Our waiter is very attentive and friendly.  He offered to explain the menu since there are so many words that I'm not familiar with; saved both of us from embarrassment.  He also made few suggestions on how he liked the dishes, so we decided quite fast what to order.  We ended up ordering California Cebiche, Pulpo (grilled octopus leg), Arros La Mar, a specialty cocktail Spring Frizz and 2 deserts.  California cebiche & Pulpo together should be enough for a woman but definitely not enough for a big guy.  However, the taste of them are just GREAT!!!  My BF and I was really impressed by the the juicy, grilled smoky smell, and the tenderness of the octopus leg; the taste exploded in my mouth!!  I have never taste an octopus leg like this!!  Arros La Mar is also fabulous!  Each quinoa is soaked with the seafood sauce and I cannot have enough of it!
 
We were a bit unsatisfied after eating all 3 plates because its portion runs a bit small, so we decided to go for desert.  I'm so glad that we made that decision.  Desert is sooooooo good!!  I don't know what the Chef did but he definitely rocked my plates!  I would totally recommend getting desert after your main course.  You will not regret!  And somehow we both are very full after our desert.
  
We ended up spending $160 for 3 plates, 2 desert and 1 cocktail drink (tax & tip incl.).  I say totally worth it!
author: CiCi H.

description: A friend in the city recommended this place to us. I called for a reservation but they were having a private party on a Saturday night. It is located at Pier 3 and a good idea to either walk down there or to grab an uber. We all decided to take a stab at getting a table in the bar on the fly. Have to say, we got lucky! We grabbed a high top in a cozy corner of the bar. They are heavy when it comes to pisco which is a peruvian brandy. I tried one with grapefruit but it was still a bit too sweet. The clasico was great. fish with red onion, habanero, corn and sweet potato. The Mixto with fish shrimp calamari octopus in rocoto leche de tigre was delish. The Nikei was ahi red onion japanese cucumber daikon avocado nori in a tamarind leche de tigre was was incredible. These are all cebiches as they call them. We had the Kaisen with snow crab and uni which was incredible. The Kanpachi with Hawaiian Aberjack red onion, tobiko in this yummy dressing. Our waiter Paul was so great, he was so attentive and replaced my cocktail for me an made me a perfect one. They have these purple potato that is in some of the dishes and they are worth trying. Very tasty, I'd love to make them at home. The Yuzu in some of the dishes if you have never had it is a bit slimy in texture with a potato like bite. If you are in the city, I think you'd be remiss if you did not come to have a meal here. They are light so you can mix an match an share and not get full.
author: Valerie M.

description: Great service.  Great sauces.  Good variety.  Menu too big in my opinion.  Lively atmosphere.  Definitely would recommend for a good meal.
author: Jeremy R.

description: We were outside on the covered deck - warm but very, very noisy. Very delicious cebiche mixto (fish, shrimps, calamari, and octopus) and causa limeña (crab, avocado, salmon caviar, and quail egg). We then had anticucho pollo and arroz con calamares -  grilled salmon-stuffed squid served over wok-fried squid-inked rice. Best pisco sours we've had in the US and some plantain chips - no room for dessert but the tres leche looked great.
author: Greg M.

description:
Growing up, I stayed at my friend's house when my parents were AWOL. Her mom made the best ceviche and when hispanics make ceviche, they make TUBS of it. I would go to town on it with a bag of tortilla chips. 
Now that my friend lives far away, having a cebiche addiction is not good for my wallet!

Wanting to give this highly acclaimed spot a fair review, I made sure to try lunch, dinner, and finally happy hour before writing.

My SFRW lunch was just alright. Neither my friend nor I liked the Parihuela; the sauce did not bode well with the clams or fish. The mediocre quinoa salad was saved by the goat cheese and I ate it out of obligation. I I enjoyed the coconut and raspberry sorbet the most. We also shared the Cebiche Mixto-highlight of our meal.

For dinner I'm glad my friend ordered the lomo saltado to share. It's tender, juicy, and wonderfully flavorful. My causa limeña reminded me of a crab louie except with potato. Very creamy and savory. You also get a basket of their awesome plaintain/yucca/potato chips with dinner. They're my favorite chips, ever! You have to pay 5 bucks for them during HH though.

Happy Hour is the BEST + trumped both my meal experiences. We biked from Sausalito and were in dire need of a drink (or many) before hopping back on the train. Drinks are 6-7 and ceviche is 8 during HH, 3-6pm (every day!)
We tried the pisco punch, sangria, bourbon buzz, blue mule, and pisco sour. My favorite was the bourbon buzz but they're all very tasty and STRONG to boot! 
My girl ordered the Cebiche Clasico and Chalaco and ate every last morsel of food from their endearing fish-decorated bowls.

I wish they'd improve the restaurant week menu to include some of La Mar's popular items. Although getting a salad, entree, and dessert for $25 during lunch + $40 dinner is a good value, it doesn't make much sense if the food is not memorable. Some of the dishes from the normal menu are delicious but definitely overpriced. You're also paying for the sleek, spacious location on a beautiful waterfront.

That being said they do have amazing cebiche and happy hour, so that's what I'll be back for ;D
author: Jenny Q.

description: My wife and I used to love coming to this restaurant, we first came here and the "host" told us we had to seat in the bar because the kitchen was closed they never told us that the kitchen was going to be open in 10 MINS, the waiter rarely came to our table, he took the wrong order and we waited for almost an hour to place our order, food finally came, was horrible. This restaurant was nothing like it used to be before. Don't waist your time nor your money coming here.
author: Carlos O.

description:
So incredible.  Will take tourists in from out of town here all the time.
Amazing wine selection and food and service.
author: Laura W.

description: Great restaurant. Large and roomy right on the water. The Peruvian menu, with lots of seafood was creative, nicely presented and showcased cuisine from that part of the world. We asked for seconds of the plantain and potato chip basket they give in place of bread--the dip was amazing. We had the white tuna Peruvian sashimi plate, the empanada sampler and quinoa salad. The cocktails were a yummy complement to the meal.
author: Bev M.

description:
Has  a nice decor , unfourtunately   They do not serve autentic Peruvian food. Sorry.

The atmosphere is nice if You seat at the patio especialy by sunset or on full moon night.

It is noisy when is crowed. I must say the pisco sour and the picarones are amaizing
author: Daniela L.

description:
Dear Chef,

I was looking forward to dinner here...I actually only had a salad at hard water (adjacent) just so I could eat here - was so excited - and I made it a point to abandon my colleagues to come.

Oh goodness, chef. Your food is completely imbalanced.  I ordered the salmon dish with avocado crema. Sent back.  Balance the goddamn citrus please.  I had instantaneous heartburn from the acidity.   It was replaced with some ahi tuna with taro or orange yuca or some starch nightmare. I ate the tuna (because well I was hungry)...the rest.  Well gross.
 
Had some absurdly overpriced chef special main dish - apparently it's so good that they had to call it out as a specialty. Some river white fish. Such high expectations. They served it with a lime based broth horrific tasteless quinoa.  Inedible.  I had 2 bites and they had them take it away.  I paid nearly $60 for food that they told me was elevated street food.  And I ate 5 bites total. Food from the streets - albeit in Jamaica, MX, India or China - is known to be affordable. Of course in SF it was about 50x more than it should have been.  And not worth it. At. All. 

I ask you chef.  How would the street vendors in Peru feel about your 'elevated' food?  Insulted I'll say. You need to go back there and reflect on the true ways because your food is not reflective of the love, the passion the people and the knowledge of the sea or land...of family and of the indigenous culture. It celebrates nothing...not the air, the mountains...the diversity, nothing. 

And (I truly laugh out loud) when I ask about your 'elevated' prices.  Honestly, this food taste and price is nothing reflective of Peru. There is no "taking it to the next level".  Matsuhisa in LA kicks your fucking ass - and their ingredients deserve the price elevation...and they are ****!!!

I was so upset and disappointed.  It actually hurts my feelings what happened tonight.  My takeaway: retrench.  Go back and learn your roots.  And reflect upon what "elevate" really means when it comes to the food of a great country. 

My Best,
S.M.
author: S M.

description:
A M A Z I N G  L Y delicious!  
Enough said.
Place right by the ocean. Get any ceviche a pisco and anything else and you are set ! Enjoy
author: Helder D.

description: Ok this what happen today 3/10/18. The server Ardjan I believe that's his name . I ask him what would he recommend , so he recommend some crab dish that had a piece of a half crab leg , jalapeño, aji sauce that was $34 . He told me it's enough for 3 people so I said great ! I'll try it and we can share it . He said yeah great for sharing . When the plate arrived it was 1 big plate with almost nothing in it!!!!!! I was thinking there was more coming out because he said we can share nope !!! That was it. Wow ! Very unsatisfied for saying it was enough for 3 people and wasn't.  I felt ripped off!!!! If he would of told me it was small portions I would of order more plates and they would of made more money but I guess he was trying to get one good sell after being felt ripped off I didn't want anything anymore. The plate I'll give a 5 out of 10 . Where's the peru in that plate . This is a Peruvian restaurant right!
author: Saia F.

description: Came with a big group when my brother visited from out of town.  Ordered everything!  We all LOVED the food, and ate way too much.  You can't go wrong with this place.
author: Karen r.

description: Unexceptional and mediocre food. Priced especially for tourists. The decoration is nice enough but the cost of the food did not meet expectations of the other reviews. A dinner reservation is made and it was obvious the notes for the reservation were not read. Will not be recommending or visiting again.
author: Tiya T.

description:
Went for lunch yesterday and got to sit outside on their patio overlooking the water. Got to taste a variety of dishes and everything we had was delicious. I've been to the La Mar in Miami and this one seems to put more of a fusion twist on some of their dishes (probably because that's how SF is). I love Peruvian food and ever since I moved back from Miami, I haven't been able to find many good Peruvian restaurants in the Bay so I was happy to discover that the La Mar here is just as good as the one in Miami. 

The purple potato causa was amazing and was my favorite out of the 3 appetizers (also had a ceviche and a tiradito). Out of all the dishes I tried here, I actually liked the ceviche the least (that just shows how good everything else is). I was surprised to find out that at this location they have nigiris, but instead of using wasabi, they use Peruvian sauces and seasoning instead. No joke, they melt in your mouth. We also got a grilled octopus that was out of this world. It was extremely tender and perfectly cooked. It was a little on the salty side but the potatoes on the plate helped. We finished off with a maracuya mousse which was light and fluffy and a great choice if you like fruit and chocolate. Even though the portions are on the smaller side, I was full by the end of the meal but didn't feel weighed down or sluggish at all (because the food is so light and fresh!).

The service was amazing and every server took the time to explain each dish including how it was cooked and what ingredients went into making it. Our main server even shared some personal stories with us since he is originally from Peru. Thanks for a great dining experience, La Mar!
author: Al L.

description:
I love eating with folks who like to share, though this time was more likely because we weren't as hungry when we arrived at La Mar as we had hoped when making the reservation.

The complimentary potato and sweet potato chips with duo dips arrived late to the table.  In fact we had to inquire about them - fortunately one in our party was a repeat customer and so was aware of their absence - though I would consider that the sole service mishap.

cebiche mixto $16 (Catch of the day, calamari and shriimp in a aji amarillo leche de tigre with cilantro, red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam)

empanadas peruanas y frituras $11 (housemade and fried with a variety of fillings all served with dipping sauce); four pieces, each with a different filling.  Shell crisp, though not the best I've had, it was still pretty good

causa limena $14 (Dungeness crab on top of a yellow potato causa with avocado puree, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, aji amarillo huancaina sauce and basil cilantro oil); 2 dainty twin towers to the order with yummy potato holding up the fresh crab.  If you're seeking Dungeness crab, this has it, but it is not quite showcased as such.

causa nikei $14 (tuna tartar and avocado puree, on top of rocoto potato, with creamy rocoto huancaina sauce, topped with Japanese nori); 2 dainty twin towers to the order, tasty

lomo saltado $32 (Traditional Peruvian-style stir-fry of beef tenderloiin; sauteed with onions, tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce and garlic with fried potatoes and rice); a decent portion for a single diner, though I'm not quite sure it was $32 worth given the rather commonality of the ingredients

Their $36.95 Dine About Town pre-fixe was a tempting option as much of what we ended up ordering overlapped with option 1,  however our server led us to believe that the portions were adjusted for a single diner as well, which is why we opted to order a la carte and to share the dishes between us instead.
author: Vivian C.

description: Five stars for the bar!!! You must come here, at least once, to try the Pisco Sour and if you like your drinks sweet, then have the Pisco punch!  It's worth it! It's fantastic getting a buzz on something you've never had before!
author: Shannon F.

description: Food was good, cebiche was great and service was good.  I went on a weekday and it was packed, reservations recommended.  I feel like I have had better at other Peruvian places in the city, the hype is definitely there but I did t feel it.  The cocktails are well made, the bar gets a shout out.  It was good overall
author: Sebastien L.

description:
Don't bother trying to speak Spanish with the servers - most of them are gringos who don't understand a single word (silly me for trying). And if you happen to be a little chinky Asian girl, they might suggest chopsticks when you ask for something to eat the cebiche with (hello...chips!).

From a food perspective, the trick is to come here with just one other person to properly sample the cebiches soaked in amazing leche de tigre and mouth-watering small plates. Actually, I'd recommend not sharing and eating everything solo, but that would entail dining alone, which is pretty loser-ish. 

Some of my favorite dishes are: Cebiche Tasting, Empanada Sampler, Lomo Saltado, short ribs, and the most incredible of all, grilled PULPO!
author: Suany W.

description:
Happy hour: 3-6pm everyday
Service: 5 stars
Food: 2.5
Atmosphere: 3

I came to happy hour with my cousin around 4pm and didn't realize how packed it gets. It's understandable because it's very close to the financial district where coworkers like to unwind with a glass of cold beer (can't blame them). I myself preferred the sangria and to my surprise it was very fruity, which I liked very much. I'm not much of a seasoned drinker, so I tend to prefer alcoholic beverages with minimal alcoholic taste. But what impressed me more was definitely the service. I have to say that the service was nonstop and I felt like it was better than some five star restaurants that I've been to. The waiter was new, but it seemed like he knew what he was doing and he was very good at it.

As for the food, we ordered calamari, ceviche, croquettes and a slider (patty made with quinoa). The best was the ceviche but it wasn't the best ceviche I've had. It's moderately tasty at best. The calamari tasted like most calamaris I've tasted but nothing special. The slider was $6, which I think was overpriced for the size. It was not that great so I'm glad we didn't get 2. Finally, the croquettes were not good at all (in my opinion). We didn't even finish it because it just tasted like potato dipped in tempura batter. There was no taste and it tasted overwhelmingly like potato. I didn't like how unhealthy I felt afterward. The final bill was $40 which was okay but I expected better from the food.

Aside from the service, the atmosphere was not that great either. The DJ played blaringly loud music right behind us. And there were way too many people for the space-- it felt like we were past maximum capacity and if there was a fire, we would all be screwed. I don't think I would come back for happy hour but maybe for dinner because it looked like a beautiful view on the inside.
author: Brittany D.

description: Our group of 8 visited for lunch in March and had a wonderful experience.  Food is fresh and the menu is creative and lots to choose from! Plates are well presented, colorful and fres!  Service was outstanding.  I recommend sitting on the deck and the ceviche trio appetizer is amazing!
author: Michelle K.

description: Had not been here in a while because so many new restaurants these days! Decided it was time to go back, and especially after I ordered for my friends visiting a few weeks back who had a blast. The food is still as wonderful as I remember and the service is actually more attentive than my previous experience! So happy to have tasty cebiche and yummy causa, colorful dishes. Good wine did not hurt. Looking forward to going back!
author: Darlene B.

description: La Mar.....the infamous La Mar.  As a Peruvian gal I'm always on the hunt for good Peruvian food.  Authentic, delicious Peruvian food.  Heard so much about La Mar and went for my birthday.  Arrived during Happy Hour.  That's a win....on the downside they won't/don't serve dinner until 5:30pm.  So we sat down and I loved the ambiance and decor.  I thought the service was ok.  The happy hour menu...the drinks were great! The Pisco Punch was personal favorite.  Also tried the Pisco Sour and that too was delicious.  Tried the ceviche, the fish was good but was not impressed with the ingredients.  Everyone knows that the leche de Tigre (tigers milk) is the best part of Cebiche(Ceviche). It lacked that kick of spice and lime.  There was a few other types of small bites on the menu.  We tried the yuca with huancaina sauce...that was ok, tried the small plate of Jalea which was probably the best item on the menu.  Also got tacos, which were more Asian tasting but good.  It's unfortunate they weren't serving any real plates.  I would love to go back for lunch or dinner because I've heard nothing but great things about La Mar.  The drinks definitely made my dining experience worth while.
author: Adrianna P.

description: I have rarely experienced such slow and bad service. One person ordered a dish that came with 3 kinds of fish. He asked to leave out the octopus. It came with shrimp only. When he asked where the halibut was they said they would get it. This was after the server gave him a hard time and said that was due to how much halibut they had. This was the catch of the day and we were early diners!  The halibut came 30 minutes later and they charged us for it!  An order of bourbon on ice took 30 minutes the first time and 40 minutes the second time. This is supposed to be a nice restaurant with good service!  When we brought all of this to the attention of the manager she took the cost of one meal off the bill but still charged us for the halibut that was supposed to be part of that meal.  Too bad the service was beyond horrible because the food was very good. Never again!
author: Sharon L.

description: Fresh, great location and fantastic service. Loved the chance to dine here while visiting for our friends bday dinner.
author: Heather T.

description:
I made reservations for a Sunday afternoon and was seated promptly when we arrived. The first thing I noticed about this place was the blue theme. It reminds me of a resort I stayed at in Mancora, Peru, so it felt very authentic. 

La Mar had an assortment of complimentary chips consisting of plantain, sweet potato, and potato chips that were crispy and appetizing.

My girlfriend and I came for DAT, but we ended up ordering one DAT and the empanadas sampler. 

The appetizer was some mashed potato topped with pulled chicken, celery, avocado puree and tori sauce. There was also the cebiche clasico, fresh fish soaked in a classic leche de tigre with red onion, habanero, celery, cilantro, chocio, and camote. Both appetizers were served on the same place and had tiny portion sizes. I really loved the ceviche since the fish was soaked in a sour broth that really brought out the flavor. 

The empanadas sampler was next and it came with four different empanadas, beef, chicken, corn, and mushroom. The beef was mouth watering, the chicken was surprisingly flavorful, the mushroom had an overpowering taste, and the corn was just okay. 

The entree was the concohos marineras, steamed mussels and clams in some delicious broth that came with a side of rice. This was my favorite dish, and every spoonful of rice was soaked in the seafood broth. The light broth was definitely the best part of this dish although the mussels and clams were both well cooked.

The dessert was the raspberry and pear sorbet. I expected it to be sour, but the after taste left a hint of sweetness. 

After finishing all this food, I left very satisfied and my wallet wasn't too much lighter.
author: Edward W.

description:
I went to Peru a few years ago and asked locals to recommend the most authentic Cebiche that would certainly not get me sick and many people told me to go to "La Mar."

When I went there, they laughed at me because they said that the exact La Mar name exists in San Francisco! What the heck!

Now, La Mar has easily become one of my favorite happy hour spots along the Embarcadero. Their Pisco Sours, Sangrias, and wines by the glass are a bargain at $6/each during HH. They also have a good variety of snacks like their fried plaintains, empanadas, and of course Cebiche - during happy hour for a discounted price.

Their restaurant is also fantastic - absolutely wonderful for a date, business lunch/dinner, or group outing. The dining room itself and ambiance are elegant and upscale. They have a variety of Cebiche and traditional Peruvian dishes. Plan ahead and make a reservation for dine-in at the restaurant!
author: Veronica S.

description:
This place is so good! :) 

I went last night for a birthday dinner. I had the prickly pear margarita. BOMB! For starters I tried the tuna ceviche, shrimp and mushroom empanada. Everything was so fresh and the flavors were on point. For dinner I just had the carne skewers w/ veggies and potatoes. So good. Best steak ever! Perfect! 

Service was great too! The waiter knew everything on the menu and everything he suggested was good! :)
author: Teanna S.

description:
Pricey but definitely worth it. We came here after our Alcatraz night tour. We saw the sign before going to the tour. We were craving (more like, I was craving) for Peruvian place. I googled the place before going, and it said casual dress code. When we went there, people were all dressed up, while we looked like crap lol.

Anyways, grilled octopus was my favorite, along with the King crab bits. Not a fan of their ceviche. I've had plenty of ceviche when I went around central america so it was a disappointment. 

Other than that, I would definitely come back, dress nicely, and drink some Peruvian drinks ;)
author: Jennifer B.

description:
" Great Happy Hour Venue "

My wife and I met our Son and his friends over the Christmas Holidays at the La Mar Cebicheria Peruana Restaurant at Pier 1.5 Embarcadero in San Francisco. We went to the Happy Hour and later were suppose to go to Dinner. But the Happy Hour was so good, we just stayed in the Bar at a table for six and enjoyed the $6.00 drinks including our favorites, the Pisco Sour, and the Moscow Mule. We also had great Happy Hour Hors D'oeuvres for only $4.00 .We enjoyed multiple orders of La Mar's Beef, Chicken and Mushroom Empanadas. We also enjoyed Plantain Chips with Habanero dipping sauce, and enjoyed some seafood by eating chicharrón de calamar. All the Drinks and Food orders were very good. Nice up scale Bar and restaurant with very unusual and delicious Peruvian Food. Try their Happy Hour, I know you will be pleased !
author: David M.

description:
So, I'm thinking 1742 good reviews can't be wrong for a lunch recommendation.  Thank you, fellow Yelpers!

Located at the Embarcadero, Lar Mar is situated right between Pier 1 and 3, and the restaurant extends from street out to the harbor (ask for patio seating).  There's a bar in the front of La Mar for some people watching as well.

* complimentary sweet potato, plantain chips w/ 2 kinds of "mustard" dip
* Cebiche clasico [Halibut, red onions, habanero pepper "leche de tigre" with Peruvian corn & yam] = very fresh halibut, light but delish "leche de tigre" marinade!  
* Rollo Anticuchero [Dungeness crab, yellowtail, & avocado roll, sprinkled with sliced potato chips on top] = sushi cut rolls served on the heavier side due to its anticuchera-tartar sauce slathered atop...which is so effin' good!
* Pulpo anticucho [traditional skewer, octopus on top of whipped potato servings]
* Milanese de Mahi [panko-breaded mahi with rocoto aioli and salsa criolla, on ACME green onion bread]
* Pollo Anticuchero [grilled chicken breast, avocado, tomato, aioli, crispy sweet potatoes and goucha cheese on green onion ACME bread, with anticuchera sauce]

I enjoy the fact that they use local ACME bakery's bread for the sandwich dishes...it was soft, crunchy, and fresh!  Our server must've been new, he was nervous speaking the entire time but still great service overall.

WOA:
* Metered parking if you're lucky, or find parking lots on nearby streets
* Make ressies
* Great for weekend brunch!
author: Sandee T.

description:
While I've been to Peru, I didn't get a chance to try the ceviche while I was there. I was in San Francisco for a business trip and stumbled upon this little gem. This is definitely the best Peruvian food I've had outside of the country, and the whole experience was amazing from start to finish.

We started off with a Black Rumble cocktail and a traditional sweet Peruvian drink, chicha morada (purple corn juice mixed with sugar and other spices). The chicha morada took me right back to lunch in Lima, while the Black Rumble brought a freshness that perfectly complemented the cebiche clásico that I had for my entree. We finished the evening off with queso helado (a traditional dessert from Arequipa) and the best tres leches cake I've ever had.

Not only was the food on point, but the restaurant had a wonderful atmosphere that seemed (if this is even possible) to be intimate and open at the same time--and our server, Nick, was absolutely phenomenal. He had great recommendations on both the cebiche and the desserts, and we chatted about La Mar's sister restaurant in Chicago (Tanta) and some other great Chicago eateries.

Next time I'm in San Fran, I'm definitely coming back here--maybe I'll try the empanadas next.
author: Carolyn G.

description:
We hung out here at the bar before returning to the sunny side of the bar on our sailboat.  

I didn't try and of the food, apart from the fried snacks at the bar (pretty good, one sauce is vegan, one is not).  This is the kind of place you want to come for great bar service - snappily dressed bartenders, friendly, and know how to make their drinks.  The beer selection was a bit lacking, although I did try a passable Peruvian lagar (I generally have a low opinion of lagars).

This is somewhere I'd consider dining, although I didn't get a change to peer at the menu. Maybe next time I'm in the area.
author: Peter N.

description: The food was excellent.  Each dish has its own flavors and they look like a work of art. I was very impressed with the entire experience. The staff really knows the food and are committed to making your meal special. Thank you to Carlos and Jorge for their great service.
author: Alejandro B.

description:
Best Peruvian restaurant in San Francisco, and a fantastic place for happy hour.  It almost never disappoints.  

Best Lomo Saltado in the City, cooked with a perfect medium rare, and served with a great sauce over sweet tomatoes and fries.  Really probably the top dish in the house.  The ceviches here are also awesome, and hard to beat.

Overall, almost all of the food here is well executed.  I like the empanadas here, but would not recommend the sampler.  Stick with the beef and secondarily the chicken.

The wine here is reasonably priced, generally 2x market value.  And they have fantastic Spanish wines.

Top place for happy hour, really.  Just come here early, as the bar area packs up quick.
author: Mark M.

description:
**I was here for a catered professional event (but would recommend it regardless)**

Service: The staff was very friendly and accommodating. The bartenders were fantastic and really selling their cocktails. I tried the chiliana pisco  (the alcohol was illusive so watch out). Wines were decent to good. I liked the Pinot. 

Food: All the raw fish dishes were delicious. They tasted fresh and had a healthy amount of acid. Especially memorable was the tuna tartar on sweet potato. Yes, a strange combination but addicting. The restaurant seems highly Peruvian but with many asian elements (maybe there's a presence in Peru, no idea). Stay away from the meat dishes. They aren't bad but not great either. For kicks, someone at the table ordered the 'most expensive dish' which was short ribs for $34. Total miss as it was pretty standard braised meat and didn't have the same brightness as the other dishes.  Finally, you can probably pass on dessert (I had a duo of chocolate mousse/raspberry and a brown cake). I will give them credit for holding back on the sugar though.

Overall, great lively atmosphere even on a Tuesday night without being too crowded. The seafood was great.
author: Tammy T.

description:
Went over here during restaurant week. The place is nice, next to the pier. Has outdoor seating facing the waters. 
We were taken to our seats by a pleasant lady.

When the waiter came to take our order, we told him  we are here for the restaurant week special. I felt the waiter wasn't very happy when he heard that,  as after ordering he tells us the entrees are appetizer size and we may have to order more. I wasn't very happy with his attitude. 
But we stuck to what we had decided as we felt it would be too much. 
The food was just Okay, not exceptional but we were definitely full with all the cheese they had in their pasta. 
We ordered the Boneless short Ribs and a shrimp pasta and two appetizers. 
Probably their other food on the regular menu would be better but this was just average.
author: Susan G.

description: Excellent meal. All the plates we tried were beautiful and very scrumptious. Plus a beautiful patio on the bay. Amazing selections of Peruvian ceviche, sashimi, empanadas, with burgers thrown in as well. Great lunch spot. Expensive but worth it.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Love this place.  It's probably touristy since it's along the Embarcadero, but the food is soooo good.  Ambiance is great, especially if you can sit outside along the water.  I could list all the good things to try/eat but then I'd literally be listing the whole menu.  Seriously, nothing disappoints.  Not even the cocktails.  (Ok, maybe the bill, but it's worth it!).

Also, ask for their hot sauce.  You gotta ask for it, but be warned, it's hot!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE La Mar. I've been here several times, my boyfriend and I first date, my birthday, and any chance I get when I'm in SF. 

Every time I go it is a slam dunk! I can't even say what is the best because I've had almost everything on the menu and liked it all. 

Service is great, fun music, and fresh creative menu.

If I had to give some feedback-- the bathrooms need some TLC.
author: Vanessa R.

description: Very cool location right on the waterfront with an outstanding outdoor patio which can be used even in winter. The cebiche nikei was astonishingly good, and so it was the cause limena. The empanada de aji de gallina was also pretty good. For the mains we enjoyed both "Salmon la mar" and the lomo saltado. Service was nice and friendly, while remaining stylish. The whole place lends itself to a bit of dressing up.
author: Stefano Z.

description:
Wow, I'm impressed. I went for lunch during restaurant week, and had a three course lunch for $25 without drinks, tax and tip. In the end, I spent closer to $45 because the service was great and I wanted a drink. 

I had an excellent meal in a drop dead gorgeous venue with attentive, informative and charming service. The general manager even stopped by to make sure we were happy. 

The restaurant is right on the water and has an open air patio (protected from the wind/rain) in the back. It was a pretty chilly day, so we sat inside. There are heat lamps though, if you're more adventurous than we were and really want a view. Everything  is swanky/modern inside. The bar was backlit blue glass, the chairs were right out of Design Within Reach.....you get the idea. Nice.

And the food. Wow the food. For my first course I had ceviche and it was delicious as well as beautifully presented. There was a lot of lime, a little habanero, red onions, and fresh fresh fresh fish, giant Peruvian nutty corn (both toasted and not) and cilantro.  It was a perfect start.

Next, Lomo Saltado. It was a generous portion and paired with both rice  and potatoes. It was the sauce that really made this dish-it was similar to a demi-glace. Delicious and a great thing to get when you go out because it's too much work to make at home.

Dessert? There was a choice of either Tres Leches or housemade sorbet. I had the sorbet, but the cake looked great too. There were two sorbet flavors- mango/passionfruit and a purple Peruvian corn. I liked the purple corn one best. I ate all of the mango/passionfruit, but it was actually a little sour for me. The purple corn had a nice balance between sweet and sour and actually tasted like a fruit...just a fruit I had never tried before.

Restaurant week is such a good thing!   I will definitely come back here for a special occasion meal knowing that I'll be paying much more. But it will be worth it. 

What a wonderful place!
author: El B.

description: Woowwwwww..... please do not waste your money. $36.00 for 4 pieces of fatty steak. I've been ripped off before but never this bad. Do not waste your money!!! You'll get my money this time but NEVER again!!! And I will be sure to tell a friend.
author: G R.

description: I came here on Friday night with two girlfriends. We shared the Ceviche Sampler which came with three different ones. The portions were a good size and nice for sharing. We then shared the Empanadas Sampler of one each of Shrimp, Mushroom, Chicken and Beef. We split those and I'd say it's good for three evenly cut pieces. The Chicken and Shrimp ones were the best of the four. The Beef one had raisins and to my surprise, it wasn't too sweet. For the main entree, we split the skewers platter of Chicken, Beef and their daily Fish. We added on the Grilled Octupus. There were single skewers but the pieces were enough to share but I think just for three people and the Octopus came add three portions so it was the perfect amount. Our server recommended the Octopus and it was delicious. The service was attentive though almost too much so. We were chatting, drinking and nibbling while the bussers came by a few times to try and take our plates away.
