Food: Marvelous and absolutely memorable. There are some foods you eat but quickly forget because they are good but forgettable. Food for me is an experience and a memorable experience requires a great cook and staff. 

Overall: I will be back when I return to SF.
author: Teddy O.

description:
I really tried to like this place but the food and service were awful. Our waitress was rude.  Also, you know the food is bad when the highlight of the entire meal was the plain, white rice. Yes, you are reading correctly. The ceviche was okay but I definitely had better at other places. 

The pisco sour was delicious but one of the drinks had too much foam. About 1/2 or 2/3. Poor quality control. Overall, I suggest that you pass on this place since it is overrated and overpriced.
author: Cindy C.

description: I love their ceviche and drinks, friendly service, nice decor. As per entrees,... Eh... It is okay but not that amazing. For how much it is, I would expect something a little better than average food.
author: mona k.

description:
I really really like this place. Perfect for a date night; the location is on the pier, and if you sit close to the window, you'll get a great view of the bay. There's also considerate amount of parking near the Embarcadero, so that's also nice.

The food is so good! We got cebiche for appetizers-- the ones we got was kind of an Asian-fusion one, in a good way. There were crunchy wantons in it, cilantro, quite tart but still acceptable. Soooo good. 

Other than that, I would say to just ask your server for recommendations. Their seafood in general is good too, as many of the other reviews indicate.
author: Jessica Y.

description: Walked in and waited to be seated, keep in mind I am in a party of 2. I was cut in line twice by two other parties of two. Food was mediocre. Empanadas are good. Waited a long time for the check. When the check came back I was shortchanged 7$.
author: John L.

description:
Great place on the bay. Right on the Embarcadero by the Marketplace. Great and welcoming staff!!  Very helpful server. 

Excellent Pisco sours. They have a whole Pisco menu. Divine cebiches. Try the Classico and the Nikkei. The Nikkei was our favorite and something YOU should try for sure.

SF has 4 Peruvian restaurants. This one is our favorite!!
author: Steven H.

description:
Went here for Dine About Town lunch with a few friends yesterday and we had an enjoyable experience. 

The location itself was nice right on the embarcadero, this would be a great summertime spot with a large back patio along the water. It was a little chilly for our group, however, as not all the space heaters were functioning properly.

We all opted for the meat option which included:

mixture of chips, including my fave-plantains
seafood ceviche
octopus tartar
seafood paella
guava sorbet

The ceviche was good, the kernels of corn in it were huge. The octopus tartar was interesting, the flavor profile was a little odd. The seafood paella was pretty good, very hearty, I think it could have used a little more citrus to cut some of the richness. 

There was a bit of a wait between our first course and the second plate, nothing too drastic, but the manager came over right away to apologize and informed us she would send us an additional complimentary dessert. She sent us the choco-maracuya, a passion fruit chocolate dessert with 24 karat gold dusted on top. This was the best dessert I've had in a while, and we felt so fancy!

We still received the sorbet which was tasty, nothing earth shattering.

Their prices aren't bad normally and we enjoyed our experience, I would definitely come back particularly on a nice day to enjoy the view or with friends over a happy hour.
author: Nicole Z.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to La Mar for our first time & had an AMAZING time. The ambiance is so beautiful and romantic. You have a view of the whole bay, its beautiful. The drinks and food were delicious. Their calamari is absolutely too die for!!! 

Also, my boyfriend arranged to have a little dessert brought out to me that said "I love you" written in chocolate. The manager was so nice to help my boyfriend set this up for me.

La Mar has excellent service. We will definitely be returning there very soon!
author: Amanda B.

description: The food was delicious - loved the ceviche sampler. The polpo seemed to be a bit overpowered by the fried potatoes to me. We ordered the sea bass on the weekly special and weren't warned of how unbelievably spicy it was. I love spicy food (would typically order a dish 4 out of 5 stars for reference) - this was a 4.5 on the spicy scale, which should just be given as a heads up in case anyone doesn't like spice. It also just didn't need to be that spicy. The desserts were delicious (carmelized quinoa dish and the tres leches), but for $13 each, were incredibly small. Great service at the table but very curt and unfriendly hostess at check-in. We had accidentally made the reservation for the next day and the reception to asking if we still might be able to sit outside was not warm. They still were able to seat us inside (it was Sunday evening, they weren't that busy) but the AC was on high and it was very cold.
author: Sophie R.

description:
A few days ago for our trip to SF, one of the rare times we go, we were all out of ideas but remembered this place being crowded and being legit for Peruvian food since it has locations in Miami and in other parts of South America. This must be the real deal!

When we arrived a little before 12 AM, nobody sat inside but everybody was outside enjoying the cool wind, nice sunlight, and beautiful ocean view. I was a bit confused that there was not really anyone since it was the ideal time to have lunch on a weekend but I soon realized that we arrived at opening time. We secured a spot and it came with the gorgeous view.

Here is what we ordered:

PLANTAIN (BANANA), KETTLE, SWEET POTATO (ASSORTMENT) CHIPS: This was complimentary and it came with 2 supposedly spicy dipping sauces that tasted very similar. My favorite was the plantain (banana) chips because they were very unique and they didn't really taste like bananas since they weren't sweet at all. 

LOMITO SALTADO ($15): This was basically a sandwich served in acme bread with melted gouda cheese, avocado, and papas al hilo with a choice of fries or a salad. It was okay and nothing too special.

CEBICHE CLÁSICO ($18): This was a ceviche and had California halibut, red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn, and yam. It tasted clean, fresh, and was one of the best ceviches I've had.

ARROZ NEGRO ($28): This had grilled calamari and shrimp on top of squid ink arborio rice with ahi panca, aji amarillo, bell peppers, choclo and parmesan, garnished with rococo creamy chalaca. The calamari was particularly strong because it had a really good texture and "chew" to it. I liked how the grilled calamari and shrimp retained the grilled taste but was not burnt at all. 

HAMBURGUESA A LA POBRE ($17): This was a kobe beef burger served on acme bread accompanied with fried egg, banana, gouda cheese, tomato, jalapeño, and greens with a salsa criolla sauce. It came with sweet potato fries. This was one of the most interesting and best burgers I've had. It was sweet, spicy, salty, and savory. It had a good balance of flavors with nothing too overwhelming. Also, it was huge and could easily be split between 2 people unless you are a big eater.

TOCINO DEL CIELO ($13): This was a coconut-crusted flan with pineapple and peach tartar, caramelized pineapple mousse, and garnished with tuple. It was pretty good and reminded me of one I had at Jaleo in Las Vegas. The flavors and the chew from the coconut-crust went well together. However, this is not worth $13. 

SERVICE: The service was nothing really special. He was nice and always made sure we were doing fine. When this other guy asked which dish goes to which person, I felt like they should have known especially for the price we were paying.

DECOR: The place was quite pretty outside and nothing that special on the inside. Outside, you can soak up the sunlight and enjoy the gorgeous ocean and the waves. The view was really nice and yet we weren't getting burnt by the sun.

Will I return? Yes, I would. I would go back for the burger and the ceviche. Most of the items we ordered were very strong and were overall just really well done. It was worth it for the price because even though it is expensive, you do get quality and quantity.
author: Jacquie H.

description: I have been to La Mar in Lima and thought they had some of the best ceviche and peruvian food in Lima. So we were so happy to know that they have a restaurant in San Fran with a similar menu!  The location was perfect as its close to the ferry building and you can get a nice water view. They had yummy plantains for starters and their maracuya sour and pisco sour was refreshing. We also enjoyed their ceviche, plancha marina and empanadas. It was a bit pricey but we expected that based on reviews. Overall, we were impressed with La Mar San fran but if you get a chance, go check out the one in Lima!
author: Karen D.

description:
When I first heard the name, I thought it was one word and envisioned soul food by some dude named Lamar.  Upon actually eating here, I was impressed by the Peruvian food that outfancied Limon.  

Chips: I can't believe this is free!  Fried plantains, potatoes, yams, purple potatoes and other tubers served with three creamy dipping sauce options.  I could make a meal of these and a few piscos... dangerous!

Cebiche Mixto: A tad spicy, but in a good way.  Enjoyed the texture contrast between the soft mahi mahi and chewy octopus.

Cebiche Chifa: I am a huge fan of fried stuff contrasting ceviche.  The wonton strips against the Asian spices of sesame, cilantro, ginger and scallion was a perfect pairing.  Would have been nice if they ventured into other fish than the Mahi Mahi which seems to appear in every ceviche.

Cebiche Nikei: Tuna, red onion and avocado have been done together so many times.  It was the tamarind that added a nice sour kick to the classic flavor profile.  Nice, but not exotic enough for me.

Cebiche Clasico: I like the use of pasty yams amongst the halibut to add some substance to the typically light ceviche.  The fresh corn shavings were a good texture differentiator as well.  Overall, a bit milder than the others but still nice.

Causa Limena: Very San Francisco with the dungeness crab and avocado.  Pretty bland against the whipped potato, though no single ingredient had a dominating personality.

Causa Nikei: Also a little bland since tuna and avocado are pretty tame.  Felt nice and creamy when eating.

Causa Casera: Veggie, but in a good way.  The asparagus added a nice crunch to the otherwise mushy texture profile.  The basil cilantro oil added a nice kick which probably should have been leveraged in some of the fish causas.

Causa Criolla: I think this one was the one with a big piece of grilled fish on top.  The fish dominated the causa and made it feel like a bit of a fish entrée which happened to be resting on mashed potatoes.  Could have used some more spices. 

Lomo Saltado: Lomo Saltado is my favorite Peruvian dish so I must try it at any Peruvian restaurant I eat at.  I was a little put off that they charged $27 for a dish as simple and common as stir fried rice.  The fries, beef strips, tomato, red onion, cilantro and soy sauce based marinade were all on point.  Though I still didn't feel this was fancified enough to warrant the price inflation.

Tacu Tacu Norteño: I'll be honest, I ordered this because I wanted to try the tacu tacu.  The canary beans were mashed into the rice in proper proportions.  They could have fried it a bit to make it crispy though.  The seafood on top was nice, but could have used more of the Huancaína sauce.
author: Adam B.

description: Best Peruvian food! The service was great, all the bar tenders and servers were very friendly! Excellent food from appetizers to deserts, and good ambiance! I will definitely come back every time I am in town!
author: Yasmine B.

description:
La mar! 
I will be back soon, I promise. When we walked in, we were friendly greeted by one of their hostesses, and asked if we would like to be seated. We explained that we were interested as to what they had to offer for happy hour. She then brought us a happy hour menu, which was just what we needed. 
So we came back at three for happy hour to try some drinks, and we were greeted by several of the bartenders and nicely welcomed into the bar.
The bar had many drinks to offer on their happy hour menu, including well drinks, wines, and daiquiris. I decided to go with the caipirinha. It was really good! If you're looking for a nice drink for a warmer day with a bit of a kick, this is your drink! My girlfriend got the strawberry gimlet, and she really liked it as well. A little too fruity and sugary for me, but that's to be expected.

 If I'm strolling down Embarcadero soon, I'll be sure to stop by here again. Great drinks and friendly staff!
author: Mike B.

description:
Had no expectation at all when I walked in with an old buddy from back in the day.  He lives in the Bay but had never stopped here.  We got drinks and apps at the Wine Merchant a few blocks away so we walked and talked till we found this establishment.

It wasn't as pricey as another that we stopped at on our quest for fresh seafood, so for him this place seemed to fit the bill.

Our bill came out to roughly $75 including tip so no too bad considering the wine and fresh seafood.  The only real issue was the two hour wait for a table or immediate seating at the bar.  Duh, we went bar.

Lively place, good for all types.  Large enough for a real gathering of friends and yet cozy intimate places, like the bar, for two to talk and relive some old times.

He's still a cheapskate, after all these years, and stuck me with the tip.  Dirty rotten scoundrel... He knows I tip well, so whatya gonna do?
author: Bill C.

description:
Actually five stars for the food, it really is very creative and high quality. We also think they make the best Pisco Sours in town BUT the noise level tonight in the back patio was over the top. It really is hard to enjoy a fine meal when you can't hear the other folks at your table.  We spoke with management about one particular party of 10 that was super loud.  The response was that they have a right to enjoy themselves. Sure, but excessive levels of noise causing everyone around them to not enjoy their meals is not equitable. This is a problem that has been happening all over town in the last few years and quite frankly it's the younger crowd that's responsible.
Our experience caused us to finish our meal quickly leave for another restaurant for dessert. 
We have been to La Mar many times in the past and we will come back for the piscos but only in the bar. Too bad LaMar.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I decided to take my parents to La Mar after a few of my friends said that the food was pretty good for being on the Emcarcadero.  I made reservations for 4 at 8:15pm on a Friday thinking that there shouldn't be a lot of people to seat around then.  When we checked in at the front, they told us that our table would be awhile but that we could wait at the bar.  Not a big deal, so we headed into the bar.  We ordered a Pisco Punch, a Pisco Sour, a beer, and iced tea from the one waitress that was trying to serve everyone in the bar area.  20 minutes, we still had no drinks, and still were waiting for our table.  Ultimately, we got our drinks and our table around the same time.  The restaurant itself is huge, since it opens further in the back and even outside.  Our waiter was nice, but not very informative beyond rattling off the specials of the day.  Anyway, for the appetizers, we ordered the Cebiche Chifa and Cebiche Nikei.  The two dishes had the right amount to share among 4 people, especially when you factor in the delicious chips and savory dips they put on your table before your orders come out.  The two cebiches were delicious, but my favorite was the Chifa with the yellowtail  tuna with peanuts, scallions, ginger, pickled carrots and daikon, habanero, wonton strips and cilantro in a sweet and sour sesame oil.  For the mains, we had the following:

- Arroz Jugoso: Prawns, clams, mussels, calamari, white fish and vegetables in rice with a blend of Peruvian sauces - served with rocoto aioli and toasted bread 
- Lomo Saltado: Your standard traditional Peruvian style stir fry beef tenderloin; sautéed with onions, tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic with fried potatoes and rice
- One of the specials on the menu, "Paiche":  Grilled Peruvian fish from the Amazon river, with wok sautéed asparagus and mushrooms with onions, garlic, ginger and oyster sauce served with a side of quinoa chaufa

Greg and I both had the Lomo Saltado since who can say no to a beef tenderloin?  Our server only came by once throughout the meal, and while the food was about 4 stars, the prices for it were comparable to a place I'd give 5 stars to.  My parents enjoyed both of their meals, which was the most important part of dinner, however I think La Mar would be a great place for happy hour or just drinks.  Out of everything, the ceviches were my favorite part of dinner, but since the service at the bar/reception was so-so and it was a pricey experience, I have to settle on this place being just OK.
author: Lisa I.

description: Lovely ambiance (seems to be a great spot for lunch with family visiting) and decor (high ceilings, yesss!) but food was nothing to write home about. It's good, but not amazing; a bit pricey, so you'd probably come here more for the view/location/setting. Service was very good.
author: Diana K.

description:
You can trust the reviews. This is a serious Embarcadero eatery between the oh-so-touristy waterfront and Ferry Terminal. 

We're talking about crazy good ceviche. Try the ceviche sampler for a wonderful treat.  We asked the waiter for the "Best Chard & Pinot you're pouring" and the results we surprisingly good.  

We enjoyed attentive, professional service.  Make sure to request seating in the enclosed back patio, which overlooks the bay. Overall, we enjoyed La Mar Cebichería Peruana and filed it to revisit.
author: Marty W.

description:
my first time being here and the food was fabulous!   the empanada sampler was the bomb and so was the grilled octopus.   everything was spectacular UNTIL dessert.   i ordered a coffee with my dessert.  They served the dessert, then the check and my coffee 10 minutes later.  That was a total buzz kill and ruined the entire experience.   I would expect a restaurant  of this caliber to know better.   and they shouldve taken the coffee off the check, since it took unusually long.   (it really should've been served with my dessert).  

I might come back, but why should i?   I can get excellent service at other restaurants nearby (hard water, slanted door, coquetta with the same experience.
author: Sherry C.

description:
I first heard about La Mar when I was watching the Malou Review. I never even knew that pier 1.5 existed. The location is pretty awesome bc you're on the embarcadero and walking distance to a lot of other great attractions. The restaurant is huge with great views of the bay! There's ample seating inside and outside...depending on the weather and your preference. 

I never tried Peruvian cuisine before, but I love raw fish so I love cebiche! Friend and I went to La Mar for dinner on a Friday night. We got the cebiche sampler bc we wanted to try them all. All of them  were fresh and great in their own ways. The flavors were very different among the four. My fav was the 
cebiche nikei.  We also got the empanada sampler also consisting of four kinds. I personally liked the veggie one the best, but they were all good. What fried food isn't good anyway? We also got the ahi sashimi which was very fresh. Of course, we had to try the signature cocktail, so we got the pisco sour. I'm not really too crazy about the raw egg white foam stuff, but it was alright. When in Peru.... (or La Mar in this case). 

You can come here with a friend, a group of friends, family or a date. It's a nice place for all occasions. It seems pretty popular, so I'd make a reservation before visiting.
author: Liv A.

description:
Food: 3 stars, ok not great
Service: 1 star, had to flag down server for everything
Ambiance: Nice and energetic but not too loud

The food was ok but not great.  The presentation is nice but the flavors are lacking.  A dish with scallop as the first ingredient had just 1 piece of scallop. 

The service was also sorely lacking, it took a long time to get water after getting seated and our entrees came before the chips (free appetizer) arrived and we had to ask for the chips. We had to constantly flag the server for anything including the chips and had a long wait for the check at the end as well. 

It's nice and energetic inside but not that loud so you don't have to shout to have conversation.

There was plentiful street parking (still have to pay but can use credit cards) on the other side of the street a few minutes walk away on a weeknight.
author: Matthew S.

description: We had almost everything on the menu and every item arrives fresh and flavorful with just the right amount of spice added. I am a big fan of their cocktails as well because they don't water their drinks down with too much ice. The restaurant can get pretty loud inside during dinner time, so I would recommend for lunch or getting seated on their outdoor patio in the back.
author: EG P.

description:
I'm writing this review mainly to inform the owners of their restaurant staff, as a small business owner myself here in SF.  I'm aware it is a family business and they have spent time and energy in building a name for themselves.  If you read many of the reviews, the poor ratings are often because of the service/wait staff.  This was exactly our experience. I seldom write poor reviews but feel I this was important to improve customer service.

We have been there previously last year, the service and food was great!  Unfortunately, that was not our experience last month with a party of 7.  To summarize, this was the first time for all but 2 of us and guests requested recommendations and explanations from our waitress.
While in the midst of explaining the menu to one of the guest - she stops and says to him "just a minute, I have to go and take care of the other table."  She proceeds to go over to the next table and take their orders.  It took some time for her to return, with no apology whatsoever.
When asked why she left, there wasn't any valid explanation or remorse - with that we asked for the manager.  

The manager came over, slightly apologized and offered another server - said they'd take good care of us, but never saw him again. Our orders were taken, the food came - service was quite frankly below par.  As a matter of fact the two salads we ordered never got came and we eventually cancelled it after the entrees were served.  When the bill arrived - the salads were still charged, when mentioned there were jesters of acts of apology.  

The first waitress' action was inexcusable, the manager's lack of concern barely acceptable and the second waiter's inattentiveness and failing to remove the cost of dishes not served after it was pointed out, was too much in one evening to let it go unreported.  Sadly to say we wonder if this is a reflection on the management's lack of concern regarding customer service.  

One last point - several of the guest attempted to use the bathroom directly across from the reception desk - ALL were appalled at the condition of the bathroom at such an upscale restaurant, or for that matter any restaurant.  In fact, after opening the door and seeing the unkept bathroom, I immediately closed the door to find one that was more acceptable.

I love peruvian cuisine - but sorry to say I will not be returning to La Mar until I read that the service has improved!
author: Cincia H.

description:
If I could give this place no stars I would. My husband and I received a gift card to this restaurant a few weeks ago. We were excited to try a nice restaurant in the city. We were able to make our appointment online, which was very much appreciated.

When we got to the establishment, we were taken by the hostess to our table. This hostess zoomed past us with a pace close to jogging. We had to make sure we could see her to know where she turned.

We were seated and given the chips and dip. After looking over the menu briefly out waiter Shane came to the table. With a hard to understand hello, he just stood there with his pen ready in hand. I guess it was our job to greet him first. I ordered a drink, and my husband asked if we could see how much we had on our gift card, our second mistake of the night.He came back and notified us of how much was on the card. By that time we were ready to order, but were already turned off at the fact that Shane made it clear that he did not want to waiter our table. To put it nicely, he had a stick up his ass the whole time. 

We received our food by Dustin, by far the most friendly person we had come in contact that night. Jose, I believe who was the busboy made our night. He went out of his way to make sure we were taken care of, very sweet man.

What was extremely disturbing from our experience was that we were given less than mediocre service, perhaps based on the way we looked or simply because Shane assumed we did not deserve good service as a result of having a gift card. Shane made rounds to the neighboring tables refilling water asking how the food was. He walked passed our table, slightly paused and saw that our glasses were half full, yet continued to walk around us and asked to refill the water of the fancier looking couple across from us. 

Shane had the nerve to ask if we wanted dessert, after really only visiting our table to get our order and to give us the check.

We spoke with the manager afterwards, expressing our complaint on what awful service we were given by Shane. She seemed sincere in her apology, and offered for us to come back to experience what the proper service of the establishment really was. As nice as the offer was, we have no desire to ever step into this stuck up, judgmental establishment again. 

For the sake of the restaurant, I hope they retrain their staff on how to do their job right and to not be discriminatory towards its patrons.
author: Silvia C.

description: Been here four times so far. This is the best flavor of the peruvian cuisine in the Bay area. Try ceviche trio and sampler of causas. You will not be dissapointed. Pisco sour is great. It is a little pricey, otherwise I would eat here more often. But definitely worth it. The owner is the famous chef Gaston Acurrio, world wide ambassador of the peruvian cuisine.
author: Edita R.

description: The vegetable chip appetizers are really good! The atmosphere in the restaurant is very refreshing as well. The Cebiche is super delicious and is very flavorful but at the same time a light dish.
author: Teresa L.

description: Love this place! Had empanadas and yuca...my oh my! So good, bartenders are on point too. Hung out at the bar, they play good music and the staff is friendly and accommodating...can't wait to go back.
author: Daiana R.

description: La Mar never disappoints! Superb food, ambience and service, and very lively! One of my happy hour favourites too! Their cebiche is outstanding, but all of their other food is excellent too. I've been here at lunch and happy hour and am looking forward to trying it at dinner.
author: Mick J.

description: First time visiting this place with my colleagues!  We had a customized menu and everything we had were absolutely delicious! I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu. The place was packed on Thursday night!
author: Stefanie G.

description:
Wait, didn't I already write a review to this place? Guess not.

I've come here twice in the last month for the same essential reason - to find a good venue for a group of people to enjoy the view of the bay and hang out with trendies and tourists.

If you come for happy hour, you'll end up at the bar with a crowd of yuppies. Grab a table before anyone else does. Drink Pisco sour to your heart's content.

If you come for dinner make a reservation or else you'll forgot dinner time waiting for a table.

Get the empanada appetizer, the ceviche tasting and the corazon...wow.

Main dish included the lomo saltado.

Lots of salt if you eat here but probably worth it. Expensive too but worth it only every now and then.
author: Julia P.

description:
My Dearest La Mar,

I am not Peruvian by any means, but you give me that feeling that I was raised by Peruvians growing up with your homeade tastes and flavors. 

I came in on a Saturday afternoon(Which was PACKED..pretty awesome). I easily found a spot where I could plop down and call my own. The pretty little thang Michelle was my server/bartender whom was fantastic and very very quick. She made me a couple Moscow Mules and then I decided to venture out and have a dulcified house specialty el famoso "Pisco Sour"...MUY BIEN...I think I've found my new favorite cocktail for the next few years.

Food Report:
fried calamari with tartar sauce- C (It was served a bit cold..)
empanada del dia- A (Phenom)
house made chips with salsas de ajies-A+(MUST have...they are lite & easy snackers)
chicharrón de pollo anticuchero- A (Love the sauce/salsas)

I came in during happy hour which is probably the best hour to visit because everything on the menu is so inexpensive.(Hence, my mule of an appetite above)

Yes go in and try..(Definitely recommend getting a reservation if you prefer the main dining room)
Yes ask for Jessica at the bar..
Yes bring your appetite, try and order everything on the menu..
Yes have a great time! There is a fantastic selection of music with a vast array of locals and tourists!

Nos Vemos,

*HH*
author: Hillary H.

description: How could dining possibly get any better than this? I dare anyone to find something on this menu that isn't both delicious and attractive. If you want a truly amazing meal this is the spot for you. Service was perfect
author: John M.

description:
5-Stars all the way.... Amazing food. I ate here yesterday for an early dinner. The waiter was very nice and recommended a few dishes, which we ended up ordering. Everything he recommended was fantastic! 

The food was a little pricey... but hey, it was totally worth it. I'll be back!
author: Samantha L.

description: Great food and very fresh fish.  Loved the cebiche.  As others have said, the service is only so so.  Was annoyed they charge for soft drink refills.  Sorry, nobody does that in the USA.
author: Robert W.

description:
We dropped in for a Sunday lunch and had a decent meal. Sadly, it just didn't live up to expectations. It had been awhile since we were last here and somehow remembered it better (guess not, since we gave a 3 last time as well)

We had an order of chef option 1- octopus/black olive causa, ceviche mixto, seafood rice, purple corn sorbet and a main menu entree order of the chicharron pork belly sandwich

For a ceviche (or should we say cebiche) place, the dishes were surprisingly lacking in acid. The ceviche mixto was extremely disappointing- no acid, no salt, just kind of a bland mush of one shrimp, one piece of fish, and some calamari. The chicharron sandwich was crunchy, fatty, but also lacking salt and something to balance the meatiness. The lightly pickled red onion just didn't do it. We craved a slaw of some sort or at least a sauce to give the sandwich a kick. Funnily enough, the thing that had the most oomph and acid in the meal was the balsamic dressed side salad that came with the sandwich. The one plate we did like quite a lot was the octopus causa which was was flavorful, balanced, and quite interesting. 

The complimentary potato, sweet potato, (and occasional) plantain chips are yummy though occasionally a bit over fried with choice of two sauces. The spicy orange one was fantastic- if you ask, they will bring you more and refill. We're excited they updated the dips since our last visit.

Overall, not too expensive of a "chef's tasting" for $19.95 for lunch but not the exciting food we were looking for. If you're in the neighborhood for a drink- they do do a $5 pisco sour every Sunday which is pretty great.
author: Amy D.

description:
Went here for dinner with a big group and was pleasantly suprised. The appetizers of ceviche, empanadas, were a big hit. So were the cones of fried plantains and sweet potatoes.

I had the yellow tail skewer which was a bit underwhelming for me. I think they were heavy handed on the salt but I tried the Arroz Jugoso which was delicious 

The desserts were also very good. We had the chocolate pannacotta with gold flakes on it. The view of the water was nice and the service was excellent.
author: Nette T.

description: Great Peruvian food on the waterfront near the ferry building. Great ceviche. Try the cold potatoes with seafood on top for appetizer.  Wonderful plantain chips to munch on. Empanadas were tasty, as was the grilled octopus. Also enjoyed the paella - loaded with seafood. Double layer mousse for dessert was a nice finish. Service was excellent. Only thing missing was no draft beer - bottles only.
author: Larry P.

description:
As a peruvian living in los angeles for more than 13 years already, i had to try La Mar when i visited San Francisco last weekend. Me and my wife ordered 2 pisco sours and while the drinks were strong and not watered down, they still didnt taste as something unique. We also ordered the cebiche sampler that comes with regular, mixto and nikkei cebiches and while my wife loved all of them (she is from mexico) it wasnt that good for me except for the nikkei one. The fish was too soft to eat and the leche de tigre juice didnt have any rocoto at all ... and thats straight up murder on a cebiche plate. Finally we ordered a lomo saltado and a La Mar seafood rice. The lomo meat was tender but the cook used too many sauce in the whole plate making it feel like a stew which is not how a lomo saltado should be. It also was suuuuuuper salty. The seafood rice was also ok, but i didnt like that the rice itself was mushy and not grainy. Flavors were average as well. 
As a restaurant that markets itself as a fancy peruvian option I wont recommend it. Its on the San Francisco pier, so of course its not going to be cheap, but as a peruvian I can say I have been to other less fancy places which offer better tasting dishes by a fraction of La Mar's prices.
author: George P.

description: Great food, atmosphere, and service. Would highly recommend others to eat here. We had items from their brunch menu and everything was flavorful.
author: Rahman S.

description: It was nice, food was good but not extraordinary, and a little too expensive for what it is... the empanadas were great though.
author: Stav W.

description: Enjoyed the new tastes.  Plentiful for the price so that offset the eye-opener of a check that came for a group of 10.  Wonderful staff, really went out of their way for us.  Open kitchen which was nice.  Slightly noisy but thats to be expected.  Otherwise great place, lots of room, really nice bar.  Known for empanadas; get the sampler!
author: Vic T.

description: Very nice restaurant. Fun ambiance. The food is more Peruvian fusion than regular Peruvian. Good but not the type I'd expect to get if I want to try real Peruvian food.
author: Elsa S.

description:
The food and service here were phenomenal. Nausea, vomiting, chills and the shakes 4 hours after my meal? Not so much. Hence, the one star. We ordered the California Cebiche, Limeña Causa, Carne Anticucho, and Arroz la mar. 

Initially, I wasn't sure if it was this meal that caused it or something else, but I've had similar reaction times when I've had food poisoning. And then this handy site (http://myria.com/how-can-you-figure-out-what-gave-you-food-poisoning) lists bacteria that cause food poisoning, their onset times and possible sources:

Illness/Bacterium: Staphylococcal food poisoning (Staphylococcus aureus)
Onset: 1-6 hours
Sources: Unrefrigerated or improperly refrigerated meats, potato and egg salads, cream pastries

Illness/Bacterium: V parahaemolyticus infection (Vibrio
parahaemolyticus)
Onset: 4-96 hours
Sources: Undercooked or raw seafood, such as shellfish

While their Health Inspection rating is 91, note that they had 2 violations on March 10, 2016: 

1. Unclean nonfood contact surfaces [ date violation corrected: 4/5/2016 ]
2. High risk food holding temperature [ date violation corrected: 4/5/2016 ]

Corrected on 4/5/16? Maybe, but looks like they've uncorrected it since then. Between all this information AND  7 other Yelpers who also posted about food poisoning, I wouldn't recommend this restaurant, unless you have a stomach of steel. Proceed with caution!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Everything was tasty and delicious.  I love Peruvian food, because it has a lot of great, fresh, and innovative fish dishes.  This place definitely proves it.  The other apps are great as well.  The drinks are superb!

I was here for happy hour, which was a great deal.  The regular menu is on the pricey side, so I think happy hour is the way to go!

Fantastic decor and views.  Also great service!
author: Vadim d.

description:
I'm so very sorry to say this of one of my favorite restaurants, but La Mar's service has gone downhill. 

We came today to have some brunch and drinks, we've been sitting for more than half an hour after ordering our drinks and looks like we'll be waiting for half an hour more :(

It gets worse, on my way to the bathroom I stepped on water or something else that had spilled on the floor and fell bumping my knee real hard. To make matters worse, nobody from the restaurant  came to ask me if I was Ok or to apologize for the inconvenience, they just kept on going like it was no big deal. Shame on you La Mar! Horrible customer service!
author: Yllari L.

description: Not sure what happened to this place. The quality of food used to be much better than they are now. I used to always get the lomo saltado but now it has lost its allure. They changed something in the recipe and now it is absolutely not worth the $$$. Bland sauce, low quality steak, and soggy fries = an unhappy customer. Found a much better spot for lomo saltado at Limon. Will not be back to La Mar.
author: Jan K.

description: Try to sample as much as you can here.  I would eat their ceviche for breakfast lunch and dinner everyday if I could afford it ($19/each).  Previously I've had their lomo sated (steak and french fries) as well as their paella.  To top it off order some Peruvian beer and their fried plantain appetizer.  You'll leave wanting more, once your bank account replenishes.  A bit on the pricey side, but you also get a great ambiance and view.  Try to sit outside on a sunny day.
author: Kyle I.

description:
We had just returned from Peru - where we were told (at a Cusco cooking class) that La Mar was the best Peruvian restaurant in SF.
We were not disappointed - great ceviche (with a kick), unusual ingredients of differing textures similar to our experiences in Peru - we will go back to La Mar
author: Terry W.

description:
Definitely the place to go when you are in San Francisco! While walking the Piers and looking for a typically cheesy and touristy place to have a late lunch - we came across this fabulous and famous restaurant at Pier 1.5. Great restaurant, beautiful interior, fabulous outdoor seating and views. Phenomenal authentic food!!!!!! What an amazing treat! 

I started with a Pisco Sour... my only let down from this restaurant. I think they were half strength. 

They start you off with plaintain/sweet potato/potatochips served with dipping sauces that are wonderful in flavor.

The cebiche was amazing. Of course I had to go with the tuna.

Causa tasting was a dream! I even liked the vegetarian one!

Picante mariscos was a delight with sautéed fresh seafood.

For dessert we had a chocolate crepe? with a fruit filling served with ice cream (I forgot to get the name of this one) paired with a wonderful dessert wine.

A lot of food for me, but it all tasted so amazing and was so light that I surprised myself with eating all of it!

I will definitely return here!!!!
author: Amber H.

description: Dropped in on a Sunday right before dining room opened for dinner service at 5:30p so was able to get seated right away. Our server was very friendly. He explained the menu since it was our first time eating there and gave his recommendations. We enjoyed everything we ordered, including the complimentary plantain chips and aoli dip. I ordered the prickly pear margarita to drink which was not as sweet as I anticipated so I really liked it. I had the lomo saltado per the server's recommendation. It was really good. I thought it would be a heavy dish because of the beef and potatoes and expected I would need to bring most of it home. I ended up eating most of it and didn't have enough to bring home after all. Though I practically finished the whole dish I surprisingly didn't feel like a blob or uncomfortably full at all. My bf ordered the plancha marina which he really enjoyed and he can be kind of a picky eater. We liked our server but he seemed to have gotten pretty busy towards the end, so it took a while for us to get our check and finally get out of there. The food was pricey, but very good. The service got a little slow at the end, but wasn't something I would raise a complaint about. The music choice that was playing in the restaurant was a little odd. Definitely heard 2 different songs from the movie Grease, among some other unexpected choices. The music did not match the vibe of the restaurant at all lol. Otherwise overall enjoyed the place and would definitely come back.
author: Ashley S.

description: Went here Friday night, had a great experience. Tuna ceviche was amazing. Service was great and all four of our dishes were unique and delicious!
author: J B.

description:
To call La Mar's menu "fusion" is an understatement. From sushi to cebiche (Peruvian ceviche) to samosas, it's a worldly menu with Peruvian flare throughout.

Sadly, it's also pricey as hell. It depends greatly on what you order, but suffice to say a simple lunch could be anywhere from $20-50 a person. For me it's not really worth it.

If you're curious about the cebiche, hit up the bar and grab an order to share with some drinks. Spoiler though- I'm not sure it tastes any different than a "regular" Spanish ceviche!
author: Nick S.

description: This place and price lends itself well to the corporate card.  Go with a group, hit it up tapas style so you can explore the menu, and enjoy the setting. Peruvian cuisine is gaining a lot of steam lately and this is a great place to introduce yourself to its splendor.
author: Ryan J.

description: The Restaurant's location : amazing right on Pier, however the prices are insane! $34 for Lomo Saltado ? $27 empanadas - a 15% Charge for the location - Gaston Acurio needs to a reality check! Be ready to pay well over $100 per person. There are better Peruvian Restaurants at half the prices!
author: Mark M.

description: Today I tried the Quinoa Chaufa with seafood, and it was extraordinary. Highly recommend it.
author: Alejandro C.

description:
I'm a little torn about this place because of what unfolded after my first time here.  The place is beautiful, the drinks are delicious, the food tastes great and is presented beautifully.  HOWEVER, despite all appearances, the seafood may cause some problems for your intestines.  It is definitely brined, which is fairly normal, but  who knows for how long--a long time is not normal, or safe.  I would venture to guess the fish in the cebiches I had were brined for a very long time because of what ended up happening when I got back to work.  Let's just say I was very lucky to have an extra pair of pants with me that day. lol.
I will need to go back and test this--without straying too far from a toilet, and to try the other enticing items on the menu.
author: N. L.

description: Started with the slowest, no-personality bartender who short-poured, then didn't honor happy hour prices. We had to flag down one of the tons of servers to take our order. David, the Sommelier of 3 days, was charming, got us another round after we complained but then charged us.  La Mar has always been one of our favorite places, but the service was AWFUL and so disappointing. The food is unique and the place is gorgeous, but a huge part of going out is the SERVICE; otherwise, what is the point? This is not an inexpensive place, but the service was just not up to par with a restaurant of this caliber.  Incidentally, we are San Francisco restaurant owners and know how it goes ... or should go.
author: Noel K.

description: Loved it!!' The chef came outside and was kind and helpful when I told him my phone fell on the sink and got wet! The food was tasty and we had a great time! :)
author: Andie M.

description:
I've been to La Mar a few times; the first two times with my Peruvian girls who took my Peruvian palate to another level here. 
The first two times, we went there for dinner; made a reservation in advance and got a table next to the water. 
Each of us ordered Pisco Sour, Chicha drink, and Inca Cola. 
Inca Cola was just like those canned ones you can pick up from Target, Chicha drink was not as impressive as the one I usually got from Destino but Pisco Sour here is the strongest I've ever had (amongst Destino, Pacific Catch, and Limon). 
For food, we got Causa with crab meat, Ceviche Mixto, Ceviche Classic, and Lomo Saltado. 
A  delicate restaurant version of ceviche and lomo saltado is something I have been very familiar with and Lamar didn't disappoint me even for a tiny bit. Causa here looked pretty and far more appetizing than what my friends usually cooked for me but it was a shame that every causa I got from here was always too salty; probably from the brininess of the crab meat on top. 
Those first two times cost us quite around $200's which was a bit expensive for a party of three small girls of which stomachs were not even half full. 

So a few days ago, I decided to go there again with my bf and my girl, both of whom have a very tiny appetite. We were there for a happy hour hangout.
This time we got 2 Cristal beer, 3 pisco sour, 1 pisco punch, 1 chicha cocktail, 1 prickly pear margarita. 
Pisco sour was strong as usualy, pisco punch was wy too sweet, chicha cocktail was not as god as what I got from Destino, and the pear margarita was a bit too fruity for me. 
For food, we basically ordered everything on the Happy Hour menu. 
Ceviche were both good, as usual. Mussels were a bit bland, probably because the juice in ceviche was far stronger than that of the mussels dish. Causa was salty as usual. Mehhh! Fried Calamari was the star of the meal! Very very very good! My mouth is still drooling as I write this review. The pork Belly sandwich was very very good as well. The empanadas were average; I guess you can't really screw up empanadas. (Except one African restaurant in mission, which I I'll be writing about it later in upcoming reviews). 
At the end of the meal, the magic piece of paper arrived with $123 written on it before tip. Given all the food and drinks us three got, it was a much better deal comparing to the price of my first two dinners with my girls. 
All in all, if you wanna go try variety of peruvian bites and cheaper drink, Happy Hour is a way to go. However, if you think about taking a girl out on a date, make a reservation and go for a dinner with a romantic sunset view next to the window. Happy Hour there is always packed with drunk people who just get off from work in FiDi; more of a better scenario for a friend hangout or an old married couple who dont want to hear each other talking, and not a romantic first date.
author: Joelle K.

description:
4.5 stars 

La Mar Cebicheria Peruana: a magical place where three people who've experienced ridiculous, hilarious, & unforgettable childhood memories together can (for one moment) feel like actual, real live grown ups. 

With its turquoise palette & cheery atmosphere, the spacious waterfront restaurant is sure to impress first-time diners (such as myself.) 

Parking: next door at pier 3 for a reasonable $5/hour. 

We ordered: everything! 
-- complimentary potato & sweet potato chips w/ 2 dipping sauces: addictive, unique pre-dinner munchables
-- cebiche mixto: I avoided the fish & calamari & stuck with shrimp & hominy, both of which were fresh & crisp 
-- causa tasting: whipped potatoes topped with a variety of seafood: so-so
-- empanada sampler: mushroom tasted like a calzone, shredded chicken reminded me of something out of my childhood (so appropriate with this group), did not try beef. 
-- lomo saltado: favorite savory item. beef tenderloin, onions, potatoes, tomatoes over rice...amazeballs. 
-- quinoa caprese salad: heirloom tomato, burrata, my favorite grain, & basil dressing. Good stuff 

We were too stuffed for dessert, but that didn't stop us each from ordering something. The one I chose arrived in a glass & was a beautiful layered orange & white wonder...passion fruit curd, mousse, meringue...heaven...highly recommended. 

The bill was a few bucks shy of $200 for 3 people. 

I'd definitely go back, but I'd try to sit outside to take advantage of the view.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Went for lunch with a friend and was absolutely delighted.  Wonderful flavors, colors and textures.  Good service.  Very interesting, open venue.  Definitely going back soon!
author: Hank W.

description:
I heard a lot about this place that's why I decided to visit it.
Pros: Food is delicious, great cocktails.
Cons: loong lines , not great service. 
The waiter was so mean. Generally she was okay. But in the middle of our diner she came and just took away our sauce for sweet potato chips while we were eating eat and after she took our dinning mats. What was that?! It was like "eat your food and go away!". I was waiting for 1.5 hour for not this kind of service.
author: Katya Y.

description: The best Peruvian food and drinks I've had since my trip to Peru 10 years ago! Excellent service by our server Mario, amazing Pisco sours, ceviches, anticuchos, tuna belly and beautiful atmosphere right on the waterfront next to the ferry landing. Expensive yes, but worth every penny. Will now come here every time I visit San Francisco! A new all time favorite.
author: Siri J.

description: This place is so good! The first time I went was for a work holiday party and loved every dish I tried. The menu was set so I'm not sure of any specifics, but it was some of the freshest fish I've ever had. Today my friend and I stopped by for a Bloody Mary before boarding a yacht and I'd have to say it was probably the best BM I've had. Not overly salty, but super refreshing. Will definitely come back again soon :)
author: Allison D.

description:
Walking down the piers, we wanted seafood & stopped here. Zagat review in the window helped. Seated right away (table for 5) and brought free homemade potato chips with dips. Nice touch.

The bay cocktail was delish. Light & refreshing. My friend has sake he said was good.

For an entree, I had the mixed skewers- mahi mahi, beef & chicken with potatoes & Peruvian corn. Loves the corn! Not bad for $30 in San Fran.

Friend had the pasta with shrimp & scallops. It looked great & was a very large serving. 

For a place we simply walked by & popped in, I would recommend.
author: DK H.

description:
The food and wine were amazing, although we had the unpleasant surprise to be taken care of by a very arrogant waitress. He was pushing me and my friends to order the main entrance all the time, even though we were still eating our appetizers.....he did that more then three times at least. in the end, after we payed the check, he looked at the fair amount of tips we left and said: "you gotta be f** kidding me?". That is not nice at all and even if the tip wasnt "enough" for him, he should have never said that.
He ruined our experience and gave us a terrible impression of the place. Pitty!
author: Debora D.

description:
Another wonderful experience inclines me to update one of my favorite Peruvian venues. The service continues to be excellent.

The dishes are consistent. Their cebiche tasting - great for newbies - and pisco sours are second to none in the area. Management continues to lead well and the staff is top notch.

A favorite of our on the Embarcadero. Well done gang!
author: Michael G.

description: I have been dying to try this place for quite awhile now. Let me just say that it was amazing. We only had drinks this time but will definitely be back for the good. The happy hour is the best time to come. $6 Pisco sours... How can you say no to that? The plantain chips looked really appealing as well. As for the ambiance, the restaurant is beautiful and the happy hour section is separate but still nice. It's small so it gets crowded easily. Come early if you want to grab a seat but people do filter out quickly. It does get hot and stuffy and everyone is crammed so the less items you have the better. Great ambiance! Definitely will be coming back
author: Allie B.

description:
This was the first time my wife and I tried Peruvian Cuisine and boy did we score on having it here!

Our experience from host-to-table were both excellent. Again since it's our first time dining here, we knew nothing about what to expect or what to order for that matter. Well of course Yelp is always a great sidekick to have for suggestions.

We started off with the Pisco Sour drinks. It was nice and light-perfect, just right to kick start the evening. One can start downing this drink and not even notice the impact so be careful.

We picked our server's brain and he described everything on the menu with enthusiasm and experience. 

When all was said and done, we went with the Cebiche Tasting on the menu and an assortment of their traditional Peruvian grilled skewers.

Two words: Da Bomb!

For all you first timers I'd suggest the best of both worlds. Get a sampling of the cebiche and skewers.

La Mar, La Mar how beautiful ya are...
author: Gary E.

description: Nice ambiance and music, right on the water. Maracuya sour YUM. Had ceviche and causa. Had to add spice but not bad.
author: Am H.

description:
I had the pleasure of dining at La Mar this Wednesday evening with close friends and work associates. Must admit my surprise and delight to have been accommodated by an excellent service staff, most notably our server Nick, who - let's be honest - was the life of our party. His menu knowledge blew us out of the water (no pun intended). 
Nick's suggestions were a tour de force, if not a tour of Peru. 
Please invite your entire family! This will give you the chance to order everything on the menu, which will only bring another depth to your more adventurous eating escapades!
author: Renée L.

description: Absolutely gorgeous! Excellent food and great ambiance! A fabulous place to eat Peruvian food with a twist. I never give 5 stars, but this one deserves the honor! Drinks are also crafty and tasty! Mango picoso was freaking delish! 5 starts for sure!!!
author: Natalya C.

description:
The chips were the best part. Everything else was quite disappointing. 

We had the Dungeness crab special...but when it came there was no crab...I then asked the waiter and he said it was in the sauce. How can you say it's a crab special when you can't see the crab. 

So ok, the FISH dish we got with "crab" sauce...was dry and lacking in flavor. The skin was soggy and the fish was dry. 

Our waiter was nice and attentive...and we got to take home the chips. 

Otherwise, I would not return.
author: rebecca c.

description: Great empanadas. And the vegetarian entree we tried this time was very nice too - quinoa, vegetables and an egg.
author: Manjesh N.

description:
Gorgeous design and location, large everything, and very classy. This is a great spot for business meetups or a cocktail/dinner with a few ounces of fancy. Expensive and very loud but still a great time with really really great food. 

Food: excellent!
we ordered short ribs (fell off the bone, perfectly done), vegetarian quoina (really amazing and full of taste), chicken skewers, and another beef dish. they give you great banana chips and sweet potato chips on the house. that's cool.

Service: normal, good
nothing to complain about, nothing to shout out about

Ambience: beautiful but loud!
typical large elegant design you can expect from a venue in the embarcadero area. large, confident, elegant, modern. it was really loud, though which means I have to reduce the love... I'm getting old and I like to be able to hear conversations and share meaningful, fun without shouting all the time.

I really liked this spot bc I'm a sucker for ambience/design and the food was really good.
author: Karen M.

description:
Great food - really tasty, traditional cebiche with a touch of originality, fantastic setting (ask for a table outside by the water, so nice), great plantain chips for the table. Outstanding, cheerful service. As could be expected, definitely on the expensive side - the three stars weight a great food and service experience as could be and should be expected when appetizer and dessert only, with ice tea (no drinks) come up to 40US pp, plus tip. 
Overall, an enjoyable experience, in particular if you are visiting San Fran on an expense account.
author: See B.

description: Fantastic food, great location, slightly snooty service. The person at the front desk insisted on us waiting the mandatory 15 minutes so that we could fully appreciate how lucky we were to eat there, despite  the empty tables and a reservation. And our  waiter-- a despairing actor type- seemed more interested in mansplaining the items on the menu to us than say, actually making sure that we had enough water to drink. However all was saved by a Super Nice Well Dressed Lady at the end who came to check on us. Thanks, Well Dressed Lady!! Oh, and the ceviche was to die for.
author: Sandy C.

description:
Some of the best Peruvian food I've had [although not the most authentic].

The cerviche here is amazing- fresh, citrusy, and tangy.  The chicharones sandwich is spicy goodness.  And the octopus (pulpo) skewers were some of the best octopus I've even had in my life.  To top it all off, I had this amazing bloody mary here and our meal started off with some amazing plantain chips.

I'm not from the area so I will only be able to come back when I visit SF.  However, next time I am in town, I definitely plan on stopping by.

The service here is pretty good (although our waitress forgot our order of cerviche).  The price is a tad bit steep but the quality is worth it.  Overall, if you are in the Embarcadero area and don't want to waste your time and money on subpar food, stop by La Mar!
author: Erin H.

description: Great place by the bay for groups or couples.  Very nice ambiance with the relaxing theme of ocean blue color.  Food is pretty good although i wish the portion size is a bit bigger.  They serve with  fresh fried sweet potato, potato and banana chips with the dipping sauce which we like very much.    What we like most was the Tiradito Conchas,  the special ceviche appetizer of the night .   However, our server is not the most personable.  Overall, servers don't seem to be friendly.
author: Sunny B.

description:
Let me start this review by saying that I hate seafood. Really, I won't eat anything that comes from the sea except salmon, and even that has to be cooked perfectly for me to like it.  So why did we go to a Peruvian seafood place? Because my hubby's boss and his wife invited us there. That's why.

Anyway, the location was great, the ambiance was lovely. Getting a table on the patio had to be reserved and requested weeks in advance, so we sat inside. I was a little disappointed (as I always am) by the casual nature of the patrons.  Men in shorts... at an expensive restaurant... on a Friday night. Why? I just don't get it. So that was annoying, though not the restaurant's fault.

We ordered 8 dishes (which we anticipated would be way too much food), all of them communal for the table.  75% of them were things I would not eat, however I tried not to look like a total weirdo in front of the boss and his wife, so I tried everything anyway. I kind of faked it -- I tried all the non-fishy things that were in the ceviches and the empanadas. It wasn't easy because there was a lot of squid, octopus, and other raw sea creatures hanging out in each bowl. That said, it all was freaking delicious.  The sauces were incredible. 

Of the items I ate in entirety, the chicken empanadas were soooooooooo good.  And the coconut salmon entree was superb.  My tablemates were wary about trying the more ordinary dishes (like salmon and chicken), but there were no regrets.  And there were no leftovers. That tells you something.

One more tidbit: the ladies' restroom is a historical landmark. Fancy that!
author: Love Z.

description:
the service was terrible.  they charge 20%? my water had a bug in it. we had 8 ppls so we had to split the bill slowly.  so at the end our waiter was tell us to hurry cause his manager was giving him pressure.

but the food was really gd. that's why it still has 3 stars overall .
author: Lyt050677 L.

description: Pricey but good food. More importantly the service is fantastic even when slammed and the drinks are to die for. Not an everyday treat but a great choice for when you're feeling spendy.
author: drew n.

description: Favorite Peruvian place in the city! The main chef, Danny is super nice brought us dessert and his famous ceviche that you must try the one with the purple sauce!
author: Danette D.

description: Interesting and innovative menu, great view of the bay, and fast and courteous service. Thumbs up!
author: Matt T.

description:
Let me drop knowledge: Peruvian food  reveals the local customs and ingredients of the indigenous Inca people and cuisines brought in with immigrants such as Spanish cuisine (Ay Karumba)*, Chinese cuisine (Wah Pow)*, Italian cuisine (Per Ching)*, German cuisine (Da Bow)*, Japanese cuisine (Lee blah)* and African influences (Zee Mench)*. You can imagine, based on my extensive knowledgable of the aforementioned subject, I was delighted to indulge luxuriously in some various delectable melodies fit for Inca kings. 

I enter this place and the foyer is confusing as shit with some sign that says "Please wait to be seated". Word? Why would I do that when I know exactly where I want to be seated, which is outback next to the bay. So I start walking back and some guy with spiky hair and orange suspenders stops me. Man, this dudes hair looked like it belonged on an 8thgraders head on yearbook picture day. The smell of this dudes hair was appalling. This dude probably gets his gel out of a gigantic blue vat that says  "super-extra-all-day-strength-hold" and has a picture of a parachute and skateboard on it. Then this mother fucker has the nerve to put on orange suspenders. Man, suspenders don't belong on a camel, let alone a man. Unless you're in some photo shoot for GQ and like 9 professional designer people are like "Ey, where this shit.", you should NEVER wear them shits. I almost had the girl I was with ask this dude to take off his suspenders and hand them to her so I could snatch them out of her hand and choke the shit out of him with his own bad decision. There should be a TV show called America's Top Fashion Police and its just me, Adriana Lima, and Bar Rafaeli shooting people with paintballs and rubber bullets who are wearing suspenders, top hats, and fingerless gloves. 

The service at this place is whack. I asked to be put outside and then they said no and I immediately snarled and responded, "The hell I ain't! Boss up!" and THEN they put me outside. C'mon, man. You know I'm Mr. Banana hands M.D. don't make me ask twice, I will get mine, whatever I want, regardless! (Pro Tip: You can get anything you want if you just say, "Fuck that, boss up!" and clench your fists.)

I ordered salmon and steak, which were $20 a piece, and was like, damn I feel like a king about to have a victory feast. But naw player. They served me my plates and the shits was just 6 pieces of meat on two different skewers served on top of hash browns. Now, I know they will deny that what you're eating is a hash brown but I've seen enough homeless people hit up the Mcdonalds breakfast menu and walk away with hash browns to know what they be. Man the small portion size for the price was just stupid-doo-doo-dumb. I don't give a damn about money, but when I spend it I better get what I expect. I spent $40 and this place hand delivered me something fit for a cat. In fact, I've seen my buddy feed his cat with larger portions than what this place was feeding me, and his fat pussy ate the whole damn thing. 

6pieces of meat!? Hair gel and suspenders!? Having to resort to Bossing up!? Naw! Naw! Go somewhere else for your Inca and immigrant delicacies!

*When I think of them immigrants, them the sounds I associate. Haaaaaaaaazahhhh Players!
author: Scott S.

description:
Revisited La Mar this weekend.  They have a new chef, and the manager listened to constructive feedback about the lousy job.  He said he would ask the chef (right..) and then disappeared.

What has changed is a confusing mess.  The sauces now blend in non-Peruvian ingredients (Jalapeños? There's not enough peppers from Peru?)  --- the causas are piped on to a plate instead of being in traditional towers -- and the pollo saltado was heavy on vegetables and had precisely three nugget-sized pieces of chicken.

I've visited Peru enough times (and stayed with Peruvians) -- there's so many amazing flavors and culture.  They aren't being represented here, and that's a shame.  Pottery from China for plates.  Uninspiring presentation with non-Peruvian garnish.  Cebiche with poor acidity.

This is Peruvian fusion.  If that's what you want to be, fine, but call it that and not something else.  It's apparent Gaston Acurio hasn't learned why his New York establishment closed.  Charging for upscale is fine.  Being something you aren't usually leads nowhere.

We didn't eat dessert.  We got stuck on the left side of the menu and couldn't make it to the right side.  Illy has been replaced with a North Bay tea and coffee company.  Again, where's the imagination?  You can get Peruvian coffees and teas?  (In full disclosure, that company does import a Peruvian coffee but they failed to mention it on the menu... Who knows what they serve.) 

You can get more authentic Peruvian from one of the many smaller restaurants in North Bay (some in strip malls) run by families.  My advice:  go there first, then compare.

(You could always tweet Gaston about the experience, has two in my party did-- but the person whom manages his social media account just blocks people that say anything constructive.) Stay classy, Gaston.
author: Matt D.

description:
Took my friend here for her birthday. It was the perfect place to catch up over dinner and Fancy cocktails.

They give you complementary platanos chips which are soo good with the sauces. We shared the ceviche sampler which I highly recommend!:)
author: Cheri K.

description: Went to La Mar during the week with a co-worker for lunch. We used this app called Allset so we didn't have to wait for our food and got it right when we sat down. We shared the Cebiche Mixto which was INSANE and super fresh, the Yuquitas Huancaina, and the Tres Leches dessert (also insanely good). I will definitely be back again for lunch!
author: Stas M.

description:
This place is expensive, but unlike most places in the same price range, it was worth every penny.

Two good friends brought my bride and I here for a late lunch to celebrate our elopement.  Our waiter, Scott, was extraordinarily attentive, helpful, and gracious, with remarkable attention to detail.  From start to finish, the food was not just good, but fantastic--the piscos were perfectly crafted, the ceviche sampler shots had us drooling, and the appetizers alone sent us to cloud nine.  But the entrees were just as good: the beef I had (lomo saltado, I think?) was transcendent, and my wife's squid-ink rice was the best rice I have ever tasted.  We couldn't resist dessert, which was the only thing I would describe as "merely" excellent.

Great atmosphere, too, right on the Embarcadero.  Tip: the outside seating area was pretty noisy, so we moved inside, where there was still plenty of light and fresh air, and much more quiet.

Not an everyday hangout because of the steep prices, but if you are going to do some celebratory splurging, this place will blow your mind.
author: Parker I.

description:
empanada sampler- great
ceviche sampler- we devoured it
pulpo anticuchos - well done octopus skewers beautifully presented.
2 dishes off the specials menu- one was a pasta with a creamy aji sauce, seared scallops and shrimp. the other dish was served in a hot stone bowl, rice, pork, seafood, veggie and a thin omelette on top.

everything was SO good. 
sat outside on the water for lunch and the food just kept coming. impeccable service. my favorite meal in SF.
author: Og B.

description: Now this place blew me away with the food. The pisco was average (B-) but the food as well as the service were phenomenal. The location was perfect by the bay and each morsel added to the flavor. Brennan was our server and he could not have been more helpful on menu and portion recommendations. We started with the tasting portion for the ceviche trio out of which the mixto was mind blowing. The yuca that followed was amazing as well as the causas sampler. I thought that it was quite awesome that they allowed us to bring our own wine while they have a decent wine list.
author: Deepak P.

description:
This place is not really worth the hype. The food is good, but it's not worth the cost. The waitstaff is decent but could not give the attention to detail that this class of restaurant should provide. Get cocktails, which were awesome - especially with the jalapeño infused booze - and some empanadas. Then get out.  My hubby and I tried pretty much one of everything on the menu (minus the salads). The empanadas were the only noteworthy bite. 

Oh, I forgot to add that their bathrooms are absolutely disgusting! I saw a used pad on the ground and tp everywhere. I know this mess isn't the staff's but the patrons'. But seriously, it needs to get cleaned up ASAP!
author: Leah E.

description:
It's becoming rarer and rarer for me to go out with my friends without the addition of children. Don't misunderstand me, I love kiddos. They are great. Much like everything in life, there is a time and a place for other people's children. 

That said, my best girlfriend in San Francisco and myself set out all dressed up with nowhere to go. After realizing that we had erroneously thought we could get in somewhere without a reservation we just started driving along the Embarcadero. We finally settled on La Mar because it had good reviews and plentiful parking.

The good news is that the meal was delicious. The service was, after an initial hiccup where we were forgotten about mid-shift change, excellent.

I especially enjoyed the short ribs with white beans beans which was the highlight of the night for me. The empanada sampler was also delicious but I wasn't a huge fan of the sweet empanada - that could be because I prefer savory empanadas but you try it and let me know what you think.

I'm giving them three stars because of the initial service hiccup and for the fact that the food, while good, was not amazing.
author: Tara H.

description:
Valentine's Day dinner plans got a little ruined due to unbearable traffic in North Beach (CNY festival = all streets closed), we ended up at this very modern looking restaurant located on the Embarcadero. Seeing as we came in without reservations, they were only able to seat us at the ceviche bar. Totally understandable, of course. The dining room looked gorgeous though!

I'll preface this review by saying that all of my Peruvian food experiences prior to this one have been in small, mom-and-pop kind of environments. So it was definitely a change to see the cuisine dressed up all fancy, and not necessarily a good change. 

We ordered the Causas sampler, which was something new for me. I thought they were all really tasty and very different from one another, but my favorite was the one topped with tuna. Not anything I'll be pining for again in the future, but I did thorougly enjoy it. 

Ceviche Clasico - I'll always be happy when you put ceviche in front of me. That being said, the ceviche here was good, but nothing spectacular.

We also ordered the Lomo Saltado. Before coming to this restaurant, I already had a love for the lomo saltado I've had at the aforementioned mom-and-pop places in LA. So while I did think the Lomo Saltado here was excellent, I can't justify it's price. $32 for this dish? When I know I've had the same quality dish (in a less fancy environment) for a fraction of the price? If you've never had it and wanna try it here, you won't be disappointed. Your wallet might be though. 

We also ordered a mixed seafood with rice dish, the name of which is escaping me. Also very good, but pricey.

Overall, the food and ambiance would give this place a 4 star rating. However, with the sky high pricing on food I know I can get elsewhere for much cheaper knocks it down a star. For that reason alone I most likely won't be coming back.
author: Sally T.

description:
WOW-absolutely delicious seafood. Extremely fresh as if it were caught from the SF Bay 15 minutes before it was served. 

My friend-Ryan and I both love food and trying new restaurants. This time it was his turn to introduce me to a restaurant and he chose La Mar in the Embarcadero. The decor and ambiance felt very much like South Beach with the white washed walls and aqua blue and lime color accents. I was already loving the place. 

We had ordered the cebiche chalaco, causa limeña, the pollo anticuchos, accompanied with an Argentinian white wine-Siete Fincas, Torrontes. The cebiche was by far the freshest cebiche/ceviche I have ever tried. The causa limeña consisted of crab on top of a yellow potato causa. This was my favorite dish because of its beautiful presentation and the interesting dimensions of flavors and consistencies. Lastly was the pollo anticuchos which was pretty much a chicken skewer similar to what is served on the streets of Peru. 

All in all this is an outstanding restaurant and I will definitely be back to try all of the other amazing dishes.
author: Stef B.

description:
If I had to describe La Mar in one word, it would be cebiche.

The bf and I sat in the bar area on a Saturday night and the atmosphere was pretty "trendy".  The tables in the bar are first come, first serve and it seems more casual than sitting in their main dining room. 

We had a couple of cocktails and a variety of their cebiches including: the clasico, the mixto, and the nikei.  The clasico was definitely the best one and my least favorite was the nikei, which was good, but lacked the kick that the other cebiches had.

In addition to the cebiche clasico, another must-order is the chicken anticuchos (skewers).  The chicken was unbelievably tender and the sauces were amazing. 

Definitely try it out for the solid Peruvian cuisine and the trendy atmosphere!
author: Juliana K.

description:
Went for happy hour at 5pm on a Friday.  It was a major disappointment for the following reasons:
1. HH ends at 6pm vs. most places which run until 7pm.
2. This place is BUSY!  Chances of getting a table in the bar at this time seemed impossible.  It was nearly 40 min from the time we arrived until I had a drink in my hand.  
3. The staff seems way overwhelmed to handle the sort of crowds they get and as such were less than friendly.  
4.  It's Africa Hot in here.
author: Chris F.

description: I visited this restaurant with a large group and we specifically asked for the check to be split before we the waiter took our order. It seemed that he just shrugged it off like, "yeah I'll do that later". We all very much enjoyed the food and drinks but because we had to wait 30 minutes for the check to be split AFTER the meal I am giving this restaurant 3 stars. The manager was the one who ended up splitting our bill, after our waiter brought the bill and told us to figure it out. I was disappointed that the manager didn't offer to deduct a small percentage of the bill due to the serious delay that could have been avoided had the waiter listened to our request at the beginning of our meal.
author: Kristen T.

description:
Came for lunch with my work team today. We made reservations and while we probably could have done without, we were glad to have them since we got a great table outside on the patio. Beautiful atmosphere! I did notice they have heatlamps on some of it, so it would be ok to sit outside even if the weather is not beautiful and sunny like it was today.

They brought out chips of three varieties: plantian, potato, and either yam or sweet potato. The chips were so good I could not stop eating them! We requested more :-)

It was a work lunch so we were not drinking, and our waiter made it pretty clear he was disappointed by that. If I had one main complaint about La Mar it was the service which was spotty and inattentive at best. (Our waiter that is, water was refilled frequently.) We also felt very rushed to order. It's a fairly large menu which he did not explain to us at all, so we needed some time to review, and again he seemed irritated by that. 

I ordered the "sushi rolls" which were pretty good. The fish part was very good, but it came with what seemed to be thousand island on top which was not listed in the description and I scraped off.

Back to the service, most of us ordered just 1 dish but one person ordered the tasting menu which was so badly timed it was almost comical. Granted it was not an ideal situation, but he finished his bite-sized first course while we were all just getting started on our food, and then didn't get his second course until well after we had all finished ours and two reminders to our waiter later.

It was reasonable for a "fancy lunch", about $20 per person, but I would not rush back given the service. They included tip since we were a big group, so maybe that's why we were ignored.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Booked La Mar for a private party last month and was ecstatic about the food, location, service, decor.. Everything. After dining at multiple restaurants around the Embarcadero and at the Ferry Building, La Mar met my expectations and surpassed the competition. 

Seated outside on the patio, there were heat lamps and clear wind covers for when the sun went down. Our server was amazing. I loved the mixed ceviche, it was packed with large fresh pieces of seafood, I could eat it as my main course forever. Everything else was delicious and balanced each other out perfectly.

What I ordered:
- Ceviche Mixto
- Beef empanadas
- Causa nikei
- Arroz Norteno
- Lomo Saltado
- Pescado Nikei
- Yucca Fries
- Ensalada Limena

And they gave us a trio of desserts that were a nice way to finish the meal.
