Love it, would recommend it, would go back.
author: Shannon C.

description:
02/14/2013

I have never had Peruvian food, until that night of course. 

Beautiful, elegant, and welcoming decor. My one word would be POSH. 

You are immediately greeted with people with excitement, which is great, that's what you expect in a high end restaurant.

Since it was Valentine's day, and it was busy, my friend and I opted for seats at one of their two bars. 

Before I mention what I ordered, I have to say that their food is "amazing!". 

We ordered: (1) trio - fried oyster, beets, and crab on a bed of creamy mashed potatoes, (2) skewered beef hearts, (3) skewered salmon with balsamic, (4) red and black quinoa with tuna, (5) scallop and shrimp with rice, and (6) pomegranate jelly with pomegranate sauce. This was part of the special menu, so it varies to availability.

Our consensus was that our first course was our favorite due the complexity in flavors and the components that complimented each other. 

I personally liked the beef hearts, because I would have not known that it was heart, although, I would have preferred that every piece to be done medium. Our salmon course was well executed, which I loved the balsamic sauce! My friend loves quinoa and loved the idea of pairing that with seafood (she wants to recreate the dish, but with more vegetables and maybe a different seafood protein). My rice was delicious, although I would prefer more scallops over shrimp (the scallops were perfectly cooked). The pomegranate jelly was on the house (my friend thought it was too sweet), to me it was fine, I felt that the sweetness and the acidity of pomegranate works well after a heavy meal. 

Price wise, a bit hefty, but it's worth it, and it's alright - as my friend says "to indulge in once in a while". 

Oh one more thing, service was great! I know how stressful it can in the food industry, and our waiter was calm. 

A great place to dine!
author: Alex C.

description: One of the best seafood places I have been to. We ordered a ceviche, a causa, a tiradito, two main courses, and two desserts which was enough for three starving people. The plates were all excellent and went above our expectations. The only criticism I would make would be towards the slightly overpriced menu. Finally, I would recommend this place to everyone that is okay with eating spicy and very sour seafood dishes.
author: DJ B.

description:
Outstanding. Everything was great. Ask the waiter for an intro to the menu because it's not easy to understand. Lots of small
Plates but also have entrees. We shared a bunch of small plates and lots of drinks. It's not cheap, but it's very good. Got the obligatory pisco sour, but the pisco punch was outstanding. It's like a white sangria with pineapple. Overall great!
author: Kris P.

description: I've been here twice already and each time was magnificent. The service and food made it worth the drive from Milpitas. This restaurant is also my new go-to place for cocktails as well.
author: Phuong E.

description: Tried there sampler dish plus octopus ~ 28, worth tasting one time and recommend doing it with a group so you can test more dishes. That's too bad you can't take the banana / yam chips out. Nice service, since I got there early and there wasn't a huge crowd.
author: John C.

description: We have a large dinner group that eats out regularly. For all ten of us to be in agreement that a restaurant deserves 5 stars is rare. La Mar is one of the few. The food is delightfully different and delicious, the drinks are super, and the service was impeccable. And don't be the least bit bashful about asking for additional cones of plantain chips. The chips and the two dipping sauces are very tasty (and a bit addictive).
author: Bruce B.

description:
I love this place and will try and come again soon! Seafood was so fresh and everything is so well composed and tasty! 

Ordered crab over potatoes -deelish! 
Empanada trio- yum!
Ceviche- also good
Sea bass with shellfish in a red sauce for the main course- super tasty! Reminded me a little like a choppino in the beginning, but it got better and better as I ate it. 

No left overs...but I felt satisfied and not overly full when I left.
author: Monica S.

description:
WHO. . .    Group of three - The boyfriend, friend from out of town, & myself

WHAT. . .  We started off the meal with Pisco Sours, recommended by the server. 
                   Which were yummy... as for the menu/ tons of options, a bit over 
                   whelming... so actually it was perfect that it was also Dine About Town -  
                   two choices to choose from. Either a Vegetarian or Non-Vegitation option. 
                   All three of us went with the 1st option. 

                   - First plate, a appetizer/main course duo - fish & squid ceviche paired with 
                     a skewered skirt steak. Both great, but my favorite of the two - steak. 
                   - Second plate, dessert was a lemon pudding/tart cup - lite & citrus flavors

WHEN. . . Saturday early afternoon for lunch 12:30ish/ During Dine about town
                  Not too crowded, lots of open seats at the bar & outside seating area. 
                  Really close to the Embarcadero farmers market.

WHERE. . .We didn't have reservations, however they were still able to accommodate  
                  us in the covered patio area. It was a chilly day, but they did have the heat  
                  lamps on periodically. There outside area also has a great view of the bay,  
                  I actually preferred it better to the inside. Great vibe, vibrant & bright 
                  atmosphere.

WHY. . .   Just in the mood for something different... had a friend in from out of town & 
                 wanted to try a different/fun... haven't been to too many Peruvian restaurants 
                 in the city. We also heard many great things about the bar...
author: Teena Marie T.

description:
Una receta para una noche fantastica:

3 parts Pisco
1 part lime juice
1 part sugar
1/2 part egg white
ice
bitters

A few pisco sours and your night will be fantastic indeed. Maybe you'll even be speaking Spanish by the end.
But, say you want something extra special, you're going to need to add a few dashes of good company before you shake.

And really, you're gonna wanna wash down a ceviche sampler with the Pisco Sour.

Clutch: bring a shot-size container and pour off the marinade from the ceviche (called "Leche de Tigre") Take this home and sip away the following morning when your head is pounding as a result of one too many the night before.

Thus concludes your recipe for success.

(As for the Pisco Sour, this should get you started: http://www.piscotrail.com/2011/04/13/drinks/pisco-sour/ )

***

If you're exhibiting restraint (and orderly behavior), you'll want to put some food in that belly so you'll try the grilled skewers (Anticuchos, traditionally beef heart, but they offer a variety), a plate of lomo saltado (Chinese-Peruvian beef stir fry) and a dish of arroz jugoso chock full of seafood. Share everything.

When you think you've had enough, the non-donut lover in you and your best company orders the picarones - Peruvian donuts made with sweet potato flour and a lick-it-off-your-fingers syrup.

Buen provecho!
author: Alissa A.

description:
-----------DINE ABOUT TOWN MENU---------------
3.5

I've been wanting to check this place out for the longest time so I was pretty stoked when Dine About Town offered a menu that actually included their popular items (usually restaurants will just include some crap items in order to get you in the door).

Causa Limena - Dungeness crab on top of a yellow potato. Loved this little appetizer. But I love crab & avocado so that made it really easy to like
Cebiche Mixto - Catch of the day, calamari and shrimp. It was reallllllllllly tangy. A little too tangy for my taste but if you're into that, you might like this. 
Lomo Saltado - One of their popular dishes and this was probably my favorite. Very good flavors & I ate the entire thing
Passion Fruit Tart - Pretty standard but still delicious

The restaurant is huge so it's pretty easy to make a reservation. Service is whatever. 

Overall, the meal was pretty solid so I don't think you'll be disappointed. But it's not mind blowing in any sense and I wouldn't go out of my way to try it. But if you come here, it'll most likely still be a satisfying meal.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I think I was overly generous with my stars.  I'm taking two back.

Took my family here for lunch on Father's Day.  The service was really slow - they weren't even packed.  While I still enjoyed their ceviche and empanadas, I was totally disappointed with my plate dish.  I asked the server what was their best sandwich and he recommended the chicken.  I'm not huge on chicken breast  but since he recommended it, I thought i'd give it a try.  And sure enough..the chicken was dry, bland, and chewy  Additionally, the fish dish was a huge disappointment. Dry and bland. The plate dishes were a total let down. 

Stick to the appetizers and salads!
author: Diana M.

description:
I did my reservation 2 days before at La Mar, using Open Table, because I was planning a dinner to celebrate my boyfriend's MBA graduation! And I wanted to have a great dinner in a recommended place as La Mar...but I ended up so disappointed of my choice! 

First, I have to say that every time that I look for a place to eat I use Yelp. Maybe I'm not doing reviews but I really trust in this website and previous experiences! And for La Mar I should trust more in those bad reviews because some of them are very accurate!

Now I'll try to sum up the worst experience that I ever had in a restaurant since I moved to San Francisco:
1- I did a reservation specifying that I wanted to be seated at the patio (waterfront). I also called to La Mar 2 days before to be very clear about this. What happened? We were seated in the middle of the restaurant, not the patio, and when I asked about my request, the hostess was very rude saying that there is no guarantee about that and if we want the patio we had to wait 45 min, So...Ok, we took the table inside.
2- 5 minutes later they put us in a table at the patio and when we went outside they had so many reserved empty tables! I did a reservation too!!
3- Besides this we wanted to have a great time so Ok, we ordered 2 pisco drinks and they NEVER came to our table. 
4- they never did the water refill to our glasses. 
5- They did a discount in our check, but...honestly, I was so disappointed of choosing that place to celebrate an important event that the discount is nothing compare to how embarrassed I was.

Those 2 starts are just for the food, we had cebiche Classico, a Nikkei plate and a vegetarian causa and all of them were Amazing! Really really good! I think that they spend money in good chefs and not in good service.

Remember, people go to your restaurant the first time because of the food, but they go back because of the hospitality! So...for us was our first and last time there! Thanks!
author: Mariale N.

description:
The complimentary yucca, plantain, and potato chips in the beginning are absolutely fantastic. If they weren't complimentary, I would spend $10, if not more on these, and the Huancaína sauces that they come with. The orange one has more of a kick to it, and the yellow one reminds you of a fancy version of nacho cheese (this is a good thing, not bad). Both pureed salsas are amazingly delicious and addictive.

I am a big fan of ceviches, and surprisingly, my favorite one here is the "cebiche nikei", which consists of Ahi Tuna, red onion, Japanese cucumber and avocado in tamarind leche de tigre. It is the perfect meld of sweetness and tang. 

Also ordered the anticuchos de corazon. Came out piping hot on the silver skewer with peruvian corn, perfectly fried potatoes, and spicy rocoto sauce. A different sauce, but again, amazing tastiness.

I've also been at lunch and ordered a trio of things, which included ceviche and some sort of causa. It was a while ago and I can't remember what exactly it was, but I remember the causa melting in my mouth because it was so divine. This place tells you to go to the ceviche, but really, you should go here for the causa.

The service here is polite, fast, and friendly. A little too fast sometimes though, was still eating the corn off my plate, and had two wait staff ask if I was ready to take it away. They also cleaned off my area of the bar, and took my table cloth, even though I was still eating chips. Can't complain if that keeps the crowded restaurant clean though.

it is on the pricey side, but for a waterfront restaurant, that's normal. And trust me, you don't want or need bigger portions. These foods are not meant to be eaten in larger quantities. That would only take away from the taste explosion in your mouth!
author: Michelle N.

description:
La Mar has a notorious reputation for being one of the best Peruvian restaurants in the San Francisco Bay Area. I had the pleasure of dining at this trendy restaurant with my good friend and her best friend. Lucky for me, they are both of Peruvian descent and they both knew exactly what to order. If you don't fall in love with the food, you will definitely fall in love with the restaurant's bright and trendy decor. I loved all of the colorful accents around this restaurant, especially the bright teal menus. 

For appetizers, we ordered Causas and Empanadas. Not only were the Causas absolutely delicious, they were so pretty that I almost didn't want to eat it. The Empanadas were appetizing, however, a bit too salty for my taste. For my main course, I ordered the Almuercito Carretillero which consisted of mixed seafood cebiche, chicken, rice and yucca fries with huancaina sauce. I am a big fan of anything Cebiche and I was told that this would be a good choice for me. My Cebiche entree was absolutely delicious. I highly recommend ordering this dish, especially if you prefer chicken as oppose to red meat. 

A fun fact about La Mar is that it is located at Pier 1.5. Be careful or you may actually miss this place while walking by...
author: Viennelyn C.

description:
There appears to be a lot of money invested into this restaurant.  It's a nice location, with interesting furniture, really cool flower displays, and superstar chef creations (at least to me).
But I have to say our recent visit to La Mar was one of the worst restaurant experiences we've ever had.  Not just in SF, but across the globe.

The waiter was a big part of it.  He was disinterested, rude, and towards the end downright scary - like if I weren't already trapped in the restaurant for 3 hours, we would have spoken with the management if it seemed like it would have mattered.
The second thing that jumped out at me was the smell of fish at the main dining area (I'd recommend sitting outside).  You know how sometimes there is a good fish smell and a bad fish smell?  this was the bad side.

The graphic design of the menus was really cool - I loved the colors.  Pisco sours were also good - as was the steak option mixed with vegetables.  I wasn't a fan of the empanadas but I know that others in our group liked them.  Nothing jumped out as spectacular though - and you kind of think you'll get something like that with the location and prices being charged.

The dessert was the brightest spot for me.  We had the special which had a small bit of ice cream with a wafer and a few other interesting ingredients that were creatively placed on the plate.  I am a big fan of small plates and appropriately sized portions (many places have portions that are far too big).  But this was on the other end of the scale when price was taken into consideration.

What I would tell friends about this place is that you'd probably be better off just about anywhere in the city.  If you want an intimate restaurant, wonderful view, good value, and friendly staff, this isn't the place.  

Our experience at this restaurant, early in a week long trip to San Francisco, made me wonder if the time has come and gone for San Francisco restaurant scene.  It was shocking.
author: Ted S.

description: This place  is simply  divine! All house cocktails   and ceviches , calamari  almost  everything worth  to try. Definitely recommended!
author: Mehtap C.

description:
Aesthetically spectacular - particularly if you can grab a table out back near the water. 

Service is timely and attentive, and perhaps a bit overbearing. Water glass never got more than half full - or half empty depending on your perspective. 

The fried potato appetizers are addicting and complimentary, prepare to eat a few buckets of those. 

For four people we ordered one tuna ceviche, one order of grilled octopus over a mashed potato concoction (mixed w basil and delicious) and a pair of veggie empanadas to go with our paella - which turned out to be nearly the perfect amount.
The seafood paella was fresh, creamy and a surprisingly large portion. 

Overall the service was an A-, ambience was an A, value is a B+ and taste is an A.
author: Seth S.

description:
Dined here on a Friday around 6 - reservations were required, but seating was available at the bar.

Pluses: 
+ delicious variety of Peruvian cuisine
+ cold and hot dishes (we ordered a mixed seafood ceviche, grilled octopus, paella and empanadas)
+ house made chips brought to the table with dip
+ high ceilings and beautiful ambience
+ very knowledgable wait staff

Minuses:
- small portions for the price

Enjoy!
author: Grace Y.

description:
I wandered over after opening day at ATT Park and sat in the bar and had dinner. I had the mixed ceviche and the yucca fries off the happy hour menu and the grilled octopus dinner.

The mixed ceviche was not a winner; the squid was OK but the shrimp was pasty and flavorless and the fish the bartender told me would be halibut was definitely not halibut. I think it was yellowtail, which is great but frankly the sauce and seasoning made it so I couldn't really taste the fish.

The yucca fries were very tasty at first but they weren't peeled enough and I got a mouthful of what tastes like floury dental floss with every bite. Not nice and I had to pick it out of my teeth at the bar. Glad I wasn't on a date.

The grilled octopus itself was very good. The texture was just right and the seasoning was great.

One thing I don't get is the hominy in everything. When it's just boiled and served cold, like it was in the ceviche it just tastes bland and once again, pasty. When they fry it they turn into hard oily plastic bits. I couldn't find a reason to eat them. I kept thinking I would never put something like that on a plate and expecting a guest to like it.

I will say that despite being very crowded the service was generally fast and very nice. The bar tenders were running like crazy but managed to so with a smile. 

My dinner cost $45 including tax and tip (no alcohol, salad or dessert) and while it was a bit pricey the location is perfect and the building is very nice. If the food had been more human-friendly I would have loved the place.
author: Scott H.

description:
Great experience and the food was delicious. We both had seafood and really enjoyed our meal.
Our wine wasn't as good as we had hoped and I wish they would have suggested one to us instead.

We did enjoy our evening though and our waiter was very friendly. The prices are high, but we expected that in San Francisco.
author: Mareike B.

description: A great spot for date night! The pisco sours are delicious and food is on point. Start with causa tasting and chose a ceviche depending on your preference. I like the ceviche mixto. We also tried the empanada sampler. All were yummy! For the entree, lomo saltsdo is always safe and satisfying. The waitress recommended a dish that was delicious! I forgot the name of it and she mentioned that they were removing it from the menu. I think it was the plancha de mar? Basically seafood on a hot skillet/griddle. It was soooo tasty and was mixed with potatoes. The octopus and calamari is really good here. I still crave for the dish as I write this review. Sad that it's off the menu. :(
author: Linda P.

description:
Turquoise is Pantone's color of the year for 2010 because it "evokes thoughts of soothing, tropical waters and a languorous, effective escape from the everyday troubles of the world, while at the same time restoring our sense of well-being."

Well at La Mar, you get turquoise - and all the same emotive qualities it brings. A mid-week lunch becomes a Peruvian escape, especially when the sun peaks through the SF fog and shines its beams through the many windows and brightens up the entire place. I honestly did feel like my sense of well-being was restored. 

On to the food. Let's start with the home-made chips. They are seasoned with crack I swear. There were different varieties of potatoes and plantains and 3 different dipping sauces that we couldn't stop munching on. 

We started with the cebiche tasting.  Out of the 4, the Mixto (Mahi Mahi with squid and octopus) was our least favorite but it was still actually really good which tells you how much we enjoyed it. The standouts on the platter were the chifa ("chinese" style mahi mahi) and the clásico (halibut). The seafood was so fresh and the flavors were simply bright and delightful - absolute joy to eat. 

Next up were the empanada sampler and the causa sampler. Let's start with the empanadas. Wonderfully flaky pastry encasing delightful fillings. The chicken, beef, and seafood empanadas were delicious but wait till you bite into the one with the corn. Maybe it's the freshness of the produce but while it looks modest, it comes alive in your mouth. 

The Causas were little pieces of art. I appreciated all the intricate work that went into each mound of whipped potatoes and the toppings. Unfortunately, it went in a hurry. 3 bites later and it was gone; hardly fair considering the amount of work that went into it. 

Wash all this down with a Pisco sour and close your eyes for a second while the staff clear your plates and bring you the check in their heavy latin american accents. Soon you will leave Peru and when you open your eyes, remember that it's back to the real world. Sigh.
author: Jon L.

description: great plantain chips, corn empenadas and amazing dessert. Bad thing was the entree I had the ordered (veggie quinoa) the waiter failed to mention it had mushrooms and raw bean sprouts after I asked him what was in it... which I strongly dislike.
author: Raymond H.

description: The food was okay. I would expect much more for the price. And the service was the worst. The server walked off with my drink still full. He did not even bother to ask me before he took it. And in fact when I mentioned it to him. He actually had a fit. Storming off to get my drink from God knows where he left it. I refused. I explained an apology was enough. And he kept arguing with me. He eventually apologized but it was not sincere in my opinion. I am shocked. Go to Coqueta down the road so much better.
author: Penelope S.

description:
Honestly the best service I have ever experienced.

Drinks & food were phenomenal. I had the cardamom mule and the Pisco sour. Both delicious. A couple nice Peruvian beer options which was cool, along with a nice beer selection in general. We tried the cebiche la mar, pulpo anticuchos, and causa nikei for dinner. For dessert we had choco-maracuya. All of it was simply amazing. I cannot begin to describe it. Cebiche la mar was a great way to try several of their lovely ceviches. The fish was great quality and there was a nice mix of traditional and fusion dishes. They do offer a lot of options, but the staff is SO helpful that it was never overwhelming. 

Also their chips - what! Amazing mix of plantain & potato and some crazy good sauces.

Possibly the best place on the Embarcadero. Please eat here & tip your waiter well!!! They absolutely deserve it.
author: Kate B.

description:
This restaurant is just okay for me!!! We walked in without a reservations on a weekday night and got seat right away. Their foods was pretty good, I can tell every ingredients was fresh and well prepared. 
Okay, but why only three stars??? Because their not so friendly service, I even had to asked for the free sweet potato and potato chips and our waiter gave me a wth face. Well, if u don't care about your customers than why I have to come back. Your foods is good but there many restaurant out there have a similar foods but with a good customer service
author: Mavis L.

description:
Taking a leaf out of Yelp's book, vegetarians do NOT go nuts for this spot, and that's because their menu favors seafood lovers. However, the food is pretty good, and the presentation is exquisite. 

Vegetarian causas: Whipped yellow potatoes topped with avocado. Explosion of flavors, thoroughly delicious; wish it had more texture, though.
Mushroom empanada: Nothing to write home about; just your regular empanada. 
Wok-friend quinoa: Too oily for my taste. I liked the bits of eggs, and I did not like the bean sprouts for it messed with the texture of this dish.
Grilled chicken skewers: Portion size, not so great; flavors, pretty great.
Chocolate crepes and panna cotta: I don't remember much about the crepes and the panna cotta coz I was busy floating to heaven. DELICIOUS!

4 stars for the food, 4 stars for the service, 5 stars for the complimentary baskets of plantain, potato, and sweet potato chips.
author: Divya R.

description:
This is a quality establishment. The owner certainly knows how to run a fine restaurant. Everything from the great service to the quality of the cuisine was top notch. The inside dining area was clean and spacious with great views of the bay and the Bay Bridge. 
Most of the servers/chefs are Peruvian. They are very knowledgable when asked questions about the various dishes on the menu that only a local would know about. I was very impressed. The ceviche was some of the best I've had, and the empanadas can't be outdone. I had a great experience and would definitely return.
author: Rex G.

description: I came here with my family after Christmas off of the recommendation of a friend. The drinks were really good, especially the chicha. The empanadas were decent as well. But everything else was mediocre at best. The lomo saltado was extremely salty. We ended up getting a bunch of stuff and sharing, but frankly, they aren't worth writing about. The other thing that was disappointing was the service. Our waiter forgot about us several times. First, he forgot what drinks we ordered and then he forgot what entrees we ordered (literally). It was just an all around bad experience. I would recommend Pucquio over this place if you are interested in Peruvian food.
author: Hassaun V.

description:
I heard about this place for a long time and being Peruvian I had to try it. I was in SF for work and on the last day of my stay, my co-workers and I took a cab to Pier 1/2 to have dinner just a few hours before our flight back to LA.

We started with Pisco sours all around of course! 

I wanted my co-workers to try my diverse Peruvian cuisine and I wanted to try as many dishes I could so I ordered many dishes for all of us to share.

Lomo Saltado - One of the best lomos I've had. So tender and flavorful. 
Ceviche Clasico - Halibut was very fresh and cut right for ceviche. 
Anticucho Corazon - beef heart... I love it and it was done well.
Causa Limena - it was good but it wasn't great.

My friend ordered the Empanada Sampler which I'm not a big fan of and I was right, it was just okay. The empanadas were small with not much filling inside.

The presentation of the dishes was exceptional. The place looks clean and very modern. I enjoyed the open kitchen. I highly recommend those who want to try Peruvian cuisine, go to a hole in a wall restaurant first so you can enjoy the fancy ones later.
author: Richie D.

description: Fantastic service! Their food is amazing the staff are very friendly and willing to make suggestions from their unique menu. This is certainly a SF gem!
author: Tristan B.

description:
Peruvian food is underrated, in my opinion. It's one of the most delicious and versatile cuisines in the world offering something for everyone--the vegetarian, the meat and potatoes guy, the steak lover, the pescatarian, the spice lover, etc. I personally prefer more hole-in-the-wall Peruvian restaurants, but every once in a while, it's nice to dress up and go somewhere glamorous and upscale to get my ceviche and Pisco Sour fix. 

La Mar is great for a date night or a night out with the girls. The menu offers some of the country's best and most well-known dishes, balanced out with more daring and inventive creations. As a general rule, I usually order the tried-and-true the first time I'm at a Peruvian restaurant because that's how I judge its quality and authenticity. 

My Pisco Sour was frothy, sharp and delicious, but it could have been a bit sweeter (the Pisco Sours I had in Peru always had a sweet touch--usually the addition of nutmeg or cinnamon). My friend and I decided to share a bunch of dishes and ordered:

Anticucho Carne - An oldie but a goodie. The meat was perfectly grilled and came out slightly crisp on the outside and juicy on the inside. The seasoning was fantastic and the accompanying potatoes were delicious. A satisfying, hearty dish

Ceviche Clasico - Classic ceviche usually features an assortment of white fish (and sometimes other seafood), so I was a little disappointed that La Mar's only had one kind (halibut) at the shocking price of $17. It was done well and the cuts were generous, but I don't think it's a very good deal overall. The leche de tigre, while tangy, had far too much pepper (???) and not enough garlic

Mushroom Empanada - Crisp and delicious

Dungeness Crab Causas - The presentation was beautiful and the causas had just the right texture. However, I found the aji amarillo incredibly disappointing. It was missing that flavor kick I'm used to

Queso Helado - Peru's answer to kulfi or gelato, this delicious, creamy dessert originating from Arequipa is one of my favorite kinds of ice-cream. La Mar's is quite good

Choco-Maracuya - How can you resist edible 24K gold? This was very well made, but by this point, I was stuffed so my friend ended up finishing most of it. Worth ordering if you're going to split it with someone

Overall, I think La Mar is a great place to go for Peruvian newbies and those less gastronomically adventurous. It's worth a repeat visit but in the meantime, I will continue searching for a casual, hole-in-the-wall Peruvian eatery like the ones I enjoyed in East Boston.
author: Josephine L.

description:
La Mar is decent (the pisco sours are quite good), but given the price point is it woth it?  No.  

Although there is nothing wrong with the food (ceviche mixto and arroz jugoso were fairly tasty and well balanced), it doesn't really stand out, and you are really paying for the atmosphere and presentation.  I'd be happy to come back if someone else were paying, but if there are plenty of cheaper options if you are simply looking for good Peruvian food.
author: Chris C.

description: Was here with a friend in from out of town and had a great meal! Cocktails were delicious and food was great. We didn't have reservations but managed to find space for 5 at the communal table in the front and the service was great! Will go back
author: Allie M.

description:
Open for almost four years, Gaston Acurio's La Mar Cebicheria Peruana has become a SF favorite for stellar Peruvian food.

With a fantastic location on Pier 1  1/2, the restaurant features a separate bar and the spacious dining room.  The bar is always a hot after work stop, the restaurant usually requires reservations.

Your dining experience will begin with complimentary fried plantains and potatoes accompanied by two sauces. Of course, in a cebicheria, seafood is the star, and you cannot miss with any ceviche.  Fresh and citrusy, the cebiche classico ($17) features California halibut in a tigre de leche sauce spiced with habanero. The causas (little bite size balls of mashed yellow potatoes with a hidden center of crab, $12) are tasty.  With light, airy crust, the empanadas ($11) are a good bet as well.  Served in a light broth with ginger and hot sesame oil, the halibut ($26) was flaky and moist.  

The skilled servers are professional and attentive, although dishes arrive somewhat languidly.

La Mar features a full bar and an ample wine list, but don't leave without sampling a Pisco sour (or two): they're so delicious and they disappear so rapidly you would think there's a hole in your glass.

There are many choices for Peruvian food in The City, but La Mar Cebicheria Peruana is certainly one of the best.
author: CJ G.

description:
Have your gallon of milk ready because you are in for a hot ride. I have never had ceviche in my life before I came here and boy did La Mar set the bar very high for me. I did the sampling which is a collection of their best civiches: Clásico, Mixto, Chalaco, and Nikei. I remember my first bite like it was yesterday. Sweet, milky, sour and spicy, It was sooooo...good. Some super spicy, some not too spicy but that depends on your tolerance for spice. I happen to eat chili so I'm pretty tolerant. 
They also have their own version of Paella. Arroz Norteño 21North Peruvian seafood combination with fried rice. Sauteed with black beer, cilantro and Huancaína sauce. Yum!!! Another favorite of mine is the risotto or sticky rice (not so sure) with squid ink. Gotta try this one it will blow you away. Just make sure to rinse you teeth before you smile as it tends to leave black residue. 

I think I left my heart in San Francisco.  =(
author: Joan M.

description: I've been to this place 3 times in the last few years, and I must admit it has grown on me. For one thing, the quality of the food has improved.The ceviche was very good; light and flavorful and not too overly dressed. The other dishes included an amazing sparerib dish and a bunch of other awesome appetizers. The location can't be beat either - being down by the waterfront is quite nice on a warm night.
author: David Z.

description: Mmmm had my bday dinner here with my girls.  Great atmosphere, great location, easy parking lot across the street and most importantly good food!  I love dining with a group of girls because we share our food and so get to taste a variety of the menu...everything was so good!  The seafood apps, empanadas, short ribs, desserts, etc!  Can't wait to go back!
author: R F.

description:
If you are not Peruvian,  this is a place to get a sample of Peruvian food.
Very nice atmosphere and the patio can be very relaxing on a sunny day.
If you are Peruvian, prepare to leave hungry. Portions are small. Maybe it is a new miracle diet where you pay for eating only a third of what you expected to get. Also $5 for a chicha morada, c'mon! My wife ordered a dcoke and never got a refill or offered another one. Service was mediocre. Not my type of Peruvian rest. Try Mancora Cebicheria or Inca Grill in Concord.
If I am paying, I am not coming here again.
author: Mi Opinon Y.

description: In the midst of the most touristic area of SF you will find this cute, chic Peruvian style bar/restaurant. The service was great, waiters friendly and professional and the food was amazing. Portions aren't huge but we like it thus way so you can share and try more things. Refreshing flavours (cilantro, red onions, spicy pepers, a bit too much mayo base). Definitely recommend it!
author: Naomi B.

description:
I love this place so much. It's a real Peruvian food heaven hidden from the stream of people going past the various piers. It is such an amazing food experience. I love everything about it... food, atmosphere, music, service, view, colors, presentation.

The menu is very  imaginative. La Mar is a little pricey for the portions but the flavors make up for it.  The plaintain chips with dipping sauce are a nice way to start your meal! Delicious!

Usually my husband and I order few dishes to share and each time it's just amazing. You can't go wrong with anything there. But we really recommend to try empanada sampler ($19) and any of the cebiches ($12 - $15). Just yummy!

They also have an outstanding menu for cocktails. You always can ask a waiter for a special drink (alcoholic and non-alcoholic ) and they will create something interesting and unuusual out of their head. 

The only negative thing about this place is that sometimes they bring the dishes not in order you ordered them which can be a little annoying. Last time we asked why it happens. Apperently some dishes are ready to go and some need more time for preperation so if you want your orders be delivered to your table in order ask the waiter to do so.

And if you are a fan of sushi, you'll love it there even more! You just must try one of their rollitos (Japanese inspired sushi rolls made with Peru's finest ingredients ($12) ). Last time we tried rollitos with onion salad on top of it. Fantastic!

Check some photos on my blog: http://www.nadyassideoftheroad.com/2012/08/la-mar-peruvian-heaven.html
author: Nadya Z.

description: Everything in this place is delicious! The staff is very nice and they make you feel welcome. Love their happy hour specials! Highly recommended!!
author: Isanna L.

description:
Arrived 15 minutes before our 8:45 pm reservation and were seated early. We sat there with menus for 10 minutes while we watched tables all around being served. We were never greeted but the waiter who appeared that he might be our waiter said he'd be right with us when we motioned for help. He never introduced himself to us, never came to take our drink order, never apologized (that perhaps he was too busy with other tables) -- all the usual, customary things that one would expect from a waiter when dining out, we got the opposite of that. 

We watched painfully as he worked the tables all around us, obviously ignoring us for whatever reason. Then it seemed like he was calling someone over -- that person came to our table and asked if he could take our drink order. We gave him our drink order and he went over to the table behind us to answer questions about the menu for 5 minutes or so. We motioned for him because, well, we might as well order appetizers while we were waiting. So we put in an order in for their famous Cebiche La Mar. At that point in time he said we'd have to remind him about our drink order because clearly he hadn't put the order in and had forgotten it while he waited on the table behind us.

Keep in mind that no one has introduced themselves to us at any point in time. We should expect better service than this from Denny's.

The drinks and ceviche arrived but the ceviche was unacceptably bland. Normally, ceviche is marinated for some time. The highly touted Cebiche Lar Mar tasted like the fish was mixed in the marinade right before it was served.

We had already spoken to the maitre'd about this issue on the way out so this should not be any surprise.

We had already spent $66 on an appetizer and 2 drinks that were obviously not worth it.  We weren't going to spend anymore money at a restaurant that is unfamiliar with how to treat customers.
author: Spicy T.

description:
Delicious!

The plaintain and yucca chips to start came with two tasty salsas. The Pisco Sour has a bit too much egg white foam on top, but still very tasty. 

The Cebiche Mixto's ingredients were very fresh.

The short ribs (forget the exact name) were great as well, and the portions were big enough to share.
author: Angie K.

description: Amazing, fresh ceviche. Would highly recommend the happy hour, and trying the pisco sour. It's an acquired taste, but highly worth trying at least once. Would also recommend the arroz del mar for the entree, my friend got it and it was full of seafood and the rice was flavored particularly well.
author: Jialin Z.

description: I was here for Vday and they had an excellent pre fixed menu for the occasion. I ordered the octopus and my bf ordered the tuna ceviche. That was an excellent option. The food was great and the service was ideal. If you come, take a chance and try the beef heart. It was very good, although the portion may be too big but that's never a bad thing. I would come back here!
author: Doan T.

description:
The cebiche here is fantastic! My favorite being the cebiche clasico. Incredibly refreshing and oh so addicting. I love coming here just for that! That and the yummy plantain chips. I find myself ordering the same thing over and over. Next time, I definitely plan on ordering the cebiche tasting variety to ensure a little bite of everything. I also thought the Peruvian whipped potato sampler was tasty and unique. I was very interested in the fact that I was able to detect a hint of Chinese influence from the Peruvian dishes as stated by our server. I love impromptu history lessons!

The lomo saltado is also melt in your mouth good. The pollo anticucho skewers were simple and tasty along with the accompanying dipping sauces. The sandwiches here are just okay. 

Seating here is great when you get to sit outside. Overlooking the bay, great food, and good company. I loved it. Perfect, attentive service each and every time.
author: Ann S.

description:
Pros
Beef hearts
Beef empanadas
Ceviche nikei
Ceviche clasico

Cons
Spotty service
I don't know if they pace out your food, but it took an hour to get our whole order out. 
Price

As much as I liked the food, the prices reflect the "area" as well as the "fine dining" aesthetic. I knew before hand the prices, and was prepared to pay, but what you are actually paying for is the location. You can get great ceviche/ Peruvian food elsewhere and for a cheaper price. It's not spectacular, but it is really good. 

I would recommend this place, and I will definitely go back, it's just that it's a hard to pay those prices for essentially street food. But I guess that's what happens when you set up shop at the piers and introduce a wine list.
author: Ricardo H.

description:
La Mar is a beautiful airy restaurant on pier 1 1/2. The space is definitely worthy of five stars as it has high ceilings, white walls and medium dark hardwood floors.   The setup is good for intimate conversation as nothing is crammed together.   We were seated adjacent to the open kitchen and enjoyed the view, both around the restaurant and across the table (at each other of course). 
I asked the bar tender to whip me up a non alcoholic cocktail that was flavorful.  
The Causa Tasting was too pretty to eat until our waiter showed us how to mash them for guilt free consumption. The vegetarian (Causa Rusa) was my favorite which is an added bonus considering meat is murder. That said,  we thoroughly enjoyed consuming fish (in our Cebiche) while it still exists in the oceans.  The Halibut  (Cebiche Clasico) was spot on. The Cebiche Chifa was a bit too spicy for me, but my date loved it.  Shy Northern European who loves spicy food? Spicy ethnic girl who wouldn't mind it slightly less so?   Go figure.
We walked around the Embarcadero, North Beach and FIDI for about an hour and half afterward. That was an adventure/education in chivalry (holding hand and protecting girl from wet walkways, excited homeless people and uneven surfaces), communication (what are your hopes, fears, dreams, funny quirks) and the need to bring an extra pair of comfortable walking shoes for such occasions.
author: Zak R.

description: I am really torn on writing this review. Lets start with the food, top tier. The food overall was a 4.5 out of 5. We arrived and had a reservation for 8. They sat us in this back room area (where they usually have the new years celebration) and it was a covered heat patio. Thats not a big deal but they had a private event that was SO LOUD I couldnt hear the person next to me. We asjed this very nice gentleman if we could move and he was very accomadating and got us a table by the bar. So far so good. Our new waitress was this woman with shortish hair. She was very unpleasant, unfriendly and not very attentive. We waited forever for our drinks which were okay. She didn't come to check in onnis often and generally just seemed lole an unpleasant person. Wish I had the waiter in the noisy section lol.
author: Daniel T.

description:
Just finished writing a review for OpenTable so I thought I'd shout out to Yelp.

First of all, Nick.  Oh Nick.  You were the best.  You made it very clear that we were your favorite guests in the whole restaurant.  You made trip after trip to drop off appetizers, more appetizers, and more snackies during the cocktail party mixer we attended Aug 26.  You were tireless, witty, and fun.  You even did the legwork to make sure our table was ready when our reservation time came.  

We made a later reservation for the restaurant, to which we adjourned after leaving the mixer.  Nick turned us over to our new server, who was terrific, but wasn't Nick.

Now for the food.  My friends think I'm the most amazing restaurant filter in California, and this place just blew them away.  Your menu and service made me look incredibly smart, educated, and refined.  In reality this is not necessarily the case - but you wouldn't know it by my choice of restaurants.

We shared ceviche, they had a couple of entrees, and we all had the wine and pisco sours.  The plantain & sweet potato chips were fantastic - a wonderful bit of starch to counter the pure protein of the ceviche.  The tiger milk sampler was really tasty, as were all the various ceviches in the sampler we shared.

All in all we had a terrific time.  I wish I lived closer so I could frequent this place more often.  Five stars, plus Nick!  What more could you ask for?
author: a.m. m.

description:
The GOOD: Staff, they are very kind. Pisco Sour is good (but too pricey), i can make one even better (using the same Barsol pisco). Sweet potatos are insanely goooood. Lomo Saltado and pisco sour are the only things that can make you feel like eating in Peru, everything else is good in general but not as a real peruvian food.

The BAD: Pricey. If you are going just for Cebiche, there's other places where you can find it for less, more quantity and same quality.

The UGLY: Americanized peruvian food. Its so weird that a peruvian restaurant from the most famous peruvian chef (Gaston Acurio), doesn't have "Aji de Gallina" and other typical peruvian dishes in the menu. And i can`t believe that Dessert Menu (selected by Gaston's wife) does not included "Suspiro Limeño"!! COME ON!!, instead you can have a Creme Brulee, which is really good, but is a americanized version because taste like Burnt Caramel (a flavor no so common in South American cuisine), other good ones are choco-maracuya (another not-peruvian dessert) and pannacotta.
author: Gio S.

description:
The boyfriend and I came here for dinner. It was both our first time and we ordered way too many appetizers because everything sounded so good. 

The one thing I want to rave about this place is their customer service. I ordered an entree my server suggested because he said it was one of the popular picks on the menu. By the time we got our entrees i was already stuffed so I didn't touch my food much . The server came back and noticed and offered to take it off the bill because it looked like i didn't enjoy it...I FELT SO BAD. Thanks La Mar. You really showed us what great customer service is.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Cannot emphasize how amazing this place was, from the food to the service to the decor. The ambience is very South American, with bright blue woven chairs and Latin music in the background. The tables outside have a gorgeous view of the ocean, but since we came at night we opted to sit inside. Our server was extremely helpful and knowledgable about what each sauce contained and how each dish was prepared, so don't be afraid to ask! The specialty appetizer, as the name might imply, is the ceviche, a classic Peruvian seafood dish served cold, and often with raw fish. We had the tuna ceviche with tamarind sauce, and I wish we had ordered another because it was so flavorful. For our dinner, we shared a grilled halibut fillet that came out on the bone, so we had to cut it out ourselves. The only precaution here is the small bones can get caught in your teeth so it's good to watch out for that. The fish was served with a really nice spicy sauce that added all the more flavor, as well as an absolutely mouthwatering quinoa. I don't know how they seasoned it, but the more you ate the more you wanted. The menu said the halibut was for 2 people, but we shared it amongst 3 and were full. We also ordered the empanada sampler (beef, chicken, shrimp, vegetarian) and those were so crisp and well cooked without a lot of oil. Definitely regret not taking any photos of the food because I completely forgot, but their presentation was nice and clean as well. Will definitely be back here as soon as I can! Definitely should be on a seafood lover's list.
author: Natalia K.

description: Delicious Peruvian food, great friendly service! Great selection of mix drinks along with a wide selection of wines!  I would highly recommend ceviche clasico, mixto, tiradito tataki, ceviche chifa, and the delicious anticucho de pulpo!!
author: Jessica R.

description:
So DAT has redeemed itself this weekend after last weekend's fiasco. Overall the meal was OK but the reason why I'm giving the extra star is for the fill-me-up-with-another empanadas. So delicious. But let's rewind.

Date: Sunday - 1p - DAT

Options: 2 choices - Option 1 came with the cebiche mixto (yellowtail, calamari, shrimp in an aji amarillo leche de tigre with cilantro, red onion, habanero, peruvian corn and yam), carne (grilled skirt steak, potatoes, peruvian corn, spicy rocoto sauce), and the pie de limon (lime cream, lime mousse, lime sorbet, italian meringue w/ an almond crunch). Option 2 was the vegetarian option and had a basic green salad, quinoa stir fry and a duo of sorbets. The regular menu looked so delicious that we had to order a few more appetizers - cebiche nikei (Tombo Tuna, red onion, Japanese cucumber, daikon, and avocado in a tamarind leche de tigre) and de tamalito verde (sweet corn, cilantro, and queso fresco, salsa criolla and Huancaina Rocoto sauce). Instead of chips and salsa, there were yucca and fried plantains with two different sauces.

Rating: The empanada was the favourite thing we ate. I honestly would have been happy just having that for my DAT. Along with the yucca and fried plantain chips. Both cebiches were fresh and seasoned very well but the portions were very small and it didn't feel like we got a lot of the main proteins. The grilled skirt stake was a little overcooked but again still very well seasoned. The quinoa was tasty but I've had that prepared that exact way at another restaurant so not very original. 

Service: Friendly and attentive. We never felt ignored and the waiter was helpful in answering our questions about portions and drinks.

With tip, DAT, additional appetizers, and 2 drinks, we spent ~$110. Yes, quite pricey for a Sunday lunch and for DAT where you're normally expecting not to spend very much. But, I'd honestly go back just to get my hands on more of the different types of empanadas. :)
author: Janelle C.

description:
I am on day 2 of sticker shock. 

Had a dinner party here last night with a pre fixe menu.  Chips, cerviche mix, crab appetizer, seafood  rice dish, short rib, yucca fries, dessert.  

Food came out family style and portions were on the light side. Food was good. 

End of the day, it was $85 per person x 20 people.  I was looking forward to this place but I have eaten at other Peruvian restaurants and had better food for better pricing.  

20 people still complaining about dinner cost.  Definitely did not feel like a $85 meal.
author: Will I A m.

description:
DAT 2012! Wish Yelp had half stars- this is more like 3.5 stars, but rounding up for the beautiful space/ambiance and service.

Came to La Mar on Saturday for lunch. There were two options for DAT- Option 1 came with the cebiche mixto (yellowtail, calamari, shrimp in an aji amarillo leche de tigre with cilantro, red onion, habanero, peruvian corn and yam), carne (grilled skirt steak, potatoes, peruvian corn, spicy rocoto sauce), and the pie de limon (lime cream, lime mousse, lime sorbet, italian meringue w/ an almond crunch). Option 2 was the vegetarian option and had a salad, noodles, and I believe a trio of sorbets. 

We went with Option 1 and also ordered the causa tasting (peruvian whipped potato with various toppings): causa limena (dungeness crab, avocado puree, quail egg, cherry tomatoes on top of a yellow potato), causa nikei (tuna tartar and avocado puree, on top of rocoto potato) and causa casera (artichokes, asparagus, avocado and tomato confit on top of yellow potato). They also start you off with complimentary fried yucca, sweet potatoes, and potatoes with two different dipping sauces.

My favorite dishes were the cebiche (and I normally don't like cebiche) and carne skewers, but the causas were solid with the nikei being my favorite. The portions are definitely small for DAT, and the causas weren't very big, but the potatoes are heavy so it filled us up. Definitely would like to come back and try some of their other dishes.

Parking can be tough, especially on a Saturday since you're battling with the farmer's market crowds, and the meters are still running.
author: Amy D.

description: We ate here last Saturday night..Had a wonderful time!! Deserved a 5+! The staff was on point with service, suggestions and adding to a exquisite experience. Food was delish. Would recommend it to anyone. Right on the bay at pier 1 so view from patio during day would be impressive. A must try!
author: Laura M.

description:
I've been meaning to come here and finally did.   I'll keep it short.  The food here is good. A little more upscale Peruvian food from what I am used to.  Being that, the traditional food you'd expect does have a upscale twist to it.  

The ceviche ordered contained coconut milk. Which was good, as it was served with a habanero chili that I ate.  Milk does fire good. The empanadas were all fried and tasty.  After a while, they all tasted the same.  

My main was the beef heart skewer. This was actually tasty.  A little gamey, but hey its a heart. If you wanted something light in flavor, you'd not order this.  This turned out to be a good dish, as it did satisfy me, as I thought it wouldn't.  

Glad that I came here to try it out. It is much larger than it looks outside, as the bar in the middle room is HUGE.
author: Marck N.

description:
The drinks were ok.
The ceviche was bland, fish was tough to chew on, and the crunchy nuts did nothing for me.
The menu sucks, it's all in Spanish and huge.   Thought my $25 entree was an entree but it was an appetizer, the waiter didn't point it out and my meal consisted of three tiny bits of octopus.  It was in the same section as a bunch of meat and chicken dishes, and it was expensive enough to be an entree. How was I to know any better? It was also tough, bland, and didn't taste that good.

Can you say overrated?
author: reza n.

description: Beautiful location; try to sit outside if you can. Food is fresh and tasty. I especially liked the quinoa dish with fresh vegetables. Service is prompt and friendly. However, I found a very coarse short black hair in my empanada (see picture), which really put me off... BLECH.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Sooo good!  I went for dine about town and everything was delicious.

It is a bit pricey and I have been wanting to go this place to see if it was even worth it and it definitely it.  I would love to go back, especially on a sunny day to be able to eat outside, enjoy the beautiful view and sunshine.

It is great for groups, dates, and catch up dates with friends.  

After eating, it would be nice to take a stroll along the embarcadero.

Beautiful ambiance and definitely worth the price!
author: Vagabond V.

description:
I must say, their happy hour is FANTASTIC. You'd need to drop close to $100/person to have dinner here, but their happy hour which runs from M-F from 3-6pm, lets you sample small appetizer plates from their menu for $3-$6. And their cocktails are only $5. At this price, I happily downed more than a few pisco sours and caipirinhas. Woo!

My cousin and I tried:
- Cebichin mixto: various fish w/ red onion, peppers and a sprinkle of cilantro
- Empanadas - flaky crust surrounding sweetened chicken/beef
- Fried calamari 
- Sanguichito de atun: seared tuna slider w/ passionfruit dressing
- Aeropuerto fried rice w/ beef

They got bonus points for hooking my cousin up with a "birthday cake". I told the server if she could surprise my cuz when I asked for the check, and she said she would work with the kitchen to whip something up. They brought out a chocolate cream puff "cake" with a candle on it. Perfect! And it was really busy at the time, so I think they are awesome for doing that.

The place itself is stunning. Open, lofty, modern, beautiful views of the bay. The type of place you'd bring someone you want to impress.
author: Mariela D.

description:
I've been to La Mar several times (SF and Bogota) and must say that I was disappointed during my last visit.

Not with the food, but the customer service fell flat in the beginning of our meal. 

I reserved a table for a weekend lunch hour, party of 10 for my Dad's birthday. All the arrangements were made via email which included a pre-fixed menu and 2 wines.

When we arrived, we were asked to pause in the main dining area because they hadn't put out the menu cards on the plate. It was awkward standing in the middle of the room waiting for them to get ready, especially since we had checked in almost 10 min prior. 

After we were seated, 10 min later I was informed the wines I had pre-ordered were no longer available and I needed to order again. Sigh.

And finally drinks took a long time to come out which in my opinion led to an "in limbo" feeling.

The food service was fine, efficient and the spacing was comfortable.

Unfortunately it was the beginning of the meal that was lacking and set the tone. 

I recommend La Mar for small groups, but if you're looking to celebrate a special occasion with a larger group I recommend elsewhere.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
This place benefits greatly from its location, right on the waterfront with a view of the Bay Bridge from the back patio, which is enclosed with plastic/see-through/tent material. There are also heat lamps, which make the back a bit warmer than needs to be, at least the night I was there, but I'm sure would be much appreciated on a cold winter's night.

Service is prompt and friendly. The menu has a variety of things, but it seems like ceviche is the main go-to item here. That was fine because I am a big fan of ceviche, and here they had at least five different types of ceviche to pick from, each for about $17 and up. 

I had the Japanese themed ceviche, which was mainly tuna. It was pretty good - delicious even, but it didn't blow me away at all. Though the atmosphere of the place I think more than made up for any shortcomings. Dinner came with a tall cup of sweet potato chips in lieu of bread. 

What surprised me was how small the portions were. Considering that we were buying fresh seafood, perhaps I should not have been surprised, but I do not thing that the portion sizes were of the filling kind. Put differently, an entree of $17 is not all that filling. I almost wish they had raised the price to $25-30 per plate and given us more, because after dinner I could have gone for a cheeseburger or something. 

Portion size aside however, this is a nice place to have dinner and Peruvian food is not something that is as prevalent as other sorts of cuisine, so I didn't mind splurging a bit. 

After dinner, definitely take a stroll along the Embarcadero.
author: Lan D.

description:
just came here for my mother's birthday lunch... wow

they start you off with sweet potato chips, banana chips and normal potato chips with two types of dips - one cheesier, one peppery.  this filled me up quite a bit before we even started eating.

i HIGHLY recommend the ceviche sampler plate if you love seafood!!  it doesn't look like a lot at first because it comes on four smaller plates, but it has calamari, halibut, tuna, shrimp, etc.  ceviche is one of my favourite types of food and they did it SO well.  i dipped the chips they gave us that they started with to pick up the ceviche... amazing!  i was already full by the time my food got there.

main course?  a little disappointing.  i should have read a bit more carefully.  apparently i ordered a sandwich without knowing it.  apparently that's what "sánguches" means!!   don't get me wrong -- the sandwiches were delicious!!  i got a tuna one, my mom got a chicken one, and my sister got some fried fish one... but if i had wanted a sandwich, i would not have come here.

my dad, on the other hand, ordered the arroz criollo, which was HEAVENLY.  very rich in flavour, filled with seafood, very saucy... amazing!!  probably was not incredibly healthy, but just my kind of food!!  portion did not seem huge, but the dish itself was certainly very heavy, so i would have trouble finishing it alone.

we ordered one of their more popular drinks... pesco sour?  i would definitely come back for happy hour + tapas!  the view is enough to keep me happy, and i don't live too far :)

also i was in love with our waiter.  he knew everything about the dishes, what was in them, and could explain them in and out.  he was incredibly charming and had a smexy accent that made our experience so much better.
author: Jennifer L.

description: While the restaurant is pleasant and the service good, if a little pretentious, the food is just not worth the high prices.  We had a cebiche sampler for four which was just ok and the portions were quite small, followed with two main courses which were heavy and uninspired.  We left most of it. I wouldn't go back or recommend it to friends.
author: Casey T.

description:
I LOVE ceviche and I've been eating it non stop lately. When I came here we got the special ceviche of the day, the empanada sampler and their (non-vegetarian) lunch special (which included ceviche, a causa, yellow tail and purple corn sorbet). My thoughts on most of it was that it was delicious but a little pricey for small food. The lunch special was a good deal because I like to try as many things as possible, and the standalone ceviche was actually a pretty good size. 

I let my mother take me here because she was in town visiting, so the price wasn't such an issue but it seems likea  nice place for a business lunch or casually expensive date. There's a deck that let's you sit on the water and depending on what boats are there it's a pretty nice view. The hostess was kind of unfriendly but the waiter was nice. 

Oh, and the chips they give you at the beginning of the meal (I think they're sweet potato fchips, fried plantains and maybe yucca?) are awesome!
author: Christine U.

description:
Cebiche mixto hits the spot every time! They have a "La Mar" in Lima Peru so this place is LEGIT! If only we could all be globetrotters like Ed *sigh*

I have been here many times but never found the need to write a review since it speaks for itself. BUT.. I have to ask the owner WHY NO MORE PURPLE POTATOES?? How is that even allowed at a Peruvian restaurant? 

Also, there used to be 3 dips that came with the plantain chips and now there's only 2. 

I'm still giving you guys 5 stars because I love everything about this place but I'm disappointed as my experience was much better in the past. Went from 100 stars down to 5 ;)

The main perks of this place include: freshness of fish & the beautiful ambiance! Dress up for this place, it's classy!

You NEED to make reservations here!
author: Kathy S.

description: I went first time here with my gf on valentine dinner, reserved through open table. Ordered 3 course menu for two people. Pros: the place has a nice interior and view of the pier, excellent serving, decent appetizer and very nice dessert. Cons: in open table it was advertised as romantic with price range $31 to $51, however the ambience is more like a bar, the seating for two is pretty separated, and we ended up paying $70 before tip per person. I guess I can understand the high price for special three course menu. However, the main entree is very, very disappointing. We ordered lomo saltado and sea bass special menu, the lomo saltado is way too salty, and the sea bass entree is just a piece of bland and tough fish meat with two piece of bokchoi. Finally, the restroom is a mess, it seems there is nobody taking care of that.
author: Yosia U.

description:
My family and I travel to Peru every year and this is the only restaurant I've ever tried that comes anywhere close to how good Peruvian food truly is.  The Chefs have it down, and for a classy, super nice day in the city...this is the place to go!
I've grown up with Peruvian food all of my life and it's great to find a killer restaurant in San Francisco that's authentic.
author: Javier M.

description: Ceviche was delicious, got the sampler which hit the spot and gave a nice variety of flavors. Drinks awesome, service friendly and impeccable. Fell short on non ceviche dish and another octopus dish -a little chewy. Dessert sorbet seemed old and hard except for the passion fruit flavor. Definitely a go back to spot and sticking with the ceviche only, more to explore.
author: Matt A.

description:
After returning from our trip to Peru and dining at the original La Mar we had to try the one at home again. They have the exact same menu or at least almost the same from what we noticed. Everything was great, like we were transported back! 

My only complaint is the noise level. It's hard to have a conversation without sharing it with your neighbors.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
The interior of this place is huge. I swear you could play indoor football in this space. Be careful of the habenero peppers they seem to like to put as garnishes on their dishes. Eat 'em and you'll have the pleasure of enjoying them twice - entering and exiting, if you know what I mean. 

The mojitos I found were a bit lackluster. It had a lot of lime flavor, and didn't quite balance out. The dishes were much better. Empenadas were flaky and savory. Ceviche was good, although i would have preferred that the portions were larger. 

You are basically paying for the very nice atmosphere here. Don't get me wrong, this place is good. But for the best Peruvian food in town, I still prefer Mi Lindo Peru in the Mission which is a mom and pop operation but the food is just awesome.
author: Kenson K.

description:
I give 4 solid stars to La Mar Cebicheria Peruana. However, I would probably never return.

Everything I tried was good, but much like Mexican food for me, I consider Peruvian food comfort food - and a price increase with better ingredients do not necessarily make everything taste better. I probably wouldn't return here, but it is an experience, mainly for the causas and the waterfront environment. 

-Cebiche Mixto - Yellowtail, calamari and shrimp with peruvian corn and yam. I actually prefer more acidy ceviche, but this was solid with really good ingredients. 

- Causa Tasting - Comes with Limena(crab), Nikei(tuna), Vegetariana.  Crab and tuna were both really good, don't even bother with vegetarian unless you are actually vegetarian. 

- Lomo Saltado - Really really good, a bit on the salty side and definitely very expensive for a lomo saltado at $32. The meat was super soft and the fries are thick steak fries. While I enjoyed this, i actually prefer the cheaper version with cheap fries. 

They have happy hour every day (even on weekends) which is good. I believe you can score a pico sour for $6. 

Bill for two with all of the above was $75 ish. Pretty pricey for what you get.
author: Julie K.

description: Never a disappointment. After multiple experiences here, the food and service have never failed to be fantastic. Fresh food with modern and interesting twists, flavors on point, and an ambience to match. One of our go to spots in SF!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Was here with a group of friends from work to celebrate a promotion. We ordered all of the appetizers which were great .. Especially the empanadas. The entrees were all beautifully presented. Cocktails were delicious..
Beautiful view of the water & the bridge.
A nice place for a lazy lunch on a beautiful day.
author: M F.

description:
I'm not sure if we lucked out, but service was AHHH-MAZING!! Our waiter was soooo nice and sweet. He gave us great suggestions and taught us a new way to eat ceviche. I loved that they never rush us to leave (we ended up staying there almost 3 hours!) 

We started our afternoon with the signature Pisco Sour and my only suggestion is to not let it sit for too long. I nursed mine for the whole meal and the taste wasn't too good at the end. Then again, nothing really taste as good when sitting for too long.

Actually came here for Dine About Town, but did not order anything from the special menu since we didn't feel that the menu gave a good representation of the restaurant. We went along with the Cebiche Tasting and Causa Tasting for the dishes. It was actually very filling and took us the whole 2.5 hours to eat (we liked talking and distractions...) Both dishes were delicious. Cebiche was packed with flavor and I definitely appreciated our waiter's suggestion to use spoons. It was a completely different experience and I will use it for all cebiche tastings in the future. I love mashed potato, so the texture of the causas were good and tasty.

We ordered the Copon de Lychee and Sorbetes Caseros for dessert. I probably made a wrong choice in the lychee since they drenched my lychee sorbet under a big pile of fluffy pisco foam. Taste was interesting, but the fact that I was still nursing my pisco sour, it didn't mix too well and gave me slight shudders. The sorbets were ultra yummy though!

Overall, I love this place! Great ambience and decor and it's a great place to go to on a Sunday afternoon and bask in the sun with girlfriends : )
author: Jenny M.

description: Amazing authentic Peruvian food!!! Celebrating our friend's birthday! Patio is the place to be!!!
author: Lavinia A.

description:
Looking to have a fancy lunch or dinner by the bay? Then this is the spot for you! 

Starting with the ambience, La Mar has a gorgeous interior with beautiful colors on many of their furniture. It's not bright inside but the blend of color and dim lighting make for a very romantic atmosphere, perfect for a date.

In terms of food, the restaurant offered a nice mix of traditional Peruvian dishes as well as greasy American food. I tried a burger that had banana on it and was really satisfied with the unique flavor and generous serving size.

Service was also excellent. The waiter came in many times to check on me and how my experience was. By the end the manager came by as well to tell me I had eaten a new item on the menu (the burger) and gracefully took my feed back.
author: Pedro A.

description:
My dad travels a lot and he kept raving about this Peruvian restaurant near the Ferry Building (which we visit a lot). I was excited to see that the civiche and pisco sour were on the 7 x 7 Big Eat!

Here's what we had:

Chicha Morada: A purple drink made from corn, pineapple and spices (I could really taste the cinnamon).  Although it has pineapple which you think would give it a tropical twist, it was warm and spicy. I think it would be great warmed up for a chilly sf day.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=jJt7LsAvtdnVpVPaUClnlw

Cebeche Tasting: My favorite was the clasico (halibut) followed by the niko (tuna). All were extremely fresh tasting and it seemed like a lot of thought went into which marinade paired with what fish.  The mixto was good, I just have to get past the octopus suction cups staring at me.  My least favorite was the chifa mainly because I am not fond of the Asian inspired marinade. 

Causa Casera: This is probably one of the coolest looking dished I've ever had. The presentation was great with the mashed purple potatoes topped with the lime green confit.  The texture of the potatoes did remind me of playdo...so it was a texture issue here.  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=bqOYd2bDOTYucIGJL-6U1A

Anticuchos de Pollo:  The chicken was phenomenal.  The sauce they marinade in it was reminiscent of an old school bbq sauce and I think there may have been smoked paprika in it.  The Peruvian corn kernels were massive!  Beware of the salsa panchita....its flaming hot!  I am typically not a wimp when it comes to spicy things, but I downed 4 glasses of water and my mouth still tingled. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=HIxEdElIk-n3ynI7tDxgOQ

The ambiance here is a little stark and cold...but the food far outweighs this negative.  The waitstaff is very knowledgeable and personable. Overall, a great find.
author: Hayley H.

description: Nice place, I have there on SFfood week, valuable set . 2 set we share with 5 people! Delicious ceviche and good choice of wine.
author: Elena S.

description: Went here again during lunch for restaurant week. The food is always amazing! From the chips, to the ceviche, to the lomo saltado. You can't really go wrong with anything here. You have views of the water, great servers, good drinks, great food...What else could you ask for?
author: Eddie K.

description:
This was my first experience eating Peruvian food so I don't have anything to compare it to. Overall, the restaurant was very good with a great vide to it. The restaurant has modern trendy decor, sits on the embarcadero, has good service and great food. We had a party of six people without a reservation and we were promptly seated at the "Chefs" table. What luck ! We all ordered something different and shared our dishes.... "family" style.  The waiter was friendly and helpful in suggestions. We started off with cerviche and Impenadas, which ended up being my two favorite items. The cerviche was very fresh and had a nice lime taste to it. The Impenadas were crisp, flavorful and unique. The two main dishes we order were the halibut which was served with a sauce over it was also fresh and the skirt steak was cooked perfectly medium rare. 

I agree the portion sizes could be larger for the halibut and flank steak entrees, especially for the price. I can also see how a restaurant this big can lose it's customer service and quality of food if they don't  pay attention to detail but overall we had a great night and a good meal.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Well, not bad at all.  The empanadas were special, I could have eaten those all day.  Complemented by some really nice sauces, these were as delicious as they were intriguing. For my entree, I tried the lomo saltado, a kind of beef and egg, fried rice dish.  This was excellent--not only very filling, but well-prepared and tasty.  I'd never encountered this dish before, and was very pleased.

I'd probably give four or even five stars to La Mar, except that the waiter was a bit of an ass.  Or I should say, too self-absorbed to be any good at his job.  My client and I went there for a business lunch and the guy kept interrupting us.  And I don't mean he waited until we were between sentences--he just barged right in while we're trying to talk business, no apology, and just starts talking.  He did this multiple times.

The quality of the food at La Mar deserved better.
author: Jack K.

description:
I am a big fan of this place.  I've been to the original La Mar in Miraflores (in Lima, Peru) -- and this is a reasonable international translation = place to take visitors (business or family) to impress them with your sophistication.  Also, you can get a reservation the day before, probably because it's a bit difficult to get to / without easy parking nearby.

Service = amazing.  I loved that the manager made the rounds and checked on each table -- actually, he took our dessert orders too -- and told everyone that they were valued customers!

We had:

The Cebiche Sampler:  4 types of their ceviches (all were great, but my favorite is still the clasico for a balance of sweet, salty, spicy, and delicious).  The chifa was too spicy, it killed your palate for the other 3 cebiches.  The chifa in Peru, in contrast, is really mild, so I was surprised by the spice. 

The Empanada Sampler:  4 of empanadas, really fresh, but pretty small ones (big enough for an entree for 1 person, or apps for 3/4).  I really liked the beef one.  The mushroom was unusual/not traditional, but still really good. 

My friend loved the pescado nikei (sea bass with a side of fried rice), but I thought the fish was 30 seconds over cooked.  (A very minor point.)  

The only way they fell short was on the coffee and desserts.  I had a latte, which was served in a tall glass (unusual for coffee-centric SF).  We also had the picarones (skip the sauce that they pour on top because they become to sweet) and the chocomaracuya (passionfruit, chocolate mousse) which was good (but still a little too sweet for me, needs more tart to balance the flavors). 

p.s. -- You can rent the patio as an event space!  The patio, which is on / facing the Bay...and it's enclosed with heat lamps!
author: Olivia L.

description: So delicious. A bit pricey for the portions but really really amazing dish to share and main courses too. The service is amazing and the ambiance is fun and trendy. It's on the water too so good for summer time.
author: Jenny K.

description: Greatest seafood in town, period. The only draw back are the prices, but take advantage of their happy hour for drinks a save some cash.
author: Franklin C.

description:
Two starts for the location and view. Definitely very nice to seat there and look at the ocean and the Bay Bridge, but...

Service is a nightmare! I've been there a couple of times and it was bad every single time! Waiters will take forever to come to your table, and sometimes they will act snob (?)  and give you atitude. Kinda unbelievable...

Food taste good. But in my last visit, We ordered some empanadas and it came with HAIR in it. Gross! I was so embarassed, cause I suggested the place to my friend/co worker and he was not believing when he found a gigant piece of hair inside his empanada. When we told the waiter he said he thought it was some ingredient (?!!!)  I had to turn all latina and be like WTF? Are you kidding me?

For this reason, I doubt it I will ever go back to eat there.
author: Paula C.

description: YUM, always so good. Excellent service, interesting dishes and well poured cocktails.
author: T M.

description:
Best happy hour ever! This waterfront restaurant is well renowned for it delicious Peruvian inspired menu. 

Having just left the amazing tcho chocolate factory we were walking down the waterfront in San Francisco when we stumbled across a sign for happy hour. We were fairly excited as our relaxed and somewhat lazy holiday schedule meant that our meal times rarely coincided with happy hour.
