Curious we went inside and what we found was amazing. For a fraction of the normal price we were able to feast on a myriad of Peruvian delights. Ceviche, empanadas, salads and creative concoctions. 

Our favorite ... Which we ordered twice was the causa limena, a delicate stack of Peruvian potatoe topped with avocado, crab, cherry tomatoes and a delicious sauce. 

The cocktail selection was equally impressive and at only $6 each. We indulged in a few.

The ambiance was good drawing in a mostly after work corporate crowd. 

This happy hour is a must for food lovers. You can sample an array of different dishes at a fraction of the normal price.
author: Emma L.

description:
Alright food. Small portions. Way overpriced.

-Plantain chips - good, loved the red pepper dipping sauce!
-Ceviche tasting - not as lemony as thought, but the flavors of each were unique 
-Causa tasting (whipped potatoes w/ toppings) - cute, pretty, but portions were tiny!
-Lomo saltado - messy presentation, tasted just okay
-Anticuchos (Peruvian grilled skewers) included two of each: salmon, chicken and beef. This was on the house complimentary of the chef to make up for slow service. Dinner service was SUPER SLOW. We were literally there for two full hours where most of the time was spent...waiting.
-Corazon de chocolate - Can you even call this dessert? Super stingy on ice cream, we literally ate this for three seconds and there was nothing left to eat.

Do yourself a favor and head to Limon Rotisserie, where you'll get fantastic food at a very affordable price. And if you order dessert, you'll actually get to eat something.
author: Cindy T.

description: Nice interplay of Asia and Latin flavors that make up this unique gift of Peruvian cuisine.  The spice profile can move to chili hot and garlicky. The seafood is artistically presented here, sushi like, but on a bed of mashed potatoes.  The grilled meats are simply meat and veggies perfectly grilled.  By all means try the Pisco Sours, Peru's national drink.
author: Richard B.

description: We have eaten at the original La Mar in Lima and this location did not disappoint and was almost as good. We loved just about everything we had: maracuya sour, Housemade chips with ahi dipping sauce, mushroom empanadas, cebiche sampler especially the jalapeño ceviche with huacatay, anticuchos, dessert, etc. We ate a lot and it was so good! Highly recommend La Mar when in SF. If you like Peruvian you probably can't find better than this anywhere nearby.
author: Jeremy B.

description: Limo saltado, ceviche, pisco sour and water views everywhere made it an awesome night.
author: Joe P.

description:
The Happy Hour was a great way to try Peruvian food. Prices for food and drinks were very reasonable, especially for being right on the San Francisco waterfront. 

Our favorite dish was the Causa Limena. It had dungeness crab on yellow potato causa, avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomato, and aji amarillo huancaina sauce. I learned later that a causa limena is a classic Peruvian dish that can be made in a casserole size and the restaurant made a bite-size version. Yum!
author: Linda C.

description:
I've been here three times. The food, the drinks, the service, all has been great each time. I chose this restaurant for my Valentine's dinner.

My date and I both ordered the cebiche clasico for an appetizer, not sure what she ordered as her main plate but I had the Salmon Fusion. Loved it!

The dessert, Chocolate Maracuya, was delicious.

My only gripe this last time was the Valentine's Day drink special my date ordered. It was good but at $14 a drink, I'd expect a little more than 3oz.

Other than that, I was satisfied. I will come back again.
author: Yelper O.

description: We celebrated our Valentine's dinner here and the food and service was out of this world. We started with complimentary plantain & sweet potato chips. Then we had the ceviche sampler (they were good but I liked the tuna w/miso & yellow tail the best), causa (Peruvian whipped potatoes -all very tasty, the beets, spicy tuna & crab), the seared scallop w/quinoa (must order) & the octopus (a must order too, my bf's fave). We had the Limon pie which was served in a cup - very lemony  & refreshing but not something I would order again. There were so many other good food to try and the bill can add up but we'll definitely be back. Our server Gee was awesome and changed our plate after every dish. Our water never made it past half full before it got replenished. The manager came to ask about our meal after we were done. It was a perfect Valentine's dinner! :-)
author: Mimi C.

description:
This is a great spot for lunch along the Embarcadero for a fresh taste of the "new sushi" with a Peruvian flair for seafood.  I love the complimentary assortment of fried chips.  The cebiche is unique with fresh ingredients and acidity to cook the seafood.  The lemon pie dessert is a sweet and tangy way to end the meal.  

The ambiance is simple, bright and refreshing even though I expected more of the scenery from Peru as the restaurant claims.  The staff is friendly and helpful.  Parking is available on the street or in the public lot across the street.
author: Jenny L.

description: Came here for Dine about Town and it was amazing! The tune tartare and cebiche limone were amazing.  If you can get a seat outside on a nice day it makes the experience all the better.  Staff is very friendly and attentive.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The food and service is always outstanding. I have been at two wine pairing and the 1st one was excellent with good seating and atmosphere. The second one we were very disappointed and will never go to another wine pairing there again. They sat us in the very back near the door by the walk way we're when door open up it smells like a sewer. The air conditioning unit is blowing right down on the table were it cools your food right away. We felt like we were sitting at a Dennys. restaurant.  I bought 4 tickets at $105 a piece.  For cold food and air conditioning blowing on me. The people I invited were people very familiar with wine pairing and wines and were as well disappointed. My wife if Peruvian and was very disappointed
author: Pisco S.

description:
Came for the Dine About Town at La Mar on a Sunday night.  The restaurant was pretty big with many tables and even had a separate section for a bar.  I've always wanted to try this place because some friends were telling me this place was awesome.  

With the DAT menu, there are a vegetarian and non-vegetarian option.  I decided to go with the non-vegetarian option because I love me some meat.

Appetizers: 
- Caisa Limena was dungeness crab on top of a yellow potato (possibly yucca potato, I forgot).  The crab was delicious and a bit on the salty side.  The yellow potato had a mild flavor not to overpower the tastes of the crab.  It had a sauce that complemented the crab and the yellow potato.  I ended up trading my cebiche with my girlfriend for half of her Caisa Limena.
- Cebiche Mixto was shrimp, calamari with some yellow corn pieces.  I didn't think this dish tasted that good and preferred it from other places in the city like Fresca.

Entree:
- Lomo Saltado is a beef served on top of fries with some onions to taste.  The beef had good flavor and came with a side of rice.  There was nothing spectacular about this dish.

Dessert: 
- Pasion Fruit Tart was very tarty. LOL Hence the name fruit TART.  After getting used to the tartiness, the dessert actually tasted pretty good with the passion fruit drizzle on the side.  However, the best part of it was the raspberry on top

The service was good; however, the time between the portions was long and left us wondering where our food was.

For the price, I expected a little more from La Mar.  There are definitely better Peruvian places in the city and the bay area.
author: Steven L.

description: Expensive uninspired touristy food and indifferent service with prices to match it.  We won't be returning.  Made opentable reservation well in advance had to wait for our table for almost an hour!
author: Alex N.

description:
This is a review for Happy Hour only:

This place ROCKED. 

My friends and I were walking along and randomly decided to go into this place because we saw that there was a happy hour going on. Of course, my friends had already been drinking and just wanted to keep the buzz goin. But, it turned out to be a great decision.

The happy hour was awesome. The bartender was amazing with what he could do. My friends and I just sat at the bar creepily staring at him the entire time. He was so talented. Not to mention, the drinks they offered were so creative. They were pretty girly drinks and I went with a bunch of guys, but the drinks were so good it didn't matter. 

They put these like fancy salted nuts out for each group.... uhh...that sounds weird. I wish there was a better way to describe them, but they were like corn nuts ... but real? Whatever, they were good. 

We also got an order of "chips and salsa," but these were no ordinary chips and salsa. The chips were made out of bananas, yams, and other strange items. Unique and delicious.
author: Melissa D.

description: The food is beautifully presented, the interior is chic with tasty drinks from the bar and awesome flavors.  However, it's just another mediocre restaurant with waiter problems (2.5 hour long dinner for 1??) and weirdly small portions- (how are there only 4 slivers of seafood in your ceviche?)  They didn't make me want to come back for anything besides the drinks, so maybe I'd be back for the bar.  After describing it, my Peruvian friend told me not to go there again.  They should step it up since the restaurants at the Ferry Building are not as fancy but much better.
author: Xander M.

description:
Whoa whoa whoa this little jazzy gem came as a LOVELY surprise this evening! 

My friends and I were driving down the embarcadero looking for a spot for a few drinks and small bites when we passed La Mar and chose it because it looked like it had a full bar (ha!) and looked nice but not too fancy schmancy inside. 

We shared the cebiche clasico, the quinoa salad, and the fish kebab - all of which were full of flavor and sass! So good! And it didn't hurt that our server was great! All in all - a wonderful evening, and my taste buds are sooooooo happy! 

Warning: it's not cheap - and oh, it's (really) perfect for a date or a special evening out.
author: Jodie B.

description: Extremely unprofessional and rude staff. Cool inside but bummer experience waited 30 mins for reservation they cancelled without permission and were unapologetic. Won't be back
author: Amanda S.

description:
It was a sunny Sunday late afternoon.

My folks offered to watch the kids while the wife and I head out for dinner.  Where to go to take advantage of the sunny, clear, but cool afternoon?  This place has long been on my bookmark list, being along the Embarcadero, I thought it would be perfect place to dine with a perfect view of the Bay.

After parking our car on the street, we entered the restaurant where we were met by one of the hostesses.  After checking our reservations (through opentable.com), we were seated at one of the two-person tables facing the Bay.  I like how well the layout of the restaurant was integrated with original interior structure of the pier (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=dWcjDraNQHBhPZrGfdPvgQ).   Very spacious, and lots of blue and white colors to give it a nautical theme (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=u05xVIAb6Ky7aZaDomZt_A).

We were met by our waiter, Alejo, who gave a brief over view of the menu, and took our drink orders.  Soon after, another server served us a basket of fried plantains and dipping sauces:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=8esAZmuk2o8kXcQ3D4bNpQ
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=3SqSA1403hdWPK0eMFcI5Q

Our Order:
-CEBICHE TASTING (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=on5F44B_WKIF1LFFng56ug):
--Clásico: Halibut in leche de tigre with red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam
--Mixto: Yellowtail, calamari and shrimp in an ají amarillo leche de tigre, cilantro, red onion, habanero with Peruvian corn and yam
--Chalaco:  Yellowtail, mussels, clams, scallops, shrimp, red onion, cilantro and cancha in a rocoto leche de tigre topped with fried calamari
--Nikei: Tombo Tuna, red onion, Japanese Cucumber, daikon, avocado, nori, and sesame in a tamarind leche de tigre
The fish was very fresh, and each cebiche was very refreshing.  Each had a unique taste with varying degrees of spicy boldness, or refreshing brightness of the citrus.  The Nikei had a very distinctive Asian taste to it, reminding me of poke.

-CAUSA TASTING (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=SSmysmgWtTZLPHiO5i3Hwg):
--Limeña:  Dungeness Crab on top of a yellow potato with avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo Huancaína sauce and basil cilantro oil
--Saltadito: fish, shrimp, calamari, red onion and tomatoes on top of purple potato with a soy-oyster reduction, lomo saltado aioli and crispy onion rings
--Nikei: Ahi Tuna tartar and avocado purée on top of purple potato with rocoto Huancaína sauce topped with Japanese nori
--Casera: Yellow potato, artichokes, asparagus, avocado and tomato confit with basil cilantro oil
I was quite surprise how light and fluffy were the potatoes.  Not dense like mashed potatoes.  Very colorful presentation, and as with the cebiche sampler, each causa had its own unique taste and texture.

-ENSALADA TIRADITO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=owE8cIb4zk7gIJCzsm04Lw): Thinly sliced Tombo Tuna with mixed greens, green papaya, cilantro, cucumber, cherry tomatoes, fried wontons and onions with a sesame passionfruit vinaigrette.  Nicely presented and colorful.  The vinaigrette was a nice complement to the tuna.

-ARROZ JUGOSO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=T9Ke5Nm80ZL3B3jcmmHhQQ): Prawns, clams, mussels, calamari, octopus, white fish and vegetables in a juicy arborio rice with a blend of Peruvian ajis  served with rocoto aioli and toasted bread  A very hearty, rich, and bold rice dish.  Nicely spiced, but not overly spicy.  Aioli served on the side gave the dish a slightly creamy texture.

Too full from desert, but we couldn't leave this place without having one.  We shared:
-TAPIOCA de MARACUYÀ (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=jums33uR2nt7-hRMny5YkA): Chocolate mousse, coconut cream, passion fruit sorbet, coconut foam and
passion fruit tapioca.  Tart, cool, creamy and refreshing.

Our server was very knowledgeable of the menu, and the wine list, and recommended a nice glass of ameztoi txakolina to go with my arroz.  The wait and bus staff were very efficient serving our courses, and clearing the plates when done.

We may be a bit biased because we had a dinner date without the kids, but we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves, and would be back again.
author: Steve L.

description: Fantastic restaurant with delicious ceviches and entrees alike. I was very impressed with the tuna belly yesterday, which was both delicious and also a very good portion!
author: Adam A.

description:
#47 on the 7x7 List: Ceviche

-Tasty?  Definitely.  I got the Cebiche Clásico (halibut).  Even if you don't like raw fish, you will like this one.   Every bite was so good that I was glad that I took the waiter's recommendation to upgrade to the full-portion instead of having it as an appetizer even though I already ate.

-Service:  I was on a tight schedule on this particular day, so I would have liked some proactive sense of urgency (pretense or not) of coming around more often so that I could pay the tab..  Otherwise, the service was fine

-Ambiance:  the bright colors  - blue, green, orange - make this place a fun place for happy hour 

-Worth the trip/try?  Yes!  Don't dismiss this place because it's between pier buildings.  If you will only get one thing, get the ceviche.  

Another plus about this happy place is that they provide house-fried plantains, yam and potato chips with three kinds of dipping sauces.  Yum!
author: Winnie L.

description: Best SF restaurant I have been so far! Great location, great view. Perfect service, delicious food! I wrote a small note to my reservation. It was my husband's birthday. They brought surprise dessert with a candle. They made us very happier after eating very delicious food. Highly recommended.
author: Gzde C.

description: It's definitely pricey, but the ceviche is amazing.  The leche de Tigre is unbelievably delish as well as the octopus plate.
author: Evelyn G.

description:
Hubby and I came with NO EXPECTATIONS...WE LOVE La Mar!  Outstanding Customer Service, Superb -Tantalizing Mouth-watering cuisine, and large open modern Latin flare overlooking the water not to mention the Latin beats and music playing in the background. Food is one of a kind and the combination of spices blend so well together you won't be disappointed.  Please note:  dishes are pricey and portions are small but this comes when you eat fine dining cuisines.  We love our waiter - Pedro.  He was professional, informative and knowledgeable with the menu and what I love about La Mar - they accommodate the most picky eater or those with dietary restriction.   We skipped dessert just because we had no room left to take another bite.  Pedro was kind enough to share three of their most popular desserts if we decide to return another time.  We appreciate his tactic as we will definitely return to this place.

Dishes we had:
Cebiche Clasico 
Cebiche Nikei
Cebiche Mixto
Empanadas - Beef, chicken, veggie, and shrimp
Causa Pulpo
Loma Saltado
author: Lyn D.

description:
Yum!! This place never fails to disappoint me. Amazing Peruvian/seafood, a must-try. For starters, make a reservation. It's highly recommended because it's packed every day of the week. I made my reservation about a month in advance - probably didn't need to make it that planned out but wanted to make sure I got the time I wanted. Also, if the weather is nice, sit outside. The first time I came here, it was one of those SF summer days, so our table outside was beautiful overlooking the water.

For drinks, we tried a bunch of signature cocktails on the menu, all highly recommended. I got the Capitan because I'm a gin fan- it was a bit small, but tasty. They make some tasty vodka gimlets too. Foodwise, we got the ceviche sample, the empanada sampler, and the grilled salmon. They also give complimentary chips and two sauces- the orange one was so yummy that was asked for more. All the food we got was great- everything was super shareable between the three of us. The only thing I didn't like was one of the empanadas - it was the one with mushrooms in it. It was too mushroomy and I just wasn't totally feelin it. 

The atmosphere is very pretty- every table has bright tableclothes and I felt like I was under the sea or something! I feel like lots of business people come here for business dinners, so make sure you dress nicely. It's definitely pricey so be prepared to shell out some cash. For 6 drinks, the ceviche sampler, the empanada sampler, and the grilled salmon, our bill came out to $175 without tip. I'd totally go back again!!
author: Priya G.

description: Back from Lima Peru a week ago before the holidays. Went to La Mar with a group of 6 people and I really enjoy the food. Favorite one was the Lomo Saltado and the cebiche or ceviche.Been told the word is of quechua or aymara dialect. Anyhow, the cebiche(v) was really good and had the right hotness. In Lima I went to the Central Restaurant who was awarded best restaurant in Latin America and really enjoy their menu. Couldn't get reservations for La Mar in Miraflores but was able to go to the one in San Francisco. Wow, Peruvian food is really a mélange of different cultures Spanish, inca,italian,black, Chinese,etc. Service was not that great and wow it is pricey. I will definitely come back and next time in Lima will try the other La Mar.
author: Vito R.

description:
3.5 total rating
4 stars for food
3 stars for service

The night that we dined here was interesting..the fire alarm had went off and no one knew how to turn it off...there would be periods where it would be completely peaceful (however, the flashing lights would be on the entire time), and then periods where the alarm would start going off..luckily, once our meal began, the fire alarm was silent.  

The servers are polite, however the food took an extremely long time to get ready.  Given the situation (fire alarm and all), many patrons had already left, so I would have expected the restaurant to not be as busy, and much quicker to serve our food.  On top of that, they had gotten our order wrong, and had completely forgotten to put an order for a dish.  

In terms of the food, I was a big fan of the causa sampler..different types of seafood with whipped potato and sauces.  The presentation was beautiful and the taste was just as impressive.  We also tried the Cebiche sampler..I didn't get to try very much of it as it was split amongst 5 hungry girls, but the tuna poke that was in the dish was probably the best that I'd ever had.  I am sure that there are tons of other good dishes served here as well, but the Causa Sampler is something that I would recommend to get as an appetizer.  In addition to that, complimentary plaintain chips are served with two types of cheese sauces...the orange colored sauce is more spicy, while the yellow sauce was more cheesy.

The interior of the restaurant was clean, spacious, and modern looking.  However, the number of bathrooms in the building is lacking.  I think there were only two bathrooms for women from my recollection.

There is also a bar located inside the restaurant, and an expansive drink and cocktail menu.
author: Patty O.

description:
Very disappointed.  The food could be so much better, everything was so mediocre.
The homemade chips were slightly soggy even at brunch, did they make them the
night before.  Lomo Salado tasted as if the meat was treated to tenderize it.

The restaurant is very attractive, they have the ingredients for excellence, but no
execution.  With food like this they may not survive.
author: elissa s.

description: I went here to try out some Peruvian food.  My Peruvian friend said I had to go, and so I did.  The Pisco drinks were fantastic, and the various ceviches were so the best I had ever had.  Peruvian ceviche is soooo much better than any other ceviche.  I can't wait to go back and try everything on the menu.
author: Ken V.

description: This is one of the best meals I've ever had!! I have been to Peru and this is real authentic Peruvian food! If you are in San Fran this is a must.
author: Carina B.

description:
Great place to experience Peruvian cuisine with a beautiful view of the Bay Bridge. 
This restaurant is perfect to take guests who have diet restrictions - there is something delicious for everyone. I recommend sharing the small tasting plates from chebiche, skewers, and empanadas. The chebiche with plantain chips is an incredible combination. The dishes are beautifully presented and cocktails unique (but sometimes can be strong).
author: Alya G.

description: Read about this place in Where magazine and decided to try it. We had Pisco sours and shared a few small plates to taste an assortment of ceviches as well as the mixed house made chips: sweet potatoes, plantains and regular potatoes. Very creative with many textures on the plate. Love papas criollas! I wasn't crazy about the egg white on the Pisco sours and switched to the house margarita which was very good. Good service at the bar. The restaurant next door looked huge. Would like to try it next visit. From here we walked to Boulevard, just down the street.
author: Tina S.

description:
Occasion: Connor's red egg and ginger party!

Very impressed to see my friend reserve the entire restaurant for a Saturday morning brunch for his 200 guests to celebrate his son's 100th day birthday!
Great place for events or just to grab a quick drink.

Must get: 
CEBICHE TASTING and Limeña!
Parking is hard.  I recommend an Uber :)
author: Ying F.

description: We had a couple of the special Piscos to start. The stir fried beef and quinoa salad were just the size with great flavours.  Ended our meal with tres leches sponge cake with strawberries.  The maitre'd was very attentive and all the staff had a great attitude.
author: Sandy W.

description:
Maybe La Mar is great, but their Dine About Town offerings didn't prove so... 

DAT 2012 - Lunch, $17.95
1st http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=jsqO_rx5dt80z6k_mEiWiw#vhs-YxVeJgcJRLNcHYT1Pw ; Dungeness crab on top of a yellow potato causa with avocado purée and huancaina sauce
2nd http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=jsqO_rx5dt80z6k_mEiWiw#IInUUq46FaIcF2bCMhfbMQ ; Catch of the day with red onions, tomatoes, cilantro and mashed yucca in an aji panca and tamarind sauce 
3rd http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Qbr2JG96K6d31NqqAUxf9g?select=jsqO_rx5dt80z6k_mEiWiw#NR74a_ylNKAF5yETddgy2w ; Peruvian purple corn sorbet

MAYBE I'll come back for their normal menu, but even then that seems quite doubtful with their service being no help in alleviating my experience. I really wanted to love La Mar, but the food was meh (though portions were beyond tiny... so maybe it was hard to really tell), and service was beyond slow and unresponsive... Their only redeeming quality was their awesome waterfront view, and that was assuming you can grab a seat by the window or on their patio - beware incoming birds.
author: Lana N.

description:
We waltzed in here because Joyce needed to find a restroom and Cerise and I needed a refreshing beverage... both of our phones had died and we were LOST! LOST I TELL YA! the only way to appease us was a drank... yes I typed DRANK. (don't judge me I'm on vacation! it's my birthday weekend, i'm in my favorite city and laughing my ass every moment I can get)

We went to the Bar which was packed with all sorts of people not a place was to be had to sit nor barely stand. We propped ourselves up at the end of the bar near the well and ordered a couple of their Happy Hour specials. Cerise - Pinot Grigio, Myself - Sangria. Both hit the spot Joyce joins us has her 2 Sangria (as not to leave Cerise on her own since she ordered another glass of wine) Parking is located right there on the Pier and it wasn't to pricey but of course we just ran in for no more than a hour.

Decor in the main restaurant is beautiful, clean and sits on the Embarcadero facing the water of course. We were in the front and it was happening. Drinks were only $5.00 each and the Sangria was THE BOMB! Perused the menu and saw that it was traditional Peruvian food... but alas we were only there to quench our thirst.

I liked this place it was loud and fun a few  people (men folk) came by and offered to take our pics since we were having photo ops frequently. I mean talk about friendly customers eh?

Respectfully Reviewed
author: Pam S.

description:
I went here on a business lunch, and was not paying.  That's the only reason I left happy with my meal.  Everything was fine to good, but portions are very small and prices are very high even at lunch.  

The small plates and appetizers are too small four four people to have a single bite of each!  Seriously: a $10 starter has three bites of food, at lunchtime!

But those bites were tasty enough to make me not drop them to two stars for the food alone, and the seating is beautiful and on the water.

The best thing I tasted was the grilled octopus; it was outstanding and I highly recommend it as well as the ceviche.  

The cocktails looked good, but it wasn't that kind of a business lunch.  

Service felt a bit disjointed; she was nice, but had a hard time explaining the menu, and how to order (it's not intuitive).
author: Zachary R.

description: We were sat outside near the water which is beautiful. I gave 4 stars because they ran out of stuff (both wines and menu items) so that was a bit annoying to not be able to order some of the things we wanted. The ceviches are absolutely delicious I would definitely recommend getting a couple to try.
author: Lacey L.

description:
2012 Dine about town

They have seafood or vegetarian options.


The free fried chips (potato, red potato, banana) with dips were quite good!

Yellow tail in a classic leche de tigre with red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam & Causa Limeña
    - more on the sour side
Dungeness crab on top of a yellow potato causa with avocado purée and huancaina sauce
    - yummy and pretty
Chorrillana
Catch of the day with red onions, tomatoes, cilantro and mashed yucca in an aji panca and tamarind sauce  
   - good taste

Peruvian purple corn sorbet
   - unique taste 

Overall it's taste good and looks good on plating.  However the portions are SOOOO small.  The catch of the day main course is maybe 1.5 to 2 oz of fish
author: Coco L.

description:
This place is so so good!! 

Food, drinks, ambiance all 5 stars - minus one for being a super tourist hotspot and kind of sleezy crowd.. IMO 

The ceviche sampler was a great way to try all their different ones. All were fantastic.  

Loved the grilled octopus. The salmon was delicious but was kind of curry-Indian-esque which I wasn't expecting in a Peruvian place. Still ate it all.. ;) 

The plantains, cassava, and root veggie chips were a great way to start while sippin on their famous pisco sour. 

Will be back again soon! Would love to have lunch on their outdoor patio!
author: Shanna N.

description: My sisters came to town so I wanted to take them to a delicious restaurant with beautiful views and La Mar was the perfect pick. I've heard such good things about La Mar so I as very excited to try Peruvian food.  We started with the Misto ceviche which was amazing! I think it was a perfect amount for 3.  We also couldn't stop eating the complimentary plantain & sweet potato chips with the dipping sauces. We then had the Salmon La Mar & the Short Ribs, both equally beautiful, delicious, and large portions!  Dessert was just ok for me; however, my sister enjoyed the chocolate mousse. I love dessert and I just wish there were more 'cake' options. But overall, beautiful ambiance, great service, caring staff (we were greeted & conversed with what I assume was the Manager or GM multiple times. We will be back!
author: Fatima R.

description:
We ate family style.  I asked them to bring each dish one at a time. Wow. Great wAy to try their food. We had 4 appetizers. Empanadas, beef heart, quinoa salad, mixto skewers ( beef chicken fish). All was very tasty and the portions were larger than expected. We followed with 3 entrees. 1 plancha de mariscos. The sauce was great and the calamari was perfectly cooked. 2 beef tenderloin. I wish there was a little more meat and less potatoes, but the flavor was great. It was served with rice. 3 red snapper. This was served with Bok Choy and rice. Again the sauce was very good. 
So glad we ate family style. We had 4 adults in our party. The portions were generous so I think we could have order two entrees and been happy. 
Service was great. The only bad thing was several of the beers we wanted were out of stock.
author: Ilene S.

description:
This review is for the great service.  I brought my mom here as an ending to our mother daughter day and our server was so attentive.  I grew up and love Peruvian food, but its not the most vegetarian friendly.  
That said I loved the quinoa causa salad and had ordered a mushroom and quinoa dish with chimichurri sauce, that I simply didn't love.  Our waiter noticed I didnt eat much of it and although I said I must be full, he still took it off our bill bc he said he knew I didn't truly like it.  I know this should be the norm, but not a lot of places do it without anyone complaining.  He was on point, attentive, and kind, not to mention gorgeous- not that it affects our service, that's just a bonus. 

Food I loved and would recommend:
Causa quinoa
Mushroom empanada
Picarones
author: Candy A.

description: We found this place by accident while looking for a light snack and a glass of wine. Terrific food, great wine list too. Loved the music and decor. Nice wait staff = attentive but not pushy. A really fun experience and I cannot wait to go back!
author: Vee B.

description: Went here for a bachelorette weekend Saturday night dinner.  The ambience was very fun and trendy.  The servers were very helpful and friendly.  We had about a group of 8, and we were seated around a large table.  It was a little hard to talk to each other, but we had ample space for yummy appetizers!  We shared the ceviche samplers, which were fabulous!  The veggie chips were also great.  I went with the plancha de mariscos - very unique and very tasty.  The portion/price was fairly reasonable for a nicer place.  Everyone seemed satisfied with their food and experience!
author: Jenna C.

description:
Hrmm, La Mar was definitely an experience, but for the price point the food should be better proportioned. I suppose this rating is closer to 3.5 stars rather than 3, but still as a money conscious (sometimes) 23 year old I would say there are better places in this great city of food.

Service was ample and the food was good no doubt, just nothing great. I love the old Pier dock location right on the Embarcadero, but in the end the food should blow me away! It didn't ... Of course if you decide to go and sample any particular dish I highly recommend the ceviche!

In all to summarize and wrap it up, great atmosphere, special location, should definitely try at least once, but otherwise just good food for too high a price and I'm not one to be stingy about fine dining either!
author: Joseph L.

description: Bravo! If I could give them 10 stars I would. It was an absolutely perfect lunch. The hostess was very pleasant and welcoming, the atmosphere was really chill, and the food? Forget about it. My first time having Peruvian but most definitely not the last. I just hope the restaurants in LA don't fall short of this place. Started off with the Cebiche Nikei...perfect. Couple of Modelos later and I was ready for lunch. Had the Mixto skewers, which were soooo tender and perfectly seasoned, and finished it off with a few more Modelos and the Sandwich De Salmon. Definitely worth the trip back to 'Frisco just to eat here again. Incredible!
author: Peter M.

description: Can you say overpriced? Met some coworkers here for a farewell HH and spent a bunch more money than I expected to. I ordered one dish and only one drink because it took way too damn long to order any more. Well, thank goodness I didn't because I straight up spent more than $50 on a drink and the skewered heart dish. Was it good? Yeah, it was above average but not life changing by any means. Was the dish with four pieces of meat on it worth the $18? Not at all. It was a nice experience and nice to try but I won't be going back on a regular basis or anything.
author: Jessica T.

description:
As I type my YELP review, I'm still reeling from the Pisco Sours I had at this place.

Let's just say that I was a Pisco Sour virgin until yesterday.  With my Microbiology background from college, I was a bit skeptical to have raw egg whites in my cocktail. (um, yeah, Salmonella entiritidis?) 

"Fear not!" the inner foodie in me said.  And boy was I glad that I listened to that voice.  It was like having a margarita, with a touch of whimsy because of the egg white froth.  

! Chevere !

As I let the Peruvian brandy from my pisco sour seep into my veins, I scan the place and notice the eye-catching turquoise color that predominates in this space.  Couple that with the high ceilings, dark-stained hardwood floors and palm fronds -- all these elements make for a very energizing, and yet relaxing, atmosphere.

I'm a big fan of ceviches.  That was the main reason I wanted to try La Mar. At the same time,  I'm also checking off must-try items on The Big Eats SF list and guess what's on there?

#47 Ceviche at La Mar

The ceviches here are incredibly fresh. The best way to savor them is to get the "ceviche tasting" , which includes the Mixta, Clasico, Nikei and Chifa.

Each one is prepared differently and some have Asian influences, like soy sauce and ginger.  My favorite has got to be the Clasico, which is Halibut and red onions prepared in a Habanero pepper-lime-juice concoction. 

Another classic dish to try at La Mar? the Lomo Saltado. (it's like the Peruvian counterpart to beef stew -- but much better!)

So flock to La Mar for the fresh Ceviches, relaxing atmosphere, awesome views of the Bay Bridge and those damn-good Pisco Sours.

As you stumble out the door, don't forget to say:

! Chevere !
author: Janice C.

description:
Great Food and Excellent Service!

We had the Cebiche Tasting, which was a four plate serving of the four different cebiches that they have: Clásico, Mixto, Chalaco, and Nikei. This is a great way to sample them all if you are a cebiche fan.
My favorite one was the cebiche nikei, which was a tuna cebiche with, red onion, Japanese Cucumber, daikon, avocado, nori, and sesame in a tamarind leche de tigre. There was a nice sweet sesame aftertaste. Highly Recommended!

Then we sampled all of their causas by ordering the causa tasting.
My favorite here was the causa camarón, a sweet and spicy poached shrimp and fried onions on top of Rocoto potato with leche de tigre aioli. Great stuff!

For main dish we had the Grilled Fish Skewers with fried potatoes, Peruvian corn, 
spicy panchita and rocoto sauce. The fish was perfectly grilled.

Great food and excellent service. 
Thanks to Tobias for all the recommendations!

I have to visit the New York La Mar and compare the food.
author: Michael A.

description: I have never dined in the restaurant, so this review is limited to their bar.  The bar could be a very fun place with good drinks; however, you should get there before the crowd (perhaps around 3:30 p.m.) and in time to take advantage of Happy Hour (4:00 p.m. - 6:00 p.m., I believe).  Of course, I usually never get here before the crowd, so I have managed to actually find a seat once.  I always miss Happy Hour, so my drinks are usually around $15.00 each (Margarita with Milagro tequila).  Finally, this place is really loud - so it is hard to have group conversations.  However, aside from the crowd, the noise, the inability to find a seat and the high priced drinks, they do make a great margarita and have wonderful ceviche.
author: Theresa C.

description:
Food was great. Expensive, but good. I don't remember the name of the dish, BUT I had the dish on the bottom right of the menu and I will say YUMM. It had beef, potatoes, rice, onions, tomatoes.... some ginger and soy sauce-ish!

The empanadas are bomb too. I would stay away from the mushroom and go for the chicken/beef. Also, if you are super hungry, add on the lobster ceviche.
author: Brandon S.

description:
Wandered in based on the recommendation of friends who live in the bay, and we were glad we did!  This being a cebicheria, we ordered the chicken ... no wait, of course we ordered the ceviche la mar sampler, which allowed us to sample 4 different ceviche dishes.

The cebiche clásico features big hunks of very fresh halibut and toasted corn kernels, just the right mixture to let the fish shine through.

The cebiche chifa was a surprising twist, yellowtail with peanuts and a sweet/sour marinade that had an asian feel to it.

The cebiche nikei has big hunks of tuna, avocado, and a Japanese-inspired marinade.

The cebiche mix to was probably the least good, featuring yellowtail, calamari rings, and shrimp, although it certainly wasn't bad.  It just wasn't as flavorful as the others, and the calamari was a tad chewy.

They also brought out a beautiful cone of freshly fried root vegetables which were the perfect accompaniment to the ceviche.

There looked to be plenty of other tasty Peruvian dishes on the menu too, including lots of non-fish dishes, so we will most certainly be back to sample more.
author: Frank W.

description:
Nice view, decent food and service are enough to make me happy. See? I'm easy!

I don't know why almost every restaurant with a great view has either bad food, service, or both, but happily that is not the case at La Mar.

I know Peruvian food is pretty trendy right now but I'm not the biggest fan. I like the ceviche, so that's what I ordered, and La Mar didn't let me down. Luscious, tangy ceviche with just the right hint of spice.

My friend got the lomo saltado. This is a famous Peruvian dish, and people seem to love it, but I just don't get the french fries mixed into the food.  I tried it, and it was ok, but it's not something I'd ever order.

Still, all things being said, I'll give this place a generous four stars since they manage to be on the water but still provide decent food and service.  Plus, I love me a Pisco Sour!
author: Mara S.

description:
I visited Peru last year and enjoyed the food, so was eager to try La Mar. A friend hosted a birthday dinner for me and it was quite good. 

I had ceviche and the 3 kinds of causa along with a salmon entrée served with prawns and vegetables.  Dessert was a delicious and generously proportioned fruit tart with a scoop of ice cream on top. There was quinoa in the crust--I like quinoa.

All items were well prepared and service was competent and friendly.
My only mistake was ordering a gin martini to start; I completely forgot about pisco sour which is a favorite drink in Peru. I had several when visiting and it's a superb drink. Maybe next time. The martini was OK, though.

Only complaint is that La Mar is very noisy in the back room which was otherwise comfortable. Expect to shout and be shouted at during conversation. The front room is probably a bit quieter but without a view of the Bay. Still, I'd return to this delightful place. Definitely try the causas and ceviche when you go to La Mar.
author: IQuack D.

description: I have always loved La Mar so I'm sad to say I had a terrible experience there on a Saturday night during the Super Bowl events. The waiter was terribly rude to one of my friends who walked in with me. So rude in fact that we walked out of the restaurant. I have taken colleagues and friends there before and never had a problem, so I am disappointed to say that I will never go back. I have also told as many people as possible whom I know in the Financial District not to go there anymore.
author: Tara K.

description:
Excellent atmosphere and friendly service.  The restaurant is right on the pier and the view average since the boats are blocking the water view. It's an open kitchen and smell the nice food aroma. The presentation of the food looks beautiful above my expectation. The causas appetizer is delightful, with the mix flavors egg-yolk sauce and spiciness of red bell peppers and lemon juice. The fried calamari appetizer was average especially the  dough is not crispy enough.

The bathroom is known as historical; not sure why but it is.
author: Evan C.

description: Simply amazing!  The place is huge and busy, but you definitely need reservations.  The food is outstanding, especially the ceviche.  Drinks are also quite good.
author: Sharon Y.

description:
My wife and I came here for lunch and it was really fantastic.   The only downside was that the waiter was a little slow and the bathrooms were not that clean.  If those two things improved my rating would have been 5 stars.  

We had the ceviche sampler and it was outstanding.  We also had the pulpo which is octopus.  It was good but a little tough.  We had the meat empanadas and they were great.  The dripping sauces were wonderful as well.   The last dish we tried was limito salto which is fillet steak with potatoes and sauce.  This was probably the best dish of all.    We will be back!!!!
author: Don S.

description: Tasty ceviche but entres were blehhhh. 3.5.
author: Daniel N.

description:
I was going on a pretty good dining streak until now. 
I found La Mar on Restaurant Week's List. Try saying La Mar fast, it sounds like an NBA player. I love ceviche and besides, it's one of the last things I'd want to eat before my death, according to my profile.

Parking is easy and there is a parking structure across the street. To keep their patrons busy from wondering where in the world the entrees are, they provide you complimentary plantains and chips with three different colored dips. This was fun to munch on but it didn't last long until we really started questioning where our server disappeared to. Hellooo out thereeeee?

Service is extremely slow. I wish I could blame it on Restaurant Week, but it was lunch and it didn't look THAT busy. I told my table I'd go back there and help them myself.  This lunch stretched out to another unnecessary hour and half or so. Need I remind you, time is parking and parking is money.

Based on Restaurant Week's specials, we had a menu tasting, this included: lomo saltado, ceviche halibut, dessert in a bigger-than-average shot glass. The beef in the lomo saltado was dry and bland. For appetizers we ordered a few more seafood items to share, stir fry with calamari and shellfish, assorted cebiches and causas. The best items were the cebiches and causas, pretty presentation, tasty and fresh, but portions are small, we shared with a table of 5 people, I wanted more of this. 

Call me impatient but the food is not worth the wait, especially if there were only a couple stand-out items. I love the eye popping turquoise splashed all over the place. It's a spacious sunny restaurant with an unbeatable location, ON the Embarcadero, on the Pacific Ocean. They really need staff help, better kitchen management and expediting of the food.
author: Thuy M.

description:
La Mar is one of the best restaurants in the city. My favorite Peruvian place by far. I love their empanadas, causa sampler and Cebiche Classico.  You must try their desserts. 
Service is always spectacular. 

Happy Hour: best in the city! I love sitting in the bar. The bartenders are extremely knowledgable and know how to make a Pisco Sour. There is always a new cocktail to try.
author: Sabrina M.

description:
Went here on Monday with work. We had a larger party and plenty of waitstaff to meet our needs. The wine selection was delish! We had both red and white. Truly delish. 

The chips were nice. The cebiche was nice - very fresh. The paella was ok. The steak platter was amazing. 

The rice pudding to die for. 

Would  I go back - Hmmm not really sure, but the location is great!
author: Claudine S.

description:
This place is amazing!!!!! The service was great! The good, oh god, delicious. Had for appetizer the ceviche mixto and the tuna tataki. Tuna tataki very small quantity but extremely flavorful, a little spicy, the ceviche was perfection, 
For entree had the lomo talteado which was very good and it would be good to share , it's pieces of steam, fries, onions , peppers. And rice, 
For dessert had the creme brûlée . Which was good but wish I would have picked another dessert , 
Although it's a bit pricey, the sea food is very fresh and tasteful, 
Would def come back
author: Laura A.

description: Location...well, yea, that's a fiver, but everything else?  I don't think so.  When I averaged it in I came up with a generous two.  We showed up long before start time and the best seat they'd give us was at the "Cebiche" bar. Apparently they were saving all those wonderful seats near the water for much more important people who never seemed to arrive.  We didn't really care about that, honestly, we always sit at the sushi bar,  but when you add very pricey poor quality food the weight of the whole experience grinds on you.  I had the "White Tuna Tiradito."  I'm a big sashimi fan and I know my fish pretty well.  Supposedly La Mar White Tuna is "Japanese Style," but I've never had my wonderful sashimi ruined by a thick, yellow, over flavored gooey sauce.  I checked out my wife's "Cebiche" which included salmon, shrimp and avocado.  Somehow they ruined that too. I prefer to call it "Ceviche," and I've eaten it up and down the coastline cities of Peru.  It's always bathed in something light and lemony. It's not hard to prepare.  Fresh fish.  Throw in something citrusy, onions, whatever...keep it light, make it feel fresh...that's the way to go.  La Mar monkeys around with their "cebiche" making it something else.  It's all about the gooey, creamy sauce.  Yuk!  Even the yuca wasn't spared. It was splattered, once again, with some concoction that came out of some misguided belief that the chef can do better than nature.  Anyway, spare yourself the misery unless you enjoy being treated like second class citizens and fed excessively priced sauce covered fish.  When I leave a good sushi bar, or eaten some good ceviche, I walk away feeling good.  When my wife and I walked away from La Mar, we felt bloated, with acid in our throat, and it stuck with us a long time.
author: Tom S.

description: Tried this place out after I saw all the reviews. Honestly it has a beautiful location and ambiance but the food was not out of the world or something that would bring me back. We tried empanada with beef which were very delicious. The ceviche mixto recommended by our server was decent. It was a white fish marinated in a lot of lime juice topped with onions and corn. Finally we had the crab causas which were just mashed potatoes with crab on top, they were expensive and not worth it. Lacked flavor. For main course we tried the skewers and the lomo saltado. Again it was good but not memorable. I would have loved some garlic in my lomo saltado and aji sauce to top it off. Probably will not be back but I had to try the restaurant. For 2 adults and 2 kids we spend $300.
author: Sonia S.

description: I cannot say that I am qualified to judge Peruvian food, but the mahi mahi I got was delicious. If you are looking for something out of the ordinary, there is a variety of types, price points, and quantities of food. The atmosphere is energized, and the patio on the water completes the experience.
author: Brent M.

description:
I am nearly homeless and yet, somehow, I've scammed my way into eating at this fine dining establishment.

I came here for a work party. ["Work party" is an oxymoron by the way. (BTW).] 

The food was good and the red red wine was fine. 

I have a suggestion on how to live one's life better. Whenever one says, "Wine," one should instead say, "Red red wine." 

My favorite was the carne: Grilled flat iron steak, fried potatoes, Peruvian corn, spicy panchita and rocoto sauce. 

I love saying, "Rocoto," repeatedly until someone slaps me in the face. 

The only bummer about this place is that men will always have to wait to use the restroom. They have a women's restroom inside. Outside in the lobby area, however, are two single restrooms for men and women, and they are almost always occupied. Bummer when you have to yellow yellow pee from drinking too much red red wine.

Nah mean?
author: Sethy Wethy ..

description:
Went here with my a group of friends. This is the place to be for Peruvian cuisine. Started out with the Ceviche La Mar and the Empanada Sampler. Both were amazing!  The ceviche sampler consists of ahi tuna, yellowtail, halibut, and octopus. Although all of them were a hit the ahi tuna is my favorite. Being Asian and living sushi the ahi tuna is the best because of the marinade. As of far as the Empanada sampler. All are very good.  It consists of chicken, mushroom, beef, and corn. 

In terms of entrees the skewer sampler is a must. Includes chicken, fish, and beef. Loved all of them. Had the beef stew with potatoes and onions. Could eat that all day with rice. 

Overall, a nice place. Great ambiance on the water at Pier 1. Destination spot!  


This is a place to try!
author: Andy H.

description:
I can't find one negative thing to say about La Mar. This place is AMAZING!

The food is amazing, the atmosphere is amazing, but most importantly, the service is amazing from the hostess, to the drink guy (Jonathan), to the bus boys and most importantly our AMAZING waiter, Alejo.

So often amazing restaurants are so pretentious. We didn't get this vibe from anyone. The hostess was adorable and polite and seated us right away.

We arrived at 6:45 pm (we made reservations 3 weeks in advance) and were promptly seated.

We did not leave (or stop eating) until 9:30 pm and we were NEVER made to feel like we were taking too long, or using up space. 

In talking with Alejo, we told him we were enjoying a child free date night and he just let us enjoy our food and time together.

He also REALLY knows his wines. Trust him and let him make some wine decisions for you.

Another amazing thing for us gluten free people, is since it's Peruvian, the carbs are mostly potato based vs. bread based so I could really eat EVERYTHING.

The sweet potato/potato/plantain chips and dips they bring out in the beginning are amazing! I had to stop myself so I could enjoy all the other amazing food we ordered.

We started with both the Cebiche tasting AND the Causas tasting. Both were so fresh and perfectly seasoned. I personally prefered the Causas mostly because it was so beautiful with the purple mashed potatoes.

We then shared the Solterito de Quinoa which was so light and fresh and something I'm hoping I can semi replicate at home.

I decided to have the Lomo Saltado for my main course which is a beef tenderloin stir fry. I was torn because the fish was so amazing but I really wanted to try a red wine so I picked the beef. I wasn't disappointed with either the lomo saltado or the Flowers Pinot Noir Alejo brought me.

My husband ordered the Chorrillana (halibut) which was almost too beautiful too eat, but don't worry, we did...

You'd think we'd be done eating here, but we weren't. 

We finished with and Espresso for the hubby and a Latte for me. This was seriously one of the best lattes I've had. Seriously.

I had a type of rice pudding and my husband had the chocolate filled beingets. Again, to die for.

Between the food, the AMAZING service we received from Alejo, and the great casual atmosphere, coupled with a beautiful view of the bay, I can't imagine us not coming back. In fact, I'm already wondering when we can!
author: Alexis M.

description: I really enjoyed my night here. I came excited for the ceviche and it did not disappoint. I ordered the sampler of 4, the only way to go!  The grilled octopus and basil caucas was also divine. The service was great, our waiter recommended a Spanish bottle of wine for entrees to accompany the beef tenderloin, both were very good.  I also really enjoyed the fresh flower arrangements, they created a beautiful atmosphere.
author: Diana B.

description: Given that this place is next door to my office, I come every so often for drinks at the bar, and the occasional food, which I have generally found quite good. Today I had a La Mar tuna burger for lunch which tasted good. When I got back to the office, some of my colleagues commented that "I don't look so good". And indeed I did not feel so good! Long story short I was on my way home to nurse the unpleasantries of a mild FOOD POISONING, which was a huge bummer. La Mar, what happened? I would never have thought it would happen here...
author: matt g.

description:
First off, the homemade chips they give you while you browse thru the menu is SUPER ADDICTIVE! I could just eat that whole tub by myself.. oh wait, I did! :)

Unlike most people who dined here as part of Dine About Town, my husband and I came to celebrate our 1 year anniversary. We started off with the ceviche sampler, which is small portion but so fresh and delicate. I got the quinoa salad, I thought the portion was a bit small, but tasty! It came with some good size scallops. My husband got a dish that's tomato based with lots of seafood and lobster which was also very delicious. I definitely enjoyed dining at this trendy and famous Peruvian restaurant.
author: Julisa L.

description:
Hit or miss. We came here for happy hour because we were in the neighborhood.

The service was friendly and capable.
THE FOOD... some was good, some was not very good. 

**CEBICHIN MIXTO** Spicy, but not too spicy. Citrusy. It was a great cebiche.

**CAUSA LIMENA** Really good. Crab sitting atop a beautiful little potato. The sauces and purees were also great compliments. Get your own you won't want to share.

**PANCITO CON CHICARON** This is a tough one for me. The pork belly was deep-fried, it was crispy on the outside and creamy rich on the inside, but the slice was too thick. The result was fat running down your hands and when you took a bit, and a fat coating your mouth. If there was any way for them to cut the pork belly thinner (1/4 to 1/2 the thickness), I think this would be a winner, but as it stands it was too rich, too indulgent, too fatty. We ended up dipping the sando in the remaining cebiche sauce to cut the richness of the pork belly.

**FRIED CALAMARI** terrible. Fishy, and overcooked. Tough, dry, and the flavor was awful.

**CHICHARRON DO POLLO ANTICUCHERO** Fried chicken thigh meat. It was good, not great. Sauces were lost on the fried coating, and their flavors were not strong enough to stand up to the breading.

THE DRINKS were the same. Some good, some ok.

**PRICKLY PEAR MARGARITA** the winner of the bunch. Hands down.
**PISCO PUNCH** good, very limey, but good.
**PASSION DAIQUIRI** I really don't like maraschino (which is a key ingredient in daiquiris). It wasn't listed on the cocktail menu as an ingredient, so I thought I'd give it a whirl. I am pretty sure there was maraschino, I should have known better. My fault, but I didn't care for this drink.

Would we go again? Maybe if we were in the area for happy hour.
author: Lani N.

description: Being our first time visiting la mar, I must say that we had an amazing dining experience. Starting with happy hour, all of the cocktail servers were extremely attentive. I tried the blue mule and it was DELICIOUS. The amount of ginger was not overwhelming at all, gave it nice spice. I love how the restaurant serves dishes family style, so we ordered three courses to share. The pollo skewer, arroz la mar, and the lomo saltado. Everything was so flavorful! No complaints from me or any members of my party. Ambiance, music, and service were all impeccable. We will definitely be back!
author: Evin C.

description: This place makes the most amazing margaritas! They're spicy and sour at the same time. So delicious:)
author: Christy C.

description:
Well, THIS was disappointing. I love cebiche, but the food was unremarkable, portions were stingy for the price, and service was slow and fumbled.

Went for lunch with four co-workers. Seated immediately on the patio. Beautiful view of the bay, which may explain the price/portion ratio. We later joked that the portion sizes may be the price diners pay for the restaurant's high rent.

Empanada sampler: Three moderately sized empanada. Chicken, mushroom and, if memory serves, beef. The chicken one was good but... uninteresting. It was a nicely prepared pastry of spiced chicken. That's all I can say about it--and if that's all I can say, then that's not enough.

Cebiche sampler: You get four small plates for $30. We each got about three bites among five people total. It included two traditional Peruvian preparations, one Chinese and one Japanese. The dishes were good, but again, not remarkable. For a place that makes cebiche its headline dish, I was expecting a transcendent experience, but I've had better cebiche at both the West Portal and Noe Valley Frescas. I think my evaluation here would have been more generous if the portions were larger. But the cebiche platter reeked of "we can charge this much because most of our clientele will be tourists who'll never return."

Causa pulpo: Grilled octopus on a basil-spinach causa (potato puree). Good, not great. We had to order 2.5 orders to serve all five diners. Each causa had a single bite of octopus on top. Thomas Keller can get away with these kinds of portions, but nothing about the experience, service, and level of food innovation supports this pricing strategy for La Mar.

So those were the appetizers. We then waited almost 40 minutes for the main dishes to arrive. When they did, only three of us were served. My carne dish was cold on arrival. A co-worker also reported his food arrived cold. About 10-12 minutes later, our other two diners were finally served. They reported their food was warm. So that's a small victory.

OK, slightly staggered serving isn't uncommon. But after one to two minutes, it's unacceptable. 

My grilled flat iron steak with fried potatoes continued the theme: Good but completely unremarkable food in small portions. There was absolutely nothing about the steak (or any of the food) that made me feel, "Wow, this was a total Peruvian experience!" So disappointing because I was hoping La Mar would take everything I've eaten at the Frescas to a whole new level. 

I would only come back for cocktails.
author: Jon P.

description:
1.) Awesome building!
2.) Hostess was snarky
3.) Great patio
4.) Great service
5.) Good food
6.) On the loud side
7.) Dressy casual
8.) Pricey
9.) Good menu selection
10.) Would come back :-)
author: Alex T.

description:
When taking clients out to lunch along the Embarcadero of the Financial District, I'm always very torn between La Mar and Chaya Brasserie so I just alternate every visit or so to change it up depending on my mood; you can't go wrong. 

The arroz criollo was my very 1st La Mar lunch entree experience and was a filling fried rice bowl filled with a bunch of seafood variety: prawns, clams, mussels, and calamari.  With the veggies they throw into the arroz criollo, it makes for a very diverse blend of tastes and it is not like what most people would pre-judge a typical fried rice dish.  It's like Peruvians went to Spain and tried paella and said "hey we can make our own paella version" and call it "arroz crollo" while putting our own unique & special twist on it.  Well that's what happened, really.

Did I mention they have a very classy but comfortable casual environment inside?
author: Albie F.

description: This place is pricey, but for a special night out it is worth it. The portions are on the smaller side with the cost being up there, but every thing I've tried has been exceptional. The service is also great! The crowd is a bit more pretentious at times, but what do you expect? I will be back!
author: Rebecca J.

description: The food was amazing and if you like sea food this is the place to be. The service was nothing but exceptional. Will definitely recommend to others and come back and visit again
author: Dari A.

description:
I should have read the reviews on this restaurant before trying. 
1) I agree with other yelpers that the hostess was very mean. ( I wanted to tell her that this restaurant is popular NOT because of YOU) 
2) Food : Honestly, I don't see how they try to make their food fancy,
especially the empanadas. The causa tasting was interesting but not really special. the cebiche was fresh but for me it was lil plain. 
If you wanna try peruvian food for a reasonable price. I would recommend Limon Rotisserie in the Mission.
author: SS K.

description: I think I've had drinks and snacks here more than I've eaten at the restaurant at this point. Pisco Sours and Ceviche are a hard way to go wrong. Be careful where you sit during the afternoon though. the sun coming in through the high windows is a killer
author: Kim N.

description: Came into La Mar tonight for my birthday with my boyfriend for the first time ever and received the most amazing experience. From cocktails to appetizer, main course, down to birthday dessert all the meals are wonderful. We would say it's 5 star dining! We will definitely return & hopefully next time sit outside by the water. We noticed that the busser Luis was very attentive, personable & overall a great employee. He kept our table clean through out every meal & brought me over the salsa I loved & informed Preetha (our server) that it was my birthday. Preetha was busy tonight yet, also did an amazing job on leading towards the right direction on what to order. She knows her food & drinks very well. Luis & Preetha made our experience unforgettable!
author: Barajas K.

description:
I went to LaMar in NY before they closed and thought the food and service was pretty good - 4 stars - but for this visit in SF, the service plus food warrants 3.  Service was good at the start (Enrique was very attentive during cocktail ordering), but then it went downhill fast.  He disappeared after a long stretch and was never to be seen again; also, a simple beer order at the 25% mark of our time there took 15 minutes to fulfill...weird huh? 

Food....eh?  I thought the appetizer ceviches were good, but not distinctive enough between them...we ordered 2 to sample and if you closed your eyes, they tasted the same.  My friend and I both ordered the polpo (octopus) and it was medicore....tender enough, but not flavorful or juicy as it can be.  

Good vibe at the restaurant, good venue, but overall, not worth the money...with all that exists in SF, I won't be back!
author: Michael H.

description: The food is delicious - fresh, perfectly seasoned & cook...but good lawd is it expensive!  If you don't mind shelling out a whole bunch of money...then knock yourself out.  I guess it doesn't hurt that they've got an attractive host...
author: Rose A.

description: Visited La Mar on Sunday around 2pm. Got lucky since there's $5 pisco sour deal. I personally didn't enjoy it that much but it was quite an experience to try. The dine about town option was great. I particularly love the appetizers: the cebiche and the causa pollo, very light and refreshing! The complimentary fries were really good with the dipping sauce they provided. I wasn't very impressed with the entree, which tasted like curry flavor mussels and clams. Need to admit that the seafood was very fresh though. Didn't really like the waitress who led us to our seat. Though it didn't take us long to wait for the seats on the waterfront porch, I did see many empty seats while I was seated. Not sure why it's like that.
author: Phoebe T.

description:
We were just walking on Embarcadero heading towards Fisherman's Wharf when we noticed their menu outside.  We decided to try this place out.  It was about 12 noon and of course, we didn't have a reservation but that was no problem.  It wasn't full yet.  We were given a seat out in the patio which was perfect.  It was warm, sunny, and breezy. 

Water is precious in California so if you do not want water, then please inform the waiter.  They have a small note in their menu about it, but by the time we saw it, the waiter had already poured water in our glass.  (Oh well.)  

An assortment of "chips" arrived at our table which was complimentary along with two dipping sauces.  I think they were plantain chips and large kettle chips, but they were good.  (We couldn't finish it, but we took the rest home!)  

We ordered the following:

Empanada sampler:  One piece of each -- "chicken", "beef" and "mushroom".  They were good, but not something I would order again.  If I had to choose one, I liked the beef better.  

de Salmon:  This is a salmon sandwich with sweet potato fries. We liked this dish.  Sweet potato fries was more than enough to share for two.  We would order this again.  

Drinks:

Pisco Sour - in a small glass with egg white foam.
Pisco Punch -- in a tall glass which lasted me throughout the meal.  I liked this drink.  

Service was good and friendly.  

Yes, we will return.
author: Amy M.

description: The food is super good, great quality and friendly servers! I had the pan fried catch of the day and the portion was perfect! I had an entrée and the crepe for dessert, delish! Would highly recommend it.
author: Bridgette D.

description:
Went this past weekend for our wedding anniversary. After asking to be moved due to the original table being super close to others - We were very pleased. 
Literally the BEST scallops I have EVER had. The dessert was literally a piece of heaven. The manager even brought over some free champagne to celebrate our anniversary. Very nice touch - beautiful space. AMAZING seafood and pretty darn good service too. :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
On our last night out in SF this Labor Day weekend, we went to dinner at La Mar. Located in Pier 1.5 (not sure what half a pier constitutes, but whatever), there's a small area in front of the main restaurant to wait / use the bathroom, as well as a bar off to the side. With reservations, getting in was a cinch - easy to glide in and take our seats. For some reason, even though we had called ahead and said we were a party of 6, we got seated at a table for 8. There's nothing wrong with extra real estate, but given the loudness (more on that later), as well as the fact we were sharing everything - it made it a bit inconvenient to eat dinner. Our waitress was a bit cold to us at the beginning, but after we started ordering food and appearing more grownup than our appearances may have made us seem, she took more of a liking and became quite helpful in explaining dishes and preferences. The atmosphere is really nice as well - you would have what I assume is a nice view of the bay with outdoor seating...except there was a DJ party that took up the entire outdoor seating area. Apparently, said DJ (who was not named) hosts a private party at this place once a month. I love house music as much as the next person, but when what was supposed to be a laid-back Sunday sunset dinner bayside is turned into indoor seating right next to the entrance of a club party - so you can hear the beats plenty loud enough - it's kind of annoying. What's more annoying is that this is a regular occurrence, so they could have told me this was happening when I specifically requested outdoor seating on OpenTable. Fail.

Aside from that little beef, I did really enjoy the food hear. I've never had Peruvian before, and my perception of South American food tends to be that it's more focused on meat than seafood - so it was cool to get a bunch of plates and sample a bit of everything. As a general comment, I really liked the sauces that the dishes came with for the most part - in particular, any that had a bit of kick or spice to it. My favorites were the causas with dungeness crab - it was really, really fresh crab, and avocado puree and quail egg, combined with the potato, give it a hearty, stern backing that makes each bite sumptuous. The arroz norteno reminded me very much of paella, except that the rice wasn't as crisp, and the base had a bit more of a punchy flavor to it due to the spice. The other highlight was the special tiradito - with scallops, razor clams, and mussels, bathed in a spicy sauce reminiscent of what you'd find in a lobster bisque, it had a really warm flavor that accentuated the flavors of the seafood.

In all, La Mar was a delicious meal that didn't leave me feeling stuffed, yet made me feel like I had experienced a very different kind of cuisine that I hadn't had before. I'd definitely recommend eating family-style so you can get a taste of everything, and if you're in the mood, grabbing some of their drink specials while you can - the standard cocktails and beers aren't the cheapest. A nice dining experience that I'd love to come back for again, maybe next time when there's not a party with loud music going on outside.
author: Asuka N.

description: The restaurant is beautiful, elegant, and not to mention has an ample view towards the bay through open windows. Usually a reservations are needed but you can try and make it through a walk in if you show up early enough. The chicha morada drink is delicious, along with the plantain and potato chips they serve with different sauces. The empanadas had great flavor, the crust just crunchy enough. Our ceviche was the right amount of tangy and the flavors of the sauces complimented the clear freshness of the seafood. Our waitress (unfortunately I didn't get her name) was beyond kind and so sweet, she made our experience really amazing. The only thing I could say is that I was a little bummed out that the restroom did not have a changing table for babies. I figured this was because it was a trendy restaurant with fine dining and it's not considered that many patrons will bring their children. I did see many patrons with their kids--it was a bummer to have to improvise one on the restroom ground. Maybe La Mar will consider installing one in the future. Other than that, this restaurant is a lovely place to have dinner especially when looking to treat your palate extra well and have a beautiful evening out in San Francisco.
author: D S.

description:
Who would have thought that Northern England and Peruvian cuisine had so much in common! My parents and I started with a sample plate that consisted of basically 4 very small pasties. One beef, one chicken, one mushroom, and one... mushy peas! Accompanied by an elaborate bowl of crisps. Main courses basically resembled fish'n'chips. The *only* difference between this and a working Northern English man's standard faire, this place is 4x the price. 

I wouldn't eat here again. Very disappointing food considering the setting and prices.
author: Alex W.

description: Love the happy hour! Bring on the pisco sours and amazing seafood! If I could, I would order an unlimited amount of causas. I would give this 5 stars, but nothing beats Pica Pica in LA.
author: Paula P.

description:
Not what it should be at all. I'm a bit biased having been to the La Mar establishments in Chile and Peru. Amazing places and was expecting the same or at least something close here. They were far off the mark and perhaps catering to a certain palate? Shame. Peruvian food can be sooooo much more. 

The ceviche is poor. Not fresh and the flavours were boring. Travel to South America and you'll be blown away. We spoke to the waiter who is Peruvian and he admitted that this is a North American take or spin from the true recipes. Shame. I think the people of SF would love the authentic flavours of Peruvian food.

Two stars for the cool decor and bar. But skip the food and save your taste buds for a trip to South America.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Now THIS is a place that knows what's up with great service. We had a reservation at 9, and arrived early after traffic driving up from the peninsula was incredibly light for a Friday. The staff quickly accommodated us, whisking us to our seat at the well lit, bustling main dining floor. They also immediately brought out a basket of plantain and sweet potato chips with two yummy dips (call me white trash, but I love getting yummy free carbs before my meal). 

Our meal was fantastic: I had the salmon and it was fresh and perfect. We also had the vegetarian causas which were fairly small but also yummy. We also loved their big open kitchen, and we were absolutely amazed by how quickly our food came out.

All in all, I was more impressed by the service than the food - it was impeccable. This also seems like a good place for a large group.
author: Serena Q.

description:
Eh. it was pretty good but definitely way too pricey for what it was.. I really like their ceviche and their lomo saltado but none of it was convincing enough for me to come back to it again. 

I would say the highlight of the meal was the plaintain chips which were delicious!
author: James H.

description:
This review is strictly based on their happy hour.

If you like tart drinks, definitely try the passion daiquiri. I get one everytime I'm here for happy hour. My friends ordered the sangria and absolutely love it. There's a spice to it that you don't find in many sangrias. 

I've tried the beef and chicken empanadas and they were both crispy and meaty. Each came with their own sauce which complemented them well. Their pancito con chicharron is very tasty, especially with the sweet potato, however, it can sometimes come too fatty. 

I don't recommend the chicharron de pollo because it reminds me of orange chicken, unless you like orange chicken. But this is a Peruvian restaurant after all.

Why the 2 stars then, the service here leaves little to be desired. I understood the slow service when we sat at the tables, but it was even worse at the bar. It was almost impossible to get our server/bartender's (Susan) attention. She was too busy talking to the other bartenders or the bar backs. I tried to tell her that some of the items we ordered never came out, turns out she never even put the order through. This happened not once, but twice and neither time did she apologize for the mistake. Luckily all of the bar backs were more than happy to help with our needs and fix her mistakes.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I went to La Mar Cebicheria Peruana after hearing rave reviews from other restaurants by the same owner from locations in Peru and Chile. Having said that, I had great expectations so we went with my wife and a friend couple. 

Entering the restaurant was quite chaotic. You can clearly see the hostesses with a load of stress. I agree it was packed but even the Cheesecake Factory hostesses put a better face and greeting then this. 

Heading over to the food, I have nothing wrong to say about it. It was great! We had our lunch portions which was more than enough.. and having a wife that it's half peruvian helped with the selection, which were great! 

I drop two stars based on service. Our waiter took forever to fulfill our drink refills on this hot san francisco day. She didn't own it nor had any accountability as she kept referring to someone else would be bringing it but that wasn't happening. Aside from that she made faces portraying how bother she felt by our simple request. 

Here is my recommendation for the owners or managers of this place. Improve service and train your crew! This place it's owned by a world renowned chef, but that can't do justice if the service leaves that much to be desired, hard for me to recommend, I would much rather do a take out of the place next time.
author: Felipe G.

description:
I ain't no globetrotter, but I've actually been to the La Mar Cebicheria in Lima. I was staying in the swanky Miraflores area of town on my way to Cuzco and Machu Picchu, and it was the one place I decided to drop some do-re-centimos before preparing for my spiritual journey on the Inca Trail. So imagine my surprise when I saw that they had opened a sister restaurant in San Francisco, and it's a lot more spacious than its Peruvian progenitor. Wait, how can a sister be a progenitor? That's sick. 

But the place is nice with a patio and dining area. I have to admit I never got past the Pisco Bar & Lounge since my friend Rene and I were in the mood for the $23 Cebiche Sampler - a set of four dishes of fresh goodness (see my photo). The Mixto is the flagship cebiche dish with mahi mahi, calamari, octopus and habanero pepper in an aji amarillo leche de tigre with cilantro, red onion, corn and yam, while the Nikei was truly Japanese in flavor with ahi tuna, avocado and cucumber in a tamarind leche de tigre with red onion.
