I had eaten way too much popcorn and cheese during happy hour at my beloved Press Club before dinner at La Mar so I wasn't as hungry as necessary to enjoy this delicious food. However, I found some room for complimentary chips (sweet potato chips!) and dipping sauces, empanada sampler (the de chocolo was heavenly) and a chicken skewer (yum).

Others at the table raved about the ceviche, martinis and pretty much everything else on the menu.  I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong with anything on the menu.

Oh, and they happen to have a lovely bathroom too. I should know because I spent the last hr of my meal in there after having an allergic reaction to something I ate. Turns out one of the sauces had soy in it (which I have an allergy to) so my throat closed up, which was no fun for me or any of my dining companions to watch. However, it's no fault of La Mar's since I was the dummy who ate something I know I'm allergic to. And you know it was a really fabulous meal when you give it 4 stars after choking on it!
author: Andrea R.

description: Flawless!!  I have been multiple times and have always loved La Mar.  Last night, I took multiple clients to dinner and everyone was blown away!!  We ordered the majority of the menu and every dish was prepared to perfection!
author: Eva S.

description:
This was an absolutely amazing place.

Decor was well done. The bar near the front had a great blue light underneath that added a really nice feel to the area. We had a seat in the back facing the Bay with candlelight.

For a Friday night, it was really busy. It did take awhile before we got out food but with the atmostphere, I did not complain.

We both at special cocktails with gingery syrup in it that were really good. They were not something to rave about, but were a great start to the meal. For appetizer, we had the Cerbiche tropical which was the special for the night. Shrimp and tuna with pineapple in a normal cerviche. It was something to rave about.

We each had fish for dinner. I don't think you could go wrong with anything on the menu. Everything looks unique and delicious. Dessert is the same way. 

If you are looking for some unique and near Embarcedero, I recommend this place. It is a bit pricey (can be easily $50/person), but it is worth every penny.
author: Matt H.

description: The service was excellent. I could not complain at all about the service we received over the weekend, but the food really was not very good. It was strange that everything was crowded with these jumbo corn kernels. (corn with the consistency/mush of garbanzo beans) We order the ceviche sampler, their skewers, and their lomo saltado. The lomo saltado was well balanced, but 36 bucks for this fairly simple dish didn't really feel as though it was worth wild. The food was not horrible, but it was far from memorable enough to ever want to return.
author: M M.

description:
La Mar is one of those places where even though I know it's pricey, I feel like it's worth it.  Like the spacious and (tastefully) colorful dining area.  Even better is the outside patio area facing the waterfront when it's warm and sunny outside.

I took my parents here and it turned out it was Dine About Town week.  The DAT menu was actually pretty good here, so we went with that.  The Cebiche Mixto with yellowtail, calamari and shrimp was excellent (all there ceviches are, in fact).  The mixto version has a great aji amarillo leche de tigre sauce (basically hot yellow peppers in lime juice) that's a uniquely Peruvian flavor.  The Causa (yellow mashed potato) with Pulpo Olivo (chopped octopus tartare) also accompanied that first dish and was another well-executed dish.  By the way, that first plating was beautiful with its vibrant colors and delicate balance.

For the main, they had the Arroz Criollo Wok (similar to a seafood paella).  

I actually went with the vegetarian DAT menu for comparison.  Instead of the ceviche, I had the Empanada de K'apchi (sauteed mushrooms).  Tasted heartier and was good ... but I preferred my parents' ceviche.  The vegetarian causa had beets instead of octopus and it paired very nicely.  The main was a Quinoa Chaufa Wok with fried rice version made with quinoa instead and topped with mushrooms, sprouts and fried noodles pieces.  Not as flavorful as the other dishes but I enjoyed it.

For dessert, we all had the Chicha Morada (Purple Corn) Sorbet with mint that finished off a very nice meal.
author: F. P.

description:
****This review is for Happy Hour ONLY**** 

Went there around 4:15pm on a Tuesday. All tables near the bar area were taken. Good that there were still some spaces at the bar :-) 

The Bartender was so friendly to give us the menu. The Happy Hour menu was limited but it doesn't matter because we just wanted to have a place to chill. 

We got: 

pisco sour ($5.00) - quite strong but very tasty. It was pisco, lime juice, syrup dash of egg white & bitters. 

pisco punch ($5.00) - strong too but delicious. It was pisco, pineapple syrup and lemon juice. My friend asked the bartender if he could make it lighter...She thought he just added more juices or ice but he actually made her another new drink. So nice of him! 

Calamari with tartar sauce ($6.00) - nothing special just standard fried calamari but the sauce was pretty good and unique 

Potato with Dungeness crab ($4.00) - the portion was so small but the presentation was very nice. The crab was so fresh 

cebiche mixto ($7.00) - very small portion and I think too much flavors. Everything (mahi mahi, calamari and octopus) was so fresh and tasted good on its own, but together it was hard to distinguish a single balanced composition. 

I LOVE the decor inside. Trendy design with high ceilings and the blue lights bar scene. It was definitely a good place to take a date or group. 

I can't wait to go back there.
author: Liza T.

description: The food was over priced and not as tasty as I assumed it would be (since it has 4 stars). My inca kola was watered down and the service sucked. I wouldn't come back to this place. If you want to try delicious, decent priced Peruvian food, I suggest going to Mi Lindo Peru or Limon.
author: Jill P.

description:
I am cuban and a huge fan of empanadas. The second we stepped through the doors I could feel the Peruvian vibe (music, etc.). Our waiter was super nice and very helpful. We ordered an appetizer of empanadas and the salmon entree. 

The empanadas we gone in less than 5 minutes. They were very filling so once our salmon was brought to the table we were already full. The salmon was very flakey and delicious.

We also ordered the pisco sours which were well made but a bit strong.

If it wasn't for my birthday, we probably wouldn't have gone so fancy, since our dinner ended up being almost $80. I would definitely recommend this place for special occasion!
author: Jena S.

description: Really enjoyable Dine-About-Town lunch.  Seated outside with the plastic all around, reminds me of living in a bubble, with heat blasting on my head, reminded me of the old style "under the hairdryer".  Loved their mixto ceviche.  The smiling and winking waiter was very attentive.  Maybe that was the enjoyable part?  A little booze, or booze fume or everyone laughing with their little cocktails, everyone in high spirits?  Great Peruvian food, great presentation.  Loved the aja sauce and the fresh potato chips!
author: Helen L.

description:
La Mar is La mazing.  You cannot beat their great wait staff, their vibrant decor and spaciousness as well as their location along Embarcadero with the restaurant's back windows facing the SF bay. 

Meals start with freshly made Kennebec potato, sweet potato and plantain chips accompanied with three different dipping sauces (green had the most kick which was my favorite).  You'll definitely be asking for re-fills.  I tried the cebiche carretillero, causa tasting, empanadas de lomo saltado and anticucho de atun.  I highly recommend the cebiche carretillero which was such a delicious combination of seafood melded with all the other ingredients and citrus juices.  If I really wanted to shame myself in such a nice restaurant, I would have slurped up all of that cebiche juice sitting in the bowl. The empanada was also just pure deliciousness and I was in awe of its deep fried glory and flavor.  

I'm definitely looking forward to returning and trying more of La Mar's dishes.  They also have a patio which I'm sure would be perfect for those meals on warmer days/nights!
author: Maya S.

description: The food is really, really good.  I am deleting a star though for slow service during a weekday lunch as well as charging for each soda and iced tea refill.  Seriously, if I'm spending $25+ on entrees and $10+ on appetizers, give me my Diet Coke.  Wth... I was annoyed that I spent as much on Diet Coke as I did on ceviche.  That was uber annoying, and the guy could have mentioned something after I ordered my 4th soda.  Had I known that, I would have ordered Pisco Sours or something like that.  Lame.
author: Neda B.

description:
gross. lousy. i need to eat some fresh fruit or drink a gallon of water to take all this bad food out of my system.

perhaps my experience is an outlier as there are so many good reviews of this restaurant...over 1,500....

ceviche. 5/10.  this was the best part of the meal.
salad with tuna and wonton. 2/10. imagine a bad and cheap chinese restaurant trying to act fancy.
crab something. so gross....was that all mayo or what? could not even eat it.
halibut. as bland of one as i ever had.
the pumpkin fritas...fry the hell out of them and add lots of sugar on the top to give it some taste...could not even eat it. the fact that at the same time saw a "server? or a kitchen guy?" taking his shirt off to change on the side of the kitchen did not help my appetite.

the server (i think his name was shane) asked how the food was...i told him politely it was really bad...to make him comfortable, i said but the service is very good...gave him a 22% tip too....but i think that was a bit too much as i think he should have told the manager or the chef...

anyways, i'm telling y'all...

again, in fairness, maybe it was an off night...but all the dishes were highly recommended by the waiter....those who have enjoyed it so far, i'm glad for you....as for me, i think it was a waste of time, money and just gross.
author: Mehran F.

description:
Believe the hype.The cebiche here makes me weak.  Clásico with a nice vodka martini does this gal in.

Have been a few times over the past couple years and can vouch for their consistency. 
The bar is fun, the place gets loud but not in an obnoxious way.
4.5 stars rounded up.
author: Athena S.

description:
5 STARS!

My girlfriend and I went to La Mar as a part of the Dine About Town week in SF. We ordered items from the Dine About Town & regular menu.  La Mar's ambiance is awesome and location is prime, situated on the pier. We went today on a sunny San Francisco day during lunchtime and landed a patio seat.

Food: 4.5 Stars

We first started with a complimentary fried plantains, white potato, and sweet potatoes with red salsa and  salsa criolla. These were either fried twice, or baked and fried because these had the perfect crunch and texture that you can only get doing it this way. The two salsas were very good but not overpowering. The salsa criolla was yellow and creamy from the cheese blended into the sauce. The second was more of a traditional salsa with a tomato and pepper base.

Onto our menu items:

1. Starter:  Cebiche Mixto Yellowtail from Mexico, calamari and shrimp in an ají amarillo leche de tigre with cilantro, red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam. The ceviche was awesome-- not too sour from lime and just the right textures you want from seafood (which was very very fresh. One bite of the calamari and it just melted away).

2.Starter:  Causa Pulpo Olivo Octopus tartare mixed with Peruvian black olives, red pepper and onions on top of yellow potato causa with avocado purée and finished with rocoto huancaina sauce. Very distinct taste of octopus, which was balanced well with the smooth starch of the puree. The sauce did not add much to the dish. 

3. Starter: Beef Empanada (Regular Menu)
My only complaint was the price of this dish. Empanadas are usually a cheap street food, usually $1 or $2, and is not a food to be served conventionally eaten with a knife and fork. I thought that the beef empanada should be less expensive but the dish itself was very very good. The pastry was crisp and yet fluffy on the inside--exactly what you want for a fried item. The filling was amazing--tomatoes, scallions and perfectly cooked but not overcooked ground beef.

4.Main:  Arroz Criollo Wok sauteed rice with aji panca, choclo, shrimp, calamari and mussels garnished with salsa criolla and drizzed with aji amarillo sauce. 
Very similar to seafood paella. The seafood was cooked perfectly. The dish was a little bland, it left me wanting a bit more spices to the dish. But we still ate the whole thing up!


5. Dessert:  Chicha Morada Sorbet Peruvian purple corn and rosemary sorbet. Perfect ending to the meal. Sweet and cold, but not so sweet to make our teeth ache. Very refreshing. 

Overall, there were some items that could've been less salty or more flavorful but the techniques used (sous vide, marinating raw fish to coax flavor), the portions, the textures were spot on.
 

Service: 5 Stars
The service was stupendous--quick and attentive but not overbearing. Our server, Manuel, was awesome and extremely helpful. And! he gave us an extra order of sorbet (we intended to share one) and a complimentary post-dessert (I'll keep what it is a secret so that you see for yourself ;) ). The way to a reviewer's heart.

5 STARS!
author: Christopher F.

description:
Ceviche sampler and the tuna and crab causas are a must try! It was like I had died and gone to foodie heaven. However, we had to order 2 of each so that it would be enough for our party of 7. For $30 per ceviche sampler and $20 per causa tasting, spending $100 on appetizers ended up being pretty pricey. 

My major disappointment with the meal was my steamed sea bass entree. It was highly recommended by the server but it ended up being underwhelming and bland. I've definitely had waaayy better. A friend of mine who also ordered it as well had the same reaction towards her dish...so it wasn't just me!

Go with the traditional pisco sour. The passion fruit flavor was way too strong.

There were a few small kinks with the service but overall it was very attentive. 

5 stars for their appetizers, service, and ambiance
minus 2 stars for their sub-par entrees

Albeit pricey, I would probably only come back for their tapas and appetizers.
author: Vivian D.

description:
This place was ok. The ceviche was decent but nothing special. The decor was nice. The only highlight was the drinks. Though the prices are moderate, they are too high for such a mediocre place. 
Also, go nextdoor to Starbucks or something if you have to use the restrooms. The one's here are so filthy. 
One star awarded for great drinks and another for great service, and both taken away after everyone we went with got food poisoning .
I probably will not be going back because there are so many great places in SF to eat with better food that will not make you sick. Why go to someplace with dirty restrooms and mediocre food that has a high probability of making you sick?
author: Zachary S.

description: Delightful lunch with friends on Saturday.  We shared the Cebiche Nikei, a Causa Tasting plate, the Anticucho Mixto, and a bowl of delicious Yuccitas. Nomnomnom.
author: Lyza L.

description: Updating from a 4 star to a 5 star guys! GREAT CEVICHE!!!!!! Love this place!!! So very fresh and good!
author: Kirk M.

description:
came here the other day with a party of 10 for a friends birthday and had a great time...

food was great...although nothing really popped out at me as amazing, being that i felt like i had a variation of each dish before somewhere else...the desserts that i had at the end were simply, REDONKULOUS. 

petite little fruity cheesecake bites on a spoon and little shortbread sandwiches filled with some type of heavenly caramel...omg, if i had it my way, i wouldve had dessert the whole time...

for dinner, we started off with a handful of ceviches and worked our way up to light and crispy empenadas filled with flavored meats and little sweet raisins...my favorite out of these was the  pulled crab on top of some yellow paste that tasted like egg salad...this had to be my favorite as i think i ate 3 portions of this while people werent watching...

also had some type of seafood risotto with shrimp and calamari...the flavor was there, but then again so was the SALT...i like salty foods but this was a little over the top...would definitely try again but would ask the kitchen to tone down the sodium on this dish...

our meat entree was amazing tender...some type of roasted beef that was meaty and fatty...almost the consistency of carnitas but was clearly a beef dish...served over a bed of other stuff that didnt matter, this thing was expertly cooked and fork tender.

once again...the desserts....ah, the desserts! sooooo good! cant stop thinking about them and will probably swing by this place just for dessert next time around!
author: Kyu L.

description: Valentines day double date dinner... We enjoyed the ambiance and the wait staff were great. But the food was over priced and under par. If it wasn't for our awesome waitress... I'd give this place one less star.
author: Ka'Neki M.

description:
I've been here at least a dozen times, I've eaten at the bar, showed up for birthdays, even had business lunches here.  It's been about a year since my last visit, and what happened the food is boring.  The cocktails have no punch, the chips are cold and chewy (yuck), the cebiches all taste the same (really I had the sampler), and the "Tequenos" special was anything but.  The tequenos featured a duck confit served in a lumpia shaped flour torilla.  I love dock confit, and what was stuffed into that taquito thing was unrecognizeable.  

Skip La Mar....
author: Rice Farmer O.

description:
The food and the location is great, but on the past two occasions the management here was just plain rude.  It's not the wait staff, they are great.

We were in the bar, spending a fair amount of money on cocktails and the staff informed us that they were going to cancel our reservation because we were 5 minutes over the reservation time.  I dont understand this since they weren't going to be able to sit a party after us AND the restaurant was not full that evening.  Another time (for a business dinner) they gave us grief because they said we had signed some sort of agreement.  After a lot of back and forth and pulling people away from the dinner they finally admitted that they didnt have one.

There are so many restaurants that have great food and make you feel welcome in San Francisco so I am not sure this one is worth coming back to.
author: Amy H.

description:
We came a half past 3 so the happy Hour was in full swing and we felt lucky to get bar seating after about 20 mins. Except for one tall skinny blonde the folks behind the bar seemed authentic and doing hard bar labor, cutting and squeezing limes for the hour we were there.

Drinks:

Pisco Sour is awesome - Never had one before, but it is one of my favorite drinks now. Two sips in, I felt it coursing through and giving me the nicest buzz. Very very pleasant to drink.

Prickly Pear margarita - is good, with an unusual earthy addition to the salt and drink.

Rasberry Gimlet - too sweet.

Apps: 

Cebichin Clasico - a very, very  nice cerviche. A little small to share, but I would order 2 of these instead of the cerviche samplers.

calamari - bad. Just tastes like deep-fried breadcrumbs - no taste of calamari at all.

pancito con chicharron - this pork belly sandwich was pretty good, but I started to skip one layer of bread to taste the pork. Also it could have had a bit more seasoning or soemthing to bring out that pork better.

The atmosphere is nice. Get there a few minutes before Happy hour starts to get your seat. And go there  after an America's Cup Race on your way back to BART.

I will definitely come back.
author: Ralf P.

description:
My buddy and I decided to take our ladies out for a surprise dinner followed by a 3-hour yacht cruise and this place really did the trick. The ambiance was great - They played bossa nova music which really set the mood. 

Our waiter was really helpful and had great recommendations. I had the ribeye which was delish and my date had the seabass which she really enjoyed. All in all the service was great and the drinks and food were better. Flavors galore.

I'd recommend this place to anyone looking for a good time.
author: Jon C.

description:
My first was on Sunday. Really enjoyed the pisco sour drinks for the first time, which I've heard that it was what La Mar was known for. 

La Mar has great patio with the view of the Bay. 

Food was delicious, and the service was top class. The manager personally stopped by to make sure that everything was in order and that my needs were taken cared of in a timely fashion.
author: Stefan S.

description:
Good food, horrible service.  Don't sit at the low counter near the entrance, you'll get neglected!  

Biggest complaints - we ordered everything at once, including 2 shots of tequila (it was one of those days for us).  We didn't get the 2 shots until after asking about it and after we were done eating.  We asked for the bill and the server took several minutes to get it to us.  Again, had to ask someone else to remind our server to bring it to us.  
Was a really disappointing experience overall!
author: Misa D.

description:
I am not sure what's all this hype about. 
Ambience was great. Food was mediocre.  

I would prefer coqueta any day which  is few blocks away from it.
author: Nifty G.

description:
Everything about this place was enjoyable! The atmosphere was vibrant with colorful tables, music you want to dance to, a tentative staff, and the food!!.. 

I had been wanting to try this place for a while but done about town was the closer for me. Met up with three of my friends and we had a ball. The cevice was delicious. The pairings of flavors and texture were pleasantly surprising. 

we had a ceviche tasting with different white fishes.  I remember that one was yellow tail, but I don't remember the other two.  This was so delicious.  Each of the different ceviches had a distinct flavor and different textures were incorporated into each of the tastes.  I would come back for more of this stuff.  I had the lomo saltado for my main dish and it was pretty bland.  It was mostly rice that needed salt and then the seafood in it wasn't anything spectacular.  

Skip the dessert..we had some short of sorbet and I could have done wo it in my meal.  If you've been reading my reviews, you'd know that I'm quite particular about my dessert and it takes a bit to amaze me.  This is probably because I am a baker myself!

I would come back for drinks and ceviche in a very New York fancy shchmancy cool ambiance type place.  Everything else was a bust.
author: irene u.

description: What a beautiful restaurant. It was very lively on a Saturday night, the place was packed. No wonder, because the food is fabulous. There were many tables celebrating a birthday. I can't wait to come back and try some of the dishes we couldn't fit in! The lomo saltado was fantastic. The ceviche was very unique and had a good kick to it. I want to try the mixed skewers next time.
author: Michelle W.

description:
I'm a repeat diner here as I love Peruvian cuisine. The food is excellent but certainly overpriced. Dish prices subsidize the premium SF landmark building La Mar occupies. 

As the numerous reviews can attest, the food is delicious and will tickle any seafood lover. The ahi and halibut tunas were perfect and I also enjoyed the chorillana (catch of the day) special which was halibut accompanied with mashed yucca, tomato and tamarind sauce. The arroz criollo was also very tasty and offered plenty of seafood with peas, bell peppers and cilantro. The punch pisco sour was overrated and didn't care for the lomo saltado (stif-fry) and the cappuccino de tres leches. I was fortunate to have dined over lunch here with a non profit group that I chair on to have enjoyed the nice spread!
author: Carmina B.

description:
Went to La Mar for our rehearsal dinner. Simply great food, even our picky parents loved the food. 

Overall, great place, and great location if you want to setup dinners for large groups.
author: Ella O.

description:
STEER CLEAR!! Complete waste of hard-earned cash! If you aren't a regular, don't mind getting expensive, unimpressive and tasteless food or crappy service, then this should be the place for you! Hmmm...where to begin??

Food:

GAG! It's not authentic Peruvian food and portions are fit for the seagulls outside. My
traditional ceviche had halibut that tasted bland. My partner had the halibut that was rubbery which she finished a quarter of it. My lomo empanadas were the only good part of the meal. The wine we had was good and created a nice buzz for me and calmed my nerves. 

Management:

My partner and I made a dinner reservation to celebrate our anniversary. The reservation specifically stated that so one would think we'd get a nice table. We arrived early and asked to be seated which he did. He gave us attitude for arriving early! The restaurant was empty for a Sunday evening. So...we were told, verbatim, "Oh we'll seat you at a nice table in our outdoor, heated patio." Well if you think a small table by a column that doesn't fit the food and drinks we ordered, then it'd be a "perfect" table. The manager needs to take the stick out of his butt. 

Server:

How does this guy stay employed?!? Shane is the WORST server and probably doesn't even know how to give a genuine smile. His greeting sounded forced and he was already irritated with us for some weird reason before we even ordered our food. He never explained the menu, drinks or provided recommendations (more on this later). Shane needs some serious customer service training. If you get him as your server and not a regular or made of money, expect to get service from a ROBOT!  We had more interaction with the bussers who actually asked how we were doing. 

Now the table next to us was female and male. Apparently the guy was a regular, so Shane was, to put it lightly, KISSING his butt. He explained the menu, drinks and made recommendations and even the wine sommelier went to their table! This made me pissed! Shane never checked on us until he dropped the check. Even with that, he dropped us the WRONG check. We left him a less than average tip and I left a note for Shane. Management really really needs to train this guy more. 

Conclusion:

This restaurant doesn't deserve all the merit its been receiving. Management and the servers all have snooty attitudes. Food was very lackluster and there are much better options in the Mission. I felt robbed and pissed. I vow to NEVER return here or recommend it to family/friends.
author: Kim N.

description: I went here for a company Christmas dinner party and we got started with a few drinks at the bar. Small but interesting and unique drinks. After this, we got seated at a large table for 36 people. For appetizers, we had some amazing complementary crisps/chips with a serving of cheese and wasabi dip. These were some of the best crisps I've ever had in my life - so thin, crispy and flavorful but not overly greasy. The dip was amazing as well. Seriously great starter! After this, we had empanadas de k'apchi, which were incredible. The mushrooms were so juicy and tender, and the crust of the empanada was delightful. Afterwards for entrees, the quinoa chaufa (vegetarian) was solid. There were some Asian elements I enjoyed, with the addition of scallions, egg, soy sauce. It was an interesting fusion dish. For desert, we had an assortment, with a chocolate mousse, a cheesecake, and a tres leches dish. They were all delicious, but the tres leches really won me over. It melted in my mouth straight away and felt like I was drinking liquid clouds. Great place overall for drinks and dinner. Great memories.
author: Nicholas Y.

description:
I have been here twice -- once for a business lunch and once for Mother's Day.

The fried chips (plantain, sweet potato and regular potato) are great, as is the dipping sauce.

The ceviche's were good.  I liked the flavoring of most of them, although I thought the fish pieces could have been sliced a little thinner.

The causas (whipped potatoes with various toppings) were yummy and i had not had them before.

The empanadas were quite good.  During my business lunch I also had a sandwich that was rocking.

Desserts were super yummy and service was very good.

I think its a good choice for kids willing to eat adult foods because its loud and airy -- no kids menu per se though.  

Great decor for a waterfront restaurant.

Recommended!
author: Stephen C.

description: Love it love it love it. Went to one of Gaston's restaurants in Lima & was thrilled to hear he was opening one in SF; have been waiting to have an excuse to come out to the west coast to try it out and this alone was worth the trip. Ceviche is to die for, particularly the clasico; would skip the Nikei, although that's my opinion on Nikei ceviche elsewhere (mostly tried in Peru)--too sweet and not as flavorful as the others. Small plates are the way to go at this restaurant, entrees were fine but not the starring moment. Don't miss the cocktails, anything with pisco is excellent. Waitstaff is lively and attentive. Beautiful outdoor seating.
author: M M.

description: My first time here and I loved it. My favorites were the ceviche chifah (yellowtail with peanuts) and the ahi tiradito. Fresh and delicious. Request ahead for a tableside window.
author: Lisa M.

description: Classy joint. Had a company event here and love the open, bright layout. Really cool spot when it's a sunny day. All the food was good.
author: Khalid N.

description: I've brought several friends and coworkers visiting San Francisco here and each time it has been a fantastic experience! It's a good go-to spot that is unique without being too 'touristy'. Great location and superb staff. This time Dianna set up our reservation perfectly and even helped put together a little birthday suprise for the guest of honor.
author: Melanie M.

description:
THIS PLACE IS OFF THE CHAIN!!! As a Peruvian, I must say that this lives up to the hype and THEN SOME. First, I must say that those people who say this restaurant "does not feel Peruvian" probably mean this isn't some hole in the wall dump that they ate at either in Peru or in the Mission. The Peruvian cuisine has evolved and trendy restaurants like La Mar are the new rave all over Lima. Last summer I've went to Peru being a trendy tourist and eating at all these new age gourmet restaurants and I still gotta say La Mar is the BEST. BTW there is also a La Mar in Peru, same great taste as the one in SF with not so pretty views.

Everything is tasty, amazing, and an orgasm for your mouth. Most def. Sidenote: I have difficulty reading reviews from people who never had Peruvian food criticizing the ceviche and the empanadas. Umm... have you EVER had Peruvian food? Cebiche is raw fish! It's suppose to be like that! My favorites are the jalea and the lomo saltado. you can't go to La Mar and NOT have some Lomo. To die for! Also you must try the causa sampler. Causa is like spicy mashed potatoes that are served cold with fish or chicken. Again, a party for your mouth!

Always make a reservation as sometimes they are limited in space,especially in the evenings!
author: Kelly R.

description:
I'd probably give 3.5 stars. 

La Mar is gorgeous and very big inside, with great views. 

We tried the empanada sampler, ceviche sampler, salmon entree with prawns and vegetables, and another entree that I can't remember. Overall, the empanadas and the pisco sours are what stuck out the most.  

For what you're getting (both quantity and quality), I find it a bit overpriced.
author: Olivia G.

description:
I had an incredibly disappointing experience here last Friday night. Beginning with the cold and ditsy service we got at the bar before our reservation. Our server seemed stoned and uninterested in helping us. She gave informative responses to our questions about pisco (which dominates the cocktail menu) but seemed to have nothing positive to say about the spirit her income was dependent on, and she portrayed the menu's many options as insignificant to people who are not connoisseurs.

(Thought we were able to rise some human emotion out of her by ordering drinks she enjoyed.) 

The drinks, when we got them, tasted great. But if the good-hearted people of Peru put any love and affection into the pisco they're making (assuming these were peruvian piscos...we're not connoisseurs so we didn't ask) it was lost on us because of our server's indifference. 

After the bar we moved to our table, where the service was friendly but spotty (I'm guessing our new server's section was way too large for him to cover by himself). 

This purported ceviche establishment ran out of ceviche (or cebiche which is how they want to print it (maybe a Peruvian spelling?)). And that applied to ALL OF IT. An entire column of the menu--the one reason I think most people come here--was a non-starter. That's not a great situation for them to be in on a Friday night and a source of some pretty severe dissatisfaction for us. 

The food we were able to order was a mixed bag. The empanadas were small, expensive and no where near as good as an empanada should be. There's no comparison between these and ones at Nopalito for example (Venga is still on my "to try" list). What was good was the beef heart skewer. Delicious! There's one bright spot on a generally poor meal. 

I know this is probably a good restaurant, but it's too expensive to chance again!
author: Luke M.

description:
I am a Peruvian from Lima which makes me a pain when evaluating Peruvian cuisine. My thoughts could be seen as incorrect by those that have not been to Peru. In my defense, I have been a couple of times to Chef Gaston Acurio's "La Mar" in New York City (La Mar-NY).  Today I went to "La Mar " in San Francisco (La Mar -SF) for the first time. These are my thoughts on what I had. 
-Pisco sour: Not sweet enough, but this could have been a mistake of the day. Otherwise the flavor was pretty good. 

-Sangria: Interesting use of Pisco and great flavor. Again, sangria was not sweet enough. 

-Sweet potato chips: They were good. What was special was the rocoto sauce (Peruvian red pepper) served on the side to dip; it was VERY good. 

-Empanada of aji de gallina: I did not like the aji de gallina filling. It lacked chicken and had a bland flavor. The dough that covers the empanada was quite disappointing

-Empanada of lomo saltado: A bummer as the empanada above. I am sorry Chef Acurio, but this empanada was just slightly better than the empanadas of Publix by Brickell Avenue in Miami  :(

-Causa limena: It might be expensive and small but dungeness crab speaks for itself. This is a touchdown for the chef. 

-Chicken chicharron: Decent flavor. 

-Cebiche chalaco: Tasted well. Nothing special.

Comparisons are often unpleasant, especially as I have only tried La Mar-SF once. I understand that there are limitations to Peruvian cuisine because of difficulty in getting the right produce.  I suspect La Mar-SF does not have access to the same produce as La Mar-NY. The latter was a much more pleasant experience.   

From a business perspective. If Chef Gaston Acurio ever considers opening a La Mar in Miami, where MANY Peruvians live, he might have to plan it VERY well. If flavor is similar to La Mar-NY he has a real shot against Ceviche 105 and Francesco. If flavor is similar to the La Mar-SF that I had today, Chef Acurio might have a headache.
author: Luis A.

description:
Food was excellent, service was really lacking. I don't need hand-holding, but perhaps our server was having an off night... She didn't share the specials with us and abruptly walked away while we were asking a short question about a menu item. We were not familiar with Peruvian food and the menu fails to mention that many of the dishes are (unexpectedly) cold... all things that could've been included in a short overview like we heard the next table receiving by their friendly server as we paid our bill. 
The salmon main course and the mascarpone mousse dessert were my favorites.
author: H. K.

description: I had a bad experience with The service, server never asked how was everything never smiled, when finish our plates stayd fo 15min on the table we felt very ignored all the time even the manager never asked or looked at my table. Food is ok. But its a nice restaurant for happy hour only.
author: Henry G.

description:
Beautiful location on the Embarcadero, view of the water, open space with lots of light.  But perhaps the restaurant is too big and gives a feeling of impersonal where you don't feel like a special client but just another table.  Besides the colorful menus, there is no decoration or feel of Peru, but more a feel of down town.

We decided to order a variety of small pates to be able to try as many things as possible.  We ordered the cebiche classico, causa limena, anticucho de carne and the empanada sampler.  

The cebiche was good, classic but nothing out of the ordinary and the fish was chopped in really big pieces, nice for the portion but a bit awkward.  The causa was the real star to our meal, beautifully presented, unique flavors and ingredients put together for a great dish.  I would definitely come back for this one.  The skewers were nice but the meat was a bit chewy for our taste.  The sauces with the meat were great but the meat itself lacked a distinct flavor.  Lastly the empanadas were nice, but again nothing special in therms of the filling, and the dough could have been more delicate.

The service in this place was average at best, our waiter took our order, didn't have much to say about any recommendations or specials and he never came back to check in to see how our meal was going or if we needed more wine.  This is a nice place and the service should be far more professional if people are dropping $100+ dinner.  

All and all, I would come back for happy hour and a few other dishes to try but I have no major desire to try the entrees.  I think this is a far better place to dine with friends than a date and a great after work stop rather than a special dinner.
author: Inga W.

description: Unfortunately, a once-great restaurant has gone downhill in the last year.  Routinely poor service, bite-size portions, and outrageous pricing have ruined La Mar.
author: John T.

description: I've been going here for a few years -- it's a great spot.  Beautiful location on the Bay, great ceviches, the causas are excellent -- and the plantain and sweet potato chips they give instead of bread are amazing.  It's in a touristy area and on the water so the prices are a little high -- but the quality is outstanding and I've never had a bad meal in 10+ times visiting.  At lunch, the ceviche sampler is $30, which is a great deal and a lot of flavor.  Don't come hungry, but come for the view and a light meal and you'll be glad you did.
author: Trent W.

description:
La Mar really is an awesome restaurant space that's well-designed and beaming with a bright, exuberant atmosphere. It's very classy, but still keeps a fun energy within its walls -- perfect for a Peruvian restaurant.

The food, however, wasn't as great as I expected for a place with such nice decor and with fairly steep prices. But before I get to the rest of the food, I'm going to start off with the main dish that my waiter (Jason K) suggested that I order. I asked him if I should get the Ma Po Tofu, since I was pretty intrigued to try out a Peruvian-influenced Chinese staple, but he STRONGLY suggested that I go for the Enoki Mushroom Clay Pot. I looked at him with a sense of uncertainty, but he was quite persuasive. Now, I've always had this slight paranoia that waiters are told to push certain items on the menu, not because they're actually delicious, but because they either have a high markup value or they're trying to get rid of it in the kitchen. After this Enoki Mushroom Clay Pot dish, I honestly believe that La Mar participates in that philosophy. 

I'm not saying that the dish was horrible, but for $25, it just really is not that good. Very faint flavors -- nothing really Peruvian at all about it. The two pieces of shrimp in there were pathetically small and overcooked. It's a dish that I would expect to be served at some cheap Chinese restaurant in Chinatown; not to be suggested so enthusiastically by our waiter. Yes, it's my fault for ordering it when my gut believed otherwise, but I just don't like it when I feel like waiters suggest a (unanimously-confirmed by our table of 7) lackluster dish, when there are so many other choices that are much better. It just ruins the experience and my trust in the establishment.

Ceviches (Ceviche Limena, Ceviche Clasico, Ceviche Mixto) = Each of them were okay. I've had much better ceviche at other SF restaurants like Fresca and Limon, but La Mar's weren't too bad. The Tuna Ceviche was my least favorite -- it didn't have much of a flavor and the tuna didn't seem fresh.

Empanada Sampler = Pretty damn good empanadas here, albeit a bit pricey at about $11 for two small pieces. I think they were a bit overly fried, but still tasty nonetheless.

Lomo Saltado = The steak was cooked a little too well done, so it lost some of the buttery flavor that Lomo Saltado should have. I also thought that it probably would have been better with less soy sauce.

Tallarin Saltado = Way too much soy sauce -- this dish was extremely salty. 

Arroz Jugoso = I'd say this is probably the best dish of the night, although the mussels were a little overcooked. It definitely had a nice flavor though.

--------------------------------------

This review has been really tough to write, because I've heard amazing things about La Mar and I was pretty excited to eat there. Other than the waiter suggesting the Enoki Mushroom Clay Pot, I thought that the service was quite good. The venue is incredible and I'm sure the daytime views would be amazing. 

Unfortunately, the food was just disappointing, especially at such steep prices.
author: Roy C.

description:
The service was so poor that it took away from us enjoying the food. My boyfriend and I came here last night for our anniversary dinner and from the moment we stepped inside we received terrible customer service. The hostess at the front desk was disinterested and even answered the phone while i was in mid-sentence. She told us the wait would be around 45 minutes. 

We went to the bar and had some of the delicious drinks while we waited. My boyfriend asked the server working the bar area if she could take our picture and she said she would come back in a minute to do, which of course she never did. She also insisted on ignoring us although we were seated in her serving area.

After being forgotten about for almost an hour, we went up to the front desk and waited to be seated. Fortunately our waiter was very nice and friendly. The food was also very good. We had the yellowtail cebiche to start, I had the pepian special which was great and my boyfriend had the halibut which was very good as well. However, starting the night off with such poor customer service really put a damper on the night and prevented us from fully enjoying our meal.
author: Jen B.

description:
I have to admit that being a vegetarian, I was not that excited to go to La Mar.  After all, it's a cebicheria!  What was I going to eat? 

However, this is where my friends wanted to go for Valentines Day 2010, so I decided to give it a go.  It was a special 4-course menu, which provided a wonderful opportunity to sample various dishes.  I was pleased to find that the staff was very accommodating in making vegetarian substitutions, and everything I had was amazing.  This is gourmet Peruvian food at its best.

The drinks were also very good.  We had the pisco sour, the pisco punch, the Santa Maria and a couple others (between the three of us).  They were all very unique and tasty.

The desserts were spectacular.  Save room for that!

The atmosphere is beautiful, inside and out.  I can't wait to come here when it gets warmer so we can sit on the patio.  

I would definitely recommend this restaurant for a romantic date, a family gathering or even a business lunch (if the other party is paying!).
author: Katie S.

description: The setting is beautiful, the service is fine, the plates are very attractive.  So this restaurant makes for a nice (though expensive)!) night out.  But honestly, the "Peruvian" cuisine disappoints.  I have lived in Peru and love Peruvian food, and what la mar serves  is more California cuisine with a Peruvian influence than the other way around.  If you want truly fantastic honest Peruvian food, the Furia Chalaca in Downtown Oakland is the place to go-  and you will only spend half as much money.  I know they are famous but for the price, La Mar disappoints.  (Not to mention  that their drinks are  on the small side. )
author: K C.

description:
I love the atmosphere of this place... very open, modern... as some have mentioned it does feel you're in South Beach or Cancun. Sitting on the outdoor patio was very relaxing since it was a nice day outside. I like how they have a shaded part, so you can enjoy being outdoors without being in direct sunlight. It made it very hard to go back to work! 

Overall, food was delicious. We had the cebiche sampler, lomo saltado and corazon. My favorite was the lomo saltado, but the cebiche sampler was also a good choice since we got to try out all the different kinds. No complaints with the service either. It did end up being pretty pricy though... a little too pricy I thought. However, the food and overall experience was great so I wasn't too upset about it. 

I can't wait to go back to La Mar. Seems like a great place to take a date or go for happy hour.
author: Alison B.

description:
I should start off by saying each visit here was overshadowed by extremely high expectations, having been set after visiting another two of restaurateur/owner Gaston Acurio's restaurants in Lima, Peru: the original La Mar, one of the most memorable meals of my life at the outstanding Astrid and Gaston...

Deserving Of its Hype: 
- Location, on the docks of the Embarcadero with an outside deck for those cherished SF sunny days
- The Ceviche's- Mmm tiger's milk is where its at...finally a takes on this dish that actually put me straight back in Lima!
- A few other good dishes such as the Arroz Criollo and Anticucho di Pulpo (grilled octopus) 
- Lounging at the bar with a Pisco Sour

Cause for Disappointment: 
- Service, meh: although I've had a good experience when with one or two people, my larger party found ourselves ridden with a pile up of plates, incorrect orders, and this all on a not-so-busy weekday lunch
- Overpriced: food may be of good quality, however not much more impressive than more casual Peruvian spots such as Fresca, while coming out with a lighter pocket than the latter
- Dishes lacking oomph such as the Causa's and Empanada's
author: Mahsa K.

description: We love La Mar, being of South American decent it's hard to find some good Peruvian restaurants on the west coast but boy have we found one! The lomo saltado was so tender and the empanadas were delicious! Everything we ordered off the menu was amazing! Thank you for a wonderful meal and ambiance La Mar!
author: Brianna A.

description:
It's Dine About Town! which is a great excuse to try somewhere you've never been, without the fear of a ridiculously expensive restaurant that you can't afford. Then again, La Mar ended up being cheaper than I expected but just as yummy.

D had never had Peruvian food before (I had been to Inca's on Mission) so we decided to go here for a lunch date. We got both options off their Dine About Town menu, which consisted of a veggie option and a seafood option. Both were good, except the second course of the menu was eh. The dessert was purple yam sorbet, which was delicious and definitely sold me on the entire place, that and the service.

As for the ambiance, the place is really nice. They have a heated outdoor patio as well as indoor and bar seating. The space is open and bright, which is a refreshing change from the usual dark and mood lighting.

Definitely putting it on my list of places to go back and check out again.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Kudos to La Mar for their superb customer service and fine food. From the staff's friendly greeting upon our arrival to courteous (yet unobtrusive) attentiveness by the bus help and wait staff throughout our meal to the scrumptious passion-fruit chocolate mousse (dusted with 24 caret gold sprinkles!) they far exceeded our expectations. We were fortunate to have Sharon as our server. Though she happened to be training a new waiter (while juggling her own tables), Sharon orchestrated a dining experience that had us floating out the door with happy tummies, satisfied taste buds and ear-to-ear smiles. We will definitely be back--next time with reservations so that we can sit at a table (instead of the Ceviche Bar which was what we opted for since we arrived at a busy time). Can't wait to try more deliciousness from their Peruvian cuisine inspired menu!

(Note to Readers: This 5-Star restaurant experience happened shortly after our 1-Star experience at a neighboring place.)
author: edna m.

description: When you need ceviche and to use a little plastic, this is the place. We tried 3 different ceviches and I think they were all different from each other and fantastic. My husband says they were "just sushi" and not the real ceviche. So we disagree sometimes - keeps it real! Also the saltados were wonderful - a bit fancier than in a typical Peruvian restaurant. We also had a dish with shrimp and octopus - with a dash of house hot sauce was excellent. The best part was the amazing tres leches!
author: Erica D.

description:
I was fortunate to come here with a friend's dad who treated us to lunch.  La Mar is a Michelin rated on one of the Piers of San Francisco.  We all started off with a Pisco Sour and boy that was strong.  Not my kind of drink, but it was good.  My second drink was the bacon bloody mary and that was delicious.  We ended up splitting up a whole bunch of dishes and I can't remember everything since the father ordered for us to share.  We got 4 different ceviches (so good), a mix of empanadas (mine had mushroom in it and that was delicious).  We then split orders of a plate of mixed kebabs (beef, chicken, fish) and some other dishes that I can't recall at the moment.  We topped off the meal with picarones which are their sweet potato fritters with powdered sugar and some kind of maple/honey syrup.

Overall, a great meal and I would certainly come here again and try dinner!
author: Byron K.

description: A wonderful Argentia restaurant. I had the Yellowtail and Tuna Tartare Roll, it was so fresh and wonderful. Jeff had a roasted chicken sandwich was also good. We enjoyed the ambience and the service. Our server was friendly and attentive. We sat overlooking the water, which was nice.
author: Rita J.

description:
cebiche chipotle was ok..the spice over powered the dish..tho the scallops and shrimp was really good..the squid was ok..i think ill try another flavor dish next time..is it worth $17? nope...

the salmon fusion..eh..small salmon..not all the way cooked..slightly or barely cooked in the middle..tho it was fine..the coconut sauce was jus too much..cant even taste the real characteristics of the shrooms n broccoli..tho the rice was fairly good..would be better if it was wild or brown rice..

tacu tacu special..the cheesy taste in the lima bean tacu tacu was odd but ok..the halibut was spot on n very delicious..

sand and beach cocktail was good as well..the side of chips (plantain, sweet potato, and potato) went well with the spicy sauce..the mild sauce was bland and didn't taste much of anything..

we dined outside under the heating lamp..it was a nice view of the bay bridge and kept me warm in late Nov..
author: Minerva L.

description: Very good service and atmosphere in general, great views, lots of tables, so usually you don't need to wait to be seated. Food is very good and unusual (a little bit too greasy for my taste though).
author: Misha R.

description: Top tier service who made great food and wine recommendations within our budget.  Their ceviche is absolutely delicious.  They have a beautiful view of the water and its a perfect place to bring groups.  I have been there with 2 but also with 10.
author: Ashley T.

description:
I reluctantly came here because my parent's wanted to try yet ANOTHER Peruvian restaurant and being Peruvian I love my country's food HOWEVER I don't like to try 'fancy' restaurants because I know the best Peruvian food is made by the authentic Peruvians and I'd rather not pay more for less food (duh). Either way the first time I ate here I was blown away by how good the Lomo Saltado was and how tender the meat was! It was like biting into a pillow! the Papa Rellena (appetizer)  was yummy too, kind of small tho (3 tiny papas) I don't remember trying anything else, when I like one thing I stick to it, except the dessert. Picarones here are so good. Personally that is like my ultimate Peruvian dessert. All in all I'd recommend it as a Peruvian Cuisine restaurant deff on the pricey side but worth it.

**August 2017** Update, I came here last month for my brothers birthday and I was disappointed to see that several things were removed from the menu. One of them was the picarones that I raved about in my last post. Also there was a huge sampler plate that was recently removed (within the last year) and that was a big bummer. So disappointing to come back here and see that clearly the audience they are trying to reach is more of the "american" palette rather than focusing on serving authentic Peruvian food. Also they were out of plantain chips when we went which was annoying on top of finding out several things were removed from the menu. I might come back in a couple years to see if this place has changed but overall, I don't think its worth the price anymore.
author: Valeria S.

description:
We had a luncheon last week at Lamars, the food was great but the service was simply Horrible.. A guy by the name of Herb brought us our drinks as we asked him a few questions which he could not answer because he had to reply to a text message. When we asked him what was more important he pretty much gave us attitude.
We will think twice about going to lamar's again...
author: Jeffrey K.

description: Super underwhelming portions and taste for the price. Service was slow across the board with seating, serving, and getting the check taken care of. It's strange that there are so few bathrooms for the amount of people they should expect for a full-size restaurant. I've never had Peruvian food before so I can't attest to how authentic it is or isn't. I had the vegetarian quinoa dish and was sorely disappointed. Out of everyone's dishes, the jalea looked like the heartiest and best-tasting. I guess I'll give some stars for the view, decor, and ambiance.
author: Cat N.

description:
La Mar is an outstanding restaurant with delicious food, a beautiful dining room, and a great bay-side location and view.  There is also a (heated) outdoor deck which is a wonderful spot to enjoy a meal when the weather is appropriate. Really this is one of the more well-rounded dining experiences in the city without getting too 'formal' or too pricy (although its not cheap by any means).  My lunches average around $25/person, dinner around $35+, not including alcohol.  However there are many ways to mix and match the menu to get a great and affordable cross-section of dishes to maximize your experience!

While there are other nice Peruvian dining experiences in SF, this is clearly the local benchmark.  La Mar is a well-known name with several locations in South America.  If you aren't familiar with Peruvian food, don't be intimidated- there are a wide variety of items to satisfy very mixed crowds- great vegetarian dishes as well. La Mar of course features a number of wonderful varieties of cebiche (raw/marinated seafood) featuring tuna, halibut, octopus, prawns, and other sea creatures.  They have very nice empanadas, causas, and grilled skewers- you can combine these items and have a great meal without delving into the main courses.  There are several delicious sandwiches which are great for lunch- including breaded fish, crispy pork belly, and grilled chicken.  Then of course there are a number of delicious main courses- risottos, tuna, and my personal favorite- a delicious traditional Peruvian steak dish called 'lomo saltado' featuring vegetables, fries, rice, and a touch of soy sauce- really fantastic.  Last but not least, the desserts are fabulous, in particular a warm pumpkin fritter dish I have enjoyed several times.

There is a paid parking lot across the street and sometimes street parking along the Embarcadero.   Reservations are recommended but not necessary, although most dinner times have been very busy when I have visited in the past.  I've never had a remotely negative experience at La Mar and place it as a consistent knock-out meal high atop my 'favorites' list.  I'm sure you will have a great experience as well.
author: Andy S.

description: La Mar is a great find on the Embarcadero.  I love ceviche and was looking forward to this lunch.  I had a double portion of the Causa Nikei for lunch and it was excellent.  The outdoor seating is beautiful on a warm day and the view of the Bay is perfect.  Service was very friendly and helpful in choosing the best items of the day.  The prices are definitely on the high-end, but if you're looking for atmosphere and a calm dining environment, this is a great place.
author: Bill M.

description:
I am writing to comment on the DISHONESTY of some of the staff working in this restaurant.

My friend went to eat at this place on Tuesday (9/4/2012) night. Her final charge was $102.20. My friend wrote down $120.00 on the receipt. 

Few days later she checked on her credit card found out being charged $128.00. She called the restaurant and told them to email back the receipt. She found an extra "circle" being written on top of the zero, such that 120 becomes 128.

My friend writes the number "8" in one stroke and would never write down as two zeros. Our conclusion: someone forged the amount! 

This restaurant will not receive any star rating until they have given a reason about this incident.
author: Clione K.

description:
My friends and I came here for dinner yesterday.  The ambiance of this restaurant is really cute, the colors and the accents really make you feel as if you're on the beach in Peru.

The food was okay. The chips they served in the place of bread was very oily but the dipping sauces were good.  The food runner also let us know that one of the sauces were made with peanuts, which I appreciated, as a tree nut allergy sufferer. 

We get the Pisco Sours to drink, which live up to their name.  It was sour alright and really strong.  Word on the street is that they use egg whites to make the foam. Interesting, but it reminded me of a margarita.

We got the sampler empanadas to start which came with a corn one (which was sweet), a seafood one, a chicken one and a beef one.  They were all pretty tasty but the beef one reminded me of an onion ring. The corn was the best and the dough surrounding the empanadas was a little oily but flaky at the same time.

There's a lot of options on the menu for dinner.  Two of my friends og the Cerbiche and the other got the spare ribs. They all said their meal was good. For my main course I got the stir-fry.  The rice came on the side, which I thought was a little weird, and in it was corn on steroids.  I've never seen corn that big! They had a weird taste too, not corn-like.  (I know what you're thinking, maybe it's not corn? but it was).  There were fries on top and chunkc of beef, which were a little over cooked to my liking, but they were flavorful.  There were onions and tomatoes in the gravy, which reminded me of a gumbo.  It had a lot of flavor, but was definitely not what I expected for a stir-fry (being an Asian and all).

The waitress wasn't very attentive and didn't seem to care very much about our table, which was another turn off.  

This was an interesting experience, but a little too pricey for what you get.
author: Marisa R.

description: I only went for happy hour and the drinks were very stiff and the ceviche was delicious! We had a few appetizers and everything was soooo good! Location is prime, very nice decor and great service. I would suggest if you plan on dining to make a reservation since the restaurant is very popular and as most of you know city parking can be a little challenging. I'll be back soon next time I'm up!
author: Vanessa P.

description: Only had drinks but they were amazing, professionally constructed and happy hour was a bonus.
author: Dustin W.

description:
The atmosphere of the restaurant makes it feel like I'm on some island vacation which is nice. Food overall is not bad, however way overpriced and pretentious for something so simple and portion size. Our waiter was nice, however he disappeared a lot and when we needed attention no one really noticed and the busboys are rude! Even when I was looking around, all the waiters and busboys were not even paying attention to how I must've looked impatient waiting for something to ring up the check. 
We had the tuna cheviche for $18 is too expensive for what it is when its so simple that you can make it yourself. But I do have to say that the chips that the restaurant offered as a snack was tasty and had 3 different dipping sauces. The pulpo (octopus skewers) were very flavorful, albeit somewhat chewy and for $18 you only get 3 skewers and its only like 2-3 inches long, soooo not worth it.

Overall, I have to say I would not come back again just because price wise, not worth it. Its a tourist trap pretty much..
author: Lily K.

description: Solid place for a quick bite and a drink. Grab a seat at the bar.
author: Kennie B.

description:
I went here last night with a girlfriend of mine, we grabbed dinner before hitting a night out in the city. We had a glass of wine, followed by some delicious appetizers, TUNA cebiche is to die for a MUST order. We also ordered the chicken empandas which were perfect and then tried a recommendation from the waiter which was the  Arroz  Norteno --  also a very flavorful dish. The staff is very pleasant and helpful, the place is classy and located on pier 1.5 so you have a very scenic display in the back of the restaurant  which also has seating. 

The only reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5, is I wasn't able to try dessert, We got too full!! I will defiantly be making another visit so dessert will be on my things to order. :) Mmmm Can't wait!!
author: Sheana C.

description: Was disappointed in this place.   The best part of the restaurant was the plantains and dipping sauce they gave pre dinner. The ceviche was decent, as well as the empanadas (chicken being the best). But our dinner was cold, we mentioned it to the waiter....who blew off our comment.  I wouldn't be recommending this place anytime soon.   The more I think about it...the more I am disappointed.  Great location on the water, huge restaurant....but much to be desired.
author: Jennifer B.

description: It was pricy, although the foot was not bad, someone came to wash the window directly behind me while we were eating, spraying around us and bumping my chair for several minutes to do so. That spot couldn't have waited?
author: Win M.

description: Service was great. Food was amazing. A little noisy for my taste. I was going for a quiet, romantic, dining by the waterfront sunset experience and was slightly disappointed. :/
author: Sancho P.

description:
Two words: HAPPY HOUR!!! 

From 3-6pm everyday you'll find yummy, well priced drinks and small plates. We tried mostly everything cause I tend to go WAY overboard when I see happy hour prices. But I strongly recommend an order (or two or three) per person of the cebiche clasico and the calamari. 

Go early cause it can get as real as the whole foods parking lot closer to 5pm.
author: Valerie A.

description: We came here for happy hour on a Wednesday night, so this review is for the happy hour menu and experience.  It was packed!  We were super lucky to get 4 seats at the bar, but i would recommend coming earlier rather than later.  By the time 6 o'clock rolled around, the bartenders were definitely in some knee deep weeds.  So, needless to say, the service was mediocre at best.  But, we were pouring delicious happy hour cocktails down our gullets, so who cares!  I think the pisco sour and the pomegranate pisco sour were the most delicious, but also the most potent, so beware!  They're tiny and they go down fast, so take it easy.  Make sure someone gets you the plantain chips.  Our friends bartender got them some, ours did not.  They and the sauces that accompany them were just what we needed to go with our alcohol.  I got the Ceviche Mixto (5 stars, i literally drank the sauce), the Pork Belly Tacos (not the best pork belly I've ever had, but once again, the sauce was crazy good), and the Chicken Empanada, which was very tasty.  The regular dinner menu looked fantastic, and i would love to come back and try that sometime.  Bottom line is we had a great time, and the Peruvians know how to dress up any dish with crazy delicious sauces, so this was a winner for me.
author: kathy a.

description:
Be warned - it is expensive, even taking into account its waterfront location just down from the Ferry Building.  It's not that I have any objection to expensive, per se, but the rating does reflect my impression that certain dishes were not merely expensive but overpriced.

It was really good.  The restaurant was clean and nicely designed.  Our server was upbeat, accommodating, helpful with menu choices and darn friendly.

We stopped by especially for their special Chinese New Year menu - not exactly what one associates with Peru, but they have a large Chinese immigrant community in Peru, and their own style of Chinese food, which we wanted to check out.

After being greeted with an assortment of chips ( plantain, sweet potato, regular potato ) and a couple sauces, we started with the Cebiche sampler.  Four small plates of excellent cebiche in different styles for $34.  Fish was without exception fresh, though we did get a single very strongly flavored mussel in one dish.  I felt the Nikei was a bit sweet for my taste, but overall found it very pleasant.  We also ordered a full-size cebiche from the special Chinese menu, which was perhaps even more delicious than the sampler plate.

For our main course, we got a very saucy and slightly spicy rendition of Mapo Tofu and an Eggplant and Mushroom hot pot over noodles.  Both were nicely flavored, and an interesting departure from more familiar Chinese cuisine, but the star of the meal was definitely the cebiche.  One of the dishes was served with a small bowl of rice and giant corn on the side.

We finished with the special dessert - a parfait of fruits topped with a creme brulee flavored whipped cream in a martini glass.  It was an interesting, refreshing way to end the meal, but maybe not worth the $14 they charged.

The cocktail list here is interesting - they have many creative variations on Pisco drinks, including one flavored with beet juice.  The ones we tried tended more toward the sweet and fruity, and were fairly light on alcohol.  They also carry two Peruvian beers, Cusquena being the more flavorful.

After a couple drinks each plus the afore-mentioned dishes, tax, tip and the Healthy SF charge, we finished somewhat north of $200.  All very nice, but expensive given the alternatives.
author: Albert H.

description:
Pisco sours, pisco sours, pisco sours! :) my best memory.

Came here last week with a friend and enjoyed a nice dinner outside with the view of the bay (lol somewhat!) 

We ordered:

Cebiche Nikei, raw ahi tuna which was one of my favorites of the night.  The tuna was exceptionally fresh, tasty, and the texture was just right.

Chicken & Beef Empanadas, another favorite of mine.  These things made me feel like a pig! LOL I could not get enough! I ate a Chicken empanada "Oh man, these are my favorite ones" 2 min later eating the Beef, "Actually this one is my favorite" stuffing my mouth back & forth saying the same thing :D 

Sushi, don't remember the order name, but had some sushi which I am happy to say was delicious like everything else.  I really enjoyed it because they have such a variety of sauces to dip your sushi & other food in.  I also really enjoyed the fact that they had banana chips at the table, I'm a sucker for these.

In the end I had a great experience, our waiter deserves a million stars! He was more than helpful, sweet, just all around a great guy & this really topped my day.  Great service is hard to find.  End the night with an infamous Pisco sour & you're good to go! They were so smooth, haven't had nothing like it before, topped with 3 droplets of "crack" LOL I say that 'cause I only could hang with 2 of these babies!

Great place.
author: Christina O.

description:
It almost pains me to give La Mar 5 stars. Why? Because it's one of those places that  screams 'trying too hard' at first glance.

On the Embarcadero? Check.

Sissy (almost tapas-style) portions of overly presented food? Check.

Pretentious ethnic variations of terms that have more commonly utilized American spellings? Check.

Amazingly though, the flavors and service here make up for the aforementioned failures. I've been to La Mar for both happy hour and dinner and while both experiences were frighteningly expensive given the relatively casual atmosphere of the place, it was worth every dollar.

Unlike some other reviewers I won't take you through a complete list of everything I ate since frankly who gives a shit, but if I have to recommend one or two things it's the ceviche sampler and the mushroom empanada. The suggestion for the former is obvious given the name of the place, the latter a little more unusual since I don't usually like to clog my system with useless vegetables. Man, if that wasn't one of the best empanadas I've ever had though, then I'm not Asian David Beckham (and of course I'm Asian David Beckham).

Good call, Erin the Server.

Overall, you win this round La Mar. I'll see you again when enough time has passed so that my boss won't get suspicious of me trying to slip by another $400 'business happy hour' on my expense report.

P.S. I can't take off a star for this since it's not fair to rate La Mar under a 5, but for the love of God, clean up the rust stains on the sink in the bathroom near the entrance. Thing looks like Aunt Flo is now paying monthly visits to inanimate objects.
author: Leo K.

description: This place sucked. Our server was inattentive and absent. The food was salty....really really salty. The only redeeming quality was the drinks.  The pisco drinks are pretty good. Its really not worth it to dine here I would suggest coming here for drinks but the server won't ever check back to see if you want another.
author: Jacklyn H.

description: If you love good ceviche, come here....if you want to get a taste with reasonable prices, make it for happy hour! Food was delicious and pricey....but will definitely come back again.  Ceviche sampler, causas sampler, glass of chardonnay, mixed drink and bottle of pellegrino:  $110.00
author: Cheryl M.

description: A great place for a dinner date in SF,  if you like seafood and ceviche.  This Peruvian restaurant is at a great location with a good view of Bay Bridge. They have a nice bar and restaurant arrangement. Good service. Their food menu is somewhat unique and delicious. They have a variety of seafood with many sauces.
author: Alex M.

description:
This place is very pricey and fancy.
Waterfront restaurant and great decor and ambiance; has indoor and outdoor seating.

Lunch was $30-40.  

They give these plantain chips with 2 dipping sauces; definitely a super awesome free appetizer.

Get:
Their soup/stew specials:  I got the one that was a seafood medley with a cream tomato base.  It tasted great, was filling, and the octopus was tender enough to cut with a fork.  Also comes with side of rice.

Okay:
Emapandas are $12 for 2.  They are small and taste delicious, but i still think $6 a pop is a little too high.
author: Steven F.

description:
This place knows how to make a good pisco.  Our server was a very friendly woman who knew the menu very well.  She answered all of my questions and didn't make me feel dumb when asking her how much food she recommended ordering.  The ceviche was really good.  If I could go back, I'd probably order two different types of ceviche, although they do have a sampler plate (I just felt the portions were too small to share with the hungry man I went with).  The one thing I ordered that I thought was just plain icky was their empanadas.  We ordered three different types, the corn, the chicken, the seafood, and beef.  The only one I liked was the empanada de choclo (corn).  The beef one had some strange spices that just didn't jive with my taste buds.  To be fair, however, it wasn't that they were cold, or stale, or tasted like they were of poor quality.  I simply didn't care for the taste.  

The menu has a good variety of food, and we sat at the bar, but I'd like to sit at a table next time.  The bar feels a bit out of the loop from the rest of the restaurant.  The other dish I really enjoyed was the causa limena.  The causas are small, but they're so delicious!  This would be my other suggestion after the ceviche.  I'd like to come back and give this place another chance and see if I can bump them up to four stars.  As for now, I'd say it's worth checking out.
author: Sarah B.

description: We had reservations here on a thursday nite. Spent 25 minutes getting ignored at bar when i was trying to order a drink. We then got seated and put in drinks order. After another 25 minutes of continuing to ask waiter with no drinks in sight, we left restaurant figuring it wouldnt bode well for food service
author: Michael A.

description:
This place is really not that good. Not worth the price. Here is my review, coming from a born-and-raised Peruvian...

Good : the view, the cocktails, location, nice place to take tourists. 

Bad: the food. It's just very disappointing, the ceviche is mediocre. 
Can be a bit pretentious. 
And very overpriced. 

For better Peruvian food in SF, go to Fresca.
author: Fogerjermjen Z.

description:
My friend and I ate here for a lovely 7:00 pm dinner after doing some shopping in the Mission District. Plenty of street parking - no reason to pay $10-$20 parking at Pier 3. 

This dinner was fantastic (maybe one of the best I've ever had). Highlights included: the Ceviche tasting, causo, and an extremely friendly, knowledgable waiter.

We started off with cocktails (vamos pa' chicha for me, the special for my friend). My drink tasted sort of like fruit punch with a cinnamon undercurrent. Was delicious and medium-strong. Our waiter proceded to give a great overview of the entire menu and we decided to order the ceviche tasting, the causa limena, and the arroz jugoso. 

Our waiter mentioned to eat Peruvian food family style, and said he would bring our food in courses. (A nice touch, I like restaurants that don't try to rush customers). 

The causa limena came out first - it was the first time I'd ever tried causa and it was amazing! Causas are combos of whipped potatoes with seafood/veggies on top - ours had crab, tomato, quail egg, and sweet sauce placed gently on top of the yellowy potato mash. The ceviche tasting was INCREDIBLE - I've been to Fresca and Limon in the city and La Mar has by far the best ceviche. There were four types in the tasting; I liked the Nikei and the Chalaco most. The Nikei had a strong Asian influence, with vinegar, sesame seeds, soy sauce, nori, and daikon added to the leche de tigre base. The Chalaco was slightly more traditional and had an orangey sauce with fried calamari on top. 

My friend and I were curious about the ingedients in the ceviches (because they were DELICIOUS as I said before) and asked our waiter for more clarification. He brought out a sheet of paper with 20+ ingredients listed for each of the ceviches. Wow! I was impressed by the detailed, friendly service. 

The arroz jugoso was just okay - a sweet tomato base with rice, white fish, and seafood, but I thought it was a bit bland. 

For dessert, we finished off with the special dessert, pineapple carrot cake with a side of Peruvian ice cream. So good - a great end to a especially delicious meal in the city.
author: Melanie G.

description: Excellent meal. Split a shrimp empanadas appetizer which was delicious. Had the filet dinner which had fantastic flavor with Onions, potatoes and tomatoes in a scrumptious sauce. Oh - and the chips and plantains with the two different sauces were excellent - just the right amount of heat. Great change of pace from the typical bread.  Would definitely come back.
author: Teri R.

description: The empanadas were AWESOME. We got the sampler... twice. My favorite was the mushroom and sweet corn. The meat ones were good too, but the mushroom one was just so flavorful. Wish I could've tried the ceviche too - I've heard great things about it from my roommate. Also really liked the various and chips and dips they bring for every table.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Seeking a special occasion spot for a fancy-pants lunch? Look no further.

There is something very exciting about eating at La Mar. First of all, the restaurant is gorgeous - the ocean is clearly the inspiration for this clean white space with deep blue accents and of course, that is just amplified by views of the bay. The food? The plating is a sight to behold and particularly with tasting plates, each bite is like a completely new experience. I like everything about this restaurant... aside from perhaps the price. And knowing that there's a location in Lima makes it feel that much more authentic.

The tasting plates certainly seem like the way to go during your first visit and are fun for group dining, but now I just go with these top picks (also attempting to try something new each time):  
*Cebiche - Clásico and/or NIkei
*Causas -  Nikei (the standout) and/or Limeña
*Lomo saltada 
*Pisco sours !!!

It's a must-try for San Francisco residents and tourists alike (+perfect spot to take parents). Salud!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
As a newbie to Peruvian cusine it was a no-brainer to try the world re-known Chef Gaston Acurio's La Mar restaurant especially since my partner in crime is from Peru.  Since every Peruvian meal must begin with a drink, one of those unwritten rules according to my Peruvian princess, we decided to try the pisco mosto verde vice regular pisco sour.
