It turned out to be an excellent choice as it resembled the pisco sour texture and taste along with the addition of passion fruit, lime juice, and triplesec.

Appetizer time aka Cebiche time!  We dined on the cebiche chalaco and cebiche carretillero.  Both cebiche's included:
* mussels
* clams
* shrimp
* red onin
* cilantro
* cancha

However, the chalaco also includes Yellowtail and fried calamari while the carretillero offers Yellowtail from Mexico, non-fried calamari, celery, Peruvian corn and yam.  Nontheless both were delicious.

Our third appetizer was the anticuchos pollo (Grilled chicken, potatoes, Peruvian corn and salsa panchita).  Yummy for our tummies.

My Peruvian dined on the pollo anticuchero (Grilled chicken breast, avocado, lettuce, tomato, aioli, crispy sweet potatoes and gouda cheese with a creamy anticuchera sauce on an ACME roll).  I heard no compliants from her just plenty of compliments.  

I ate the anticuchos corazón.  Hmm..grilled beef heart with potatoes, Peruvian corn and a spicy rocoto sauce.  Guess I have a heart to a heart especially since my entree was a surprise.  Once I bit into the beef I knew it was a heart as I've recalled the texture and taste from our DC Peruvian restaurant (Las Canteras).  My Peruvian Princess was amused by my reaction to say the least.  I have to admit it was tasty. 

In summary, the food and environment was outstanding as La Mar foodies will enjoy the tastes of Peru while sitting outside pier 1.5.
author: Charles H.

description:
5 stars for food, 4 stars for service. 
I can not get enough of their fried plantains and dipping sauces! mmM! The ceviche classico is AMAZING, I love how the halibut is always fresh and flavorful but not overwhelming. I don't really care for the yams though.   I also like their beef empanadas and the Dungeness Crab appetizer. I've tried their lamb shank before and it melts in your mouth! The seafood dish was also very delicious and fresh. I love how beautifully my food is always presented at La Mar, makes me salivate some more just staring at other people's food and waiting for my food. Order the Pisco sour, it's light and yummy and try to sit outside on the patio for the view. It's a perfect date night or just catching up with the girls! IBtw, they add 4% for the SF health tax.
author: Suzzie B.

description: This place. The causas (whipped potatoes with amazing stuff on top of them) are my absolute FAVORITE thing in this world. They set them up in the most beautiful way (vertical!) and use a combination of yellow & purple potatoes. It is by far one of my favorite restaurants, ever. The atmosphere, the food, the INCA COLA - amazing tastes like friggin bubblegum soda.
author: Callan B.

description:
This wasn't nearly as good as I was led to believe it would be but it was a little more expensive than I thought it would be. 

The jalapeno cebiche (a special) was a little weird. The carne skewer also had a very odd texture that was not pleasant.  The seafood and beef fried rice dish was decent and the empanadas were actually pretty good, but I've have better and cheaper empanadas elsewhere in the city. 

We also had a few cocktails, but none of them stood out as being very good. I remember the pisco sour at Reed and Greenough as being much better than the one I had here.

Mark this down as another anecdote supporting the theory that "Where there are smiling happy people having fun/when you are near a place full of tourists, don't expect the food to be very good for its price."
author: Jeff L.

description:
My reviews, are based on how often I go to a place. While I can't claim that La Mar is outstanding in any particular way ( other than the Sangria; their Sangrias are fantastic ), I am here several times a month.

It's in a beautiful place, has a wide variety of seating options, including a bar, a giant interior space, and deck with a partial bay view. The food goes from "not bad" to "pretty damn good" (but avoid anything with the word "sampler"), the mixed drinks are damn good, and the service is good enough to not upset me.

Despite not being excellent in any one particular way, it somehow manages to combine a number of good things in a way that keeps me happy and coming back on a regular basis. I figure that's worth 5 stars.
author: Max R.

description:
Great food, nice servers, always clean, great food.  Only thing I didnt like is there are only two restrooms, which can suck after having a few beers!  
Also, sit outside if you can!
author: lauren s.

description: Great ambiance, cuisine and service.
author: Barney C.

description:
So I decided to throw my wife a surprise 30th birthday party and La Mar was one of the few places in SF that could accommodate the size of my party.  From the start, Fatima, the events coordinator, was on top of everything, answered all my questions, and really made me feel taken care of.  As the event date grew closer, Fatima assisted me with wine selections and also was extremely helpful with selecting the perfect menu.

We were seated on 'el patio al la mar' which is the outside seating area.  I initially thought this would be a problem because it is in fact outside, but it is completely enclosed and there are many heaters.  In fact, we had to ask the waiter to turn off/down the heater because it got too warm.  The table was perfectly set and there was a personalized menu with my wife's name at each setting. As soon as we sat down the wine began flowing and was paired by our waiter to the menu selections as they came out from the kitchen.

We started with cebiche mixto which is the catch of the day and La Mar's famous 'aji amarillo leche de tigre'.  This happened to be octopus and it was amazing.  Octopus, if not prepared carefully tends to get very chewy, but this was prepared perfectly.  Next we had the ensalada tiradito which is a salad prepared with thinly sliced tuna and papaya.  This was a very tasty salad but failed in comparison to the final of the first course.  The last salad, ensalada limena, was out of this world!  An arugula and spinach salad was served with queso fresco cherry tomatoes and dressed with the 'aji amarillo' vinaigrette.  This was by far the best salad and everyone at the table agreed.

The main courses included the chicken empanadas, which were very tasty but a bit on the dry side, arroz norteno, a seafood rice that left me desperately wanting more seafood, and finally La Mar's famous lomo saltado.  This is by far the best lomo saltado I've ever tried (yes better than Frescas and Limon's).  The sauce, soy sauce, garlic, and the 'aji amarillo' sauce, was absolutely fantastic.  The beef tenderloin was perfectly cooked and the fried potatoes were crisp and not soggy.

Surprised at how full I was, I completely forgot about desert which I was not expecting to be as elegant and tasty as it was. For my wife a large puff pastry stuffed with ice cream along with a piece of chocolate cake was brought out.  For the table there were two selections, individualized chocolate ganache shots (served in a shot glass and small spoon) and raspberry sorbet served over a small piece of chocolate cake.  Both were excellent and gone within seconds from the entire table.

Overall, celebrating my wife birthday here was an amazing experience and La Mar did a fantastic job with the details and making the night special.  From the small details of personalizing the menu to pairing the wines with the menu selections, it was all spot on.  The food was fantastic and the service was impeccable from start to finish.  The prices were all preset based on the menu selections and were fair.  My wife and I are already planning out next visit.
author: Matt J.

description: Delicious-absolutely delicious! Their outdoor patio is the perfect lunch / cocktail spot! The Cebiche sampler is fresh perfection as were the skewers and empanadas. Highly recommended! @sfmagazine
author: Michelle Q.

description:
Went to La Mar for my birthday dinner. We had a party of 12. For large parties, the restaurant requires that you pick from a prefix menu. It was rather complicated having to choose the menu and also give them my credit card information for the reservation, but result was well worth the effort.

We had the following for dinner:
Appetizers: Cebiche chifa mahi mahi, cebiche clasico, anticuchos de carne
Especiales: Cau cau, asado de tira and chorillana
Para acompanar: ensalada limenaquinoa tabouli

The mahi mahi ceviche was marvelous, not fishy at all and well balanced. The short ribs stole the show. It was braised in some sort of port reduction, so amazing!!

The atmosphere was great, servers pretty attentive; the food was lovely and well presented. Definitely a good place to go for special occasions.
author: Alice W.

description:
This review is only for the bar area.  Came here for happy hour which is nice that they have everyday 3-6 even on weekends.  We got some drinks.. it's $6 for a medium sized cocktail, but I got a couple pisco sours and I liked them a lot.  We ordered some food, their ceviche mixto and a pork belly sandwich?  Well they were out of the pork belly sandwich even though it was still early.  The ceviche was very small, with one large shrimp, one small piece of fish, and lots of pickled red onion, big corn things and some calamari rings.  It was good and tangy.  

The service was bad.  I didn't understand it at all.  Bartender gave us the bill, I put my credit card in, and he just stared at it from a far.  It wasn't crowded at all, he knew he just handed it to me, he wasn't doing anything else.  He turned away a couple of times.  I nodded at him, nothing.. he just stayed at the other side of the bar.  Finally I waved him over and he came over.  It wasn't like we sat there for 20 mins or anything, but I thought it was weird.
author: Easter E.

description:
La Mar was very different than what I expected, in a good way.  For instance, I thought the cebbiche would be like poke.  I like sushi but I'm not that fond of poke.  But I like people who dismiss things without trying them even less than poke, so I tasted everything in the 4-cebbiche sampler and found it light, a little sweet and very delicious.  Especially the calamari, which was smooth and tender and extremely fresh.

I was also wrong about the plantain chips.  A strip of dried banana-like crunchiness dunked in spicy sauce doesn't sound appealing at all, but it turned out to be very nice.  Fortunately more food arrived before I could gorge on these.

I was proven wrong again on the empanadas; I figured they'd be a little greasy, since they're fried.  But they're not.  They're actually light and crisp and very tasty.  And I was wrong yet again about my entrée, which sounded like your basic surf and turf, but as it turns out, both the surf and the turf were cut up and mixed together in a heavenly sauce along with some more of that awesome calamari, flanked by some very flavorful pozole and some delicious potato discs. 

I was very right regarding dessert.  I have this fetish for passion fruit, and the mousse dessert made me very happy.  It had chocolate on top, raspberry on the bottom, and a long stretch of creamy center that mixed very well with the passion fruit puree (after I ate all the chocolate first, so it wouldn't distract me from the passion fruit) (there was some raspberry stuff on the bottom but I was mainly interested in the passion fruit so ignored it).  My dinner buddy had the fritters, which looked exactly like donuts, with a nice chewy texture. 

Everything was light and fresh and tasty.  The waiter was friendly and the service was prompt. 
 
And finally, I'm a restaurant acoustics prima donna.  Nothing wrecks a meal like continually mishearing your dinner buddies while all the ambient noise bounces from one stark/chic flat reflective surface to the next and the annoying shrill nasal laugh of that diner seated 10 yards away sounds like it's aimed directly at your ear.  La Mar has a mostly-exposed kitchen, and I didn't even notice this fact until dessert time.  I'm sure the kitchen folks there are as prone to crashing pans around and cussing as they are in every other restaurant, but the fact that I didn't even hear them tells me La Mar is doing something very right as far as the sound level.  This is a large place, even a crowd-friendly place, but it's also a place where the ambient noise is well under control.
author: C D.

description:
Yumz. 

This place is a bit pricey. I don't think the food is so amazing that I would come back again because of the large price tag...nonetheless, my stomach was happy and not overstuffed. 

We got to sit on the outdoor patio, which was a really nice setting. We could see the lights from boats crossing by and feel a soft breeze. The space heaters kept the area warm so I was sitting comfortably. 

The service was very slow. I think it took about a hour for any of our appetizers to come out. Also, we asked for a glass of water that never made an appearance. 

Since we had a large dinner party, we ordered the ceviche tasting and an empanada sampler as appetizers. All were good. I think my favor ceviche was the mahi mahi; however, I don't know for sure...they all ended up tasting the same to me. The corn empanada was definitely the best. The sweetness countered the fried part.

I ordered the roasted white sea bass served with massed yucca, South America's version of a potato / yam.  The yucca was delicious. A nice texture you would hope good mashed anything would have. It also had a lightness and was flavorful. The white sea bass was very nicely cooked.
author: Margaret R.

description: Literally one of the best ceviches I have ever had.  I haven't been to Peru, but outside I'm fairly confident La Mar serves the best around.  My mom and I dined there to celebrate our August birthdays, and we had such a wonderful time.  Started out with the prickly pear margarita, and a pisco sour both of which were well made and balanced.  Everything we tried, the ceviche, the causas, the anticucho de corazon were all perfectly prepared and delicious.  The restaurant itself is beautiful and open.  Oscar and Nick were wonderful helping us pick out wine and food.  For desert we had a chocolate cake with passionfruit mousse that was incredible, and I'm not even that big on dessert, so yeah.  Thanks so much La Mar!
author: Leslie H.

description: Great ceviche and drinks! I haven't been amazed by the cooked food here, but I love to come to La Mar for a bowl of ceviche and a pisco sour. My favorite is the ceviche mixto, because I love having a variety of seafood, but the classic ceviche is also tasty. It's well worth a visit on the touristy Embarcadero.
author: Hannah G.

description:
The corn empanada was pure heaven.  My chichamorada was fab!!  I was dining on the water and the view was stunning.  My lomo saltado was like butter - awesome.  

My family ate at the one in Peru and they were so excited to hear what I had to say and not at all surprised to find my stellar review.  Loved it here.
author: Shannon M.

description:
I came here with a friend for lunch for the dine about town experience and it was pretty nice. 

Food: 
TWO pre-set menus for dine about town and we ordered both of them. 
Option #1: 
1) braised beef: really tender and juicy! Loved the flavor! 
2) Cebiche: Loved it!! Very delicious! Very well marinated! The sour/tangy flavor really burst in your mouth! 
3) Strawberry/Mango sorbet: Strawberry was bitter, the mango was pretty good but the sorbet was overshadowed by how good the lemon meringue was!
Option #2: 
1) Quinoa: very soft and well seasoned. 
2) Salad: loved the dressing! I really liked the freshness of the ingredients!
3) Lemon meringue: BEST dish of the meal! Sweet enough to satisfy a sweet tooth but not too overbearing! It came in a cup so if you dig far enough downward then you'll find crumbles of what tasted like pie crust. it was like an extra nice surprise! 
**On the house Plantain, sweet potato and potato chips with two types of sweet dips: Very nice way to wet the appetite before the main course comes. 

Ambiance: 
Right on the edge of the pier, you get a nice view of the bay. The restaurant gets plenty of sunlight. The decor is very bright and tropical themed featuring turquoise as the main color scheme. It almost made me forget that it's 50 degrees outside in the dead of winter right now. 

Service: 
Nice, no complaints. 

Price: 
Pre-fixed dine about town prices of $17 each person. Given the small portions, I would say that this place is kinda over priced! 

Overall:
I think it would be nice to dine here again and try other things on the menu. I just hope the portions aren't as small as dine about town portions.
author: Amiee H.

description: Today I had a great lunch here with my brother. Carlos was our server and he thoroughly explained the menu and provided great service. Great for lunch on the beautiful bay.
author: Nicole C.

description:
3 stars is for the food.Empanada and ceviche were yummy! The food was delicious but service fell short. It is a $$$ restaurant so you would think service is $$$. 
Unhappy host. 8 pm reservation had to wait until 820. Asked if we wanted to order drinks while we waited, sorry but if it's not complimentary for waiting 20 mins then no. Server wasn't super friendly & he looked tired like he didn't really care. Food took long to come out, server didn't check on us, we ran outta of our cocktails, they took our plates away before we finished the dish (which were super tiny portions), EMPLOYEE came out of bathroom after #2 w/apron still ON (that is a serious health code violation!) They ran out of a dish and a cocktail. I can understand running out of a certain dish, but a drink..... lastly the outdoor heat lamps  was on blast burning our foreheads while we ate. So sad because I wanted to come back for HH but I guess i gotta find some place else. ***oh yeah the BDay dessert was hard as a rock. It was prob premade and left in the freezer. and the pan cotta texture was off more like hard jello. and not custardy.
author: Lola S.

description:
Causas are delicious... small mounds of creamy, whipped potatoes topped with seafood! The beignets were amazing too... filled with warm, melted chocolate that oozes out when you take a bite, with ice cream!

We shared a few other things tapas style (empanadas, Peruvian version of sashimi, and cebiche) which were also enjoyable and well-prepared.

Although I will probably go back, if just for the causas and beignets, the reason I can only give this place 3 stars is that I find it too expensive for the portion sizes. I'll probably give it another try for happy hour!
author: Kavita S.

description:
Wow... La Mar, I had SUCH high expectations of you - perhaps since I've only heard nothing but good things about you.

We got seated right away at a table for four.  our waitress came right away, introduced herself. on her second stopby we asked her the fish of the day. said she had go to check. over 10 mins later she comes back to take our orders. fish of the day? "i heard two different things... so i think its this one". great.
takes our drink orders. two piscos, one sangria, bottle of white.
food starts rolling out.... we ordered some of the skewers without bell peppers since my MIL is deathly allergic. what's on the skewer? bell pepper. strike one.
drinks arrive. "can we please have our wine?" oh sure!
another 20 minutes roll by. "can we get the wine?" sure.
another block of minutes go by. "... and the wine?" of course. 
strike 2.
while we're chowing down we realize we're missing something. "and the shrimp?" "oh, ah, er, its coming". rushed shrimp that's not cooked all the way? strike 3.

i mean look. all of the other dishes were outstanding. but if your servers keep messing up and not owning it, then i have a problem. yes, i've worked in restaurants before. 

and the check? it took at least 25 mins for us to pay/check out.

just not thrilled with the service. no dessert or coffee or anything taken off the bill or even offered for the craptastic service. thanks la mar. i thought we could've had something.
author: laura f.

description:
The cocktails are really good but the food just isn't doing it for me. I wish they had more of a happy hour set up for the back patio. It's such a nice spot and would be packed after work if it were more of a social vibe.

The "sushi" was ok but overly sweet. Chips were greasy, as to be expected. I ordered a beef dish that reminded me of Chinese beef broccoli. I got really excited when I saw the giant corn kernels. Yes, I'm an idiot. They did not taste like corn, but were just chalky and grainy with no taste.

skip the food and sit at the bar.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
There is just so much to love about La Mar. Where should I start? Their fancy cocktails or the wonderfully prepared ceviches and entrees? Either way, you will not be disaapointed.

My friend Amy, brought us to La Mar for our first visit to San Francisco. It was sunny, so of course, we had to sit outside by the bay. Their menu is very interesting but their specialty was apparently the different kinds of ceviches. So we ordered a sampler of four ceviches to try - Mixto, Chifa, Nikel, and Clasico. My favorite is the ahi tuna and the halibut ceviche - they were elegantly seasoned with the right amount of lime and onion-y condiments. When I make ceviche, mine gets too sour due to being drenched in a sea of lime juice.

We also ordered their sushi but my favorite was their arroz norteño and the grilled beef heart skewers. The heart was surprisingly tender and there's none of those funny tastes that you get when eating offal sometimes. The barbecue sauce also goes well with the hominy and potatoes. On the other hand, the rice was flavorful and was presented beautifully. It reminds me of a good plate of seafood paella but with a vibrant green color and delicious Huancaína sauce. This is one of the best rice dishes I've have in a while.
author: Kwoky L.

description: Amazing food & service!! Delicious ceviche sampler, carne, and salmon with very flavorful sauce. Great experience, highly recommend & will definitely return!
author: Ami W.

description: One of the best places to do happy hour. They have great food consisting of yucca fries, ceviche, pisco sours.
author: Amy T.

description: Excellent food, excellent location. I just think it's way too expensive for what they give you and the portions they serve. Tiny plates and very expensive!Come on people, we are talking about Peruvian food here! Are we eating food brought from Machu Picchu? If you have the money you will love it.
author: Sanjeev T.

description:
I came here with some family and had a great time!

We came here during the Thanksgiving holiday....I know this review is late.

There was a nice group of patrons when we were here. Their restaurant was closed because we arrived too early, but when you are hungry - you are hungry. 

I ordered their Beet cocktail which was different, but nice and refreshing. I liked the caipirinha which was strong -- yes!! 

My brother ordered a huge mix of dishes. Everything was delicious. I couldn't stop, but I had to. The food was very fresh. 

We literally ordered almost everything from the bar menu I think. I would definitely come back here.

Best part was watching the soccer game, and watching a mother playing with her toddler who sat on the bar table...what?!

When are we going back?
author: Anisha G.

description:
Friday evening after work was time to hop on BART & head into the city to meet the girlfriend. She, in turn, was meeting up with an old college friend along with that friend's husband. The 4 of us were converging on La Mar Cebicheria Peruana for happy hour, meet & greet, catching up on old times & general joviality. For me, it was my first encounter with Peruvian food & drink.

From the nearest BART station, it's not too long of a walk along a beautiful stretch of waterfront to the Pier 1 1/2 building in which La Mar is housed. Immediately turning right upon entering, I saw my party already seated at the nearby corner of the bar & saving me seat. Precious real estate considering how busy & full it was.
 
The bar area of La Mar is a modern & clean looking space employing a liberal amount of glass, steel & concrete in its design. With this sort of construction, acoustically, busy & full means loud. Even shouting conversation can't be heard more than 2 seats away. Being the last to arrive, I was the only one without cocktail. I decided to start off with one of the drinks from the Happy Hour menu, a Pisco Punch. So, if you don't already know, pisco is basically a Peruvian brandy. A Pisco Punch is: pisco, homemade pineapple syrup, lemon juice. This would be a fantastic drink on a really hot day. Though there has been a severe shortage of hot days this Summer, this drink was still enjoyable on a cold & windy evening in the city.

To help soak up our libations, we ordered a pair of Causa Tasting dishes (there's a comprehensive 'gastronomic dictionary' on the La Mar website for looking up Peruvian food terms, like 'causa') & a pair of Anticuchos de Pulpo (grilled octopus skewers). The Causa Tasting dish is a sampler of 4 causas & each had a different, distinct, delicate sauce. All were nicely tasty. The octopus skewers were tender & also covered in a tasty, delicate sauce. While chomping on the snacks, my drink ran dry.

As busy as it was, service from the bartenders was just a bit spotty for the next drink & the one after that. Trying some of the girlfriend's Pisco Sour & a couple other pisco cocktails, all the pisco drinks I had were pretty good & unlike other drinks I've had as pisco isn't exactly a common liquor. With our food & drinks down, we settled our tab & went for a short walk around the Pier 1 1/2 building. Being down by the water, La Mar is in a nice, scenic area.

La Mar is a good looking spot in a good looking part of the city. Happy hour deals are decent & bring in a lively crowd. The drinks & appetizers at La Mar were a welcome little introduction to the tastes of Peru.
author: John M.

description: You know a place has bad service when the manager asks you how you're doing, you tell him not so good, and he turns and walks away.
author: Randi H.

description: We were trying to go to hog island but it was closed for maintenance... Slanted door next door was reservation only ( heard great things) ... We walked to la mar cause I was craving seafood. Lots of reviews. We walked in got a table for 2 easily. 1st off was the ceviche la mar (4 types) the calamari and tuna was very best one... Next was the corazon skewers (wow) it's a must try! I am glad we stopped by here so far... Service was kinda slow but it was some what busy. It's a must try.
author: Tone N.

description:
I've eaten at La Mar twice and both times have found the food and service to be quite good.  

I had never eaten Peruvian food prior to my first dinging experience at La Mar and found the food to be really unusual and very good.

As a person with a disability (I use a wheelchair for mobility), I am also very pleased to know that the owners are making every effort to make their restaurant completely accessible.  Much appreciated and I will be back!
author: Richard S.

description: La Mar has great food!  We ordered two different entrées which were both amazing! Great portions and very tasty! We have been to Peru and have to say that this is some of the best Peruvian food that we have had outside of Peru. The ceviche was a little disappointing though. We ordered the sampler option and for 32$ it was unimpressive, both in size and taste. The ambiance here was alright, not great but it was fine. I will definitely return!
author: Katelin N.

description: I have been to La Mar many times over the last couple of years.  They definitively have the best ceviche in town, but everything else has gone down in quality based on my last 2 visits.  Not sure if these were off days, but the quality and taste of the food is not worth the price anymore.
author: Gabi P.

description: Food is great!  Locale and amazing bar is what makes this place work for me (near the Waterfront).  HH is packed, but worth it.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
It's a trendy place and always packed but always have a good dining experience. Peruvian is one of my favorite cuisines so La Mar is on the list of go to SF restaurants. 

Drinks are great - the Pisco Sour and lots of fruity concoctions that girls love.
Yummy ceviche, although plates are kind of small.
Love munching on the dried plantains.
Braised beef is awesome.

Overall - tasty food, great location on the water and Embarcadero but pricey for small plates.
author: Alex C.

description:
Good atmosphere and perfect place for taking visitors from out of town.
I brought someone for business dinner and It turned out to be a good one.

Food is just ok...., but I just like authentic home style ceviche, that is all.
I would not choose here for family dinner with my hubby.
author: MJ F.

description:
Good & Not So Good...

Pros:
- Cebiche Clásico $17 with halibut was outstanding
- Complimentary fried chips were starchy, but good
- Unique flavors of other foods
- Pisto drink had good balance of sweet & sour
- Friendly waiter (Oscar)

Neutral:
- The Empanada sampler plate for $20 was just ok.  Thought the mushroom version was the best, followed by the corn & cheese, then the chicken.  The beef was pretty basic.  Not sure why they choose to fry them (vs. bake) because they were very bready and heavy.  The accompanying sauce was also heavy.  Opted not to finish all that fried food.

- The Tallarin Saltado $21 (seafood noodle dish) was just OK.  It tasted more like an Asian black bean sauce than anything else.  All the fish was fried, which surprised both of us.  Swear the menu said that only the calamari were battered.  Yet, everything was fried and not sautéed like the menu showed.  Again, it made for a heavy meal.

Cons:
- We arrived in jeans and without reservations.  The hostess politely offered us the"tall tables", which shortly discovered are in far corner of the the Ceviche bar.  We were totally on our own like being in a restaurant that hadn't opened yet.  There were there no customers and no serving staff either.  NOTE:  As we left a comparably dressed couple was being offered our same lonely table.

- The bathroom, which was a unisex room directed to by the hostess (directly across from her station) was FILTHY &  GROSS!  No one had done maintenance there for a least a day.  It was worse than a gas station bathroom.  Did not want to touch a thing.

Overall:
We have never had Peruvian food before, so we cannot comment on authenticity like other Yelpers.  The flavors were different and fun.  But, it was pretty expensive $82 (without tip) for two drinks and small portions that were, for the most part, essentially basic.

But, maybe we ordered the wrong combinations?
author: Tony S.

description: Its been a while since Ive been back here and its definately not like I remembered it. First off...I would definately go back for the ambiance. This place is beautiful, and evokes feelings of airyness and a beachyness as its right by the water and has high ceilings and lots of light. They play brazilian music that is so nice...it all takes me away to differnt place far away in south america. Secondly, I would definately go back for the food. Its different thank anything else around...with traditional peruvian classics(see my photos). I really enjoyed the sangria...even though it took me a while to get it. Yes...the service here was extra slow and Im not sure I would go back for that. I sat by the counter and even though all the servers were walking past me nobody stopped to asked if I needed anything and they kept forgetting to bring me things I ordered. I was kind of anoyed. There are plenty of other fantastic restaurants around...dont waste your time here!
author: Danielle M.

description: I came here with the boyfriend during Dine About Town and got a good sampling of the menu. It was my first time having Peruvian and the food was delicious and the service was friendly. We got ceviche, empanadas, salmon, steak... everything was amazing. We also got the passionfruit mango mousse cake, that was probably the only thing we were not fans of.
author: Katharine G.

description:
This restaurant is fantastic. I went in not quite knowing what to think, but came out incredibly satisfied. 

I'm the kind of person who likes to engage with people, and the staff at La Mar didn't seem to mind. 
As a (still learning) spanish speaker, i noticed that many of the staff spoke spanish, and didn't mind taking my order, and doing everything else, as such.

The staff was just overall friendly, asking me about my interests, and starting nice, enjoyable conversation. 

Not to mention the food which was absolutely FABULOUS. 

And coming from someone who isn't typically a seafood fan, that means something. 

I got the empanadas, and was blown away. I half expected the typical dry, fried dough stuffed with tough, unimpressive filling, but got delicious, moist, empanadas that had delicious, flavorful filling. 

And the atmosphere is amazing too. they've turned a waterfront restaurant space into a modern, charming space that would be great for a party, or an intimate evening.
author: Will C.

description: This was our first time trying Peruvian food and it was a great experience. We sat outside overlooking the bay bridge at night with the beautiful lights. The variety of chips they bought out were delicious and much better than the typical Mexican tortilla chips and salsa. We ordered chicken empanadas as an appetizer and had the salmon for dinner. The salmon came cooked in a curry sauce with saffron rice which was delicious and kind of tasted like a Thai dish. We enjoyed the whole meal along with the ambiance and service.
author: Ashok P.

description: Decent Peruvian food- esp the appetizers/ empanadas
author: Romita J.

description: La Mar is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. It is such an amazing dining experience. Peruvian food itself is so amazing, and La Mar finds great ways to put their own touch on each dish. Every ceviche dish is unique and delicious, and every time I go there (which is often) I try to order something new off the menu. There hasn't been anything I haven't liked yet. I particularly recommend the Roll Nikei. The drink menu is also fabulous and they have a variety of piscos, which is a great alcohol if you've never tried it. I really like the Scarlet drink, it's so fruity and delicious. Usually the service is really good, and I always end up staying there for hours.
author: Regina L.

description:
Great service, great atmosphere, great food. This is one of my favorite restaurants. If you like tapas - this is a place for you. You probably better off to park on the other side of Embarcadero (but not on the street itself) or you can always do valet. This place has an inside area and a covered patio area with heaters that is also quite nice, considering you have a bay view.  

This place is located in a touristy area and it comes as a surprise that the food would be actually tasty. The prices are somewhat higher than average Peruvian food, but worth every penny. This place is good for some type of occasion, its formal looking and expensive enough to keep (at least me) you from coming here too often. The only other thing that I remember is their great pisco sours!
author: Andrew S.

description: Delicious food!!!! I want to try everything on the menu. The free chips and flavorful dipping sauces are amazing.  I highly recommend it!
author: M G.

description:
Where to start?  The setting is beautiful with great views of the waterfront, the staff is friendly, gracious and thoughtful, the food is sublime and the overall experience is as good as it gets.
The must try here is the Cebiche.  The fish is fresh, expertly dressed in Leche de Tigre. silky in the mouth and delicious. We went there to celebrate our wedding anniversary and had a fabulous experience from start to finish. The Pisco Sours are done just right and even the coffee was terrific. We tried the Arroz Criollo and were delighted with the plethora of fresh seafood in the flavorful rice. It is now the dish I will want to order every time I visit La Mar.
 *I do wish the chef would consider regularly offering the toasted quinoa with chocolate and caramel mousse, as that dessert is simply one of the single best dishes I have ever tasted. I had it the first time I came to La Mar was immediately smitten with the amazing flavors and contrasting textures.  I never appreciated quinoa before but found a new appreciation for it when I tried this dish.
author: Janet V.

description: My stomach did thank me the night I had dinner at La Mar! One gem of a place in SF.
author: Rabab M.

description:
I was extremely excited to visit La Mar in SF since I have dined in 3 other Gaston Acurio's restaurants while on vacation last September in Peru. Unfortunately, La Mar does not do justice to Gaston Acurio's great reputation as the Ambassador of Peruvian Cuisine. 

We were tourist dinning for lunch on 12/24/2011. I start with the positives; great location, adequate service, great Kobe Beef Tiradito and Causa sampler. We were a party of 4 and for one of my guests, this was a first-time experience with Peruvian Cuisine. The sampler empanada was quite bland, almost insipid.  The Cebiche Clasico was nothing to rave about and the Pan con Lomo Sandwich and the Pollo Anticuchero were sandwiches that I could have found at any sandwich shop. The Almuercito Chalaco was forgetable ...

My daughter and I had Pisco Sour cocktails, which by the time we were done with the meal I had a headache - cheap Pisco, perhaps? My daughter found a hair in her Lomo Sandwich, so they gave us a courtesy dessert sampler. When it arrived, it had lint on it, which the waitress herself first saw and was clearly enbarrassed. I declined further desserts. 

Management conpensated us for the mistakes by taking the Pisco Sours off the bill, but those mistakes were not the worst part. Who hasn't found a hair in their meal, right? The worst part was the mediocre meal. It was far below our expectations for a restaurant of Gaston Acurio's reputation.
author: Charo g.

description:
Well I have now had Peruvian food  here and it left my knees trembling!

Not exactly trembling, but the "Cebiche Mixto" and "Causa Limena" were to. die. for.

Note to owner/management: Your front of house guy Zack is really what made my experience there the best! Refreshing personality, prompt seating and made sure I was comfortable.

We even joked around on the way back to the table- he probably now thinks I'm a serial killer. On any note, he needs to be paid top dollar!


I'll return to you La Mar and I'll leave the creepy jokes at the door! =)
author: Meghan W.

description:
All I can do is rave about this place! Never had Peruvian food, but I'm definitely a fan now!

We had a few appetizers, including an assortment of the ceviches... INCREDIBLE. So perfect. All of the seafood was divine and the portions were huge! The drinks here were delicious as well... the Pisco Sour was perfection. 

What else is to say? Besides the fact that everyone should try this place!
author: Madeleine T.

description:
I love this place!

First of all, the drinks were great.  I cannot recall the name of my friend's drink, but it was sweet, sour, fizzy with a jalapeno floating in it so there was a touch of heat right at the end.  Really great!

We shared a cebiche and a potato appetizer with crab and avacado on top.  Really really good and left us wanting more.  I had a grilled octopus and seafood dish that was amazingly fresh with octopus as tender as I had ever had.  My friend had a salmon dish with a kind of curry coconut sauce that was just great.

Service was amazing!  I only took away one star because even with reservations, we were seated on a porch / tent covered area that had ceiling heaters cranked up so high we were roasting.  We asked them to turn them down (they turned them off) resulting in a cold draft coming in from a crack in the tent cover.  Overall though, they were able to regulate the temperature about halfway through our meal.

I would pass on dessert here as the desserts were just ok - nothing over the top delicious.
author: Karen H.

description:
My first taste of Peruvian food! Quite an experience.

First off, I looooove the atmosphere at La Mar. I totally felt like I was in Cancun with the bright colors of the restaurant decor and the oceanfront view. We started off with some plantains chips (dried bananas) and two different dipping sauces that were equally delicious. We also ordered a few cebiches (fresh fish marinated in fresh squeezed lime juice and our special collection of spices and herbs) and they were ALL good! The fresh fish included like...shrimp, calamari, tuna, hamachi, etc. We also got this appetizer that had potato in it that was really good.

For my main meal, I got the lomo saltado which is supposedly the most popular Peruvian dish. Did NOT like this very much at all!! It was basically pieces of really really salty steak and french fries. Big whoop. 

The cebiches and the potato appetizer were really good though. Main meal was meh.
author: Sophia L.

description: Romantic restaurant. Scenic views. Decent food. Terrible service. I probably won't be back.
author: Pretty Intelligent A.

description:
After recently returning home from a trip to South America my wife and I were craving some ceviche.  We stopped by Le Mar for lunch looking to satisfy our craving and were treated to a wonderful meal.  We tried the ceviche sampler and were thoroughly impressed with the cebiche clasico, cebiche mixto, and the cebiche nikei.  We washed down our ceviche with some creative cocktails that complimented the the spice and tang of the ceviche well.

When you get a chance to pop into Le Mar I recommend sitting at the bar as the service there was very prompt and the bar staff was extremely friendly and personable.
author: Oski B.

description:
I took my girlfriend here for our anniversary. This was an excellent choice! The food was fantastic and the ambiance was perfect. The waitress was able to provide insight into what the best choices would be for the evening and she picked just the right dishes. 

My only complaint, it is a small one, is that the waitress was somewhat rude when correcting my pronunciation of menu items. I know I was pronouncing the items correctly but she insisted on repeating me with the correct accent added. Nothing major but trying to correct patrons every time can make them feel awkward.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Great food and presentation, but overpriced. Honestly, I think you're paying for the premium SF spot and view, which is spectacular BTW. We had a party of 15 and had no complaints about the food, service, or drinks. 

The atmosphere is great for a night on the town and I will be back for the delicious drinks.
author: Raskolnikov I.

description: Awful experience.  We walked in at 12:15 and stood in front of the reception desk.  There were 3 employees talking behind the desk.  None of them acknowledged us.  We stood there for a minute.  A woman came in after us and approached the desk, and they seated her immediately.  I approached the desk, and the guy looked at me like I was inconveniencing him.  I said we were trying to be seated.  He told us to sit in the reception area.  We sat.  More people came in and were told to seat.  We waited 5 minutes, and no hostess came to seat anybody.  The restaurant as not full.  We were turned off by the stuck-up attitude and lack of service/acknowledgement of our existence.  Sad because the place looks cool.  Crappy attitude and service prevented us from even getting seated.  I would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Incognito O.

description:
Alright. So the best things about this restaurant were the ambiance, the appetizer, and our waiter...

Super expensive, and the food is really not that great. Ive been eating Peruvian food since I can remember and I just found this taste to be really disappointing. I went in super optimistic and happy because the owner of this restaurant is a really well known and renowned chef in Peru. 

We ordered the ceviche mixto. The portion was what I was expecting for a high scale restaurant, but the taste was super bland. It also wasn't spicy in the least bit like the traditional kind. I'm assuming this is because it is located in a very American area. 

For the main course, we ordered tacu tacu, arroz norteño, lomo saltado, and tallarin saltado. My favorite was the lomo saltado. The beef was really tender and tasty. We didn't order dessert, but when tw waiter brough our check, he also brought us a complimentary dessert that was a pastry filled with ice cream. That was nice. 

I think this place is just a lot of hype. The food is okay. But nothing i would want to do again. I've had better meals that weren't 160 for 4 people.
author: Angelica V.

description:
I used to come every Friday for their Happy Hours a couple of year ago when i worked a little closer and it was a fun spot to meet up friends. 
My last experience there totally sucked. The drinks were too watery, a lot of the food tasted off, even the ceviche could not make up for it. I kept thinking it would get better, but something has changed with this place, it's almost as if they let their reputation speak for itself they don't care about what they deliver anymore. I definitely don't plan on coming back to his place anytime soon.
author: Katie L.

description: I came here for my boyfriend's birthday in November. We made reservations and they were very friendly and as soon as we arrived they had our nice big table set up. Now on to the food and drinks... The Maracuya Sour is to DIE for!!! It's one of the best drinks I have had. The ceviche and lomo saltado were also on point. Service was fast and accomodating. We will definitely be back next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Maira G.

description: Fresh and delicious. each plate is more tasty that the last. I have eaten there at lunch and dinner and nothing has disappointed from the kitchen. my only criticism would be the drinks - very small with lots of ice, and overpriced for what you get.
author: Peter F.

description:
They really serve you right at La Mar!  I was lucky to dine here with my agency for our founder's birthday lunch.  A short walk to the Embarcadero and you're in paradise.  We sat on their outside patio; no wind and a nice view.  Their interior is also designed nicely.  You can't go wrong with either. 

Our waiter was one of the most informative guys to wait a table that I've sat at.  He knew everything about their extensive menu, the wines they offer, where they source their coffee, the dietary needs of those at our table, desserts, everything. 

As someone who has never really experienced Peruvian food before, here are a few options that I've found very pleasant: 
The appetizer chips with their milk cheese dip
The Causa Casera
Cebiche Clasico
Pescado Nikei
Quinoa Chaufa - an absolute must, perfect choice for vegetarians as well
And the alfajores for dessert, a dulce de leche between two thin chocolate shortbread cookies

I had an great time here. It may run a bit expensive. But in this case, you get what you pay for, an awesome experience. Cheers!
author: David O.

description: An overall excellent dining experience. I had cebiche mixto as an appetizer. It was wonderful, beyond words. The lomo saltado main course was excellent. The steak was so tender it melted in your mouth and the entire dish was exceptional. Dessert was coconut ice cream with dried pineapple and a ginger gelée. One of the best coconut ice creams I have ever had.
author: Chris F.

description: I've been craving ceviche since I left Peru, and this was the best place in SF for ceviche. I had, listed in order from my favorite to least favorite, 1) the choco-maracuya dessert (chocolate passion fruit), 2) grilled octupus (causa), 3) ceviche sampler, and 4) empanada sampler. We were so full from the causa and ceviches that we didn't really need to get the empanadas. I loved the avocado puree that came with the causa. I was expecting the ceviche to taste fresher. I liked the traditional ceviche the best, because it was simple and I could enjoy the fish. I felt the other flavors (e.g., Asian chifa) took attention away from the fish itself. I didn't think the empanadas were as good as they deserved to be but if I were to recommend one, it would be the beef one. La Mar also has a great view of the Bay Bridge, so it's a good date spot! ;)
author: Elaine L.

description:
Pretty good spot but might get a bit expansive if you are not on happy hour 
First things first: 
Food: 
outstanding ! Fresh, very different flavors, very enjoyable. we had cebiche tasting and something else - WOW fan!

Drinks: 
of course had to try  pisco sour - good but not my type of drink, some special drink made with Pisco and hot peppers - Awesome, even though spicy 

Service: very good for such busy place!!!    

Definitely will be back (but for happy hour :) )
author: Alex S.

description:
Best peruvian I've had in years! Eclectic/ fusion food. 

- Best Ceviche Mixto ever! Love the peruvian corn, and yam along with the seafood!
- Causa limenea was awesome. Mashed potato, crab meat, some yellow sauce towers. To die for!
- Good fusion food- I had Chinese wok style noodles with some peruvian flavors that I loved.
- Great ambiance and personal service
- For such an amazing place, the prices weren't bad at all!
author: Pooja M.

description:
Came here for dinner before watching Ovo. Was greeted by the hostess and then led to our table.

Here's what we ordered:
-cebiche tasting ($28): it was all ssooo good and fresh
-atun ($28): perfectly seared, bursting with a robust flavor. wasn't a fan of the purple fork-mashed potatoes, thought it was a bit dry and bland
-cau cau ($31): the creamiest risotto I've ever had
-arroz norteno ($24): didn't know it had octopus in it, but the Huancaina sauce made the rice tasty!
-pisco sour ($10): strong drink, nice and tangy...would definitely order another!

The food was great. Even the complimentary chips and the dipping sauces were equally tasty and unique. Every entree dish I tried was full of flavor. I felt like a pig since most people were ordering entree dishes and splitting them since the majority of the dishes are served tapas style. For our party of 5, we each ordered an entree for ourselves! But I'm glad I did, since my entree was delish and apparently everyone else was happy with eating a full plate too!

Service was friendly, attentive, patient and knowledgeable. Our server knew the menu well and described the dishes as well as typical Peruvian cuisine. This place left a lasting impression on me, loved the relaxing colors throughout the place...makes you want to take your time and enjoy your food; that's how it should be!
author: Janel Y.

description: Peruvian food! Went here with the team. AMAZING flavors, but at a price ... and small on quantity!
author: Thomas C.

description: Very nice atmosphere but the food is too Americanized and clearly lost its Peruvian taste and pride.  Senior Gaston go back and learn how to cook lomo saltado!
author: Emad S.

description:
LOVED - Cebiche Sampler, Emapanada Sampler (I liked the beef one the most), dip that came with the chips, and Pisco Punch. They also serve a strong Cappucino.

OK - Seabass prepared traditional Peruvian style. I think the Asian style would've been better. Lomo Saltado was pretty good - beef was REALLY tender, but I couldn't justify the $32 price tag for beef with fries and rice.

Service was good. Food was a little slow to come out, entire dinner for 2 took 2.5 hours. Bill came out to almost $200 after tax/tip. Kind of pricey, but it was an anniversary dinner.
author: Freckles H.

description: I absolutely love the food and ambiance in this restaurant.  The dishes are so fresh, and come out relatively quickly.  If I were to make one small comment it would probably be the price.  Maybe it's the location and the insane rent they must be paying, but I think it's just a bit overpriced. But, they have an amazing lomo saltado, empanadas and leche de tigre ceviche....mmmmm peruvian french fries and plantain chips.
author: Vince B.

description:
Food was great

Hostess was bad!

Lets get the food out of the way.  We dined in on Friday night, 13th of September 2014. 

We had Empanada tasting, causa tasting, ceviche tasting, Short rib Seco. Chorillana with Cod, and Lomo Saltado.    

 Chorillana was good, but the fish was very fishy for what we liked, Ive had cod numerous times before and it wasn't this fishy.   

The tuna in the ceviche Neikkie was extremely FIshy. We couldn't eat it because of this.  Ive had ahi poke numerous times before which is typically the part of the ahi they don't use for sushi and filets and its never been this fishy.    
 The rest of the fish seabass yellow tail was great.   

causas all very good, but again the ahi was fishy.  

If I had to say though, I would say the Ceviche chino was the best, you could taste the ginger, daikon, and sesame, great texture and perfect balance of flavors. 

Empanadas, were great. the huancaina, and rocotto huancaina were also great, very traditional. 

Lomo saltado, very good. A little too much ginger for my taste but non the less good. 

Seco, incredible  very rich and filling, there was no way I was going to finish this dish.  I felt bad tossing it but my stomach was done.  

4 stars to the chefs!!

Our female server was great too.  she wasn't too intrusive and gave us plenty of time on the menu, and explained anything we needed.  I actually liked that she wasn't hovering over us the entire time. 

We had a reservation for 4 at 9:15 under my name, I arrived at 9:25. This is why im giving them 3 stars.  the Hostess were not happy. they didn't smile. they had attitude.  I told the first host I had a reso, she said theyre still setting up our table and it would be a few minutes.  I had no problem with this and asked if I had enough time to grab a drink at the bar.  She said I shouldn't because the kitchen is closing soon. It was all in the tone, she seemed frustrated or bothered that I was there.   SO we sat down just inside the door on the couch. 5 minutes goes by which we could have had a drink and another tall host walks up to us and asks us if we have a reservation. wtf?  yes, Andrew for four. ok  give us a few minutes...... what???   the sat us right after that, but as we walked toward our table the original host was walking in the opposite way looked my girlfriend up and down and rolled her eyes.  anyway, I don't know what this was about, maybe she wasn't rolling her eyes at her but it sure seemed like it.  they both seemed like they didn't want to be there.
author: Andrew G.

description: Went here with a few colleagues for drinks and light apps.  When we got there the bar was pretty full but we were told we'd by seated at the main dining area at 5pm. We were actually seated after 5:30.  We waited a while for the waiter to get us drinks and we had a few questions on the menu. We proceeded to order, but was disappointed to find that the server lacked knowledge of the menu. Drinks are fabulous, the food was okay. I may try it again.
author: Abby T.

description: I've been here three or four times. I like the food. The ceviche is fresh and tasty and I LOVE the mix of like plantain chips and the yummy spicy dips. I'm giving three stars because once I dropped in and met two friends who were having dinner. I had already eaten, so I just had a cocktail (a jalapeño mango concoction). The restaurant was not full. My two friends ended up only ordering drinks and appetizers. I suppose for this sin, the waiter felt justified to be really rude and abrupt. He kept grabbing food and things off the table before we were done just to get us to leave. It was really sad watching him snatch away the chips and dip without a backward glance :(  On other occasions where I've ordered full dinner, this hasn't been a problem. Admittedly, if I were just having drinks and apps, I would chosen to sit at the bar. But my friends didn't do that, and that's no excuse to be rude. The people who order appetizers and drinks aren't necessarily going to spend less money than the people who order one entree. And the appetizer and drink people may in the past and future be the sit-down dinner people.
author: Cat M.

description:
Went here w/ The Mr. after waiting to dine somewhere in SOMA. We had reservations but decided to grab drinks at the bar. Pisco sours were the drink of choice. Interesting Peruvian cocktail. My favorite cocktail was the sangria. So refreshing. We were seated in the outdoor patio which I loved. Secluded from the hustle and bustle of the kitchen. I loved the plantain chips that they serve in the place of bread. We shared the cebiche sampler, causas casera, anticucho de carne, and the empanada sampler. A hefty serving and all prepared to perfection. The cebiche was amazing. Trying each one is a must as you can see the differences between each one. The empanada was also pretty good. Wasn't a fan of the seafood but the rest were pretty tasty. For dessert we had the 3 milk strawberry shortcake. Different version from the standard shortcake, but edible. 

Best part of the night were the bathrooms. 2 of them, historic and co-ed. Awesome.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
The short summary - there are some great peruvian places in the city that offer equal or better food for a better price. I'd still recommend the place as a spot to have dinner after work or a place for drinks around the Ferry Building area.

The first time I visited La Mar I was looking for a place to have a drink and an appetizer. In our initial encounter with place, the hostess and the bar were rude to use, so we decided to leave. We decided to give the place another shot for a dinner with friends knowing that the first experience was circumstantial. Our experience the second time was in the main dining hall and it ended up being great. The food was good, but not spectacular, with the ceviche being the highlight. The drinks were good change of pace from the norm. The reason I gave it 3 stars instead of 4 is because I think there are some better peruvian places that offer a better bang for your buck (Limon in the Mission, and Fresca in Pac Heights). I guess that's the price you pay for a place right along the water.
author: Adrian G.

description: Waitress was delightful but the the food was so so.   Expected so much more for the money.
author: Jim W.

description:
I've been here several times. I've even been to Chicha in Cuzco, Peru (same owner Gaston Acurio). The food here is good, nothing amazing.

Last time I came here with my boyfriend, my boyfriend asked (before the meal started) if they do take his company's voucher. His company has a list of restaurants where if we dine there, we get a free entree. It is a way for restaurants to encourage these big companies' employees to dine there. La Mar is one of them. (Regardless of the voucher, we were going to eat there any way).

The waiter confirmed that they do, so we gave him our orders. This was the first and last time we saw our waiter. No one came to refill our water. I wanted an extra drink; no waiter came by to ask if we wanted one. We had our appetizer and main course served, and no one even came by to ask if we wanted dessert.

Finally, after FLAGGING down someone to get the check, I looked over and saw our waiter taking care of an EXTREMELY large party to our right. When he came over and dropped off our check (with no communication), we looked at it and saw that there is an 18% tapped on gratuity with the voucher.

Okay, so you were getting tipped no matter what at our table. And you had a large party to take care of so you can get another large tip. 

Don't think I'll be coming here again unless it's for some sort of happy hour. I could do without the condescending attitude and nonexistent customer service for some passable food.
author: Aggie Z.

description: While we on the topic of Peruvian cuisine, La Mar off the Embarcardero is good but misses the mark on taste for me.  Actually, someone once wrote that based on its incredible bay-front location, the food doesn't even have to be that good to attract visitors in staggering numbers.  This is partly true:  walking into the elegant interior really sets high expectations.  I would say the presentation is flawless and I almost feel like I can't eat the food because each plate is like an amazing work of art.  As usual, we had the cebiche la mar, plus the corazon skewers (I was able to override hubby's squeamishness and share these with our business partners from Beijing) and the grilled octopus.  Best dish of the night was the sea bass.  Loma Saltado was overly salty and more vegetables than meat.  Most intriquing item of the night was the huge kernels of Peruvian corn.  Best drinks of the night:  the infamous Pisco Sour.  Perhaps drinking enough of these helps people remember only how beautiful the night was...
author: Sherri C.

description:
I might have had too many expectations going to this restaurant as lots of people raved about it in the past. 

The first red flag was their bathroom at the entrance - I was not expecting to find such a ghetto bathroom in a pricy restaurant. We weren't crazy about the food either - liked only two dishes out of five we've ordered. It was Thursday night, the restaurant wasn't even full but it was so noisy we could hardly hear each other. They were definitely short stuffed and the waiters kept running around like crazy. 

Overall it was not a good experience - I might come back there for drinks and snacks but definitely not for dinner.
author: Ata N.

description: La Mar is a fantastic culinary experience! The food, views and atmosphere are a sensory delight. We saw the movie- "Looking for Gaston" which is a documentary chronicling the Peruvian Food Revolution of Gaston Acurio- the owner of La Mar. It's an extraordinary story best pondered feasting at La Mar!
author: Janet O.

description: La Mar is a great place for dinner.  I requested and got a table on the patio with a view of the Bay.  The three of us shared three appetizers - the special cebiche of the day, the crab roll, and the empanada sampler - all very tasty!  We shared two main dishes between us - the skew sampler and the Lomo Saltado.  Both were delicious.  You can't go wrong with the recommended dishes on Yelp or your server's advice.
author: Carolyn K.

description: Absolutely delicious - the menu items are unique and prepared to perfection.  Wonderful service.  If you get there early they have a great bar to go to before hand.
author: L R.

description: I finally got a chance to come here it was on my to do list! lol. Went with a group of friends and shared all the dishes, we had an odd number of people and they were nice enough to make all the dishes for 5 people. it was great!  Love the Ceviche and Lomo saltado, you can't go wrong with that!
author: Melissa R.

description: Real Peruvian food, it's a little beat expensive, but with the happy hour (everyday including weekends from 3pm to 6pm) it makes sense and it's affordable! Nice experience to remember my "hometown" food!
author: Pablo V.

description: Great food, ambience and yes, they have outdoor heaters .. so chilly evenings are still great for patio and views! A wee bit pricey.
author: Neha M.

description:
I really wish I could give this restaurant 4 stars but the service was HORRIBLE!!!  It was like we did not exist.

The food on the otherhand was very delicious.  The empanadas were by far the most amazing items on the menu!! And if I were to go back that is what I would order for my entree hands down.
author: Rosie S.

description:
Dine about town SF, thank you for letting me try your restaurant for lunch. Pre fixe menu for $18, not a bad deal considering how pricey this restaurant can be! The moment I walked in, I fell in love with the interior decor. Such bright blue colors with bright colored place mats. It made me feel so summer'ish!

I don't think I'll be back, though. I came here to support the Chef Diego Oka because my aunt had sent me an article about how famous he has become with his vision about introducing Peruvian food all over the world. He's got Japanese roots like me! The reason why I wouldn't come back? Although this is delicious and fancy Peruvian food, it's too fancy for me. I like hole in the wall, greasy peruvian food. That's not to say you shouldn't try this place! The restaurant itself is beautiful and the food presentation when it comes out makes you not want to touch your food because it's so wonderfully presented. If I could, I would just stare at my plate all day. Leave that plate alone and just drink in the patio.

The best part about this restaurant is the patio overlooking the water. OH MY, how romantic it is to sit out there and have a few pisco sours on a summer day. The thought of water soothes my brain.
author: Kathy Y.

description: Nick is by far the best waiter in the city!  Seriously.  I have a not-so-fun list of food intolerances (gluten, dairy, egg, soy and beef), and not only did Nick NOT make my feel like a freak, which usually happens, he worked w/ the kitchen to produce one of the best meals I have ever had in the city. Ever.  I was with a group of 30 for a work dinner, a pre-fix menu, which typically complicates customizing the menu even more.  Nick was magical in making me feel extremely catered to and after 9 perfectly prepared tasty courses, I was in awe.   The rest of our party also adored him and were blown away by his flawless service, attitude, sense of humor and attentiveness.    Everyone also raved about the food they were served.   All in all, a 5 star experience for service, venue and cuisine.  Thank you Nick and La Mar!
author: Rhonda M.

description:
Did you know that La Mar has a great happy hour?!?!?!??

I sure as hell didn't! But one gloomy SF afternoon, my friend and I just wanted some good drinks, and good small bites to take away our blues. We were shopping in the Ferry Building, and grabbed a disappointing drink at Market Bar---- then we remembered--- La Mar is just a skip away! "I wonder if they have happy hour?"

It was 4 pm on a Friday. This was the perfect time to check it out!!!

La Mar.... was a wonderful escape from the gloom! It's such a beautiful bar with the friendliest bartenders we've had in a very long time. They just opened their doors, so they were still making all of the concoctions and tasting them for perfection.

We each ordered a specialty cocktail for $5 -- both were delicious, and both were refilled :) There is also food specials at the bar until 6pm.

We had the yucca fries, "chips and salsa", and the ceviche mixto. The flavors and textures made me want more more more!!! The chips were thin-sliced sweet potatoes, banana chips, and potatoes. The salsas that came with them had a unique and amazing flavor. The yucca fries were so smooth and sweet but still savory.

We will definitely be back for a full meal. And again for happy hour!
author: Mar A.

description:
THANK YOU SF Chefs 2011! 
Alex O. and I came here to try their prix fixe lunch deal. $20 for lunch gets you a taste of 3 different entrees, along with a side of rice, complimentary plantain chips with 3 dipping sauces, and 2 desserts. Deal-o-rama!!

Entree samplers:
Cebiche Clásico - California Halibut in a classic leche de tigre, red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam. Watch out for the sliver of habanero chile that's in the cebiche, delicious but deadly! The cebiche was alright, however it was missing a punch of flavor. The yam was sweet and bright orange. Gorgeous colors.

Causa Camarón - Sweet and spicy poached shrimp and fried onions on top of purple potato with leche de tigre aioli. Talk about impeccable presentation. The purple potato looks and has the consistency of bright purple play-doh. Of all 3 entrees, this was hands down my favorite. The flavors are amazing and the presentation is incredibly unique. The Leche de Tigre aioli is tangy and good to the last bite.

Lomo Saltado - Traditional Peruvian style stir-fry of sautéed beef tenderloin, onions, tomatoes, cilantro, garlic and soy sauce, with fried potatoes and rice. The soy sauce "gravy" in the dish was my favorite! After chowing down on the beef and fries, there was enough sauce left over to dump in my rice. Mmmmm.

Desserts: (in a shot glass)
Pie de Limon - Lime cream, lime mousse, lime sorbet, and Italian meringue with an almond crunch. Light and tangy, just the way lemon pie should be. (see: Tartine review)

Tapioca de Maracuya - Chocolate mousse, coconut foam and passion fruit tapioca layered in a glass.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Great service.  I reconnected with a waiter who served me at B44 from 1999!

I had the dish that was similar to Paella Negra, but thicker.  Absolutely delicious.

Recommend reservations in advance if you want a table looking out over the Bay.
author: Robert C.

description:
My husband picked this place for dinner on our wedding anniversary because of the ratings on Yelp.  I'm torn on how to rate it.

Flavor: 5 Star
Service: 5 Star
Value: 2 Star

The flavors were unique and exciting but the dishes were extremely small and pricey.  We paid $16 for a fennel/cucumber salad that I thought my husband and I could share as an appetizer.  I could have fit the entire salad in the palm of my hand.  The drinks were unique as well, but again I felt over priced.  My favorite drink was Blood and Sand and my favorite dish was the cerviche tasting.  We also had the Empanada sampler and skewer sampler.  I found it ironic that everything was a small portion except the desserts, which were quite large.
author: Misti P.

description:
Delicious food and great ambiance. Service was excellent as well. 

You MUST get the causa tasting. Whipped potato towers topped with aji amarillo and seafood. Seriously unbelievable.
author: Cristina P.

description:
Not Impressive at all. If you have a chance, and you want Peruvian, stick with the restaurants in the Mission like Limon.

It's probably nice ONLY because it's on Embarcadero, that is the only thing I can really say.

Honestly, I'm a bit confused on all the 4/5 stars here. Service was nice but the food was just "eh"
author: Eric A.

description:
My first experience here was for Dine About Town lunch.  It was a beautiful day outside so the girls and I decided to sit on the patio.  What an amazing view of the Bay!  The food was good and the empanadas were amazing.

I came here again for my husband and my 11th Anniversary.  We initially had reservations for dinner at another Peruvian restaurant, but with the traffic on the bridge we had to cancel.  La Mar was close to where we were going to meet my cousin after and I remembered how much I liked the food last time that I suggested it.  I immediately made our reservation on Open Table.  When we arrived they couldn't find our reservation.  Come to find out I made it for the following day.  They didnt turn us away and kindly accommodated us.  We had the tuna ceviche which was amazing!  However I did think it was kinda pricey for the you get.  I love the atmosphere and the people.  Overall another great restaurant.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Where to go on a cold sunday night after a long day out? La Mar popped up and seemed like a decent place to stake out a new restaurant in the City. 

Two of us sat down in the bar area which was cozy with mixed decoration (never got the point of a red lantern there though). 

We ordered...

Drinks: Pisco Punch, a bit punchy and pineapple taste. Interesting and passed my friend's taste. Passion Andina, ah my drink. A bit of mint, lemon and small touch of sweetness. Went well with the dishes we selected.  

Salad: Ensalada Tiradito, a well prep and nicely looking salad. Wish it had more pieces of Tuna and a bit more sauce but overall not bad. 

Skewers: Pollo Anticuchos, a surprised dish for us as the taste proved to be better then our expectation. We ordered this dish because they ran out of the beef heart, however we were not disappointed! The corn that comes on the side is amazingly good. 

Main Dish: Quinoa Chaufa, a veggie dish as we wanted something light. It needed a tad bit of the hot sauce served with the Pllo Anticuchos. We added a bit and mixed it in and Voila, a great dish to finish the meal off. 

Dessert: Trio de Postres, a taste of three different desserts. Interesting mix. 

Overall, we had a great time especially since we were not super hungry but the dishes managed to be filling and the service courteous (except the guy bringing the candles)

Thanks for the great meal La Mar!
author: Jean-Marc L.

description:
We came here for an anniversary dinner.  The food is OK, but I would stay away from those Asian Fusion dishes.  Those soy-sauced fish dishes are pretty bad compare to the ones from the real Asian restaurants.  On the other hand, I love their appetizers.

I would come back again for their appetizers, but would hop over to Slanted Door for the entree, for example.
author: Lolipop W.

description:
Bad NYE experience overpowers a very good ceviche/cebiche. 

Food: Definitely go for the ceviche.

Ambiance: Very large restaurant, with great views of the bay if you can sit out back.

Service: This is where we were let down and maybe it's because it was NYE. Fairly large group dinner, 12 people, and we had a nine course menu picked out well in advance to the evening. They ended up only serving six of the dishes and when we asked the waiter about the other dishes, he said we were wrong and they had been brought out. After going over things with him and the manager, they said we were right but sorry the kitchen was really busy and it was too late for the rest of the food. The manager refunded us the difference between a six course and a nine course meal and acted as if he gave us a good deal. After stating to him, all he really did was charge us for what we got he said sorry again and "comped" us a free round of Pisco Sours. Unfortunately ust a disappointing experience.

Price: Well over $120 a person, including champagne and drinks.

Overall: The ceviche is worth going to dinner, but don't plan a big party here.
author: Binh D.

description:
Great food. Greater bar.
I stop by from time to time, it is worth your time and $.
author: Mike A.

description: Great food!! We had salad, chicken skewers, salmon, beef tenderloin, and grilled chicken breast; they were all very tender and cooked just right. We ordered from the restaurant week menu but the portions were still pretty good except the salmon.
author: Amy Z.

description: I've had much better cebiche, but they do have a great happy hour here which I frequent!  I come for the Pisco Sours alone.  You won't find a better one in the city!!! If you dine in the restaurant part,  I feel like the space is so big that its not super inviting, but it is nice to sit outside and have the beautiful bay view.   I do appreciate that.   I guess I'm a little torn on this place because I so badly wanted to love the food, but I just didn't. : (
author: Coraly S.

description:
Great Food and the back deck is great.
The Cebiche sampler is not to be missed.
author: Larry L.

description:
Hipsterish, trendy and a feel good vibe is what came to mind when I first entered the restaurant.  The hostess was friendly and our waiter was super nice.  This set the mood right for my Friday night (hey I just made a rhyme, ha).

Okay, so the food is a bit overpriced and the portions could be a tad bigger.  But what do you expect from a pretty nice restaurant on the Embarcadero that is serving up seafood?

Me and the GF started with the cebiche tasting which allowed us to try 4 of their cebiches which was a very nice way to start off the meal.  Each one had the right amount of acidity and did not overpower the flavor of the seafood.  The next thing that came out was the causa nikei (tuna tartar and avocado puree on top of a rocoto potato).  I could have enjoyed this one a bit more if I didn't try to pop the entire thing in my mouth.  All of the components complimented each other creating a pleasant flavor.  The main course was arroz jugoso (prawns, clams, mussels, calamari, white fish and vegetables in a juicy arborio rice) which was my favorite dish of the night.  This is the first time I tried arborio rice which I thought was different from any other rice I've had before.  The sauce was very tasty and went well with the rice and seafood.  Delicious.

Everything was good:   Service, food, and the atmosphere.  This satisfied my trifecta of what I look for in a restaurant.
author: Suzi K.

description:
The decor at La Mar makes you truly feel like you're out on the ocean. The colors & friendly service made this lunch all the better.

Started out with the cebiche clásico, causa limeña and rollo fashion. They were all awesome choices. The cause limeña was SO good - I could've eaten a lot more of it!

I had the lomo saltado that was good. Not great, but good. The rice was a little hard for my liking, but the actual tenderloin was extremely tender. I probably could've cut it without a knife. The chicken sandwich was too aioli-y according to a friend and the salads are extremely small. 

Would I go back? Definitely!
author: Francesca F.

description: I'm conflicted - one of the best meals of my life and a greasy disappointment were both here - and the same dish on two separate visits!  I see it's been eliminated from the menu now (a pulpo dish), so you needn't worry about getting similarly burned.  Grab a cebiche, a couple of causas, a few empanadas and a main or two (including something with leche de tigre) and your group will leave smiling.  Don't forget a pisco sour!
author: Allan H.

description:
I am going to preface the review with the information that I'm reviewing the food from a prix fixe menu for a large group dinner.

I never thought I'd say/type this but I had the worst meal ever for $96 per person at La Mar. Every course, and I mean EVERY course, was a disappointment. The scale to rate the tastiness of the food ranged from I-can-tolerate to I'd-rather-eat-at-Burger-King. It also wasn't just me but my entire table that felt the food was sorely out of line with the price.

First off, the Inka Cola and Chicha Morada - both Peruvian non-alcoholic drinks - tasted like medicinal syrup than sweet drinks. The latter was worse because it contained star anisse. If you don't like yuca, stay far away from this place. I used to believe that any fried starch would taste good but I even left the yuca fries alone after one bite. The appetizers were a combination of fish and a mayo-like substance over yuca. Again, I left the yuca behind and regrettably swallowed the fish topping. Of the two entrees, the beef with potatoes was probably the best dish of the night. By best, I mean the one that I could eat more than one bite before stopping. We ended up leaving at least 65% of the dessert behind. We had a butterscotch-like substance that once again tasted like medicine.

The pros to La Mar are the service (we had a fantastic waiter) and the view of the Bay. Street parking is fairly easy after 7 pm. I am now $96 poorer and $95 hungrier.
author: Gwen L.

description: Always good food and great service. Love the ceviche.  Good happy hour too.
author: Bee M.

description:
