I came here after an all day workshop in SF for work. This place was DELICIOUS.

The piscos are strong and tasty. The complimentary plantain, sweet potato, and potato chips are addicting. The ceviche is fresh (definitely recommend the ahi ceviche). The empanadas are a MUST HAVE as a result of their light, flaky, buttery crusts. Service is friendly. The view of the bay from the outdoor seating area is amazing!

I really can't say anything bad about this place so 5 stars :) I'd come again and again (especially if I didn't have to pay!)
author: Wendy S.

description:
For my 100th review (hooray!), I wanted to write about something special.

La Mar - located right next to the Ferry Building - was wonderful. Catered to every expectation that I had for me and my GF's 3 year anniversary. Why not Five Stars? Well, for the price I would have expected a bit more. But taste-wise the food was excellent! The complementary chips and dipping sauces were the perfect way to start the evening. But the best part was definitely what they're best known for - the Cebiche. I had never tried Cebiche before La Mar, but I've got to say that they set the bar high!

Go here and enjoy yourself =)
author: Brad Y.

description:
I've been here a few times and I love it.  The atmosphere is beautiful and relaxing, the food is sublime.  The wait service is always good.  The drinks are amazing.

The only slight downside is it was a little louder than anticipated on Saturday night where I just wanted to have a quiet, romantic dinner with my boyfriend.
author: Kristin G.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect of Peruvian food. But I loved the decor and the food was amazing!!!! The ceviche was so tasty, I must come back again to introduce others to this place!! 
The pisco sours (drinks) were very tasty and packed a punch! Loved them!  :)
author: Lucia A.

description: The service, the food, and the atmosphere, was excellent! I was meeting a new friend and we had just the right amount of space to talk at a comfortable level, get to know each other, and enjoy earthly delights, such as the Jalapeño Ceviche and the heavenly grilled octopus main course.  And the gratuitous fried plantain sweet potato starter was a mouth-watering treat.  I focused on the oak-flavored Chardonnay options for beverage choice, which was a perfect accompaniment to the hearty, yet delicate octopus, flavor of my dish. The sweet after dinner selections were amazing too! Fresh and fabulous, featuring exotic Peruvian fruit concoctions with yummy homemade vanilla bean ice creams! Honestly, my dessert was so excellent, yet so exotic, and after three glasses of amazing wine, I don't even remember the name of it. My friend was delighted and so was I; now we are bonded by this excellent sensory experience. :)
author: Toni M.

description:
Came here a little while back with a HUGE group of friends to celebrate a birthday. Its a great splurge and I love the place!!  La Mar is located in Pier 1.5 (I think...), which means you're basically in a huge warehouse.  Its very upscale though and roomy.  The fixtures and basic architecture has to stay the same, because its a historical building, but it only enhances your dining experience.  You can also see the entire kitchen, if you'd like, and that makes it really cool!  

What we had:
cebiche nikei - made with Ahi Tuna and was really light and yummy! I loved the tuna!

cebiche clasico - made with California Halibut. There was a lot of Halibut. For a second, it threw me off that it had so much Halibut, but I enjoyed it. Some other Cebiche's have tons of other stuff, but this was really just focused on the one seafood it advertises. 

chorillana - This is a roasted Thai fish, with mashed yucca.  Took a little bit to distinguish the fish from the yucca, but its really good.  They leave the skin on...

arroz norteno - Was like a fried rice. Pretty good, but it felt like an Asian fusion...or maybe its just me.

ensalada limena - arugula and spinach salad. Was very fresh. 

vegetales saltados - kind of like a veggie stir fry. Also good.

I mean, seriously. Overall, for the price you're paying for all this food, its really good.  Because we went with a dinner combo, we got to try a lot of different stuff at once. Good, but it also made the price pretty high.  Our waitress was very friendly and came by frequently (but not incessantly) to make sure we were ok.  La mar also has room to fit a huge group (we had like, 15), but there were also smaller tables for more intimate settings.
author: Lily W.

description:
Peruvian happy hour 3-6 everyday.  Sounds like a steal but if you read on, you might want to rethink getting happy hour food + drinks here. 

My cousin told me that La Mar has locations all over the world and is mainstayed in Peru.  Upon going in and taking a look at the menu, I found out that the SF location is the only one in the U.S.  This added a heightened interest for my party and I as we decided to wait for tables to open up and perused the happy hour menu and decided to get drinks and a all the small cold plates to try.  

Fast forward 30 minutes later, we received our food but no drinks!  We were so disappointed in the portion sizes.  We realized that the plates were going to be small, but their definition of a small serving was for less than 1 person.  But I thought to myself, oh well.  Maybe America just has different ideas of what a small serving is compared to Peru.  The taste of the food was just ok, nothing to write home about- I've had better Peruvian food elsewhere.  I then proceeded to signal the waitress and ask her about the status of my drinks.  She apologized and told me that the bar is a little backed up.  I looked around and decided that yes, that was plausible since the bar was pretty crowded and there were a couple of people just standing and drinking.  However, I did notice that the table behind me who had arrived later had received their drinks first!  Because the plates were so tiny, my party and I finished our small plates in no time.  We added some chips and salsa + more drinks to our tab.  This second time around, the drinks came all in one shot, but we had to wait on the chips and salsa!  This was inacceptable given that at this time the crowd at La Mar had died down and there weren't as many people in the room.  We again told the waitress that we were waiting for our order, and she had to go into the kitchen to grab our order for us.  

CONCLUSION TO LA MAR: **I don't know what was going on with La Mar that day, but I expected much better service.  I would give them a 0-rating if possible and will never be going back.  **
author: Mary N.

description: We has a reservation for a month prior to going there, since it was 4th of july and it was a big deal for us. We got there and it was obviously very crowded. The waited asked us what we were going to drink and we wanted to start out with water, he got kind of pissed like if we werent ordering enough for it to be worth his time. We asked for an appetizer to share to stat out and it was an octopus appetizer. He didnt even bother taking out menus when we gave them back to him. When he brought out appetizer he threw it at the table, the food was knocked down by the menu he refused to take away before. I put them on the floor, cause the table were incredibly small for the 3 menus and the plates. The appetizer was extremely small but delicious. He took forever to come back so we decided to order the check and have dinner elsewhere. It was an awful experience specially for us on out honeymoon and on the 4th of july!
author: Katha N.

description: Happy Hour! Yuka fries & a prickly pear margarita! Small plates, nice ambiance, embarcadero/ferry building area.
author: Josie C.

description: Great Peruvian food! The pisco sours are delicious and I love the causa limena. The location is great with views of the bay. A nice spot for a date or a group get together.
author: Sam P.

description: Food is OK but too expensive for the quality.  More "hip" and a "scene" than good place to actually eat.  Good view I suppose but remember it's next to ferry building.  A bit over-hyped and over-priced.  Great place for someone with no strings attached and got cash to burn.  If not, it's over-priced for what it offers.
author: Joe H.

description: Excellent, fresh Cebiche and The most tender Grilled Octopus I've had.
author: Kaz M.

description:
Having now been to La Mar twice, I'm confident in saying that I really like this place.  Usually places like this (nice?) aren't my scene.  But the restaurant is a beautiful space and having dinner on the water on an unseasonably warm day makes for a pretty special experience.

One of the great things about La Mar is that the menu is set up for sharing-- the cebiche and empanada samplers are super easy to share, as are the meat skewers.  I always enjoy making a dinner out of snacking and La Mar allows you to do so with delicious, seemingly healthful, sustainably farmed fish and other goodies.

Pisco sours were tasty but kinda small.  Pisco punch, on the other hand, was served in a nice punchbowl like glass.  

If you're looking for a not-too-stuffy place on Embarcadero to enjoy a sunny day, check out La Mar-- its just good enough to get me to leave the Mission :)
author: Kristin P.

description: Cute place for a lunch date! Although I guess everyone here seemed to be on a business lunch, so that tells you a lot about my approach to dating. The food here is good -- the pork belly sandwich was delicious, although it had a little too much pork belly on it (such a lame problem, I know). It tasted a lot better once I took a few pieces out though -- much more balanced. The weird purple mash thing was not good either. Kind of gummy and weird. Their ceviches were great though and the back room's view of the Bay is perfect on a sunny day!
author: Esther K.

description:
Thrilling lunch.

Not as thrilling as dinner (one of my favorite meals ever), but still good. This was a business lunch (I'll let you guess who was in town) and I'm glad I wasn't picking up the tab for a $14 seared tuna sandwich.

That said, it comes on an Acme roll with passion fruit dressing, a side salad, the Embarcadero view, a beautiful space and in my case, the good memories from dinner.

Worth the return.
author: Jason B.

description: One of go to spots when I'm craving something unique! The service is generally good (I have had my bad experiences, but the drinks and food bring me back). You cannot get a better ambiance than they have set up. A little pricey, but happy hour is great, and it is worth the splurge.
author: Lauren J.

description:
This brought me back to my travels in Peru. Pisco Sours, mindblowing ceviche -- all the entrees were good. Try the Dungenness crab on potato. Service was perfect. Stunning views. Yummy chips. They told me another LaMar is open in NYC -- will definitely go when I get back home.

The only downsides-- was really tough to get a table, and on the pricey side but worth every penny.
author: Minerva T.

description: THE FOOD IS AMAZING!!!! I liked Peruvian food somewhat, but this place will make you fall in love with Peruvian food!! My aunt who lives here in SF, took my mother and I here and easy to say I fell in love! We had the pisco sour to drink, which was strong but delicious! I forget the name of the appetizer but we had some sort of crab and tuna on Peruvian sweet potato which just melted on your tongue. I'm big on ceviche, and this was hands down the best ceviche I have ever had! Not fishy at all I don't know how they did it! A must have if you come here! We had the paella and the salmon for our entrees, and the salmon was the best! It comes with this yummy coconut sauce which sounds a bit odd, but is what really makes the dish to die for! I definitely recommend the salmon over the paella, but paella was amazing as well! The coolest thing about this place is the overall ambiance and outside view! Gorgeous viewing of fisherman's warf which makes this restaurant a must go to for anyone visiting San Fran! We did have to hail our server twice, but overall I was very impressed by the food and ambiance!! Can't wait to come back!
author: Nikki B.

description:
I came here a few weeks ago for my friend's birthday happy hour.  I arrived around 5:15, and it wasn't too crowded yet.  My friends were able to snag a spot at the island.  

We sat for a while and nobody came by to take our order.  We finally flagged someone down, and he said he would get our waiter...tick tock tick tock.....another 10 minutes, and our waitress finally arrives.  So we put in a huge order since it was 5:30 and happy hour specials ended at 6:00.

We ordered....
-Sangria( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/lgZi4BMhKIFgZVy5XKsSog/l )
-Cristal-Peruvian beer( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/oIUTC5I6m2qsYpMSoGnnhA/l )
-Pisco sour( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/qgQvhrlEbUBdZnQ80eQ48A/l )
-Empanada del mar( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/6xIS03PNMLiVKh405hBeeQ/l )
-Chicharrón de Calamar( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/Np8hK6qmRcfkfk9c_jNQ-g/l )
-House made chips( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/c8LinzSPUL40Zhs4Oiymfw/l )
-Cebiche Clásico( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/I5_17BTsLOVn6aoTqgUe_A/l )

It took about 15 minutes for our drinks to come out and even longer for the food!  The sangria was probably the best thing that I had there.  The food didn't wow me at all.  The empanada was ok, but I've definitely had better ceviche and calamari elsewhere.  They even got our order wrong, but that worked to our benefit because they brought us extra food and didn't charge us.

The service was way too slow.  My friend ordered a drink, and it didn't come until 30 minutes later....when we were ready to leave....and they made it wrong!  I highly doubt I will ever come back here for happy hour because I was definitely NOT happy.
author: Patra I.

description: Great Peruvian food! I have been here for their happy hour a couple times. Just recently visited for dinner. Great Food and drinks! Will definitely be returning.
author: Marcos M.

description: I had the plancho de mariscos and it was one of the best meals I've ever had. The octopus was extremely tender and cooked perfectly. The sauce was flavorful without over powering the seafood. My husband had the beef skewer and enjoyed it but felt there could have been one more skewer to be filling. They were running a drink special on Sunday which was unexpected and lovely. Careful the pour heavy! One was plenty for me. The prices were reasonable abs the service was fantastic. Attentive but not smothering. The waiter knew a lot about where the food came from etc. Great experience I hope to return soon!
author: Katie R.

description:
Enjoyed a Christmas Eve lunch at La Mar with our family! The food was good but the portions were ridiculously tiny, especially the Causa. I'm from Lima and fanatical about food and in particular, Peruvian cuisine. Of the hundreds of Peruvian restaurants around the world I've personally have frequented, when we received the Causa, I sincerely thought it was a practical joke! I appreciate smaller portions at restaurants because it's quality not quantity I'm after but this Causa was not that great to be that small! For the pricing, the value for all of the food is simply not there. Granted the overhead for being located on the pier must be high but do not forget the fact that it is a restaurant and one goes there to eat not simply enjoy the atmosphere. 

This brings me to my second discontent about such a celebrity chef as Gaston is around the world. I did not see one single Peruvian item on display. Peru has an extremely rich culture renowned around the world. For a Peruvian restaurant outside of Peru one would likely make an attempt to showcase something. I believe having some Peruvian items enhances the atmosphere and takes you closer to Peru and makes the entire experience more meaningful. In the Mexico City location in which I had a similar complaint, they at least had a picture of Machuu Picchu in the women's bathroom. At this location, even that small token item was MIA. I do not understand the logic and feel sad that a Peruvian of his stature feels his culture must be hidden in order to succeed in a foreign land. Should I have had the ability to be such a fine, renowned chef as Gaston, I would proudly display my culture especially outside Peru so that foreigners would see the marvels that are so treasured by Peruvians and world travelers as well and again something that enhances the entire experience at a restaurant.

One other item missing was the spicy Aji. Once again, while I concur that the general food dishes must be edible by all, a spicy Aji on the side for those if us that would like to feel the warm sensation of this fabulous tasting pepper as many in Peru would agree, should be a staple in any Peruvian restaurant. Finally, with the not so positive aspects, the wait for the Picarones would make one think they were coming form Lima and not the local kitchen. Once they arrived, I must admit they were very tasty! 

The final pleasant item was our waitress who was knowledgeable and with a great demeanor that seemed uncommon to the many other wait staff.

I give it 3 stars as the food was tasty! I hope he can be successful in San Francisco but I hope someone conveys some observations that I believe would enhance and grow his clientele.
author: George G.

description:
A great place for tapas type food.  I wasn't really a fan of their entrees.  But, the tapas were great and the interior and outdoor seating is inviting for large groups!

Tapas devoured: 1) beef hearts, sounds weird but it's yummy 2) sushi roll, it's a peruvian restaurant with an asian flare, why not, it was decent 3) empanadas sampler - tasty tasty.  

I love variety so maybe that's why I loved my dining experience there...and didn't really care to eat any more when our entrees came out.  

I'd definitely come here again.
author: Janet L.

description:
I've always wanted to have a good experience here since a lot of people say good things about it, but it just hasn't happened. The three times I have been here, the service has been awful and the food is really mediocre. To be fair, I haven't tried a lot of things on the menu besides their ceviche, yucca fries and empanadas. The yucca fries are AWESOME though so that's why they get three stars instead of two. I'm also a fan of their drink specialties, in particular the pisco sour. Don't get the tasting menu of the empanadas - I'll save you time, the chicken one is the best.

Atmosphere is cool - I prefer sitting in the bar rather than the main dining room.
author: Jenna Q.

description: Great food.  There was party here the first time, but that's understandable.  The ceviche was incredible along with the anticuchos.  The entrees were just okay.  Enjoy the small plates and the drinks along with the fried chips.
author: Stan V.

description: Came to La Mar to check out the happy hour in the bar.  Thumbs up for the prices, decent drinks and very good small plates.  Pretty much all drinks on the menu are $6 and the small plates are $4.  Pisco sours were very good (although it is the first time I have had one, so nothing to compare against).  My better half had a raspberry gimlet - it was also good but glass about 3/4 full, so a little strange.  Food plates small but good deal for SF.  Causa limena was tasty (dungeness crab a little fishy smell but not bad) as were the empanadas (deep fried but not greasy) and chicharon pork sandwich.  Debated on ordering the chips but glad we did - plantains (not sweet), sweet potato and regular potato - two dipping sauces - the orange one spicy and did wonders for the chips.  Good service considering one waitress for the whole bar area.  Overall a good deal for happy hour in the city.  Futbol on the TVs.
author: Mark O.

description:
This was our second visit to La Mar and we have decided to make it a tradition whenever we visit San Francisco. It is in a great location on the Embarcadero and the perfect place to sit down and relax after shopping at the Ferry Building. They have a beautiful outdoor patio with incredible views and the inside of the restaurant is gorgeous. There is a nice intimate lounge/bar at the front which always seems to have a crowd. 
They start the meal off right with complimentary homemade potato chips and dips. Delicious. The ceviche and empanadas are excellent. Each of the fish dishes that we have had have all been fresh and uniquely prepared. They have great signature cocktails and the service has been solid each time that we have visited. The restaurant is so large that I have never had to wait for a table - a nice plus when you are trying to have a relaxing Saturday.
author: Brad M.

description: Best Peruvian food I have ever had. Must get the cholito cocktail spicy, beef heart, seafood medley , tuna cerviche and grill octopus. Soo good, can't wait to come back
author: Coba C.

description:
Came here for lunch post Ferry Building with some friends from out of town and was really impressed with the service and the food. 

For entree's we had the arroz criollo, de atun (sandwich), and solterito de quinoa (salad). All were excellent but the arroz criollo was by far the star of the show.

Sure it's a little pricey, but it's a beautiful location and the service was fabulous. Try it for lunch and save a few $$ vs. the dinner menu.
author: Todd H.

description: Fancy Peruvian food. Atmosphere was nice but busy. The free plantain chips were very addicting. Cebiches, carne and octopus skewers-all good.  And I really liked their giant Peruvian corn.
author: Ali F.

description: Fantastic food - ceviches and empanadas in particular were outstanding. Very nice ambience and service as well
author: Ajay K.

description:
After my second visit, I need to downgrade to 4 stars. It's a solid place and I still think the cebiche is FANTASTIC but I didn't enjoy my entree as much this time. And sadly the entree I got the first time no longer appears to be on the menu. 

Also, the drinks take a ridiculously long time to come out and I didn't love any of the cocktails I tried. 

Still a great place, but not consistent enough for 5 stars.
author: Priya N.

description: Solid Peruvian cuisine.  Best ceviche & pisco sour.
author: Victoria Y.

description: The ceviche tasting and beef empanadas were so yummy! Pella was whatever, and there was a dish (sorry forgot the name) that had potatoes and steak, this was really salty and our table's least favorite. Service was great. Very nice place, would come back to try other dishes.
author: Cindy B.

description:
I've been back to La Mar twice since my birthday, and it just gets better and better! My favorites still remain the same as what I mentioned in my previous review. Make sure you check the huge specials chalkboard above the kitchen. The cebiche special last night was phenomenal... the cebiche afrodisiaco. Everything was so fresh, and my guy especially LOVED it. Unfortunately, the lightweight konked out at home after just one pisco sour. Him, not me!

Must try dessert: chocolate filled beignets with ice cream. Mmm... beignets...
author: Connie C.

description: This restaurant has a fabulous view and an amazing outdoor seating area. It is well ventilated with high ceilings and decor that makes you feel like you are on the beaches of Peru or somewhere beach like and Latin of course. I really love the ceviche , it had an amazing taste. There was no fishy after taste at all, and tons of zest. My overall meal was amazing but my only complaint was that our server took a long time to come take our order. It was during lunch, and my party was the only one sitting inside on a beautiful sunny day so maybe that contributed to the server forgetting about us. Most of the patrons were outside in the beautiful weather. I would  suggest this place to anyone who wants to go on a nice date or dinner with friends before hitting night spots downtown which isn't too far away from this venue. Overall, I LOVE this place and plan on returning.
author: Alex U.

description:
I am in a very serious relationship... Yes I'm married but my husband knows I have another love -- San Francisco!   My heart is absolutely in love with this gorgeous city!  I've had a relationship with this gorgeous city since the young tender age of five.  I digress,  so last Monday was a very BIG birthday for me and we were blessed with fabulous socal weather.  

So to celebrate my birthday my lovely boss and co-worker/friend took me to La Mar to kick start my birthday week celebration!   This place is such a special treat.  The very minute I walked in, the place took my breath away.  Like Jessica said, this place has tons of open airy space a rare gem in this magnificent city of ours.  It was PERFECT for a nice sunny day.  I felt like I was stepping into a Carribean Island when I walked in.  

We decided to eat outside so we could enjoy the weather.  We had a gorgeous view of the SF bay..  awwww.. It was too gorgeous for words. 
We ordered some appetizers, ceviche, tuna, some special rice which was mouthwateringly delish!  I had such a great experience here that I'm considering using the place for a work event.  Don't miss this place - you will absolutely fall in LOVE!  If you're a local and have friends visiting, you've got to take them here.  If you're going on a date and want to impress them, you MUST make a stop here.  Even for drinks. 

I will be back with my entourage of lovely ladies next time.
author: Christine P.

description:
This place is strong!  The parking attendants are actually really cool... they have a lot along the side of the restaurant and the valet guy was relaxed and complimented my rims... what guy doesn't love that?

When stepping inside the first thing that caught my attention was how modern and chic the atmosphere was... before the main mess hall is a sushi bar that features very translucent lights.

In the main dining you'll see that FISHERMAN'S WHARF style large chalk menu but also very clean and modern furnishings.

I love the chips that came w/ the meal... the dipping sauces were amazing--kinda felt like eating high end chips and dip haha.

The ceviche was delicious, it came out quick and was incredibly fresh.  I had a more typical Peruvian dish that included rice and meat (gotta have meat)... everything was tender and flavorful.

The service was strong as well, our waiter was VERY cool... like literally a COOL guy (translation : cool kid in high school).  He kinda reminded me of the bald guy in The Devil Wears Prada... you know? 

Anyways, the whole experience was fun... for some reason though it doesn't garner the 5-star rating because the majority of the experience doesn't seem as memorable as the rest of San Francisco... felt a bit too corporate and a cookie cutter chic... shrug--iono, different strokes I guess.

Worth a visit though if you're in the area!!
author: Dennis N.

description: Had dinner for the first time here tonight and had the worst service ever! The food was ok, not great and definitely not worth the price. When our orders were brought to us, many of the dishes were wrong. One person from my party ordered the fried rice and the server came by to stir the contents of the bowl. Then I see him use the same utensils on another person's bowl! Next the server took a drink order, never brought it, and claimed that he was not the person that took the order. Our $700 bill came which included 20% gratuity, tax and the SF mandated restaurant tax. Everyone chipped in and paid the bill in its entirety as well as leaving additional tip. Here's the worst part of the night... As we were saying our goodbyes outside the restaurant, our server, James C., came racing over to tell us we didn't leave enough money. Apparently he claimed we were short $50! That's impossible when we clearly left more money than required. Everyone at the table witnessed and counted the cash multiple times. Yet the server and the manager on site would not let us go unless we paid the additional $50! Well, now you have 10 disgruntled customers who will never ever want to come back. As a caution to for visitors, get witnesses if you plan on paying by cash. Or I suggest you count the cash in front of them. Something is definitely fishy with the sever... And the manager is also no help. Be warned future diners and keep your wallets safe!
author: R D.

description:
It was my friend's , Helen, birthday so she wanted to try the food at La Mar. My good friend and I arrived early around 6pm so we sat at the bar area and ordered some drinks. When the drink arrived, I paid and closed out the tab. I ordered the chicha morada (purple corn drink) and it was very refreshing and tasted like pomegranate juice. Finally all my friends arrived and we were promptly seated at 6:30pm.   For appetizers we ordered the calamari, cebiche tasting, causa tasting and the ensalada nikei. The calamari is pretty tasty and crispy. The cebiche tasting consisted of mostly raw fish (mahi mahi, ahi tuna, scallop and halibut) and is pretty good. The causa tasting consisted of dungeness crab, ahi tuna and purple potatoe which is tasty. Also there is complimentary chips: plantain, sweet potato and regular potato. 

For entrees five of us ordered the daily special which was steak, octopus, scallop and shrimp cooked with veggies in tomato sauce which was not bad except the steak was well done. My other girlfriend ordered the arroz norteño (cilantro fried rice with shrimp, scallop, clam, mussel and octopus) and it was delicious. It tasted better than the paella with the added cilantro to give it more flavoring. 

For dessert we had the tiramisu (pretty good), buñuelos de chocolate caliente (a deep fried dough that is stuff with dark chocolate--very yummy) and a complimentary picarones (sorted of like tempura sweet potato and pumpkin--too sweet and doughy.) 

The price is not bad considering we all had one or two drinks and it came out to be $82.00 per person between the five of us since we are treating the birthday girl. This is where the problem is. Apparently they charged us for a few extra items such as three drinks. Apparently, the waitress at the bar ran did not close up my tab and tried to double charge us for the drink plus a glass of wine ($4.00+$5.00+14.00 =$22.00 extra). The server was very nice to talk to the manager for us and got those charges waive because I paid for the purple corn drink and beer at the bar and gave her $11.00 already. We felt that the waitress was trying to rip us off and was glad the whole issue got resolved.

The decor is very nice with a bar up in the front area and the nicely decorated and blue dining hall. I would definitely come back for the food but not the bar area because I felt that waitress was dishonest.
author: Allison H.

description: My husband and I had dinner here for my birthday. We hesitate because of the bad reviews but we tried anyway, and we loved it. The food was amazing and yes a little bit expensive but I think that is something to be expected in San Francisco and in this location. The food was exceptional, the service normal for a Saturday night and the place is definitely gorgeous, I didn't love the Pisco Sour and the Tres Leches dessert though, probably because I have very high standards, I'm Chilean and I have tried them many times before. Anyway, for sure we will be back for our next celebration.
author: D S.

description:
Made reservations for lunch on a Tuesday and yes it gets that busy here. 

Excited to try Peruvian food because I've never had it- super excited about the seafood selection. 

The decor is very white on blue bright hues with a view of the Bay in the background.  Great ambiance for any meal. 

There is yummy complimentary plantains that come with 3 different sauces for you to dip with. 

We started with the ceviche sampler- presentation is impeccable with different fish, calamari, shrimp, etc.  Very flavorful with emphasis of onions.

Also shared the lamb empenadas which were yummy but I think its hard to mess this up.  The sauce that went with it was very tasty.  

The majority of the tables got salads-  I got the enselada with prawns- wow the prawns were battered and had so much flavor.

I'd love to come back and try their other dishes.  Everything is so fresh and yummy.   Fast and decent service- got slow towards the end when it got busier.
author: Anya R.

description: We've eaten here 4 or 5 times and never been disappointed. Top notch Peruvian food beautifully presented. We've been to a couple of Gaston Acurio's other restaurants in Peru and they were fabulous as well. I adore the ceviche and causa. I wish I could make mashed potatoes taste and look like that. Very imaginative. Muy rico!
author: N J.

description: Great service, great location. Not so impressed with the food. This was my first time here and my expectations were a bit higher. I had the ceviche sampler first, which didn't impress me in terms of texture and flavors, but it wasn't bad either. The fish of the day was Cod.  I asked for the sauce on the side, but they didn't quite followed. I thought it was tasty, but over cooked.  I had two Pisco-based cocktails, including the Pisco Sour, which were a 7 out of 10. I asked for a wine suggestion and the waiter recommended a Txakoli, which I thought was pretty cool.  I later asked for an Unoaked Chardonnay, but the waiter's recommendation had certainly seen some oak.  Overall, a bit of a sweet and sour feeling, but I'll give it another chance.
author: David B.

description: There are lots of Asian live at Peru. So peruana food kind of taste like chinese food in a certain way. Overall, it's a great place for family dinner! It's pricy but worth it.
author: Danielle C.

description:
I live right across La Mar and unfortunately could not find time to go there.  Two days ago I finally did!!!!

This restaurant is not just good, it is really really really good!!!!

The menu has so much to offer! Their wine list is awesome! 

I loved the decor. I'm from Europe and I'm used to attending very glamorous and chic restaurants. Some of them charge you insane money for nothing!!!!  I can't say that about LA MAR. The decor is simple and nice! It is just right for enjoying the delicious food.

The service is 5+++++.

I would definitely suggest this place for big companies and romantic dinners.  Make sure  you make the reservation!!!!!!!!!
author: Julia G.

description:
Admittedly, I was there on a busy night (NYE), so in all fairness, I should give them a try on a less frenzied night, but here are my initial impressions.

First of all, order the Peruvian Pimm's cocktail. Don't ask questions. Just do it. Truly a phenomenal drink...one of those dangerous ones that's easy to drink quickly because it's so refreshing BUT full of alcohol. We had to reign ourselves in after two!

Given all of the hype, I was expecting to be blown away by the food (especially the ceviche). While everything was good (including the ceviche and the kobe beef entree), the only thing that truly stood out was the octopus anticucho. That dish had a major wow factor between the sauce and the texture of the octopus. 

Finally, for a restaurant of that caliber, the service was disappointing. The table right next to us that was seated a full 30 minutes after we were was receiving their first courses before us. It took nearly three hours for us to get through a meal of two appetizers, entrees and dessert. (For the record, though, that actually ended up being a blessing rather than a curse because we were planning to just hang out there to watch the fireworks and enjoy the DJ afterward. But, if it had been any other occasion - especially if we had to be somewhere else afterward and were on a schedule - I would have been truly irked.)

All this said, I do think it's worth giving La Mar another go because it seems that the menu was limited for such a big dining night, so maybe I'll uncover those amazing dishes that everyone seems to be raving about. And, hopefully, they'll be served at a more regular pace.

But for now, I think I'll stick with the tried and true Limon in the Mission.
author: Rachel G.

description: Food is great, but the service is lacking skill and management.
author: Allison G.

description:
I went here for drinks, only, so I can't comment on the restaurant. Maybe it was the awesome Pisco Sours, but this place is a fantastic bar stop. I went with two other people during an off hour right before dinner, so we almost had the entire bar to ourselves. The bar area was lit by the soft, filtered lighting of the late afternoon sun which was perfect since we were right on the water. (It sits on the Embarcadero.) They keep windows and doors open so you can smell the sea air which, as a native-San Franciscan-- is one of the most soothing scents to calm you down. 

The bar was not loud and everyone could speak at a regular decibel to be heard and carry on a conversation without screaming. We ordered drinks and several appetizers. 

Since La Mar IS a cebicheria (ceviche), a lot of their appetizers include raw fish, but there are some non-seafood items like yucca chips, which are equally good. I ordered the causa (whipped potatoes) with raw tuna and yucca, sweet potato and platain chips. Drool worthy! Someone in my party order the Nikei Cebiche which she raved over. (I don't care for ceviche, but others in my party loved it.) All of the ceviches are apparently marinated in (wait for it) leche de tiger --translation: Tiger's Milk. WHAT?! Tiger's milk. As exotic as that sounds it's basically the fish run off (yup), lime, fresh peppers, onions, and salt. I think they figured Tiger's Milk sounded sexier than marinated in its own fish juice. (Yeah, that's how much I don't care for ceviche, but folks love it. God bless 'em.)

I don't know if Pisco Sours are the official drink of Peru yet, but it should be. Be careful with this rummy tasting drink as it will hit you hard before you know it. If you're a beginner, just have one and see how you feel for fifteen minutes before ordering another one. It's a sneaky drink. The one made a La Mar is fresh and clean tasting and doesn't leave you with that headache feeling like tequila drinks. It's taste is similar to a Brazilian caipirinha except darker.
author: Adrienne A.

description:
My favorite restaurant in San Francisco bar none. The ceviches, the empanadas, the skewers, and the lomo Saltado. I'm a white guy and everything is kind of OK by me. But this place knocks it out of the park... 

Even the drinks are amazing - try the Capitan if you're a whiskey fan like me.
author: Adam H.

description: Excellent food, excellent service, excellent location, what more could you ask for. The ceviche Nikei, Empanadas , and arroz la mar were stand out items. A bit pricey and noisy, but to be expected in this part of SF. Great place to take out of town guests.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Ladies, leave your LBD hanging in the closet.  Put on something bright and colorful, kick off the pumps and slip into some strappy sandals, ditch the Blackberry, and come away to a culinary paradise.

La Mar ain't no Lima shantytown.  Spacious and open, each room begets another until it leads you all the way to the water.  Bold blues and whites make up the room, and if you sit in the back the fire from the kitchen will imbue the room with an amazing amber color.

Drinks are amazing...who doesn't love pisco? As others say, the passion fruit cocktail is delicious, as is the one with elderflower, which my dining companion ordered.  The touches are nice: zest tied to the straw, perfectly concocted, and the bar area makes waiting for your table pleasurable.

If it's your first time, as it was mine, I recommend the cebiche tasting, a sampling of their four cebiches: mixto, chifa, nikei, and clasico.  They're mostly perfect, chifa and nikei having Asian elements such as sesame, ginger, Japanese cucumber. The mixto and clasico are a bit milder...unless you bit into a habanero like I did. Yowsa. That merits another drink on its own.  House made chips of plantains and yucca come gratis with three great dipping sauces, very rich.  You must order the anticuchos de pulpo! Octopus grilled over some exceptional charcoal, served with herbed mashed potato with chimichurri sauce.  These little octopi pack a flavorful punch.

My companion and I are both love rice pudding, so when we saw rollitos de arroz con leche we became giddy.  Rice pudding spring roll topped with homemade aji amarillo and orange marmalade with passion fruit sorbet. Perfect light ending to an already light meal.  Each bite of every dish ordered was immaculate and unique.

I feel like my tryst with La Mar is only beginning, because there is so much more to taste and savor, and if next tastings are anything like my first, we'll have a bright future together.
author: Joanna M.

description:
I am not Peruvian and have next to no experience with authentic Peruvian cuisine.  We heard about La Mar from a Peruvian friend of ours who said it was not bad at all.  So on two occasions, my family and I went to La Mar for Saturday lunch, sitting at the back patio and enjoying the view of the bay.

The restaurant has a very airy and relaxed ambiance.  Everything on the menu looks appetizing so we ordered all samplers, such ceviche and empanada, and a few other dishes such as the rolls and grilled corazon.  Everything tasted delicious!  We were happy with all the dishes, the kids especially like the beef empanada.

The service was friendly and attentive.  We had the same waiter on both occasions and he seemed very happy and proud to work there, which is always a good indication.

We enjoy La Mar very much and recommend it to anyway strolling on Embarcardro.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
It's a bit pricey, but for excellent food in a restaurant with a great view, it's worth trying at least once. 

After taking a trip to Peru a couple years back, I have become obsessed with Peruvian food.  I search high and low for Peruvian cookbooks, ingredients, and restaurants.  La Mar is one of my favorite.  Great decor, great location, and really amazing seafood is the best way I can sum up this place.

Cebiche is the star of the show here.  The seafood is super fresh, and there's a bit of a zing from the lime and herbs.  

Even on a blustery day, sitting on the patio is a treat.  Since it's covered, the tables are protected from the wind.  There are enough heaters to keep the space warm and comfortable.
author: Emcee K.

description:
Best food incredible desert
Great service!!
author: Dennis E.

description:
I would give 3.5 if I could: great food until you get the bill. 
We went on a Monday during OracleWorld so every restaurant along the waterfront was packed. We stayed for several courses and many drinks (the wine list is actually pretty amazing) but I expected more from the food - tomatoes weren't ripe, sauces were kinda bland, small plates didn't quite come together... yawn. 
Large open room so quite loud at peak hours. The service was good though, especially for how busy they were. 
Probably won't be back - there are many of other restaurants that offer more of a culinary experience at that price level.
author: D C.

description: Amazing food and service. Highly recommend the ceviche tasting platter to start with, as well as causa limena. The lomo saltado and skewers are very tasty.
author: Christophe C.

description:
Came for Dine About Town Lunch in January. 

The menu ended up being a sampler of an appetizer and a sampler of an entree, plus a dessert. I chose menu #1 with the Cebiche Misto and Anticucho Carne. I don't remember much about the Ceviche (must have been middle-range), but the Anticucho Carne was quite delicious. With those large corn kernals underneath? Awesome. 

The best thing about the lunch by far was the dessert...Pie de Limón. SO GOOD. Perfectly sweet and sour with a wonderful crunch in the middle. 

For a complementary appetizer before the meal they brought out Plaintain, Taro, Yam, and Potato Chips with 3 dipping sauces. Great way to start the meal. 

The only reason that I give this place 3 stars instead of 4 is that the portions were SO SMALL. I don't need to eat very much, but an hour after I left I was legit hungry again! Not cool when you've paid over $20 for lunch.
author: Talia G.

description: This place is a place you go to where you just want to grab a bite to eat on a not so empty stomach. Their portions here are very small and pricey. the upside though is that the food is good. You really get what you pay for QUALITY wise. They start you off with these free sweet potatoe chips. Delicious especially with the side of dips they give you. OMG it makes the chip taste even better. I really liked that they did that. I ordered just one beef skewer for $18. I wasn't so sure what to expect with it coming out. As soon as my food came of course it was a some beef stuck on some stick with it laying over some thick cut fried potatoes. As soon as I took a bite of my food I was actually really impressed with how good and flavorful it was. The beef you can tell was very well marinated and cooked right. what made this dish even better was the potatoes. Those potatoes were sooooo good and it definitely complimented the beef with it. I actually got light weight full off the dish. Customer service was good but there's always that one worker who isn't too good. I ordered a drink and he came back with something totally different. also, when he came back he didn't seem too happy to give me the drink. I ordered a strawberry mojito, ummm yeah it was OK. I had better. Seemed like they just added a mixer of strawberry. Not REAL strawberries. Price of drink was reasonable. $11-13 . All in all I liked this place. Only thing is that don't come here expecting to get full unless you want to pay an arm and a leg.
author: Myphan L.

description:
I came here twice. First time was lunch in a DAT event, 2nd time came here for dinner with a group of out-of-town visitors. Both times I was wowed by appetizers, but the wow quickly disappeared on second courses or main courses. On my recent visit, we shared the following:

Cebiche Mixto: A great starter!  
Arroz La Mar: prawns, clams, mussels, calamari, white fish and vegetables in rice
Pescado Entero: whole red snapper in a spicy nikei sauce
Lomo Saltado: Peruvian style stir fry beef tenderloin
The above three are good, but fail to impress. 

And we had a bottle of Shafer 2011 Merlot (Napa valley), excellent!
author: Emmy P.

description:
CeViche or ceBiche? I'm still getting the hang what to call it, as well as the idea of eating seafood "cooked" in acidic lemon or lime juice. But when done right, it's ooh soo nice.

La Mar has lots going for it: great location, view, stylish interior, and tall, dark and hunky servers talented at making my girlfriend smile with their latin accents. But most impressive is its food.

We were knocked off our designer bar stools by the cebiche sampler. The perfect composition of sweet and heat, savory and puckerlicious sour complemented delicate chunks of octopus, halibut, ahi and mahi mahi. If you needed a break from the sweet'n tart you could fall back on La Mar-style "table bread" consisting of delicious fried plantains and other mystery root chips'n dips.

The seafood empanadas were buttery and creamy with a flakey crust and gooey essence-of-the-sea filling. It was paired with an intensely sour and salty salad. 

The Peruvian classic lomo saltado featured juicy, incredible strips of Peruvian beef lounging in a saucy mixture of veggies and frites. I loved alternating between puckery bites of greens which prepped your taste buds for that next strip of beef.

The service was impeccable, attentive, informative and friendly. With a location so close by and decent pricing, if you skip wine and dessert, we'll be back soon to drop some more acid infused seafood.
author: Brady K.

description:
I am conflicted about this place. 
The ceviche was easily the best and most derlicious of my life. 
The service, not so much. 
The waiter was obviously frazzled and had no idea what gluten free meant. 
-Never reassuring-
We ordered yellow tail ceviche, chicken skewers, grilled squid, salad, cocktails, and the crab topped potato bites. 
Everything except the chicken was tasty. 
The view was good as well. 

I will go back for ceviche and cocktails alone.
author: A. H.

description:
La Mar is consistent in two ways: delicious food and  disappointing service.  My most recent visit was this past Saturday night.  For their prices, I expect the host and server to be a little more friendly and service-oriented.

Service: I made reservations more than two weeks in advance.  They required a credit card to hold the reservation.  They were 25 minutes late seating us, not offering us a thing while we waited until I pointed out that had I been 25 minutes late for my reservation, I would have lost it and they would have charged my credit card.  The host was apathetic to the delay, so I asked for a complementary round of drinks, and they brought out an order of empanadas instead.  At least it was something.  The service was very, very slow.  It took over 30 minutes for a round of cocktails to be delivered.  The server never smiled.

Food: Delicious, fresh, creative.  The plantain chips, causas, ceviche, caprese quinoa and pallela-like dish were phenomenal.  I've previously had the sea bass with mushrooms and ginger and that is also delicious.

I recommend the place strictly for the food.  Do not come here if you're tight on time or enjoy pleasant and efficient service.
author: Caitlin T.

description:
This place is a modern take on Peruvian cuisine. I personally was not so into the food but loved the bar scene. 

We came here on a Friday trying to catch a bite before a 7pm engagement. The restaurant was closed but the bar was open and serving the full menu. We sat at the bar and tried every specialty drink on the menu. 

The happy hour was decent, more about the food special than the drink specials. The best thing on that menu was the empanadas. The calamari was not the best I have ever had but it was good. 

My favorite drinks were the Santa Maria (Pisco, pomegranate infused tequila, lemon juice and ginger syrup) & Tumi (Pisco quebranta, passion fruit and prickly pear). 

For dinner we ordered the cebiche mixto (Mahi Mahi, calamari, octopus and habanero pepper in ají amarillo leche de tigre with cilantro, red onion, Peruvian corn and yam). It was good but it was more of a modern take on ceviche, very chunky. We also ordered the causa limeña (Dungeness Crab, avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo Huancaína sauce with basil cilantro oil) which was cold and did not taste so great. 

For dessert we had buñuelos de chocolate caliente (Orange glazed chocolate beignets with banana and passion fruit ice cream). These were super yummy! 

Overall- the amazing service and the great drinks make this place a great pick for cocktails.
author: Caro S.

description: First experience with Peruvian food, and loved every bite. We listened to our server, Nick and he was an excellent guide. We started with a sampler of ceviche and empanadas. There were 4 of us so we doubled the empanadas order. A perfect sampling.  Wish I could say what were our favorites but we loved it all. Something for everyone. We each ordered an entrée and ate family style. I strongly suggest this tactic (thank you Yelp reviewer, who suggested it) it gave everyone a sample and it was plenty to eat. The bar was very busy and the specialty drinks were labor intensive but the bartenders did a very good job of keeping up. In fact it was kind of fun watching them at work. Not cheap but worth it.
author: Dwaine M.

description:
I love La Mar and would have given it 5 stars except that they've been removing a lot of my favorite dishes from the menu. 

Favorites:
- cebiche nikei (actually any of the cebiches are amazing)
- empanadas - my favorite was the corn emapanada but they've changed it slgihtly. It's still good but the old item had a nice sweet corn flavor to it. I really miss the sweet corn empanadas!
- picarones 

My biggest disappointment the last time I visited was that they no longer carry the beignets for dessert. When I asked our server why they no longer carry it, she said that it was "too popular"... :(
author: Michelle V.

description: I keep coming back! Love the food! Love it that they don't rush you! They explain the menu so well to new people.
author: Clark L.

description:
The ambiance reminded me of Cancun, love the turquoise color! Their food was good but the service was a little lacking (3 stars). We sat outside and the waiter wasn't too attentive; pretty much refilled the incorrect wine and took a while for the right one to come back out.

We ordered the cebiche tasting, loved it but kind of pricey $32. The best sample was the cebiche clasico, halibut. I just love the citrus taste and the sauce complimented the fish really well. The three remaining cebiches were pretty good too. The empanada sampler was great in presentation and tasted good. I thought each sample had great flavor and wasn't too overpowering. It was very light. The two entre samples are your best bet, if it's your first time and just wanted to try a few things.
author: Nhung T.

description:
Walking the Embarcadero last nite and took a chance at La Mar.
Having been to Peru over 35 years ago was wondering if it would bring back memories of the interesting flavors and tastes of those visits.
We arrived before dinner hours so sat in the bar for happy hour. One group was way too loud even before they started drinking. Noise level not pleasant.
Checked out the bar menu and drinks while deciding whether to stay or not for dinner.
Had a passionfruit margarita (very weak) and the wife had the cucumber gin drink which she liked enough to have another. I switched to Tequila and admit they have a great selection of liquors.
Ordered the potato with crab and the fried chicken thigh meat and mushroom empenada appetizers.
Potato good........chicken a bit too spiced and the empenada  was dried out.
Asked if we could get into the restaurant for dinner but was told it was booked till 830. 
So ordered a beet/carrot salad which ended up being the best thing of the evening.
The quinoa risotto and the chicken skewer both were way overdressed with spices etc.
The potato and corn with the skewer were dry and cold. Almost unedible in my opinion.
Wont be back............sorry.
author: LarryJohn P.

description: Best Peruvian outside of Peru, just too bad they have to work with limited local ingredients, no crazy variety of Peruvian veggies...
author: Frederic P.

description:
I've always been a fan of Peruvian food, and the few other locales I've been to in the City were really tasty and seemingly more homestyle.  

La Mar is like Peruvian - Asian, meets Miami Beach decor.  It's kinda all strange yet melds this SF hipster vibe together with South American food.  

The happy hour from 3-6 was packed.  $5 drink specials and I'm a new fan of pisco sour!!!  The caipirinha was ok...nothing like I got in Puerto Rico. 

On to the food:  In honor of the Chinese vibe on the menu, our table split everything and turned this family style!  We got the cebiche tasting, causa tasting,  empanada sampler,  the corazon (grilled beef heart with fried potatos, Peruvian corn and a spicy panchita and rocoto sauce), the solterito de quino (quinoa salad, olives, lima beans , cilantro, bell peppers, queso fresco, and red onion in olive oil dressing), the lomo saltado (tradition Peruvian stir fry of beef tenderloin, onions, tomatos, cilantro, soy sauce, fried potatos) and the special fish dish of the day, California rock fish, fileted and deep fried with tamarind dressing, baby bok choy, and some other seasonings.  

Can I say I'm in love with their cebiche nikei made with ahi tuna.  Very fresh, and light.  Not really a vegetarian, I don't particularly jump at trying vegetarian items, but the best causa of the night was the causa casera, it was light and refreshing!

The BEST dish of the evening was the California rock fish.  Although they did filet it, they still presented as a whole fish, in the traditional good luck style of Chinese influence, albeit, also a standard style of South American influence.  The tamarind added just that extra special hint of sweet yet tangyness to the freshly caught rock fish.  FAN!  

Added bonus, it's so close to BART that after X number of drinks, y'all don't have to worry about the drive home! Double fan!!!
author: Taylor Y.

description:
It is always dicey to eat in touristaville.  But, La Mar was spot on for ambiance, service, and quality of food.  

Major props to Jonathan, our server.  His attention to detail and concern for my visibly pregnant friend was amazing.   So much of the food is raw and he made sure she had plenty of options. 

How can a basic chicken skewer be so delicious?  If they can make that taste delicious, imagine what they can do with cerviche.
author: E T.

description:
I'm going to begin with the end... As we walked out, we both thought "the food was 'fine', the service very thin, and the prices expensive. You never want to have an expensive, 'fine' meal, especially in a city where places like Limon exist. 

We had the meat empanadas, the yellow tail skewer, my wife had a quinoa dish, and I had a mash of octopus, calamari, fish, and other unknown pieces swallowed up in a sauce that made everything the same. The homemade sorbets for dessert were the best part of the meal; actually quite good. That, and the Pisco Sours.

Just not a place we'll return to, or recommend. Sad, since it's such a nice large space and really a nice atmosphere.
author: tom s.

description:
Sooooo loud!!! This place was crazy crowded on a Thursday night! I expect the bar to be loud but the restaurant itself was obnoxiously loud. 

I felt that the food was just mediocre at best. Service was incredibly slow. Atmosphere was nice, seating was comfortable. The portions look like they are meant to feed a toddler. Pisco Punch was delicious, highly recommend, and my cousin loved her calamari. 

I realize that most people that come here don't get the ONE chicken dish on the menu, (in fact, the waiter laughed at me when I ordered it) so they probably don't worry about making it great. The chicken was just really fatty and pretty tough. All in all, it was just whatever to me. Prices were fairly reasonable considering its a popular place on the pier. $220 for 7 of us. But I probably won't come back.
author: Amanda H.

description: LOVED THE FOOD :) The ceviches are all great, but our favorite was the grilled ahi-tuna which was the special of the day. It came with mango chimichurri and causa-a-mashed-potato like dish. The flavors were great and the texture was so unique. The causa salad was also superb, in both taste and presentation. It came with causa at the bottom, avocado in the middle and quinoa on the top. Also, they bring out these comlementary sweet potato and yucca chips that are soooo good.
author: Jenny B.

description: Had a great lunch here. If you're looking for great Peruvian food, this is the place to go. Our waitress Jessica was friendly and gave us great customer service. If you haven't been here, check it out. You won't be disappointed.
author: Chelle N.

description: For a drink the Pisco Sour was so yummy. The services was excellent. Delicious cebiche with flavors of Peru, citrusy and spicy  Everyone in our party left nothing on their plate.  A good sign!    So good!
author: Dawn S.

description:
Beautiful location right on the water and although the restaurant was packed, the high ceiling and open layout made the sound level tolerable.

Great good, lomito saltado was good, though, the ceviche is the best I've ever had.

Good service too, though, a bit slow (they were busy!).

I will be back, great place.
author: Luis B.

description: La Mar is great.  The fish is fresh and I love all of their ceviche.  When it's a nice day out it's great to sit outside on their patio, but even if it's a little chilly they cover the patio and keep it heated, so also nice.  The second time I went (at lunch) the service was pretty slow-- not sure if that was because it was a busy lunch day, but definitely leave time if you're going to eat here during a work day lunch.  All in all, everything was tasty and fresh!  I'd definitely go back.
author: Erin B.

description: Yum! This restaurant was a treat! We made reservations for New Year's Eve and enjoyed our meals. The pisco sours were dangerously delicious, I liked those better than any other cocktails I tried that night. Our waiter was extremely helpful in suggestions for drinks and entrees. I went with the arroz la mar and really liked it. (Only negative-- the bathroom situation is a little small for the size of the restaurant...and not well-kept.)
author: Nikki M.

description: Probably my favorite Peruvian restaurant in San Francisco. I absolutely love their plantain chips! I have had many dishes and I have yet to be disappointed...
author: Jasabel L.

description:
There's two ways to look at La Mar.

The first is experienced Latin food diner who realizes that a meal of ceviche and empanadas should cost (literally) about $6 and any mom & pop stop in Argentina, Peru, or Costa Rica would be equally good.  That was my first instinct, and if that is you you'll probably give La Mar 1 star.

But for great bayfront view, sweeping venue, and unique presentation style...along with fresh ceviche and very decent empanadas...upping to 4 stars.
author: Geoff C.

description: Great service at this place. The place was packed but the hostess was able to get me a spot at the ceviche bar. I had both the Carretillo and Jalapeño ceviche. The Carretillo was the perfect amount of hotness. The Pisco sour drink sounds strange but it is excellent.
author: Jim T.

description: I don't mind it's pricey Bcoz this place delivers every thing possible for what you pay. Good ambiance, excellent food, flawless service - what else would you expect from a restaurant. The restaurant closes at 10 and they weren't pushy to throw us out even at 11. Very friendly and can't explain the quality of food - Amazing!!
author: Bumble B.

description:
1pm lunch on a Monday with 5 people.

Service was meh, our server was non-existent, my pisco drink was empty the majority of the time we were there and I could have drank 3 of them.  He never once came to ask how we liked our food and I was halfway through eating when he offered me a regular sized place for sharing.

I can't remember all of the items ordered... the empanadas sampler, cebiche tasting, causa limena which is like crab salad with whipped potato (all apps)
flank steak kabobs, almuercito limeño, almuercito carretillero
fried calamari with cebiche and crab/potato -server should have told us that this entree was accompanied by 2 of the appetizers already ordered.  We spent about $280 which included tip and alcoholic beverages so it was a fairly pricey lunch at about $50 per person.  This restaurant was just ok. I don't know if I will return though.
Plantain chips were yummy, great location near Embarcadero, great layout and bar area.

I have to say I was disappointed this time around as I was here with my husband for lunch and ordered the same cebiche; the flavors are less distinct and not as tasty as before.  Since he wasn't on this trip with me, I'm sure he's going to be happy when I tell him it wasn't as good. We really loved our experience a few years ago.

Beware it is really expensive for the amount of food served.
author: Phi N.

description:
The atmosphere at La Mar is really balanced on the edge of  a knife between cool ultra-lounge and cheesy-on-the-pier-tourist-trap.  I only saw it in the light of day, so maybe its more appealing in the evening, but in the daylight, I wasn't particularly impressed overall.  I did like that the kitchen was open, but the counter is so high that you can't see anything interesting from the tables anyway.  I saw some beautiful pictures on here on Yelp, but I for one would rather the food taste good than look pretty, and overall La Mar drops the ball on this one.  

The coktails were pretty much spot on; the Pisco Sour was delicious, as was the cucumber habenaro cooler (I don't remember the precise name).  The potpourri chips (sweet potatoes, plantains and a variety of other tubers) was very pretty, but I really wanted the chips to be warm. I don't understand why this is such a problem in restaurants, get a damn heat lamp.  If you're going to go through the trouble of making homemade chips, then at least give me the impression that they're fresh! 

The cebiches were all pretty tasty (we got the sampler), but the portions were really small, just one bite per person per sample (of which there were four).  

We ordered arroz con mariscos (a peruvian equivalent of paella), which was underwhelming.  The seafood was completely drowned out by the tomato paste, and overall it was too sweet.  It was the only reasonably filling dish served, so it had that going for it.  

The tacu-tacu (the evenings special) again was tasty, but considering it was basically a large plate of refried beans with a 1-2 ounce portion of fish on top, it wasn't exactly worth the $30 we paid for it.  

The broiled scallops were also tasty, but also not deserving of the $17 for four.  They literally opened some bay scallops and broiled them with parmesan cheese and worcestershire sauce, nothing more.  

In the end, we spent about $240 for four people and I left feeling hungry and without a buzz.  On top of the that, there wasn't a single dish that left me feeling impressed or wowed.  Basically we paid La Mar not to mess up our meals, which they did, but at these prices, not messing up isn't quite good enough.
author: Jason B.

description:
The food is alright
Drinks and appetizers, too
Ambiance not so much
author: Christophe C.

description:
When I go to restaurants I like to look at their menu and scan for interesting items.  I was here for lunch, and instead of getting a sandwich I got...

[causa nikei 12 --
Ahi Tuna tartar and avocado purée on top of whipped purple potato with creamy rocoto Huancaína sauce topped with Japanese nori ]

You basically get 3 cylindrical shot glasses of whipped purple potato with the rocoto sauce.  What you get is a starchy mouth feel, but balanced with the sensation of fat (cream, milk?) in the potato.  It is topped with the tuna and the rocoto sauce.

I had a chance to talk with one of the chefs and the rocoto pepper is special where the heat comes very quickly and intense, and leaves pretty quickly also.

This dish was off the wall amazing.  I tried even to make it at home, and I COULD NOT figure out how they get perfectly shaped cylindrical potatos.

[lunch empanada - 3]
Their baked empanadas are really good.  The dough has the perfect mixture of butter with a really nice filling.

[fried empanada]
Now, I really wasn't a fan of their fried empanada.  Stick with their baked one.

[overall]
Flavor wise la mar is doing some amazing things.  However it is a tad bit on the pricy side, so I'm sure you'll have to take that into consideration.
author: Dan Q.

description:
FOOD:

1.) Baked chips & dip = Complimentary chip & dip of 3 pixel square plate of spicy, mild, and not or orange, salmon, and yello. Baked dried slices of potato, sweet potato, banana! I like the banana and sweet potato ones ;P The potato chips taste like... well, potato chips. But better coz it's baked. 
2.) Cebiche = I like raw fish. um. If you eat the lil bright orange pepper on top, it gives the whole appetizer a nice swift kick in the tastebuds.
3.) Carne Skewer = Yum, taste like yummy steak. Wish it were a steak ;/ Kind of just a skimpy singular skewer. What a tease. I guess technically it's supposed to be an appetizer. But yeah. Appeteaser. Le sigh. Quanity!!! In addition to quality!!!! Por favor!


SERVICE:
Timely, cordial.


ATMOSPHERE:
Very interesante! Like a pixel theme going on. Menu and place settings are like that of a Photoshop geek, zoomed in at 100x, magic wand-ing and paintbucketing the pixels of the water theme or lime theme or sardine chromatic swatch. Hexadecimal of turquoise #00C5CD or hexadecimal lime #00FF00 ;P *snort snort* Nice resort feeling to it, of I guess in Peruvian tropical vacay, bar area in front, cabana-like couches and tables near the inside bar, blue mood lighting under the middle food bar feels like underwater bar haha, to the side, open window to very nice looking side of the pier to other establishments, the back of the restaurant, a nice dim ambiance of fine casual dining. Take a stroll outside the side doors, to see ferry boats and a rather stunning view of the lit up Bay Bridge ;P

15
author: Angela L.

description:
A few things about me that I'm willing to admit for the sake of Yelp, is that I'm close minded when it comes to food, with bland, undeveloped taste buds, unwilling to try anything new. I'm that person you know who always orders the same thing at a restaurant, who refuses to try anything new and must have it my way. A lot of my friends and people who dine with me will say I remind them of the character Sally from How Harry met Sally. Although I hate to admit it, yes I am Sally. 

So when my sister told me we were celebrating her birthday at La Mar, I was pretty hesitant especially when she told me they were famous for their cebiches. If it was any other occasion I would have been "sick" with the flu. When we got here, I was in a crabby mood due to the rain and the traffic. But it was all worth it. 

The food was delicious. My favorites were the cebiche nikei (ahi tuna, red onion, avocado, and Japanese cucumber in tamarind lecha de tigre) I'm usually hesitant to eat the raw stuff, but the ahi tuna just melted in my mouth. My other favorite dish was the arroz norteno (north Peruvian seafood combination with mussels, shrimp, octopus, calamari, and fried rice with cilantro and Huancaina sauce and salsa criolla) I don't even know what Huancaina sauce is, but it was really good on the fried rice. The fried rice texture was unlike anything I've had before. There was this creamy texture to it. 

The service was ehh but I don't blame them, it was pretty busy that night. 

I'm actually really glad my sister decided on La Mar, the atmosphere was intimate and cozy. The food was delicious and the company was great.
author: Ha N.

description:
I remember embarrassing little about the meal aside from the fact that it was all very delicious.

I was dining with VIPs used to taking charge of the situation so I barely looked at the menu and ate what was put in front of me.  Luckily the guy doing the ordering is a regular so he knew exactly what to order.

Favorites:
Lomo Saltado - If my skirt steak the other night had meat this tender, I would have eaten the entire cow.  Last night, I had to be a lady and not scoop the entire plate into my belly.
Anticuchos - I've never been a fan of octopus ... (odd because I like calamari) - but this was divine.  I also heard a riveting story of how to catch octopus ... all you need is a lot of rope and cut up Clorox bottles and 4 beers.  But de-inking in an entirely different story.
Nikei - so cute, just like the name would suggest.  Next time I'm getting a plate just for me.  NO TOUCHY!
Cebiche Tasting - which included the Mixto (mostly mahi mahi), Nikei (ahi tuna), chifa (yellowtail) and clasico (halibut).  Great sampler, but the tuna was my favorite.  I wish I had chips for the scooping.
Criollo - Peruvian Fried rice ... Chinese girl approve.

There were about 3 other dishes and several bottles of wine ... but alas, the names allude me.  Hard to remember everything when it's family style dining.

Super busy on a Wednesday night - but luckily parking was relatively easy in the area.  They have a bar section, a lounge section and way in the back, the dining section with supposedly incredible views.  We ended up in the lounge section which was drafty and noisy and despite all the foot traffic in the area by the staff, we'd go for long stretches without any service. 
 
While it was a great meal (made better cause it was free for me), I'd prefer Gail's homestyle cooking anyday.  I will however be back to try the pisco sour.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
We had an early 6"15 pm dinner reservaion tonight (Friday) that I got through Open Table.  
It was out first time here and forst time eating Peruvian food.  Thr fish eaters at the table oved the cebiche.  My appetizer was kind of weird and my entree of flank steak skewer was just okay.  But, I am NOT a good eater, so what do I know?  I'll tell you!  I could have eaten three baskets of the potato chips they bought to the table.  Maybe 4!  Dayum, those were good.  OH!  I forgot....the dulce de leche mousse??  Pour that down my throat...YUMMMMO!
author: Cassie P.

description:
It's not a BAD restaurant, but it's quite expensive and I felt gypped for the price.

The acoustics were terrible -- I could hear the two neighboring tables better than my date.

The ceviche was decent but not great, but the empanadas tasted like Hot Pockets and I didn't even finish them. 

On the plus side, all the cocktails (we tried many) were darn tasty.

Service was slow.  There's not enough waiters for a crowded Friday night.  The waiter himself, though, had a charming accent.
author: Dean M.

description:
After a cold windy day touring Alcatraz and walking along the Embarcadero, La Mar was the perfect choice for a romantic and relaxing dinner. Located on Pier 1.5, La Mar was set against the gorgeous orange purple sky during sunset, with gorgeous views of the bay. As we sat down, we were offered a complimentary bouquet of plantain, yam, taro and potato chips with 3 dipping sauces.  

For starters, it was imperative that we order a Cebiche because of course I did my yelp research beforehand...I also wanted to check off another item of the 7x7 The Big Eat SF list. :) After much discussion, we ended up choosing the Cebiche Mixto with Mahi Mahi, calamari, octopus and habanero pepper in ají amarillo leche de tigre. Ohh, deliciousness!! This is unlike any ceviche that I've ever tried and absolutely deserving of a spot on the 7x7 list for 100 Things to Eat and Drink Before You Die.

As our main courses, I chose the Arroz Jugoso, a juicy paella-like rice and seafood dish. I'm a huge fan of paella so it is really no surprise that I absolutely loved it. Not only was the rice so flavorful and seafood so tender, there was so much of it that I had to take half of it to go. My date ordered the Chorillana, Roasted striped sea bass filet. Although Paella is always my fav, the sea bass surprisingly almost took the cake. 

Thanks La Mar, for helping make such an amazing weekend in SF.
author: Jeanne S.

description: The place has a cold modern ambiance with average food and good service. over all I think it would be a good spot for happy hour or business lunch that food quality is not that important. We got the cebiche la mar out of which only the Tuna was great everything else below average. then we got the empanadas de lomo saltado which was a let down. then I got corazón (beef heart) which was ok (I have better) but the sauce they used was not matching the meat! our servers were very pleasant and helpful so service was great. over all experience was average thus why getting 3 stars.
author: Arash H.

description: Not a fan of paying a lot of money for small amounts of food.  Nuff said!
author: C L.

description:
Whoa. This place was... in-cre-di-ble. 
First of all, service was REALLY great. Our waitress was super nice and helpful. 
Secondly, food was AWESOME. It was slightly salty.. but according to my friend, Peruvian foods are all salty. It makes savory.
This is what we got: 
For appetizer: 
-Jalea with calamari, shrimp, and other kinds of seafood (basically, this is just deep fried seafood) 
For drinks: 
-Chicha Morada ( boiled corn water, but served cold) and 
-Inka Cola (just a fruity sprite) 
Main course: 
-Quinoa Chaufa (OMG. speechless dish... can't describe it.. YOU ALL PEOPLE HAVE TO TRY THIS.) 
- Lobster Parihuela (my friend got this.. its lobster with beans on the side. It wasn't bad at all!)
Bonus!: This place gives you Peruvian chips while you wait for your meal. They serve you homemade fried banana chips, sweet potato chips, and potato chips. 

Overall, although this place is on the expensive side, ALL IS WORTH IT.
author: Kirsten K.

description:
Heavenly.

Drinks - unique and thirst quenching for those of us who weren't ready to get back to SF's fog and drizzle after spending a week in true summer heat. We were fans of the Passion Secreta and the Chimpun Callao

Cebiche sampler - great place to start before decdiing which one you want. Favorites were Cebiche Carretillero and Nikei

Empanada - Tamalito Verde mmmmmmmm 

Entrees - all delicious. Lomo Saltado, Cau Cau, Arroz Criollo, and Chorrillana
author: Shahrzad K.

description: Came here last night for my brother in laws birthday.  I was less then thrilled. My husband ordered their lomo plate which was $32. I got the empanadas sampler and chicken kabob plate. The empanadas were about the only GOOD thing there other then the sweet potato chips and dip. The lomo had a Chinese take-out taste to it. (Soy sauce is all I tasted) and definitely not enough beef. More potatoes an onions then anything else.  Our server never brought my side order of pickled onions as we requested and seldom checked on us. Mind you that my sister in law had to return her dish.  It was like a seafood fried rice plate covered with egg. Overall the experience was not great. Definitely not going back. Overpriced for what it is. IMO.
author: Erica M.

description: Love this place! Came here a month ago and not only was the food amazing but I loved the ambiance and the whole setting of the restaurant. So my boyfriend and I basically ordered everything. I highly recommend getting the samplers that way you can try a little bit of everything. We ordered the ceviche sampler, the causa sampler, the emanda sampler, and the skewers. Sounds like a lot but it's definitely worth it. The ceviche and the causa were our favorites. One of the bests I've ever had. Ceviche was fresh and so delicious and the causas were melt in your mouth SO GOOD! The empandas and skewers were really tasty too, but definitely not as good as the other too. So if you wanted to order just one of the empandas I would say go with the mushroom one. It was the most flavorful in my opinion and for the skewers I liked the fish and it's whatever their catch of the day is. And you can't forget about the drinks! I ordered the pisco sour and it was my first time ever having one and I loved it! I'm not a huge alcohol drinker, my go to drink is normally red wine or just a beer and this drink was so good! I highly recommend this place if you want some good peruvian food. Loved it.
author: Rachna S.

description: I've been in Peruvian restaurants in NY and they are really good. This was my first time in the West Coast and in San Francisco and La Mar was very dissaponting. The presentation was really good, but the food was salty, way too spicy, it wasn't fresh and the service was slow and food overpriced. My mom ordered lomo saltado, but the beef was salty, the rice had to much salt and she always orders the fries aside and they were salty.
