description: I came here on Valentines day after the big pillow fight with a good friend. We had the whipped potato trio, salmon, beef tongue, quinoa risotto, and scallop/shrimp rice. The service was great. They were still able to be attentive dispute how hectic it was. The food was amazing, the whipped potato was both of our favorites. It came with crab, beets, and fried oyster. I think I liked the crab one the most. The salmon was not over cooked. It was my first time trying beef tongue, and I'm proud to say I'm a fan. My quinoa risotto was tasty. Since it's qunioa it's not too heavy and much more healthier than the regular arborio rice. It was a bit more expensive that I would have hoped but overall I had a good time and good food.
author: Luna C.

description:
Have you ever wished you knew the owner at the hottest swanky restaurant in town, so you could walk in, see how the wait staff treated you, and then you could rat out every snobby and rude waiter or bartender or hostess? Mwahhh ha ha.... they would be soooooo fired! 

Well, I do know the owners of the hottest swanky restaurant in town, La Mar... and I have to report that I got nothin' -- service here is fantastic.  (Maybe I was blinded by the freakin' hot waiters!)

But let's get to the important stuff: Drinks at La Mar. Pisco sours. Pisco punch. Pisco anything. You heard it here first: Pisco is this year's mojito. So fresh and addictive. It's worth a trip to La Mar just to experience how it's supposed to taste. 

Now finally the food (you don't have all day). Delicious. Hard to describe because it's so unique but I'm sure the American palate will love it. All the cebiches I've tried are fantastic (Crudo is my favorite though) and the rice dishes are also terrific -- it's a hybrid of paellas and fried rice if you can imagine that -- and heaped with juicy mussles and clams (Arroz Norteno). And do not leave the building without trying the chocolate filled beignets. Imagine a doughnut hole filled with warm chocolate cake. Yeah, I know! Basically, the food is terrific. If you DON'T love the food? Then I have news for you: You're the final Cylon.
author: L. M.

description:
I actually really enjoyed the food here and the atmosphere. But I'm only knocking off one star for a reason... 

I arrived maybe 15 minutes after my reservation I made for my boyfriend's birthday. (Surprised him with some of his friends there. Yay. Hurrah. Hurrah. Anyways... haha jk.) We were seated promptly. We ordered our food, and it came out within maybe 10 minutes. Great. Had an overall good time, and paid then left. 

A few days after the meal (today), I check my bank statements, and I have an additional $95 PLUS my bill I payed for at La Mar. Um, wtf? Where did this $95 appear from? I don't think I ate THAT much food. And I certainly didn't give that big of a tip. 

I'm currently getting it situated, and hopefully it works out and they give me my money back or hell will break loose. And it's sad, because I actually enjoyed my time here. I would like to come back and I would have given 5 stars, but maybe I'll be able to do so when this mess is fixed.
author: Denise D.

description:
Coming from a large family of talented Peruvian chefs and from a strong Peruvian gastronomic background - I hereby rate La Mar - San Francisco, as the best in the greater Bay Area and Nor-Cal.

So what does best mean? To me, it is the best because of:

1. Authenticty - In which the way the food is prepared is truly focused on the traditional means of preparing and cooking the various foods. Peruvian food takes mastery to get the flavors just right when cooking and preparing, and La Mar Chefs have gotten this mastery down, which stems from years of experience of the head chef rooted in Lima.

2. High quality level of ingredients,
I cannot find another Peruvian restaurant which offers such a diversity in Peruvian ingredients. Quinoa, aji amarillo, miel de anis - these are just some of the items that can be found at La Mar. When tasting these dishes, it makes you seem as if you were in Peru. As we all know, the reason why its so hard to duplicate Peruvian dishes outside of Peru is due to the different varities of foods offered locally. The tastes of the natural raw ingredients coming from Peru's 3 Zones are simply unmatched when you leave the country, however that being said - La Mar Chef's have managed to do it!


3. Ambience & location, 
Just to the left of the Historic Landmark Ferry Building at Pier 1 1/2, La Mar sits on the bay nestled in between 2 large piers. The cool colors and warm glows of the restaurant add to the chicness and moderness of the building. While the water is visible, it is not noted for a fantastic bayview, but rather focuses on the restaurant. The bar upon entering is almost its own mini restaurant with stool and couch seating available to order food. 

Either eating at the bar, stopping in for a Pisco Sour, or having a full fledged  menu in house - I reccommend this one of a kind San Francisco Peruvian Dining Experience.

Some of my favs:
Lomo Saltado, Picarones, Ceviche's, Causa's, Aji De Gallina, Anticuchos, Pisco Sours
author: Bruce N.

description:
I have Terry D. to thank for introducing me to this place.  Even while entering early for our reservation, I got to enjoy the last few minutes of happy hour where I ordered myself a drink and just chilled by the bar.  Definitely enough to become cracking, but not overboard.  

By the time dinner started, we were given some sort of plantain chip that just went great with everything.  I almost wanted to eat everything with it, but caught myself in the process and immediately stopped.  

Dinner was delicious, except for the service.  I can understand when a restaurant gets busy and things take a little longer to happen, but my goodness, that shouldn't completely pause on your meal and delay you for 30+ mins.  Timing was not this place's strength, but foodwise, it is indeed good. 

-Causa - great.  The texture and flavor of the whipped potato is perfect.
-Cerviche - so fresh and perfectly seasoned.  Shrimp was good too
-Sea bass - well cooked with a half cooked center..just the way I like my fish.  
-Allorz Limones - The paella like dish with plenty of flavor and zest and great seafood.  I'd go back just for this alone.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Being Japanese/Peruvian, I can definetely say that this place is peruvian cuisine at it's finest. I was happily surprised that they had japanese beer to make us fellow nikei feel appreciated and well ackowledged. 

Love the view of the bay and the electric blue decor, really lives up to the name of the restaurant. Didn't hear any music but it's pretty loud in there from the kitchen firing up and everyone talking having a such a good time. 

The pisco sour cocktail is a must if you want the whole peruvian experience! Food is A++++. Seriously better than a home made peruvian meal. Decadent, rich, exquisite.
author: Toshiro T.

description:
We went there last night for a friend of mine's birthday. She is actually from Peru, and thus was familiar with all the styles of food we ordered. Right up until the main course, I left ordering in her hands, and we were not disappointed.

There were 8 of us who arrived on time, with one more person coming. As a result, we needed to wait a little longer for our actual restaurant table, but to be honest, it did not matter....we were seated in the lounge area, which was a lot of fun. 

We ordered round after round of different kinds of cebiche, seafood, fish, etc with all different textures and flavors. I am a fan. Everything was incredibly fresh tasting, and very different.

After many rounds of Pisco sours, a Peruvian drink made of brandy, lime juice, egg whites, simple syrup and regional bitters, I switched to margarita. Their drinks are tasty and well mixed.

Finally we sat down to dinner. I was perfectly satisfied at that point, but ordered dinner anyway since everyone else was. Service remained good, and the espresso I had for dessert was fresh.
author: Jordan C.

description: LOVE this place, and their peruvian corn pieces mixed in with the ceviche is AMAZING!
author: Lisa W.

description: Way over priced. Decent service and nice view, but too many great dining options in SF to come here.
author: Charlie H.

description: Great ambience, excellent wine selection and great service. Happy hour is worth all the marbles. Pisco sours are highly recommended.
author: Tee Z.

description:
Why was the food so good but why did it seem so understaffed? I will keep it short because my gf wrote a pretty detailed anniversary dinner. Ceviche mix tasting. Got to try 4 different styles of ceviche perfect to share with another person. I loved it!!! The fried potato & sweet potato chips + plantain chips were an awesome little bite to eat while we were desperately waiting for our waiter to come around to our table.  I had the traditional beef tenderloin mixed with french fries and this very light but flavorful sauce. It was sooo good! We had a few drinks, that were okay in my opinion. 

I loved the food, but the service was just out of place servers were bringing the wrong food to other tables. Our server accidentally broke a glass full of wine at another table. I think he just way to flustered with all the tables he was working. It seemed like they had 4 different women hostesses in the front who had no idea what they were really doing. I saw some staff members just floating around and not really doing anything inside the restaurant.  Our bill came out to 122 dollars but still managed to tip the guy well cause I just thought he was a bit overwhelmed by the crowds in the outdoor seating.
author: David K.

description:
FREAKING DELICIOUS!
The location is great, I wish we could have sat outside because there is a great view and the weather was perfect for outdoor dinning.
we ordered the Cebiche Carretillero, the Carne, and the Lomo Saltado.  I would definitely get all three of these things again!
For drinks, we tried the Pisco Sour and the Pisco Punch.  I was a little worried about egg whites being an ingredient in the Pisco Sour... but this was just a sort of meringue layer at the top of the drink, which actually compliments the sour cocktail below.

Dessert time!  We ordered the Cappuccino de Tres Leches.  I was the perfect way to end the dinner!

The only reason La Mar isn't getting 5 stars from me is because I had called ahead two days in advance to make a reservation and to request outdoor seating.  I was told this would be no problem.  Upon arrival, I was politely told that the outdoor seating was not possible.  This was not too big of a deal, but what I didn't like was that we were then sat in one of those shared benches with a tiny table for two and I am bumping elbows with two strangers on either side of me.  I realize lots of restaurants have this sort of seating arrangements, but I personally do not like it.  

so... I really think La Mar is great, don't get me wrong, I will definitely go back!
author: Thomas O.

description:
Hands down one of the best restaurants in SF.  Bring some friends or a hot date, either way you can't go wrong.  It's seriously the whole package--venue, service, and of course food.  Just about everything I've had here is awesome.  

You'll start with a round of chips and three fantastic dips.  Seriously, these are free??  They're sooo good!  While this alone works as a great appetizer, you'll definitely want to try the cebiche.  If you've never had it or don't know which to get, just get the sampler.  It won't let you down and you'll find both the taste and presentation flawless.  For drinks you can't go wrong with the pisco sour or sangria.  Sadly they don't do pitchers of sangria, so glass is all you get.

For a main course I'd recommend either the empanadas or my favorite, the Arroz Norteño.  A-freakin-mazing.  Fresh seafood, big portion, and sinfully delicious.

The venue itself is really nice--incredibly spacious and well designed.  If you're lucky enough to find yourself there on a warm summer day, definitely try and get a seat outside by the waterfront.  It'll only enhance an already wonderful experience.

Man, why did I move from the Bay Area again??
author: Eric O.

description: I would give LA Mar 5 stars. I went there couple times for lunch and happy hour. Absolutely love their fusion food presentation, as well as the taste. The ambiance and service quality are awesome as well!
author: Shell J.

description: After the amazing experiences i've had at la mar, I am shocked at how terrible my visit was today. Let's forget the awful "white party" that was going on on the deck where I'd hoped to sit, and the terrible dance music that was blasting into the restaurant every time the door opened. No, the issue was the manager's bizarre indifference to customer service: I gave him a chance to smooth over the party leaking into the restaurant (of which we were given no advance notification), but he just shrugged. I also gave him feedback on the way we were "welcomed" at the reservation desk, and that it too did not measure up to my previous experiences - he told me "she did her job." When I then said it didn't seem like we'd be able to enjoy our meal and we were going to go somewhere else, he again shrugged and let us leave without making any effort to rectify the situation. Restaurateurs always complain that people leave negative yelp reviews without giving them feedback at the time, but most of the time it's futile like this, with even managers getting defensive about their own poor execution and behavior.
author: Gabriel D.

description:
I came here with a large party for work and got to sit out on the patio to enjoy the unusual perfect sunny SF weather.  Our party of nine had to choose our menu ahead of time so we could be seated and ready to eat family-style.  I don't mind eating raw fish and I'm not picky about anything, but it's hard to find a good place that everyone will enjoy.

First thing I noticed was how large the restaurant is.  The bar area at the entrance is really comfy and chic looking.  The second thing I noticed was the gigantic octopus in the window near the bar.  I didn't really think twice about it until I saw my coworker's horrified face.  I'm pretty sure they were all turned off right there.

We ordered the cebiche clasico and a lot of my coworkers had never eaten cebiche let alone anything raw but vegetables.  I swear I had that whole dish to myself and I thought it was excellent.  Not the best halibut I've had but the flavor was just right -  a tad of spice and the large peruvian corn.  Luckily, their salad was something everyone enjoyed.  We had the ensalada limena and boy I can still taste that one.  Perfect amount of sweetness to the salad, not too tart.  Probably a favorite for all of us.

Our main dishes included risotto de calabaza, arroz norteno, and the lomo saltado.  Unfortunately for me, risotto and I sort of hate each other so I took the words of all my coworkers who ate it.  Sold.  They all loved it.   I can handle the raw, but can't handle the butta.  Anyway, I ended up eating the arroz norteno (again, my coworkers freaked out.  Lo and behold - the octopus shows up all over the rice).  I quietly swallowed all the octopus just so they wouldn't have to look at it.  Finally, the lomo saltado - a highlight, especially because it was the only dish with meat.  Unfortunately, I swear each plate had about 3 pieces of tenderloin buried under the french fries.  Definitely a delicious plate, but not enough meat for a large party.  Not everyone got to try it.  It was a great piece of meat though.

Finally, dessert.  Cappuccino de tres leches.  Ah.  All I can say is 5 stars.  One of the best desserts I had an actually the only thing our group unanimously picked when we pre-ordered.  The perfect little dessert in a shot glass, just enough to make you say mmmm before it's devoured.  Sponge cake was excellent and coffee creme brulee?  Who can say no to that?  It came out chilled but my chocolate was melted.  I was tempted to eat another one because we had one extra but I really had to hold back.

Overall, a great location, great food aside from the lack of meat.  At least it was something for everyone, even the ones afraid of seafood.  Service was good although on the slow side.  Definitely not a place to come if you are in a hurry.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Stacey C.

description:
I love how many photos fellow Yelpers have taken of La Mar's causas- I don't see any of the purple variety though, which is what I had the other weekend when I visited for the first time. They're made with actual purple potatoes so no food coloring is even used, but they're bright, fun, and delicious so I wouldn't really care otherwise anyway. I kept raving about them well after dinner because it was such a unique dish with such a sharp presentation.

La Mar is just exciting- the windows on the pier make it feel very light and fresh (which is how I feel about the food) and the colors really pop. We had the cebiche special from the chalboard and I literally licked every last bite off my plate from the fish I ordered. My parents each had a different variety of the risotto and of course we split a couple desserts.

Oh, and I earned my Yelp Global Domination badge when I checked-in here which was also cool. I can't wait to return.
author: Brianna H.

description:
I LOVE this place! We sat outside for lunch on a Saturday- beautiful weather. I had reservations but the place looked pretty empty for being right next to the Ferry Building the day of the Farmer's Market. Beautiful restaurant- loved the colors: Turquoise, Blues, Greens. The scenery was beautiful out on the back patio. Yummy sweet potato fries were served with three dipping sauces- complimentary. 

I ordered the ensalada tiradito. It was yummy- but kind of small. I recommend sharing it before having an entree. I'm not a big eater, but I left feeling a bit hungry. (Which ended up being fine- I had a nice big scoop of cinnimon caio bella gelato in the ferry building afterwards ;-) ) Had the peruvian punch: AMAZING! Also had a pisco sour.... it was small and definitely sour... kinda weird, but not bad. My boyfriend and dad ordered some kind of sandwich which looked really yummy. My stepmom ordered the vegetarian empanada sampler which she said was good. 

Would give it five stars... but my salad was a little small and the waiter told me it would be fine for an entree. Otherwise amazing!!!!!!
author: Lauren P.

description: nice venue, but doesn't really seem to have a 'peruvian vibe' about it.  the entrees were mediocre compared to authentic peruvian food.  they use larger steak fries for their lomo saltado and the sauce they cook it in could use a bit more sugar.  ceviches were pretty good, but not great.  I did, however, really enjoy the anticuochos.  Though I prefer chicken heart, the beef heart option is nearly as tasty.
author: Mason T.

description:
I've been here 3 times now. Once when they first opened, last year for New Year's Eve, and this past weekend (9/2/11). The first time, I wasn't very impressed with anything but decided to give it another chance and I'm glad I did. Our dinner on NYE was fantastic as was this past dinner. 

The most recent dinner I had at La Mar began with my group asking to be moved inside, as the ambiance is a little better at night inside versus the big plastic covering they have when it's windy outside, in my opinion. They gladly and promptly found us a great alternative table. 

We ordered some aperitifs and our food all together. The server was super friendly and helpful and he also told us what sort of order he had in mind for our different courses. I couldn't agree with his suggestions more. Although excellent in theory, the dishes did not come out in any such order. We didn't even get our before dinner drinks before the food :( 

We ordered so much food that I won't get into the details of what came out when instead of when it was supposed to come out, but let's just say it was VERY backwards. However, the annoyance of the chaotic order dissipated with each delicious bite. 

We ordered: 

Ceviche Sampler 
Causa Limena 
Empanada 
Ensalada Limena 
Lomo Saltado 
Blackened Sea Bass (one of the specials) 
Picarones 
Tapioca de Maracuya 

Everything was absolutely fantastic! It's hard to pick my favorites because everything was SO good, but I would have to say the causa limena, the beef empanada, the lomo saltado, and the tapioca de maracuya were at the top of my list.

All in all, great food & drinks, lovely ambiance, and friendly service. I would say the kitchen needs to improve their communication, along with the bar. Timing is such a distinguishing factor between a good meal and a great meal.
author: E G.

description: Stopped in because it was packed when walked by.  The food was incredible.  I am not a fish eater but I tried  the ceviche since the waiter recommended it to my friend.  To my surprise, I enjoyed it.  I had the shorts ribs which were awesome.  Highly recommend this place
author: Chris P.

description: I've been here for lunch a couple times but came for dinner for the first time last night with my husband.  Other than the host not ever making eye contact with us, the experience was very good.  The seafood was fresh, and the flavors were crisp.  We had the cebiche classico, the causa with crab, the salad andina, and the octopus kebabs.  They were all tasty, and the octopus was succulent and tender.  Our server at the bar area also made up in spades for the host.
author: B. Y.

description: excellent food , the service was a bit slow but overall was an amazing experience the best pisco sower i ever tried , my family and I was celebrating my daughter graduation and we enjoyed the experience we were happy with the food , the location is also very nice !!!!i recommended !!!
author: Kenya R.

description: Came here with 2 girlfriends. We shared 3 dishes. Everything was fantastic! Fish very fresh. Sauces are amazingly flavorful. Service is great. Place is clean. Check it out!
author: Caryn W.

description:
Great  Ceviche and their pisco sour is pretty amazing.
We enjoy taking people who never heard of peruvian food and offer them some ceviche and Pisco sours, or their cuzquena beer, yum.
Their patio is amazing, a great location to entertain guests. Worth the xtra $$$$ for the fun.
author: Raffi A.

description:
it was good until I found out one of my my entire orders was missing from my take out box. We came here for a family celebration with 9 people last night. Tried many things on the menu. In general the food and drinks are very creative and beautiful to look at. My uncle who has traveled the world was thoroughly impressed by the originality and presentation. 

My husband and I had something very similar at this place called Osaka in Buenos Aires, which is a very happening place filled with celebrities. They are also opening one in LA. Comparing the food, Osaka definitely has some high notes and low ones. The dishes in La Mar are all consistently good, but not as good as some of my favorites at Osaka. so I would give 4 to the food.

On to the service. We had 9 people, seated by the terrace in the back. The setting was great with heat lamps above us and also very private. My mother in law and grandmother asked for hot water, which made the bus boy confused and brought out way too many hot water cups and took away some water glasses that other people wanted. It was just very confusing overall for a long time. Since the portion were small, we asked for suggestions on how much to order. We ended up with way too much food and we actually didn't order as much as the waiter suggested. At the end, they charged us for my grandmother's birthday sorbet thing, which we thought would be on the house like most restaurants do. especially we made reservation and they knew it was for her birthday. 

the last disappointment was an entire order of chicken skewer was missing from our take out box. the food was good, so I was looking forward to the take out box for lunch today. it's just rather disappointing to me that our food is not there. It was the same bus boy that messed up the water cup/glass that packed up the food. so he definitely needs some more training. I've worked at a restaurant while in school, so I'm usually pretty forgiving. However I have to deduct a star for the restaurant because of the service. They just need more training, please fix it.
author: Cicie W.

description: Go for their Happy Hour. Drink specials are really good and the food menu has some great choices as well. The dinner could have been better. I knew everything would be overpriced due to location but it just wasn't worth it. Service was good. My stars are for the Happy Hour and complimentary chips they give you.
author: Bella C.

description:
Loved the food, but not that great of service.. I don't recommend coming here with little ones, as I did... 
Food: 
For starters we had the ceviche platter which was DELICIOUS! then we had the Lomo Saltado empanada which was really good, chicken skewers and finished off with the Arroz Norteno. Our dinner was a party in our mouths! We loved the food. 
Service: 
Although our waiter was really nice, the hostess were rude! We had a 6:30 reservation for two and a highchair, they sat us down 20 minutes late. Then it took them another 20 min to get us a highchair and they sat us at a two person table when clearly we were three.. I just hate bad service. 

I hope to go again someday without my daughter.. Hopefully we're treated better. :)
author: Laura M.

description:
I would give La Mar 5 stars, except their host and hostesses are so rude that you almost want to leave before you have been sat.  I've never seen 3 people running the wheel at a restaurant (I was a server, host and busboy for a combined 5 years) do such a horrible job at doing what is traditionally a 1-person job.  Mainly, it's their attitude.  It's like they're doing you a favor by allowing you to spend money in the restaurant.

The food, servers and chefs get 5 stars all day!  Unfortunately, the front end staff gets one star and I'd fire them if I had the power to do so and hire some people who understand the service industry better.  Smiling while being an a-hole to someone still means you're being an a-hole.

I will still keep going back because of the food, but I have to bite my tongue with them every time...which may be why La Mar doesn't seem to care much about how rude they are.
author: Rocky D.

description:
Don't go here. Don't go here if you hope to receive a warm welcome with a smile from the host. Don't go here if you hope to be seated when you arrive 10 mins before your reservation. Don't go here if you hope the menu might be explained when you're dropped at the table by the host. Don't go here if you expect a server to arrive at your table within the first 10 mins of you being seated. And certainly don't go here if, when you try to offer feedback to the general manager, you expect him to listen, not talk over you and to apologize and tell you it was an unusual and a one off lapse that you experienced. This place was recommended by a friend so I over looked the poor ratings about service already on yelp and I overlooked the variable ratings on food quality. I wish I hadn't. The DMV and IRS provide exemplary service compared to this general manager and his hosts. Instead of listening to our issue, the Zoolander General Manager placed one hand on his hip and said "I don't have to listen to this. The server did her job and explained the menu when she got here. You'll have to go somewhere else." He then took the menus from us and walked away. I am not joking or exaggerating. This is exactly what happened! 

Zoolander actually did us a favor. We did go somewhere else. Somewhere else way superior and spent our $376 at the fantastic Slanted Door. The hosts greeted us with a smile and "Hi, do you have a reservation with us?" When we said we didn't "no problem, let's see what we can do for you here" and then proceeded to seat us at the last remaining table in the whole place. We were immediately attended to by a server and had great, attentive service the whole night. Slanted Door is a phenomenal place! 

Choose La Mar only if it's the last restaurant in the entire city, if you don't care about service and if you think you're lucky to get in the place as this is exactly how they will treat you. My advice - Just don't go here until Zoolander, 'General Manager' Gabriele Originario has learned something about hospitality and service. From our experience, he knows nothing about it today.
author: Lee R.

description:
We took a chance with dine about town here. Not a great idea.  While everything was well prepared, the portion sizes were more appropriate for a tasting menu. That  would have been fine if there had been a few more courses, but unfortunately that wasn't the case. The bill for the four of us ( with a $46 bottle of white) came to $240. 
In the future, I wish they advertised it as a mini tasting menu. That way, people won't feel disappointed.
author: Marc w.

description:
This restaurant SHATTERS the widely-accepted EUROCENTRIC notion that a 5-star restaurant can only  be French or Italian.  If you don't believe me, look at the proportional representation of cuisines in the food section of any good bookstore, or count how many $$$$ restaurants are Chinese, Mexican or Indian in the Zagat's Guide.  Sorry, NYT's food critic - you got your review of this restaurant dead WRONG.  

We just got back from Peru two weeks ago, where we tried one of Gaston Acurio's other restaurants.We had dinner at LaMar last night and were not disappointed.  

LaMar is located in a beautiful setting with a promenade leading to the seating area, gorgeous succulents, and great food. I ordered gluten-free and didn't feel deprived at all.   We topped off the meal with Lucuma Panna Cotta  which had a wonderful contrasting degrees of sweetness & textures.  (Lucuma is a fruit from the rainforest known as the "Inca's last gold").  

Afterward, the young , charming, Japanese-Peruvian executive chef, Diego Oka, came out to chat with us about the food. Then we took the cable car home for the perfect San Francisco date.

Peruvian food is a world class cuisine in it's own right - with amazing new flavors, textures, and combinations with novel ingredients. Peruvian cuisine has at least two advantages:

1)   A lush, fertile environment where 28 of the world's 32 microclimates are represented leading to a tremendous BIODIVERSITY of edible plants and seafood available year around.  There are a wide range of peppers, potatoes, maize, fruits and shellfish (not commonly known in the US) from the Andes to the the rainforest to the coast where the cold Humboldt current meets the warm waters of El Nino. LaMar ships many of the special ingredients directly from Peru as they're not available here.

2) The innovative fusion of traditional Andean cuisine with the food of later  immigrants -  Spanish, Italian, Japanese, Chinese, etc.  - led to classic Peruvian dishes like ceviche (heavy Japanese influence) or lomo saltado (beef & red pepper stir fry with a Peruvian twist).

Eat here and decide for yourself.
author: Raine L.

description:
Tried La Mar after constantly hearing the name on 'top 5' San Francisco lists from foodie friends.  Everything we had was quite tasty and there are a lot of choices on the menu.

There were four of us and we started with two cebiches and one causa dish.  The cebiche carretillero (shrimp, octopus, calamari, mussels etc) and the cebiche nikei (predominantly ahi tuna with cucumber and avocado) were both light, fresh and quite nice!  We tried the causa tasting at the server's recommendation to try a few different tastes and this dish was a lot of fun.

We each then had our own entree - I tried the arroz jugoso which reminded me of seafood paella.  

In the end, I felt like everything I tried was delicious - there were so many things on the menu that looked great so I'll have to go back to try more.

Reason I wouldn't give 5 stars is the restaurant is quite large and can get hectic...we would lose our server sometimes and try to have another server get a message to him.  It didn't work out too efficiently.
author: Janelle C.

description:
To celebrate my nephews' birthdays, I asked one of them that was home from the Navy where he wanted to go.  He said he wanted to try something different.  I kept in mind the fact that he has recently acquired particular tastes over the last few years when it comes to food.  I figured we'd try something that even I haven't had yet, so I told him let's try Peruvian.  I turned to my first resource (Yelp! of course) and the reviews on here convinced me to make a reservation.

Boy howdy, I am sure glad that we did.  The food here is fantastic!  Fresh, delectable, tasty...name just about any superlative and it pretty much applied.  Our waitress was very knowledgeable and was more than a willing guide to us.  Unfortunately, we did not have dessert (it wasn't that we were super stuffed, however we were satisfied) because we all agreed to grab a couple of scoops at Humphry Slocomb, but the descriptions for their desserts did look quite good.  

I will definitely be coming back.
author: Ree-och G.

description: I did not think the food was worth the price and the service was pretty bad. You can say you basically pay for the presentation of the food. I did not find anything amaze; however, I did like their complementary chips and dip. I will go there for chit chat with my friends and reunion with family member or happy hours.
author: Vivian S.

description:
Having been to La Mar three previous times, I will say that I was disappointed in my most recent experience with regards to the food. 

We had a group of 11, and as such had to do  a $65/person menu instead of ordering off the menu. I ended up being very disappointed in the quality, variety, and flavor of the food, not to mention how the different items were timed with one another. 

Our entradas were all very good, and were on par with my previous experiences at La Mar. However, I was disappointed with both the main courses and the dessert. I was surprised that the Jelea was considered a main dish (from the description, it was not was I was expecting). It was overly fried, dry, and the tarter sauce, which was good, was barely enough to go with half of the plate. We had nearly two full plates left (out of three plates) of the Jelea at the end of our meal. Also, seemed very bizarre to me to deep fry clams and mussels (with their shells). 

The sides also were also oddly timed with the meals. The ensalda limena (which came out with our mains) was no more then a simple mixed green salad, 2 cherry tomatoes, and some crumbled cheese. From the description, I was expecting something more. While the quinoa salad (which was very good) came out at the same time as the causas - which was odd given it was two items with quite a bit of potato (flipping when each of those were served would have made a lot more sense to me). 

Lastly, the dessert was remarkably under whelming, and more honestly, was barely touched by the group. I've never had dessert at La Mar, so I don't have anything to compare it to.

While I realize much of this was on me for not choosing the options well for the group, for a $65 menu, I would expect that all of the options would be on par with one another. 

I rarely complain, however bringing together  a group of international guests for this dinner, I was rather embarrassed by the quality/diversity of the food relative to the cost. 

Having previously placed La Mar high on my list of where I take guests to when visiting San Francisco, I unfortunately don't expect to be back to La Mar in the future.
author: B M.

description: -minus 1 star cuz our waiter forgot to give us the commentary chips. Everyone else got them around us.
author: J. C.

description:
Really good & completely affordable...for the 'To-Go" options.

A little over $20 for 2 lunches to-go

My friend got the tuna salad & liked it.

I got the tuna sandwich w/ side salad & alfajor cookie. The tuna was cooked perfectly - seared on the outside & medium raw inside. The ACME bread wasn't toasted (I thought it was on the menu) but very fresh & the dressing/condiments/tomato, etc highlighted the taste of the tuna. Everything was well portioned. The side salad had shaved jicama & carrots with a very light vinagrette. The alfajor cookie is worth every calorie. Shortbread cookie with caramel oozing out the middle. A perfect combo & since it's small, it's a good ending to a delicious lunch!
author: Marissa H.

description:
I selected this place for an important birthday celebration. I wanted Peruvian food and the fantastic flavours that were in my mind since I visted to La Mar in Santiago, Chile. This San Francisco's branch of La Mar didn't let me down. 

We began with Pisco Sour (por supuesto!) and cheered to the taste of that heartwarming drink. Also ordered a Cebiche Mixto and Empanadas de Lomo Saltado as starters... the cebiche was fine, maybe a bit short on spices, but the empanadas were superb. The intense aroma of lomo saltado's sauce filling a very soft fried dough that perfectly paired with the tartness of the cebiche. Excellent way to begin. We were hungry so we accompanied the started with a complimentary basket of plantain and potato chips and a couple of sauces. By the time the entrees arrived we were kinda full, but that didn't stop us from enjoying almost all the delicious Salmon Fusion with coconut milk, shrimps and the mouthwatering taste of soy and oyster sauces, and the mix of seafood and sirloin in its lomo saltado sauce with a sort of risotto with beans on the bottom. Both dishes were succulent and large for having them after starters, but this was a special occasion so we enjoyed, and deal with it! To finish we only ordered espresso, however the server also brought complimentary small shots of arroz con leche. So nice and delicate detail!

Overall, this restaurant worth the visit. Although a bit pricy, you get a good experience at dinner. There is a lot of space, nice decoration, high ceilings, an open kitchen (with view to the occasional flames from the stove!), and separate rooms for bar and dinning. The products are fresh and the dishes are an excellent version of modern Peruvian cuisine. Completely recommended!
author: Florencia G.

description: "Omg it was so good- margarita, pisco, bottle if wine, we got ceviche sampler, special ceviche and seafood entree as well as two amazing desserts... I think food wise la mar can't be beat, our waiter was very helpful and funny :)"
author: Julie R.

description: Made reservations, sat down, and the waitress forgot about us for over 20 minutes. We were so forgettable, another couple sat down next to us 15 minutes later and were serviced immediately. Instead of being treated like 1970s wallpaper, we decided to go to the Watertower. Excellent service and amazing food. We were actually treated like human beings there, which is a really awesome thing.
author: James H.

description:
I love how La Mar moved in and retained some of the character of this pier-house for their Peruvian seafood paradise.  

AMBIANCE
It's an 'upscale' Peruvian chow house.  The abundance of whitewashed surfaces give it a seaside feel, including the bathrooms.  They've also got a nice deck that overlooks the Bay which I'd imagine would be pleasant on a sun-filled afternoon.

FOOD
Art on a plate.  The Cebiche Tasting had a quartet of colorful combinations ~ delicious.  

As for my main course, I wasn't ravenous so I had the Causa, which is a 'Traditional Peruvian Whipped Potato With " Ají Amarillo " And Seafood Or Vegetarian " Salad "'.  Specifically I had the *Causa Criolla*  which is "sautéed mahi mahi, limeñan escabeche with quail egg, avocado puree, ají amarillo huancaína sauce and crispy parsley".  The presentation was eye candy.  I didn't realize that his would be a cold dish...the flavors were tasty, but not quite for my palate.  

The highlights of my meal were the fried yum basket, filled with a medley of hand cut, fresh fried potatoes and plantains, served with a trio of bright sauces.  We ended up ordering multiple baskets since it was sooo good!

The 'Buñuelos De Chocolate Caliente warm chocolate beignet glazed with passion fruit reduction, bananas and passion fruit' was also dreamily memorable.

COCKTAIL
My favorite, the Pisco Sour - try it.  *I'd definitely go back for the fried basket of chips+plantains + a Pisco Sour.*

NOISE LEVEL
Pretty loud since it's a pretty cavernous place, but ambiance is still modernly hip + charming.

SERVICE
Wonderful!
author: Cathy K.

description: Maybe a tad bit stuffy, but the food was delicious. Peruvian cebiche is definitely worth a try. It's beauty is in its (seeming) simplicity, but make no mistake, if you're not starting with the freshest ingredients, it's a disaster. The flavors are crisp, clean, and complement one another perfectly.
author: Andrew M.

description:
HAPPY HOUR:

Fried chicken wings: Boneless and oh so amazing 5/5

Fried rice: Eh, so-so 2/5

Ceviches: Tangy and perfect for a warm day 4/5

Tuna slider: YUM. But it's hard to share. Maybe you can ask them to cut it before they bring it to the table 5/5

Beef slider: Not as amazing as the tuna one--kind of ordinary because the sauce was overwhelming everything else 3/5

Pisco sour: Alcohol content seemed good, but the taste wasn't very pleasant 2/5


Overall, it was a pretty good experience because each item was relatively tasty if not delicious. Prices weren't bad either!
author: mimi k.

description:
Fabulous waterfront dining!  I guess this place is no secret (from the 1200+ reviews) - but this was our first time and it definitely will not be the last.

I loved the wide open space overlooking the bay and yachts.  The service was friendly, our waitress provided good suggestions for cocktails and wine to complement our meal.  My hubby and I decided to order mutlple dishes to share (instead of an entree each, which would've left little room for much else in our stomachs!).  

* Cebiche mixto $11 for the half size - Delicious yellowtail, calamari, shrimp, red onion, Peruvian corn.  My only complaint is that it's a little pricey for such a small dish - we probably had 3 small bites each.

* Empanadas de k'apchi $11 - Flavorful shitaake and oyster mushrooms in a flaky crust.  I was hesitant to order a non-meat empanada but this was delic!

* Carne anticuchos $16 - A metal skewer of grilled skirt steak on a bed of Peruvian corn and fried potato.  The meat was a little disappointing, tougher and blander than hoped.  

* Arroz jugoso $26 - My favorite of the evening!  A delicious bed of arborio rice with shrimp, clams, mussels, calamari, and fish with a surprising tangy spice.  Loved it!

Oh, and can't forget about the FREE chips with 3 dips to start the meal as you wait for your food to be prepared.  I'm a sucker for plantain chips and these were especially good!  The sweet potato and regular chips were also, but they're horrible for my low-salt hypertension diet!

$100 pre-tip for the two of us = a fabulous meal in SF!
author: Heather s.

description: The food is amazing and the service is great. We arrived very early for our dinner reservation on a Saturday evening and were seated right away. Drink orders were a little slow but not too bad - the piscos are worth the wait. Definitely try sitting out on the patio because the view is pretty stellar. So many variations of cebiche and the lomo saltado is a must. A bit on the pricy side but will absolutely return!
author: Rusty S.

description:
The food is quite good, but the amosphere is very lacking. Don't go on a busy night (but do go!) because you'll leave with your ears ringing. No sound absorbency in the construction AT ALL.

I highly recommend the causas and the scallop dish, both were delectable.
author: Kali M.

description: La Mar is one of my favorite restaurants in SF!  I love Peruvian food and La Mar never disappoints.  I honestly haven't had a dish that I did not like.  They also have an awesome happy hour, 3-6 PM.  It gets a bit crowded and it's difficult to find a seat after 5 PM.
author: Deanna H.

description: This was our first time trying Peruvian food and it was good.. I got the cebiche of the day and my wife got the fish skewers. Both were delicious. Would definitely recommend the fish skewers, the sauces that came along were finger licking good. The restaurant is huge and the ambiance is great. Our server was polite and courteous, however conspicuous most of the evening. Nice celebratory dinner.
author: Pushyak K.

description:
I love this place: the atmosphere, the food and the Pisco Sours! The cebiche choices are fantastic .. it's a great choice for visitors as well (since you get great views with great food -- and can hang out at the Ferry Building as well).

Love it
author: Diane Dwyer D.

description: I still remember when La Mar opened up a few years ago .... The ceviche then was superb, in general the food at that time tasted so good that surpasses even authentic Peruvian food mainly due to the high quality of ingredients they used. E.g., magi mahi to make ceviche. During those first months La Mar employed sophisticated waitress and waiters that were Peruvian and took pride in explaining the guests the sophisticated ingredients involved in the preparation of Peruvian dishes. Regrettably Now I feel compelled to warn people to not go to this place expecting good Peruvian food anymore. Nowadays La Mar is not a good a place to eat good Peruvian food. The menu has been turned into some weird ethnic concoction that is not palatable e.g., Empanadas with "guacamole !!!!"  The pisco sour has hardly any pisco flavor because they put so much ice in it. It tastes like water with a gooey foam on top. The ceviche mixto has an orange color that is not discernible ! No, The food does not taste good. The portions are ridiculously small. The waiters are from different ethnicities and are not familiar with the ingredients or have even tasted the menu for what they say. I had to spell cancha and even explain what it was. I wonder if Gaston Acurio knows how bad things have become in this place. Today I felt  embarrassed to have insisted that some friends go and visit La Mar as a way to introduce them to what I thought was going to be a wonderful culinary experience . I give this place a 1 star only because of its location and ocean view. But ... Please by no means go to La Mar expecting to taste authentic  delicious Peruvian food. I hope they do something about it. It use to be a wonderful restaurant. Moreover, I visited La Mar last March for my birthday and I was so disappointed.  the food and also the drinks were terrible then , but I excused all thinking that it had to be an isolated incident . Today I have confirmed that this restaurant has lost all the stars they received in its beginnings for the quality of the food and service. C'mon ..... please do something about it. Peruvian food is delicious .... Serve it right .
author: Liz K.

description:
We were 3 and decided to give this place a try.  

Place was good but not a must have.

The cebiche, causa, empanada samplers are perfect for 1st timers to share.

Don't order the beef heart on a skewer (it's too tough for me)

the peruvian rice with seafood was good.  Good amount of seafood.
author: David L.

description: The food and servers are great. The front door staff is always a bit snooty. I cannot figure it out.
author: Brian H.

description:
Quite good if you're in the mood for cebiche.   The cebiche sampler was excellent.  The empanada sampler was ok ... the pastry was flaky, tasty, and not too greasy.   In fact, some of the best empanada pastry I've had.  However, most of the fillings were just ok; nothing special.    

Loved the selection of pisco cocktails; my favorites are the Santa Maria and the Scarlet.   

The setting is tres San Francisco; take your visiting relatives here and listen to them ooh and aah about the setting and the exotic food.  Check out the historic photos in the restroom!
author: Sarah G.

description: Fresh, innovative, colorful and delicious cuisine defines La Mar restaurant. We've had the occasion to bring out-of-town guests to La Mar on multiple occasions and it was always a delight. The chips and salsa are very good and addictive, the tiraditos are also highly recommended.
author: po j.

description: Delicious! Sometimes people are confused by the Asian bent of the food at this place, but you should know it's authentic. There is a very large Asian population in Peru. Also, the chef runs a great place in Lima called Astrid y Gaston, if you ever get down there. I know their appetizers are great, but I always skip them because I order the seafood fried rice-ish dish (varies by name, but there is always something of this type on the menu) and I can't stop myself from cleaning my plate. Slightly dressy. Also, they make real pisco sours, and they're awesome. If it's warm enough, sit outside on the back deck and enjoy the breeze off the water.
author: Caitlin C.

description: Beautifully prepared Peruvian dishes on the water. Can't beat the flagship restaurant but a nice addition to the SF foodie scene. Pisco Sour, the national drink, is not to be missed. Wish they served their national dessert at this location. The menu is a bit lighter, more California cuisine styled than his other locations (it's 3 stars in comparison) but 4 stars considering the SF scene. The lomo saltado is a good way to start if you've never had Peruvian food.
author: Emma G.

description: The food was quite good - not quite stellar. But THE PRICES omg! two couples: one cocktail and one glass of wine each. Two shared appetizers and one entree , no dessert or coffee= $155.00 per couple not including tip. I should have been prepared for this when I saw the $12.00+ cocktail menu and the wine list with every bottle over $45.00.If you can afford it then go for it. Oh and BTW our waiter advised that we better hurry up and order because "its gonna get real busy soon and the wait will be longer" this was a Wednesday night.
author: Richard P.

description: I liked it.  The food was decent.  A little expensive to go for regular lunch.  But overall, I had a good experience.  The server was sweet and attentive.  That's all I ask for.  Decent food and good manners.
author: Aban E.

description:
After the great Elite event at Alexander's, we met up here for a friend's birthday and had even more food and drinks. 

I didn't get to savor the food as much with a full stomach, but it's probably the best Peruvian food in SF. I've been to Peru, and the chef here offers more than just the typical ceviches and lomo saltado.

My favorite dish was the causa limena, which featured seafood atop a medium soft cooked potato. I loved the texture and flavor of this dish.

The varieties of ceviche were quite nice as well. Their lomo saltado was probably the best I've had, although I'm not a fan of this dish.

Pisco cocktails are creative and tasty, and don't forget about Cusquena beer, from Cusco!

Be prepared to pay though, this place is not cheap.
author: Derrick V.

description:
For ~$30/person, there are much better Peruvian places in SF - e.g. Limon Rotisserie.  The food here was very bland.  That said, the decor is great - a beautiful blue color scheme, a lounge vibe.  The service is also very good, our server explained all the dipping sauces and dishes, and recommended the delicious Peruvian drink (chicha).  

You get yuca, plantain, and squash/pumpkin chips, which come with 3 delicious dipping sauces.  

The only things we enjoyed (aside from the chips) were the empanadas k'apchi - empanadas stuffed with mushrooms, and the non-alcoholic chicha morada (nonalcoholic beverage of purple corn spiced with cloves).  I highly recommend the chicha morada drink!  $5 for a truly exotic taste.

Don't get the causa saltatido (purple potato mash topped with shrimp) - it's very bland.  We didn't finish the dish.  The carne here is also bland.

All in all - save your $, this place is overrated and packed at prime dinner hours (we sat at the bar).  Or just come here for the chicha drink.
author: Bee M.

description: We were very disappointed with the service at La Mar which used to be one of our favorites. Everything was slow and we had to ask for everything more than once. They didn't bring the chips and dips until we were eating our main course. Two of us got served and the others had to wait until we were nearly done just to get their entree. My daughter's meal seemed like it had been sitting out under the lamps for awhile and my tuna tartare looked like it had been sitting out also.   My son's dessert was forgotten and came much later. All of this made the dinner much longer than it should have been. Sadly I won't be returning
author: Susana A.

description:
the food here is surprisingly good! we thought it would  be a scammy touristy restaurant with a view but it definitely was not. we got lucky and got a seat at the bar as a walk-in. 

we ordered:
tuna ceviches- really good but would prob have preferred one of the other mixed seafood ceviches. we ordered the weekly special that had the scallops, octopus, etc so we got the tuna instead. 

weekly special mixed seafood plate was really good

grill octopus skewer: 4 out of 5 stars. my boyfriend loved it (5 out of 5). i LOVED the texture. it was grilled to perfection but I did not like the sauce. it tasted like bbq sauce which i think should only go on foods like ribs. however, i would still highly recommend this dish. 

service was a bit slow- good thing we weren't in a rush. 

loved la mar and would definitely come back!
author: Janet Y.

description:
My fiancé, friend and I went there for lunch on a Saturday.  My fiancé is from Peru, so we thought to try La Mar since it's a famous Peruvian restaurant in the city.  We have tried plenty of other Peruvian restaurants in the city, such as Mi Lindo Peru, Limon, etc. We also heard La Mar is overpriced and not as authentic; hence haven't tried until now, but we thought to give it a try.

We got to the restaurant, the ambience was great, located at the Pier, nicely decorated and overseeing the bay.  First, we realized some of the special are not available during the weekend; we were sad, but realized it could be our timing.  My fiancé works for Oracle and get an Oracle rewards card, which gives some incentives for different venues.  We looked online and saw that it gives a second entrée for free after ordering the first entrée at La Mar.  When we ordered, we asked the waitress, since we are ordering three entrees, does that mean we get the second entrée for free OR if we order a forth entrée, we also get that for free?  Without hesitation, she replied, "I think you get the forth entrée for free as well".  So, we thought it would be a great opportunity for us to explore more entrées and ordered the forth entrée.  

The food was okay.  It was a fusion between Peruvian, Asian and American -- nothing special.  I've definitely had much better else where in the city.  But to our surprise, when the bill came, we were charged for the forth entrée. We called the waitress over and explained our confusion.  Only to get the explanation, "oh, I guess I was wrong".  She didn't apologize at all for her mistake and told us we could speak to the manager if we wanted. So, we thought it could be a mistake, so we decided to speak to the manager.  The manager came over, stood over us with an intimating stance and asked us, "is this the first time you used your Oracle card?"  I was flabbergasted at how we were treated!  Not only did we not touched the forth dish, we ordered it under the assumption that it was complementary!  At this point, it was not about the money, it was about the principle that the waitress was the one who just flat out told us it was going to be complementary!  After a not so pleasant conversation with the buffoon of a manager about the situation, without a word, he simply took our forth entrée away and then took it off the bill.  

The service was horrible!  We were treated as if we were the ones lying.  At no point did they apologize for misleading us.  They didn't care if we enjoyed the experience and the manager was clearly trying to just make us pay for something we didn't intend to order.  

There's much better Peruvian restaurants in the city.  There are also many other restaurants with much better views and service.  I would NOT recommend going to La Mar!  It's simply overrated.
author: Carrie L.

description:
I came here last thursday with a friend for a drink and we ended up having drinks and delicious food! My first drink was amazing: passion secreta, while the second (el chalan) was really not my cup of tea and far too bitter!

We ordered the ceviche tasting which was absolutely delicious and a causas sampler (also yummy!)

Overall good drinks, great food, and I'm a fan and will definitely be back!
author: Maria G.

description:
My overall impression was: "Everything is pretty, but nothing is exciting."  

This is, perhaps, inherent to Peruvian food.  I sampled the ceviches, causas (this is something new and unusual -- see the pictures to get an idea), empanadas, and lomo saltado, and I feel I got a decent chance at a variety of foods here.  The only surprising thing was the very tender lomo saltado (grilled beef with fried potatoes on top) -- mostly surprising because most other places use lesser quality cuts.

Prices are also a bit high for what it is.  If you want to have a unique experience, I wouldn't dissuade you, but it's not a regular place.  Oh, and the pisco sour is really good.
author: Daniel S.

description:
we came to la mar on a friday night with a group reservation.  when you have a larger group they tend to put you in the lounge section and require a set menu.  the set menu did make everyone pretty full so there was no lack of food.  they didnt sell pitchers of sangria ... only cups at a time!  the pisco sour was strong but good

the chips are delicious as people have said.  i liked the sweet potato ones the best.  to start we had the spinach salad with corn and hearts of palm.  the cebiche was good.  for mains we had lomo saltado and also the seafood rice.  both were good.  also a quinoa side dish.  to finish we had a rice pudding and also a caramel thing.

i wouldnt mind coming back to try other things on the menu.

we came back for happy hour but HH here ends at 6.  5 of us came in and only got one round plus two dishes and the bill was over $100.  pretty expensive for HH i guess.
author: claudia y.

description: I came here with some girlfriends for the cerviche. It was good but I had better. It was listed on the 7 by 7 list and I have to say I am starting to doubt the palates of the editors of the magazines. The ceviche was fresh and flavorful but I wouldn't sing about it. If you could sit outside, the view is amazing. The inside is pretty as well. The plantain chips and the dips that it came with was yummy and we got multiple refills. The beef skewer was tender. The empanadas were a favorite of the table except the seafood one. The crust was flaky but not greasy. It was the right amount of crust to filling. The meal was good but I am not sure if I would come back. There are other places in the city with pretty views.
author: Eve C.

description:
So my girlfriend and I heard this place had a great happy hour.  Good food and drinks at reasonable prices.  The prices were reasonable for food and drinks, true.  But all things considered, it really wasn't worth the visit.

Arriving at 4:45, it was already crowded, with very little seating left.  As the servers walked by us (clearly waiting for a seat) they made no effort to suggest seating (there were 2 seats in the back that we didn't see).  We were greeted quickly enough and our drinks/food order was taken.  After our order was taken, 3 other tables sat down and ordered and despite the fact that we ordered food 10 minutes before they did, all those tables got their food before us.  All in all we waited about 20-25 minutes for our food order, and then they brought out the wrong food to us.

Portions were small (I understand the pricing was low so it's probably on par for the amount of food you got), the hot food (fried calamari) was cold, the cold food (cebiche) was room temp and none of it was that flavorful.

The restaurant was beautiful and the drinks were good (the extra star) but I don't think I'll be going back there anytime soon.
author: Mike I.

description:
I had never tried Peruvian Food. I heard this restaurant is suppose to be owned by some famous Peruvian chef and what not so I decide to give a try. MISTAKE.

I went with my boyfriend and our bill came out to roughly 107 or 108. We order an appetizers that came with three mini potato formed structures filled with rotten tuna or chicken. Bleh.

ANd then we ordered to entrees. One had a tiny piece of fish with two salsas and some chopped up lettuce. And the other was some sort of beef stew. However everything here is served so small it should be like 5 or 6 dollars at max. WAY OVERPRICED!

The only reason I gave it a star is because one i can't give no stars, and then two because the waiters make their best efforts to offer good service. But honestly, don't go because its wasting your money. I felt so hungry after going here. It was like this food barley tickled my stomach.
author: Cecilia A.

description: Great place to go with friends or on a date. The food was great along with a wonderful view. My friends and I had wonderful dishes that we would try again. I would definitely come here again.
author: Sara A.

description:
Decor- beautifully decorated with blue and green hues and tropical plants
Food- only got the cebiche mixto which was mediocre at best
Service- crappy, we were ignored the whole time we were there

We were so fed up that we decided to get our check after the cebiche and headed over for a scrumptious dinner at Osha Thai!
author: Lucy K.

description:
Ordered the lomo saltado here which I attempted to try elsewhere but failed and the empanadas de lomo saltado . The beef was seasoned well and tender but tasted just ok. My date ordered a special that looked unappealing to me and the taste was similar. I also had a pisco sour, nothing mind blowing, a thick shot with foam. What I did like...love...was their chips and dips.

The environment is really nice overlooking the bay with bright colors against the hardwood. Out waiter was distracted by other tables even when it wasn't lunch rush and the host didn't seem very happy to be there.

My experience for a $100 meal for two wasn't as good as I had hoped and I won't be returning.
author: Cristine I.

description:
Always really fishy ceviche and taraditos.

My husband is Peruvian, so I've had some of the best Peruvian food both in Peru and in SF (Limon, Fina Estampa), but La Mar is just OK. I've eaten there about 4 times now. We go there for the atmosphere but the food is by no means that great.

Everytime I have ordered the ceviche - the fish was very fishy and tough. I had one of their specials made with Yellowtail and I could barely cut through the fish with my knife it was so tough. 

Their Lomo Saltado is pretty good. Always tender with excellant rice.

The Pulpo anticuchos is the best thing on the menu.

Empanadas - so-so

Desserts - not good at all. All too sweet and overdone.

The last reason why I gave La Mar 2 stars is because it is WAY overpriced. For 3 of us, we spend on average over $200. The drinks are also very very pricey!
author: Janelle R.

description: Good food.  Good atmosphere.  Good wait staff.  Terrible hostess with a can't gave a damn attitude.
author: Richard F.

description:
This is the best Peruvian restaurant in the Bay Area.  The menu covers all Peruvian favorites except indiginous meats.  We tried the ceviche sampler, all 4 were great.  Had a tuna steak for dinner, great sauce and very tasty.  All washed down with well made pisco sours.

The inside of the restaurant is loud and the outside dining is cold, consider yourself warned.
author: Shen J.

description:
Let me start by saying the rating was partly because of the restaurant, partly sentimental.

I first found out about La Mar on Trip Advisor while researching for Lima. It was 2 blocks away from the Mira Flores motel I was staying. I stopped by for dinner one night and it was closed, undeterred, I went back next day for lunch and it turned out to be one of the best meals in Peru. I remember sitting there thinking how this place would totally work back home: the casual yet contemporary decor plus the fresh and tasty fare.

Fast forward, there it was. I have visited a couple times in the last couple of years and  enjoyed it on both occasions. Another bonus, now that the menu is in English, I don't have to guess what I am eating. (I had the 5 ceviche samples in Lima because that was all I could manage in Spanish.)

The azure themed decor was the same but definitely more upscale. The service was very friendly and once the manager came to say hi to every table (this being early evening on a week night, the place was not filled).

I was more than happy to see the same chips and dips were served, because they were addictive!

The avocado and crab was fresh, light and delicious. The steak was nice medium rare as I liked, smothered with a flavourful sauce. The puprle potato, while tasting the same as the common variety to me, was a nice visual.

I don't normally drink but the cocktail menu looked enticing, if a bit gimicky. Of course there was the pisco sour and it tasted great.

It's definitely authentic Peruvian food, except not having cuy or alpaca on the menu.
author: Cindy B.

description:
Came here for dinner during the World Series. We were able to grab stools in the bar area for pre-dinner drinks. The bar was crowded and they had the game on. Bar service was friendly and quick. I tried the pisco sour (yum) but wanted to save room for dinner so skipped the appetizers. 

We headed to our table after our drinks and ordered:

-Hamachi cerviche 
-4 sampler of empanadas
- Lomo Saltado
-Special fish of the day

I loved that when we were seated they brought us a basket of a variety of plantain chips with the assorted dipping sauces. The hottest one was yum!!! The ceviche was fresh and delicious and the empanadas were a great appetizer to share. 

I liked the serving of lomo saltado, I've had much saltier versions elsewhere so this was much better in comparison. Love that it comes with  french fries. 

The service was great at the restaurant, our glasses constantly being refilled.
author: Julie F.

description:
Late night (not that late, 8:30) Saturday dinner.  Some menu items not available.  Other should not have been available (i.e., that sitting-around-too-long thing).  
Maybe it caters to tourists too much--but it had even been recommended by a Peruvian restauranteur in Florida who has a tiny strip mall location--but was 5 times more 'a taste of Peru'...  The complementary chips were the best part of the meal!
author: Bryna S.

description:
Delish! Came here for lunch on a Friday. Definitely enjoyed it. 

Had a seat on the deck, the weather was perfect and the view was great. 

Started off with a Pisco Sour which is their signature drink. It was good. Sour and tasty, almost as good as a margarita! 

They give complimentary chips as well, plantain chips (sliced really thin), sweet potato, and regular potato chips. Comes with three sauces: spicy, mustard, peanuts. Really liked the spicy. 

We ordered the Causa tasting, it had three kinds: 
- causa limeña: Dungeness Crab, avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomatoes on top of yellow potato with ají amarillo Huancaína sauce and basil cilantro oil
*This was refreshing and light. The quail egg isn't raw, it's just hard boiled and a little slice of it. The crab was super fresh so it was delish! 
- causa nikei: Tombo Tuna tartar and avocado purée on top of whipped purple potato with creamy rocoto Huancaína sauce topped with Japanese nori
*This was my favorite. It had a little kick to it. 
- causa casera: Artichokes, asparagus, avocado and tomato confit on top of yellow potato with basil cilantro oil
*This was ok. I'm not a fan of just a veggie item, I like some kind of meat so it was ok. 

For my entree, I ordered the cebiche tasting, it had four kids: (*Beware the habenero, it's good in small doses but don't pop it into your mouth*)

- cebiche clásico: California Halibut in a classic leche de tigre, red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam
*This one was ok. I didn't care too much for it because it was so simple. It was very clean tasting and refreshing. Maybe I should have started off with this one... 
- cebiche chalaco: Yellowtail, mussels, clams, shrimp, red onion, cilantro and cancha in a rocoto leche de tigre topped with fried calamari
* This really tasty. The fried calamari gave it a different pop with the cooked calamari. I didn't get any mussels or clams though... just the shrimp. Not a big thing to complain about but I know one of the girls I ate with did in her tasting dish. I was cheated... sorta. 
- cebiche mixto: Yellowtail from Mexico, calamari and shrimp in an ají amarillo leche de tigre with cilantro, red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam
* The flavors weren't there for me. But the other girls liked it a lot.
- cebiche nikei: Tombo Tuna, red onion, Japanese cucumber, daikon, and avocado in a tamarind leche de tigre
*My favorite one. I thought it was just really tasty and flavorful. Had almost a miso taste to it. With a little habernero, it was even better! 

AND I discovered cancha for the first time. It's SO good. I want that in everything now.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
[ Food: 3.5/5 ]    [ Ambiance: 3.5/5 ]    [ Services: 3.5/5 ]
Prices $$$ (avg $35/person)

We sat outside the back open-deck with heater, its quieter. High ceiling, spacious, tastefully designed restaurant with the kitchen in the center. Great color scheme everywhere including their menus and place mats, very eye pleasing and welcoming ambiance. Typical San Francisco services, friendly and efficient.

Cebiche Tasting $29: Mixto, Chifa, Nikei and Clásico. The best was Chifa, its Mahi-Mahi mixed with the ginger, peanut in ala-sesame dressing, it remind me of a traditional chinese specialty called "yee sang" that only available during the Chinese New Year season. The second fav was Nikei, similar to Hawaiian poke.

Causa Tasting $17: Limeña, Criolla, Nikei, Casera. My fav was the Limena with Dungeness Crab, avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo Huancaína sauce with basil cilantro oil. This blended well with the bland but very smooth mashed potato.

Buñuelos de Chocolate $12: Orange glazed chocolate beignets with banana and passion fruit ice cream. Recommended by our waiter. Simply fried doughnut with chocolate filling... oh, you get those in Shipley's, they are bigger and better ;-) oh sorry, there's no Shipley's in SF!

This is my first time eating Peruvian food and I sort of enjoyed the different (fusion) flavors of the cebiche & causa. And the Tasting option is a great way to sample their specialty if you are a first timer or dont know what to order. Eventhough I found some of the fusions didnt really worked well together, I still would recommend this place for those who like to challenge their taste buds or simply want to get a light meal and relax in a comfortable setting...
author: Peter T.

description:
Writing my review for Serpentine reminded me that I forgot to write a review on La Mar.

The start was a bit rocky as the place requires that all members of a party be present before being seated. I arrived a few minutes late and while we were waiting for the last person in our party to arrive, we were told that we pretty much were going to lose our reservation since the 15 minute grace period was right around the corner. After explaining that our friend was going to arrive any minute, the hostess finally agreed to seat us, but not without a bunch of hemming and hawing about how she shouldn't be seating us, etc. She made it seem like we were putting her out. And of course what do you know, the dining area was pretty empty and throughout the night there were still some tables empty. 

Luckily the food made up for the rest of the evening. We decided to go family style as that seemed the best way to try as many of the dishes as possible. We started with the cebiche tasting, all very refreshing and light. Next up was the causa tasting. My favorites had to be the limeña and the nikei. The chicken and the steak were my faves out of this tasting set. Last up was the lomo saltado which was a tasty tenderloin covered with french fries. The fries served a dual purpose as all of us used it to dip in the sauce.

So despite the bumpy beginning, the evening went well and we enjoyed our meal.
author: vivian h.

description:
I am Peruvian (well, my parents were born there) and I know my Peruvian food. 

I'm sad to say that this place was not what I had expected. Peruvian food is supposed to be powerful, incredible flavors. I had the causa, the chicken a la parilla. They were both amazingly bland--I dont understand how there wasn't that much flavor in the food. Even the sauces weren't that impressive.  I can make better food than this and charge half as much. (One day I will open my restaurant to make this point...)

The service was abysmal. Had to ask for a menu TWICE. I had to ask for my food TWICE. Even though we were at the bar area, this is not acceptable.

Hopefully, friends do not plan any dinners or gatherings at La Mar. I will probably eat dinner before coming here again... 

For a much more authentic, amazing Peruvian food, go to Limon Rotisserie or El Perol in the mission. Also, there is a great spot in pacifica that has mexican and peruvian food. Amazing!
author: Edward G.

description:
After going to astrid and gaston in Lima,Peru this place definitely does not compare unfortunately.  The cocktails were made nicely and their pisco drinks are good similar to the other restaurants in the family since they share the same drink menu. The service was good. The food however just didn't have the strong tastes and flavors that we were expecting from a Peruvian restaurant. Our guess is that it's due to the fact that it is on the embarcadero so it's catered for that crowd and tourists as opposed to being actually good Peruvian food.
The ceviche was good, the classic is the best. The tuna ceviche was a little on the sweet side. the chifa one tastes just like a chinese chicken salad. The crab potato was just ok. 
The beef stew was cooked nicely but wasn't very flavorful. The empanadas I thought was pretty good and were nice and crispy. The sauce wasn't the best. The octopus skewer tasted sort of Mediterranean to me.
author: Alex H.

description:
There are good reasons how some restaurants are still packed nightly after 2 years and some have since closed down or struggling.

La Mar is definitely one of the few successful ones around.  We have tried to eat here a few times without success.  On a recent Saturday, we finally made it in and it was a very enjoyable experinece.  

Our waiter, Alfonso, was so friendly...this was a great start to a wonderful meal.

Hubby had a glass of the Crios Torrontes ($6.75) and I had a glass of Talley Sauvignon Blanc ($8.75) followed w/ a Chilcano $10 (pisco quebranta, lime juice, ginger beer, and angostura bitters).  What we had:

cebiche mixtura - $19 - it was one of the 3 weekly specials - a nice plate of ceviche of calamari, octopus and small shrimp.

trigoto cam - $25 - another one of the 3 weekly specials - they used barley as the "risotto" served with 4 large prawns - the sauce was an intense flavor of the shrimp head roe, so creamy and tasty.

anticucho de corazón - $12 - grilled beef heart skewer with potatoes, Peruvian corn and a spicy rocoto sauce - this was delicious!

there was a long wait between plates and our friendly water gave us a complimentary causa limena - dungeness Crab, avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo Huancaína sauce with basil cilantro oil.  This was absolutley divine!  We will definitely have to have this on our return visit.

buñuelos de chocolate - $12 - orange glazed chocolate beignets with banana and passion fruit ice cream.  It was ok - can't taste any orange but there are plenty of warm gooey dark chocolate oozing out from the mini beignet (more like donut).
author: Gloria H.

description:
We had reservations and sat outside for lunch.  The food was quite tasty and the service was fine.  Where it went bad real fast was when I was waiting for the check and noticed that there were mice running around our feet.  I grabbed the check since I was uncomfortable waiting for the server to return to take my credit card.  I found her inside and explained that I could wait for her outside with the mice and she explained that I should wait in the front and she would send the manager over.  So I waited for the manger on duty in the front near the bar.  

This is where it went worse than seeing mice under your feet.  He very rudely approached me and stood and stared at me and said "what?!"  I explained that the server sent him to me per her request and he said in a very rude and abrupt tone "this is the port!".  That was it!  He wasn't apologetic for my discomfort and did not try to make the situation any better.  I didn't cause a scene since I was with my 7 year old daughter so I just paid and left.
author: V F.

description: Nice atmosphere. Pretty interesting and reasonable priced dishes.
author: Alexei A.

description:
I like Peruvian food, and I think this restaurant has well prepared food to be sure. My review is more about the overall experience and the value, rather than about the quality of the food. The quality is good. 

We had a reservation for 5:30pm, but we were not allowed to sit near the windows (overlooking the bay) because they said that the window tables were only for parties of four. They also would not let us order anything off the happy hour menu and take it in the dining room, which is understandable--but at the same time they said that if we ordered something at the bar, then we would lose our table in the main dining room. Therefore, we ended up having to spend a lot more for the beer (at the table) than we could have by taking advantage of the happy hour, which lasts until 6pm. I thought they were really too controlling about that.

Secondly, the waitress was kind of pushy about trying to get us to order drinks and cocktails even though I clearly stated that I only wanted water. It was annoying, since the food itself was plenty expensive for the portion size, and if I say I want water, then I actually do want water and not a pisco sour or a non alcoholic cocktail.

The portion sizes are small. The causas consist of two small potato cakes with some topping on them. At $10-12 per causa plate, you are essentially paying $5-6 for a large spoonful of mashed potatoes with a small amount of fish topping. Delicious, but super over priced.

If a restaurant is going to charge me $10-12 for mini appetizers, and $20-30 per plate, then I am at least going to want to have a good view and a superb waitstaff. The view from the middle of the dining room was not great, and no better than any other restaurant in SF. I would say go to the happy hour and save your money.
