You'll get the same food at a way lower price.
author: John S.

description:
I've eaten at La Mar a half dozen times, including once with a group of 20. This is one of my favorite places to eat and my wife and I eat her often we were are in town.

Things I like most on the menu include ceviche (we usually get mixto, but all of them that I have tried are good), various anticuchos (beef and chicken), causas and several of the specials (if you can read them on the dimly lit board above the kitchen -:).  I'm particularly fond of the lomo saltado, either as a large plate or in the empanadas.  I'm also a big fan of the chips that they bring to the table as an appetizer.
author: Richard M.

description:
Go here on a warm, sunny day and sit outside and you will feel like you are on vacation. 

Don't get the peruvian mashed potato ish dish because it looks like purple play-doh and as you eat it, you will not be able to get that out of your head, and it will taste like play-doh. And your friend will start to make figurines out of it and you will feel slightly awkward as the waitress passes by.

The rolls were delicious though!
author: Richa A.

description:
After all the rave I've been hearing about this place I finally tried it and I must say it did live up to my expectations!  Here we go...

Cebiche tasting - Of the 4 different tastings, cebiche chifa was my fav...it tasted a lot like chinese chicken salad but instead of chicken it was halibut. 

Causa tasting - A very unique item...the best way I can verbally describe it is it's like sushi but except with rice it's with whipped potatoes.  Of the 4 different fillings, the causa limena was my fav...very tasty crab salad.

Empanadas - The chicken ones are filled with a creamy chicken mixture, not what I expected...it was tasty but the spices didn't quite satisfy my taste buds.  However, the beef ones are perfect for my taste buds!

Cordero - The braised lamb shank was a bit overcooked so it was on the dry side but the flavorful sauce made up for it so it still turned out really tasty.

Chocolate beignets - Definitely can't compare to the cajun style beignets!  It was decent but I would not order it again.  

Now on to the service...everyone was really nice but the only complaint I have is not being attentive enough.  We ate our dinner over a period of 4 hours so you can imagine how many alcoholic bevies would be needed.  Our waiter was always more concerned about how our drinks tasted rather than noticing that the glass was empty already!   How about asking what we would like next?  Same with our water glasses, we constantly had to ask to get our glasses refilled.

It's definitely a really fun place with a great view and worth the money for the food.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Tina L.

description:
I adore ceviche, the fresh fish here, and the decor (dark wood, white, and sea blues). I've been coming here since they first opened. However the prices are outrageous and the service has gotten slow and inattentive. Getting a table has also gotten tough.

The complimentary chips are good, especially the sweet potato or yam chips. I love the red sauce they come with. On my most recent visit, the octopus in the appetizer was really mushy and the potato puree tasted like it was from a box. The chipotle ceviche special was oversauced. Still, I realy like the regular ceviches on the menu and what sets them apart from other restaurants is not the flavors as much as the high quality of the fish.
author: Marina N.

description:
Really, really good and flavorful food.  The variety of ceviche is rather unique and both my wife and I enjoyed ours immensely.  We also had sampler plates of empanadas and skewers and both were equally good.

My wife's dessert was fantastic - passion fruit mousse inside chocolate cake with a soft praline "crust" with raspberry sauce & fresh four-milk ice-cream was awesome.  But outside of that dessert the rest didn't seem very inspiring - I hope they can bump up the variety of desserts.

Would also like to see more wines by the glass - the ones they have are good but I think they need more then 3 reds and 3 whites.  Maybe add a couple more of each?

Service was attentive and not overbearing.  Our waiter did a great job recommending things to try and pairing wines with the dishes as best he could given the limits of the list.

Definitely a return trip is in order!
author: W R.

description:
Happy hour drinks = 5 stars (yum!)
Food = 3 star
Service = 1 star

I've been here a few times - it's a great venue and they have an excellent happy hour menu (and typically it's not super crowded), which is a win-win for me. Sadly, my most recent experience was a BUST. Met a work colleague there for happy hour and the service was just appalling. This is a nice place - not a dump - I've had better experiences at Denny's. Our server was constantly MIA, several people actually got up to ask if there was service in the lounge. When she finally appeared, she ignored us completely. Our drinks sat in front of us, empty, for well over 10 minutes. When our food arrived, it cold and pretty obvious that it had been sitting in the kitchen long after it was prepared. The best part was her attitude - which you can probably guess wasn't apologetic...it had more of a "what do you want now?" tone to it. That's a winner. 

For the caliber of the restaurant, the service falls painfully short.
author: Megan C.

description:
The design of this place is very nice. There are big glass windows opening up the view of the pier/bay/etc. The ceilings are high which make the place feel big (but it is actually big to begin with). There's a blue x hardwood theme going on here. 

Our waiter was not very attentive. I don't think he came to our table to check up on us once. I don't know why we still tipped at all (no service = no tip right?). 

Now onto the food! The give you complimentary dipping sauces and chips (banana chips, sweet potato chips and normal potato chips). Loved the banana and sweet potato chips and wished the whole basket was primarily these two (the basket was primarily potato chips which were still good). As a starter, we ordered the cebiche classico and I'm not really a fan of cebiche. My two coworkers loved it though so lets just take their word for it. Our entrees included the market fish, tallarin saltado, and lomo saltado. The fish was good and cooked just right. Flavorful and crunchy. My only gripe exists with the other two dishes. The tallarin saltado was far too salty. It felt like I was drinking soy sauce as I was eating this. The lomo saltado had amazing meat, but the "fried potatoes" are literally french fries. They felt and tasted like they were the premade/frozen french fries that you can get anywhere. I would think that at an establishment such as this, fried potatoes would be something more than just french fries. 

Overall the place is very pleasing to the eyes, but the food and service is lacking.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
What Peruvian caballero first discovered that if you put some fish in lime juice, the citrus will actually "cook" the fish? And then this awesome genius added chiles, cilantro, onion and garlic. I bow down to you oh ceviche inventor. You are god-like. You make me want to go to Peru RIGHT NOW just for the ceviche. Bring me that halibut and squid ceviche with a side of plantain chips. To hell with Machu Pichu. I'll see it if I have time. 

It seems so simple, and yet, so few restaurants can actually do justice to this magical food. Fresca is one such place. And now, so is La Mar. 

Incredible. This is one of the few times I wish there was a 6th star.  

The surroundings: Elegant, without a hint of pretension. Hip, without hipster. I love the vast, high ceiling thing, and the blue lit ceviche bar.

The food: We had the ceviche sampler and I fell in love with the mixto ceviche, which is mahi mahi and calamari. The spicy skirt steak skewer was also excellent, and the salad with papaya, jícama, pickled carrots and daikon, crunchy quinoa, and corn is making me hungry just writing the words. 

The service: Even better than the food. As some of you know, I don't have a lot of patience for poor service. Said another way, I'm a demanding asshole.

But I could find nothing to bitch about. It was peak dining hour on a Saturday night, and the service was perfect. The waiter showed up to take drink orders within a couple of minutes. Just to go with the whole Peruvian theme, I tried to order a bottle of Peruvian wine. He was pretty wine knowledgeable, and politely talked me out of it, instead suggesting a Chilean wine if I really felt the need to keep with the South American thing. 

He was there when we needed him throughout the evening, never trying to push too much food on us, and offering his opinion when asked. We ordered in stages, but it didn't disrupt the flow of our meal, and we never found ourselves wondering when the next course would arrive. 

I love the location too, right on the Embarcadero. After dinner we took a pedi-cab down to Pier 23 and saw a fun reggae band until it was time to stumble back to BART for the ride home. 

Awesome. I love you Oakland, but my new favorite restaurant is on the west side of the bridge.
author: Jay Z.

description: The service is great and the apps are wonderful. The ceviche mixto is fresh and really good. They also have a great Happy hour menu. Go to Happy hour if you want to try a little bit of everything!
author: Amanda N.

description: Parking is tough. Parking across street is accessible heading south on Embarcadero.
author: Michael D.

description: If you are looking for Peruvian you should check this place. Fabulous location. I loved the ceviche and the casas (yellow potatoes filled with shrimp and crabs). Good selection of wines and good service.
author: Alex82 S.

description:
Great food!  We asked our server to pick what as popular since we had out of town guests and we are very happy with everything.  I love the cebiche, empanandas and causas (you have to try it to understand it) YUMMMM! I will be back again.  
Oh I forgot get the pisco sour... delicious!
author: Johannah V.

description: Everything was excellent! We made our reservation for party of 5 @ 730, but we arrived about 30 min. early and they were able to seat up within 5 min. Hostess is a little bit lazy, she didn't place all the menu on individual seats, but asked us to help. I am ok with this but rest of us was like what the... Anyways our waiter is super knowledgeable with the dishes and we were able to order our food with no trouble. Definately come back again!.
author: Lovetea C.

description: Get the ceviche, causa and pie de limon for dessert. Yum!
author: Kassandra Z.

description:
I am not sure how many stars La Mar really deserves.

I am peruvian and when La Mar opened for the first time in San Francisco, me, like all peruvians in the bay area, was incredibly excited.  The original La Mar in Lima is absolutely delicious and i was sure this was going to be the same.

The first time i went, when it first opened back in October 2008, it was all that i had hoped for.  Delicious food.  It was a bit of Perú in San Francisco and our peruvian palates as well as our hearts were completely satisfied.  Very pricey, but this wonderful journey to peruvian deliciousness was well worth it.

My last visit to La Mar, about a year ago, was a disappointment.  The cebiche was okay.  My favorite drink (Maricucha) was not made right.  The anticuchos were bad.  The lomo saltado was very good, fortunately.  The suspiro a la limeña was okay.  But this is La Mar, this is Gastón Acurio's restaurant, i am not paying for okay food, i am paying for excellent food.

  I haven't gone back since.  And it breaks my heart not to give La Mar 5 stars.  I am still debating whether to give it 3 or 4 stars.  I think 3.5 for now...  until i go back again.
author: Rita F.

description:
The location is fantastic.  I wish I could move into La Mar with it's huge windows and view of the water.... so upon walking in I reallly wanted to fall in love with this place.  Like most other times when I want to fall in love, it fell short of my expectations.

First, the ceviches were really watery and although they listed a ton of ingredients, it seemed like all octopus.  The rest of the dishes were mediocre (had a special rib-eye steak that was overcooked and served with potatoes that were too hard to cut).  The winning dish (according to the bf) was the special coconut covered fried shrimp appetizer served with mashed yams.  That is unfortunate considering it was identical to any kind of coconut encrusted fried shrimp I have ever tasted.  The empanadas with tri-tip (I believe) were good, but only because of the accompanying dipping sauce or else it would have been bland alone.

I do want to say, though, that dad was obsessed with the ceviche and the empanadas.  Perhaps I'm just a player hater? NEVER.

Why the 4 stars then, you whining baby? obvi because of the alcohol (yumm pisco punch) and the location. DUH.
author: Josie A.

description:
I have an unusual relationship with La Mar.  I am never displeased, disappointed or sad when I leave Pier 1 1/2.

My last and probably fondest memory of La Mar was a few weeks ago on a very rainy Sunday.  I went here on a whim, without having made any reservation in advance, and nervous that we might be turned away. 

To my delight, my date and I were magically seated in the outdoor heated patio overlooking the exceptional waterfront views.  We passed our time with good conversation and amazing food and drink under the rain.  Our experience was bolstered by the friendly service and feeling of familiarity, almost intimacy that you receive when dining here.  

For starters we enjoyed the anticucho de pollo skewers with the heat of the salsa balanced by the sweetness of the corn and split the lomo saltado, which is just really hard to describe how good it is, as each of the unique flavors offer complements to one another.  After a few cocktails and a bottle of wine, we finished the evening off with the chocolate beignets.  If you are a chocolate lover, these truly are a must try.  I owe my co-worker for introducing me to these heavenly desserts.

As I ended my evening on that particular Sunday, we actually closed the restaurant down and left before they would have politely asked us to leave.  Perfect end to a perfect dinner, captured by a perfect night.

Dining at La Mar always provides an environment to create long lasting memories whether it is with friends, family or even dates.  Thank you for never disappointing.
author: Carolina H.

description: My wife turned me into a huge Peruvian food fan. For years we have searched the bay area for an excellent Peruvian restaurant and I must say that by far this is the best one we have ever experienced! Lomo Saltado was amazing!
author: -J A.

description:
BEST meal i've had in a long time and trust me i eat out a lot. went here while my family was in town visiting and we ordered a wide variety of dishes. probably some of the best ceviche and paella dishes 've ever had.

definitely the kind of place to go with a group of people so you get a taste of multiple dishes.

a bit on the pricey side but SO worth it.
author: Jae C.

description:
Lunch review.

3.5 stars overall.

I think they over sell and overhype their ceviche. That just annoys me and as a result, I dinged them a half star to 3.5 stars. The ceviche is not that great to be honest. Very good, but not "world class" as I had expected based on how they talk about their own ceviche.

That said, the prix fixe and pre set lunch options are fantastic and I would not hesitate to get those every time. But overall, this is a pricey place with smaller end portions so know that going in.
author: Ravi A.

description:
I wanted to like this place, I really did since my sister was raving about it and from reading the mostly positive reviews on yelp. At last, I must say it was just OK.

The place is very trendy and has a very open atmosphere with the high ceilings and all. The décor is very fun, bright, and sophisticated. The patio area has an amazing view of the bay and the bar area looks like a good spot to go to after work. 

The food however, was disappointing. I heard so much about the ceviche, what they specialize in. We ordered the Mixto with the 4 different kinds. They were all okay, but lacked the wow factor and depth of flavor. For the next course, I can't remember what it was called but had 3 little things made of mashed beans and potato? It wasn't impressive at all except for the nice presentation. Our last dish was the beef relleno, which was quite good! Unfortunately, that's the only thing I enjoyed out of all the dishes. I did like how they give you the mix of chips with the 3 different sauces to munch on though.

Service was a bit slow, but courteous when our server was present. Perhaps we didn't order the better dishes so I'll be back again to give this place another try, but for now I'll give it 3 stars.
author: Linda C.

description: Very disappointed on the ceviche, as a filler they added hominy and very little fish.  Taste was not your true ceviche flavors,  I visited La Mar long time ago and wow the ceviche was great then, not anymore.  to bad!
author: Henry M.

description:
This place is where I first fell in love with Peruvian food-- especially their ceviches! My good friend took me here with his family because his dad owns the restaurant, which could be a bias to their service other critics have ragged on, so I'll stick to just rating the food.

The restaurant is located on the pier and has a nice ambiance with the dim lighting and South American music. I don't even remember all the names of the ceviches we tried, but everything was bursting with flavor. Even their bread had a variety of sauces that were all delicious! I got their seafood pasta and my friend got the ahi tuna, which were both very flavorful. We finished our meal with their creme brulee, which wasn't my favorite but still good nonetheless. Although, my experiences with Peruvian food is limited, I was pleasantly surprised and will definitely be on the watch for other Peruvian places in my area!
author: Priscilla D.

description:
While in Lima, I had the life-altering pleasure of eating at Astrid y Gaston.  Fast forward to me being back in San Francisco and craving some tasty peruvian eats...

La Mar is the kind of restaurant that may be common in other cities but is sort of a rarity in SF.  The first thing you notice is that it's big.  Like really big.  There's bar seating, kitchen seating, a ton of tables in the middle area and then there's a separate chef's table for big parties that's off to the side.  It's loud, bustling and you almost feel like you could be in NYC or LA.  And maybe it's because the restauranteurs are international superstars who pull from a playbook that defies our hyper-local, micro-hood driven culture.  But whatever it is, just walking in the door, you know this is not your typical SF joint.  

it's relatively posh but can totally deal with the San Francisco casual crowd as well.  I've been there a few times and have worn: 
- a short party dress with sky-high heels 
- my "fancy" jeans and a button down shirt
- my "unfancy" jeans and a hoodie and my sauconys

It caters to downtown 9-5ers, marina daters, foodies, tourists, and people just looking for a quick tasty bite to line their bellies before enjoying the amazing passion fruit pisco sours.

The food is delicious - the specials change regularly but you can't go wrong with any of the ceviches, the lomo saltado, the empanadas, or any of the soups.  Everything has nice clean Peruvian flavors - good use of spices, but not overly spiced (if that makes sense).

I have two relatively minor gripes: the prices.  It's a really expensive place to eat and it's not like you can order intelligently and make it cheaper.  If you come here, plan to drop some serious cash on dinner. 
Second gripe is that the servers have a bit of attitude going.  Not sure what that's about but it reinforces that there's something decidedly un-SF about the place.  LA? NYC? Sure, I totally expect snotty service.  But in SF?  i'm just not feelin it.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
cebiche nikei + pisco sour +chips and dipping sauces=HELL YES.

Cool as a cucumber with Lily R enjoying the hot cebiche making guy behind the counter.  It's how I roll.  

$$$$$ but live a little....!
author: Flor D.

description:
You can't beat the location of this place, right on the water with a beautiful view. Expect to pay a premium for it, this place is pretty pricey. They have a great happy hour with specials on drinks and bar menu items, but it is done by 6PM.

The pisco sours are a must and the ceviche sampler is great way to try all 4 with a small group.  The empanada sampler and yucca fries are good for sharing too. I have a hard time eating dinner here because the menu seems overpriced to me. I can get the same items at Limon for half of what it costs here. 

I come here often for the piscos, I wish I got off work earlier to take advantage of the happy hour.
author: stacy b.

description: This place is awesome...my boyfriend and I came here twice during our weekend in San Fran. The first time we came was during an off-hour & we sat at the bar. The bartender was extremely friendly and spent 10 minutes teaching us the art of making the perfect pisco sour. The second time we came here was for the happy hour. It gets  a little wild in here with the after work crowd but if  you can grab a table or a spot at the bar, the happy hr is a good time to try many delicious apps and tasty cocktails.
author: Inna B.

description: I would have given this place 5 stars had the service been better. It's not that the server was bad; she was just the only server in the bar and the bar was packed.  She should have clearly had some help. There were also four bartenders behind the bar and they were all hopping. However, the food was FABULOUS! We opted for tapas in the bar late in the afternoon, after the Americas Cup races,  instead of dinner before heading out to the opera. The ahi tuna ceviche was to die for. The empanadas were delicious as was the calimari. Presentations were beautifu. This was my first experience with Peruvian food and I am now a fan! I love this restaurant and look forward to returning for dinner. Great location right there near The Ferry Building and on Embarcadero. Great location for people watching!
author: Lorraine P.

description: I knew I had to try La Mar on my recent trip to SF. I'm soooo glad I did. Being Peruvian, I can often be a snob when it comes to restaurants, nothing will ever be as good as my moms cooking. But this place was soooo worth the prices (and late reservations) because of how innovative it made Peruvian food! A tamale inside an empanada? Mazamorra inside of a pie? There are no words.
author: Alexandra P.

description:
So here's the thing. AMAZING space. It's a little cold. but it's huge and very hip. If you're lucky enough to score a table in the bar you'll be set for the night. The bartenders are friendly, but they seat people in the bar as though it is the restaurant so you can't always settle in with a group.

In the main restaurant our service was somewhat subpar. Not to mention, the food itself just isn't very good. The portions are tiny compared to the price. I've had much better Empanadas for sure.

Ultimately I will go back, but i'll skip dinner there and just enjoy drinks. Try the Pisco Sour which is amazing. Chicha Tu Ma is also a sweet little treat.
author: Nikki M.

description:
pwahhaha....Cholo-politan....how could I NOT get one?  The passion fruit dominatrix'd the cocktail AND it was pretty strong :)

mmmm...good signature drinks and yummmmy appetizers.  I wish I stayed longer for our company happy hr to taste all the h'orderves but I'll say those potato bites with tuna was really good and the calamari had a tangy kick...in the face!  mmm...  I definately want to come back and try their entrees.

The blue and green lighting at the bars were swanky and classy looking...didn't realize the place was so big!  The back room had fun-colored couches and the servers were very professional and friendly.  

Hm...not sure how I feel about the unisex bathrooms...AND my seabreeze was under par...but the bartender asked me to try it and see how I llked it...meh...it wasn't good but I didn't want to make a fuss.  I had a good time and am definately curious to try the food.
author: Kat C.

description:
LIKES - pisco sours ($5 during happy hour), ceviche, lomo saltado (the rice has hominy in it), empanadas and the ambiance of course

I would have given them a solid 5 stars, but their lomo saltado is incredibly expensive;  limon and fresca are great alternatives for the same dish at a fraction of the cost.
author: Laxme G.

description: Wonderful and unique restaurant in a fun atmosphere.  Great for large parties and/or a casual night out.  The ceviche sampler is a great way to get a little taste of everything.
author: Lauren T.

description:
We had our office Christmas party here and when we got to the restaurant there was some miscommunication because they didn't see our reservation in the system. No problem, they quickly rounded up a table on the patio for all 15 of us. They even had an area for us to leave our presents for our annual white elephant. 

This large restaurant serves generous amounts of seafood all around. I love the buttery crust on the empanadas and the Cebiches are winners but the Lomo Saltado was the worst I've ever had. Disappointingly watery, flavorless, and overcooked. This is a great place to take someone that's here visiting from out of town because of the location and view but over-priced for inconsistent dishes.
author: Jen Y.

description:
The fabulous Amanda B. walked me through this place and I instantly fell in love with the interior. It's very spacious, with dark dark dark wood furniture with a very vibrant pop of blue on the chairs. It made me feel as though I was transported to a beachside restaurant in Latin America somewhere... Or maybe i've just got a great imagination. Anyhow, the interior made me think of the ocean, and being somewhere far away. I love love love the matching blue lighting underneath the bar as well. It is only turned on at night so I didn't get to see it the time I actually dined there.
Okay, now on to my dining experience.
Everybody orders this: causa tasting - limena, criolla, nikei, casera. It's the multicolored thing that keeps popping up in all the photos. To be honest, the best was the nikei one. It was yummmmy and had the most flavor out of all 4. Everything else? Flavor was lost in the mashed potato.
Be sure to check with your server on the specials of the day (there's also a board so look for it!). I ordered: Cebiche criollo (special) - mahi mahi, Japanese octopus, calamari, celery, habanero, garlic, claims, ginger, red onion in classic leche de tigre and it was good, damn good. It gave Limon a run for its money.
anticuocho de pulpo - grilled octopus skewers, herbed mashed potato w/ chimichurri sauce and aji panca was very very tender, like chicken! not chewy or rubbery at all pretty good
anticuocho de carne - grilled skirt steak, potatoes, peruvian corn w/ spicy panchita & rocoto sauce was pretty tender, especially for skirt steak. Seriously DID NOT like that spicy panchita sauce though. It was all heat and no flavor.
anticucho de corazon - grilled beef heart w/ potatoes, Peruvian corn, spicy panchita and rocoto sauce very good as well.
arroz norteno - N. Peruvian seafood combo w/ mussels, shrimp, octopus and fried rice w/ cilantro and Huancaina sauce VERY NASTY. this dish was recommended by our server and unfortunately, all three of us hated it. We eached spooned some into our plates and into our mouths. The rest went untouched. I also hate cilantro so I don't even know WHY I thought it would be acceptable, hahaha
My absolute favorite dish of the night was: asado de tira - short ribs marinated in red wine & chicha morada w/ aji panca sauce over choclo pepian & herb salads. So tender that the meat was falling apart before I could even lift my fork.  I must also state that I love chicha morada so I had very high hopes for this dish. It passed with flying colors.
For dessert: crepe de chocolate - with lucuma mousse (soo yum) & ganache meringue ice cream ice cream w/ cointreau and fresh orange sauce. The chocolate overpowers the lucuma mousse completely. The delicate, exotic flavor of that delicious Peruvian fruit is lost within the chocoate :( but the fresh orange sauce complimented the lucuma mousse beautifully on its own.

La Mar, i'm coming back with the boyfriend and I hope you impress him just as much as you did me. 

besos!
author: Susy C.

description: I had super high expectations for this place as I had a couple of friends who had been and said nothing but great things about the food.  My boyfriend and I came in on a whim on a Friday night, and as soon as we walked in the door, we were treated like second-class citizens (probably because we came in wearing casual clothes as we had just gotten off work).  Either way, that has to be one of my biggest pet peeves about service-oriented places.  The food was good, but the service really killed it for me.  Probably wont go back.
author: Whitney I.

description: I'm peruvian, and I can say that Gaston is representing us very well in San Francisco. My american friends loved La Mar's food and that's what I was looking for. For me as peruvian, this food is plain and that's all. The service is just regular and in some point ridiculous when you want to make a reservation or waiting for a table in the bar. Foreign, this food is really good, best of the best in this world. Peruano, compatriota, esta comida es solo pasable pero nada parecido a lo q prepara nuestra abuela o madre preparan p preparaban, asi q no espereces algo bien taypa o recontra rico. This is the reason of my 3 stars.
author: Alex C.

description: Yes, the Pisco Sour is all that. Especially during happy hour at $6.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Decided to check out the restaurant for dinner when friends were visiting town.   Some of the appetizer dishes are actually pretty large so the entree like prices.  I had the salmon entree which the waiter gave a thumbs up, it was ok not as flavourful as I expected it to be considering it came recommended.  Wouldn't go back again for dinner.  Nice place to have appetizer and drinks.
author: HB K.

description:
I picked this place for the good reviews it had gotten but unfortunately I was not that impressed. We were friendly greeted by the hostess and our nice waiter. 
We started out with a ceviche which was ok. We ordered a bottle of wine but instead we got a glass. When we told the waiter that we hadent ordered that, we had to wait 15mins to get our wine. We had no napkins and had to ask for those as well. 
We were reccomended two entres which we went for. However after having waited for a solid amount of time the waiter told us that one of them was not available, and recomended that we get something else. He also suggested of bringing our one of them since it was ready. We selected another entre, 5 mins later the waiter approached us and told us that there had been a mixup and we got the initial food we had ordered... 
All in all I do not mind the service, these things happen and he was very nice about it. The food however was not good. The fish smelled of ammonia and the sauce was way too salty. Not impressive to say the least. Not exactly what I expected from a place like this but we may have been unlucky.
author: Athanasios E.

description:
I'm sold. 

It's a more upscale and better food version of fresca

cebiche yum, causa tasting beautifu - good but a tad bit bland, octopus skewer- so tender and meaty

dessert- got the tasting, and my fave was the fruit creme surrounded by a hard candy. 

great place for cocktails and getting dinner that you can still get frisky with your hubby with afterwards  ;)
author: Hannah W.

description:
Being a peruvian myself I think I can recognize a good peruvian dish. This place serves great tasting food - with a combination of horrible service. If I actually told you the story, you would hesitate twice about showing up here.

Of course, I have to mention this place is extremely overpriced - there are much better peruvian places - with comparable (and sometimes better) food with much better service.

One thing I have to say is that they do have a mean pisco sour - the best in town. Go a head and try it, and then move on to a real peruvian place for good authentic peruvian food.
author: Ragi B.

description:
I've lived in SF during the summer for the past few years. So, I'm sort of a tourist. But, with the good luck of being able to go back to places regularly that stick in my mind. La Mar is one of those places. The decor is well-done with beautiful colors that remind me of much warmer places than SF. The food is stellar. This past visit was a drop-in on Father's Day. They kindly fit us in even though they were very busy (Thanks!). 

The ceviche sampler is always good. The salsas are amazing concoctions. You really say things like "Wow!" after tasting some of their foods. And, I've had some of the best salads ever at La Mar. The spicy, citrous flavors with liberal use of cilantro are really incredible. Yes, it's expensive but it's great food with a great view in a great town.
author: Robert W.

description: Great atmosphere for a meal during the day. We wanted to get a seat on the patio but there was a 20 minute wait so call ahead if it's a nice day. Got the ceviche la mar and it was delicious.
author: Judy L.

description: Really good food but very small portions for the price. Expect to pay a lot to feel full, but your palate will be satisfied no matter how your stomach feels.
author: Catherine M.

description:
Went here with some girlfriends for late evening cocktails and dessert.  I ended up trying the cebiche tasting, the chocolate crepe and pisco sour.   The food portion is definitely on the smaller side but wow, LOVED the cebiche!  And the complimentary plantain chips they serve with the dipping sauces were awesome.  I'd go back just for the chips.  I probably wouldn't order the pisco sour again as the foam topping just wasn't my thing.  But great ambience, great service, and very tasty food.

I have recommended this restaurant to friends looking for a nice place to celebrate special occasions and La Mar has not disappointed.  It's a perfect first date type of restaurant too.
author: Szu H.

description: I have been coming here since it opened.  Sadly, the quality and portions have decreased.
author: Amber B.

description:
OVERALL:3.5   FOOD:3.5   SERVICE:2.5   AMBIANCE:4   VALUE:4
For a good time, call this hot mama!

Tasty seafood (cebiche nikei & carretillero are awesome), large space (bar area gets crowded, FAST) with mile-high ceilings & mood lighting, even tastier drinks (Peruvian mule, pisco sour), great people watching both inside and outside on the Embarcadero.  Happy Hour ends early (6pm), so shut down the computer a few minutes early & rally the troops to catch drink & bar bite specials to avoid the high-ish prices.

Ooof, but the service...?  I'll chalk it up to extenuating circumstances and a fluke bad day, but whoa nelly the hostess/server was NOT on her A-game.  Pretty sour face all night, edgy, and scattered on drink orders.  To her credit, it was busy (but isn't that a daily thing...?) and loud (waaat...at a bar...?!?), so maybe she deserves some slack.  Maybe?

Overall, great place to kick back, throw back some pisco, have some laughs, or even linger over the candlelight with that special someone.
author: Amy K.

description:
Okay, finally got a refund.  When my boyfriend FINALLY got a hold of the general manager, Andrew, he had suspiciously heard NOTHING of our plight.  NOTHING about the +8 phone calls to him, nothing about the letter we sent to him, nothing about trying to reach him, nothing even about our incident!  What the eff???

Apparently he was pretty straightforward on the phone, not every empathetic and was just like "email me your info, and I'll get it done."  What I don't understand is why every other lower manager couldn't have passed on the info...what a headache.

Talk about horrendous communication and management.  

I'm only adding one star because Andrew followed through with what he said but I'm never going to step foot in this joint again, and I'm going to warn my friends about the (lack of good) service that plagues La Mar.
author: Laura S.

description: This place gets 4 stars from me for the ambiance and the food.  The only thing that was lacking was the service. Our server was around a lot, but seldom stopped by our table. He would look right at us and stare at length, but then wouldn't materialize at the table unless I literally waved him down. For instance, we had our dessert menus for 20 minutes (yes, I timed it because at this point, it was getting to be very annoying) before he came and took our order.  We sat with our empty entree plates for a half hour before he cleared them and asked if we wanted anything else.  But, enough about that...I would go back for the cebiche sampler, it was heaven.  We had a causa nikei (sp?) that was very good, and the quinoa/caprese salad with burrata cheese was to die for. Our entree was a steak dish whose name escapes me, which was fabulous, except it had a few too many onions. The tenderloin was melt in your mouth good.  For dessert we had the mousse cake sprinkled with 24k gold dust and it was gone in no time, it was delish!  I would like to come back and try the empanadas, we didn't get to those.  Service from the bussers was spot on. I really think our waiter was the only one with an issue, as the table next to us was equally annoyed and I noticed everyone else seated nearby us that had other staff waiting on them had their meals moving along at a "normal" pace.
author: Rachel H.

description:
La Mar is that sexy Latin beauty who at first glance appears only fit for a one-night stand, but upon further interaction, you realize there may be more than what meets the eye. That was my experience w/ La Mar. 

The restaurant, housed in a large and open space, has an infectious energy. The cocktail menu has the usual suspects you'd expect from a Peruvian restaurant but it also features innovative drinks with good use of seasonal fruits. Highlights from the food menu include fresh ceviche, buttery empanadas, tender octopus skewers, perfectly cooked paella and savory lomo saltado. If you're a seafood lover, you'll enjoy dining at La Mar.
author: Alice W.

description:
Went here tonight again with a friend. No change in the rating but thought I'd add some color --

I love the atmosphere of this place. It feels summery and festive with all the bright colors as soon as you walk in, even if it's foggy and gross outside.

The chip assortment is fun - really like the sweet potato and plantain chips. The green and red sauces are good but the yellow is just blah.

For the record I liked the Cebiche Nikei quite a bit better than the Cebiche Chalaco. And, while the Causas are all beautiful, I liked the Causa limena (with crab) and the Causa Saltadito much better than the other two (perhaps because I don't love avocado...)

The Empanada K'apchi was good though I would have liked a higher filling to sauce ratio

It's a little expensive for the amount of food you get. I walked out plenty full for $33 (post tip) but if you're really hungry, this probably isn't the place to go
author: Sydney L.

description:
Probably the last place that I'd ever look to for a romantic evening out for two.  Frankly it feels a bit like a turquoise cafeteria, and ALL of the tables for two are buried in the center of the restaurant.  Four tops occupy all of the window placements, and no exceptions are made.  
The food is ...ok.  I'm a little awed by a dish that includes both rice and french fries...not exactly sure what to do with it.  The cebiche was very good, the empanadas good but not spectacular.  
Service is stealth invisible...and not in a "cool, what the hell just happened" kind of way.  IMHO, it was someplace that we needed to try out, but it's not ever going to be on our "go to" list.  In any case, it's not worth the snotty attitude from most of the staff.
author: Nick S.

description:
This is our 2nd time here, still not impressed with the food.  The service is much better this time.  On the expensive side, not good value.  Most likely we will not return.

Empanada sampler:  Very little fillings and uninteresting.  They're deep fried instead of baked.
Rollo de lomo saltado: Beef was okay, tasteless sauce.  The rice was terribly mushy.  I guess it's our own fault to order sushi roll at a Peruvian restaurant.
Grilled skirt steak skewer: The best dish of the day.  Beef was little tough, but flavorful.
author: TopCat W.

description:
My first visit at La Mar, my friend and I sat at a table in the bar area, and the food was delicious, and the service was great!

This past weekend, my husband and I went on a double date.  I was excited to go back to La Mar, this time we had reservations, and sat at a nice table, ear the window in the main dining area.

While my girlfriend and I waited for our husband's (they were parking the car), we sat at our table 10 minutes before our waiter Roberto introduce himself.  Instead of asking if we wanted to order drinks (which I did) he sent over water.  Another 15 minutes go by no Roberto to order drinks, appetizers, dinner.  Finally, he comes over and we just place our order (drinks, apps, and dinner) - Who knows when he was going to be back.  After several times of going over the order, he forgets some of the drinks, and one of the apps.  I understand it was a busy night, but he could've came by to check on us to see if our entire order was delivered, how we were enjoying the food.  I wanted to other another glass of wine, and some more water would've been nice, but trying to flag him down was impossible.  Finally, one of the bus boys was able to get him to come over, in which we just asked for the check.  To our surprise, we  were charged for a drink that we never received.  At this point, we were very annoyed, and just decided to pay the bill, and go somewhere else for drinks.

I will not be returning!
author: Raquel B.

description: I know it can get a little scene-y, especially near the bar area, but don't let that dissuade you from checking this place out. Definitely the best ceviche I've had in SF and some nice views of the water. Pretty solid wine list as well--and the plantain chips also rock.
author: Paul C.

description:
What do you do when it's St. Patty's Day, you're 1/8 Irish and you avoid your mother's corned beef & cabbage for fear of certain gastrointestinal explosion? You freakin' RUN for it, fork in hand, like it was the Potato Famine with zombies at your heels! 

Back to reality and you find yourself on the Embarcadero for an evening of delicious Peruvian food at La Mar Cebicheria. 6 months and 450 Yelps after my first blissful encounter, I realized this über reviewed place can be different depending on the fateful combo of who your server is and where you choose to sit. When you visit, my advice is to think about what mood best suits the occasion. There are 3 places to dine in, each one invoking a different feeling: the lounge with dark wood ranch style tables and square ottomans, the open and lively dining room and their heated outdoor area with a beautiful view of the Bay. My fave is the relaxing atmosphere of the lounge, but that's just me.

If there's one thing you should know about La Mar, they are ALL about the sauces. (And I am too!) So much so, that they outnumber the dishes by 3 to 1. The seared beef heart, the empanadas, grilled octopus and tequeños all came with a rainbow of savory dips. At one point we had 4 dishes, 12 little dipping sauces to sample and no table room to spare!

So now I have to geek out a little with a bit of dorkiness that you graphic designers reading this will understand. I would totally lay down some cash to take home one of their menus. And no, damn it, it wouldn't fit in my purse! A simple, elegant design that matches their blue and yellow square motif in the restaurant, matte with a small square of spot varnish over their logo. Ooh, just scrumptious! From the bright square ottomans to the criss-crossed backs of the chairs, it's just so brilliantly thought out that it makes me sigh in design ecstasy. Mmm, LOVE it.

So will I be back? Absolutely...but definitely in the lounge and hopefully with our original, upbeat server.
author: Kira R.

description: Good enough food, insulting service. We stopped in for early (6pm) cocktails and an appetizer. After an immediate introduction, our waiter (James) disappeared for 20 minutes after I asked for a minute more to look over the menu. We ordered the ceviche he recommended as well as a few cocktails but said it was too early for dinner for us.  We got a condescending "that's too bad" as he disappeared for an extended period again. As my wife was eating the ceviche with the included sweet potato chips, James returned to show us how we were doing it all wrong and that we were supposed to eat the ceviche with the sweet potato chips (he made the motion and a crunching sound, it was hilariously awkward). When he came back with the check he reached around me to clean and said "pardon the gorilla service, I'm a bit of a knuckle dragger. Kind of like looking in a mirror, right?"  The guy was clearly annoyed we were at his table and was condescending for no reason but we got out quickly and later went to another restaurant far more comfortable in their own skin. Good enough food but there are enough great restaurants in the area to not make it necessary to visit.
author: Philip J.

description: Try the grilled squid dish. It is really good. Also our server was really friendly and made the time there really enjoyable.
author: Benjamin K.

description:
I don't get all the good reviews unless standards in this city are getting LOW for things like service.

This was my third time dining here -first two were for lunch. The food - especially the anticuchos & cebiche tasting were all that I remembered - the sangria the real thing - perfect - 

However - they messed up our reservation and gave me a hard time when I asked them to get it right - service was slow as our poor waiter (who was good) was given WAY too many tables. We never got the b-day dessert I ordered for hubby as it took too long and the patio was "closing" so we had to get up and leave. Not cool for a $130 price tag for dinner. Overall - GREAT food but there are many other views in SF with food as good or better for less $$ - the service was a turn off - won't be going back with all the other amazing places in SF that COMBINE great food with fantastic service.  I am a local and can get the view for free on a run so don't want to pay for that and bad service.
author: Mylea C.

description:
Great place if you're looking for a creative cocktails or beer after work as well as for grabbing a few appetizers (the menu of entrees is a bit limited and personally not all that inspired)...in any case appetizers are way better for sampling and sharing.

The various cebiches are the stars of the menu...the mixto, clasico, and nikei are all quite good, although if you get more than two everything starts tasting very similar...so limit yourself and don't go all crazy.

The empanadas are great. Super light and flaky crust. Great filling options in particular the skirt steak which is uber tender.

The beef heart antichucho is stinking awesome. Definitely on-par with the version at Limon. It's very easy to overcook beef heart, so the fact that this dish comes out tender each and every time is a testament to the abilities of the kitchen staff.

For dessert, the beignets are chocolatey goodness. Like a molten lava chocolate cake and a donut had a baby together.

As noted above, the entrees selection is well small and so-so, perhaps the one exception being the lomo saltado.
author: David H.

description:
We just got back from Peru a couple of months ago... La Mar's got authentic Peruvian styles and flavors but it's quite dissimilar from "typical" Peruvian food. This is a good thing, as I found food in the nicer restaurants of Peru a bit heavy and one noted. La Mar utilizes a variety of non-traditional Peruvian cooking techniques while staying true to Peru.

The entire meal proceeded slowly -- a great thing if you want to savor the night, not so great if you're trying to watch the Bay Bridge Lights turn on. Overall, the meal took about two hours from the original time of our reservation.

We had: The cocktail special a Pisco drink similar to a Cosmo, with the Pisco flavor masked behind fruit flavors. Yummy if a bit weak. Cebiche Chifa (Chifa is Peruvian word for Chinese food.) The fish tasted wonderfully raw and slightly "cooked" by the acid on the outside. The "Chinese" flavors were bold, if a bit stereotypical (peanuts, ginger, deep fried noodles.) The slight acid was balanced nicely by the peanuts and deep fried noodles. Next was Corazon or beef heart. Beef heart tastes awesome, though the texture can be a bit difficult for people not used to it. I notice that La Mar tenderizes the beef hearts, making the outside texture similar to other beef, but the inside has the slight toughness of heart. We prefer the beef heart texture, but the tenderizing makes it more approachable. Next, we had the sous-vide squab stuffed with fluffed rice. Not bad, but unremarkable. The fluffed rice was interesting.

Finally, we ended with a Lucuma Panna Cotta with chocolate foam and Queso Helado (4 milk ice cream.) Everything tasted excellent except the Panna Cotta. It was served as a roll rather than in a traditional glass -- the extra gelatin to help it keep shape made its texture unpleasant. The flavor also had more of a spiced flavor than a traditional butter scotch tasting Lucuma, which made it slightly unpleasant. Ask your server if they have Lucuma ice cream, which I hear is wonderful (though it's off the menu and they don't always have it.)

Sometimes a server makes a meal. Tobias M (or Tobias M's manager), if you're reading this, Tobias rocks! He was extremely pleasant about everything, knowledgable, and gave great advice without being pushy.
author: Alexander J.

description:
DELICIOUS! The fish was so fresh, it was as though they went and fished it out of the bay before serving it up!

I have to start with the fact that this place has amazing drinks! I had the pomegranate martini, can't recall the name, but this was the most decadent martini ever, I just wanted to savior it!

Any who- we started with their mahi mahi ceviche with squid... yummo, the ceviche sauce was amazing, drinkable amazing.

Also- before they started bringing out our order, they brought a basket full of plantain chips, with 3 types of sauces... it was also great!

Continuing with the crab empanadas served on steamed bak choy, wow- this dough less empanada was amazing, once again the crab was amazingly fresh. We also had the chicken skewer which was tender, and came with two sauce's... everything had hot sauce here, which made my experience a very enjoyable one!

The service was awesome! Definitely recommend this place!
author: yana Z.

description:
I just want to get this out of the way right now. When I go to any restaurant in San Francisco, I like to order alcoholic beverages first. And this place has AMAZING pisco sours. Strong and quite tasty. 
I hate to admit it...but I was buzzed after one. As you can imagine, I jumped all over the complimentary chips basket.

If it is your first time coming here to La Mar, be sure to order the causa sampler (which several Yelpers have so graciously provided pictures of). Very good stuff. My favorite was the causa limena (crab meat and avocado puree with potatoes? SCORE!). 

Also remember, the cebiche here is GOOD! We got the cebiche tasting (basically a sample of most of the cebiches). I've never had octopus before...and I can tell you that it was actually really good here (the buzz also helped, I guess).

For the main course I ordered the Seared Ahi Tuna. It was delicious. I purposely STOPPED drinking to enjoy the taste of it (because a few more drinks would have faded my memories). The tuna was encrusted in delicious crushed black peppercorns, served with sesame sauce and nikei salad and purple potatoes. DELICIOUS!

Just heed this warning...if you order dessert, do NOT get the crepe. Drive somewhere else in SF to get one. Why? The crepe was the size of a wallet. A small Hello-Kitty sized wallet. It tasted ok. Spend the money to get another pisco sour instead.

And there you have it folks. I can say that after delicious food (minus dessert) and 4 pisco sours, I am a fan of La Mar. Once my income gets better, I'll be sure to come back here again.
author: Daniel M.

description:
Walking down to the ferry building and stumbled upon this place yesterday. And, since I started dating a guy who's half Peruvian, have become quite a fan of cebiche and the like! 

Their full menu isn't available until 5:30, but before than you can sit at the bar and order yourself a lovely pisco sour (a bit stronger than I usually like, but still good) or their drink of the day along with some appetizers. 

We got: 
MAIN:
Cebiche clasico (I thought it was definitely lacking in acid, but the fish itself was better quality than Fresca. But, like I said, when Fresca gets it right [sometimes the guy at the Noe Valley location goes overboard with the peppers], their leche de tigre is better balanced.) 

tiradito nikei (Ahi Tuna in Nikei sauce with passion fruit and honey leche de tigre -- sort of like sashimi in absolutely divine leche de tigre)

empanada sampler (My boyfriend says that usually in Peru empandas are more like a "baked, egg-shellacked dough" versus the "fried wonton-ness" La Mar has going on.)  But with that said, still tasty. His favorite was the seafood or lomo saltado. The one with corn had really yellow sweet corn in it, which isn't actually the sort of corn typically found in Peru (there's is more big, white, and more starchy than sweet). Still tasty -- but almost dessert/baked good-y to me. 


DESSERT:
Picarones (traditional warm pumpkin and sweet potato fritters with spiced Chancaca honey -- basically circle donut-shaped thick and fluffy funnel cake with a sauce that is NOT FROM EARTH!  This is seriously the best dessert I've had in a long time. 

Buñuelos de chocolate (Orange glazed chocolate beignets with banana and passion fruit ice cream -- basically little balls with some seriously rich chocolate gushing out, served with a baby amount of ice cream.) All that rich chocolate could have really used a lot more ice cream to help it out. Still quite tasty and if you're in a chocolate mood, this will definitely satisfy your craving.

Inka Cola (the perfect non-alcoholic soda to complement your cebiche!) 


All in all this place is definitely worth a try. If you've been to Fresca (which I HIGHLY recommend -- their lomo saltado, tequenos, and aji de gallina are constant cravings of mine), it's fun to go somewhere else and see their interpretation of Peruvian cuisine. 

Definitely get a cebiche and save room for dessert -- it's worth it!
author: Heather W.

description:
This place was recommended by the doorman at the Ritz--we are glad we listened. I noted on our reservation that it was birthday, and everyone we interacted with wished me a happy birthday. They were very friendly. 

The atmosphere is fairly basic--open and airy and nautical.

The food was awesome. We started with "causas," very delicate and tasty servings of mashed sweet potatoes with crab and tomato--yum. The chips that come before the meal are meh, a good effort. My salmon was okay, but the flavor was totally overwhelmed by the peppery coconut milk it was soaked in. All of their entrees seemed very over-flavorful and complex for a high end seafood place--can the fish stand on its own? The dessert -- alfajor -- was okay, the cookie was the best part. But I got a tasty profiterole for my birthday, too--I actually liked that more! 

Would recommend this place and maybe even go back and try a different entree.
author: Kate P.

description: Din here is solid, but the happy hour is really what's banging.  I started with a caipirinha, and $160 and several additional drinks later, one of the most enjoyable evenings I've had in a while.  Strong drink list in terms of selection and potency of their cocktails, victory was mine.
author: Rachel N.

description: Great dinner. Great service. Some of the food had very heavy Asian overtones, which was not expected, but I don't really know what Peruvian food should taste like. Drinks were very professional done. Though every seat in the house was full everything was very efficient.
author: ben h.

description:
Warning - this review will be "almost" as useless as the "moron who went to a churrascaria (Brazilian steak house) and doesn't eat meat" review...

So....I don't eat (much) seafood and really dislike most ocean-borne creatures (yes, I'm a Turf-and-Turf kinda guy).

I admit to ONLY eating tuna and some fake crab (since it's innocuous in most items like sushi).  Oh, and I can only eat that tuna raw...since cooked tuna is pretty nasty.

So if you're looking for a helpful cebiche review...it won't be from me!  =P

The drinks here are delicious but costly (hey, it's SF)  - I recommend the "chilcano" (pisco quebranta, lime juice, ginger beer, and angostura bitters).  This drink is light, lively and refreshing (I hate ginger beer by itself but it really works in this drink).  Great drink for the summer (or any time really).

This place is pretty pricey since it's a tapas-style restaurant (and if you're like me you love to try a LOT of dishes)

The "cebiche nikei" was great (Ahi Tuna, red onion, Japanese cucumber, in tamarind leche de tigre with avocado).  As I mentioned....tuna is the only fish I'll eat (save for some white fish fried up chinese style with pepper and salt)

I also highly recommend the "empanada sampler" (so you can taste the chicken, seafood, beef and corn empanadas).

For main dishes I recommend the "quinotto" (Grilled portobello, chimichurri glaze with roasted ají panca sauce over quinoa risotto) and the "asado de tira" (Short ribs marinated in red wine and chicha morada with an ají panca sauce over choclo pepián and herb salad)

Food was excellent and the wait staff attentive and helpful (when trying to select what wines pair best with the food).

The location is nice (right on the pier) and the interior is spectacular.  It's basically one wide open room bustling with tons of customers.  Not too formal and not too confining like some restaurants.  The colors blend in with the aquatic menu and are very relaxing.  Overall...a very fun atmosphere.
author: Richard C.

description:
I thought I had maybe had Peruvian food at some point in my life, but obviously it wasn't memorable. So after being pointed here by a lovely waitress at an unnamed very packed restaurant which wasn't going to let us in, we wandered into the doors of La Mar at sat down at la bar. Or is it le? Whatever. 

First, let the waitress pick your cocktail. There was some thing she must have made up that had cherries and sage in it that was so good I think I just gulped it. Second, let the waitress pick your wine. We got a few tastes until she found one that appealed, but she seemed to know by my ramblings what I was actually looking for. 

The food. The food! The food. We both had one of the rice dishes - me the one with every type of fish ever in in (starts with an M, mercona, mer something...) which was incredibly tasty and fresh, and him the norteno (?) which was absolutely excellent, and he said it was even better at 7am when he got up to shove the leftovers in his mouth sans fork. 

Atmosphere is great, I bet the view from the back is fantastic, and the food is wonderful. And great service!
author: Allison A.

description: I been here a few times for happy hour because they have decent drinks and affordable bites. Anyways, I came here one night for happy hour with my friends and we also wanted to have dinner here since the photos on yelp look delicious. However, the food did not exceed my expectations. I was hoping for something flavorful and yummy. I was left thirsty since my arroz lar mar dish was salty! Ahh. This sucks. Some of their dishes weren't on the menu anymore so that was a shame... Also, the cebiche were too sour for my liking. The squid was fishy and had a chewy texture. What made the rest of the night unpleasant was the fact that the waiter messed up splitting our bill when we wrote down how much to put on each card. He even said "TIPS are not included!" Rude much? We know how to read but the fact that he didn't split our bill accordingly and was rude about us tipping. Well, you shouldn't even deserve a tip since you weren't serving or checking up on us. Sheez.
author: Ann L.

description: This is a pretty nice place. It's gigantic compared to most restaurants around the area. I came here on a Monday night and it wasn't crowded, nor empty. The service was great, quick and courteous. The food was phenominal, but not as plentiful as I would have liked. The price is moderate, not everything was expensive, there were numerous options that weren't too pricey. I had the carne and it was delicious along with the salad, which was tasty but nothing to write home about.
author: Phan H.

description: I went to La Mar on 11/10/2012.  We got a reservation for 4 adults and 2 children and they sat us in back at a huge table near the bar.  It was nice to have the extra space, especially with the kids and the stroller.  We started off with the Pisco Sour and it was very tasty (I though the meringue was unique).  They brought a bucket of fried plantains and potatoes (potato chips).  They were thin and crispy...we polished one off and asked for another.  We ordered the cebiche which was a little different from ones I ate at other restaurants.  La Mar's version is less sour and the seafood was very fresh.  I think I could have just stuck to cebiche for dinner.  We ordered the empanadas and it came crispy and hot.  We got some other dishes but the gauge for Peruvian food is the Arroz Jugoso (called arroz con mariscos at other places).  This is a rice dish cooked with seafood.  It was very good but I have to say the Arroz Con Mariscos at Isabella's Restaurant in San Jose was better.  Overall, the service and the food was great at La Mar.  The portions are a little small so it gets expensive quick.
author: Lily L.

description:
A couple of days ago we had a lunch at La Mar. Big dining room and very pleasant outside sitting area with great views of the bay made the visit worthwhile. 
But... service was slow and not very attentive. A waiter came to the table and wrote down what cocktail each person ordered. After that another server brought our order with no idea who ordered what. That restaurant is well known for house made plantain chips but we waited more than 20 minutes to finally get them. It looked like our waiter just forgot about it.
For appetizers we ordered Cebiche Mixto and Empanada Sampler. Both were good but expensive and not big portions for the price. 
The biggest problem was with main dishes that didn't taste fresh at all. Meat was chewy, seafood deep fried to condition where I wouldn't recognize what that was if I didn't read the menu discription. 
I expected much more from such famous and expensive restaurant.
author: Laura B.

description: Delicious drinks. The pisco sour is delicious. Great scene.... The restaurant is on the water, open floorplan, well designed, and always packed. Amazing food... Order the salmon! Best entree on the menu. The mahi mahi ceviche will also rock your world. Not cheap, but worh every penny :) five stars!
author: Braden B.

description: Peruvian which was a first for us. Food was awesome. Would highly recommend skewers of octopus.  It comes with mashed potatoes with parsley. The flavor of the rub used on the octopus was soooo good. Was going to order the beef, but the waiter recommended this and he was so right.
author: Kathe P.

description:
La Mar Cebicheria- Review

Exec Summary:  Very good food with some stand out dishes, but not the best Peruvian I've had.  I prefer La Costanera in Half Moon Bay and Isabella's in south bay for a more casual setting.  La Mar's ambiance is nice, especially on a sunny San Francisco day.  The service was excellent, drinks were average and it is a bit spendy.  I'd likely go back to sample some more dishes and recommend to friends or out of towners who want to sample some unique and tasty food. Parking wasn't bad; once I located the place- right on the Embarcadero b/t Broadway and Washington, I found parking on a side street.  There is paid parking close by and I think my friends only paid $10.  

I met up with 5 of my girlfriends on Wednesday evening; we had a reservation and were seated immediately and without any issues.  A few of us had drinks and an appetizer at the bar; they have small plates around the $6 price range and drinks were around $6 dollars.  The prickly pear margarita was very pretty- it's bright pink- but I thought it could have used more tequila.  They had a decent wine list as well I was surprised that they didn't have a huge variety of salsas with our complementary plantain and sweet potato chips.  I've sampled many more Pervuian salsas and La Mar only brought out two kinds- the yellow huacaina and a red one; no green salsa that is very common in other Peruvian joints.   I didn't get around to trying their Pisco sour which was a miss on my part.   Next time!

We started with some appetizers; a tuna Ceviche Nikei; Causas and empanadas.  The ceviche was very similar to an ahi poke tuna you'd get at a Japanese restaurant; it had nice big chunks of tuna and was very fresh and flavorful.  One order of causas was super tiny and me not being a fan of potatoes, I didn't even bother trying them.  The empanadas had a thick, crunchy shell which was beautifully fried, but I had a hard time telling what the filling was because we ordered the variety plate.  I think the beef one would have been the right one to try.
For our entrees, we ordered a variety of things:  Lomo Saltado, Braised short ribs, a Sea Bass in a tamarind sauce and a seafood stew similar to a Cioppino but not as tomatoey.  And a vegetarian Quinoa Chaufa.   I've had better Lomo Saltado at the neighborhood Peruvian joint in South Bay; the beef was tender but they were a bit chunky; I prefer strips.  Interestingly, this didn't come with rice.  The braised short ribs were super moist and tasty.  This was my favorite dish; it was accompanied by a white bean and pea puree with some whole beans which was incredibly tasty.   When all the meat was gone, I cleaned that plate right up with the tasty sauce/accompaniment.  The sea bass was perfectly cooked and a nice portion size.  I like the tamarind sauce very much- savory and not too sweet. It went really well with rice we received with our order of the seafood stew.  The mussels in the stew were huge and tasty and the broth was yummy.   It would have been nice to have some bread to soak up some of the extra sauce we had.  I'm a sauce girl!  Finally, the quinoa was amazing!  It was nothing like the boring quinoa that I make at home.  The grains were a little larger and super tasty fresh.  They had some crunchy lightly friend things on top which obviously gave the quinoa a nice crunch but made the dish even better.

For dessert, we ordered the homemade ice cream with caramel marbled in with alforjores (the Peruvian cookie) which was the best one we ordered.  The ice cream was creamy and the marbled caramel and cookie combo was very tasty.  The fried plantains and sweet potato dessert with a caramel sauce wasn't as good; the crunch was off and they were a bit greasy, soggy and heavy.  We also had the panna cotta which was average.  The presentation was nice though.  
The total bill ended up being about $70 per person, which isn't too bad since we were all super full and had a couple drinks, appetizers, main courses and dessert.  I have been to other Peruvian joints- Andina in Portland which I would say is hands down the best- great ambiance (more cozy and fun), creative cocktails and very, very good food.  Isabella's in South Bay has great home cooked food in a more casual setting.   La Costanera in Half Moon Bay had slightly better food than La Mar and I like that is overlooks the ocean but their service was not as good.  

Overall, you can't go wrong with La Mar; I'd go back and try some of the other dishes and recommend it to friends as it was a nice experience with some unique food.
author: SanJoseSun D.

description:
High-end Peruvian food in a great, open, elegant yet relaxed space - yay, I'm a fan! The staff is also very friendly (our server and busser had thick accents making them difficult to understand at times - but charming nonetheless). 

Favorites: 
- Empanada sampler : SO good, the fillings were varied and delicious 
- Bunuelos de chocolate: billed as beignets, not so much, but SO tasty especially with the orange glaze 
- Waikicha: sweet and sour, and pretty to look at
- Potato and plantain chips w/ 3 sauces: complimentary, bomb!

Meh: 
- Causas: not a fan of the slightly sour whipped purple potatoes, the toppings and sauces were good though 

Note: 
- Our server insisted some dishes were already spicy, but definitely ask for extra spicy if you want to feel any heat 

Will try to sit outside next time!
author: Vicente G.

description:
Simply put, La Mar lived up to all my expectations.  Impeccable and friendly service, great atmosphere, better company and memorable food.  The menu was overwhelming having never been, but we allowed ourselves to be guided by our server and trusted her unwavering recommendations.  It was perfect -- the two of us shared cebiche chipotle (I don't think you can go wrong with any of them), causa nikei (awesome if you love ahi tuna like I do), anticuchos de pulpo (see Jason B.'s perfect review on these surprisingly delectable octopus skewers), a couple of seafood empenadas del mar (not greasy, perfect sized, delicious) and split the lomo saltado - a highlight for me.  Yes, it was a lot of food...but spread over 2+ hours with a few Peruvian libations, it was just right.  

It's no wonder this place is as lively and colorful as it is -- La Mar does it perfectly.
author: Louis M.

description: 3.5 really -- solid food but too pricey for what you get.  Seriously, the $10 cibeche was about 2 tablespoons in size, and while the lomo saltado was delicious, the portion, again was lacking (especially at $27 a dish).  Love the location and decor, but at these prices, I'll pass.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Came here with some friends without a reservation & were lucky enough to get a table! I suggest calling in for a table because the bar area is nothing compared to the inside area. There is also an outside area over looking the water. 

The food is absolutely delicious! It can be pricey, but I suggest sharing so you can try all the great food.

Dinner:
-Cebiche tasting (Clásico, Mixto, Chorrillano, and Nikei)
-Empenada sampler (4 different empenada's)
-Causa limeña (Dungeness Crab on top of a yellow potato causa with avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo Huancaína sauce and basil cilantro oil)

Dessert:
- Bunuelos de chocolate (Orange glazed chocolate beignets with banana and lemongrass ice cream)

I didn't order any of their mixed drinks, I had a house red wine instead. The cocktails all looked great, so I will definitely be getting one next time I'm there.
author: Nicole A.

description:
D-Lish! I went with my boyfriend's family to celebrate his birthday on a Sunday night - we chose this place because he had recently returned from traveling throughout South America. I had never tried Puerto Rican food and was quite impressed!

First, I started with the the Waikicha cocktail (pisco 100, pomegranate, lemon, mint), which was not only good, but artfully done with a foam layer on top and single mint leaf in the center to finish it off. Others had straight pisco (not recommended), Pisco Punch and Pisco Sour - both good. The Cebiche appetizers are a must - the seafood ones are delicious! As for entrees, all of us (4 total) got something different and ALL were amazing. 

The ambiance is nice with soft Puerto Rican music, an interesting blue light bar and a modern feel. The place was packed, but hard to notice as there's the perfect amount of space between each table, the ceilings are tall and the food is amazing! Not a good choice for recent college grads like myself since it's a tad pricey, but man was it good.
author: Katja W.

description: The food here is to die for! My favorite is most definitely the ceviche, I haven't found a restaurant that makes better ceviche than these guys. I would recommend getting a reservation though. You could probably wait for a table but I've always made a reservation and its a lot easier that way. The service is great. My only complaint would  be is that it's expensive and sometimes the dishes are really small for the price you're paying. Don't get the potato dish, all it really is is overpriced mashed potatoes. I'd come here more the price tag is special occasion only :).
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
Had a great dinner at La Mar.  Ordered the cebiche mixto - delicious - especially love the peruvian corn which really added flavor.  The empanada sampler was also yummy as well, with one each of the four empanadas offered, a bit pricey though for empanadas.  I still don't know what the dipping sauce was, but it added a little kick to the taste which was great.  For the main dish, I had the lomo saltado, which was the beef tenderloin.  Although I am not a big beef person, it was delicious!  The beef was very tender, the meat separated easily with a few touches of the fork, and when coupled with the rice with the peruvian corn, it just made my meal.

The one thing that I did not think was great was the timing of the food.  We were not even done with the appetizers and the main dishes already showed up.  I felt like I was rushed to eat.  Although they left the appetizer on the table it was already time to move on to the main dish, so I didn't get to go back to the appetizer until the end of the meal.  Room for improvement there.
author: andy w.

description: I have dined here a few times but always at lunch. The restaurant is beautiful, with modern decor & bright blue seats, so combined with all the sunlight that comes in through the windows & skylights, its really an enjoyable atmosphere on any given afternoon. With that said, the place is pretty spendy for what you get. I don't mind forking over cash for a great meal - any place, any time. But I have had quality ceviche many places & this place gives you the least for your money. Granted, it IS tasty, and I keep coming back, both for the ceviche & the empanadas...but haven't felt the need to venture there for dinner. So...will keep coming back for lunch, enjoy the place, and call it good.
author: Jen S.

description:
It seems like everyone starts reviews of restaurants on the Embarcadero with, "so my coworker wanted to come here for lunch..." or "so I was here with my family after a trip to the Ferry Building..." and I'm no exception. I came here especially for the cocktails and a light lunch, and picked it because it was within a quick F-car ride to and from the office.

Cocktail (!): Pisco punch, which is pisco brandy, lime juice, and sugar. It was invented in Victorian San Francisco (holla) and was only $5 instead of $12 thanks to Yelp's cocktail week.

The sauces really put the food over the top in this place. He had a chicken salad, but whatever delicious orange sauce was drizzled on the chicken gave it a delicious edge. I went with causa casera, which, in addition to being fun to say, is yums. It has a base of purple potato causa, which is basically potato-based dough. It looked a lot like a sushi roll, with its neat pile of artichokes, asparagus, avocado, and tomato confit with cilantro. 

An expensive payday lunch ($40 total), but a good one. Viva Sudamerica! I will definitely be back.
author: Tara R.

description: Excellent experience last night at La Mar! Date night with the husband and looking for a nice place to eat prior to a concert. We'd been to La Mar once before, and although the food was great, the service was mediocre. Last night, La Mar redeemed herself! Our fabulous waiter, Nick, was attentive to every detail of our dinner - from helping my husband choose the perfect bourbon to helping me choose the perfect entree. We ordered the ceviche la mar, empanadas sampler, short ribs and arroz la mar. Yes, we were hungry! Everything was wonderful and Nick made sure our leftovers were carefully wrapped to go and that we were on our way to our concert in time for the show. I highly recommend La Mar! And, if you've written a previous review about poor service - ask for Nick as your waiter the next time you dine here. I think you'll have a different experience.
author: Nicole C.

description: Nice view. good ambience. Mentioned anniversary dinner, and they got us table with a good view and a free dessert. good service. food is decent.
author: Ashutosh T.

description:
This was the fifth time I have been to La Mar in about 2.5 years, apart from a few stellar items on the Menu, I have to say that service levels may have gone down a notch. It may be because it is always busy, but I definitely noticed it this time. Although I will say that our server, who seemed like he wanted to run away from our table every chance he got, did go the extra mile to get a non-shellfish tainted ceviche for my severely shell-fish allergic husband.

I tried the mixed sea-food saltado and it was excellent, not as good as the lomo saltado, but still pretty damn good. The pisco cocktails are excellent as well.

Definitely try it out...a few times :)
author: Ayesha K.

description:
After hearing so many people rave about this place, I had to give it a try.  

I absoultely LOVED IT!!!

The service was friendly, the food was superb and the atmosphere was lively... everything a restaurant should be!  

We started off with the Ceviche tasting.  I think this is a great starter for those that want to try a little bit of everything just to narrow down the favorites.  Then we had the empanada sampler.  Loved all the flavors, but I think my favorite was beef.  Lastly, we tried the grilled skirt steak skewers.  It was yummy...but I think I enjoyed the samplers more so than the steak.

Overall, it was a wonderful experience.  I will definitely be back again and will share my new found joy for this place with others.  Although I can't see myself coming back every week since the prices for the food were a bit hefty... but I could see this as a nice treat a couple of times a year.
author: Vindy C.

description:
This may be one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.

The location was amazing, the atmosphere was great and the food was awesome.  The empanadas were especially great.

I highly recommend this place!
author: Mike S.
