description: When it comes to trying a new cuisine, the first experience is crucial. I had an amazing experience. The waiter provided excellent influential entrees and drinks that would convince me to come again to try the various dishes they have to provide.
author: Cherie B.

description:
My dining experience here was fabulous! Made a reservation for a team lunch on a Friday afternoon and they were very accommodating for our group of 9.

The restaurant decor is very bright, open and airy.  Reminds me of being back in Cabo.  The menu and place mats were so colorful!

Everything I ate was amazing. La Mar is now my favorite Peruvian restaurant in the city :)

I had:

2 x passion andina: very refreshing, mojito like drink.   You can definitely taste the liquor

cebiche mixto: all of the seafood was so fresh! good portion for sampling/sharing.  

rollo fashion: sushi in a peruvian restaurant? i thought that was interesting.  The roll was good but nothing out of the ordinary.

causa nikei: this dish BLEW MY MIND. WOW. I love tuna tartare in any form and this was no exception.  Something about it being on top of whipped potato just gave it the extra punch.  The presentation was also really really pretty.

ensalada playera: great lunch dish! i had a bite of my coworker's dish and it was delicious! I can't emphasis enough how fresh everything is. 

I had the ARROZ CRIOLLO.  If i can lick the bowl afterwards i would have.  This dish is the peruvian style paella. I love paella.  I usually like mine on a sizzling cast iron plate.  This dish came in a bowl and it did not disappoint.  The flavors were amazing! Even though it is described as "fried rice" it not what you think fried rice would taste like.  The rice was cooked perfectly with the right amount of seafood in it.  I ate the whole thing! What made the dish even better was the waiter telling me that they do not use butter in their cooking.  So even though I ate my entire bowl of arroz criollo i will not be in a food coma for long.

Lastly for dessert I had the crepe de chocolate.  I didn't much care for the stuffing ( lucuma mousse and chocolate ganache).  I was actually so full by then that I just ate the crepe (sans stuffing).

HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMEND LA MAR FOR HOT DATES AND WORK FUNCTIONS!!!!
author: Terry D.

description:
I am overdue to with this review, so a little hazy on the details.

Large restaurant, great location and good cocktails - recommend the Pisco Sour (of course)

Unusual menu, beautifully presented, a very pleasant evening.
author: Kevin L.

description:
It's official! La Mar is hosting a Pisco Sour day on Feb. 4th and 5th in honor of the national holiday "Pisco Sour Day" in Peru. All pisco sour drinks are just $5. Only 2 of these little treats make me a drunken mess so its a great event to take a "cheap" date. 

My love hate relationship began with pisco, not just pisco sours, on a trip to Peru in 2003. As I am always looking for a cheap alternative while backpacking, my friend and I decided to buy a bottle of Pisco from a corner store in Paracas to enjoy as we planned our tour of the Poor Man's Galapagos Islands otherwise known as Islas Balletas. Ironically, it really wasn't a bottle of pisco, but a Peruvian tradition of making your own homemade hooch and repackaging it in used water bottles. Clearly we should have stopped there, but what the hell we drank it. Never been sicker and never touched the stuff again for years. Sadly pisco was ranked with tequila as the devil's drink for about 3 years until I enjoyed one while in Mexico. Not officially a Peruvian pisco sour but not as bad (or may I say controversial) as the Chilean rip-off version. 

The La Mar Pisco Sour is nothing like my little dirty corner store version. Me encanta! La Mar carefully crafts their delicious beverage treats using only the finest ingredients: Pisco Quebranta, lime juice, simple syrup, egg white, and regional bitters. Don't be thrown off by the egg white, it creates a cappuccino like frothy top that is so entertaining to scoop with your finger. Remember Pisco is a brandy distilled from grapes, so if brandy doesn't agree with you, likely Pisco won't either. But what the hell give it a try and come out to La Mar on the 4th or 5th to try one (or five).
author: Alice S.

description:
Some things to consider before going here:

1) Although you CAN make a reservation for HH, they won't let you sit down in the restaurant if the bar is full. (Le Mar here's a tip, don't take the ressys if you can't honor them)

2) We asked to sit down in the BIG EMPTY restaurant to order drinks and apps, but were denied. We needed to order a "full meal" according to the hostess, who was a straight B--atch to my friend, really that's not necessary.

3) The bartender was actually misinformed as to when the HH stopped, and proceeded to argue with my friend who actually had an email that stated the correct times. He was WRONG. 

4) Overall the experience was ok (due to the company of my lady friends), the drinks were good, but standing in the hallway of the restaurant, and the terrible service was enough to put me off of this place. Plenty of other places in SF to get fancy cocktails and be treated nicely. 

And, FYI, we went and ate a FULL meal at Osha across the street.
author: Ingrid K.

description:
Mostly for the ambiance and design of the place, its the perfect location to take our friends out from out of town... The taste of the food was OK, it wasn't too crowded, the staff and service was very helpful making choices.  

Its quite pricey and when you're hungry, the small sauce drizzled dishes, just don't leave you completely satisfied.  Don't think I'd come back, but its worth a try.
author: Michael R.

description:
Who loves sashimi? I do! It tastes even better when it's in a sauce, ceviche style! My friend and I went to La Mar for lunch one Saturday afternoon on a bright and sunny day. The atmosphere of La Mar was fabulous! The restaurant is super clean, spacious  and modern. It contains a large patio overseeing part of the bay. With patio tables and umbella, the scene makes a sunny Saturday afternoon very relaxing and divine. 

Upon seated, the waiter brought out a basket of complimentary freshly made chips that consists of taro, yam, plantain and potato. By the way, it was the best chips I ever had! It wasn't too oily and it was filled with  flavors. It also comes with three housemade dipping sauce. 

La Mar is known for the ceviche, so my friend and I ordered a ceviche sampler since we couldn't decide among the long list. 

Starting from top left, the sampler contains ceiche nikei, which is ahi tuna in a Japanese tamarind sauce. The on top right is my favorite, cebiche chifa, which is yellowtail with peanuts in a sesame ceviche sauce. The bottom right one is cebiche mixo, which is contains mahi mahi, calamari and octopus in a ceviche sauce made with cilantro, red onion and habanero. Lastly, bottom left is cebiche clasico, which is Caifornia halibut in a classic lime and pepper sauce. 

We also ordered a pan con lomitos chimichurri, which is a sandiwch that's made with Peruvian style skirt steak strips, with tomato, avocado, onion gouda cheese and chimichurri sauce on an ACME roll. The meat is so, so tender. The gouda cheese was delicious, very smokey yet doesn't cover up the other flavor. 

La Mar is on a pricer side of a restaurant but I highly recommend it, especially on a sunny day. Sit at the patio, sip on their famous pisco sour cocktail and of course, eat some ceviche and chips...oh yea...my kind of relaxing Saturday!

Oh yes, also try their Pisco Sour. It's interestingly good!
author: Mandy C.

description: A decent Peruvian restaurant in the financial district. The cocktail and wine menu is pretty good and the ceviches are good too. I had a chance to try a range of different foods and it was all decent. But nothing special. I really like the vibe of the place in the post-work evening hours.
author: Wesley H.

description:
As my friends and I were walking down the street looking for a good lunch option, we stopped to look at the menu  and a couple came up to us and raved about how it was the most amazing food, so we went inside. 

The decor was beautiful - spacious, high ceilings, gorgeous blue detailing. The restaurant was full so we opted for bar seating (we were also starving as it was our first meal in 24 hours after flying in the night before). 

The service was pretty slow, but mainly because there seemed to just be one bartender running the bar and taking orders in the lounge. We wanted glasses of sparkling wine, but he told us they didn't have anything like that on the menu, which was odd because we noticed not one, but three other tables drinking sparkling. 

Since it was our first time, we weren't familiar with what most of the menu items meant, so we asked him to give us his favourite dish recommendations. He recommended something off the brunch menu, so I ordered the Causa limeña:

Dungeness Crab on top of a yellow potato causa (whipped potatoes) with
avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo
huancaína sauce and basil cilantro oil. 

When it came out, my friends and I were all shocked - it was the smallest amount of food I'd ever seen on a plate. Like a tiny amuse bouche appetizer instead of a main meal. For example, the "quail egg" was literally 1/16 of an egg, there was barely a sliver on my plate. The "cherry tomatoes" was ONE cherry tomato cut in half. To be fair, we hadn't realized how small this dish would be, and we were starving, so to see something so small come out as our main meal was equally hilarious/sad. 

I kind of wished the server would have jumped in and said that the portion would be quite small (obviously we were clueless about the entire menu and needed his help to even choose a drink), but I think because he was so busy he wasn't that attentive. Although it was a tiny portion (and overpriced, in my opinion), it was a delicious two bites of food.
author: Jenna S.

description: Food was fresh and inviting. Service was superb. Server was well knowledged and offered opinions.
author: Dan H.

description:
We had a group of five on a Saturday evening, so we  tried a lot of dishes. Service was attentive and the waiter knowledgeable and explained  everything you would want to know about the food and drink. Water glasses were always filled. General recommendation: go for Lunch and stick with the apps or small plates.
They  start with a cylinder bucket  full of Yam, Plantain & Potato Chips w/ 2 Housemade Dips, mild pepper based sauces one red  the other yellow. The pisco sour was a great drink to go with the chips,and it's the house specialty. Highly recommend this one.
The ceviche starters we  had were super and really we should have stayed with those and the empanada and the causas courses.  All of those  were outstanding, with unique flavors and fresh ingredients. They have a few treatments, one is the more typical Peruvian with some citrus type flavors and they also do a asian inspired  Nikei ceviche with  (Ahi Tuna, Red Onion, Avocado, Nori & Sesame) similar to a Hawaiian Poke. These were all really good and presented beautifully. The causas are a potato base  little cylinder topped with with seafood or  vegetables, these go down really smooth and creamy , great with a crisp white wine. Then the empenada or salads to finish off the meal, there you will get meat if desired or the freshness of the salads. That would have been plenty even though these courses tend to be small.

I go their arroz norteño , their version of Paella, and in retrospect I should have sent it back ,  it was  waay over salted . Not at all the caliber of the other dishes. We also got a sea bass entree and a salmon entree, which were  all  good just not as refined or exciting as the ceviche seemed to be.

As a lunch spot and especially for a visitor in town,  I would recommend this restaurant as "excellent" for their ceviche, and for their service. The atmosphere is also very inviting, right on the water, with the Bay and bridge in view.

La Mar is worth a visit, for a splurge as it will run you approx $ 40-50- pp. with  drinks and tip. The other features of La Mar  is the out door seating, which for lunch would be really an awesome lunch or snack spot, as well as the size of the place make it ideal for larger groups of 10 or more.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Ceviche at La Mar is by far the best I have tried. I later found out from an article in Time that it is the brain child of Peruvian celebrity chef Gaston Acurio. So on this trip to SF, I made a point to go again, even though I was by myself. The challenge of eating by yourself is that you can't sample a lot of the delicious food. After much debate, I settled on the two Peruvian favorites: ceviche and anticucho de corazon (grilled cow's heart). 

To start, I took the waiter's recommendation and went for ceviche de chifa. Wow, that was tasty! Mahi Mahi in sesame leche de tigre, with peanuts, Chinese onion and crispy wonton. The leche de tigre is made from 17 different ingredients. The mahi mahi was marinated in the sauce for just a couple of minutes before it is served. That is why the fish still has that sashimi freshness but also are extremely flavorful.I couldn't stop stuff it in my mouth. 

Next the anticucho de corzaon cooked to perfection. It is really easy to make it chewy, but here the heart pieces are tender but also has a bite to it. The spicy sauce they use also adds some additional kick. It is very satisfying and filling. 

I wish I had more room for other delicious food, but these two are certainly the must have in my opinion of La Mar.
author: Ally W.

description: Delicious! Had  the tuna ceviche.. It was fresh, very good. Also had the lomo saltado "sanguiche" it was my first time and I loved it. My bf had the skewers which had beef, chicken and fish. He liked it but the portion was very small. Def recommend this place.
author: Foodie G.

description: I've been here 4-5 times and LOVE it!  Love the root vegetable chips they serve before your meal with the spicy dipping sauces.  I also love the ceviches, which are super fresh and flavorful.  I'm not a huge fan of the causas and empanadas so I usually order ceviche and an entree.
author: Jen Y.

description: Very unique menu and absolutely delicious - setting is very nice and the restaurant is big with high ceilings. Definitely worth a visit!
author: Joana P.

description: Excellent meal. I sat in the bar which worked fine for me, and they offered the fu menu there. Empanadas, pisco treats, and fish skewers made for a great meal. La mar contributed to a great visit to San Fran!
author: Phil S.

description:
Peruvian food in the Embarcadero overlooking San Francisco Bay.. C'mon thats hard to beat!  The ceviche is a must here, especially the mahi mahi ceviche... which is probably the most refreshing fun food I've ever had.  I also tried the emapanada sampler, which was also delicious.  
But I really loved the pisco sours (an alcoholic drink)!  It was different than any other cocktail I ever drank and it surprisingly creeps up on you.  I was little tipsy after my second one.  You need to try this place, or else your missing out on a true culinary gem in SF.
author: Emmett B.

description:
I have been at La Mar 2 times already and is by far the best cevicheria I have been in SF bay area.

They have all kinds of cevice and of course all sort of food as well. The service is a little slow at times but it does get crowded. 

This cevice unlike the Mexican ceviche. It has what they call Leche de Tigre (Tiger's milk) which of course is not really but is a mix of lemon juice and other stuff instead only lemon juice. 

The fish of course is very fresh, I dont think I will get tired of this place....
author: Claudia D.

description: Don't go anywhere else for empanadas.  They are really good here.  I dined at La Mar with my Peruvian friends.  They know what to order but the best was the empanadas.
author: Wendy K.

description:
When the crowds and lines at the Ferry Plaza Market start getting you down and your stomach is rumbling . . . sneak over to La Mar for some of SF's best waterfront dining! 

I'm not entirely sure how this happened but, I had never had a Causa before La Mar. The bartender talks me into the Causa sampler. Dear GWAD. I died and went to heaven. Hands down the best potato snack I have ever had. In fact I dream about them now. We also had some banging Scallops in a mint & clam broth. The service was spot on and the Peruvian styled drinks flowed like water. 

La Mar, when are you coming to LA???
author: Deidre H.

description: Had dinner here last month for a friend's birthday. Good food, the waiter was giving good service and was being helpful.
author: Sunli G.

description:
Came here for my birthday with my beautiful peeps and it was an embarrassment of riches when you combined the people, the atmosphere and the food (and the service was utterly attentive).

The fish in any form or fashion was amazing but the real surprise was their dessert. I'll let you guess which one but very in line with one I had at the French Laundry...
author: Raul L.

description: Top notch Peruvian restaurant. Beautiful food. Great quality, presentation, and flavors.  I've had a lot of Peruvian food, but this takes place really takes the cake. Big menu, lots of things to try. Great for a cozy dinner or a night out with friends or colleagues. Cocktails were good, wine list also good, and food was exceptional.  I'll definitely be coming back again and again.
author: Bonny B.

description: Overpriced food. Entrees are the size of appetizers. I paid $20 for 3 little pieces of octopus and an extra $5 for tiny little fried balls of yucca as a substitute for potatoes. The waiter had such a snobby attitude like he was doing us a favor by just being there.
author: Linda R.

description: When for lunch on Thursday. The food was good but wasn't great. The service was good. All the food look pretty decorated but the portion is small compare to the price. It's good place for chit chat snack on. If you expect something to fill you up, it definitely not this place. Good food but not worth the price.
author: Erica J.

description:
I love the food here: I've been a regular since it pretty much opened and the quality has not suffered a bit over the years. The seafood is fresh and tasty, the presentation is fun and colorful and the place is always teaming with the A- crowd.

Two stars off because I went here on a Monday night a couple of weeks ago and we were rushed by the waitress who could not get us out of there fast enough even if we were not the last table in the restaurant and we spent $400+ on the meal and drinks. She was bordering on aggressive and that really threw a wet blanket on an otherwise tasty meal.
author: Tudor H.

description:
I can't stop thinking about the cebiches and the bestest bloody mary I've ever had at La Mar.  I love the food, the decor, the view, and the atmosphere.  Its located right on the water, got awesome drinks, outdoor seating, and will make you feel like life is just a breeze.  A great spot for date night I must say.

My favorites:
-Cebiche tasting: Mixto, Chifa, Nikei and Clásico (The national dish of Peru, made with the freshest fish and shellfish, briefly marinated in "leche de tigre" (lime juice and peppers) 
-Causas tasting: Limeña, Criolla, Nikei, Casera (traditional Peruvian whipped potato with ají amarillo and seafood toppings)
-Lomo saltado (traditional Peruvian style stir-fry of sautéed beef tenderloin, onions, tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic with fried potatoes and rice.)
-Cordero (Braised lamb shank, mashed rice and lima bean tacu tacu,
seco limeno (cilantro sauce).)
-Bloody lorcho (pisco quebranta, home-made bloody mary mix, and octopus)
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Mmmm mmmm mmmm! I LOVE sea food and this place here is a party in your mouth!!!! I get here for happy hour, get a pisco or two while I wait for a table and try to have something new from the menu every time. So far I have not bee disappointed! Come with a date or with friends. If it's a nice day, make sure to sit outside!

*Just note that the servings are small compared to other places, but it makes up the bitty sizes with good drinks and an great location next to the water.
author: Fredo L.

description:
I love Peruvian food so after seeing the reviews on Yelp! this place was getting I had to try it. 

As always whenever I go to a Peruvian place I order empandas, Lomo Saltado, ceviche, and Chicha Morada. Everything at La Mar tasted good, but the flavor of the food wasn't spectacular enough to justify the price and portion size to make me a regular here. I mean I spent $100 for two people when a comparable meal at say Limon is roughly half.

I'll give it 3 stars since it's worth a try, but only the uber rich can make this a regular dining spot.
author: Francis A.

description: La Mar is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  We did the corporate dinner thing for a group of about 10 of us, and they put together an awesome, varied menu at a great table near the back.  Service was professional, the drinks were fun, and the food was delicious (with the possible exception of the desserts, which largely went uneaten).  Easy pick, especially when the company is footing the bill :)
author: Laurence W.

description:
This place was simply amazing! The ambiance and the music I just loved.
The pizco punch is really really good. My husband got a drink with more of a kick and although it was strong it was pretty good. 

We ordered the cebiche mixto which was everything I expected and more. I am a ceviche feen and am very critical on anyone else's ceviche lol. I've also had ceviche food poisoning so I was a bit iffy about trying it since it wasn't fully cooked in lemon. It's more like sashimi. I did not get sick after and it was the best cebiche we've ever had.

We also ordered empanadas de lomo saltado. My husband was convinced these wouldn't be good since he just loves my empanadas so much and anywhere else we've gone they are just not that great.....these empanadas blew mine out of the water. They were so flaky and light. Perfectly seasoned. Amazing!

I had the octopus skewers and they were also very very good! My husband had something with filet mignon. It was a traditional Peruvian dish. He just about died and went to heaven. I had a bit and this was so good! Not too sure the sauce they use but whatever it is-wow!
This Peruvian- Asian fusion thing they have going works so well together. I can't wait to come back to SF and make a stop here. I will be recommending this place to every person I know coming up here. 

Please La Mar open a location in San Diego!!! Lol
author: Erica T.

description: Monday? Wednesday? Saturday? Any day, any mood is La Mar time! Fresh seafood and fun atmosphere. The Causas are amazing!
author: Maria C.

description: In summary overpriced so-so food. There are other Peruvian restaurants in the city that serve food which is much more flavorful. Had I not experienced another restaurant in the city that has awesome food I would have thought the food at La Mar was good, but I guess I'm spoiled now. The location of La Mar is great and the service is good, but food is just OK. I probably won't be back.
author: Elzabeth G.

description:
Came here for my birthday during happy hour right before we headed off to the Giants game. Their happy hour prices are extremely fair, but we still managed to spend about $20-30 each. I was looking forward the most to the cebiche and the causa, but both were just okay. Nothing spectacular.

The restaurant itself is beautiful, but their food is just average.
author: Lily Z.

description:
I loved this place!
4 - 6 HAPPY HOUR!  Pisco Sours for half price!  I was drunk after half of one.  Bar is super crowded though.  And sports a financial district vibe, but I didn't let that stop me.  
Cebiche was amazing!  It was all about the octopus!  I could straight DRINK the sauce.  In fact, next time I will, as they do offer their sauces as SHOTS!  
I can't wait to come back here.
author: Zman S.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner a couple years ago. (Yea I'm catching up on all the reviews). My co workers recommended me this place and I decided to give it a try. I guess I'm not a fan of Peruvian food. My favorite dish was the plantain chips served on the side...... All the other dishes we ordered tasted plain. Not impressed. The waiter was polite and the service was good. He packed our food at the end. But we will not go back there.
author: Bob H.

description: Amazing service, deck and food!!! Have no idea what the menu said but our waitress gave us great recommendations.
author: Chloe C.

description:
I really admire the bright blue and green color theme of this restaurant, it makes the atmosphere feel lively. There is an abundance of windows for natural lighting and ceilings are high, so it makes this restaurant look and feel spacious. There is plenty of seating inside the restaurant and outside on the patio. 

Highlights
Cebiche is listed as an item to try here for The Big Eat SF 7x7. 
-Cebiche Tasting: Mixto, Chifa (Mahi Mahi with peanuts, scallions, ginger, pickled carrots and daikon, mango, habanero, wonton strips and cilantro in pineapple leche de tigre), Clásico, and Nikei (Ahi tuna, red onion, & Japanese cucumber in tamarind leche de tigre). I wasn't too pleased with the Mixto and Clásico, but I highly recommend their Chifa and Nikel (we ordered additional orders of these two items). 

-Causa limeña: Traditional Peruvian whipped potato w/dungeness crab, avocado purée, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo Huancaína sauce with basil cilantro oil. Absolutely divine. *Favorite along with the two aforementioned cebiche dishes deserves my 4 stars*

-Anticuchos de pollo:Grilled chicken skewers, potatoes, peruvian corn, salsa panchita. Nothing special to note, it was really orange and a bit too blackened for my liking. 

-Lomo saltado: Traditional Peruvian style stir-fry of sautéed beef tenderloin, onions, tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic with fried potatoes and rice. Overly salty, but the beef was pretty tender. 

-Buñuelos de chocolate caliente: Orange glazed chocolate beignets with banana and passion fruit ice cream. Delicious! 

- Some type of coffee/chocolate Mousse: Divine. *Favorite dessert of the day*

We also ordered a special fried rice dish of the day, but it was quite salty like most of the entree dishes that I tried here. Service was very attentive and our waiter was informative in suggesting dishes to try. 

P.S. It gets pretty busy during lunch, so make reservations. Parking is limited to all the lots surrounding this restaurant, but they do validate parkting here.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Good food, great drinks, fantastic location.

Had a great time at La Mar, starting with happy hour and ending with dinner. Everything we tried was great - and we ordered a lot. The empanandas and ceviche were my especially yummy.
author: Michelle D.

description: For my first immersion into Peruvian food . . . amazing experience. Fortunately I was seated with food writer Virginia Miller (The Perfect Spot), her husband Dan and my friend Cathy. We did get a lot of VIP treatment so my opinion is obviously colored. That said . . . the infusion of so many different taste profiles was truly wonderful. If you going to be in SFO this is a "must visit" restaurant on the water near Ferry Building.
author: Martin M.

description: Good food, but for the price, not too great. Service was really bad. Gave us the check before desert. Restaurant was half empty for lunch, but we were still rushed.
author: Suren E.

description:
Pricey, yes, but everything about this place is top notch.  Food is fantastic (ceviche, causas, and lomo saltadoa are stand outs).  Drinks are equally fantastic (have to have several Pisco Sours).  Only thing to be cautious of is the noise, it can get quite loud when they're at full service.  

Place is best for large groups, especially business parties.  Outdoor back patio is best.
author: Matt C.

description:
very fun place to celebrate with your friends. Food is exotic and beautiful. I'd have to confess that I went home and had some more food;) this food is for play and fun and not for overcoming hunger.

Beautiful restaurant. Cute waitresses and very delightful food.
author: T I.

description: We went to this place for a friends birthday. The food was amazing but very expensive and the portions were small. We had a set menu and for the price we paid I really was still hungry at the end of the dinner. We had like 5 different types of food and a couple deserts and a couple of appetizers come out for the table. The place has a lot of room and the environment was pretty trendy. The drinks were very extravagant and a great selection of beers too.
author: Pejman A.

description:
I've only been for drinks, so I can't comment on the food, but based on the drinks alone, I'm giving this place 4 stars! They have some amazing Peruvian concoctions, that scared me a little on the menu, but wow -- they really know what they're doing! Definitely try the Pisco Punch and the Pisco Sour. 

Oh also, just an FYI, we walked in dressed VERY casually, and sat at the front bar (it was early and pretty empty), but the rest of the restaurant looks a bit dressier.
author: A H.

description: The ceviche tasting menu is so memorable that had I not photographed the entree, it would be the only thing I remember from the meal.  Service was excellent and the ambiance and decor are beautiful.  There's a stylish lounge area with couches when you walk in, which would be a great spot to just grab a drink amidst some fancy people.  A convenient parking lot at the adjacent pier makes for a pretty easy parking option.
author: Tara C.

description:
A few weeks ago my friend and I ventured here for his birthday. He wanted to go somewhere scenic where we could also drink. I had always wanted to go to La Mar and made the suggestions. Great Pisco sours. Nice and frothy, the only way to make a girl who is sometimes hurt by citrus take it in like it ain't nothin'. 

In addition to drinks we also ordered the ceviche mixto. I thought it was a great helping and pretty good. Lots of fresh fish and the sauce was unique and creamy...almost like a very light curry. My date didn't like it as much because he prefers the lime, lemon, and onions approach to ceviche and didn't like the creamy juice the fish were in. I think I like both. 

Though that was only a small trip. I really really hope that I get to visit La Mar again soon for a full fledged dinner.  I have heard so many things, and man would I love to sit by the water.
author: Alexandra M.

description: If you are not Peruvian! You don't know what are you paying for? Very disappointed, the food is not real Peruvian is a mix of everything except for being real Peruvian food, host and servers must know about the menu, takes forever to get an order. Is not cheap for what are you paying, I don't know why you can called it gourmet, Is always about quality and not quantity. Happy hour there is the worse. Stop tricking customer with this type of food.
author: Juan M.

description:
I should probably recuse myself, as I'm invariably disappointed by Peruvian food, but I'm just so annoyed that all the raves made me violate my no-Peruvian policy and give it a try, thereby wasting one of my oh-so-rare, successfully-guilt-the-BF-into-taking-me-out-for-a-romantic-dinner opps. 

They claimed not to have our reservation, even though I had a print-out of the Open Table confirmation in hand. The restaurant--what we saw of it as we were whisked through to the patio--looked lovely. Like others, we too had difficulty attracting and sustaining our waiter's interest. The food looked beautiful but was so bland that we simply lost interest midway through and cancelled whatever hadn't yet been delivered (unusual, but at those prices...). So, it's probably me, not you. But if you like bold-flavored ethnic, be forwarned. I lost a lot of street cred with the BF that night.
author: Faith A.

description:
Went to La Mar with some friends. Started with happy hour snacks and drinks and then moved onto dinner. Pretty disappointed. Bar was like an oven, and they wouldn't let you move to patio or anywhere else until 5:30, so we baked and starved. Snacks were 1/2 price but they contained VERY little food. So-called sliders were tiny slices of bread with an even tinier sliver of meat and some shaved lettuce - really a bit of a joke. Ceviches were all tiny. Ended up spending a lot more than expected because we had multiple orders (guess that was the plan).

Also, I tried their Pisco Sour. I am a bit of a Pisco snob and know a great Pisco Sour when I taste it (try Fonda's in Berkeley- fantastic). This one wasn't. Not very sweet or sour and I think they used mediocre quality pisco. I never thought you could have a bad one, but this one verged on bad. Very frothy (too much egg white - cheaper than actual liquor, I guess), with little taste and pisco tasted on the edge of harsh.

Went to the patio for dinner. Greeter was pretty unfriendly (bald young guy with glasses and an unfriendly look). Waiter was professional and nice, but food was overpriced and ridiculously small portion. I order Lomo Saltado ($34) and got about 4 small cubes of meat over some french fries. After eating still had a half a plate full of onions (most expensive onions I've had). Clearly they pile your plate will cheap stuff and give you rice and onion filler. Guess they think their customers are stupid and won't notice being ripped off.

Nice to sit on the patio with a breeze and a drink, but you definitely PAY for the privilege.

I WON'T be back.
author: Peter D.

description: Delicious!! Came here for dinner and also another time for their happy hour from 3-6 pm.  The pork belly sandwich is truly amazing and melt in your mouth tender.  Their selection of ceviches and other dishes are top notch.  Drinks are great - I loved their pisco sours, cucumber gimlet, etc.!   Will come back again..and again....and again!
author: SHOU LIN C.

description:
All we had was delicious and fresh. I can totally recommend all kinds of ceviche in this place because they were so fresh and yummy. Also another favorite of mine was the beef heart prepared very tender and the variety of corn which is very common in peru.
drinks are also great at this place and since the waiting for the tables are long if all of your group are not there, they also have a nice bar.
author: Visda G.

description: This is the best peruvian food that I have tried in a while. The service is a little to slow sometimes but the servers are really nice. They have a good location and the ceviches are great.
author: Sandra V.

description:
Came here with visitors from out of town on a recommendation from a concierge at one of the Hyatt's in San Francisco. Ho-lee-shazbot this place rocked. I think since someone else picked up the tab I have no problem giving this restaurant 5 stars (otherwise the expense might have pushed me to give them 4 stars - I'm a cheap date).

We decided to make a go of trying a bunch of the different appetizer sized plates on the menu. We ordered a ceviche sampler plate, an empenada sampler plate and a causas sampler plate. We also ordered a few anticuchos (steak and mahi mahi). Everything was unbelievably delicious. Each of us had different favorites, but generally the anticuchos and the ceviche were the favorites of the table.

We also ordered some peruvian cocktails and beer. The two peruvian beers they have are pretty good and the cocktails they offer are amazing. The pisco sour is really, really good. And the pisco punch was also popular at the table. The beers (cusquena and cristal) went well with the food and we thought they were pretty decent.

Desserts had to be ordered after a meal of such excellence. Their Bunuelos weren't quite beignets like any of us had seen before, but they were still delicious. The cappuccino de tres leches and the suspiro limeno were also really well liked with the suspiro limeno being my personal favorite.
author: Ahmad A.

description: I have eaten here before with no problems.  But never go during happy hour. By far the worst service I've ever experienced in SF.  I will never go back or recommend it to and of the patrons from the hotel I work at.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Went here for a whim with my girlfriends.  The location is waterfront and parking somewhat easy  (when meters are not being monitored) if you don't mind walking a bit.   

We arrived on time for our reservation and we were seated promptly.  The decor to me seem a bit dated (reminded me of a cruise ship).  The service was average - nothing spectacular. The restaurant concept was upscale peruvian seafood.  We tried the causa casera: purple potato causa, artichokes, asparagus, avocado and tomato with basil cilantro oil.  The Ensalada Nikei (which didn't have half the vegetables it said on the menu). Anticucho De Carne grilled skirt steak, potatoes, peruvian corn, spicy rocoto sauce (mmm - meat on stick but very skimpy meat). And finally Jalea crispy mahi mahi, calamari and octopus with plantains, yucca, peruvian corn chalaca salsa and house made tartar sauce which we referred to as the "Captain's fried platter."  

The food was A-OK.  Nothing to write home about....if it didn't have the peruvian names there wouldn't be anything peruvian about the food except for the causa.  While it satisfied the hunger and the quanity was sufficient for the price I don't think I would come back...Major negative: the cocktails were watery and not very flavorful!  

So many other places to try...
author: Lea G.

description:
La Mar was our best dinner during our stay in San Francisco. The restaurant is beautiful--it was busy and bustling on a Tuesday night. The specialty drinks are on point and delicious. The cebiche tasting is a MUST. Four very different types of cebiche that is deliciously prepared and tasted so fresh. We also tried the sea bass sashimi, which was delicious as well. 

I had the Arroz Norteno and it was HUGE. Full of seafood and flavor. 
My Mister had a new special of lamb chops with quail eggs and risotto. An absolute culinary dream! 

Servers, hostesses, and managers were all so knowledgeable and friendly. I recommend La Mar for a great culinary experience. I am getting hungry for La Mar just thinking of it!
author: Aliah D.

description:
I really wanted to like this place: it's super convenient to my new grownup job, serves wine and lots of small plates, and I am a huge seafood fan.  I was even willing to look past the exorbitant prices now that said grownup job enables me to afford the occasional splurge.  The space itself is grand, and walking in with a friend from NYC, I thought, hey, my city's cleaning up nice for our out of town guest.

Trouble is, the food is just not that great.  Perhaps it's a side effect of the gigantic menu or of the can't-fail location?  Either way, we wound up spending more than a hundred bucks for what amounted to a mediocre snack.  (Along with a decent amount of wine, admitted.)  Most importantly, some of my ceviche tasted less than fresh.  I felt fine afterwards, but when you're slurping down mostly raw things you don't want to have to question that for even a minute.  I'd suggest you do your slurping elsewhere, e.g. Limon in the Mission.
author: Elisabeth D.

description: I love La Mar! So much so, that I went twice in one week once I was introduced to this restaurant by a co-worker. The food is fresh, well seasoned, beautifully plated, and perfectly portioned. The assorted chip basket at the beginning is also a nice change of pace from the usual bread and butter or chips and salsa. I will definitely add this to my list of places to go for lunch when the weather calls for a nice, long, relaxing lunch break.
author: Cortney S.

description: Came back with my daughters last sat. I remembered the drinks were super good here. So I was excited to have their drinks. But unfortunately, this time around, their drinks were meh.....not so good...hmm, I wonder what happened? The food was still delicious and the waiter we had was awesome!!  But still, the parking, prices & now the drinks r bad....hmm...maybe I gotta find another place for good peruvian cocktails.....
author: Alyce l.

description:
Dined here with some of my New Yorker friends and it was a divine night.  Started at the hip and trendy bar with some rounds of Pisco Sour.  Definitely a must-order if you come here. 

For Dinner,we ordered:
Ceviche Tasting - DIVINE
Grilled Tombo Tuna
Beef Hearts
Dessert Sampler

My friends were in charge of the wine selection and the wine paired well with everything we ate.  LOVE LOVE the food, ambiance, and service.

Come here if you want to impress your guests or need a fix for Peruvian food.
author: Jackie D.

description:
The location is the prize for this restaurant. The building itself is lovely and the decor is surprisingly contemporary. The menu looks great, a little on the pricey side for what you get (but this should be expected, given the location - you are paying for the view!). Service was outstanding. 
My biggest disappointment was that the food was hardly authentic Peruana. Fine, we are in California, but having traveled the entire country I was hoping for some more comida autentica!!! Oh well. It all tasted delicious and I would have given them more stars if the value had been there. They do have a fantastic cocktail menu with lots of local Peruano ingredients, including Inka Cola HA!
author: Carrie L.

description: Some girlfriends and I l had heard great reviews about this place and decided to check it out.... The food was AWESOME!!! It was G R E A T ! But the bartender (or mixologist)... (White guy- tall one- with a well trimmed beard- Sunday night) said he bought one of our drinks but REALLY added another drink to our bill. So NOT COOL! Not ok!!!!
author: Liliana B.

description:
Went here with a small group for my coworkers goodbye dinner. It was my first time and I've been wanting to dine for since they first opened. It's a bit confusing when you first walk in the doors. To your left is a bar. To your right is a one person restroom that EVERYONE including employees use and there's a line for it. 

As you walk past this, there is yet another bar to your right. You pass that and in front of you is the dining area. To your right is ANOTHER bar. 

This place is known for the Pisco drinks. I didn't try any but one friend from the group did and he liked it enough to buy another one.

They ordered a few ceviches and empanadas and we all shared it. Each dish I tried was really good!

For my entree I got the lomo saltado. It was strips of steak with onions and tomatoes. Fries were sitting on top. It came with a side bowl of white rice with garlic pieces in it. I mixed that in with the sauce and it was yummy!

Hubby got the chorillana (red snapper). There was a small mound of mashed potatoes next to it. This was pretty good too.

Coworker that was leaving got the short ribs. This was the best dish this night. The meat was so tender and flavorful. 

For dessert, we got the tres leches. This came in a champagne flute. I thought this was a bit on the pricey ($11) side. Reading the description on the menu, it was sponge cake with chocolate and creme brulee. I just imagined these layered together. 

What I didn't like was that the sponge cake was all mushy and soaked up all the liquid. Imagine throwing a piece of spongecake into the blender/food processor.  

Don't get me wrong, it still tasted good. 

This place is very spacious. You're not too close to the table next to you. I recommend sitting in a booth. Maybe that's just my preference.

Service was friendly and timely.

Parking- If you're lucky enough to find street parking (meter) make sure you have PLENTY of quarters. 

We parked in the lot in the next building. They have valet and self park. It's a bit tight here. Don't get valet unless you're a terrible parker. We chose to park our car ourselves. You enter and the guy comes out and asks if you want valet. It's $5 an hour for self park and you pay upfront. You also lock up your car and keep your own keys. He gives you a receipt to put on your dshboard. I told him we would be there around 2 hours.

It's a good thing I looked at my receipt. It expired like 4 hours ago and was paid with a MC. I went to him and he played dumb and asked "yes???" I asked for another receipt and he says "oh yea.....I gave you the wrong receipt. Here's your real receipt." Ummmm...... 

Anyways we went a lil over our two hours and they didn't charge us extra. Yay! 

Now....I have to go back with some gf's.

Look there is no Peruvian food anywhere so I will go back  Just to be clear, not as good as Gastron's places I went to in Lima.  Not  close.

Cebiche -- very good (you can't find it up here)
Corazon -- not good (yes, I like beef heart usually)
Empanadas -- the beef empanadas were good, the others just ok
Causa Limena -- awesome
author: Craig R.

description:
went here last night and decided to get the ceviche, empanada's and the causas tasting menu. They were all really good, but some of them were better than others. 

Ceviche's-  the one's that stood out to me was the ceviche nikei which consisted of  Ahi Tuna, red onion, Japanese cucumber, daikon, avocado, nori, and sesame in tamarind leche de tigre and the other one i liked was the ceviche mixto (but can be a bit spicy if you don't usually eat spicy foods). The mixto had Mahi Mahi, calamari and octopus in ají amarillo leche de tigre with cilantro, red onion, habanero with Peruvian corn and yam. (They top the ceviche's with a habanero pepper, so take it off before you eat it or it'll burn up your mouth and you can kiss your taste buds goodbye).

Among the causas tasting I liked the causa chicharrón that had fried calamari, quail egg, avocado purée, salsa criolla on top of a purple potato puree and huancaína tartar sauce on the side, very yummy.

The causa limeña was also really good you can taste the freshness of the crab.

We ordered the special of the day which was a steak with sauteed mushrooms, and some vegtables along with the anticucho de carne- which is a grilled skirt steak skewer. Came with fried potatos and peruvian corn. The beef was incredibly tender and cooked to perfection.

We had 4 empanada's, but the chicken and beef were the best in my opinion. The shrimp i thought was very bland, and the corn was only okay, but I'm don't like the texture of the peruvian corn. 

you should get the sangria (which isn't on the menu) and a pisco sour- strong, but very sweet.
author: Jessica L.

description:
#47 on 100 Things to Eat Before I Die if SF: Ceviche and a Pisco Sour

GO NOW!  

I mean, in a nutshell, that's all you need to know.  This place has fantastic ceviche.  And our Pisco Sours were the perfect accompaniment.  Citrusy, tangy, fresh, delicious.

We tried two ceviches: 

the Cebiche Chipotle with scallops, calamari, shrimp, red onion, cilantro, habanero, in a chipotle leche de tigre with Peruvian corn and yam

AND

the Cebiche Nikei with Ahi Tuna, red onion, Japanese cucumber, in tamarind leche de tigre.

The Chipotle was a-MAY-ZING.  GO NOW.  No, I mean, you shouldn't even be reading this last sentence - NOW!
author: Tamar D.

description:
Chose this restaurant b/c a member of our party (Jo) knew a staff member. 

Restaurant was quite full for a Monday night. 8p reservations for a party of 4 (me, J, E, Jo). Only I had dietary restrictions. Walked in at 7:30p and were told we would have to wait. I suggested we wait at the bar. Seemed like no one wanted to order drinks, so  I walked into the restaurant, found a table, went back to the hostess and informed her I saw an empty table & I have a back issue and wanted to be seated. She complied right away (after asking if all of our party was here - didn't she see us the first time?). After putting in drink orders, 2 Pisco Sours, 1 Passion Andrina, 1 Desayuno Peru, a server brought us a complimentary basket of sweet potato, potato and banana chips with 3 dips. The dips - ranging from hot, medium to mild spice - were delicious.  We ordered the following:

1. Cebiche Tasting - J, E, Jo all enjoyed.
2. Causa Tasting - scrumptious - must order. There is one vegetarian causa. I ordered an extra - costs $5.
3. Empanada Sampler - 1 vegetarian empanada (corn). One extra cost $3. The corn empanada is sweet and perfectly fried. 
4. Seco Cordero - Lamb shank - meat so tender, falling off the bone - worth the long wait per my friends.
5. Ant. Pulpo -  octopus on a skewer 
6.  Enormous plate of ahi tuna with sauce served at one point - compliments of the chef. 

Bathroom was clean. Stark decor (black and white tiles). Restoration Hardware?

I would give 2.5 stars for the service (seemed hurried & no one offered suggestions) and 4 stars for the food. Everyone at the table seemed happy with our choices. Delicious potatoes (causa) and corn (empanada).  Not many options for vegetarians, though I didn't try the quinoa entree or salads (I refuse to order salad when I eat it daily at home). At one point, before the main entree (took a LONG time for the lamb to arrive), the server brought cocktail menus, which I found amusing (I'm a teetotaller) since no one in our party was a big drinker.

Portions were small. J & I ate beforehand, so we weren't hungry when we arrived and left feeling good.

We sat in an elevated booth (bench one side/ chairs the other side). 
Cushioned bench comfortable.

Total tab for 4 people including 3 drinks & 18% tip = $206.61

Tip calculations (15%, 18%, 20%) printed on bill. We decided to give 18% b/c of Jo's connection, Manuel. He inspired me to change the original order of arroz norteamericano (with seafood) to the lamb (seco cordero).

Found parking across the street due to luck. Spots taken quickly - even on a Monday night.

4 out of the 6 items on our table were due to Yelp reviews. It pays to do research beforehand. Thanks Yelp!
author: Grace C.

description:
Oh la La Mar! Oh you exquisite dream on the palate.  You dare me to come back and experience again your succulant flavors of aquatic life dining.  Is that laying it on a bit thick?....NO

I brought my girlfriend here on her birthday and we were both pleasantly satisfied with our food experience.  For starters we had the Causa Limena (how do you put the thingy over the n?)  The presentation of the dish was clean and enticing.  The creamy avocado puree worked well with the dungeness crab and mixed with the basil cilantro oil to give a fresh, light even flavor. 

Our 2 main courses were the Atun (how do you accent the u? I am symbol illiterate, not to be confused with imbecile literate) and the Arroz Parihuela.  I just have to say, hands down, I should have just ordered 2 of the Arroz Parihuela.  The paella-esk dish was outstanding with it's rich mix of seafood amidst the aji panca and aji amarillo risotto.  It was a meal to warm the stomach with goodness and happy fuzziness.  Good call girlfriend!

Not to dissuade you from ordering the Atun (damn yous accented u's!).  The ahi tuna was seared to perfection and the honey sesame sauce, along with the bok choy, gave it an asian fusion flavor.  However, because I had eaten so much tuna over the course of the week, I had overloaded my palate already with too much tekka.  Note to self, eating too much of something in a week is probably not a good idea, unless they're bananas. mmmmm....bananas, banana milkshake, banana fritters, banana cream pie, fried banana and coconut icecream...uh, excuse me, I digress.

As for drinks, I simply had sparkling water, since I am considered a non-alcoholic being.  My girlfriend had the Chicha Tu Sour...hee hee I said chicha.  Judging from her reaction, it was a splendid aperitif...see I can use big words too.

Now, I do have to deduct one star for spotty service.  Our waiter was amicable enough, but he had a strange tendency to not address my girlfriend directly...that's a no no.  He also didn't pour my bottled sparkling water...not that I'm not strong enough to open my own bottle and heft it up to pour it (that's right, I lift some weights), but at an establishment like this, it's expected of the waiter.  That's it, small complaint. No biggie.

Look, just go there.  It's great for groups, it's great for romance, it's great for single dining and people watching (if that's your thing, just saying) Enough said.  In the words of the great Starsky played by Benjamin MF Stiller...Do it.
author: Ehb T.

description: Stopped in last Saturday when looking for a place with a view of the water for lunch.  Food was ok, service was terrible,  server did not bring the chips and had to hunt her down to pay the bill so we could leave.   The view was nice but will get that elsewhere next time.
author: Karen D.

description: Heard a lot of great things about this place, my husband and I had our second date here...and the food was so-so/good. Portions were on the smaller side and expensive for the quantity. We get it, its SF and a busy place...beautiful decor and ambiance, I definitely would try it again for the food...nice place to have cocktails;)
author: Joshua And Rose-Marie E.

description:
ceviche! ceviche! 

the first time i tried la mar was at the sf street food fest and it left a major impact! i had their halibut ceviche (clasico) that was amazing...i wanted to slurp up the juices! i was so happy that i finally got to come in and get the sampler, which included the infamous halibut, along with the mixto (yellowtail, calamari, & shrimp - my second favorite, great combo of sour & spicy), chalaco (yellowtail, mussels, clams, scallops, & shrimp), and nikel (tuna - poke-esque). we then had the empanada sampler - steak, corn, mushroom, & chicken. the corn and mushroom tasted like the same thing, so i'm not sure if they actually were. the chicken and steak were so tender and flavorful!

i was so happy to experience the actual restaurant and would love to come back for more!
author: Marjie T.

description:
My friend Carol said I had to try this place so we went there last Wednesday for happy hour. I was a bit concerned about how the experience would turn out when our server struck me as uppity and inattentive. 

I hate to say it but this place knows nothing of Empanadas. They served me a deep fried lump of thick hard crust with a bite of non descript filling for $5. It was too small to share and there were 3 of us so it would have been $15 to get one each.  No thanks! 

In South America the Empanadas were hand made and had a thin flakey fresh crust and were filled with tasty meat and veggies and baked in a wood fired brick oven and cost 50 cents each. Okay I know it's San Francisco, but please! I wouldn't eat another if they were free. I won't even comment on the spring rolls. I've had better from the frozen food department at the grocery store. 

Okay the civiche bar looked like it might be fun and back deck was really nice and I only had a few appetizers and a sangria which was okay so I can't comment on what the whole dinner experience would be like, but I can say that the appetizers should encourage one to stay for dinner not to leave in disappointment.
author: Michael L.

description:
I have tried to like this place but after 5 experiences I have to drop them to a 1 star based on their reservations and service. There are so many more places less stressful to deal with in SF. The final blow was making my friend's 86 year old grandmother stand for 20 mins for bar service, not dinner, bar service because her nephew was running late. 

Between Myra doing group reservations (my company no longer uses La Mar due to her behavior) and the hostesses the lack of total class is appalling in a city full of wonderful dining experiences.

This review is for regular dining and for groups of 8 or more. 4 stars for less than 8, 1 star for 8 or more diners.

Groups less than 8 people:

4 stars - The food, service and design are all excellent. La Mar has an extensive menu and the wait staff is very knowledgeable.  If you can get a table on the outdoor deck on a warm day there are few better spots in SF!  La Mar is also a good spot for local celebrity sightings.

8 or more people

1 star. If you need to seat 8 or more people I highly recommend anywhere else but La Mar. You have to go through Myra in event planning and she is completely unprofessional. No follow up, incorrect dates for the reservation and fairly rude as a person. Unfortunately, reservations will not be able to help you at all and you are stuck with this lady. It is not worth it  - especially with Epic in the same area. Epic on the other hand provides fantastic service for group events.
author: James H.

description:
MAHI MAHI! Would have been 5 stars, I take off one and a half (but rounded down) for ... poor/nonexistent service. 

Tis another interesting dining experience with Sandra C. and Anita T. for dinner this evening... interesting dining experiences seem to follow me around, rather than the two ladies I dined with... 

We arrived an hour before our actual reservation, but the restaurant wasn't too crowded for a rainy Wednesday evening. The decor in the restaurant is beachy... bright colors and adds personality to the otherwise warehouse/lofty looking room. We order the pisco punch for our drinks to start. 

Our waiter announced the specials... rather than reciting them from memory, he read them off of some list he had with him - odd.  He emphasized MAHI MAHI several times when reciting the specials and also when he 'recommended' dishes to us.  Keep in mind, he already seemed a little PO'ed at us. What the heck did we do?! We just sat down. 

A French man came into the restaurant, met his friend who was sitting behind us, and then handed his large golf umbrella to the hostess/waitress when he sat down... they have umbrella service?!? Meanwhile, all of our purses, laptop bags, and umbrellas occupied the empty fourth chair. 

We ordered: 
- cebiche tasting
- anticucho de mahi mahi
- empanada sampler 
- lomo saltado

The ceviche tasting came in larger than normal portions. Be forewarned. This isn't a place where you leave hungry. 

The mahi mahi skewer came with ONE skewer, not multiple. 

The lomo saltado was probably the smallest dish - but very yummy and tender. 

The empanadas never arrived... and we were concerned but more so relieved because we were full after 3 dishes and a drink each.  Yet when we told the waiter that the empanadas never arrived, we just wanted to make sure he didn't charge us for a dish they didn't serve us... not to place blame on anyone.  

A server suddenly appeared at our table when the waiter was trying to take our dessert order to explain something... but all we got out of the one sided conversation was "I moved the umbrella and placed 2 plates down on the table..." Um... did we eat the empanadas and forgot? Is he trying to say he delivered the dish to the table and we ... didn't notice?? Why is there so much confusion?! 

Our silverware was cleared before we were done with dessert (buñuelos de chocolate and suspiro limeño), the cups of coffee held no more than 6 oz... and my cocktail was removed from my line of sight before I finished all of it. 

To top it all off... We paid with a gift card and cash, and our waiter assumed he got to keep the change. How do we know? We lingered a little too long to see if he would bring us our change and he walked by the table several times to never acknowledge that our bill was paid... or to thank us for dining with the restaurant this evening. 

Hmph. Good food... will try to come back another time. Maybe the rain got our waiter's undies in a bunch...
author: Lisa L.

description: Absolutely stellar meal. Everything was delicious, and the waiter gave great recommendations to a clueless pair like ourselves. Thumbs way up!
author: Michael M.

description:
While I don't typically go to waterfront restaurants, I'd go back.  Cool vibe, not over-the-top formal, just trendy enough.

Pisco Sours -- Danger!  They are that kind of drink that will sneak up on you.  Yummy and light.  I can see sitting on the patio during the summer ... a few of those could get you in trouble.

Dinner for 2: 
Ceviche sampler.  Awesome.
Empanada sampler.  Ok.  They weren't bad.  I think I'm just not that into empanadas.

That was more than enough food.  We also had a nice bottle of sauvignon blanc.  Don't know anything about that - where it was from, etc. - I didn't order.  

The staff was friendly and attentive.  

Enjoy!
author: brandie y.

description: Cebiche....ohhhhh the yumminess...it just doesn't get any better....service..food...atmosphere....
author: Julie P.

description: I've been forced to go to a lot or restaurants in the touristy Embarcadero area, and most of them are not very good. But La Mar was very good!  It's not very cheap, but the food was very good and so was the service!
author: P K.

description: We sat at the bar since we didn't have a reservation.....and it turned out to be a great time.  We started off with a mojito and a Peruvian beer, both were excellent choices. There were 3 of us, so we decided to order a few dishes and share amongst us. First choice was the cebiche mixto with yellowtail, calamari and shimp...very good. Next up was the Causa Casera, which was a yellow potato causa, articokes, asparagus, avocado and an aji huancaina sauce with basil cilantro oil....excellent. Then we had grilled flat steak skewers with grilled veggies, Peruvian corn and a spicy panchita...this was awesome! We ordered another one. We would definitely go back....great food, friendly service and a lively vibe.
author: Wayne A.

description: Cute place. Never knew this place existed. Happened to walk by and found it. Tables and chairs are weird...height is all wrong.  I felt like little munched-kin sitting on high chairs and table was same height as my lap.
author: Jen L.

description:
Let me up front, I wasn't super impressed by this restaurant. There was a bit too much hype but the only reason why I gave it 5 stars was because it was super cheap! Compared to most other fancy date night type restaurants, this place is right on the ticket! I was so surprised by the check. I actually told my date that my parking ticket actually balanced out the evening. 

Now onto the restaurant. The setting is dead on. It was formal enough to be trendy but not super formal where you had to go all out. But that didn't stop my date and I from dressing to our nines and getting out the jean and tshirt rhythm of daily grad school life. We were seated right away even though we had a reservation the place was maybe about 75% capacity at around 9pm. Get street parking and don't bother with the $20 lot. 

There are enough items on the menu to keep you coming back. For a simple elegant date night that's not going to be murder on your wallet gentlemen, this is a good spot.
author: Jon H.

description:
We were looking for a place to bring out of town guests and this place met our expectations.  This is your typical, "doesn't look like much on the outside but you enter a new world once you walk in".  While the inside was pretty, the outside took my breath away.  You walk out to a pretty patio on the water and beautiful turquoise and green decor, including a nestled corner couch with pillows and low tables.  We sat in a somewhat private, protected area and it was beautiful (we had a table and chairs - no couch...there's only one section with the couch).  It was a sunny day in SF but not super warm.  The 
ambience is lovely.  

There were 8 of us and the waiter suggested we order family style, which we did.  We decided how many of each type of item we wanted and requested that he pick for us.  i.e. - 3 cebiches, 2 empanada plates etc.  He was very helpful and professional but was tough to get a smile out of him.  When I ordered my wine he suggested I try another wine on the menu which was from Spain, and "better" than the Sauvignon Blanc I ordered - he was right!

The food was memorable but a little too adventurous for me.  I really enjoyed the cebiches we ordered, and the California roll type items (I can't remember what they're called) were very good.  You should really be a seafood fan if you choose this place (it'll hit ya in the face when you walk in), although there are many other options available on menu.

Food I give a 3 1/2 and then another 1/2 for the pretty patio area.  Very crisp, clean place.
author: Rachael C.

description: Really enjoyed the decor and space. Not too stuffy but still special. It's nice to sit in the patio area if the weather isnt crazy cold (they have heat lamps and faces the water). In terms of food, I had better in terms of ceviche but their grilled items and entrees are definitely a cut above some of the other peruvian restaurants. I also had their causas which were good. I am just not a fan of causas.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Disappointing. 
It was a beautiful day and we wanted to have a nice lunch on the water. We were walking past La Mar and decided to give it a try. 
We walked in and were greeted with a "yes?" from the host. Uncomfortable. He then led us to a table on the covered patio without a word. No smile. Not even a "welcome" or "thank you for joining us" or even a "hello"
We felt this was rather odd and unfriendly but shrugged it off as we sat taking in the menu. It was later in the afternoon so it wasn't very busy, maybe six tables that we could see. Water arrived a short time after we sat but then that was it. We sat and watched a server serve and check on the tables around us for more than 15 minutes.  I am a patient person, but no one greeted us, smiled at us or even looked at us even though we were sitting in the middle of the patio, it was hard not to take it personally. There was a manager(?) standing in the doorway maybe 20 feet away who either didn't notice that we hadn't been helped or didn't care (also never smiled). Our server helped a guest seated after us before finally coming over to us. Maybe she didn't know we were her table? Even so, there was no apology or explanation as to why she walked past us for 15 minutes without stopping. 
We were actually about to leave when she finally came by, I kind of wish we had. 
The food was pretty good and the service (once we got started) was fine, but none of it was great nor could it make up for the cold greeting and neglect at the start. I don't really mind spending $100+ on a nice lunch but if I do, I expect an experience: fantastic food and service- at the very least I would expect to feel valued as a customer and taken care of. We felt from the start that no one cared if we chose to spend our money there and no one was interested in making our experience fun or enjoyable. 
I do agree with other reviewers that the food is overpriced but it was the cold shoulder we got from La Mar that irked us. It has been a few days since our visit and I purposely waited so I wouldn't write a review out of anger but I am still offended.
author: Kater C.

description:
The drinks and appetizers are fantastic here. 

Entrees are very very plain, mediocre and over priced. i ordered the braised pork shoulder and it was awful :o( it had too much sugar, tamarind, and clover in its glaze. 

Desserts are great!
author: Sherry O.

description:
If this is Peruvian food, then I'm moving to Peru.

I was a little bit skeptical about this when I first brought my manager to this place for lunch simply because I had no idea what this place served. But running by the Embarcadero every day and seeing the place PACKED does keep me wondering what all the fuss is about...

Anyway. Boss lady is picky about the places she goes to. Here are the criteria: trendy, chic, good food, good service, innovative dishes, good drinks...

Well? We walked into this beautifully decorated room with bright green and blue all over the place (think chairs, napkins, bar counter). It made us feel like we were in the Bahamas on a summer vacation even though it was overcast in SF. 

Then came the menu in the same bright green and blue and it was full of dishes that we haven't tried before. 

Here are the things we tried:
Cebiche sampler - think sashimi but with lime juice, onions, and sesame oil? (I think?) and you've got yourself a beautiful appetizer! The fish was FRESH and perfectly portioned. It was really like a little bite of heaven.

Empanadas - oh don't be so healthy. So what if it's fried? It's definitely worth getting especially when it comes with different dipping sauces. Yum!

Lomo Saltado - perfectly cooked beef tenderloin stir-fried La Mar style. It comes with white rice with corn in it so you can stir it in. Definitely my favorite main course.

Arroz Norteno - mixed seafood with fried rice stirred together with a Huancaina sauce. Flavorful and filling.

We also got the Pisco Sour (and man, one of these babies will get straight to your head) and the Pisco Punch. Girly but STRONG.

Overall, an awesome dining experience... and it always is when all of the Big Boss criteria are met. 

I will DEFINITELY come back.

p.s. some tips: they don't do take outs for dinner... only lunch.
author: Lynn C.

description: The abysmal service we received really tainted our experience. I have dined at La Mar before and had a great experience.  But this time was very much different.  It took forever to order our drinks and never received the complementary chips.  Our server snapped at us several times during the meal and was once rather aggressive about it.  We had to clarify ingredients of a dish for one of the guests due to a food allergy.  We were informed that it did not contain the allergen but had requested for the sauce to be on the side nevertheless.  Once it arrived with the dish covered in the sauce the server was reminded we requested the sauce on the side.  He barked, "I told you it didn't have it in there!"  Left us all with a bad taste in our mouth.  However, The ceviche are very well done.  Based on this unfortunate experience, and the many wonderful places to eat in San Francsico, we won't return to La Mar.  Plus, it is a really LOUD.
author: Ann B.

description:
This review is for happy hour only. 
Great spot, great location! 
Two words , pisco sour! 
Apps and drinks 5 stars.
Con= Not enough seating in the bar during HH
author: Nina B.

description: I love this place. Good food, good drinks, good atmosphere good service. Everything is perfect. great location. I highly recommend this place. Good Corazon, good ceviche. good pisco sour
author: Christian F.

description:
Fantastico!

Food = 5.  The ceviche tasting was an amazing array of four fishes with different flavors and levels of heat.  I also recommend the tasting of causas. For my entree, I had the arroz jugoso, which had incredible depth in flavor! 

Service = 4.5. Our server was knowledgeable about the entire menu and wine list. The courses were well-timed and  paced perfectly for leisurely dining. 

Atmosphere = 5. The dining room had high ceilings and large windows that created a light and airy feel. The various large floral installments were impressive and beautifully arranged.
author: Eddie L.

description:
Food - Delicious!! Service 5/5! Front desk hostess - snooty and rude. Not very nice! Which is the only reason i didn't give it that extra star. We came in around 5:30pm and didn't have reservations so we sat at the counter, when there were 6-7 tables available. While sitting on the bar we wanted to sit in another spot, she said "no you can't sit there", then i put my purse and coat on the chair next to me since it was only 1 chair between me and the other person and she again said "sorry you can't put your stuff there". My point is for the 1.5 hour we were there, those tables remained empty and that chair where i was not ALLOWED to put my purse and coat remained empty as well. 

Now moving on to the food.

 My favorite on the menu is the Lomo Saltado. It's this delicious dish with onion and fries and beef. The sauce in the dish is so finger licking good. Goes well with the rice. They have a Malbec on their wine list which goes really well with the lomo saltado.  We also got this chicken dish which tasted like Indian Chicken Tikka. I don't remember what it was called but it was good! 

First time we went there we sat outside and quite surprisingly it was not cold. Those heaters kept us pretty warm in the cold sf weather. I'd give it that extra 1 star that it deserves if the hostesses were nicer and more pleasant when first entering.
author: Ms C C.

description:
less than half a star!!! 

WAY over priced and I had all 4 ceviches and I make better ceviche for the price ----Pooooo. 

OVERALL--- OVER priced for what you get.  If you are ready to drop almost $200- $300 on a good date then go... NOT worth it! maybe $100
author: Alejandra M.

description:
Heaven!

Empenada, Causas and Ceviche oooooooooooo my!!!!

My father, my boyfriend and I shared a wonderful meal with excellent service on a busy Saturday night.

The view was exquisite, the crowd was fun, and even though the place was packed it felt like we were the servers only table.
author: Natalie J.

description: We went here for a company outing. We made a reservation for 18 (just two days in advance) for 8:30pm. We arrived to be told that there was a party at our table who was lingering, so we were asked to wait for what turned out to be 45 minutes. Frustrating for us, though we understood it was frustrating for the restaurant as well. When we were finally seated, it was worth the wait. The food was amazing, and the staff took great care of us. Each dish was wonderfully prepared, and the presentation was beautiful. The family-style servings certainly worked well for a large party, and we had a very nice variety of dishes, from cebiche to salmon to beef. Delightful evening. I would give them 5 stars if it wasn't for the 45 minute for our reservation (which wasn't really completely in their control). Great place. Lovely meal.
author: Bret W.

description:
Went to La Mar to celebrate my boyfriend's first week of work! We ordered Lomo Saltado and Arroz Criollo. Here's what I thought:

Lomo Saltado: came with a broth reduction that was slightly on the saltier end and the fries were soggy from the moment the food arrived -- who likes soggy potatoes? The beef tenderloin was cooked to perfection though! I wouldn't order the Lomo Saltado again, as I've had much better for the fraction of the price...

Arroz Criollo: way better than the Lomo Saltado! The seafood was great -- it's nice knowing that their seafood is sustainably sourced. The rice was creamy, rich, and flavorful. I would definitely recommend ordering this!

The service was great -- we didn't get the complementary plantain chips, but got sweet potato chips with this delicious spicy orange colored sauce.

+ I regret not ordering the ceviche -- I will have try it the next time I go!
author: Christine H.

description:
Great Happy Hour esp. good cocktails

a little pricey.

will go back
author: Ron A.

description: My favorite part about this place is the ambiance and location. It's a great place to wine and dine and when it's warm in SF. amazing to sit outdoors. I've been here a few times and always had a great meal, but nothing memorable. It can get really packed and busy so make sure you make reservations and be patient with the wait staff. I would come back here again, but I prefer some of the other great Peruvian restaurants in the city.
author: Tif L.

description: Tried the ceviche sampler and enjoyed it. I'm a traditionalist so next time I will just order the ceviche clasico. My wife ordered the lomo Saltado which was to my surprise a bit of a disappointment. Sauce was too heavy ( lots of it - a pool of it). This is a staple Peruvian dish so I was surprised an Acurio restaurant could foul that up. I had the anticuchos de corazon and they were the BEST I have ever had!  Drinks of choice were pisco sours - excellent.  Will come back next time i am in SF.
author: G V.

description:
At $70 a head,value could have been a bit better, but the quality of the ingredients was good and the flavors were punchy. The wine list was somewhat lacking, the service was good and the atmosphere was fine, if a bit noisy.

The lime was overpowering in some of the Ceviches, but the Beef Heart was delicious. The Causas were nice if all a bit similar.
author: Will H.

description:
Came here on a rainy weeknight and found this place teeming at the brim with the post-work FiDi crowd.  The waitress was curt with us for being late (yeah ok, rain does that sometimes), though having been late to a reservation before I find there have been much more pleasant ways to address us.  Especially when we get to our seats and find out that while the bar area was happening, there were plenty of open seats in the dining area.  

There are 2 bar areas - one to the side of the hostess table that looked like a perfect place to grab a drink after work and maybe a few apps.  Once you walk past the hostess table through the main doors, you'll find yourself in the main bar area which made me feel like you should be lounging poolside (teak looking benches) outside (windows on the ceiling) and listening to some spanish guitar under the lazy sun.  Makes for a perfect place to impress a date.

Once I walked past the main bar area I noticed that La Mar was by far the biggest restaurant I have ever been to in the city.  So that's a nice plus.  Despite our experience with the hostess, our waitress was very friendly and accommodating.  Now to the food.  The dishes were served at perfect intervals which I can always appreciate however I can't say my feelings toward the food were so warm.

We ordered the Halibut Cerviche, the risotto special (similar to the Arroz Jugoso dish that was on their main entrees menu), and then the Dulce de Luche for dessert.  The complimentary plantain appetizer was a treat.  I really enjoyed the spiciest of the sauces.  The other two were too sweet and didn't offset the flavor of the plantain chips as well as the spiciest sauce.  Although admittedly the sweeter sauces came in handy when I ate the habanero hiding out in the cerviche.   Beware!

Other than its milky appearance, I didn't think there was anything special worth noting  about this halibut cerviche (Cerbiche Clasico).  The main entree I thought was way too dense and the heaviness of the rice did not match well with the heaviness of the seafood.  Not to mention there was very little flavor imparted from the actual dish.  The Dulce de Leche dessert is in liquid form (we should have read that) and honestly, was far too sweet.  It was almost like downing a cup of Hershey's caramel syrup.  I think had it been paired with some vanilla ice cream, it would have at least been tolerable.  We ended up sending our dessert back and the waitress was kind enough to exchange our dessert for the sorbet trio (reedemingly refreshing and ... delicious!).

Our bill came out to $100 (including tax and tip) for the two of us for one appetizer, 2 main entrees, and one dessert - overpriced considering the iffiness of their food.  Overall, just a lukewarm experience at La Mar.
author: Jean A.

description:
Okay, now I'm going to put on my snooty food critic hat. I'm doing this not because I like being snooty, but because this restaurant, for its location and reputation, sets high standards for itself.
