Overall, I'd give it 3.5 stars. Because I'm a snooty food critic now.

5 stars for the food: Delicious, refreshing, filling but leaves you weight-less. All the qualities of a restaurant that cooks its food perfectly and uses fresh, quality ingredients. A menu full of unique dishes and most is a-la-carte with good proportions, so it's a fun place to take a group of people. Also, they use real peruvian choclo (thick, starchy corn) which is a testament to the authenticity of this restaurant.

4 stars for ambiance:
- Little secret here: sitting outside is warm with plenty of heat lamps, offers a view of the water, and is quieter/less chaotic than sitting inside.
- Inside is pretty loud and bustling. It's a large restaurant.

3 stars for service: There was really nothing wrong per say about the service, only that it was a bit confusing. Our server was super friendly and even chatted with me about the tea selection. Wait staff is knowledgeable regarding menu items. However, this is not the kind of place where you go to feel like you're being served a 5-star menu in a 5-star restaurant. The service is a bit more casual than that and bumbly at times.


All in all, it was a lovely experience with fantastic food and good service. However-- and I'm sorry to say this-- it was forgettable. If you go, go with someone special or a fun group of people, and the food will live up to the happy vibes you set out, but don't expect the restaurant itself to make your night.

Chocolate beignets are life-changing, though.
author: Jen N.

description:
Just had a late lunch here and my experience was nothing short of heavenly.  To the point where I actually wrote a thank you note when I signed my receipt.  Who does that?  (Definitely not me, prior to this day!)

A good friend and I ate here on a whim.  Walking through the doors off the Embarcadero felt like stepping into a whole other world--a cool, breezy coastal one where time slowed down considerably.  We sat right up against a window with a view of the bay.  Since it was late afternoon, the restaurant was sprinkled with a few people, but not many--so the whole affair felt peacefully casual and service was spot-on.  Now for details...

Setting: Spacious, airy, plantation-like beach villa. White walls, dark brown fixtures, bright splashes of turquoise and lime green on the backs of chairs and on top of tables. Big windows that let you swim in daylight.

First up: Chips and a trio of sauces.  When I say chips, I mean tasty, paper-thin slices of potato, plantain, and yam that are lightly salted (with crack, I think, because I could have eaten those alone and been satisfied). The trio of sauces were a visual treat: bright orange, light yellow, pesto green. Per our waiter, they were arranged in order of spiciness and each highlighted a unique ingredient. 

Appetizer (to us, at least): we each requested a half order of cebiche--my friend the cebiche mixto, and me the cebiche chorillana. As a fervid fan of the stuff, I was completely enamored. The seafood (calamari, octopus, fish, shrimp, scallop) was soaking in an orange puddle of tart, lime-infused juice and the taste was simply amazing. Not to mention the texture!  When I finished (it was agonizing to see the plate empty) I took a spoon to the remaining juice and ate that too.  Not my finest moment, but it's behind me now.

Main act: The sampler platter.  I don't remember what it was called, but to future diners, it was located in a box on the upper right side of the menu's second page.  It consisted of a skewer of mahi mahi on a bed of Peruvian corn; a serving of the ensalada limena; and a side plate of lightly-fried octopus and fish.  As a visual, it looked awesome.  I was compelled to take a photo.  And the taste...

The skewer of fish and vegetables was dripping in a bright red marinade, which offered a delicious chili pepper background to the dish.  The salad--soft spinach with baby tomatoes, queso fresco and a light, fresh dressing (that I would love the recipe for) demanded all of my attention.  And the fried seafood was a great crunchy complement to the rest of the plate.  I loved the combination of flavors, colors, textures...and amusingly enough, while my friend and I were ooh-ing and aah-ing over our food, two people came up to us and asked us what we were eating--then ordered it too. 

Dessert: Rice pudding with butterscotch, chocolate and fresh strawberries. Mind you, I am a texture person and had deep reservations about rice pudding, which proved to be correct--so the restaurant is run by humans after all. But a few strawberry chunks in butterscotch sauce to cap off a fabulous meal still proved to be a great ending.

All in all, I didn't want to leave the place. You know when you spend an entire day at Disneyland and manage to see everything you wanted to see and you're left with that feeling of satisfied exhaustion?  That's how my tastebuds felt afterward.  Exhausted but in a crazy good addictive way. 

So yeah.  When can I go back?
author: Shirin H.

description:
La Mar is probably my favorite Peruvian restaurant in the city.  The food is great and I like the modern,spacious, and trendy yet not pretentious decor.  It's a great place to come after work if you work nearby in FiDi, and I've also enjoyed bringing friends from out-of-town here.  On weekends, I've had lunch here several times out on the patio, where you have a nice view of the SF Bay.  

Now to the food...
For appetizers, you MUST have the seafood empanadas.  If you're coming in a large group, I would recommend the empanada, causa, and cebiche tastings.  

For the main course, my rotation has always been between the arroz norteno, arroz jugoso, and the lomo saltado.  All three are excellent.  It just depends if you're in the mood for seafood or beef really.

Lastly, they have a great cocktail menu.  I always get the pisco punch, but haven't yet mustered the courage to try the bloody lorcho, a bloody mary mix with pisco and octopus bits.  I will next time!
author: Allen K.

description:
One of our friends gave La Mar a recommendation so we took her up on it. I mean, when is the last time we've had Peruvian fine dining?

La Mar is located at Pier 1 1/2. This reminds me of the scene in 'Being John Malcovich' where the elevator reaches a 1/2 level. From the outside La Mar doesn't look anything special. But once you go in you realize that it's a relaxed upscale dining restaurant with adjoining bar. They have a happy hour and from what I hear the drinks are really good. Later we had two Sangrias ($9) which were quite refreshing.

I really like the interior design along with the colorful menus. It's minimally clean with color interspersed for interest. If you feel like taking a cerebral vacation from San Francisco without leaving it you should check this place out. The single person bathroom that I used was a bit claustrophobic.

The menu is somewhat perplexing. If you don't know Peruvian or its cuisine the ordering process can be a little intimidating. I'm sure La Mar gets a lot of its profit from confused patrons. We basically went with own waiter's recommendations, ordering three samplers, one appetizer, and three main dishes.

Here's a breakdown:

Free chips with three dipping sauces of differing spiciness
-Great idea, yet I hate to start my meal on an empty stomach with oily fried chips and cream based dips. It makes my me bloated. Any bread?

STARTERS

Cebiche tasting 28
Mixto, Chifa, Nikei and Clásico
-Quite disappointing. La Mar is supposed to be known for their cebiche. This is simply a case of too many ingredients. I couldn't even taste the fish. Everything was fresh and tasted good on its own, but together it was hard to distinguish a single balanced composition.

Causa tasting 17
Selection of four causas: Limeña, Criolla, Nikei, Casera
-I was puzzled by this. Maybe I'm just not used to cold potato appetizers. I'm not too fond of the texture.

anticuchos de pulpo 16
Grilled octopus skewers, herbed mashed potato
with chimichurri sauce and ají panca
-Tasty stuff. Eating some meaty octopus skewers was good.

Empanada sampler 18
A tasting of all four empanadas
-My favorite of the small dishes. The fried dough is as flavorful as the filling. I could have passed all other appetizers and had more of these. Frying makes everything better.

MAIN

Cau cau 31
Roasted scallops and clams, tiny potatoes, sweet pea and corn
risotto with an aji amarillo mint broth
-The most popular of the night. Creamy and bright.

Lomo saltado 27
Traditional Peruvian style stir-fry of sautéed beef tenderloin, onions,
tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic with fried potatoes and rice
-Underwhelming. While not entirely bad, it just reminded me of a dish from Carrows, not Peru.

Arroz norteño 24
North Peruvian seafood combination with mussels, shrimp, octopus,
and fried rice with cilantro and Huancaína sauce
-Interesting interpretation of fried rice. Maybe like two mussels, but a decent amount of octopus. Wouldn't get again.

Dessert

Suspiro limeño 10
Classic dulce de leche mousse with port wine meringue
-Waaaaay too sweet. Tastes more like a dipping sauce than a free standing dessert. I did like the sprinkling of cinnamon.

Dessert tasting, cakes and cream filled pastries
-Alright but I think the flavors start to taste the same after awhile.

Cookie wafer crisp with whipped cream and caramel
-Interesting and good texture. Not entirely fulfilling.

Ice cream puff, complimentary for birthdays
-An off menu item that's actually really really good. Why don't they have this on their menu??

All of the dishes are beautifully presented. Any of the dishes could have been shot for a magazine opt. The ingredients were fresh and properly cooked.

Now for the negative. I think that way too many of the dishes have too much hominy or Peruvian corn. It's just everywhere. Plus many of the dishes are overpowered by a sense of cream or an element of carbohydrate. While I was expecting a big punch of flavor, the fine dining atmosphere made me believe that there would be more subtlety. La Mar's dishes tend to be one-note. In the end it doesn't really add up to much unless you're looking at the bill.

Service is great. Our waiter was really nice and helpful. We had our dishes cleared out multiple times. My glass was refilled without asking once. I felt pampered.

___

A great location, interior, and staff. Even though the food is a complex arrangement of multiple ingredients, there isn't much depth. By the end of the night my stomach was uneasy. Just way too much oil, cream, and carbs. The desserts had way too much of the same caramel taste to it. I know caramel and butterscotch is supposed to be big in Peru, but give me different shades of the same color not the same thing over and over. Balance, balance, balance. Pretty food 'though.

I'd come back for Happy Hour and a couple of appetizers but not a full blown stay. Go for a beach stroll, not an ocean-liner voyage.
author: Michael H.

description: Sublime cebiche!  I can't get enough of the cebiche Classico (halibut).  The causes are good, but I think the cebiche is better.  Try the quinoa salad with burrata cheese.  That was very tasty!
author: Debby C.

description:
If you are looking for a taste of excellent Peruvian cuisine, then this is the place for you.  If you are looking for a meal, head someplace else.  The portions are tiny.  After $50 a head, we all left hungry.  We went for a birthday party and despite being seated in the corner between the kitchen and the back wall, the noise level was very high.  Conversation more than 2 seats away is nearly impossible.  The staff was attentive, but a little too aggressive at clearing the table when the group is clearly trying to take photos and be social.

We ordered about half of the menu and everything we ordered was excellent (and tiny).  The ceviches are all excellent, most especially the clasico version which uses very tender California halibut.  The chicken dishes are all great, and the beef heart was the best I've ever tasted hands down, anywhere, including in Peru itself.  They also serve the best Pisco Sour I've ever had.  The chicha morada left a lot to be desired.  Several of us ordered deserts in vain hopes of feeling full and found ourselves with about 2 cubic inches of desert and the tiniest ball of ice cream ever served.  Again the taste was great, but it was over too soon.

Like everything in SF, it's parking jihad.  There is a paid lot across the street that's easy, and also you can get valet parking on Pier 3.  Otherwise its parking meter hell that charges 25 cents for every 7.5 minutes with a two hour maximum.  This isn't enough time to have a respectable meal here and then go out for another meal someplace else to finish filling yourself up.

So in summary, if you want to try Peruvian food that's so good it better than authentic, head here.  But I wouldn't make a habit of eating at La Mar on a regular basis.
author: Bobby K.

description: I went to La Mar for my Anniversary. My friends suggested this restaurant for my special occasion and I had never been there before. When I walked in the door, I knew I'd chosen the right place! It was very upscale and beautiful! We ate on the patio by the water and it was very romantic. We had the cebiche classico and the cebiche mixto which was amazing!!! The Malbec wine was to die for and the arroz jugoso and the plancha anticuchera was delicious! The staff was friendly as well. Thanks for an amazing dining experience.
author: Andrea D.

description:
I don't think this was the best dinner I've had...but those empanadas were damn good.  I came here on the suggestion of my friend's Peruvian boyfriend.  Apparently the guy who owns this also owns all of the best restaurants in Peru, so it must mean something right?

I ordered the lomo saltodo.  I wasn't expecting the fried potatoes to actually just be french fries.  The beef was very tender...although I didn't feel like it was marinated long enough...it still tasted beefy.  And mind you, I love beef, but I was expected more flavor.  I did very much enjoy the bowl or rice that accompanied my meal.  I don't know why, maybe it's the Asian in me, but I definitely thought that was the best part of the dish.

Overall the service was just ok...when we asked our server what the best way to order...they didn't really give us any direction and just said "I'd order this" and then proceeded to just list all of the sampler plates and all of the big ticket specials.

The boyfriend really enjoyed his dish.  He got the arroz norteno.  Maybe my mistake was not getting a seafood dish...because he enjoyed his way more than I did.  But like I said...the empanadas were to die for amazing...and if for some reason I come back, I'm only ordering that.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
Ok so .. I may have now found my new favorite place to get ceviche! first off they have a large selection of different ceviches... and the basket of fried platiaines, yams and potatoes delicious and a-pleanty :) (I hate running out of crunchies before the fish is all gone)

The Pisco sours are great... the back patio is amazing and the service was steller. 

My favorite item was the pineapple/habanero mahi mahi ! I also loved how the ceviches came with sauces on the side... I have never seen this and thought it to be a nice touch/addition.

Did not try the desserts as we were SO full .. but next time. 

Two big lime soaked thumbs ups!
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Met my brother for lunch.  They would NOT seat me until he came!! They were not busy, but hey they got rules..... surprise so do I.

Halibut Ceviche, definetly the fish was not fresh... Fish is not suppose to be smelly!!

Had high hopes when I went it.. very disapointed.
author: nisha c.

description:
sooo yummy!

ive been there twice, and each time i left feeling totally satisfied. i enjoyed two different types of ceviche, my favorite was the fresh ahi tuna one. and that potato dish with fresh crab and tomato was to die for...

i cant forget to mention the entree, my mouth is still watering from the loma saltado(sp?), which is a steak and potatoes dish. its no ordinary plate, though. the sauce drenches perfectly crispy yet tender french fries and juicy steak... a total stick-to-your-ribs, mouth-watering, plate-licking concoction that i cant get out of my taste-buds memory! 

mmm and for desert i enjoyed those donuts with a vanilla chocolate and raspberry creme and a coffee. im getting hungry just thinking about it...

the staff was very friendly and knowledgeable. didnt have to wait and my cup was never running low.

perfect date place, too. its right on the water so make sure to be there for the sunset!
author: Alma W.

description: This is the 3rd time we've been there and realize the food is just OK. Ambiance is great though. Probably the last time we purposely choose to go there...
author: J S.

description:
La Mar gets 5 stars for it's decor and setting, the food and service are more in the 2.5 to 3 range. The ceviches here are just ok in my opinion, the clasico is good but the others I've tried have ranged from so-so to downright awful. I think it's the Japanese style one( don't remember the exact name) that nearly made me vomit with that thick paste smeared on it. The lomo saltado is tasty, good meat, but it's just the servings are so small. As for the service, they're not rude or anything just
Pretty inattentive. Very pricey and really in my opinion only worth one visit just to check it out. Don't mean to sound harsh but Ive been to Peru multiple
Times and my wife is from Peru so maybe I expect more? There are other Peruvian restaurants in SF that are much better, but try La Mar for the experience I guess.
author: Nick R.

description:
Hostess service could use a big lift.

We made a reservation at 8:30pm for 5, 2 of which are close friends from out of country.  We showed up at 8:15pm and was not sitted until close to 9:15pm.  

We might as well made reservation for 9:00pm and show up at 9:30pm !

We made multiple requests to the hostess and the responses we received were that the table were still taken and the guests were eating desserts, paying their bills, and then the last responses were that the manager is telling the guests that they must leave.  

Is this the way to treat its customers? I highly doubt it.  I am sure the hostess is just telling us that to sooth our hunger and growing displeasure.  Upon peeking around the restaurant, we noticed that there were many empty seats, especially around 9:15pm on a Sunday night.  Also, before we were sitted, a party of 6 came in and were immediately directed to a table. 

This is highly unacceptable and a showing of poor poor customer service.  

So, by the time we sat down and ordered our food, it was close to 9:45pm.  We were offered free drinks but we do not drink, in turn, we were given one single dessert.  

Our final bill was close to $300, so a free dessert is merely a slap in the face and a show of disrespect.

In addition, the food is merely mediocre.  The sauce is the same for all dishes.  Most of the dishes are deep friend and covered in the sauce.   Too bad this is the only Peruvian restaurant in the city, otherwise, we would not have chosen this place.

My wife and I dine out occasionally and are not strangers to finer foods in and around San Francisco.  We had chosen La Mar based on its reviews and words of mouth from friends and are extremely disappointed at the services we received and embarrassed that our guests had to suffer until 9:45pm for dinner. 

We will not return to La Mar and will NOT recommend it to our friends and guests ever.
author: Jason H.

description:
We had a really good Christmas Eve dinner with the family. We had the cebiche sampler, the veg empanadas, the beef empanadas, octopus skewer, beef heart skewer, the soup of the day, beef entree, Ensalada tiradito x2.

We were stuffed!

The food was good too. There were a few things that weren't to my fancy - I was the one who had persuaded the table to try the beef hearts, I don't think any of us liked them. The cebiche sampler was a good size for all 5 of us; we all got a bite of something and we love seafood but we wanted to try a variety of the menu.
I highly recommend the octopus skewer, and the vegetarian empanade was awesome!

The silent thief of the night was definitely the soup of the day. It was amazing! Shrimp and other fish and veg and just so tasty. I'll be back just for soup for lunch in the future.
author: Kym P.

description: I ordered the Ceviche and the Lomo Saltado and they were both outstanding! The flavor and presentation of the ceviche was excellent and the Lomo Saltado was prepared perfectly. The meat was very flavorful. I was also happy with the service. The food was delivered quickley and the waiter was attentive.
author: Christian V.

description: We've dined @ La Mar before.  Again the food was very good, but the service was just alright except I had finished about  1/2 of my entrée, the quinoa chaufa [vegetarian], & asked for the remainder to take home.  When I had not gotten the take-home by the time we had paid & were leaving, I asked my server.  After waiting for some time w/ the rest of my party now waiting @ the door, he gave me a bag w/ a container.  As I was walking to the door, I looked in & I don't know what was in the bag, but it was about a spoonful of something not even remotely similar to what my lunch had been--had a shrimp on the top.   When I asked the server, he seemed to have no idea what he had done w/ my take-home.  I didn't keep everyone waiting longer & left w/ basically  1/2 of the lunch that was paid for forfeited.
author: Karen L.

description: We had a nice evening at La Mar.  The pescado skewers were fantastic! Mild fish seasoned well, hominy with incredible sauces- a memorable dish.  We ordered the empanada sampler and it was just like the pastries we had is S.America.  The one dish I wasn't impressed with is the chorrillana- yuca has a lovely delicate flavor which was smothered by the saucy fish placed on top.  Service was adequate.  I noticed the desserts floating around look amazing, wish I had room!  Next time!
author: Liz Y.

description: I don't understand how a lomo saltado can cost 32 bucks. You toss some steak together with tomato, onion and french fries and serve it with rice. The one we got at La Mar Cevicheria tasted like a bad stir fry with too much oyster sauce. The quinoa tasted like it had oyster sauce. The ceviche and anticucho were delicious, but the portions were small. No alfajores, no picarones. I'm not going back.
author: Susan B.

description:
OMG! It doesn't get any better than this! I took my son in law (his 4th time there). My first. They have a way of doing seafood like you wouldn't believe! There's something about adding citrus to seafood that makes it really work. It was so good that I almost came back for dinner that nite.

And I really like the decor. Great color mix of the interior.

Get the ceviche sampler. And be sure to try the fried rice. And finally the octapus on the skewer! The best!
author: Paul F.

description:
Que fabuloso restaurante!

I was blown away here. Not only was the style of the restaurant really chic, but it was a HUGE location. My Dad was the first to comment that it didn't seem like we were in any type of economic rut. It was a Tuesday night and this restaurant had EASILY 70 diners inside. There's an outdoor patio, a Cebiche bar, a waiting area (for people who aren't yet seated) and of course roomy tables scattered around the restaurant with happy diners. 

It's not a quiet place because of it's size, but more importantly, the service and food were amazing. Giant potato chips and banana chips were served as appetizers to tease our pallets. We also had great pisco sours, Manhattans, and Peruvian sodas. A must-order would be one of the cebiche dishes which are fresh and tasty. We enjoyed the food so much that we actually ordered dessert. (Usually in our family we skip dessert and eat something cheaper at home.) The bunuelos were warm and fresh and the overall experience was one of the better dining experiences I've had in a while. 

I'll speak for my parents too.. they loved it!
author: Katy H.

description:
Our boss treated the department to a Peruvian cuisine lunch at la mar (it's spelled without caps, a la e. e. cummings) and it was excellent. Since there were about a dozen of us the organizer had selected the menu in advance and it was served family style--very stylish family style. The presentation was beautiful. There were even special little menus printed just for us. Since we were being treated to the meal there were no prices on the menu, so my price range choice here is based on a glance at the online lunch menu. (It'd probably be more than that with drinks.)

Since its name includes Cebicheria the cebiche appetizer was excellent, as one would expect. So were the Ensalada Nikei and Anticuchos de Pollo. The entrees--Chorillana and Lomo Saltado--were delicious. I believe the sangria was the best I've ever had, less sweet than I'm accustomed to drinking and very nice.

The "dessert duo" was a "chef's choice of dessert specials" which don't seem to be on the online menu, but were so good I was ecstatic.

The service--not always easy with a large group--was quiet, attentive and very nice.

We were seated in an outdoor area looking out on the Alcatraz and Hornblower cruise docks. Since it's a rainy, grey, chilly day the area was enclosed and heated nicely, but I imagine it'd be a lovely place for a spring or summer day lunch, too.
author: Michael E.

description: This was an amazing restaurant right on the Pier overlooking the water. The food was fantastic, as was the wine. I'll go back on this trip and recommend it to others.
author: James P.

description:
Had a great dinner there with a couple of friends; the causas were yummy as always, and the cebiches were also good -- fresh-tasting and tender.  I had the tuna and the textures and flavors were awesome.  However, the arroz dish was not super; I wouldn't recommend it.  It was salty and spicy, and the seafood flavors just did not come through as well as I would have liked.  Otherwise, though, a great meal at La Mar as usual.

Service was excellent.
author: Danielle G.

description:
I really like Limon and Limon Rotisserie---but I love La Mar Cebicheria for the same and different reasons.  The same because I am enthralled by Peruvian cuisine and different because some of the menus items are simliar this takes the expression of Peruvian food to it's fullest extent outside of Lima.   This is a part of the Lima based restaurant and to transport this wondrous cuisine to North America.  While recipes are easy to copy and paste, however, the ingredients are not.  The vast availability of corn, potatoes and fish is different here than there--less abundant here--yes, Peru the birth place of the potatoes has many more varietals and the fish stock and species varieties is the world's largest.  

The food here is tremendously fresh and is a brilliant homage to Peruvian food.  The execution of the Causas and Ceviches are so well done-- each cut and slice of ingredient is precisely done.  The service was attentive but not overbearing.

I keep hearing the noise factor can be a bit much but when I was there--I was there with a large party and enjoyed a view of the bay--and being close to the kitchen.  A nice and by San Francisco standards--a large space.  

I will be back real soon.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Fantastic ceviche with just the right amount of spice. The arroz was delicious. Our server, Melissa, was lovely and attentive. When my coworker's ceviche had a shrimp in it (he's allergic) Melissa facilitated a quick replacement for no charge.

All in all, it's a winner. I'll be back!
author: Mark W.

description:
ONLY GOOD THING IS THE VIEW

Beautiful scenery right on SF Bay. Beautiful restaurant and a nice menu. My meal was a brunch special of eggs, italian sausage and potato which was so tiny, it took only four bites to finish it and looked like like gray eggs puked up. Service was indifferent and often delayed.

Only thing going for this place is the view.
author: Flynt I.

description: Location and ambience is very nice. A good place for happy hour.  The passion fruit pisco sours are nice. However the food is not what it used to be. Quality have greatly decline and for the price they charge there are much better options around the city. Very disappointed as a restaurant.
author: Sergio M.

description:
La Mar is a restaurant owned by my husband's cousin's sister's brother.  Having said that, last night was my first visit there.  

The weather in San Francisco was exquisite.  A clear blue sunny day.  I arrived early and ordered a glass of wine from the bar.  At 5:45 pm, the bar was at capacity, so i entered into the restaurant area and sat at a quiet empty seating area.  I was joined by another woman waiting for her husband, and then another mother/daughter team awaiting their spouses.  Friendly people.  

Once our whole group arrived, we were seated. I found this to be the only downside to La Mar.  They do not seat you until your whole party is present. The place was not full at the time so it would have been nice to be seated.  There was no room to sit in the bar, so we crowded around the empty seating area and waited for 30 minutes.

The waiter was fantastic.  Authentic, knowledgeable, polite, attentive and all eight ladies at the table voted --- very cute!  He reviewed many of the menu items with us with beautiful detail.

The wine list is extensive with many imported wines.  We selected based on our own knowledge and then had more help from our waiter.  The choices were excellent.

We split the cebiche tasting and causa tasting plates.  WOW.  They were amazing.  All of the fish was very fresh.  The sauces were terrific.

The main course that I ordered was one of their specials.  It looked a bit like a stew upon arrival.  It was filled with beef, scallops, calamari, shrimp and bok choy over a mashed potato bed.  The sauce was heavenly.  All of us were very happy with our menu selections.

We celebrated 3 birthdays this week.  The staff brought out two plates of what looked to be donut holes (actually French benguits?  sp?  sorry, i am on my first cup of coffee) and fried donut fritters with a maple sauce.  The donut holes exploded in your mouth - filled with liquid chocolate.  My neighbor licked her plate with her fingers --- SOOOO good and she was completely in her right mind to do so.  

The ambiance was great.  Couples, groups, even a few with young children.  Young, old --- a great mix of people.  The flower arrangements were also beautiful.

I have eaten many places in San Francisco and have a few favorite restaurants that are out of state.  La Mar was in my top 3 best meals ever (probably top 2).  I can't wait to go back.
author: Jaye Lynn R.

description:
My love and I came here for a belated birthday/early anniversary dinner on Friday night.  

Our reservation was around 9:30, but we got there around 9:15 so that we could enjoy a cocktail before dinner.

The boy had a Santa Marina -- which is something sweet and girly.  While I opted for a Bloody.  Little did I know that it came with octopus in it.  Little chunks of octopus floating in a drink is neat.  I think.  

However, it was a little spicy and chewy, and halfway through I put it down and did not pick it back up because I was breathing peppery, octopus flavored fire.

We were seated promptly and ordered just as quick.  Two types of cebiches, seared ahi and chicken empanadas to share.

A basket of fried amazingness (plantains, potatoes and sweet potatoes) are served as a complimentary app with three dipping sauces.  The spicy one, a liquefied gazpacho salsa of sorts, was amazing.  The other two needed a hefty dose of salt.  

Boy ordered a second cocktail which took forever and two days to arrive.  We had already hungry caterpillared our way through the two cebiches when it was placed on the table.

While not the most amazing food I've ever had, everything we ordered was really nice and fresh.  The space alone is worth visiting.  It's industrial without feeling cold and sexy without feeling cheap.  

I picked up the bill, cause that's how I roll.  

When I have birthday money.  From my parents.  Yes.  My parents still give me birthday money.  Uh huh.  I realize that I'm almost 30.

When I don't have birthday money you can find me at Kiki.  Or more likely, Taco Bell.  They do pretty nice Peruvian.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I was trying to plan my sister's birthday party at La Mar since we love nuevo latino cuisine and ceviche! 

I contacted them several times and it took them at least a week to get back to me. Once I spoke with the event manager, she was cold, not really helpful and kinda impatient. Although I'm pretty picky, I do know what I want and she didn't seem like she cared to listen. 

I eventually gave up on trying to work with La Mar and hosted a successful event at Limon in the Mission which was fantastic!
author: vinney a.

description: I don't see any reason to keep this review long because this place is in my TOP 3 list in the city as someone who constantly keeps trying out new spots and has very developed taste buds! :) Beside my love for peruvian food; i could have never imagined dreaming of rotisserie chicken with dipping sauces they serve by side but Limon made me daydream of it. Almost tried all ceviche kinds in the menu and so far my faves are tuna, red snapper and mixto. Another great thing about the place is it's neither a torture nor hassle to make a reservation before 10pm ! unlike many other overhyped places in SF.
author: Beril Y.

description:
I read an article a while back stating that ceviche is the new sushi.  That's something I could rally behind.

The ceviche here was wonderful, especially the tuna (nikei).  I would eat that all day long.

The other apps we had, including the chicken and steak skewers and the empanadas were tasty too.


Only three stars though because none of the entrees were great.  The best, by far, was actually the vegetarian risotto.  That was kind of a shocker.  I had the pepper crusted tuna and it was just ok.  The pepper didn't really compliment the tuna.

Oh and the red sangria was great but I wasn't impressed with any of the other cocktails either.

So yeah, 3 stars.  But if you skip the entrees and get a ton of ceviches, a couple additional apps and glass after glass of sangria then it's totally 4 stars.

Plus there's one waiter who is the hottest thing I've ever seen.  EVER.
author: Evan L.

description:
If you are looking for a busy, bustling, hot spot and don't mind hearing the conversations of your table neighbors, then La Mar is a great choice. 

My husband and I went to La Mar for our anniversary dinner and although we absolutely enjoyed every morsel of Peruvian goodness, we were turned off by the lack of intimacy that La Mar embodies. There is no one to blame but my haste in choosing this restaurant for our "romantic" dinner.

Here's the scoop - Booked our dinner for an 8 pm reservation on a Thursday night via opentable.com. La Mar has great South Beach-esque decor, but we felt as if we were in a high school cafeteria. Everyone dressed to the nine's, and everywhere you turn, it is as if everyone is vying to be part of the "popular" lunch table. It's a definite people watching (and listening) spot.

On to the goodness - the food we ordered was simply deliciouso! We started with the empanadas de chocio and both my husby and I ordered fish as our main course - atun (seared and spiced Ahi Tuna) and the chorillana (roasted sea bass): they were fantastic and the sea bass - BLISS! To end the night, we shared afajores and beignets.

La Mar is a great resto - I should have booked for a "fun" dinner not a "romantic" anniversary dinner. Minus 1 star for the pricey tab and the loud ambiance, otherwise, we will return.
author: April D.

description: Great cocktails! I've only ever stopped in for happy hour - but they have a great vibe and the space is trendy. The bartenders are equally friendly, I've asked multi times for them to make me a surprise drink - but keep it skinny girl style. Never disappointed.
author: Tara T.

description: Okay, I've only been here for parties but they've all been really good and the party food makes we want to come back for a meal.
author: Cynthia J.

description: Came here for my bf's sister's bday on a weekday at happy hour time.  I enjoyed the view and color schemes of the restaurant.  However, i would never dine here after work hours when i am surrounded by business suits.  I think i would have given 5 stars if we had dinner at night where it is more intimate and less happy hour like.  Other than that the food was great especially the ceviche.  Another two thumbs on making a delicious lemon drop!
author: Crystal I.

description:
I've been here for happy hour and for lunch.  The outdoor patio space right on the Bay is so perfect on a warm day.  The food is hit or miss.  I'd stick with the classics - their pisco sour is amazing!  Sour, sweet, and incredibly strong.  If you think you can drink more than one, maybe pause and consider how drunk you are first.  The cebiche is fantastic.  The fish is very fresh and the other ingredients, including onions, radishes, lime, and cilantro, give the dish a delightful, refreshing taste.

I've also had the empanadas, steak sandwich, and prawn salad.  The empanads were sub-par, kind of dry with gooey, okay tasting filling.  Not even close to what you would find in South America, much closer to what you might find in a deli or coffee shop.  The steak sandwich was nothing special.  It had this red sauce that just tasted oily with a hint of olive and bell pepper.  The prawn salad was disgusting.  I don't know what kind of dressing they used, but it was sweet and soaked the entire salad.

I'd go for happy hour and get a pisco sour and cebiche.  Maybe some chips.
author: Pearl L.

description:
Sorely disappointed. 

I was super excited to eat at La Mar after reading an article in Gourmet Magazine, and the SF gate. We had reservations at 8:15, and were promply seated at a tiny table placed incredibly close to other tiny tables. If you're claustrophobic this is not the place for you. It felt like we were eating at the Cheesecake Factory, sitting elbow to elbow, hip to hip. Dinner conversations were reduced to shouting, and any attempt to try and tune out neighboring conversations was impossible. 

Ambiance aside, I was still ready to taste some eye-opening ceviche, and splurp down a few shots of leche de tigre. We ordered the ceviche tasting, leche de tigre tasting, and a empanada de aji de gallina.

To keep it short, the best part of the meal was the sorbet.

Ceviche's are supposed to be light and refreshing, what we got was creamy and heavy. It wasn't what we expected. The empanada was bland, and the accompanying sauce was not an aji I've ever tried before. It was thick and creamy, and tasted of butter. 4 out of 5 leche de tigre shots were creamy and thick. The ceviche mixto was the best. Sour, spicy, light, and refreshing. 

I knew the dinner bill would be expensive, but when I pay good money for food, I expect good food in return. Next time I'm craving Peruvian ceviche, I'll stop by Limon and Fresca instead.

Boo-Yah bitches!
author: Robin K.

description:
Have walk passed by this restaurant's back patio multiple times during lunch break without knowing it is such a great restaurant! What a gem I found on Yelp! 

Honestly I have no clue what Peruvian food is.  This was the first time I tried so I can't judge on the authenticity of the dishes.  Looking at the menu, it seems like there's a bit of Japanese fusion on a few items.  

Overall very nice interior decor - crisp and clean, excellent dish presentation, and good quality food.  I'd give TWO STARS for the very nice "chips basket" (plaintain, sweet potato, and potato) with 3 different dipping sauces! loved it!

Ordered:
1) the most popular Causa Trio Sampler ($12 - mashed potatoes with 3 different toppings: Ahi Tuna, Avacado, and Crab Meat) - EXCELLENT!

2) Cebiche Classico 1/2 order ($11 - Halibut Cerviche) - GOOD 

3) Almuercito  Criollo Trio Sampler ($16 - Ensalada Playera (Seafood salad), causa criolla (potato and mahi escabeche) and empanada de choclo (corn empanada.)  - The mahi mahi maybe a tad overcooked.  The seafood salad is a bit too tart for me, and the corn empanada was excellent!

4) Anticucho de carne ($15 - Grilled skirt steak on a skewer, potatoes, Peruvian corn, spicy rocoto sauce) EXCELLENT! The steak was cooked just right, tender and juicy!

5) Dessert - some kind of ice cream made with evaporated, condense, and coconut milk (??) - it's a bit too icy and I'd not recommend.
author: Shirley H.

description:
I was so excited to come here since i've heard so much about the place and read the reviews of course before coming here. 
IDK if its because i came here for lunch or what and they did not have a lot of selection to choose from, but i was not pleased with the food. Well at least the food that i ordered. 

I started off with the empanada sampler and my main course was the cebiche classico. The cebiche at this restaurant is not your typical cebiche that you would find at a mexican place! It is not chopped fish that is placed on a tortilla. It's more like chunky pieces of the fish. 
The only thing that was good during lunch were the free chips they offered us, which BTW are available at costco because my dad used to buy them. 

The restaurant itself is pretty nice,spacious, and i love the outdoor sitting area. My company and i sat outside but under the shade of course, i do not want birdies flying over and taking a shit in my food! 

I know most yelpers are curious to how much food is...so here it is! 

Empanada Sampler (4 kinds) 19.00
Pan con Lomo (peruvian sandwich) 14.00
Cebiche clasico 18.00

$51.00+tax $5.02+SF HEATLH crap thing $1.79=$57.81+$7tip= $64.81

PRETTY PRICEY PEOPLE for just 3 things for 2 people!
author: Rose P.

description:
Food was great. Service needs work. Dined here a Friday night with a party of six and the place was packed
Took forever to get our cocktails.  Ceviche was excellent, some of the best I've ever had.  Main courses were very good 
One of our apps didn't show up until the main courses were served
Coffee took way to long to arrive.  Two ordered cappuccinos that took and additional 5 minutes before it arrived.  Not surprising that they were cold.  we finally flagged down our waiter explained to problem.  To our surprise he said it would probably happen again so he would just take it off the bill!
 First rate food, second rate service that doesn't seem to keep up with the crowd.
author: Steve M.

description: Amazing, fresh, and full of flavor! Excellent service. Don't fill too much up on the potato chips (they are addicting, trust me!) We had the Chipotle Ceviche and the Udon Noodle entree.
author: Nicole M.

description: Have gone there a few times, lunch and dinner, for a date and with our toddler...fantastic ceviche, usually staff is accurate in their descriptions, and it's a beautiful spot.  Highly recommended.
author: Ludovic B.

description: might have been better on a sunny day. Went for dinner. The "views" through the clear plastic windows in the covered patio weren't very good. The service was spotty. Drinks took forever. Food was good but overpriced. Again, probably great on a sunny day when you can sit outside. For a cozy dinner experience, i'd rather go to a smaller, more authentic place like Mi Lindo Peru.
author: slapaham s.

description:
I came here last week for dinner after hearing great things about this place and I was not disappointed. There was no room inside so we sat on the patio, they had the heat lamps on and I was in a skirt and very comfortable on a chilly SF evening.

The food was amazing, we got the grilled octopus skewers and crab appetizer. The octopus was very tender and the grilled flavor was delicious. The crab was mixed with cream and served on potatoes and it was yummy. We shared a traditional Peruvian entre of seafood and rice which was also very good and reminiscent of Paella. I am originally from the Mediterranean and it reminded more of food from home - a very pleasent surprise since I expected something totally different. 

For drinks I got something with ginger in it and my date got something with pommagranate, don't remember the names! But both very different and yummy. Although I did make him switch drinks with me, because I liked his a little better:)

All in all I would highly recommend this place. Their happy hour is said to be excellent as well. The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is the decor was a little less cohesive than I would have liked, but I'm a huge girl so that's just me! But don't me wrong it is very nice.. Definitely coming back.
author: Aleksandra B.

description: The friendliest staff, amazing ceviche, and my favorite happy hour!
author: Laura L.

description: Went for SF Restaurant Week, and after experiencing Dine LA, it was quite disappointing. We were seated quickly, but after sitting down, we were left alone for almost 15 minutes with no one coming to check on us to ask about drinks or to bring out the banana chips (which are great). For appetizers we tried the cebiche and the chicken skewer, which were both very good. While we had ordered our drinks with the food, they didn't arrive until our entrees came out. For entrees we had the Lomo Saltado and the Salmon. The lomo saltado was delicious. The beef was cooked to perfection and the sauce went well with the rice and fries. The salmon was the most disappointing part of the experience. I thought the concept of SF restaurant week was to showcase restaurants by offering a nice meal at a lower price point than usual. It seems like this restaurant decided that if you're paying less, you should get less food as well. The serving size of salmon was minuscule. It was no bigger than the size of my thumb. Honestly it looked more like a sampler than a main course. After being disappointed with the salmon it was nice to see that dessert was included in meal, which was not mentioned on the menu. I tried the tres leches cake, which came with fresh strawberries and was nice and sweet. The service throughout the meal was very slow, from the employees leaving us waiting at the start to the delay in bringing out appetizers and beverages. They were exceptionally fast at charging my card after bringing out the check though. Overall I would say this restaurant is okay, but due to the mediocre service and extremely small sizes I would not come back again.
author: Phillip D.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants of all time. Whenever someone visits SF, this is one of the first places I take them. Yes, it's pricey, but it's absolutely delicious. You pretty much can't go wrong but here are my favorites:

Chips and salsa: The chips and salsa they bring you when you sit down are amazing, definitely dig in. 
Cebiche Mixto - Delicious aji amarillo sauce that's divine
Causas -- pretty potato things with different toppings. They look almost like cupcakes. Hard to describe, but I promise you'll like them. My favorite is the one with crab.
Empanadas del mar - yum. 

Oh and the drinks are fabulous too.
author: Megan B.

description: ....if you go to a fancy place on the San Francisco waterfront expect to be hosed,,,,been there once as a guest...just not my cup of tea, if your going to spend this kind of money better to go to one of the really good places in San Francisco...
author: jim b.

description:
You know what I love?  Sitting at a table for almost twenty-five minutes (during which the server came over once to drop off menus, and a second time to assure us that she hadn't forgotten about us).  After waiting that long without having even our drink order taken, or glasses of water brought, my friends and I left and had a fabulous meal at Nopa. 

And the really great thing?  As soon as we left and were walking out the door, the server went to the table we had been sitting at and pushed in our chairs.  Classy.
author: Rowena S.

description: Awful experience.    Decided to stop by on a whim in the afternoon because I had heard of the restaurant.    Almost all the tables were empty.   4 of us wanted drinks & an appetizer.   We said this when we got menus.    We ordered & said again we were only going to order drinks & an appetizer when we ordered & the waiter said that was okay.   After the drinks came out someone came over (person at front desk) and said the tables were for dinner only, and that we would have to leave the table & go to the bar.   I said that would be fine if there was a table there but he said there was no guarantee of a table in the bar.   My 87 year old father was there, and sitting down was required for us to stay.    I explained we had been upfront with the waiter from the beginning & was either leaving without food or drink or they needed to find us a table.   They were rude & insistent we leave the table despite many empty tables.   Eventually they found us a spot in the lounge on the sofa & moved us.   Way to make someone feel second class.   I love Peruvian food but they will not get my business.    Rude rude rude!
author: Louise H.

description: I went here for Valentine's Day dinner with my BF last night, and was disappointed that they didn't offer the regular menu, instead they had a Valentine's menu, with very limited selection.  The ceviche and wagyu beef were good, although, I wasn't fond of the service.  I understand that the restaurant is busy on Valentine's night, but customer service shouldn't be compromised.  Over all, not sure if I would come back here again.  The food was good, but definitely not worth the price.
author: Ngoc N.

description: Great food, ambiance, and water front! the sampler Cebiche is a must! you have not had raw fish taste so good before (and i don't like raw fish not even sushi). Cebiche here melts in your mouth.
author: Mahasti T.

description:
The restaurant is very nice inside. Great location too.
The prices are high, which I don't mind as long as I get what I pay for
Well, their ceviche had no salt.... (yuck)
Their anticuchos were not marinated, they had no flavor what so ever, they were simply cooked, and a sauce was just added to the top. (argh!) That is NOT how you eat anticuchos.
Their entrees were ok, but not as good as I expected.
Their picarones & Pisco Sours were great! That was pretty much the only thing we were 100% satisfied with. 
When the waiter came back, I asked if the cook was Peruvian, he said no, he told us the cook was Mexican, lol.
I said no myself no wonder!!! There is no way a Peruvian chef would've allowed his food to come out with no seasoning.
To make matters worse, they charged my atm card an extra $20. I guess they decided to add their extra tip? (The bill was already almost $200) (?) Im not sure, but when I called, I could get not help, so screw it.
I had a nice time with my family because of the location, but I will not be going back to this restaurant, this place is over rated.
author: M.I. A.

description:
A Peruvian restaurant which is trying really hard to appeal to the chic, S.F. nouveau riche.  
Being a relatively positive individual, it's rare that I lament going to a restaurant with good company, but that's what happened here.

I came here in a group of about 10 friends and we were seated at our reserved table (indoors) without fuss.  We all parked on the street.  If you have a late reservation, street parking is doable.  

Decore: 
the interior decorator failed at emulating an underwater experience.  The high ceiling, hard furniture, concrete floor, and close glass entryways made for terrible acoustics.   

Service: 
The waiter was slow enough to have anemia.

The Food:
For starters we ordered cebiche chifa and cebiche clásico.
Both had sinewy fish.  This might be due to use of poor quality cuts of mahi mahi.  The chifa one has delicate flavor and included ingredients like ginger, pickled carrots and daikon, habaneros, wonton strips and cilantro.  The clasico contained the same low-grade mahi mahi and calamari, octopus and habaneros, cilantro, red onion, and corn.

Tenderloin empanadas: 3 dumplings on my appetizer-sized plate.  I was reminded of dim sum, at 3x the price.  The flavor and texture of the meat inside each of these bite-size morsels resembled simple stew meat.  The sauce around the meat was basically standard beef stew also.  The fried, layered dough wrap was the highlight.  Light, crunchy, and layered well.  But seriously, something out of chinese dim sum would have been as good.  

The Fish empanada had better flavor.  There was a sweetness in it from the added corn.  That means there really was very little fish used in these.

The calamari risotto was slightly, not extremely bland, but enough to take note.  

The only thing excellent on the menu did not come out of the sea and therefore defies the name of the restaurant.  It was a Lomo steak w/ french fries and a bowl of rice, but the price of this simple, lunch sized entree was nearly $30.

The wines were expensive, we ordered 2 bottles and there were a few single glasses dispersed about the table as well.  The carmenere was commendable in flavor and, as expected, had less tannin than a Cab.

This restaurant reminds me why locals should avoid touristy areas.  The lofty price tag for this lesson was $70/person and I was starving when I got home.
author: Gersey C.

description:
Lets start with the homemade potato chips, crunchy, not greasy and served with dippin sauces.  I could not have the sauces, but my dining companions said they were good.  The chips were quite tasty regardless.
We started with two wonderful appetizers.
The cebiche tasting was fantastic. The fish is superb and the opportunity to try four at a time is a treat. The second appetizer was the causa limeña, and it was AMAZING!  It was this fluffy potato delight (3 actually) topped dungeness crab, cherry tomato, chive and on the side a slice of quail egg and cilantro oil. I could have eaten them all myself, but my two companions would have been more than a little pissed.
Then came the entrees.  We shared two entrees, first were rich and tasty red wine marinated short ribs in a beautiful sauce. It was lip smacking good. The other dish was a lovely sea bass.   We enjoyed them both. 
The desserts were pretty great as well. We had the sorbet trio, yuuuuum, and Classic dulce de leche mousse with port wine meringue
cappuccino de tres leches.  Don't know how to explain it.  It was like velvet in the mouth and when it was gone I wanted more.
The server was incredibly knowledgeable about the menu, my gluten intolerance (w/o having to refer to the kitchen, even though I'm sure she did) and Peru.  She did a great job.
This place is dynamite.
author: Heather S.

description: My parents took me to La Mar for my  29th birthday and if you are looking for good cebiche, a view of the bay- if you're lucky- and pretty decent cocktails I highly recommend La Mar. If I had gone with a friend I would have shared cebiches and I'd probably give 4 out of 5 stars because when it comes to Peruvian food this isn't as good as it gets, but it is very good. I'm giving 5 stars because our waiter was so friendly and didn't look the least bit annoyed with my mother announcing at least a ten times that the food she was eating was most definitely the best thing she had ever tasted and maybe it was, afterall she does live just 30 minutes from Sacramento. The sauce on the food my mom ordered was good, but since I don't eat meat I can't say what the actual food tasted like. I loved my cebiche, I thought my sangria was ok and overall had a lovely 29th birthday.
author: Natalie M.

description:
My wife and I ate there last night. I have visited Peru twice in the last two years. This restaurant did not feel Peruvian. However, I liked the bar and the decor despite its lack of Peruvian authenticity.

And of course, in an ideal world I wish we had a Peruvian waiter. It would have made a bit more fun. However, the food was delicious but vastly over priced. I probably will not go back. Overall, the service was pretty good too. Also,they do really like to confirm your reservation...2 emails and a phone call the day of. Yeah. Like duh, whenever I make a reservation I immediately forget it 24 hours later. They must know that I am a card-carrying AARP member.


We had a number of Pisco Sours-- which are to die for. Very pricey. $10 each....you can get 4 of these in Cusco, Peru for this price but then I guess you would have to fly there to get them.

My wife had the lamb which was terrific. I had their etouffee-like stew which was also outstanding. Appetizer was a Mahi-Mahi (Chifa) concoction..also wonderful.

Overall, it is a great place. Right by the Bay, nice.  It is just not worth the price...or....as they say in Spanish..".no vale la pena."
author: Jeff H.

description:
Gorgeous location, gorgeous views.
Strong Pisco Sours. Delicious Cebiche.
Sloooooooooow drink service at the bar.
I'll be back for a leisurely drink out back by the water. By the bottle.
author: Carnley P.

description:
Solely for happy hour. 4-6pm. Be prepared - it seems as though it's often packed.

This is me being understanding. Yes, Ms. Waitress Lady - I know it's super busy in here, there are many tables to tend to and I understand that it will take some time for you to get to us, but please just don't forget my drinks and come back when you have time for my food order. There's still 40 minutes left to happy hour, so that's okay.

This is me being a raging bitch. Ms. Waitress Lady - please at least PRETEND to care that my friends and I exist in your happy hour space. It's okay that you don't say hi, but when we try to catch your attention, could you please at least tell us you'd come back to us? There's only 40 minutes left and I want to get my cebiche, dammit!! Where the hell are my Piscos?!!

If the service is anything like Peru, send me home please.

The 2 stars is really for the food and drinks.

I enjoyed the Pisco Punch and the Pisco Sour, but I like the Pisco Punch more because it was sweeter. Pretty much everyone in the bar was holding onto a Pisco Sour, if you were wondering.

The cebiche clasico is delish! The fish is flavorful and fresh. Yummy.

Yucca fries were good and you get a small basketful. 

Rollo Fashion was a fancy version of a California roll topped with sliced salmon and crispy noodles. 

If this is how the food is in Peru, sign me up! Duh, it's Peruvian, it has to be. HAS TO.

I realize I am now torn on Peru. Thanks a lot La Mar! 

I really wanted to like you, but I guess you don't like me. :(
author: Dolores L.

description:
CEVICHE!

GREAT food, GOOD wine, PERFECT view from the outside patio. Inside can get pretty loud so I prefer sitting outside, it's a little more intimate. Great to go with friends or on a date. The staff was very friendly. Highly recommend giving it a try especially since this was the first place I tried ceviche and I loved it. If you do plan on dining outside bring a light coat, it gets pretty chilly towards the afternoon.
author: Holly P.

description:
One of my girlfriends took me out to dinner here for my birthday a couple months after its grand opening. She was Peruvian, so her family went to the grand opening and ever since then she ranted and raved about it. We had reservations, so they seated us right away. OMG, the decor makes you feel like you're on vacation. If this is anything like Peru, please send me there NOW. There were lots of blues used in decorating. The bar had a gorgeous cobalt blue light underneath and our place mats were also blue. Gorgeous. We were seated inside, but there is outdoor seating overlooking the water.

I ordered a pisco sour. I had heard a lot about piscos, but never tried them, so I was definitely intrigued. The drink was very strong! I don't know if that's how piscos normally come because I have nothing to compare it to. I couldn't finish it because it was so strong.

We ordered the Plantain, Taro, Yam and Potato chips with 3 dipping sauces. The presentation of the sauces (even the color) brought out the decor. Needless to say, they were orgasmic. 

We also both kept it boring and ordered the Lomo Saltado for our entree. This was pre-vegetarian days for me, during my steak phase. I had tried home-cooked lomo saltado at her house before, and I remember loving it. The Lomo Saltado is a tender cut of beef cooked with onions and tomatoes and came with french fries and rice. It was sooo delicious, and filling. I wanted to be adventurous and try ceviche, but I definitely will next time. Every plate and drink that I saw come out added tones of orange, yellow, and green to the decor. Very well thought out by the owners.

When we were there, there was just plain tres leches on the menu and I LOVEEE tres leches. Definitely didn't disappoint.
author: carol a.

description:
A friend and I shared the cebiche, causa, and empanada samplers, which ended up being a perfect amount for the two of us. (We were on the hungry side.)

The cebiche came out first. The seafood was fresh and everything was good, but after a while, it all started to taste the same--like citrus and onions. 

My friend and I agreed we liked the empanada plate the best. Our favorites were the beef and mushroom.  The other veggie one (not mushroom) was too mushy and sweet. The texture wasn't appealing and it reminded us of baby food.

I wasn't a very big fan of the causas. Or maybe I was just too full to enjoy them.  I liked the top parts, but thought the potato bottoms were kind of cold and gummy.

Service was a bit lacking. The people were nice enough, but a bit inattentive. We had to ask to have our drinks refilled a few times.  Also, our waitress was pushy when it came to dessert. She asked us if we wanted anything at least three times. "Are you sure you don't want anything?" It felt like I was on "Who Wants to be a Millionaire." We don't want dessert tonight, thank you. And, yes, that's our final answer.
author: D E.

description: I would avoid this restaurant. The service is horrible. The server spilled red wine ( not ours ) on the table and arm of one of our group. The manager came over after we asked since the person who spilled left and left the wet napkins from cleaning up the wine on the floor next to the table. At that point, another server spilled another drink at the table. The manager said " there is always one table every night that everything goes wrong for " . That was the extent of the apology. No, I am sorry you have red wine on your shirt....just that comment.
author: Jon C.

description:
I've been fortunate enough to visit La Mar for both dinner and happy hour.  Both were divine.  Should you brave the happy hour special get there early, stay late, order strategically - the drinks and app specials are off the hizzo.   Alert - pisco is in the sangria - which explained why i felt oh so good after the second one. 

In the main dining area, our server was patient and very attentive. I am a seafood lover so I walked in ready to love the place and was not disappointed.  The dishes are fun, light and full of flavor.
author: Angela N.

description:
Went here for a Sunday late lunch with the Mrs.  The location and decor seemed like the perfect spot for a sunny weekend day.  Right on the water, this place is done up with brilliant blues and lush potted plants.  You walk in and start thinking vacation.  Walking past the bar, you'll see the catch of the day nicely displayed on ice.  Really sets the tone for what's to come.

The food was really good however the service started out strong but fell flat mid-meal.  We had to scan the restaurant with that "Where are you?" look till someone found our waitress.  Thus I give them 3 stars.  How can you leave customers stranded mid-way at a place like this?  Location alone should demand staff try and turn tables as often as possible.

The menu is set up for sharing and tasting, mostly appetizers where you can get a specific items or a combo of their most popular.

Ceviche (or Cebiche) was fan-fricken-tastic.  I will go back for this again (and maybe again).  The perfect blend of citrus and salt and spice.  Next time I plan to get a sampler, the hamachi we had was great and I can only imagine how the other fish tastes.

The empanadas also a real winner.  The filling was just the right amount to comliment the crispy outside.  Sometimes empanadas wind up either doughy and uncooked or dried out and tough but these little darlings left us wishing we had ordered more.

The only items not to my liking was the grilled octopus and the drinks we ordered.  I love me some octopus but it's got to be done right.  These were a little tough and by the time we got them a bit cold.  Such a heat sensitive beasty really needs to come right off the grill and right to your mouth otherwise you get seafood taffy.

We ordered pisco sours (for the first time)  which were okay but just not my taste.  I can't knock them too much for that I just don't like things too sweet.

Again I liked most we had to eat and would go back again for sure but I'm not rushing to get there.  I have to wonder when service is slow when the restaurant is half empty, how is it when tables are stacked up?
author: Henk V.

description: Omg yum! This place is sooo good! My company had a client holiday party here last night and they totally took care of us. The service was prompt, friendly, and delicious. We got to try an assortment of their small bites, my favorite being the beef/red pepper/onion skewers, and spoonfuls of fish, potatoes, cheesecake, etc. Oh and how can I forget the mousse as dessert, which was rich and hard for me to resist more than one. I also tried their Malbec and sauvignon blanc wines, which were tasty as well. We could tell that our guests really enjoyed themselves and we of course loved it as well!  I definitely want to come back for dinner one of these days...
author: Sonya D.

description:
Stumbled on this place by accident (no reservation). It wasn't showing up on my Yelp app map as we walked along the Embarcadero, but lucky for us, we stopped to check out the menu.

Staff were very nice and attentive. Environment was agreeable in a historic building. You can sit at the bar, out in the main restaurant where the action is, or on the patio (which had heaters) where you can look at the water.

Good, interesting selections on the menu. Kitchen is essentially in the main part of the restaurant so you can see the staff working on preparations. Everything looked great. The rollitos (sushi options) looked really good but we didn't try them.

Instead of bread they bring you a basket of a mixture of chips: plantain, sweet potato, and regular potato chips with two sauces, one mild and one spicy. Found out later the mild one is from emulsified queso fresca and some kind of yellow chile (not hot). Sauces were very good with the chips.

Interesting drink selection with a variety of beers & sakes (didn't look at the wine list but there was one). I tried one of their sakes for $11 a glass. It came in a cordial glass which is very small. I didn't expect that nor did it specify what a 'glass' was, but the sake was good. For anyone who likes warm sake, they don't carry any.

We each got a sandwich: one chicken, one roast beef. I tried both and they were very good, served on fresh baguette. The roast beef sandwich was a little light on meat though and is assembled in such a way that it slides apart (meat piled on top of lettuce & tomatoes = slip-slidin'-away). I had to restack things to make it easier to eat. The chicken sandwich gave you more substance. Both sandwiches have the choice of salad, or fries. Fries were good, generous portion. Salad dressing tasted like a light sesame oil asian-style dressing and was very good, but the salad was the size of a cup of soup.

For dessert we tried the tasting trio: 3 desserts served as mini versions of themselves, in shot glasses. One was a limon pie (very much like key lime pie, not too sweet which is the way I like it), a chocolate mousse creation with a touch of raspberry, and an arroz con leche dessert that is not featured by itself as a choice. It was a perfectly sized dessert for us - enough little spoonfuls for 2 people to get a variety of flavors without overindulging and feeling stuffed.

I would definitely go here again - loved the service and saw lots of other things that looked great to try. Lunch for the 2 of us was $58 without tip.
author: Jody T.

description:
Decided on this place to have Dad's bday dinner because of an article I recently read in Time about Peruvian food being amazing.  Good choice!! 

I made a reservation a couple of weeks ago through OpenTable so that was taken care of.  They don't seat you until your whole party has arrived though.  While you're waiting you can take a tour of the two contrasting bathrooms in the lobby area!  One is a "Marked Historic Landmark" while the other is a very modernly decorated one.  Just to, yknow, pass the time. 

The decor is really nice and on a clear day the view is spectacular.  I love the shade of blue they use, it's unique and beautiful.  

Our waiter was pretty helpful and very nice.  He was also incredibly handsome.

I had my first Pisco Sour and it was quite strong but delicious!  Definitely recommended.  

We ordered the Cebice Tasting (4 Ceviches), Empanada Sampler (beef, seafood, corn, chicken), Una (cashew croquettes with crab and shrimp and chicken.. served on  bok choy), and the antichuco de corazon (beef hearts).  My brother ordered the steak entree.

The chips ARE good but the majority are potato chips which kinda sucks because the plantain ones and the sweet potato ones are so much better!  

Okay.  So first comes this plate with what appears to be some meat salad atop 4 yellow and purple pieces of play dough.  Our server went to explain each of the toppings and we kind of just went at it.  For some reason we thought this was the ceviche.  After all, there were 4 things... but it was so small!  Later we found out, it was not.  They had given us the causas tasting instead.  (traditional Peruvian whipped potato with ají amarillo and seafood or vegetarian toppings) Our waiter came by to tell us as we were digging at it, and our server later asked us why we didn't say anything.  WHOOPSIES!!  lol they gave it to us on the house but I do feel really bad about eating something that we didn't even order.  

Then the ceviche came for real.  And it looked like what you would think it should look like.  My favorite was the Mixto.  The hailbut one (Clasico) was way too fishy/chunky for me.  I enjoyed the Ahi Tuna one (nikei) as well as the Chifa (mahi mahi).  Mmm so fresh and so yum yum!

I'd never had beef hearts so I was a bit apprehensive, but it came with this amazingly spicy sauce that I had to try.  It's kinda more chewy than beef from other parts of the cow... but it has a very distinct flavor and texture.  I liked it a lot!  It was also served with huge corn kernels that were chewy and just interesting, as well as a couple of pieces of fried potato.

The una was cool.  Wetter than I imagined it would be.  By that point I was too buzzed/full to truly enjoy it, but my dad liked it a lot.  It looks like those crab croquettes you get at dimsum restaurants that are actually stuffed with shrimp meat.  Do you know what I'm talking about? Yeaaa those!

Brother liked his beef entree a lot.  It was served with fries and a bowl of corn-infused rice.  I had a chunk of steak and it was divine.  Even the tomato was amazing.

What a great dinner!  Wish I had had room for dessert.
author: Lydia W.

description: Just a warning the green dipping sauce that comes with the chips, and the brown one that comes with the empanadas has peanuts in it, but you should anyways ask for their other red salsa/sauce, its damn spicy and damn good. Just a little will go a long way with all the habaneros they use.
author: Johnny C.

description:
My friend spoke highly of this restaurant so I decided to try the place on a Friday night.  The restaurant is huge and located along the Embarcadero and thank goodness they offer valet parking.  The decor and ambiance of the restaurant is sleek and modern.

I've never had Peruvian food so I really appreciated the server's explanation of the menu.  We picked a little of everything off the smaller plates (tapas) and had a great time sharing everything.  When you get to sample many different plates and get to savor each bite and each bite tastes really good, you know you've found a great place.

Even the drinks were good.  Do try their pisco sour.

But, I cannot give them 5 stars as I find their prices a bit high for what it was.
author: Elaine L.

description:
I should start by saying I've never liked cebiche, so read the rest of this review accordingly. But: I'd heard such good things about La Mar, I thought I'd give cebiche another try. I still don't like it. It's not bad, I just don't see what the big deal is: it's like sushi with some mayonnaise and lemon mixed in.  So that's the food. My guess is: if you like cebiche, you'll probably like it here just fine. 

As for the rest of it: service was a little too casual for my taste, and the waiter missed a couple things in our order. But it's an attractive, lively restaurant, the pisco sour was excellent, and it's a nice view out onto the water. 

And is it authentic Peruvian? I've been to Peru, and La Mar didn't taste anything like the sour alpaca steak with mushy potatoes and coca tea I got served multiple times. So maybe La Mar might not be authentic, but that's probably a good thing.
author: Syd S.

description:
I've reviewed this place before when the first opened and a bit later when they found their restaurant legs. However, I think they deserve a brief update.

My BIGGEST complaint with La Mar was portion size.  They seem to have figured this out and adjusted. We had the Ceviche Classico last week and it was tasty delicious and just right for two people.   The ONLY thing missing are the cancha. This is easy to import and toasty cancha make all the difference with traditional peruvian ceviche.
author: Kent L.

description:
La Mar is definitely a fine dining restaurant that deserves acclaim, but I think it was just overhyped for me.

My company had our department lunch here and we all left hungry! The food was prepared well, but for the price and portion size, FORGET IT! We had one entree of los saltido (peruvian style beef tenderloin) to split amongst FOUR people. It was definitely not enough. We also had the squash risotto to split amongst 4 of us.

In the beginning there were some h'ors deurves being passed around in cute little spoons, but not enough to go around for everyone. I didn't even get to try the cebiche! 

The wines they had for us were very good, crisp and fruity. Service was also just so-so. They went around asking what kind of coffee everyone wanted, however that wasn't covered as part of our group purchase...the waiter probably didn't know..but we all got hyped up about coffee until we learned we'd have to pay out of pocket for it.

Anyway, based on this brief experience, I most probably will not be coming back here. I didn't see what was so special about this place and I would not pay the price they ask for for their dishes. It's just too expensive for food you can get elsewhere.
author: Julia K.

description:
So in a "dance 10, looks 3" mentality, La Mar is a food 10, service 3.  Maybe the waiters are still on unemployment...

I went here with a colleague after a full day at the Fancy Food show so we were looking for a light dinner.  We were seated very quickly, but it took forever to actually get a waiter.  We got water quickly, but really it was like 20 minutes before we saw our waiter. We even had to ask for a waiter twice.  We should have just left then, but decided to stay.

Once we finally did get our waiter's attention, we decided to split the cebiche sampler as well as the empanada samplers.  After waiting so long for the initial visit, we weren't sure how long our food would take, but it was out in a matter of minutes.  The empanadas were tasty, but the cebiches were the star.  All four were great, although they were a little heavy on the red onions. And listen to them when they say avoid the piece of habanero chile on the top of the cebiche.

Sadly, we did not see our waiter once while we were eating and when we were finished, it was a complete repeat of the before food experience. It took us another 30 minutes to get our check, wait for him to take the card, and then wait for him to return.  

So, dance 10, looks 3.
author: Robert T.

description:
This place is amazing!! 

First off, the wait staff was awesome. The waitress my boyfriend and I had was very attentive, gave great tips and recommendations, and gave great explanation of what we were eating. 

Secondly, the portions are pretty good. We ordered, a bottle of white wine, the ceviche sampler, the empanada sampler, a main course, and dessert... and we were perfectly stuffed. Also it was reasonably priced, we spent under 200 with tip for all mentioned items. 

Definitely make reservations to eat here because it is very popular.
author: Ashley s.

description:
We came here for Valentine's day, so couldn't order off the regular menu, but that certainly didn't impact the food or the experience.  Everything was absolutely delicious.  For $75 we got a 4 course meal & 1 drink.  I ordered a couple more drinks than that, and this is what I got:

1) Ceviche course - Ceviche Nikei (Tuna with Japanese cucumbers & avocado).  Realllllllllly delicious.  The tuna was very fresh, not at all fishy, & so delicious.

2) First course - Causa duo (One topped with dungeness crab & a quail egg, One topped with aritchokes, avocado, & asparagus.  Equally delicious).

3) Main course - Risotto Camarones (Quite good & the shrimp were cooked perfectly).

4) Dessert - Trio of desserts (Rice pudding, dulce de leche mousse, & a chocolate crepe.  Yummmmmmmm on all 3.)

Drinks: started with the Chica tu Ma! (my favorite), and followed that with the Santa Maria & the Passion Andina.

Besides that, service was outstanding & the ambiance/decor was great.  I would definitely make a return trip here.
author: Jenna H.

description:
The decor in this place is lovely; main theme being white with a few accent colors. I am a strong believer in a visually pleasant atmosphere. The place is huge including a patio facing out to the bay, a separate bar room, indoor dinning area & very big sushi bar. 

Recommend Cebiche;  Ahi Tuna & carretillero (mixed sea foods)
The Cebiche's is served like sashimi that is covered in a bowl of zesty sauce (each is different depending on selection of Cebiche) definitely different then spanish Ceviche.

As for the Main course; 'sanguches y platos' (Peruvian classics)
I highly recommend; lomo saltado

I love that they use traditional Peruvian ingredients in their menu, which makes each recipe unique including - the red pepper served as a side (looks like salsa) its extremely good & doesn't leave the chilly after taste in your mouth (by far the best chilly sauce i've had) and I have a love for spice. 

Overall the ambiance, waiters service knowledge, especially the food was fantastic!
I am now definitely a fan of Peruvian food! 

http://lamarcebicheria.com/web/index.php
