author: Milena R.

description: I lived in Peru for several months, and this formal place takes away from authentic Peruvian culture but stays true to the taste. I went here and was surprised that most of the items on the menu you would also find in Peru as well. The sauces were pretty on point and the seafood was delicious. The atmosphere is a bit too haughty but that's probably because it's on the water in the Embarcadero. The staff were more than nice, they were over-accommodating, and the food was not bad. It's definitely a fusion of Peruvian and California cuisine with a couple items that stay true to Peru. If you want a night on the town and try a new type of cuisine come here, but don't expect to be transported back to your homeland if you are Peruvian.
author: Dani B.

description:
Dinned here on a saturday night.  The food was okay.  I've been to another Peruvian so I can't really say I'm an expert on Peruvian food.  The cebiche was good.  I would go with the tasting cebiche again.  

The reason for the lower stars though was service.  Service was slow that night.  Our waiter was never around.  It seemed like he was overwhelmed for his station.  And when he was around, he seemed rushed to answer our question and take our orders so he could move on to this next person.
author: Doug C.

description: Sloooooow service, though restaurant was empty. Vegetarian options limited and not easily amendable for vegans. I ordered a quinoa "salad" which was literally a scoop of cold quinoa on a plate. Overpriced. Not my favorite.
author: Stacey R.

description: If you love fresh seafood and interesting combinations, then La Mar is the place to go.  Their ceviche combinations are truly out of this world.  Also, you can't go wrong with the local cocktails either!
author: Nancy L.

description:
wow this place is amazing! I came here for lunch with my husband and mom and ordered a few dishes. As many of you might now by reading my other reviews you know  I am a die hard ceviche fan. I grew up eating ceviche and I had never had peruvian ceviche till I came here. I ordered the Ceviche Mixer which had four different ceviches my favorite was probably the ceviche carretillero which had mussels shrimp calamari and clams. The ambiance was relaxed we sat outside had a great view of Alcatraz and the Bay bridge. definitely coming here again when im in San Francisco
It only doesnt get a fifth star because the servings are too small for such high prices but over all good.
author: Juliette P.

description:
Pisco sour - interesting, a bit strong but that's fine as one's all you need
Chips with 3 salsas - awesome, and dangerously easy to fill up on especially after the pisco-sour-induced "drunken munchies"
Ceviche chipotle - very good seafood but overwhelmed by spice
Sea bass sashimi - very good seafood again with an excellent sauce
Octopus skewers - delicious, very flavorful
Empanadas - still craving these
Bunuelos - still craving these as well, delicious
Environment - very chic decor and fun, lively atmosphere
Service - terrific, very friendly server
Price - a little expensive but worth it for all of the above

Overall, it adds up to 5 stars, easily. One of the best and most unique meals I've had in SF.
author: S R.

description: Magic happened at this restaurant because of the amazing company, great service and food/cocktails. Hopefully it will be as pleasant when I go back.
author: Valerie V.

description:
I am for sure coming back here again! It's a great place for food (tapas style!), and seems like a fun place for happy hour.  Our service was pretty good, I think one of the managers or maybe owner had helped our table, so he knew all the low down.  Everything was so fresh and presentation was so well put!  

*Cebiche tasting:  I liked them all, I couldn't pick a favorite.  Though I would say for a table of 6 the cebiche tasting wasn't enough to go around.
* Causas tasting:  I had no clue what this was.  I thought it would be like a seafood type of American baked potato or something.  Ha - so wrong! When I saw it come out, I was admiring the pretty little things.  But the potato also reminded me of the bright purple and yellow play-do. It was very interesting, but quite yummy nevertheless.
* Rollitos:  Peruvian - Japanese inspired sushi rolls.  I love my sushi!  Way good!  

Great place to dine, while not having food weigh you down.  It's chic, refreshing, and fun!
author: Kathy D.

description: This is a really gorgeous restaurant. I got 2 pisco sours - they were great. Got beef empanadas that I devoured in 10 seconds. Also they put like, yucca and sweet potato chips on the table with different dipping sauces. So addictive! I was so full by the time my cebiche clasico came around...mmmmm that was some fresh fish! The citrus and the hunks of white halibut flesh, it was everything ceviche should be. Peruvian food is one of the best cuisines in the world, in my opinion. My mom got a noodle dish that was also wonderful - it had calamari and meet and shrimp and was pretty decadent. We were stuffed at the end of the meal and I would have gotten dessert if I didn't think I was going to explode - but the people next to us got these donut looking things with a chocolate sauce dumped all over it. If my stomach wasn't already at its wits' end I would have just smashed my face in it. Incredible dining experience - I highly recommend going to it for the food and lovely view of the bay!
author: Anna T.

description:
This is my 2nd time and was not disappointed good food and service, casual dinning.

The price was perfect! I recommend this to anyone
author: madi b.

description:
On Labor Day, we came here for an afternoon...snack. We went to the bar to order some cebiche and drinks.

Granted, I know that bar service sucks substantially less than the restaurant side, so I do cut them a little slack...but...well, read on.

It took a while for our waitress to drop off menus and we had to wait a long time for her to come back. By then, we flagged her down in order for her to take our orders.

We ordered the cebiche tasting (Mixto, Chifa, Nikei and Clásico) and a cocktail for each of us (4). 

We ended up getting our cebiche well before our cocktails, which is NOT supposed to happen. All four cebiches were...bland, sorry to say. The cocktails were all good, though, so that was nice, but...we were there for the cebiche and...nope...did not hit the spot. 

We all hung out for a bit just to talk and enjoy the company, but we all started to realize that our waitress had...disappeared. We continued to wait to see until she would reappear, but after almost two hours of waiting for her, we had to flag someone else down. Mind you, we could have walked straight out of that place and nobody would have noticed! Our waitress did not come to check up on us, nor did we see her anywhere after our food was dropped off. What kind of service is that? At least pass us along to someone else.

Instead of walking out, we ended up getting our check and leave $0 for tip. Yes, sounds harsh, but you had to be there. Bad service, mediocre cebiche, and...BAD SERVICE. Sorry La Mar...not coming back.
author: Diana Lyn Z.

description:
Go here for their Pisco Sour during happy hour.  Tasty!

Can't recommend anything else.  Food was over priced and not that good.  Especially their ceviche is sub par... sushi with a splash of lemon juice.
author: Pietari G.

description:
I have to admit that I am the only misfit I know who does not love La Mar.  I am always open-minded when it comes to food, but sometimes it's hard to get out of that comfort zone and succumb to the seduction of foreign, *exotic* flavors.  In this case, it was Peruvian that failed to enamour my taste buds. 

The restaurant itself is absolutely exquisite.  The shades of blue and the chic decor is very impressive, and is also a great place to go to for special occasions (i.e. first date, client meetings, reunions, etc.).

What I've heard -- and also found to be true -- is that they have a great selection of drinks.  After trying several Pisco cocktails, I found love in the Pisco punch.

I spent the night with my Pisco punch while I cautiously tried different cibiche, mahi mahi, ahi tuna, and fancy salad dishes.  My favorite was the causa nikei.  The purple potato and creamy avocado puree was heavenly.  However, as beautiful, colorful, and carefully prepared each dish was, I just wasn't able to acquire the overall Peruvian taste.

If you're the cool kid who loves extraneous, unoridinary, sexy Latin food -- this would be the perfect place for you.
author: Judy C.

description:
I came here for happy hour and was a little disappointed...

ATMOSPHERE

The restaurant itself is really swanky and hip, which is cool, except if you come for happy hour, you're restricted to a TINY room by the bar (which is to the right of the entrance, right next to the host/hostess). It's impossible to find a spot to stand/sit if you come late.

The bartender was nice, but some of the servers were very hasty and rude.

FOOD
The portions are SO tiny, which I guess are to be expected since the prices range from $3-7. 

I ordered the CEBICHE CLASICO, which was tasty but very small. It wasn't the traditional cebiche that I'm used to. It came with bigger chunks of raw mahi mahi and it was sitting in leche de tigre, which is this murky white water that was flavorful. The blend of flavors was nice and fresh, but it just wasn't enough food!

My friend ordered the ROLLO FASHION, which was just an expensive and mediocre California roll. There weren't that many pieces (of course...) and I could've gotten better "sushi" somewhere else.

The PISCO SOURS were all over the place-- almost everyone was holding one. I personally didn't try one, but my friend did and said it was very delicious.

We asked for TEQUILA SHOTS, and the bartender gave us a cool history lesson on tequila and served us tequila from the original makers of Patron.

Overall, I didn't get the entire experience during happy hour, so I'll probably come back in the future for dinner. However, my advice is to stray away from La Mar during happy hour because it's too crowded and the food's not worth it.
author: Krystie M.

description:
A few months ago when I pulled in to Sam's in Tiburon on a boat I felt like a total douche.

When I pulled into La Mar, however, I just felt like a baller!
author: Jason R.

description: Absolutely love this place. Right by the water and the food is incredible. Authentic Peruvian dishes are all over the menu and empanadas are magnificent. I had the combination which was well worth it. Also had a ceviche appetizer that was packed with flavor and seafood. Not the cheapest place but is well worth the dining experience.
author: Brad B.

description:
My fiance and I ate here tonight. We sat at the cebiche bar because we didnt have a reservation. We ordered the seafood rice in black beer, which was awesome, the beef empanadas, and a delicious cebiche with clams and octopus. We had great drinks--pisco mule and a a passionfruit  mix. 

The service was good. Second time here and just as great.
author: Lady L.

description: Yum causas and empenados, washed down with a beer
author: Derek L.

description:
Awesome food + great scene + wonderful friends = Perfect birthday celebration!

I went to La Mar last night for my "22nd" birthday celebration, and it was a great night.  We had a comfy booth/table that had one spot with a pillow on it; somehow, they knew I was a midget and needed an adult-style booster seat.  The staff was super friendly and helpful.  The wines they suggested were tasty and reasonably priced.  

We started with the delicious. savory cebiche sampler.  All of it was great, but I looooved the ahi tuna (it is my favorite fish after all).  The causas pretty much melted in my mouth!  At my friend's prodding, I did try beef heart, and while the flavor was good, I was not a fan of the consistency (it felt like I was crunching on a firm, spongy piece of fat).  My entree, the atun, was pretty darn good, but almost a bit too peppery.  The empanada sampler was heavenly; I don't remember what was in each of the empanadas, but I do remember loving each bite of them.  For dessert, they brought out a dish of a trio of sorbets made of things that I've never heard of; interesting flavors.  Then came the picarones; yes, I know if you fry just about anything, it will taste good, but fried sweet potato drizzled with syrup is just yum!

I love the design of this place.  Sleek lines, cool lighting.  Trendy without feeling cold or pretentious.

This place is a bit pricey, but you are paying for some quality food in addition to great atmosphere.  And, we did get a ton of food, so I think it was worth it.

La Mar has made it to my list of favorites in SF.  Thanks for helping to make my birthday so special!
author: Danielle B.

description: I had read and heard a lot about this restaurant and finally got a chance to go last night. I maybe a little biased but I am in love with Embarcadero area in SF..its just beautiful so needless to say if you can score an outdoor seating..its totally worth the trip... Since I had a diner reservation, finding street parking wasn't a big hassle.. though during the day specially weekends parking could be a nightmare... food was phenomenal and thank you fellow yelpers for identifying the good stuff :) we went for cebiche tasting ... the fish was fresh and full of flavor...next we had a causa limeña and empanadas de lomo saltado.. both dishes came with 2 servings.. a lot of fellow yelpers have complained about the portion size.. I sort of agree though I wasn't starving hungry when I got in... however, the best part of the meal were complimentary sweet potato chips..they were just awesome...
author: Sean M.

description: Do go here for happy hour.  It gets busy, but the food and drinks are solid.  I actually came here twice because the Pisco Sour is that good.  I actually tried making one a few days back, and it turned out horribly wrong.  The bartender gave me the step-by-step and then gave me tastes.  Order the Pisco and some chips and salsa.  Then hit up ATT Ball Park.
author: Bruce B.

description:
Service: average, the waiter that served us was really nice but he didn't check up on us until quite late.

Food: decent, portion is good.  

Atmosphere: slightly pretentious but design is refreshing

Price: could be cheaper for such simple food and minimal service

Overall value: B-

Go back again?  Probably not.
author: julia c.

description:
Maitre d'  was welcoming, accommodating and positive. He did come check how we were enjoying our meal, and I very much like that!
Hubby and I shared everything. 
-Delicious and tender lamb entree-*seco de cordero (tI don't think we got the mint sauce with it)
- Tried  skirt steak empanadas-*empanadas de lomo saltado and both hubby and I agreed they had such little filling, we couldn't taste the beef. I forked over the bulk of mine to hubby since deep fried crust was okay with him.
-The crab-causa limena had a beautiful presentation and was so delicate, I suggest trying it before anything else to truly appreciate it's delicate flavors. I'd enjoyed some of the dipping sauces with chips and a cocktail before I tried it. The other flavors I'd enjoyed "roughed up" my taste buds, and make me think that dish needed salt!
-Loved the chicken skewer-*anticucho de pollo
Really appreciated the CLEAN,smooth and spot free  hand polished stainless utensils and loved getting new forks! 
Had chocolate envy when I saw private party getting shooter or shot glass  sized chocolate desserts that I didn't see on the menu.
Tobias took care of us. Was there for and on my birthday and received a little treat that was covered in chocolate. That cleared up the boo-boo lip very quickly, and had me smiling brightly. Only wished I'd ordered a coffee or espresso drink with it!
Hope to go back soon.
author: Monica K.

description:
I like this place. The food is good to great; I personally always order the lomo saltado ( a staple Peruvian dish), their ceviches options are always fresh and love the  empanadas ( chicken the best). I love Peruvian food period so this is the place to go to impress. There are one or two other places with almost equally as good food and cheaper but the decor and service has always been solid so I rather spend the extra cash here.

On a side note they are open for lunch on the weekends so if it's nice you can sit on their patio area looking out on the bay.
author: Lynn L.

description:
Came here with a friend on a lovely Friday night last week around 6p.  It wasn't crowded when we arrived, but by the time we left around 8p, it was BUMPIN'. We sat outside and it was SUCH a nice view with great food.  It was all the better b/c he paid (he owed me - BIG TIME); I savored. 

What we ate:  

cebiche clasico - California Halibut in a classic leche de tigre, red onions, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam ($18)
- tangy and just enough spicy to make you want more

anticuchos de pulpo - Grilled octopus skewers, herbed mashed potato
with chimichurri sauce and ají panca. ($16)
- the octopus was unusually tender and the mashed potatoes complemented it v. well.

empanadas de aji de gallina - stuffed with stewed chicken in an aji amarillo sauce ($10)
- probably the best empanada i've ever had. had a buttery, flaky, crispy taste which made all the difference...

lomo saltado - traditional Peruvian style stir-fry of sautéed beef tenderloin, onions,tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic with fried potatoes and rice ($27)
- just okay...i was expecting the flavors to explode in my mouth as it normally does at other peruvian restaurants where i've been. the beef, however, was ridiculously succulent. 

Drinks: 
- get the Cusquena beer, NOT the Cristal (beer, people, not the champagne - calm down).  I mean, both were good, but the Cusquena has more body.  ($4-5: not bad for imported Peruvian beer)

Dessert: 
- chocolate-filled beignets (more like little balls with semi-sweet chocolate) with passion-fruit ice-cream.  ($10?  BIGGEST disappointment of our whole meal. Sounds better than it tastes. Save your money and get dessert elsewhere!).  

Unexpected treat: 
- home-made chip medley made from potatoes, sweet potatoes, plantains (on the house)

I don't understand why people complain about the service.  Our waiters were awesome.  The only problem was that they cleared our plates too quickly.  My friend wanted more chips but they took it away before it was too late.  Just be on-guard of the super vigilant plate snatchers!
author: S K.

description:
Fresh fried chips w/their dips was awesome.

Complimentary shot of pisco sour!   Yum!

Sampler of empanada's were good.

Sampler of their causas were OK, some were better than others, I liked the Nikei and the Criolla best.

The special they had that night w/duck confit risotto was delicious, but their special whole fried fish was only mediocre.  The lomo saltado was tasty, but not sure it was worth $27.
author: Kit E.

description: So Delicious! And a great atmosphere. I had never tried peruvian food and this was a great intro! Loved the pisco sours and they have the most amazing ceviche. Will definitely be back for more.
author: Jackie G.

description:
A Cebicheria indeed... they have like about 5 different kinds I believe, or more. Me and the GF went for lunch, so of course the menu will be a little different. When we were first sat, we were given a basket of slim cut fried potato slices and plantains (platanos to my Latino peoples!), they were served w/ a trio of dipping sauces. Like the ceviches, one was sweet w/ a mild earthy flavor, another had a nutty flavor, and another was spicy w/ a bit of awesome sweetness. 

I wanted to try all the different ceviches, but didn't wanna stuff my face w/ nuthin' but ceviche. We ordered the sampler that came w/ four different ceviches, an ALL OF THEM WERE EXCELLENT! I forgot the names of the plates, but each had a distinct flavor to them. One was spicy, sweet, tangy, and a combination of them all. The ceviches were made w/ fresh ingredients which only added to the great flavor! 

We wanted to try a bit of a few things, so instead we decided to share a couple of dishes. We ordered the beef empanadas, which were AWESOME, and a few other things... I apologize since I have been a way a bit I cannot give further accurate comments. I do plan on returning soon! 

But I do remember one of the desserts we ordered... it was the binuelos, which was VERY GOOOODDD!  Small puff fried balls filled w/ melted chocolate.... mmmm.... along w/ a sort of ice cream.... double mmmm....

I will say this. The Pisco Sour, good stuff, however if you're not a fan of sour flavors, then this ain't gonna change your mind. I had to get a different rum drink! A bottle of rum for me please! 

Anyways, I recommend this place to anyone who is out to try something fresh and new.
author: Jo R.

description: Dinner last night with four friends. I had the Peruvian equivalent of paella, excellent. Four friends had other dishes, three were excellent, one only good. Nice atmosphere and service. Interesting menu. Will definitely go again.
author: Ellie O.

description:
We had found this place purely by luck as we were driving toward Fisherman's Wharf and decided to stop at the nearby outdoor market.  Saying this, I'm really glad that we did and we will certainly come back the next time we're in San Francisco.  

For starters, the staff were posh yet really friendly and provided excellent service.  After some great tips, we ended up ordering the daily special cebiche and arroz dishes.  Our daughter ended up enjoying the chips made of plantains, potatoes, etc. and the yummy dips (she REALLY enjoyed the creamy dips!).  So we're off to a great start!

Then the cebiche came out and now I'm a huge fan of a Peruvian food.  As I am a sashimi lover and having disdain in the idea of cooking wonderfully fresh fish (i.e. the foodie in me says fresh fish must be raw!), I shamefully have to admit I never tried cebiche until now.  And now that I have tried it at La Mar, I have a sneaking suspicion that I will have to fly to Peru to get anything better (now, that's a great excuse to go to Peru but far outside the bounds of this review!).  

Already sated on the cebiche, the arroz dish came out and provided us a mixture of great seafood, rice, and wonderful flavors.  It was a very satisfying dish yet you never felt weighed down.  

If you consider yourself a foodie or just plainly interested in Peruvian food, I do highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Denny L.

description: Ceviche selection is phenomenal. Good drinks, fun atmosphere.
author: Jules A.

description: We only stopped by here for one thing.. pisco sours! Bar was busy, but we found a seat easily. The pisco sours were delicious, frothy, and strong. They must sell quite a few of these as they are pre-made and poured from a pitcher. Service is quick. I do want to try the food next time.
author: Angie Q.

description: Wonderful food. Awesome location. Spectacular views. Huge place with great staff. Five stars.
author: Christoph O.

description: I'm a fan of the happy hour! Great deal and the waitress was perfectly attentive. The only critizism that I have to say is that the yellow orange sauce that is on nearly every dish is made from the strangest NOT gluten free ingredients. The sauce is made from nacho cheese and soda crackers blended up to look like the average cream sauce. It didn't even cross my mind to ask what was in the sauce because everything else was made with such purity and naturally flavorful. I ate a few bites before asking what the sauce was and now I'm gluten sick. :(
author: Jess G.

description: I've been to this place 3 times, and each experience has been mixed. The meal starts out promising with the complimentary chips and sauces, and then goes downhill after that. The ceviches are fresh, the entrees uninventive but good. The worst part of each visit has been the waitstaff.  Arrogant and dismissive. Our waiter last week was the worst, and seemed to purposely avoid us. Maybe we weren't hip enough. We were celebrating a birthday and had brought in our own cake. Mr. arrogant wasn't aware of the cake and after 15 minute announced that it was mistakenly frozen and said he hoped for the best. Another 15 minutes before they brought it out. Luckily it wasn't ruined. After we paid for our check we asked for the reminder of our cake. Waiter seemed surprised and eventually brought it out.  Nice atmosphere and promising menu; the waitstaff just needs an attitude adjustment.
author: Nancy F.

description:
I went here for a weekend lunch with some friends from Peru who had been to the Lima, Peru restaurant on several occasions. I was, as always, my own food critic, but I was even more interested to hear their opinion of the food since they are accustomed to true Peruvian cuisine.

My take on La Mar - 

Restaurant Décor/Location: The restaurant itself was large and tastefully decorated. The best part is the outdoor seating (make sure to have a reservation to get outside) that overlooks a beautiful Bay view.  

Service: The service was slow but that didn't seem to affect my experience as I was enjoying the company that I was with - if I were on a time crunch, I may have been slightly annoyed. 

Food: Good - the classic ceviche was fabulous - the halibut was wonderful but the star was the liquid that it was "cooked" in - I'd get it again. We also tried the mahi mahi ceviche with habanero - it was good as well but was second to the classic in my opinion. The surprise star was the causa with the tuna tartar on top. It was a beautiful and unique dish that was really flavorful and well prepared. The free chips (plantain, sweet potato, potato) and three dips were a nice start to the meal and kept coming throughout).

Drinks: The best reason to come to La Mar. I tried about 5 different drinks, all containing Pisco (no, I did not order 5 drinks for myself), and all were fabulous. The Saxon was my choice and was so refreshing with the basil and lemon flavors. At about $10 per cocktail, I'd say that's worth it.

Value: For quality fish, the prices seem to be fair. It is a little expensive for a lunch meal (I'm not sure how dinner is) but the ceviche was quality so that's what you pay for (plus probably a little bit of a name and scene).

Overall: I would go back and think the best way to experience this place is to go for drinks and accompany them with a bit of ceviche.

Peruvian take - 

Authentic. They said it tasted just as it does in Peru. There are a few Americanized items but the classic ceviche here = classic ceviche in Peru. They even asked for shot glasses to drink up the remaining liquid in the ceviche - a common habit in Peru I was told.
author: Katie S.

description:
All around good fun spot to go to. Their sangria is delicious!!! Definitely make a reservation before you go. We went there on a Tuesday night and the wait for the dining room was an hour! YES, I said a Tuesday night! 
So, anyhoo, there was no wait for the ceviche bar so we sat there. BEWARE of the ceviche bar, you will have to flail your arms around just to get service. Once you do, however, the service is great and friendly. Wait, except for the guys that just serve you drinks. Don't even think about asking them for a food item because they get mad. They also don't even tell the right person for you...weird right? In fact, I'm going to deduct a star for that. Now they're down to 3!
Ok, onto the good part. Their food! Their ceviche is soooooo good. We got an extra spoon just to drink the sauce like soup. The causa with prawn was really good too. It was also really rich so be prepared for the filling whipped potato. The beef skewer wasn't so great. It was really over cooked and tough. What's the number of how many times to chew your food? 30 or something? Yeah, well the beef required about 87.
I'll go back again for sure BUT I'll make a reservation and also probably stick to their seafood.
author: Janu A.

description:
I'm probably one of the few people that didn't find this restaurant to be that great.  

We had dinner on the patio at 7:30 on a Saturday night.  The outdoor seating was perfect.  It was a windy and cold night, but they arranged the patio to make sure it was comfortable.  There was a clear barrier between our seating and the water to make sure the wind wouldn't bother us.  Heat lamps kept me from freezing to death.  

Instead of bread, we were given yukon chips and plaintains to dip in their three sauces.  These were delicious!!!  We scarfed them down in a few minutes.  

We decided to order a few things to share:

Cebiche tasting Mixto, Chifa, Nikei and Clásico for $28
- Everything was great, but my favorite would be the Nikei (Ahi Tuna, red onion, Japanese cucumber and avocado).  If I return, I would just get that one.  The portions of the sampler were pretty big.

Empanada sampler- Tasting of four kinds for $18
- We really enjoyed the empanadas, sooo tasty!

Anticuchos de pulpo- Grilled octopus skewers, herbed mashed potato
with chimichurri sauce and ají panca for $16
- I thought this was just okay.  The waiter recommended it, but I didn't find it mindblowing.  

Lomo saltado- Traditional Peruvian style stir-fry of sautéed beef tenderloin, onions, tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic with fried potatoes and rice for $27
- I didn't find this dish to be very exciting at all.  A big disappointment for $27.  

Sorry yelpers, but I also didn't care for the Pisco Sour.  :/

La Mar is definitely a place to go at least once.  The location/view is perfect...right on the water.  It's great for a date, you can walk around the pier before or after dinner to enjoy the view. 

The food was eh and it was way overpriced, therefore, La Mar gets 3 stars.
author: Vivian W.

description: Love this restaurant!! I just came back from Peru two weeks ago and have been craving Peruvian food ever since. My partner and I happened upon this restaurant and boy am I glad we did. Service was EXCELLENT, food was sumptuous and atmosphere was modern, spacious and airy. I highly recommend La Mar!
author: Charles M.

description:
I really don't know what the hype is.  I went to this restaurant once on a corporate budget out on the patio where we got to sample just about every thing on the menu. I probably would have given it four stars then because the food was unique and fairly good, not to mention the fact that it was all free.

Unfortunately, I went back again, this time with a large group of 10 and they seated us in the "Ceviche Room".  FYI, do not be fooled. The Ceviche Room is actually the lobby, outside the bar and the restaurant.  You feel like you are sitting at some random communal hotel lobby where there is absolutely no ambiance and you are treated like an unwanted stepchild.  I don't know how to describe it but it was just embarrassing, especially if you are the one hosting the dinner because it looks like you couldn't even get a reservation at the restaurant and had to be seated in an outside bench.  

Then comes the food.... I don't know what happens between the walk from the actual restaurant and this "special" room but everything was pretty crappy.  The lomo saltado was about 50% chunks of onions and 10% beef... and the portions are small to begin with!  The ceviche sampler was lacking except in the classic one.  The tallarin saltado was like burnt and super salty chow mein with large chunks of onion and minimal seafood.  Seriously, it's like they ran out of the anything good and dumped in a bunch of onion chunks with their fingers crossed that we woudln't notice.  I've eaten in the main dining room and it was much better so I can't explain it.  It was one thing if the food in the special room was discounted but actually no... there's an automatic 20% gratuity put in there because it''s in the "special" room.  The one saving grace was that the service was decent... though the trek from the resturant to the Ceviche Room did take awhile and cause some spotty service.  

NOT RECOMMENDED FOR LARGE PARTIES
author: Susan L.

description:
La Mar represents Peru and Peruvian food well.  Each time eat here for lunch or dinner, it makes me want to sprint up Machu Picchu and yell, "I'm King of the World!"... just kidding.

Seriously though, this restaurant kicks ass.  Every dish is solid and prepared well.  Every cebiches (Peru's national dish) is tasty.  Once I ordered and reorder so much I thought I was in an all-you-eat sushi place.

Empanadas are good to really good with my preference towards the beef and red onions. Skewers are really tasty.  For mains, you can't go wrong with any of their fish and seafood dishes, but their asado de tira (short ribs) and lomo saltado (traditional sauteed beef tenderloin) shows their excellence across proteins.

Desserts?  Are you kidding me?  Just order one of each and go run a marathon the next day and you'll be fine.
author: Bernard M.

description: Highly recommend this place. Yes, the cost is very high, but it's one of the most famous chef's in Peru. I've been to the restaurant in Lima and this is every bit as good.  Sample the ceviche.
author: Johnny K.

description: If I could give them more stars I would.  My friends and I were having a party here, and some details fell through the cracks and we ended up showing up late.  Not only did the restaurant stay open late for us, but when out reservations somehow went missing (which was maybe their fault) they made room for us right away.  They made us a ton of food for our group.  Thanks La Mar for saving our day!
author: Kimmy G.

description: LOVE this place. The bright, simple ambiance sets a great tone especially on a clear afternoon or evening along the Embarcadero. The menu offers great options and it gave a chance for my wife and I to try some dishes we'd never try otherwise. This was the first time we tried octopus and absolutely loved it. We still rave about it. I also love the proximity the Ferry Bldg and other bars/lounges along the Embarcadero.
author: Jigar C.

description: I love this place. I've been to the La Mar in Lima and this is a close second (why I give them 4 in stead of 5 stars).The prices are high (San Fran) but the food...as good as it gets for cebiche in the states, My only complaint is the service could be a little less snotty-take a lesson from your southern brethren and lose the attitude. Serve your guests with warmth and kindness and they will not have any excuse not to call this their favorite place.
author: Helena P.

description:
It was like a party in my mouth but . . . I don't need to go back.  
Everything was a visual masterpiece but sometimes the food played mind tricks on me.

Things that looked like sushi (causa) tasted like potato salad.
Things that look spice-less (no red chili or green habanero in sight) actually put my mouth on fire -- hey not fair (cebiche ciasco - the habanero was hiding).

First -- I don't want to be ungrateful -- because I was just happy to have a restaurant open at 9:30 and still serving dinner.  My husband and I were staying at a nearby hotel and read all the impressive Yelp reviews so I feel bad giving only 3 stars.  

In the effort to be a bit adventurous, I ordered the beef heart.  I was expecting small Japanes-style skewers with tiny morsels of heart.  Well -- I was WRONG and got four LARGE medallions that put together equal the size of a steak.  So kudos for super sized portions -- but unless you want to make this organ your main course -- I recommend you be more gutsy about some other dish.  Heart just tastes like chewier steak.  The saving grace and bright bang to each dish are the dipping sauces (I preferred the yellow one to the red one).  

My favorite part of the meal was the dessert:  lucuma served three ways (tiramisu, cannoli, chocolate coconut brownie with lucuma ice cream).   Lucuma is a Peruvian fruit that the waitress said tasted like caramel.  I agree.  The taste is similar to flan, the burnt sugar of a creme brulee or even a hint of pumpkin.  Each dessert had a different texture: creamy, crunchy or cold -- again, another adventure.  Be careful when eating the cannoli -- the candied sugar got jammed in my mouth the wrong way and I thought it was going to slice the roof of my mouth!  Hey -- sometimes food is risky business.

Bottom line -- interesting tastes, but there are too many other restaurants in SF for me to try that I don't plan on making a return visit.
author: Sabrina G.

description:
Great bar scene and good food.  This is my second time visiting La Mar and I had similar experiences each time.   The service at the bar is nearly non-existent, but in the restaurant has effective, if not great, service.   

The cebiches are good, but not great... a bit too much going on in all of them, so that the fish doesn't really come out.  I have similar issues with the tiraditos.    The skewers are delicious and not overwhelmed by sauces.   The empanadas are to die for.    The lamb shank spring rolls are spectacular, the strong flavor of the shank just pops out. 

The prices are pretty good... had a huge meal for about $40/person (after tax & tip).    It's a great place to celebrate.
author: jay w.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants from when I lived in Santiago Chile, so I was very pleased to know that there was a location in San Francisco.

While not quite up to the same standard as the Latin America locations (perhaps the seafood here is not as high quality), it was still excellent.

Ceviches are my favorite part of it all but everything I've had here has been excellent. Cocktail list is extensive and they've got a good selection of pisco sour type drinks if you want the authentic experience.

Yes, this place gets crowded. Yes, it's trendy. Yes, it's expensive. But if you can get past all that (and just make a reservation in advance), it's great food and a great view of the bay!
author: Lina L.

description: I like the sea food appetizers and the Peru cocktails.
author: Byron L.

description: I just wish this place wasn't this small. Great food, great service and GREAT happy hour! if you go during the day you should be fine with no reservation BUT if you are planning having dinner here reservation is a MUST!
author: Kajal P.

description:
Arguably one of the best meals top to bottom I've ever had. From the drinks, to the appetizer to even the fried plantains with the 3 different sauces. Let's start shall we. Me and my girlfriend dined here for our 1 year anniversary and we were looking to try something new. 

1. Pisco punch: Peruvian brandy with lime and pineapple juice. It was on point. Not too strong, but still taste that brandy, which is finished off with the citrus juices. 

2. Cebiche sampler: 4 different types of cebiche. One that stood out was their ahi tuna one. Just think Japanese style poke with the citrus and lime flavors. What i didn't know what how much Japanese cooking was inspired in some of the Peruvian dishes. It was definitely very appetizing and good. There was another cebiche that was very spicy, so be careful not to eat the slice of habanero that is on the plate. 

3. Arroz jugoso: Their version of paella, without the saffron. All the seafood, meat and rice all in one. It was flavorful, delicious and felt like comfort food. 

4. Crepa de chocolate: This was a crazy dessert! Our waiter Tobias explained to us the origin of the lucuma fruit that comes from the Andes region and that the dessert consists of the lucuma cooked through and made into a mousse and placed in a chocolate crepe. Anyways, what made the dessert crazy is that with all the flavors of the mousse, chocolate and orange, it tasted eerily like Thai tea. I kid you not. 

It helped that our waiter Tobias was very accomodating and helpful when looking through the menu. He was very thorough and walked us through everything and was spot on with his suggestions. This restaurant is a bit pricey, but if you're out celebrating something or even just a date night or enjoying it with a group of people, this is the spot. 

Next time, I'll be trying their happy hour and empanada samplers!
author: Shane R.

description: Pisco Sours and Punches are the perfect way to start out a meal here.  Their cebiche never disapoints, and even the post-cebiche "tiger milk" is great.  Entrees are tasty, as well.
author: Matt L.

description:
Er, why is ceviche spelled cebiche in Peru? The "b" is less appetizing somehow, and, at the risk of being un-PC (fuck it), it sounds, well, gay. 

We stopped in for a drink to see if we felt like eating here, and the experience at the bar was enough to send us down the road. I asked the bartender for an interesting cocktail based on mescal, he suggested a straight shot of pisco. Sure, I get it, Peru, pisco, but not what I wanted. Neither of us could stomach the shot, so we asked for a cocktail again, and hey, guess what, there is a cocktail menu after all... I order something else, and the frat boy bartender says hey, what he always did at the Sandy Marlin or whatever was hey, just pour the unwanted shot into the cocktail. Classy, bro. I mean, sure, that was the right thing to do, but at $12 a cocktail. 

I have to say, the bar didn't give off a very classy vibe, and that plus the aqua color scheme in the main restaurant, well... I guess "cebiche" just isn't my deal, although I do like good ceviche just fine.
author: Bowen D.

description: I was at La Mar a few weeks back with a friend for San Francisco "dine about town" event. 3 sampler dishes were all great.  Food portion at first looked small but after finishing you would actually found that is good enough.  No hungry feeling, no overtake guilt.  I love their Pie de Limon.  I felt I had the world best class pie ever.  This is a place I would definitely go back and try other stuff on the menu.
author: Caroline L.

description: YUMMM!  The food here is so tasty!  We started with a few different ceviches.  Delish!  My favorite was the ceviches nikel.  The setting is splendid.  I would highly recommend going at sunset.  We arrived slightly after they closed and luckily got seated ..  yay!  Being close to the water is a highlight of this spot.   They have a dessert with gold flakes on it.  We had to order that.  You should too.
author: Sya - 'Urban Oasis' W.

description: If the weather is nice, sit outside close to the water ask for a heated table! By far my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. If you can sit at the bar, watch the bartender  tastefully add 30+ ingredients into your drink!
author: Michael C.

description: Fantastic wine pairings, fantastic food. Once we mentioned that we waited 20 minutes before being spoken too, we were treated like royalty. Great waitstaff and great place overall. INCREDIBLE food.
author: Josh K.

description: This is a huge restaurant right next to the waterfront near the Ferry Building and although I have been here for lunch, I think it's better suited for dinner with its high ceilings, big windows, plenty of good natural light and cool blue outlines. They have a huge bar, the  seafood tastes fresh oozing favors of lemon & South American peppers. I had the Ahi tuna here and so glad it was served with nice seasoning and was not dry, unlike other restaurants that give you the feeling it's been sitting in the freezer for a week. The place, at least for lunch, does not heave a mark but it's worth a visit.
author: Monish S.

description:
I came here with my buddy who is going through the 7x7 list to try the Pisco sour and their cebiche.  While bueno, my favorite BY FAR was the Octopus skewers (Anticuchos De Pulpo).  That was the definition of cooked to perfection.  I'm not sure why that wasn't on the list.

The decor was very nice.  We went on a sunny Sunday afternoon so it was perfect since the dining area was very open.  The prices were OK since we shared everything.  Otherwise I can see how you can easily rack up quite a bill though.
author: Z C.

description:
Great for happy hour!!!
Excellent pisco sour. The cebiche are sooo good.
author: Maria C.

description: There is no ways this place deserves anything more than 2 stars.  We ordered 2 appetizers for $50.  The food is mediocre, the price is high, and the service was awful.  Waited a long time just to get the check.  All the hostess, waiter, server at this place was rather unfriendly.  On a positive note, the ambiance is very very nice.
author: T. C.

description: If you ever find yourself in Lima, Peru, DO NOT MISS OUT on going to the original! I went there 4 times in the span of the week or so I was in Lima! great food, drinks, service, location and prices!
author: Melody T.

description: Great food and atmosphere. Make sure to reserve a table.
author: Digde E.

description:
One of the great benefits of living in San Francisco is the fabulous restaurants with their art deco decor, the impressive wine lists, the artsy light fixtures. This is also one of San Francisco's down fall. 

La Mar had a spectacular atmosphere, and is a beautiful setting for a romantic evening or a special event. The service was prompt and attentive, and the food was tasty and enjoyable. But paying $27 for Loma Saltado was a hard pill to swallow, especially since you can go down to the market in the Mission and get it for about $10. It's Loma Saltado, it's steak with french fries. It's not a decadent dish. 

We are fortunate to live in a city with extravagant restaurants, but my rule is if you can go down to the Mission and get it at a locals spot for a third of the price, and it tastes probably, even better, skip the white cloth napkins.
author: Kristin C.

description:
I love La Mar. I have lived in Peru and this is authentic and delicious....!
The classic ceviche is as good as it gets......the way it is made in Peru and....those Pisco sours are from heaven!
Do not miss this very special place!
author: Diane G.

description:
La Mar is in the perfect spot: just next to the ferry building it picks up locals and tourists alike.  It has size, a great view, if you happen to be seated facing the right direction, and an undeniable corporate feel.  Service was modestly attentive but the meal was poorly paced.  A salad that was to come with my first course arrived between my first and last courses.  I suspect a problem in the kitchen.

Being of an age where family is not a distraction and generally dining alone, I have the time and inclination to research a place before I go.  To me the search said go with the smaller rather than the larger plates.  

So, to begin, I get the sampler of causas, which is comprised of four distinct varieties of seafood or veggies above whipped potatoes.  I enjoyed this plate a great deal as there were contrasts of crab or tuna with more or less assertively spiced sauces.  

Salad nikei was a not especially interesting blend of mixed greens with less green papaya and jicama than I would have preferred.  OK but just a step above salad mixes you can get in the supermarket.  

Finally, a tasting of their empanadas.  What makes these nice is that despite being fried they are not heavy.  I found that the beef and vegetarian (mainly sweet corn) empanadas stood up best to the fried casing whereas the chicken and seafood were overpowered.  Also, this plate was poorly presented: four empandas, side by side, over a few scraps of greens.  Some pickled vegetables or a small salad with vinaigrette would have provided some contrast to the empanadas.

One surprise was that two attractive, spanish-speaking lovelies seated next to me attracted more attention from the male staff than I.  Okay, they were very pretty and seemed very sweet so one can give the staff a bye on this one.
author: David D.

description:
Great for a first date! You can start by loosening up at the front hip bar over a few drinks before heading to the main dinning area. The food was succulent! Especially the enpenadas and the llomo saltado though I have to say I still prefer Fresca over La Mar. 

Oh and the pisco sour was quite good! (tho I only had a few sips, still true to my Malbec)
author: Nez B.

description:
I have had Peruvian food many times, and am kind of picky because I have an uncle that makes some incredible dishes.  I always compare ceviche at restaruants with his homemade ceviche.  In this case, his beat out the ceviche clasico, but the lomo saltado and all the sauces were deliciso!!!!  The ceviche was great, but not the best.  

Oh, a nice sipping drink was the Inka de Oro!  Whiskey, Pisco with a slice of lemon peel!!

Also, we found an AWEOMSE parking spot right across the street FOR FREE!!!  Couldn't believe it, New Years Eve and a parking spot in the City!!  AND FREE!!!  hella yea!!!
author: Matt D.

description: Not worth the money, limon rotissierie is better! The place is too big, the pisco sour's watered down and I have had better ceviche at home!
author: Chrissie M.

description:
Fresh off the US Airways plane two weeks ago from Lima , Peru. While in Lima,
visited original  La Mar Cebicheria in Miraflores, Lima-Peru twice;  the  food in Lima was executed with years of seafood experience and visually striking.Service was excellent. Therefore, we had stratospheric expectations for this branch of La Mar.
In Lima, the fried plaintains, sweet potatoes and white potatoes were served with 3 sauces, in San Francisco, it is served with 2 sauces; you have to ask for the 3rd sauce  (wonderfully spicy). We ordered the Causas( crab, tuna,& vegetarian); delicious.
Next, we had a Quinoa(pronounced "Kin Wa") salad/mixed lettuce, the mixture has creamy, citrus, crunchy and nutty flavors; seductively satisfying; Of course you have to order a fish dish, we salivated over ceviche( yellowtail, tuna, & halibut); ectasy!
Consequently, we had coconut and berry sorbets( coconut was OK, please use Macapuno in the coconut; it will elevate the taste). Overall, we  both reached a climax and had a smile
author: Bill M.

description:
I was impressed as soon as I walked in- the decor is really beautiful and different...I'm not used to seeing that style in San Francisco. 
Now, the important part- the food was yummy. I had the ceviche mixto and it was really, really fresh. I also ordered the Cau Cau (aka scallop entree)- omigosh that was so good. It could be because I have been craving scallops for months, but they were subtly sweet and delish. 
Service was good- our waiter was very nice and attentive.
I highly recommend it and can't wait to go back.
author: Cindy D.

description:
I've been here multiple times and always get the ceviche sampler. I never know what is what and what I like, so I made notes this time:

In order of my preferences on the platter: 
Yellowtail - light, sour, sweet, with peanuts and wontons
Ahi tuna - sweet dark soyish sauce with cucumbers
Halibut - slightly sour with carrot slices
Mahi: too hard, too sour. Didn't like. They serve it with this vegetable (?) that looks like giant corn kernels. 

I've had the empanada sampler. All 4 are delish (chicken, beef, corn, and one more). I think I like the chicken and beef the best. The corn is a bit sweet.

The causas (on mash-potatoish things) are ok. I'm not a big fan of potatoes. 

Had a steak skewer, which was good. It tasted like grilled steak!

I've never had any specials or any entrees so I would be curious to try next time!

The pisco sour is an interesting drink that I recommend you try. I'm not sure if I like it or not because there are raw egg whites and create a nice foam, but it is rather strong (yet tasty ie not super alcohol flavored). Apparently its very Peruvian. 

Service is a bit slow. 

Expect to pay at least $35-40 a person
author: Julia L.

description: Loved the food and the crowd. I'm vegetarian so ordered the causa casera with yellow potatoes (purple ones have fish oil) - it was great! Also had a complimentary basket of chips with 3 dipping sauces (forgot the names but the middle one was my favourite). We loved the cocktails, I tried chicha tu ma and then cholopolitan (which wasnt as good). Felt pretty full after that and we decided to split dessert - ordered buñuelos de chocolate calient. It was served in a huge dish but the portion was tiny lol, anyway the banana ice cream was very good. Overall dinner for 2 was around 90$ well spent.
author: Meghna G.

description:
I'm sometimes a bit weary about restaurants located on the Embarcadero because I think you're most likely paying for the view and the location instead of for the food. Well, La Mar proved me wrong. The ambiance was lovely and the clientel was a very diverse mix. The food...here's the rundown:

Cebiche - you can really tell that the fish is VERY fresh and high quality. My only complaint about it was that it was a little bland and all you can really get out of it were the lime juice from the leche de tigre marinade.

Tried two of the anticuchos (the carne and the mahi mahi) and was most impressed by the Peruvian corn. It's definitely nothing like the corn you get out of a can or from a bag.

Arroz jugoso - was very impressed and was very much like a paella. Each bite had seafood in it and it was quite rich. 

Arroz norteno - probably my favorite dish. Like the arroz jugoso, this dish was also bathed in seafood. The fried rice with cilantro and Huancaina sauce from this dish was DELICIOUS. 

Overall, the entire meal (and the company) was top-notch. However, it was all so filling that I couldn't finish my entire dish and I asked to have my leftovers doggie-bagged so I can enjoy the rest of it later. Well, when the check came, the rest of my meal didn't. My heart broke for two reasons: (1) it was such a damn good meal and I didn't get to finish it and (2) it was a damn expensive meal. Minus one star for not paying attention to me after you have the credit card in your hands...
author: Blenda L.

description:
Ceviche is bomb ass..it was one of those times when you put something in your mouth and then you close your eyes real tight and say a lil mmmm, and then after you let it savor a bit more and then swallow, you can't help but to gasp a 'mmm that was so goood!'.

Seriously tho, the flavor and tuna in ceviche nikei was excellent. my brother had the ceviche norteno which was exc as well. the entire la mar enviro, decoration and being next to the water, makes it all an experience, which is part of the reason why we go out to eat in sf right? the service was great as well, we had a lot of fun w the waiter talking about exotic fruits.

few draw backs.. it doesn't seem like they offer table service for walk-in's, only at the bar, even when tables were noticeably available throughout the night. the other thing i was like come on guys, was the empanadas. i mean they were delicious but 10 bucks for 4 bites? i can get one in bsas twice the size and twice the flavor for tenth the price...but i know that's bsas.

i would def go back again, make some ressies, and have it as a special occasion.
author: Mikey B W.

description: Ok, Pisco i love you too.  I didn't do a Pisco Sour because the egg white scared me but i had a Pisco drink with grapefruit that was one of the best cocktails of my life.  We ended up sharing a ceviche (unbelievable) type of payaya with loads of fresh seafood and empanadas. If you can get in you should go, we went on a Tuesday and had to wait almost 3 hours for a table but it was worth it.
author: Courtney R.

description: absolutely loved it! we had a couple of appetizers- ceviche, the empanadas de carne were bomb. def would go back again.
author: Erika O.

description:
La Mar was AMAZING. 

The food was really good -- the bursts of flavors, the colors and presentation -- seriously plates of artwork.

I LOVE the wine list. I had a two-glass wine flight (you pick a red and a white) but they ran out of the white we wanted. The sommelier/server did a really great job in suggesting a replacement white wine.

Great place to sit and relax for a long afternoon, to take out-of-towners, or to go for business lunches/dinners.

Must orders: cebiche, empanadas.
author: J T.

description:
La Mar is in a nice location - you will find parking next door (Pier 3, Hornblower). The staff is friendly and helpful for recommendations.

Some suggestions for ordering:
Make sure to try the Civiche tasting: halibut (cebiche clásico) or mahi mahi (cebiche chifa) were my favorites. If going for dinner - I'd also suggest ordering family style. Everything we tried tasted good. Make sure you save room for dessert too (buñuelos de chocolate). I had my eye on the cappuccino de tres leches, but they were out - so i'll have to go back and try it sometime.

enjoy
author: edwin l.

description:
I have to give major props to my girl amy k for recommending la mar. it was the perfect end to our anniversary celebration!! thanks girl! you are da bomb!!

we loved everything about this restaurant.  the food, service and ambiance were top notch. yes, you do pay a little extra for being on the water, but sometimes it's nice to dine in serenity. the interior has a nice blend of  modern and the ocean's blue and green. our wait person was awesome. he was knowledgeable, personable and patient. 

here's what we thought of the eatz:
free Chips and dips to start- wow!!!  they make their own chips from sweet potatoes, white potatoes and bananas (perhaps plantains?). to compliment the chips were 3 different chips, from mild to a little spicier. amazing! i think we filled up on these. watch out. they are  addicting like killer sourdough

grilled Octopus skewers- wow!!! Wow !! and wow!!!  one can't help but notice the octopi as one is walking to their table. we decided to take the wait person's recommendation and we were most impressed. i think this was our favorite dish. it had an amazing smoky rich flavor and the sauces provided the perfect contrast

Cebiche frutis del mar- this was the special of the day with mahi mahi, clams, mussels, scallops, calamri and shrimp in leche de Tigre (lime and pepper). warning, there is a thin slice of jabanero right on top.  The seafood  was the freshest that you can desire; however it was totally raw, not at all cooked by the lime juice like other ceviches I have had (perhaps it is supposed to be that way). the scallops were the sweetest i have ever tasted. yum. i would have liked to let the seafood marinate in the juices for an hour or so before or serving. use the spoon and eat the seafood with a little bit of the sauce for some extra kick and flavor

Chicken empanadas- these were good. fairly light for a fried dish

Arroz norteno - risotto with seafood and a green sauce. i was expecting risotto with saffron so this was a pleasant, yummy, surprise!  honestly we were so full by now we took most of this to go

almost forgot to mention our drinks. we had the Cholopolitan (is this PC to say??) and Chutta tu ma (the one with the antioxidants, 3rd down on the left side). both were yum

I was going to pass on the the beignets because they were just screaming doughy and heavy, but our waiter-extraordinaire informed us they were small bites of heaven that were like molten-chocolate filled. um, ok. yeah, duh that was a no-brainer. these little Chocolate beignets were HEA-VEN-LY wow!! it came with a banana ice cream, passion fruit sauce and a chocolate brittle

it was the perfect dinner. we will definitely be back for drinks and more food!
author: joyce l.

description: Had Sunday brunch here a couple weeks ago.  We sat outside and the view is nice but not terrific, as the restaurant is set back from the open Bay by a couple piers that extend out way further.  Still, it was a delightful experience.  The staff was very professional and attentive.  Food was excellent; all five of us loved our dishes.
author: Kevin M.

description:
I love Peruvian food. A good friend of mine is Peruvian and she's extremely proud of her culture and food. Her causa, papa rellenos, beef stew, etc. are the best I've ever had!

So when she recommended I go to La Mar, I had to listen. The seafood was fresh - cebiche clasico was delicious. The anticuchos were good but my boyfriend and brother didn't love the cow heart for some reason. And these two are adventurous eaters. We also got the multi-empanadas. They were ok. I feel like I've had better. Something about the pastry shell wasn't super awesome.

But overall, I found the food to be delicious and the best Peruvian I've had in a restaurant.

The biggest downside is probably the bathroom situation. There are two unisex bathrooms for the entire restaurant. The lines get long and the bathrooms get smelly and dirty. Ick.
author: Esther K.

description: A great place on the water to celebrate a special occasion; you should expect a pretty expensive evening. The plantains served before dinner were addictive. We split the ceviche sampler, which was delicious. I believe my favorite was the nikei version. Pisco sours were also very good. We all got seafood entrees, which were OK, but not really memorable. Service was excellent -- I think we were at dinner for about three hours and we never got the feeling our servers were eager to get rid of us. Dinner with shared appetizer and dessert and two cocktails was $73 w/out tip.
author: Beck B.

description: Get the appetizers (items in the first three colums on the menu). Although the entrees were good, the ceviche and skewers were outstanding! I didn't have room to try the empanadas. Ceviche was amazingly fresh and perfectly seasoned. Cones of plantain and potato chips with salsas are provided for each table and are perfect for scooping up ceviche. The grilled beef heart blew me away. It comes medium-rare with a wine reduction glaze. Waitstaff was on top of everything despite having a full-house.
author: Ogre V.

description: Amazing Peruvian food! I loved the selection of ceviche and other appetizers. Don't go there without trying at least one!
author: Karin Z.

description: went here for a fun birthday gathering and it was amazing!  I'm always a fan of any food 'below the border' style and La Mar definitely does not disappoint.  I could not get enough of their empanadas, and they serve fried potato and banana chips with really unique and fun sauces!  Also love that it's right on the bay so you can take a walk on the pier before or after dinner and soak up the beautiful bay views.
author: Evelyn T.

description:
I had a dinner with my wife and two friends. Excellent pisco sour. Excellent ceviche. Good seafood. Good selection of wines
Remarks: by the price I paid I was expecting more generous portions.
I will come back.
author: Mauro N.

description: Fun place but a little loud which is fine if you're not intending on having in depth conversations. We were there to have drinks and enjoy company so that was fine with us! We also got to try beers from Peru which was a first for me. I enjoyed this place. In the end, we couldn't locate our waiter to bring us our tab. So maybe we were supposed to have free drinks? :) Really fun bar.
author: Jael J.

description:
When I first tried La Mar, I expected it to be a lot like Slanted Door where you spend a lot of money for the location and scenery but the food tastes like elementary school cafeteria food.

Quite the contrary, La Mar has the great location, awesome service, and high quality food to back it's high prices. My experiences here have ranged from one on one lunch meetings to company happy hours and every time I go, I'm never disappointed. I mean, how could you not like Peruvian food? At this point, I've tried just about everything on the menu and it really is that good. 

If you've got a client to impress or feel like putting on a company outing, La Mar is an easy choice.
author: Anthony C.

description: What a beautiful place ! great service and tasty cocktails. when you have out of town guest or just hanging the locals a must see place. enjoyed all of the food as well
author: james m.

description: The Happy Hour made me very happy.  All of the items the locals I met at Union Square recommended, we awesome!
author: Renee H.

description: Very good food and service! The prices were reasonable (I would only give it $$ and I'm by no means rich at the moment) Try the China Sunrise cocktail, you won't regret it!
author: Dominique C.

description: we had an absolutely awesome time! everyone was so nice...someone did steal our reservation, but the hostess still honored it.  Its a little pricey but worth it due to the ambiance.
author: Carolyn P.

description: LOVEEEE this place and love Peruvian food!! Their ceviche is amazing, and their dungeness crab is pretty decent as well. One bite of their ceviche is like a million different flavors dancing on your tongue.
author: Sami A.

description: I have had Peruvian food a few times and the food here is good, but I wouldn't necessarily say it was to die for. I had the Scarlet cocktail, cebiche chalaco, and the anticucho mixto. The cebiche had yellowtail, mussels, clams, shrimp, red onion, and calamari with a nice spicy sauce. I didn't like how the calamari was a little too fried and crunchy, but the other items were very fresh and delicious. The anticuchos came with meat, fish, and chicken in a yummy panchita and rocoto sauce. The corn had an odd texture, but the dish was still good. There are so many delicious options on the menu (almost overwhelming amounts), so I'd love to try more next time. I'd give the food a 3.5 but I bumped it up to a 4 because the view from the outdoor patio is lovely.
author: Sheeva G.

description: Yum Yum Yum! I only eat super fresh well made fish and this hit the spot! Great cocktails too!
author: Katrina H.

description: Like the place. Service was good.  Ambience was on point.  Food was just ok.  I was disappointed about their ceviche.  The flavor was lacking.  Bathroom needs some clean up.
author: Miss Y.

description: We came here for our pre-Thanksgiving lunch with the company, and it was a gorgeous day.  They sat us outside, right on the water behind the ferry building.  We ordered pisco based cocktails that were delicious!  2 of us were new to Peruvian cuisine, and the waitress was very helpful.  She pointed out which ceviche to start with (the halibut...delicious).  I had the beef skewers with mixed seafood ceviche as my lunch and every bite was delicious.  I wish I had ordered more of the ceviche...to die for.  Everything is perfectly seasoned and while I find ceviche to sometimes be overwhelmingly acidic, this was perfect.  2 cocktails and a delicious meal later I found myself fighting to stay awake on the train, but that's another story...
author: ashley B.

description:
I wanted to give this place 5 stars, really I did.  This modern mecca almost had it all - delicious cebiche (as spelled on the menu, aka ceviche), warm empanadas, lomo saltado that made my mouth water.  But what's with the crappy service?  Our waitress forgot about our requests (a few times) and she was trying to push extra orders down our throats (lady, we're sharing - it's called family style!  that's how Asians do it!)

Oh the cebiche, though!  Holy hot mother of God, I thought I'd died and gone to an underwater heaven.  The only way that tuna would have been fresher would be if it swam directly into my mouth.  Come here fishy fishy!  Get the cebiche nikei (the tuna one)..you'll be licking that bowl clean because the sauce is that delish.

What was the best part?  My friends...it was the sauces.  The three sauces that came with your sweet potato chips and regular potato chips all had a unique and distinct flavor.  The hot one was my personal fav.    Then there's the sauces you get with your empanadas and salmon skewers.  All...perfecto.

Loved the pops of color against the white furnishings.  A bit on the pricey side (lomo saltado was how much?  $27 for lunch and it wasn't that much better than Mario's!)  Overall experience was pleasant.  Nothing beats eating family style with your friends, enjoying the beauty of San Francisco. I'll definitely be back!
author: Alice Y.

description: This place is a must if you are looking for high quality, expensive-ish memorable Peruvian food. My only gripe is that I really don't feel like good Peruvian food should be this costly. The cost is justified by the freshness and the top notch service. The restaurant bar area feels very trendy and they offer happy hour. The portions for HH are tiny but amazing! I tried the causa limeña, cebiche mixto, calamari and the lomo saltado empanada. All were delicious. The empanada and cebiche were my favorites.  I ended getting a seafood dish served over purple sweet potato ravioli in a sweet and spicy sauce! It reminded me of Italian butternut squash ravioli but better! The anticuchos de corazon were probably the best I've ever had. And now, for my favs...passion tiradito? OMG!!! I am going to dream of these for months until I am forced to come back. Choco maracuya dessert!  The best!  The passion fruit mousse was sweet, intense and so fluffy. The chocolate mousse was like cream that could float. It was served with raspberry puree and some fresh cream. I want 4 for myself next time I'm there!  The cost was a little over $200 for 2 people but it was worth every penny. This is coming from my fiancee that is Peruvian.
author: Marcia M.

description:
0 stars for service
1 star for wine

Service was deplorable. Restaurant was not full at 8:40pm on Friday night but we were seated outside. The area was almost full with some tables in mid meal and others were finishing. Two other couples were seated before us because they still had their menu's. It's been 10 minutes since we were seated and no one has said anything to us. Head waiter for our area was too busy to deal with us so he sent his backup after I tried to get his attention.  His backup took our drink order and then when on check on another table. Five minutes later and the backup is still talking to the other table. On his way past our table we ask for an appetizer (Ceviche La Mar) and he asks us to tell him what wines we wanted. Ugh. Bad service is getting worse. Wine arrives, still no one has followed up with us even though we still have menus. Ceviche arrives so we decided to put our menu's on the ground, hoping someone would notice. Head waiter walks by menus and says nothing. Bus boy walks by menus and asks if we still needed them. Meanwhile we're not happy with the ceviche, we've had better at Mochica in SF. The fish/seafood was bland. We decide that we don't want to order anymore so we waved the manager over and ask for the check. He asks if everything is ok and we tell him no and that we would be happy to explain out front. Head waiter comes to clear the appetizer plate and take our next order. Still hasn't introduced himself. We inform him that we are leaving. Paid the check and spoke with the manager, detailing our experience. Manager apologized and wants us to try them again. Told him we'll think about it. Went to Chaya down the street and had an excellent dinner.
author: TheYster A.

description: Get the sampler of everything. Great variety and makes for a very interesting meal. My husband and I split the cebiche sampler and the causa sampler. The potatoes were mediocre but the fish was outstanding. We split the short ribs as well, which were absolutely amazing. That was just enough food for the two of us. We did order dessert to take home but it wasn't worth it. Skip dessert, get another drink! The place is known for its pisco sours but the passion fruit pisco was the best drink I've ever had!
author: C N.

description: Loved the food and atmosphere.  Although pricey it is worth the money. Staff are friendly and attentive.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Everything looked great on the menu and it was definitely difficult for me to make a choice. I know I'd be more biased than I should be in this review because 1) I love seafood 2) I haven't had fish in 3 weeks and 3) I was excited to try Peruvian food for the first time! But what I liked most about this place was their creative dishes, presentations, and drinks. Needless to say, I was very satisfied with my main dish. My friend really loved her chicken skewers too. The portions were pretty good for the price (rather big for some dishes), perhaps this only applies to the entrees, not the ceviche or tasting plates. 

The highlight of our dinner: Picarones - crispy doughnut-shaped pumpkin and sweet potato fritters with spiced Chancaca honey. Have something different for dessert next time you're there! :)
author: Lily X.

description: Went here a couple weeks ago for a friend's birthday. Sat only in the lounge area and ordered our food and drinks there. The food was pretty good quality, but for the price, you are paying for the view too. Drinks could have used some more variation, but they were good also. Overall, a fun place to go with friends but be prepared to spend more for the view and location.
author: Christina F.

description: The food here was very good. I don't remember the name of the dishes that we had but I do remember that the choco-maracuya for dessert was especially good.
author: Hussam B.

description: The chips are to die for. Great food, service, and atmosphere. Can't wait to go back.
author: Mary L.

description:
We headed here after a upsetting and unsettling encounter at Limon Rotisserie...see previous review. 

We were craving tapas so we headed to La Mar. Have your taste buds and stomach ready for gastro-festival.  Everything was sensational, from the hostess, wait staff, the amazing bay bridge view, and of course, the food. The Cebiche was amazing, I wanted to pick it up and lick the bowl and the variety of chips are an excellent complement. The empanadas left me yearning for more! Everything was delicious, you could close your eyes and randomly point to a dish and it would be scrumptious!
author: Kristina L.

description: Let me start by saying that is a perfectly fine restaurant that has a lot going for it: classy ambiance, water front location, heated covered porch dining area, and authentic Peruvian cuisine and Pisco Sours to boot. The servers were also professional and knowledgeable. I would have given this restaurant a higher rating if it was not so hyped to me ahead of time---For being billed as " one of the best restaurants in SF," I did not feel it lived up to expectations. If you are looking for high quality seafood, and authentic Peruvian cuisine this La Mar offers it---just be prepared for to pay for it, and not to experience anything unique.
author: Culinary C.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!  The atmosphere is HOT the servers are very attentive, friendly and helpful.  The food is great and you get more than enought o leave you feeling very satisfied.  The Pisco drink specials are so yummy and the servers always do a great job recommending based on your tastes and preferences.  I love the fish dishes.  I particularly like the variety of options on the menu.  My husband and I have very different preferences and we are both left very happy and satisfied with our selections and the variety offered to us.  When in the area, definately check this place out - You may want to ensure you make a reservation as it can get a bit crowded if it's a weekend evening. :)
author: Kelly M.

description: I've only been here once, but I will definitely make it a point to go back soon. The dishes are amazing, and I always love it when chefs even make the presentation  of the meal look lovely. Employees offer great and quick customer service and are very accommodating. The view of the bay is also beautiful during dinner time. It is a bit pricey, but you get what you pay for! Great location as well!
author: Alexa S.

description:
Forgot to review! How could I!?

I am probably going to be bias since I was preggo last time I was here...  Came here with a friend.  It was a busy weekday night, so we ended up at the bar without waiting too long.  The service was a little slow.  I had to take a star away.  

My friend had the ceviche which he mentioned was ok and I had the mahi mahi; I had better somwhere else.

We did enjoy the ambiance and the decor.  We also saw former Mayor Willie Brown.  

Would I come here again... probably not...
author: Natalie O.

description: Took the in-lawas here for an anniversary dinner.  Thank you La Mar!  I don't know if it was the amazing pisco puch or the outstanding food.  But taking your in-laws out never went so smooth.  It was however pricey...
author: Amanda M.

description: Went there for happy hour on a Sat afternoon. Nice ambiance at the bar area with good food and drinks. Unfortunately we had a not so welcoming experience with the hostess. I don't think she wanted to deal with anyone. Either that or she probably thought she's the bouncer at a night club. Attitude. Too had her presence ruined our experience slightly.
author: teatzar s.

description: Always come here for HH or lunch. I love thier pisco sour's and Chicken sandwich.
author: Angela B.

description:
Amazingly great.  Ceviches were great.  Fresh fish dishes were super too.  Sauces were tasty.  Not very spicey, so you are safe there.  Nice location, with a trendy but friendly look.  Staff were friendly and fun.

Wines from South America are featured here.  

Total tab was just north of $50 per person but we bought pretty decent wine.
author: Don C.

description:
I'm peruvian , this place is nice but the food is a garbage, this food is not peruvian ........ok., the " cebiche " is not the real flavor (too much ginger, in the plate is only 5 fish pieces, no onion, no sweet potatoe) oh my good.... they need read the recipe again....please.
And... is expensive...soo expensive .
and ....the janitor is cleaning when you are eating....terrible.
Sorry ,yelpers but I'm very proud of my food .........this place dessapoint me too much.

Hola , soy peruana y siento decirles, que este sitio me saco de mis casillas, hace un mes fuimos con mi esposo e hijos a probar es ceviche, yo pense que tratandose del mejos cheff peruano iba a estar riquisimo, pero no , era un poco de sushi con limon y kion, solo cinco piezas de pescado, en los 3 samples, uno peor que el otro.
Mientras comiamos venian como 4 mozos diferentes uno mas pesado que el otro, mozos salidos del cuadro , no sabian ni explicar el menu, .....pesimo....
Oh y mientras comiamos pasaba la senora de la limpieza con su escobita a barrer al costado de nosotros.
Lo unico que nos gusto fueron los anticuchos de pulpo y los piscos, de ahi lo demas estaba demas.
Ohhhh el precio , ni que decir, un ojo de la cara .
author: claudia g.

description:
It was another amazing meal this Christmas Eve with Nilo and my friend Ralph. Peruvian food rocks...especially the corn! The halibut cebiche was still as fresh as any I have ever had and was just delicious. The lunch entrees were all good and the selection of red wines from Chile and Argentina were exceptional. I recommend the 2007 Terra Noble Carmenere Gran Reserva; it was very reasonable, amazing color and simply delicious! You also must try the home made potato chips. The restaurant itself is beautiful with wrap around window views overlooking the San Francisco Bay. There are two bars to sit at if you just want appetizers and some amazing drinks. This is still  a definite "must go" restaurant. 

I also tagged the restaurant: Fit for Foodies, Good for Groups, Great for Brunch, Great for Lunch, Great for Outdoor Dining, Neighborhood Gem, Notable Wine List, Romantic, Scenic View, Special Occasion
author: Tom B.

description: Hit this spot for happy hour. We were lucky to grab the last two seats at the bar. The place was buzzing on a Thursday evening!  I was impressed the exotic cocktails being made.
