Each one was quite tasty. They definitely don't skimp on the booze. We tried a ceviche appetizer and it was a bit tiny for two people to split. That being said, it tasted good so I'd give this place another try and perhaps order the ceviche mixer instead.
author: Stacie M.

description:
First visit to this place - so based on the preview buzz I heard about it, I was really expecting to be wowed - and I was only pleased.  First let's talk about the restaurant itself...great location right on an Embarcadero Pier - but the insides are kind of plain.  The table we set at was on a covered part of the patio and table and chairs were almost cheap looking with nothing to write home about style-wise - a look into the main bar and restaurant, a little better, but still kind of bland.  Since you are going to pay some money to be here and with a prime location, the ambiance of this place was a little bit of a yawn.
Now let's talk about the menu.  Okay - so this is Peruvian food - also a first, so I'll give my my take on it - seems to be inspired by the Paella and tapas of Spain meets the Chinese food of San Francisco Chinatown - several wok designed meals featuring Chow Mein noodles and bean sprouts in hot sesame oil.  The national dish of Peru is cebiches - made with 100% sustainable fish and shellfish - so I get it that the citrus acid "cooks" the fish, but I'm not a fan of raw anything, so I passed on these in favor or the safer salad - very fresh ingredients - really big kernels of sweet corn and a nice kick of cheese with a good oil/vinegar style dressing.  They also have some fancy cocktails, if you are into those that you may want to give one a try.
Entree - my boss is from Peruvian ancestry and told me to try the other "national dish" which was called Lomo Saltado -  this is a stirfry of sauteed beef tenderlion, tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic with fried potatoes and rice on the side (also with those wonderful giant kernels of sweet corn).  The fried potatoes kind of reminded me of the Pittsburgh way of serving fried on everything, so somehow, that has also made its way to Peru.  This was actually very tasty.  It had everything in it I liked.  I just thought for $32 it was a little cheap on the beef.  You also get the Peru version of Chips and Salsa, which is a mix of several types of chips and a couple of interesting dipping sauces.
Service was good here - waiter never was far from providing whatever we needed.  I'd eat here again and give something else on the menu a chance, but bring money, it's not a cheap date.
author: Steve A.

description: We had our wedding rehearsal dinner at La Mar this past August - it was perfect. The setting was beautiful (we had the back patio to ourselves), the food was wonderful and the staff was accommodating. Our guests are still talking about it.
author: Lauren L.

description: This was my best OVERALL EXPERIENCE of my trip to SF. The service was excellent!! I was with a group of 7 women and we went to have a good time. Our reservation was at 6pm (nope we're not old - that was the only time we could get in) and we didn't leave until close to 10pm! The ambiance was great, our server was nice, helpful and attentive, nobody tried to rush or kick us out (I might have if I was the manager! LOL), the drinks kept flowing, etc. Ohh, yeah, the food. Delicious. I'm generally not a huge ceviche (or cebiche as they spell it) fan but it was all fresh and flavorful. The little cupcakes (potato dishes topped with seafood) were really good. My table was skeptical at first but after I tried it I wished we had ordered more. The catch of the day came on a tiny plate though. Since we were sharing everything it was kind of underwhelming because we each got maybe a fork full. Every dish tasted really good, was well flavored, fresh, had a nice presentation, etc. We also ordered the dessert empanadas... yummy for sure. Two thumbs up!
author: Alfreda D.

description:
Went here for my friends birthday. Happy hour is from 4-6!
Bartenders were inviting and friendly. $5 caipirinha were delish... as well as the pisco sours.
The restaurant was super cute. Enjoyed the vibrant colors and the great natural lighting. Thank god it was a nice day!
We had the cebiche clasico (with yellow tail), empandas sampler, and causa tasting.
All entrees were pretty delicious. I've never had Peruvian food until this day. I'm jealous of my sister and my best friend because they went to Peru two years ago and probably had better! 
Anyway, my favorite was probably the cebiche clasico... Pretty spicy too! 
We didn't have a problem with getting a table because we had a reservation. We were like the first ones there, then it started filling up quick! So I would suggest getting a res! 
I'll go here again for sure. I think it would a nice place to go on a date.
author: RJ S.

description: As a vegan and a first time customer, I didn't expect many options at La Mar. I went on a Saturday night, so the wait staff was busy, but attentive. Despite being delicious as my friends say, their vegetarian empanadas and quinoa are not vegan, which is a bummer. So I enjoyed a couple drinks instead. One of the waiters, Alex, noticed that I wasn't eating and kindly asked if there was anything he could do for me. I told him I was vegan, and he started talking about his vegan friends and being vegan in the Bay. He was so relaxed and kind, I felt like I was talking to an old friend. Then, he helped me tailor a dessert option that worked for my diet. It was a 3 layer sorbet topped with fresh fruit and it was fabulous. I would definitely order it again. He bent over backward to make sure I enjoyed my experience. Despite being busy on a Saturday, he took the time to talk to me and make sure my needs were taken care of. Alex made me feel welcomed and appreciated. Because of him, I'll be returning to La Mar and recommending it to my friends, vegan or not.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
First of all, this place serves Peruvian food. (Hey, it wasn't obvious to me...) Being a Bay Area native, there aren't too many cuisines I haven't tried, but Peruvian food is brand new to me and I loved it. Great place for groups. Great views of the Bay. Great for those times you don't want the usual Japanese/Mexican/Italian food that you eat all the time. This place is awesome!

Must try: (1) scallops, (2) beef medallions with fries on top

I know it sounds like food you can eat anywhere, but whatever Peruvian flavors/spices they infuse into the food makes it taste amazing. 

For drinks, we had a Chilean wine - who would've thought...Chile makes a pretty good sauvignon blanc. And the signature cocktail - Pisco Sour - is made with Peruvian brandy and apparently whipped egg whites...

All in all, a great, unique restaurant with flavors/drinks you've probably never had before. I give it my stamp of approval.
author: Richard Z.

description:
My first taste of Peruvian food was good, fresh, well seasoned, and flavorful - but I didn't find it especially inspiring as a cuisine. Everything tasted good, but the 'foundations' just didn't stir the stars. I didn't try the empanadas, but stuffed and fried dough is commonplace in all cuisines - my guess is that the empanadas (however common in Peru) add little design to the 'foundations' of this cuisine. Of course that would depend on the spicing of fillings - but given what I tasted, I doubt the spicing would be staggeringly original (see samosas as a contrast). Also, technically, what they're serving are empanadillas, not empanadas, which is traditionally (in Spain anyway) more of a pie - baked, not fried like dumplings.

Wikipedia reports that approximately 5% of Peru's population is Asian, which is the only explanation for the highly Asian flavors in the food I sampled. If I labeled the food, I would say Asian-fusion - so thick is the flavor profile - but fused with what, I don't know. There is the distant Spanish influence but Latin-American sometimes seems more like an afterthought, a garnish - a bright flavor, not a profound statement. A cynic might say it's only a few specific South-American ingredients that make this 'fusion' at all.

Below, what I sampled with comments in [brackets].

Chips - potato, other tubers, plantains, and 3 dipping sauces [Excellent - crisp, salty, and tasty dips - but chips are chips.]

Sangria [Okay, neither sweet nor expressive - but I prefer my wine as wine.]

cebiche chifa: mahi mahi w/peanuts, scallions, ginger, pickled carrots/daikon, habanero, wonton strips, pineapple, and rocoto leche de tigre (lime juice and peppers) [Good. Barely tasted habanero and am not the biggest fan of mahi mahi, but it was bright, Asian, and seasoned well.]

causa casera: Peruvian whipped purple potato, artichokes, asparagus, avocado, tomato confit, basil cilantro oil [Cute little things and a clever little appetizer - nothing stunning, but tasty. Purple base potato mash in tubular form (Play-Doh like texture and color), topped with all the rest of the veg chopped and combined into a kind of Peruvian guacamole.]

ensalada nikei: mixed greens with papaya, jicama, soybeans, pickled carrots/daikon, crunchy quinoa, Peruvian purple corn, and rocoto dressing [Well, it is what it says it is - good flavor, Asian (except for the obvious ingredients) - but I found the dressing too sweet.]

anticuchos de pollo: grilled chicken skewers marinated in anticuchon sauce, served with salsa criolla [Tasty. Didn't think Asian at all - which was good. They used chicken thigh too - a wise decision from the chef.]

risotto de calabaza: calabaza squash and aji amarillo risotto, with wild mushrooms saltado criollo [The least Asian and probably my favorite - the risotto was al dente and the flavors were wild, big, and fulfilling. There were more button mushrooms than wild mushrooms, but the dish was tasty.]

atun: seared Peruvian spiced ahi tuna, sesame sauce, purple mashed potatoes with nikei salad [Another favorite. This dish has been done to death by everyone but this was an excellent version. Perfectly prepared ahi - and again, Asian, with the purple mash and nikei salad as flavor repeats.]

lomo saltado: Peruvian style stir fry of sauteed beef tenderloin, onions, tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic, aji amarillo, and fried potatoes [I was surprised how much I liked this, but it reminded me of an Asian-flavored (yes, again) version of Jacques Pepin's 'instant' beef tenderloin stew, which also surprised me - the key, I suspect, is the originality of the use of tenderloin, which is my least favorite cut of beef. My only complaint with this Peruvian take was that the 'fried potatoes' on top looked and tasted like store-bought frozen fries.]

vegetales saltados: fresh daily veg prepared saltado style with tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, and garlic [Tasted a lot like the previous dish - without the beef. So yes, it was Asian and yes it was well seasoned and yes it tasted good - but you know, so it goes.]

Service was a bit sloppy and inattentive at times, but good natured and fine - did not distract from the meal in any way.

In sum, I liked the food, thought all of it tasty; it just wasn't gutsy enough to move me in any direction, forward or back. This is good food for people who are not adventurous but would like to be adventurous - it is just exotic enough to get that far, but it would wilt in the face of something like Indian cuisine. I should also note - for the price you get high quality product - but I would not ordinarily pay so much for high quality product prepared just this way. I am happy I went, might go again, but life is short my people and the dollar is weak. 

3.5 rounded up.
author: Brski B.

description: The food was great but service was awful. First of all the waiter would not come to get our order forever. Then at the end they charged my card more than what I totaled with the tax and a tip. I think it is just bad taste.
author: elena a.

description:
Not my favorite and i was prepared to fall in love. First, I had to get over the hostess who obviously had somewhere better to be. I am not a grudge holder, so she was easy to shake off. 

We had a great waiter (or so we thought),  attentive and offered food suggestions according to our preferences. The food itself was good but not worth the high prices and I never mind paying for amazing. 

Another draw back is sitting inside, which had no view of anything. The restaurant sits on the water and yet all views were blocked.

It was really when our credit card bill came that it became annoying. We had a bill for a little over $190 (for two) and tipped 20%. The charge on the statement was for $10 over our tip. We called, they apologized, sent us a form, we filled it out, faxed it back and waited. Two weeks later hubby was walking in the area and decided to stop in.  The form was sitting on the managers desk, she said that she had not gotten around to it. 
Great customer service......sarcastic tone....
author: Stacy T.

description:
Delicious. Delicious. Delicious. Nuf' Said. :)

I would definitely reccommend this place, go there over and over again, and take all of my friends/family here when they come to visit.
author: Todd O.

description:
I do really like the atmosphere of this place and the staff are all really helpful. It was actually a good example of how all restaurants staff should work, well done.

Aside from the people and location, La Mar is also a tasty place to try some new dishes and tasty sea food. I tried the sampler and an empanada, both were quite satisfying. Dessert was a really good ice cream with more flavors than I can recall. 

For lunch this place did the job and more. I'd come back for a second round.
author: m K.

description:
Its hard to find a place that has consistantly good flavor, presentation and selection- but La Mar nails it. Everything we ordered was really delicious. 

The first time I came to La Mar, it was a saturday afternoon, the restaurant was empty and my friends and I made a stop on our bike ride hoping to have a leisurely libation on their patio. Unfortunately the restaurant wanted nothing to do with us smelly missionites, so we left.

A year later I finally decided to give it another go (well attired). They're still quite pretentious, but the food, drinks and ambience make up for it. It's a beautiful large open dinning space, with an equally impressive bar and viewable kitchen. 

My girlfriends and I ordered the causas sampler and all had different favorites (mine was the vegetarian cesera). One friend ordered the risotto, which is a delicious and solid veggie option. I had the quinotto (quinoa risotto) which was kind of blah. Our other pal ordered a salad and skewer- the portions were much larger then they let on, one or the other could easily be a meal with an appetizer. 

They lose points for trying to upsell us on everything and rarely coming to check on us. 

We went on a Monday night and it was packed, so make a reservation. 

Oh- the pisco sour is as good as everyone on yelp says it is.
author: Rena B.

description:
Good did and fun atmosphere. Our server knew the menu well and made great recommendations. I had some sangria to drink and loved it. I've never had peruvian prior to this experience. It was nice to have someone explain what I was ordering. The cebiche was delicious and I really loved the cause sampler. It was awesome to try the different variations. Sat outside on the deck with heaters with made for a beautiful night on the waterfront, although without the heaters it would have been rainy and cold. this place goes to show how service can make or break your experience. Our Server was slow to return to table when needed and we didn't get our free veggie chips that we saw on every other table. Disappointed enough that his that it's in my head 2 days later. 
I recommend you check out the pictures below so you know what you're getting if you haven't had peruvian before. also, beware. the food is served cold.
author: Sonja R.

description:
La Mar has been on my list of places to try, it's a transplant with locations in various Central and South American countries, which brought about high expectations for authentic and quality dishes.  La Mar did not disappoint.  I finally had the opportunity to try it as one of my many birthday dinners this year, thanks to my sis to treating me and my cousins.  

The best way to go is family style.  Order up your favorite ceviches, skewers, causas, empanadas and maybe a main dish or two.  The ceviche sampler is a must have and gives you the chance to try the popular items.  If you're getting the causa, skip the sampler and order the crab or the tuna tartar versions.  The fried tuna and avocado causas that came with the sampler weren't that great compared the other two.  They have an pretty decent drink menu, but you really can't go wrong with the traditional pisco sour.  

The decor is great and they have an outside patio area which would been amazing to be seated at during the summer.  I definitely will be back for more.
author: Wei K.

description: I have been to La Mar about 5 times now and each time the food is very good. You have to get the cebiche (yep, it's in the name, otherwise known as ceviche). They have many exotic combinations with different fish, spices, other unexpected ingredients that all work. To start though, they always bring the equivalent of bread but theirs is much better-chips of sweet and white potatoes along with plantains and 2 sauces. This is an appetizer in and of itself. It doesn't matter if you gorge on them, trust me you'll still eat the rest of your food! The large menu has quite the variety, from  Empanadas to sushi-style fish combos and other ecclectic small plates, along with purple potatoes and other Peruvian staples that more make for an always-interesting, delicious meal. If it's a nice day, be sure to sit outside. I have never sat inside but it seems pretty noisy when the restaurant gets going.
author: Janice C.

description:
The service is much much better from my first visit. Our server Michelle was really sweet and knowledgeable. Her knowledge of Peruvian customs and cuisines even impressed my mother and aunt. 

On this recent trip I had found that the menu had changed. The lunch menu is not as large as the dinner menu so for a party of 5 we were able to try several dishes. Needless to say the four picky Peruvians at the table were more than happy and approved with great fervor. 

If you're not in the mood for dropping serious coin then definitely stop in for lunch. On those rare warm and sunny days I definitely recommend requesting a table outside.  And don't forget to order a south american white wine to cool you off, if you're in search of a good value. 

On a disappointing note, the arroz con leche has been discontinued. Wtf. What's a peruvian to do?!
author: Roger H.

description: Best Peruvian restaurant in SF.  Great ceviche, lomo Salgado, arroz nortendo, empanadas. Great date place.
author: Hiroshi F.

description:
La Mar lived up to all the hype.  It has an airy and tropical feel to it.  The ambiance is just perfect.  I personally love restaurants that have big open spaces.  The blue chairs and menus are so eye catching and looked exceptionally well with the white base. The staff was great.  There were knowledgeable and our waters were always filled.

Now about the great food..  

sweet potato, plaintain and potato chips were delicious with the 3 dipping sauces

Ceviche mix platter - my favorite was the classic peruvian ceviche with mahi-mahi; it was so light and refreshing but i was thankful for this sampler to try the different flavors which were all very good

Ensalada Nikei - light and refreshing; i really enjoyed the little crisps in this salad

Causas - super good purple potato with mahi-mahi, avocado and onions

Empanadas sampler - beef, chicken, seafood and my favorite was the corn because of the sweetness

I loved everything that we ordered, the ambiance and the staff.  There isn't one bad thing I can say about La Mar. I'm definitely coming back here and introducing this restaurant to other friends who would also appreciate it.
author: Michelle D.

description:
Excellent! Best Peruvian restaurant in SF. Amazing location.. 
They have a wide array of various types of ceviches, which I love! 
We tried the cebiche mixto and the empanadas sampler (corn was my fav) - all highly recommended. 
The Pisco Sour was delicious if you're in the mood for a cocktail. 
For the main entree I had the Arroz Norteno - 4 of us ordered the same.. It was Fantastic... 
We were all truly too stuffed to have dessert however since we were celebrating my brothers engagement it was required.. 
Picarones and Tiramisu de Lucuma.. mmmmmm
This is my new fav place.. I'll be back next weekend!
author: Monica S.

description:
After eating at La Mar in Lima and in Arequipa, Peru, I was excited that they opened one in SF and have been procrastinating in trying it.  Alas, I was disappointed in the food.  It was lacking the flavor and spices of authentic Peruvian food.  I remember my mouth burning after devouring the aji's at their restaurants in Peru but it was so worth it.  It's such a shame that they "Americanized" their dishes thinking that we can't handle the heat and flavors.  The aji's are nothing like the versions in Peru.  We also ordered 2 different ceviches and they both tasted the same except the tiger's milk was different colors.  In their versions in Peru, there were very distinct flavors among the different ceviches and the amarillo version was creamier (but not too heavy).  Also, the arroz de chifa we had in Peru did not have that thick creamy sauce that they stuck in the arroz dish I had here, which made it too heavy.

The complimentary sweet potato chips were a bit stale but still flavorful.  That and the lemon/lime pudding (tasted like a key lime pie) were the best things we ate.  I don't think I will be back knowing what the real deal in Peru tastes like.  I can't believe there are so many stellar reviews of this place.  Those people are missing out on how much better La Mar is in Peru.  Limon is a better alternative.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Went here to surprise the bf with a nice dinner, perfect to the T! We had never eaten at the Embarcadero. We were seated in a very cozy spot on the patio (fully enclosed with heaters), with a view of the dock and cruiseliners/yachts. Super cool! Our server was awesome! Had an excellent pisco! I had made reservations on OpenTable and added notes about a birthday dessert with a candle and they totally followed through - I was probably more impressed than my bf was!
author: Celeste L.

description: Went there for a lunch meeting yesterday and as usual they delivered.  The assortment of fresh cebiches and grilled entrees were generous, but not overfilling.  Most importantly the freshly fried doughnuts rocked for dessert.  A special thank you to Gabriele and his team for a fabulous mid afternoon lunch in the city, we'll be back soon!
author: Nick A.

description:
Very cool place.  The cocktails are amazing.  I had this orange flavored cocktail.. so fresh!  The ceviches were deliciious too!  

The bar is fun and lively with views of the Embarcadero and the dining room is so light and airy you feel as if you're in South America feeling light breezes on the beach.  

Definitely a great place on the water to come while keeping away from most of the tourists at the Ferry Building.
author: Philip D.

description: I love this place. The location, the venue, the food, the vibe, everything is pretty amazing. Other than their Cebiche Sampler, my favorite dish is Lomo Saltado (stir-fried beef), which is really tasteful. And this is coming from someone that does not like beef normally. The place is always crowded especially during happy hour. I celebrated my birthday here a few years ago and had a great time. Good memory of good food:)
author: Ally W.

description: Came here fo a Christmas party; when everything costs free.99 it tastes freaking delicious.  Awesome food and drinks, especially the pisco sours and ceviche.  The beef dish and chicken dish were only okay.  If I had to pay for it, I would probably go elsewhere though.
author: Erika C.

description:
Absolutely one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Not only is the food great but the service is always outstanding. The place itself is spacious and open- makes you feel as if you're in Miami! Also, La Mar is great for groups as the portions are very generous. I also feel like I have to mention that every time I've had dinner here, we've had a hot waiter- great looking staff for sure :)

The various pisco cocktails are also lots of fun... don't forget to try the ceviche nikei, the causa limena, jalea and the saltado... yum, yum, yum. 

Make reservations! Not really a 'walk-in' type of place...
author: Donna V.

description:
With all the great reviews on this place, I feel like I am become the ultimate food douche for not liking it all that much. There was nothing inherently wrong with the meal, but it just wasn't fantastic, novel, or unique. It was just okay. Maybe it was over-hyped.

Three of us ended up here one night, and we raked in a pretty high bill, so I'm  certain that I got a good taste of the range of the menu. The ceviche sampler first, then. The Nikei and the Chifa were the better two of the four that came out. However, in the end, it all tasted a bit muddled to me. When I have ceviche, I like to taste the fish - here, the fish was almost always overpowered by the accompanying ingredients.

Actually... that was my main problem with everything we had. While the ideas behind each dish were good, the execution was lacking. Either the spices overpowered the main ingredient, or the balance of the ingredients was off.

Another example: the Causas Limena. Potatoes topped with Dungeness crab. Too much potato, not enough crab, too much mayo in the crab. I was really excited because I love crab, but I didn't even notice it was there in this particular dish.

In the end, I found the food to be pretty average. I give it a harsher critique than usual here because of the price tag that comes attached to the meal. It makes it to three stars because the cocktails are solid.
author: Amy C.

description: Beautiful setting, indoor/outdoor tables. Full family style meal and the food just kept coming. (Company dinner) Beautifully prepared. I liked snacking on the yucca chips and dip, which was probably just the appetizer.
author: Micah J.

description:
We went to La Mar earlier this week because we couldn't get into the nearby "Slanted Door". I hadn't expected that we'd need a reservation on a Tuesday night!

La Mar was bustling and crowded itself but we were ushered to our seats after only a short wait. Just lucky I guess. 

The first thing to arrive-complimentary- was a basket of homemade crispy doo-dads. (alternative to bread) Deep fried thin chips made from potatoes- at least two kinds- and yams. (maybe) We devoured those and requested another basket.

We split orders of empanadas, ceviche classico and salad which were all scrumptious. I had the crema volteada for dessert. Lovely! My husband was surprised that his order of bunuelas was not at all like the Mexican dessert by that name but it was delicious, nonetheless.

This restaurant is quite pricey, especially the cocktails. But I'd visit again -after I save up my money!
author: Paula H.

description: It's just ok. Really it's just OK. We ordered half of the menu at least it felt like it. But our food just OK and the service was slow. By the time we finished our first appetizer I had not gotten my beer, maybe if I had ordered a custom drink it would have been faster.
author: Mario J.

description:
The food is amazing here. Absolutely amazing. But why only 3 stars you might ask??? -2 stars for the service.. very.. bad.. service. 

I'll keep this short. 
-2 year anniversary with the boyfriend. We were in town for a friends birthday and I decided to make online reservations for La Mar about 2 weeks in advance. I make a note that its our anniversary and I would like to sit some where nice and romantic. 
-We get to La Mar on time. We are seated by a table of 3 and a table of 9. It was very loud and the head lamps above us were catching fire and even burned my boyfriend's shirt.

-our server does not come by to take our order for a GOOD 10 minutes. I am very irritated. The server himself was very charming and helpful when it came to the menu. Its not that he is a bad server, but I think they were understaffed and very unorganized. 

::FOOD::
Cebiche Tasting: Mahi Mahi, Tuna, .. and two other fishes.. served "sashimi" style in different sauces. Excellent. Extremely well executed and each Cebiche had a very unique and memorable taste. 

Lomo Saltado: Stir fried beef tenderloin mixed with french fries and came with rice and corn on the side. My boyfriend loved his dish!! He kept saying "Oh my god, this is so good.."

Arroz Norteno: Almost like a Paella. Mixed seafood in rice topped with two mussels. Delicious. highly recommended 

::DRINKS::
Pisco Sour: ..actually very sour. My boyfriend ordered this drink because Anthony Bordain was drinking pisco sour on his TV show "No Reservations"

Cholopolitan: Nothing special. Like a cosmopolitan but with passion fruit juice and pisco acholado instead of vodka.

hierba buena: tasted like 7-up with alcohol. nothing special about this drink either..

::SERVICE::
-We were given food that we didn't order. Our food was taken to another table. We saw multiple tables being offered food but then taken back immediately because the server mixed up the table numbers or where the food goes. Food took forever to come out. Our server was so busy with other tables I really felt like he neglected us. Our tab was over $122 and I really expected great service but was not offered anything close to it. It was such a shame but I don't think I'll return because the service was very very awful... I don't think I need to pay that much money to be ignored.
author: Steph C.

description:
** Happy Hour Review Only **

I walked in on Wednesday at 4pm expecting to try the ceviche bar.  But when I saw the Happy Hour menu inside the actual bar, I thought, "Why the hell not?"  

Unfortunately I wasn't all that impressed with the menu.  For $120 (including tip) for four people at HH, I could have gotten much more elsewhere.  

- The fried calamari was too crispy, almost burnt like.  Is that how Peruvians eat fried calamari?  My bad, if so.

- Empanadas were good, but for $ 5 a piece, I wish they were just a tad bit bigger.  We tried the beef and chicken stew and in my opinion, the chicken had more flavor.  We ordered four pieces, so that was twenty bones on empanadas alone.

- The yucca fritas were highly recommended by the non attentive, lackluster waitress.  But I didn't taste anything incredible.  They tasted like thick cut steak fries. 

- Of course, we had to try the ceviche, so we ordered both the ceviche classico and ceviche mixto.  For $6 a pop, I really expected more.  I've had much better ceviche at Cha Cha Cha and Mario's in LA.  I think I counted three pieces of fish in the classico ceviche.  

Maybe one day I'll try the real menu on someone else's dime (aka, on a date).  Hopefully my review will be better then.  After we were done drinking and eating here, we went to Cha3 in the Mission.  The same four people spent $ 80 and the ceviche, sangria and calamari were way better there.  I know, I know.   Spanish tapas and Peruvian food aren't the same.  I probably shouldn't be comparing the two.  But it's my review and I can say whatever I want.  :)
author: Christie X.

description:
pisco sours.. a little too sour in my opinion
but the empanadas sampler includes some pretty tasty variety
i think i've now had about eveything on that menu once and i can say there is nothing that i dont enjoy
worth every penny
author: Sunni B.

description:
When I visit San Fran my friends and I love going there. The food and service is excellent. I get all sorts of stuff and I have never been disappointing. The portions are not large and it can get pricey but the food is definitely excellent. 
They also have very nice unique drinks.
author: Mike M.

description:
good, not great!!
I did love their arroz con leche!
author: Carolina R.

description:
So i've tried just about every cebiche that is on the menu, but i've never tried the causa until this week. 
for some reason, i was expecting a mash potato situation and was quite put off by it on paper...but we did a causa tasting...and it was Fabulous! 
The potato was airy, light and fluffy (and a beautiful shade of purple and yellow) and the spicy ahi one was amaznig. 
it was made even better by the fact that it was a biz lunch. ha!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: This is one of my favorite seafood places in San Francisco. The fish is incredibly fresh and flavorful. The pisco drinks are hella good. Service was good. I highly recommend getting the tasting samplers, that way you can try a little bit of everything on the menu and not miss out. The Ceviche sampler is nice and spicy. The empanadas are very savory and complimented well with the dipping sauce. The desserts are incredible. The Tres Leches cake is outstanding and the beignets are explosive; they are filled with a warm chocolate orange sauce. This is a great place to come on a hot San Francisco night.
author: Marco M.

description:
This was a pure Yelp find. Back in a late June visit to SF, wandered over to Belden Place on a Sunday eve for a meal at one of the many restaurants there, but alas, all were closed. Whipped out Yelp, found La Mar Cebicheria Peruana nearby, called, spoke to manager, and within minutes, despite the place being packed, wifey and I were seated outside on a comfortable couch facing the bay. The sun was setting, the weather lovely...Score!!!

The service was impeccable, and because we weren't familiar with Peruvian cuisine, asked and received great recs from our server. We loved the cebechi sampler, as well as the chips/salsas, and for main course dove into the cau cau and the arroz norteno. Wowzer! Everything was unbelievably fresh, tasty, and simply amazing. Excelente!
author: Bruce A.

description:
I REALLY HOPE THE OWNERS AND MANAGERS READ THIS BECAUSE I WANT THIS RESTAURANT TO SURVIVE AND THRIVE.

I have been here a number of times.  In fact, I am going again on Saturday night.  The food is very good and the location is great.  Nice place to take a walk before or after dinner.  BUT...please work on the service.  There are some specific, individual servers who are very good, but as a whole, the experience from the host/hostess through the busboys is rough, uneven and amateur.  San Francisco has many good restaurant choices and to survive long term in this town you have to hit on all cylinders.  I have been here enough to say this was not just a random evening or lunch were the service was not great.  Its pretty consistently not good for a restaurant of this quality.
author: Gary H.

description: Drinks are pricy but the Pisco Sours are yummy. Ceviche was good, but stick with the finger foods. Chicken and Sweet Corn empanadas were great, the other two were ok. The chicken skewer and that crispy potato was great, the beef heart one, not so much. Too chewy. The main course, tacu tacu a lo macho was not good at all. It was the least favorite dish. For dessert, get the picarones. Who doesn't like warm donuts.
author: Scott M.

description:
From the outside this place looks small, but once you walk through the door your brain will be saying...wow I thought this place was going to be small...I mean what else would your brain be saying when it thought this place would be small...right?

Ok so you're probably saying this review sounds strange already, but so would yours after bottomless glasses of wine. If only you could hear my brain slurring.

Well back onto reviewing this wonderful restaurant.

YUMMO!  If you're like me and you enjoy sashimi swimming in luscious sauces, then the ceviche sampler is a must...big must!  Must Must!

The mashed potato sampler I could have done without, due to the flavors being a little bland.

As for the seafood paella style dish, I'll be talking about that, with many oohs and aahs for a long time coming!  The skirt steak was also another favorite.

Now onto the dessert...the chocolate beignets, and the sweet potato fritters were a-m-a-z-i-n-g!!!  Careful with the chocolate balls as the warm chocolate sauce oozes out of them and you'd be left trying to lick the plate ..best bet is to pop the entire thing in your mouth.

Overall this place was great...although I thought it was a tad overpriced for the amount of food served.  Yeah yeah I know, they've got high rent to pay for their prime position...so I don't mind paying for location, just throw a few extra pieces of cubed fish in the ceviche.
author: Karyna K.

description: I travel alot so 5 stars from me is an achievement! #1 DRINKS!!!! The are amazing.  I think majority of my check was drink...very unique and different! #2 FOOD!!!!! Almost as amazing as the drinks.  You have to like seafood.  The flavors had my taste buds sings! Try the salmon! #3 Service was cool...no issues at all and they are very friendly.  #4 Atmosphere is really nice...bar area is trendy and the dinner area is romantic and good for groups.  You will leave here feeling like you got your money's worth!
author: T A.

description:
Pretty place for cocktails but not the food.  We ate at the bar which was really loud but not overly packed.  High ceilings with bad acoustics.  Nice set up at bar.

Service was good and friendly.  We had beef hearts which was served less than warm and didnt really taste grilled and lacked flavor.  Chicken empanadas which were dry and didnt taste homemade, barely any filling.  Halibut cerviche was ok, but again bland.  Causa tasting - 4 dollops of whipped potatoes with various toppings - this was the best plate we had which was pretty and tasty.  

Even the sauces served with these plates couldnt help these bland dishes

3 glasses of wine and 4 apetizers = $117 without tip just at the bar.  Wish it tasted better.  I'm not an expert in Peruvian food but definitely like Piqueos better.
author: May M.

description: Not impress! I had better ceviches, I tried it 3 times because family & friends rave about the chef but every single time it felt like something missing. The fish is fresh I give them that but it's missing something. The service was great the first time but the last two times we were totally ignore.  I hope it gets better next time I'm going to give them one more time because we love to go boating and its a great spot to hang out!
author: Charo S.

description:
Our party of six arrived without reservations.  We were told we could be seated, but that they would need the table back by 8:15.  No problem, I didn't want to spend all night there.  Oddly, the waiter didn't seem to do anything to help us meet this goal.  While the service was not slow by a general standard, it was slow for a party with a deadline.

The food was good, but much of it was fried - not very healthy.  I had scallops with risotto as a main dish and it was very good.  A dulce de leche mousse was a big disappointment.  This dessert did not have the consistency of a mousse at all - just ducle de leche poured in a glass.  Boring. 

As far as I could tell, there is only one bathroom.  It's a one person at a time, unisex bathroom.  It's gross enough using a public bathroom without dealing with the issues of having both genders use it.  And having just one isn't enough for a restaurant of this size.

But the main reason for only three stars is the seating.  We were at a table for six that had benches instead of chairs.  OK, but the benches were not as long as the table.  This is just stupid on the part of the restaurant.  Can you not see that the benches are shorter than the table?  This required everyone at the table to sit much closer together than was comfortable.  I was on the very edge of the bench and spent the entire meal feeling like I was going to fall off.

The bench had no cushion or padding, so after a while my legs hurt from lack of circulation.  I had to stand up several times during the meal to avoid deep vein thrombosis.  

Overall, this was just an OK experience.  I don't regret going, but I would not return.
author: Bay G.

description: Loved the ceviche clasico! Right off the water it was perfect even when dining alone.
author: Priscilla A.

description:
I should have waited until I'd tried a sit down meal before submitting my original review.  Loved it for a group, but the one-on-one dining experience left a lot to be desired.  2.5 stars at best...I'm rounding down though to balance out my earlier 4 star.

For one the service was weak.  We were seated for about 10 minutes with absolutely zero attention paid to us.  Finally had to flag down a manager to put in a drink order and get water.  Then they messed up my drink...no sir, Rye and Bourbon are NOT the same thing.  They were sensible enough to comp my first Manhattan due to that...but still.

The basket of plantains and sweet potato chips with dipping sauces (the one in the middle was really good) arrived about 15 seconds before the cebiche sampler, and after we'd been seated for close to 30 minutes...weak point #3.

Things went mostly smoothly after that.  Our server was friendly and knowledgeable about the menu and the wine list.  We had the cebiche sampler (quite good, but very pricey...like $30 pricey) and the causa sampler (I enjoyed this more than the cebiche).  We both had the specials, sea bass with prawns for me and a seafood paella-like "arroz con something" for her.  Both solid but not fantastic, actually, now that I think about it the sea bass was a touch overdone.

Weak point #4: Had to wave at our server a couple of times for the dessert menu (which we skipped) and then for the check.  He was too busy drying glassware 15 feet away from us.

As it was a school night (I long for the days when I assumed I'd never go to grad school and used the phrase facetiously)* we managed to limit ourselves to one bottle of wine in the $50 range, and even with the comped cocktail the damage still came to roughly $200 pre tip...2 cocktails, no dessert, no coffee.

Short of tasting menus, there aren't many places in the city you CAN'T dine at at that price point and there are literally dozens I'd prefer.  Even with spot-on service, It's just not a good value, which all of a sudden matters to me (thank you AGAIN Jimmy Cayne for running Bear Stearns into the ground).  

In the future, I'll get my cebiche at Fresca for half the price.

I'll probably stop in for cocktails/apps again based on proximity to my digs, but will be very surprised if I ever make another reservation.

* - Actually I'm on spring break- woohoo! But my date has one of those pesky job thingies I keep hearing about.
author: Jay W.

description:
The best CEVICHE ever!!! what a way to cook seafood, man!! so tasty and healthy at the same time, Sushi cannot top this, for real!
I can't say no more, just try it and you will see...
I am starting to become a Peruvian food maniac that I am actually planning to travel to Peru sometime just to eat lol (and of course know that beautiful ancient citadel of the Incas) peace out!
ps: that juice Chicha Morada is also the bomb!!
author: Anth T.

description: Besides the obvious ambiance of being on a pier, this place has delicious Peruvian food (Anticucho de Pulpo & Cebiche Chipotle), the service (Victor) is fantastic! It has a "sustainable kitchen", so all of the delicious food is enjoyed more knowing caught & grown appropriately!
author: Garret M.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of raw anything, but the cebiche here is really tasty.  I'd recommend getting the cebiche tasing platter so you get a mix of everything.  Also a plus is the little chip platter you get with 3 sauces.  I don't know what flavors they are, but it definitely beats the usual bread and butter.  The dinner entrees are yummy and a good proportion size-wise.  

I also LOVE the decor inside.  Very open with high ceilings and the blue/green theme gives off a very clean and fresh feel.  Wonderful place to take a date -- not extremely pricey with a casual atmosphere. 

I want to come back again soon for happy hour!
author: Jean O.

description: It's all about the seafood! We had three of the ceviches. One had octopus which was the most tender octopus any of us had ever had. My friend has been to the restaurant in Peru and said this restaurant spends a little more effort on the presentation but the food is equally as good. This was the best meal we had during our San Francisco/Napa trip. We'll definitely come back here each time were in the area.
author: Jason T.

description: My husband and I went here for our anniversary dinner. The restaurant was very nice and the staff was friendly. We had a reservation and were promptly seated. Our waiter was nice and took our orders. The only thing that was a little disappointing was that the food was only ok. I ordered the lomo saltado and my husband ordered a salad. The lomo saltado was a bit salty and it was drenched in sauce which made the fries soggy. Additionally we noticed that the other tables were getting a complimentary bucket of chips (or something similar) when they sat down. However, our waiter never brought us this. When I confirmed the reservation the day before I told the restaurant it was our 1-year wedding anniversary and the host told me he added the comment to the reservation but the restaurant didn't offer us anything special (no special dessert, no comment about it being our anniversary).
author: Kim N.

description: This review is just for happy hour. I am a big fan of their Chicago restaurant Tanta - amazing from the space to the staff to the food to the drinks - so I was excited to try the sister restaurant in San Francisco. We did not have time for dinner so we stopped in for happy hour. (FYI: someone has put the fear of god into the staff regarding the times each menu can be used. Honestly - you can not hand me a happy hour menu until it starts? really? ESPECIALLY ANNOYING BECAUSE IT IS DIFFERENT THEN THE ONE ONLINE) The service at the bar was spotty and not very friendly. They did not seem that busy, but it took concerted effort to get anyone's attention. The drinks are something special. Loved the sangria, blue mule, and the one with raspberry and I think champagne - sorry forgot the name, but it was great! Food service took a while.  One dish came after about 10 minutes, but none of our other items showed up for over 25 minutes.  The servers that dropped off food had snippy remarks for the bartender in front of us. The cebichin mixto and clasico were both good and fresh, but I was not a huge fan of the yucca . I wanted to try their causitas as they are one of my favorites at Tanta (and on the online happy hour menu but not served anymore during happy hour)- will have to try dinner in the regular restaurant to see if it is better.  The restaurant itself is BEAUTIFUL and I hope to try a meal on their deck to see if I can up the star rating. Another star guaranteed if they import the verdura nikei dish from Tanta - romanesco broccoli, cauliflower, mushroom, spicy nikei sauce YUM!
author: J M.

description:
Good food, very fresh ceviche. Had many other dishes as I went with a large group and had a lot of variety.

Didn't get a view however because of the amount of people. I think the price was quite expensive for the food. Maybe can only come here once in a while. I've been to other similar restaurants and maybe half as cheap.
author: Hai Y.

description:
Color: In this bland array of black, greys, and neutral earth tones, La Mar is a bold and colorful splash on SF dining scene! The food, staff, and service at La Mar is amazing. I want to try everything on the menu! 

For drinks, we started with the Pisco Punch, which came in a wine glass with a perfectly sliced circle of orange, lemon, and lime to decorate each side of the glass! I live for this stuff! The presentation was amazing. I can wait to try their sangria! 

You have to try the Cebiche! Either the sampler, or the Cebiche Chifa (Mahi Mahi) which was served with freshly deep fried plantain chips, sweet potato, and potato chips. Amazing! 

Next we had the Mahi skewers? I can remember what kind of fish it was, but it was amazing. served in the leaves of corn with octagon shaped potatoes and corn. It was my favorite. 

We ended with the Empandadas and the Arroz Norterio. This is not one of the restaurants where you walk out hungry. The food is filling and each bite is amazing. 

Now onto the decor. Anything on the Embarcadero is romantic. You have views of the water, and it truly makes your night feel special. The patio is perfect for a Sunday brunch, or a lunch on a sunny day. The main dining room is too large, and very loud. It reminds me of the buzz you hear at Town Hall. I wish they had separated the spaces and painted the walls. The stark white walls and the oversize main dining is anything but quaint. If you're on a date, ask to be seated in the main bar area near the front entrance or the outdoor patio, it's quieter and has more charm. 

The servers were incredibly knowledgeable and charming. Ask them for their recommendations. They are required to try everything on the menu so they know everything! 

I love this place. I'll definitely be back!  Fresh, Colorful, Great Food and Amazing Service.  Well done.
author: Sandy C.

description:
This place is a gem! 
Sit out on the deck on a sunny day on the water and order any of their fresh Ceviches (ooops sorry, CeBiches) and a pisco cocktail of a variety of options , pure heaven. The portions are elegant and of very high quality, do not come here if you need to "pig out" if you are such a type, go to Chevy's.  The restaurant has a remarkably large and good quality wine list, too. The potato, plantain and sweet potato chips on every table with three lovely dips are a nice touch. We come back here all the time.
author: Nicolas E.

description:
Upon entrance, La Mar Cebicheria Peruana has high ceilings, bold lightings, and modern furniture.  The place is on the spacious side in comparison to SF standards.  

We sat at the bar for half an hour, enjoying our Yelp happy hour drinks for drink week.  I recommend the Pisco Sour.  It's unique, and sour (what girls like, right??)  The Pisco Punch sort of tastes like a normal bar drink, nothing special.  So, four drinks later, we waddled to the dining room for our reservation.

Since it was our first time dining at La Mar, we opted for variety.  This included three samplers: Cebiche (It's actually spelled "Cebiche", not "Ceviche".  I thought it's a typo too), Causas, and Empanadas. 

Although they're samplers, everything was very small.  They're quite tasty and unique, so I'd recommend trying it all.  What one person likes, another might not.  For dinner drinks, we ordered the Santa Maria and the Passion Andina.  They definitely had a kick.  I was so happy from the drinks, that I ate two baskets of their chips (which included potato chips, banana chips, corn chips?? I don't know.)  

But yes, go to La Mar.  It's nice decor, beautiful view, strong cocktails (if not happy hour), sort of affordable food, tasty variety, and semi good service.  They need to hire more waiters.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
Great place to go with a group.  The drinks are fantastic, the food is simple, prepared expertly and seemingly very healthy!  If you're on a diet and trying avoid carbs, you could seriously enjoy this place (the beef, ceviche and fish dishes were terrific).  Also, for those of you not avoiding carbs, the rice and potatoes were tasty.

Great wait staff and the owner even dropped in to make sure we were happy.

Great ambiance too. Very cool place.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Tried the skewered beef hearts, skewered octopus and the ceviche sampler. One of the best meals i have ever had. Delicious!
I would recommend this place to any seafood lover!
author: cesar m.

description:
I left this place pretty amazed.  I am a big time ceviche fan and I wish that I could have devoured more of it.  Unfortunately, I was with my wife which had her client there.  That was a good and bad thing.  The good:  free dinner!!  Yay!  The Bad, was I had to show restraint and not pig out.  So we all shared the ceviche tasting which had 4 kinds- mixto (mahi mahi, calamari, octopus), Chifa (Mahi Mahi with peanuts!), Nikei (Ahi Tuna), and Clasico (Halibut).  I wish I could have tried all of them though.  My favorite was Chifa.  

The empanadas came up next, and of course we had the sampler plate.  I had to share.  Jeeeeez.  I had 1/4 of each one which equates to one bite.  So I had one bite of Chicken, Seafood, Corn, and Beef (chunks of Beef!).  My favorite was Beef.  Lastly we had the Lomo Saltado.  That was the bomb.  That was an eye popping $27.  

So we ordered desert, and then the waiter didn't come back anything we ordered.  Instead he came with other stuff because they didn't have what ordered.  Its all good because they hooked it up for free.  

Keep in mind that I didn't pay for the dinner and I just love the flavors.  I have never been to a Peruvian place this good, but then again, I have never seen ceviche and lomo saltado soooo expensive.  I will come back to try more of their good fresh seafood.
author: Rob Y.

description:
Yum, yum and yum. Went here for lunch with some friends and got a bunch of cebiche dishes, a whole fish (trout) special, a rice dish with seafood that reminded me of paella. We also got a mahi mahi skewer for my 2 year old daughter which she ate up...so it must have been good! 

No complaints about the food -- everything was really fresh and tasty, flavored really well. Cocktails were strong.

My only small complaint was that the service was a bit slow. It just took them a while to bring things out and then come around again to check on us. When I asked the server for juice for my daughter, she said, "oh I have a little one about that age, I know how it is, I'll be right back with some juice" and it took her forever which was kind of weird. 

Not the most kid-friendly place in the world (i.e. the majority of the menu is raw fish), but at least the place is kind of loud so if helps drown out any fussing. Or in our case, Elmo videos on the iPhone.
author: Susan L.

description: This is a nice place with an amazing view where I had lunch with a friend of mine. The service was pretty good as well, and my friend told me that she enjoyed the food. I don't know, personally, I was expecting something more because of the reputation of this place, but it can be that I ordered just their standard menu, next time I will try something more specific.
author: Roberto V.

description:
4.5 if possible.  Can't say much which hasn't already been covered so I'll be terse: vibrant colors, lots of blues, wonderful environment, great date place...duh!  Sit outside if you can or if weather permits.

Cebiche Mixto, chifa, nikei and clasico.  All great but chifa my choice.

Causa Limena:  never have I tasted or seen better whipped, formed then rolled potatoes.  Incredible with dungeness crab atop.  I'd give this dish alone 5 stars.

Empanadas Del Mar

I think we had Nikei Planchas.  It's not on the on-line menu for SF but I saw it on Peru's.  They had it, I ordered and I approved.  We ate it all.  

Sangria was, in her words:  dee-lish-us!  Basket of chips including fried plantains.  We ate two!  Her idea but she can eat three and not worry.  Basically, we were P-I-G-S!  I'd go back in fresh heartbeat.
author: Steven R.

description:
Slurp. Yum. Glug. Chitter. Suggestions. Clatter. Yum.

I went in a Peruvian virgin and came out almost a woman. The waiter had great recommendations. The little potato fish thingies were divine, the sauces were rich and spicy.

I lost my ceviche virginity here. After a cocktail and a few Peruvian beers, I stomached the raw concoction which could have been the best ever. Not my cup of tea, but the rest of the meal and the bustling atmosphere made me skim over it.
author: Garreth W.

description:
This place is talked about alot.  Disappointed and then taken advantage of.  The food was tasty however way overpriced.   After spending $150.00 for 2 people we left hungry....  the service was disapointing. 

The bar seemed more interesting that the restaurant, however, wanted to get out of the place as soon as possible.
author: Mauri L.

description:
Group dinners can be really painful and unsatisfactory.  Last night was the complete opposite.  

La Mar is a great space for groups. They had it down perfectly!  We had about 20 people and they gave us the chefs table.  What I loved about this space was you had your own little corner but didn't get stuck in a back room.  You were part of the entire restaurant scene and were able to enjoy the ambiance of the space, while still having a sense of privacy.  

The food was delicious!  Presentation perfect, flavors amazing, and service was off the hook!  They did a great job and should be commended for their work.  

I will always consider La Mar when it comes to group dining.  Heck I will consider them for when I am dining alone as well.  

Way to go La Mar staff!
author: Scott P.

description: I really like La Mar. I have eaten there several times. I like their cebiches, which are atypical and well executed. The bartenders have creative cocktails and will recommend a good match based on your mood. I've never been when the bar was overly crowded. The dining room is quite large, and surrounded by lovely large windows. The servers will gladly allow you to start small and add plates, I've never had to wait long for an order.
author: Marco N.

description:
This place is way too nice for me. I did happy hour here on a Friday in the front bar area which is separate from the main area. It's quite an amazing space. I can't even imagine how expensive things must be in order to pay the rent here. 

I tried their $5 happy hour special Pisco sour and it was pretty good. I was almost done with it when one of the bartenders asked if i wanted another. I said, "not yet." STUPID! Never turn down a drink invite. Never! 
I then stood at the bar for 15 minutes waiting to order my next drink. A different bartender came back and I asked him which Peruvian beer he recommended since they're $3 during happy hour. He brought me one and I handed him a twenty. He brought back my change and went back to work. I realized he charged me full price for the beer. I downed it ASAP and left no tip. Sorry buddy, not your fault. I'm off to Mission Bar. "Nice" places give me the creeps.
author: Corey V.

description:
Dapper, yet mellow little Peruvian spot.  Love that you can sit at the ample bar, main dining area inside or enjoy your meal al fresco while taking in scenes of the bay.  Everyone that works there is super friendly as well, from the hostess, to the waiters to the bus boys.

The food was so fresh and dee-lish!  We had the cebiche clasico, the causa limena, empanadas del mar, and the lomo saltado.  All of them were so tasty and I loved the presentation.  Simple but delicious!

The drinks were just as good.  Not a huge fan of pisco, but it was nice out and the drinks sounded so refreshing so I just went with it.  I had a dulce amargo which was SO good, and tried some of my friend's pisco sour.  

I already recommended it to some friends who went for dinner last week, and wouldn't you know...they loved it as much as I did.

I am definitely coming back.  The sooner the better!

P.S.  Absolutely LOVED the chips that they bring to your table.  I think they are plaintain, yucca and potato.  They are accompanied by 3 equally tasty sauces too!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Finally got to try La Mar today.  My boss took me so yippie it was free but since it was lunch and my boss I didn't get to drink so boo hoo.    

Tried the cebiche chifa, a quinoa appetizer which was on the specials board and the ensalada camarones laqueados.  Overall the flavors of the food were great.  The shrimp on my salad was perfectly fried and crunchy and yummy.  The chips and sauces they give you as a starter are delicious - I used them to scoop up my cebiche.  My only complaint about the cebiche was that I'm used to it being chopped and easy to pick up (at Limon) with a fork or chip but it was in long strips that you had to put on your plate and cut up.  Maybe that is the Peruvian way, not sure.   

The service was a little slow between courses and the restaurant was half empty so that was a little disappointing but I am anxious to go back and try more items (menu and bar) and will be sure to update my review then.
author: Julie P.

description: Have eaten at a number of Peruvian restaurants and went here on our Anniversary.  The expectations were very high as I have recommended many people to this place based on others advice. Not impressed at all!!!. Over priced establishment for the food, quality and quantity. Personally we were both very disappointed with La Mar.
author: Daoud M.

description:
The causa nikei will be the reason why I'll be going back.  It tasted a bit like spicy tuna on mashed potatoes.  (pardon my ghetto palate) Perhaps a peruvian version of stamppot but delicious.  

They give you house made chips instead of bread with dip which is pretty good but a lot greasier than bread so you end up feeling a bit guilty afterwards.  The main dishes are fresh and light enough to make up for it though.
author: S. K.

description:
3-star reviews are often borderline. Some of mine, at least, carry the tone of "at least check it out." Some 3-star establishments should be avoided. I think that La Mar fits into the former category, but given how disappointing some aspects of it were, I can't fathom giving it four, much less five, stars.

The good: Inca Kola is not my favorite soft drink ever (Cherry Coke Zero, for those of you keeping score at home). It's green but tastes like bubblegum. Say whaaaat? But it was a nice touch that they carried it. The ceviche with "leche de tigre" was amazing. I wasn't sure if I liked mahi-mahi, but I think this cevhiche in particular convinced me. And the plantain and potato chip combo they served was a great improvement over bread. :) The three sauces were not amazing - except the so-called "spicy" sauce - which, while not spicy, was still flavorful and pretty darn good.

The Bad: The service was painfully slow. I know, we Americans like everything super-fast, and we should savor more. Fine...but the meal was just timed badly. It honestly shouldn't take that long to get Diet Coke or Inca Kola or whatever. There's a difference between savoring a dining experience and passing that point into sheer frustration. The waiter was nice enough, too. Of course, there was a lack of communication with the runners, as the two women next to my cousin and me got our two ceviches. (We also got the Japanese-themed ceviche [yeah, I forgot its name...], which fell short of expectations.) They were nice, so it wasn't awkward to finally interject when they kept wondering "Hey, why do we have these two ceviche plates?" Uh, maybe it's because the kitchen's probably-large profits can't buy a kitchen having its shit together. At least not that day. Jacob F and I both got dishes featuring red meat, and his was pretty tough. I love spices, but mine (a burger) was basically spiced and slathered in sauce to mask recognition of the actual patty. 

I'd go here again and try something else, but there were a few kinks in the visit. I enjoyed the food we sampled in the Ferry Street Market more. :)
author: Melissa F.

description: I only tried the bar, (not the restaurant) but I LOVE it! You can sit at the bar or in community tables, food comes quickly and it's really good. Drink menu is wide enough to make you happy. Try the Cebiche Nikkei!
author: Steve E.

description:
I waited and waited to try this place.  I'm crazy for ceviche so my friend recommended I try this place and it was on 7x7- 100 things to eat before you die.  So we went here for dinner one night and I have to say I was a little disappointed in the ceviche.  

We had a bunch of sampler plates including ceviche, empanadas, whipped potatoes with toppings, and a sashimi plate.   The ceviche was decent but not the best I've had.  The sashimi plate had salmon and yellow tail with a yummy sauce on it.  I was a fan of that.  We also had a dish with whipped potatoes with different toppings on it which was pretty good.  Overall, for the main food I'd give this place three stars. 

I give La Mar 4 stars for 2 main reasons.  Service and ambiance was perfect.  #2 plantain chips and dipping sauce.  YUM YUM YUM! We went through 4 baskets of our free plantain chips and the habenera was AWESOME!!!

La Mar is definitely a place to check out.  Especially in good weather since you can sit on the patio area and it's beautiful.  Next time I go there, I'm going to bring tupperware and steal the dipping sauces :)
author: Jaein L.

description:
Good gawd almighty! I love this place! Continuing my "Day of Decadence" after a morning of indulging on caviar and champagne at Tsar Nicoulai...uh, from two weekends ago (Yeah, yeah, I'm behind on writing reviews, ok, so sue me!). My friend and I decided that we had to try La Mar before leaving for our upcoming trip to Peru. We were hoping to see cuy (guinea pig) on the menu, but no such luck. Ok, I'm lying. My bad. I always scope out the menu online before I try a new restaurant. Anywho...

We started our fabulous meal with the Cebiche Tasting, which included Cebiche Mixto, Nikei, Chifa, and Clasico. Each cebiche was delicious and the portions were hearty. We could have started and ended our meal with this and would have been happy campers, but we were just whetting our appetites. The leche de tigre had just the right balance of acid and flavors from the rest of the ingredients, and after consuming all that leche, I sure felt potent (if you know what I mean). I stockpiled that natural Viagra, so I should be good for about another month.

Next, we had the Causa Tasting, which included Limena, Criolla, Nikei, and Vegetariana. The presentation was beautiful with perfectly crafted masterpieces of whipped purple and yellow potatoes with different toppings, but none of the flavors really wowed me. They are not something I would try again only because I hate filling up on a lot of carbs or starches like bread or potatoes, but I'm glad I tried them.

As if Cebiche and Causas weren't enough, we decided to be bold and adventurous by trying the Anticuchos, beef hearts! You know what? It tastes just like chicken! Just kidding. Beef hearts actually taste just like beef. It was delicious and grilled perfectly. Give it a try, and you too, can have the manager personally deliver a plate of beef hearts to your table. I'm sure the staff is always curious to know who is adventurous enough to order them. We also had grilled octopus skewers on top of herbed mashed potatoes with chimichurri sauce and aji panca. The octopus was tender and delicious. My only complaint with the grilled food that was served is the obvious gas grill flavor that accompanied it. It was a little distracting from the true, natural flavors of the meat and seafood. 

But wait, there's more...

After loosening our belts and unbuttoning our pants as gracefully as we could underneath the table, we had to make room for dessert! We had the Bunuelos De Chocolate Caliente, warm chocolate filled "beignets" with banana and a passion fruit reduction. The round "beignets" were heavenly and the warm silky chocolate inside was soothing to the palate. Last but not least, we tried the Crema Volteada, a tasting of four crème caramels. The blending of flavors of both desserts was unique and complex. They were the best restaurant desserts I've had in a long time.  

I'm hoping to make it to La Mar in Lima to compare the food, but if not, our server recommended Astrid y Gaston, one of Chef Gaston Acurio's many other popular restaurants. Overall, the food was delicious. The service was excellent. The ambiance was a bit noisy from the open floor plan and the open kitchen. Oh, and I forgot to mention the fried plantains and yucca chips they serve before the meal with three different dipping sauces. Fantastic! Also, if you're going to order a pisco sour, have it before your meal because it's very sweet and doesn't blend too well with the meal.

After an indulgent day of caviar, champagne, seafood, and beef hearts...that concludes my "Day of Decadence" my friends.
author: Anastasia B.

description: I loved La Mar. I called the make reservations the day of and was only able to get seating in the lounge so didn't have any view of the bay but was still able to order from their full menu. I started with the passionfruit pisco cocktail which was tasty. My friends and I shared the cebiche nikei (ahi tuna), cebiche crudo (shrimp, sea urchin and scallops), chicken skewer with Peruvian corn, the arroz (tasted like paella), whipped potato causa tasting, and the chocolate beignet dessert. Everything was delicious. I agree with Cathy K. that the highlight of the meal was the basket of fried plantains and potato and yam chips with three dipping sauces. I can't wait to return to try the rest of their menu and hopefully get a table with a nice view of the bay, maybe even in the patio!
author: Diana B.

description:
I took two clients to La Mar, got a great table for four and the experience was akin to a great movie that was spoiled by the ending.

Two of us started out with La Mar's happy hour.  I am not a fan of bars that advertise a happy hour and then give you a list of about six or seven happy hour drinks but the drinks were not bad (I would not get the happy hour white wine) and the bartender, Ricardo was wonderful. He has one of those infectious smiles and if you are planning a trip to Peru, this happy hour is for you. Ricardo will tell you all that you need to know. I recommend the Calamari, at $4.00 it is a steal and well presented, and the Chilcano if you like zesty drinks. Suggestion: the dinner drinks are pricey so order a happy hour drink if you your reservations are near 6 pm and take the drink with you.
Dinner started off pleasant enough. Our server was Shane who was knowledgeable about the menu and offered good suggestions.  The restaurant is pricey but the food is really good.  I highly recommend the Arroz Criollo and Cebiche Chalaco. 

While waiting for the food we asked our waiter for bread. He appeared to find this to be a strange request but nevertheless asked the kitchen. A couple of minutes later he returned with what appeared to be bread chips. The pieces of bread looked and tasted like croutons and were the size of silver dollars. We received four pieces. We all looked and wondered "can they spare a little bread?" so we asked for more.  We pointed out how small the "bread" was and our waiter brought more out. We received four more silver dollars. We were rather amused at this until we received our bill and noticed that they charged us a dollar for each round of bread. We found this tasteless, chintzy and sad.  I mean, the setting was nice, the food was pretty good and then you charge us two dollars for eight chips of bread.  To add insult to injury I asked to take half of my Arroz Criollo to go and somehow the folks who cleared our table lost my food.  

The saddest part came when it was time to leave a tip. We go out quite regularly and almost always leave twenty-percent whether it was earned or not because we understand that being a server can be arduous work. Last night we left 15% and complained (very little) on the way out.  Come on La Mar, your restaurant is expensive enough. Two bucks for eight chips of croutons, really?
author: Chocoolate I.

description:
Let the birthday dinners KEEP COMIN'!  I really have great friends!  They took me here for my 3rd birthday dinner.  (It was more of a birthday WEEKEND if you will)

I have heard so much about La Mar and I was so excited to eat here.  Wow! I'm glad that my experience lived up to all the expectations!  As soon as you walk in, you feel like you're not in San Francisco.  It's more of a light..."welcome to Miami" feeling to me.  I loved it! 

We started with the plantains and chips with three different sauces. They all had different levels of heat.  They were to die for!  I seriously wanted to stuff them in my purse and take them home!  Then we had the Ceviche Nikei.  It consisted of Ahi Tuna, red onion, Japanese cucumber, in tamarind leche de tigre with avocado. Super yummy! We also ordered the chicken epanadas which are my personal favorite and for our main course the arroz jugoso (Prawns, clams, mussels, calamari, octopus, white fish and vegetables in a juicy arborio rice with a blend of Peruvian ajis).  This resembled the classic Spanish paella but I honestly think it was BETTER!

Holy cow everything was good!  The entire experience was five stars! Thank you Lily R and Renee for taking me.  It was everything I hoped for and MORE! :)
author: Candice M.

description:
I realize that it's rare that i leave a restaurant feeling perfectly balanced and without eater's regret.Yes, I do pig out, that might be my problem. But..... I mean, french is awesome but creme brulee? foie gras? c'mon, talk about straight to the gutt! asian cuisines also tend to be over-msg'ed-out, mex fare tend to be all greased up as well, italian=creamy pastas=carbs; steak=heart attack; and i can do salads, but those never satisfy me for more than 1 hour.  

It's been awhile since I left a restaurant saying "gee, i'm glad i ate that!" Ok, so what's the point?

La Mar's seafood options are fresh and tasty, lite, perfect portion-sized. Diet-friendly without scrimping on taste! Just proves that we don't have to sacrifice date nights because of that pesky diet!
author: natassia s.

description:
Well what to say...I have eaten here several times and had a pleasurable experience - great food, fun atmosphere etc...HOWEVER...After guiding a large group to the bar for drinks and apps after work recently, I was severely disappointed. 

This is primarily a service issue, as I have NEVER been treated with such disrespect by a bar-server. When I raised the issue with the bar manager, I became even more frustrated. NO apology, NO sympathy and to top it off she refused to let us write the tip - 20% group tax for the worst service ever...dont worry about it.
author: Nick R.

description:
Sits in one of the pier building, with some nice outdoor seating in  the back.  A little snooty, but great Peruvian food.  The 18 year old waiter mispronounced a menu item and when I corrected him he reassured me I was incorrect.  Poor kid didn't know any better ...

Recommend the Ceviche and Empanadas, their mixed drinks are great (Pisco Sour), even if they are expensive.
author: N M.

description: Hands down the best Peruvian food in SF. The pisco sour, ceviche and entrees are all to die for. You can have an intimate dinner or large group. It is a large restaurant with many different spaces for any atmosphere you desire. I am so thankful we have this here!
author: Ann K.

description:
Wow, excellent excellent.  First, the dishes come out so beautifully presented, it's hard to start eating it right away.  My friends took pictures of all our dishes before digging in.  Ceviche, paella, fish, meat, it's all good.  

This is a happy place in the day, when we went, very bright blues are highlighted by the sun.  High ceilings and a view of the bay make it easy to have a relaxed time with awesome!!! food.  Come here to impress visitors and locals alike.
author: Jonathan J.

description:
Being Peruvian, I have mixed feeling about La Mar. I have been there a handful of times including during their transitional "opening" week when the service was horrible!! But they have since redeemed themselves! Thank God! because food is actually good and I am a big fan of the plantains and the dips.

 I would recommend La Mar to anyone looking for a chic and upscale place with some flare. The drinks are creative and delicious! I would recommend the chica morada (alcoholic version) any of the delicious appetizers and cheviches. Portions size run small and prices run BIG. Don't have reservations? Plan on waiting.

If you are looking for authentic and cultural...maybe not for you, but if you are looking for sophisticate, not-so-generic, chic and yummy...yes!

I stick to the appetizers which are my favorites. The empanadas are great especially for those not brave enough to try the octopus or cow heart skewers (which are pretty good for being cooked in a restaurant) I've had both and they each that unique aji panca flavor. 

I would highly recommend the causa samplers. These are delicious little potatoes creations with a variety of fillings. Personally I like them spicy and would add more lime juice, but they are quite a starter. The lomo saltado is pretty good but not mind blowing... although I will admit this is a difficult recipe to pull off. The lomo meat should be quite soft and the french fries not too soggy but crisp enough to pair great with the meat and delicious pieces of onion. I would recommend most main dishes. I would not recommend the risotto only because you can get plenty of that in north beach at a much better price and plate.

Best desert ever: Picarones - These are Peruvian donuts. Deep fried pieces of heaven! They are actually made from Camote (a common sweet potato used profusely throughout Peruvian cuisine)

The missing star is for the insane prices. This also where my mixed feelings come in. I don't believe the prices are reflective of the actual ambiance and level of service. Granted the service is great for the most part, but if it's more than $50 per person I need at least a gorgeous view, or an intimate setting with some first-class waiters or something else! (i dont consider this venue much of a view unless you are on the back patio getting blown away by the sea breeze or in the back near the windows) I would go back just for the plantains and dipping sauces anytime though!

P.S. If you are looking for a smaller, more intimate setting with equally as delicious cheviches I would try Mochica in Soma.
author: Crystal D.

description:
OH MY GOSH -- why did I not come here earlier? I finally came tonight for dinner and liked everything about my meal, the location, the decor, even the blue woven seats! Being right next to the bay has its highlights too.  The restaurant is an explosion of colors! Even the menus are colorful. The remodel of the pier was wonderfully done. Very modern, very spacious and very unique.

First off, the chips - yumiliciousness! I could just eat that and I liked the plantain and sweet potatoes ones the most.  We shared the cebiche which came in a quad of plates. I liked the ahi the most out of the bunch, but all were good.  We then had the causa nikei - a purple potato with ahi on it - sooo good...those are definitely a must order.  

I shared a salad with my bf and that was also very delicious. There was something in the salad that gave it a certain flavor, which kind of reminds me of the li hing mui dressing I had at Alan Wong's in Honolulu.  We then shared a chicken empaladas and a corvina fish.  The fish had a delicious tomato sauce and the fish was over more potatoes.
