Finally, we had a sorbet with two Peruvian flavors that I cannot remember, but one was white and the other was sort of sweet and sour. I feel that it may have been in the salad. We also had the tamarine flavor. 

Everything was delicious and the company was great. Definitely will come back and try more!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Stopped into La Mar for lunch last Saturday, the weather was beautiful so the piers were mobbed with people and therefore so were the restaurants. To avoid the wait we opted to sit at a high top table in the bar.

Food: 4/5
We split a half order of one of the cebiches (the classic halibut I believe) and each had the mahi mahi skewers. The cebiche was really good, flawless even. The mahi was good, but didn't blow me away, in fact we wound up talking more about how good the potatoes and corn that came on the side were. Don't get me wrong we enjoyed the meal very much, but I couldn't give the food 5 stars because the mahi wasn't 5 stars.

Drinks: 5/5
There were so many things on the cocktail menu I wanted to try I wish we could have sat there all day, that being said what I did have was very good. The mojitos were on the mark, and the Peruvian beer I had was really quite good (I wish I could remember the name, there were only two on the menu and I didn't have the Crystal, so whatever the other one is).

Service: 3/5
Look, it was the bar and there was no dedicated waitress for the high top tables so it was really two bartenders taking care of the whole thing - one working the well and the other taking care of the bar front and the tables in the bar. Therefore I can't blame the bartenders, I blame whatever manager is charged with the staff schedule and the server sections. There were enough tables in the bar to warrant a server section but alas, there was none. Basically this caused the service to be slow, it was good, just slow.

Ambiance: 4/5
It's chic and modern with a light airy feel to it. Perfect for a relaxing lunch on a nice day which is exactly what we came for. I can't comment on the dining room since I didn't sit in it but from what I saw it looked more of the same. Atmosphere was casual, every having a good time and relaxing.

Value:4/5
It's not a cheap place, but it's not overly expensive. I think the cocktails are marked up too much, most of the drinks are 9-10$ which I think is a bit steep for what this place is. $7-8 would be acceptable, 9-10 is high. The food price though is fair in my book, for the location, freshness and quality of the food I had no problem with the prices. I guess my take away point is check this place out, but don't have too many drinks unless you don't mind a large bill.
author: Chris E.

description:
Took my ever so fabulous best friend here to celebrate her birthday (belated -my fault) and was entirely pleased with the experience.   From the minute we walked in we are greeted by this super fabulous receptionist (wish I got her name to give her a shout out) that hooked us up with a primo spot on the back deck with the most impressive view.   

We couldn't decide on an entree and chose like 20 appetizers...the waiter was an absolute doll and accomodated our ridiculousness (a few wines in, he deserved better customers).  We were giggly, silly, taking pics and making goofy requests.   He never once was rude or blinked an eye and didn't pawn our table off on to someone else.

The food matched the service and was EXCELLENT, however the soups (only two) and we got both, tasted the same except one was green and one was red.   My friend swears the green was better, I wasn't partial to either.  Keep in mind, I can not speak for the main dishes (definitely next time) but every single appetizer was delish!

Back to the ever cute receptionist that half way through our meal and enjoying our silliness made an attempt to hook us up with 2 other single guys having dinner....LOL now that's service!  It's a shame we were both seeing someone at the time but now I'm single and kinda wishing I took her up on the offer...next time : )

Ooooh definitely MUSTmake a note of this - you will pay well for such excellence.   Our meal topped out at $250+ but that included 4 glasses of wine, a dirty martini and a dozen or so appetizers.  Just be forewarned.....
author: Deena B.

description:
I first learned about La Mar at the SF Street Food Festival. I never got to the front of that line so i decided I would re-visit its restaurant. I was NOT expecting this gorgeous setting. The ambiance was very romantic chic. I mean who wouldn't love the pleasant company of the bay bridge as one of your dining companions. So definitely, the ambiance gets a 5 stars hands down! 

Service: The wait staff was civil but definitely didn't make us feel completely welcomed. You know that stereotype of the upscale restaurant that has really attractive people working there but looks down on the common folk? Yea, definitely gave off that vibe. However, by the end of the night, they warmed up to us. 

Food: Mixed with hits and misses. A hit, deserving of 4 stars, was the mixto and classico ceviche. The mixto had a thicker feel but it was really yummy with squid. The classico was your typical ceviche but any ceviche purist would love it. There was a thai inspired ceviche (mahi mahi) and also a Japanese ceviche (tuna), which were misses and I was disappointed. The thai was yummy but the Japanese inspired ceviche was simply tuna tartare. In fact, very uninspired. 

We also had the empanada sampler, which had a very amazing crust. Personal favorites were the veggie and the chicken was pretty yummy. The seafood empanada fell short. The beef empanada was standard and I think I've had better elsewhere. 

Drinks! were really yummy. First time I had pisco and my gosh that shit is strong! Or maybe I just can't handle my liquor anymore. The PIsco punch was so yummy. My santa maria tasted like a strong sex on the beach.  I'd love to come back and revisit for their happy hour! 

Conclusion: I'm gonna leave La Mar an open book because I have yet to try their entrees and their causas, which looked amazing. Also, heard great things about their desserts. But so far, I like what I see. Although La Mar is more of Peruvian fusion rather than a traditional approach, it's got a whole lotta yummy.
author: Wendy L.

description: Food was delicious! The prices are reasonable. Waiter was nice, will be visit again!!
author: Irasema A.

description:
Good to try once. It's been the hottest spot in the City last 3 months. Their LA style launch has definitely paid off. Unfortunately, the details of this restaurant is still being worked out. I'm glad to have experienced it so that I won't have to return.

Food: 4 stars
For the price point, they give you a good size portion. The flavor of the food is pretty good. Cebiche tasting for $24 was a good value. (they spell it with a "b" instead of "v" that we are used to) The potato dish with quail egg, crab, avocado puree was very good. Lamb shank was delicious, especially the mashed rice and the sauce on the plate. Seafood empanadas were awful, unfortunately.

Beverage Program: 3.5 stars
Great selection of wine at great prices. We opted for California vs Spain flights of albarino and tempranillo. It was a clever concept, but the California wine that's "fighting" against the Spanish just doesn't carry it. I would say choose all of the fabulous new world wines that they have (plenty!) instead of California bottles there. Usually, the "cost performance" of the new world wines are better than the old world's.
Many spelling error on sake list. It was very weird. We didn't get to try the cocktails.

Service: 3 stars
You will wait for a long time to be noticed here, as the line of communication between the servers, runners and the bussers are still fragile here. The servers are "too good" to take empty plates off the tables or give you ice water. So that attitude, we thought, was very LA in a bad way (as we've seen it first hand in the industry back home). Don't let your server course the meals out, but ask him/her to bring whatever comes out first, if you go there hungry.

Decor/Up Keep: 3.5 stars
Funky fun color scheme. Beautiful semi-private bar area behind the host stand. "Historical" bathroom kind of dirty, but oh well enjoy the history. A huge minus for leaving a big tall ladder right by the back entrance. A restaurant of this class should really not have done that.... When you leave from the back doors to the parking lot after your meal, be aware of the terrible smell coming from the ocean. It almost made us puke.
author: Kokoro I.

description: To be honest the food was just okay.  The Restaurant was busy and very loud.  The waiter was very slow and it took forever to get our food.   When we were finally done I requested our check, which again took awhile to get.  But that wasn't my issue while I was waiting for our check the person that seated us came up to me and told me that they needed to make our seat available for the next reservation!!!   So basically telling me to hurry up.  We'll that's about time when I lost it.  I will never go back to this restaurant again.
author: Jerry O.

description:
I ate here for the first time on Saturday May 14th. The decor is amazing, food is delicious, but the service was poor and unfriendly. My server, Shane, doesn't smile and did not care about customers. He made a mistake on one of my orders which resulted in 15 more minutes of wait time for a new dish, and he did not apologize. He also kept pushing us to order cocktails, and when we finally ordered, he came back 20 minutes later telling us that the Sangrias we ordered was out. Again, he did not apologize.  Same with the dessert, he just handed us the dessert menu and left. He didn't say a word or made recommendations on anything. When we finished looking through the dessert menu and got excited about ordering the esfera de chocolate, he came back to tell us that the kitchen is out on all the desserts except the limon tart and sorbet. We got excited over nothing and wished he had told us in the beginning. **The restaurant should just hire a robot to serve customers instead of him!!**

The two of us ordered Chicha Morada, Causa tasting, Anticucho Corazon, Lomo Saltado, and Ceviche Clasico. I wished the Chicha drink was sweeter. Everything else taste great except for the Ceviche Clasico. I've had better Ceviches at other Peruvian restaurants. The catch of the day was Halibut, and it tasted fresh but it wasn't cut right which resulted in a chewy texture.  

I do need to compliment our bus boy name David. He was smiling all the time and asked us how we liked our dishes. Much better than our server Shane, we should have tipped David directly instead.
author: Amanda L.

description:
This is a great place to go for drinks. The pisco punch was great. The food was good and I loved the dessert! You have to get the Dulce de Leche! 

The service was outstanding. My friend and I shared the samplers (or tastings as they call it) of the cebiche, empanadas, and causas. It was yummy. 

I could just go here for a drink and dessert and I'd be happy!
author: Sunshine J.

description:
#47. Ceviche (2009) and a pisco sour (2010) Big Eat SF 
**bar, not restaurant review (no patio!)

minus a star because their happy hour is 4-6 ...that's tough for us working peeps!

 BUT the drink is awesome. as for the ceviche, they have a ton of different kinds... some really spicey, some squid based. got a 4-type sampler to share for the table (but should have checked the price...) ... luckily went also during yelp drinks week, so the stragglers could still drink at a good price!

ambiance of the bar is chill and classy. If you have a big group, try heading to the south end, there's one table but there's a ledge to put a ton of stuff and space if you borrow extra chairs.
author: S V.

description: I've went twice, exclusively for cebiche.  The cebiche gets no stars. 1 star is for the Pisco Sours made to perfection and another star for the location.  The ceviche was "meh". Nice looking white fish yet flavorless and not tart enough; a very small portion not worth the $14. The cebiche came with a sliver of yam and a table spoon of hominy grains.  They use habanero chile instead of limo chile. Habanero is not Peruvian.  They have a full bar and the drinks looks very sexy.   The beer selection sucks and they only have bottles.  Maybe good for sexy drinks and a pretty not so yummy snack.
author: Jen C.

description: Good service. Food was pretty good, but it is on the pricey side for what you get. Beautiful views. My bf and I are both gluten intolerant so it was nice to be able to have a variety without worrying about contamination. My favorite was the grilled octopus, perfectly cooked. They know how to cook seafood.
author: Eldar B.

description:
***Just for Drinks****

We decided to kill a little time before we went to Waterfront Restuarant down the street.  We had some cocktails since I noticed they had a pretty large bar when walking pass earlier.  My bf had a santa maria and I had the passion andina.  With a serving of our fav. corn nuts like nuts and sipping on our cocktails it was a great pre-dinner drink before we went for our dinner.  Warning to "manly men" though althought santa maria was great...it was a pink drink lol.  Overall, very relaxing bar with great drinks.  I would try to come here again for another drink or even some food...I do love me some Peruvian food.
author: Kim D.

description:
Don't judge a book by its cover.  My wife took me here for my belated birthday celebration.  La Mar is an international chain with three locations currently open (SF, Chile, Peru) and three more on the way.  It was Sunday and we went for lunch.  The location is great and the atmosphere is open and filled with light.  Outdoor seating is available on the Bay which is a great spot on a sunny afternoon.  The place looks nice.

We started with the Cebiche Clasico which was Halibut in a wonderful lime and habanera marinade with red onion and corn.  My only complaint about this dish was that the halibut has a texture that is best served in small pieces or thin slices when raw.  This dish had hunks of halibut.  Nevertheless the fish was quality and the marinade was delicious.  We also had the empanadas del mar.  These were stuffed with shellfish and what seemed to be yellow cheese.  They were pretty good.  Next I had the grilled, skewered octopus on herbed mash potatoes.  Out of everything this was the best this we had.  The octopus was young, fresh and tender and well grilled.  The dishes my wife had were bland and not worth mention.

The prices were high and the service was very slow and forgetful.  Since it was the Sunday afternoon crew and since their lunch menu is limited I will give La Mar one more chance, but next time I'll go for dinner.
author: Hale J.

description:
In my mind, it was going to be a perfect night. I was going out with a guy I liked who neither 
1. was in academia 
2. played kickball

Yes I tend to go for one or the other....don't ask. Anyway, so he said pick where you want to go! My roommate could not stop talking about Ebisu, so I suggested going there. Of course, the downtown Ebisu only does catering, so I was at a loss. We wandered around the embarcadero sq. but since this guy and I had already been to Osha we decided to head to the pier. He mentioned that he had been to La Mar before, so we decided to go there.

We go in, on a tuesday, and there was only room at the bar. That's fine, I had a whole octopus to stare at the whole time since we were seated right where they cut up the seafood. The server was super attentive and asked us if we wanted a drink. We each got a drink, and then proceeded to order the following

1. Ceviche chifa. He was deadseat on ordering a ceviche. I liked how they had a bunch to choose from. It was pretty good, best one I've ever had.

2. arroz jugoso. Wasn't anything to write home about. The sauce was kind of bland

3. lomo saltado. I was really disappointed. Their idea of fried potatoes were french fries that are less impressive than mcdonalds. i can cook better than the person who made this dish, and that isn't saying much. 27 bucks? good thing I wasn't paying

overall, decent food, great service, but not worth the price at all. Just makes me feel like we fell into a tourist trap. My best friend in college is peruvian, so I've had some home cooked peruvian meals and they were all better than the food I had here, except maybe the ceviche.
author: Ashley B.

description: Excellent restaurant.  Beautiful view, good food & nice staff.
author: Kathryn Y.

description:
The food was great..  We loved all the ceviches and the empanadas. The causas sampler was OK...some better than others.  I had a their house bloody mary which was very very good.  My main dish was the lomo saltado was very good also.  I thought they were a little skimpy on the meat but the flavors were excellent.  Loved the rice that came with it.  Must try their awesome rice pudding.  

My only complaint was that their waiters had no regards to cutting off our conversations.  Quite rude since I was with clients.

All in all a great meal.
author: Tommy N.

description:
Most of what I will say will be some form of "I am truly blessed in being able to say I've eaten here."

I came here for my company's holiday dinner and did I receive a treat. 

Every dish that we had, was better than the one before and it didn't seem like the food would stop coming. We had everything served family style (I'm not sure if this is the case with everyone) and had a great variety of dishes.

We started off with plantain and potato chips with three different sauces and moved on to the cebiche classico for the appetizers. I had never had cebiche in such big chunks, but there was no loss of taste here. I even threw down a slice of habanero for good measure. 

Next up were the tequenos de seco, lamb filled, deep-fried egg rolls. When I first saw these, I thought "Spring rolls? Really? Spring Rolls." I've eaten everything from lumpia shanghai to vietnamese egg rolls and anything in between, and these weren't too bad. I wouldn't have minded taking a shot at the more traditional empanadas, but that may have been a bit too cliche at a South American themed restaurant.

Now on to the meat. With the exception of chicken, I believe we had a smattering of most living things, land, sea, and sky inclusive. We were treated to chorillana (roasted thai snapper), atun,  and lomo saltado (essentially steak and potatoes, one of the signatures of Peruvian cuisine). I must highlight all of these not only because they were main courses, but all the care and precision that was put into their production.

The snapper was perfectly cooked, not really fishy, nor seafood mush. Atun, La Mar's take on seared Ahi Tuna succeeded where so many others fail. The outer rim of the fish was perfectly seared with peppercorns, yet not overly gummy or (fill-in other searing mistake here). As for the lomo saltado, if you are messing up steak and potatoes, you just shouldn't have it on your menu.

One of the best dining experiences I've ever had. Waiters were attendant and the food was delicious. More importantly, they kept the booze coming, which of course can make or break a meal. All together an experience like none other.
author: D L.

description:
First time trying this place for lunch and had mixed feelings about the place. The food was great, flavorful and in good portions. The Cebiche was refreshing.  

The ambiance is also refreshing with the blues and dark brown wood, Right on the Pier. A couple of gripes were of the service and therefore the 3 stars. First the Hostess was missing a lot and you would get straglers walking into the dining area, including us when we first walked in, looking lost as hell or just sitting anywhere they wanted. Once we were seated, the waitress took our order and was great, then as it got busier we were totally put to the backburner.   We wanted to try dessert but she never came back and so we just asked for the check, then she totally forgot and waited more tables, so I actually had to flag down the manager and have him get us the check.  If it wasn't for the food this place would get less stars.  
I'd go back, and i'll give the service the benefit of the doubt. Chalk it up to an inexperienced waitress......
author: Charles M.

description:
Just keep going!  

Every time I've been back to La Mar (several times since the first), they never fail to impress.

I measure all other civiche by their standard and it's a very rare occurrence for any to measure up.

Go. NOW.
author: MoMo D.

description:
Perhaps my dining habits are not up to snuff. Inelegant. Uneducated.

No matter the case, I felt that La Mar Cebicheria Peruana was too well-studied and too fussy to be "real". I coudn't shake the impression that a real Peruvian would look askew at the fussy plating and overblown presentation, let alone the prices.
author: Hunni B.

description:
What a gorgeous space! 

They start you off with freshly made chips and 3 dipping sauces. 

Halibut ceviche was yum especially the marinade itself which I slurped up like soup. Beef heart skewers a little rubbery (that's the nature of beef hearts), nice dipping sauce on the side. Wine flight...Chardonney...Argentina vs. California, was fun...Argentina won.
author: Bleep S.

description:
4.5  The perfect place for the rare hot SF day.  Outdoor seating is relaxing right by the water.  

The Cebiche Chifa is the one that I will be craving and have to go back for - citrus and heat complemented the Mahi Mahi well in this refreshing dish.  The tiradito nikei (thinly sliced ahi) was very tasty.  The salmon skewers were cooked perfectly with a delicious sauce.  The empanadas del mar were nothing special.  The food presentation makes you want to try everything.

The passion fruit pisco cocktail was tasty.  The crisp fried plantains and sweet potatoes with various sauces (the Peruvian equivalent to chips and salsa) was the perfect starter snack.  Too bad I didn't have room for dessert because there were some interesting options...next time.
The ambiance is bright, clean and warm with fun summer colors - very inviting.

It is pricey, with tip about $100 for lunch for two.  However, the fish is fresh and well prepared, the service is excellent and then there is the view of the bay.
author: s p.

description: A company with which our company does business hosted a meeting and reception there for their clients.   Never having bee there, I was pleasantly surprised and pleased with their service, ambiance, and food.  Although we did not order from the menu, the selections that they offered to us were very tasty.  The service was very good.  I would recommend this restaurant to any of my friends and colleagues.
author: Ray K.

description:
I was introduced to La Mar by a Peruvian friend who was visiting from out of town and happened to know the manager there.  I'd never had Peruvian before, and damn, did I enjoy it.  

While the food is slightly on the expensive side, it's worth the money.  I believe the chef for this place also has several locations in Latin America and is considered one of the best chefs in his cuisine.  The causas in particular are outstanding, as well as the lomo soltado.  

The ambiance and view are amazing - how can you beat a patio right on the Embarcadero, in the sun on a nice Saturday, drinking a Pisco?
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Ask me to eat Peruvian any day of the week and I will not object.

La Mar is super sexy and oh-so-hip.  I walked in and was immediately impressed with the openness of the layout and the buzz of blue lights serving as not-so-subtle touches to the bar.  [Inner voice says: "This is my kind of a place".]

I adore splashes of color and La Mar does a great job in decor.  Love the electric turquoise-colored chairs and the neon green and coral-colored menus.

And speaking of color, sweet Jesus do they know how to plate at this restaurant!  My dining companion + I shared the causas tasting menu and were totally blown away at how artfully and meticulously plated those little suckers were!  And oh were they delicious.  In retrospect, if I could've eaten any one particular dish over and over again that night, it would've been the causas.  Man.... 

I would definitely recommend La Mar as a sexy spot for a date who's open to try new + flavorful dishes.
author: Katie C.

description: The quinoa chaufa (vegetarian) was delicious. As was the inca-cola. Great food , and location - on the water.
author: Sunil M.

description: The ceviche here is divine. Yes, small portions, but savor it & drink your pisco in the sunshine & bliss is attainable. I usually come here at off hours during the weekend & have a pisco with some appetizers at the bar.  I have had dinner here once, I have to say it was good but not great, but there are so many things on the menu that I feel like I could try it again & get something delicious.
author: Lily R.

description:
I DIE.

sushi grade EVERYTHING with a treading-the-fine-line-between-tacky-and-classy decor make la mar the ultimate business lunch destination.  

DISCLAIMER: to avoid any potentially embarrassing moments in front of coworkers, avoid menu items starting with the word "pisco"

... not that i speak from experience or anything...
author: Mooni P.

description: My husband and I and two couples had an amazing dinner here last night. I tried everything, the Chilean wine was amazing and the server John/Jim gave us amazing service and suggestions. Very pricy but worth it for a special evening on the town!
author: audra d.

description:
Came here for dinner. Not only was the restaurant really pretty, the food was delightful, drinks were good and the waitstaff was hot. You really can't go wrong. 

We tried a little bit of everything--the ceviche was delicious! I had the mahi mahi asian-esque one. 

We also had the sea bass "sashimi" which I thought was only OK. The sauce was a little heavy for the fish.

The potato thing with tuna was good and had a kick. Really beautiful presentation...

Skirt steak skewer, great flavors and cooked perfectly.

Empanadas with lomo saltado...outstanding! 

Finally dessert, the server was so sweet and gave us dessert because it was our birthdays. We had the picarinos(?) with honey.  Reminded me of some yummy donuts my grandma used to make when I was little.

Also had the dangerously good pisco punch and a potent after dinner drink.

All in all a lovely night and I can't wait to go back!
author: Lu E.

description:
Slow service and okay entrees muted this otherwise decent experience.

+Appetizers were delicious. The causas (causa camaron) were the favorite; the cebiche mixto didn't have too much fish.
+Picarones were also tasty, and a nice follow-up to the meal.
-My date and I had the Tallarin Saltado & Tacu Tacu, respectively. The former is dismissable and could've used a bit of heat, while the latter lacked seafood.
-Server was a bit awkward and slow. The awkwardness is okay, but slow is less tolerable.

Overall, a nice date place but there are plenty of other restaurants to visit first before making my way back.
author: Alvin Y.

description:
Not the La Mar I used to know... 
I discovered La Mar about 1 year ago and was a loyal customer until recently. Let's just say, I am very disappointed after my recent experience. The restaurant isn't what it used to be. I have a HUGE problem with the services- very inflexible. 
1) Small tables/crammed- host was not flexible and refused to  accommodate us to a normal sized table. 
We made a reservation for Noon during a weekend (the very first reservation for lunch). The host sat us at a tiny little table.  For party of 2, we were used to be able to sit at a table large enough for 4 people. When I asked if we could switch to one of the large tables as all of the large tables were available at that time, I was told NO and these were reserved for larger party. 

Of course, the so-called larger party didn't arrive until 1 pm (we were about 2/3 done with our lunch) and there were plenty of other "large tables" available to accommodate these people. 

I don't understand why La Mar is so inflexible to  accommodate its customers, given the prices they charge and more importantly, restaurant is a commodity business and their customers have ZERO switching cost. I guess I should be happy that we weren't told to hurry up and finish our food like one of the other reviewers. 

2) Portion is becoming smaller and prices have gone up vs. 6 months ago. 

Like I said, I was a loyal customer for almost a year.. loyal enough for me to notice remarkable differences in portion and prices. For example, the size of the Ceviche Tasting is about 2/3 of what it used to be and $2 more. Yes, $2 is nothing, but $2+much smaller portion= not a happy customer.
author: Rong S.

description:
Pisco sour, mojito, sangria... Oohh-yahh!

The drinks here are great.  

Foods good.  We've order two sets of samplers, plus some grilled mahi and mushrooms.  

The service is great.  Very attentive.  Good ambiance... and we brought our 5 yo with us for an early celebration of mother's day in peak Saturday dinner hour... and the staff was very hospitable.  [we take our 5 yo to more fine dining restaurants and exotic vacations]

We closed the night out with some desserts... rice pudding was a thumbs up.  The sorbet was too sweet, according to my other half.

Overall, a definite thumbs up and will drop by again.
author: Eddie T.

description: Maybe our expectations were high, but we were not impressed. The price is acceptable for the ambiance and location, but portions are small so be prepared to order seconds or be hungry 2 hours later. It was a good experience, but is definitely not on the top of my list to try again.
author: Ricky C.

description: i was here for happy hour ,  food is ok but service is so horrible.    i dont think im comging back.
author: Oz Z.

description:
Bloody Lorcho, how I miss you!!!! Other pisco cocktails will have to become my new best friends.

*The Experience*:
I generally come and sit in the bar area during the afternoons to grab a drink with friends, but it always ends up that by the time we finish two or three cocktails we are all ready to nosh. Even though you popped in for just one drink because you have plans later to eat at the Ferry Building, you'll end up ordering a few appetizers and ceviches. Unless you hate pisco, you can't help but have more than one $10ish cocktail. The drinks are wonderfully mixed, the bartenders friendly, the bar area is inviting with long tables, stools, tall windows with light streaming through, and the view of the city's buildings and people walking/running by...if you get bored of your friends, there will always be something to see at La Mar's bar (also try out their awesome historic restroom for a piece of SF history). I've only come here once for an actual sit-down-made-a-reservation-for-4-kind of dinner and felt that La Mar is more of a lazy afternoon kinda place for me and my crew where we can get some bites to eat to tie us over so that we aren't starving when we are waiting in line for dinner somewhere else. 

I've also called to see if I could hold a bridal shower here because the space and the views are impressive. The staff here are so friendly and willing to work with allergies, etc. that I was disappointed I didn't end up using their venue and chefs for the party. Perhaps another time when I want to plan a party to impress out-of-towners with the great views of San Francisco from La Mar, I will call them back again and wait for their promptly-returned and very professional call. 

*The Food*:
As I've written in another post, I'm a sucker for ceviche and La Mar's ceviche satisfies my ceviche-taste-buds. There are also these yummy causas...whipped potato thingies...In full honesty, I'm usually a little tipsy when the food comes so I can't really remember anything specific about the food except: (a) I inhale the ceviche because the seafood mix is so delightfully fresh and wonderful to my pisco-laden tongue, and; (b) the causas are the fanciest mash potatoes I've ever eaten while drunk. 

When I was here for dinner we ordered a whole mix of foods like beef, fish curry and the same drinking appetizers I always end up getting. I was surprised that some of the "Peruvian" dishes tasted like someone was experimenting with asian-fusion. I guess I shouldn't be surprised since Peru has had a large share of Asian immigrants, but in my drunken state it just didn't really hit the spot...was it Peruvian? Asian? Can I just get another drink?

*Would I Eat Here Again?:
When my beloved Bloody Lorcho was at this place, I would've said , "Hell yea!" But since the bar no longer makes that delicious, spicy, bloody mary with pisco and cut up baby octupus that is known as the Bloody Lorcho, I can't really say, "Hell Yea!" It's more of a "Ok, sure!" The feeling is I'm more than happy to go if friends make the suggestion, but wouldn't really think to suggest La Mar for a night out. I would take people from out of town for the views and use of space, but I would only think of it if we've exhausted other cuisines and restaurants in the city.
author: Patricia S.

description:
Peruvian food isn't really my thing, but La Mar blew my socks off.

Not only was the food incredibly tasty, but the cocktails were INSANELY delicious and the ambiance was relaxing and not too loud...even with a crowded restaurant. I took some co-workers and executives, and everyone unanimously praised La Mar for its food and service.

A superb culinary experience.
author: David P.

description:
A friend was in town and wanted to eat Peruvian. He was recently in Lima and attempted to go to the La Mar Cebicheria Peruana there, but said it was WAY too crowded and couldn't get in. He was elated to find out that we had the same restaurant here. And it would be interesting to compare the two places. 

We arrived really early since everyone has said they had to wait so long for their food. The hostess gave us the "We're clearing the tables now" speech. Yeah right... So we went to the bar and grabbed a drink while waiting to be seated. I guess we were lucky since we only waited about 10 minutes for our table. But we were not seated by the window like I asked. Oh well. 

I started with the Scallops and octopus in ají rocoto emulsion with cilantro and Peruvian corn. It was wonderful. The flavors went very well together and the corn was GREAT! For my entree I had the vegetarian risotto. The flavors were good, however this was not risotto and the rice was WAY undercooked. Couldn't finish it. My friend ordered the "lomo saltodo" which he says is his favorite peruvian dish. It's Traditional Peruvian style stir-fry of sautéed beef tenderloin, onions, tomatoes, cilantro, soy sauce, garlic, aji amarillo with potato fries and rice. He took a few bites, but didn't like it. So I guess that was a miss too. Overall, he said the place in Lima was defintely better, but that was to be expected anyway.

Service wise. It's not bad, but there is still much left to be desired. Our server with pretty absent the entire time. 

The space though large and beautiful, is a wide open, lightly decorated space therefore it is EXTREMELY LOUD inside. This is not a date place in ANY WAY. This is more of a business dinner location. 

I will be back, but next time I think I'll just sit at the cebiche bar.
author: Jen D.

description:
Happy Hour!  Pisco sours are awesome, so is the sangria (though a bit sweet).  They have Hinano beer!  

Empanadas are amazing (we got the sampler), actually all the food we ordered was great.  

Really beautiful restaurant, and great bar area.  Nice date place or to take out of towners.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I was having trouble deciding between a two and a three star review.

Their Pisco Sours are great. You can also get a good one at Pisco on Market Street if you don't want to be at a sitdown place. At La Mar I recommend the one with the passion fruit infusion, very nice. The drinks deserve 4 stars.

Our waitress was ok. She seemed annoyed when we were asking questions about the menu. Wasn't super attentive. We were entertaining friends from New York and she didn't go out of her way at all. She seemed to slap on a friendly disposition as soon as the check arrived as if we were supposed to give her a big tip for being friendly at the end. The service deserves 3 stars.

Food. This was just disappointing. I'm sorry, but I think Fresca is much better for Peruvian cuisine. The portions were incredibly small and expensive. None of us were impressed. I would go back if the food was great. It wasn't. It was just ok. The food deserves two stars. 

So the average appears to be more of a three star review, but the overall experience was a two. Wouldn't go back.
author: Gina M.

description:
A+ Amazing location. Love sitting outside looking onto the pier.
Food is OK. The NYC location is better (for some reason, I haven't put my finger on it. The one in Lima? Don't know.  :)
Location/Decor: 28/30

Food is OK-to-good. Their specialties they do as well as a restaurant should.  It really just feels over priced by about 20-30%. 
Food: 22/30

From the hostess who seats people in random order to the waiter who speaks too quickly to possibly be understood, to the bussing service who forgets knives: Not bad, just spacey. 
Service: 18/30

Still a decent enough place...with your out-of-town guests who are not foodies *and* you can't get a reservation at nearby Slanted Door or Il Cane Rosso. Much better than nearby Waterbar or Waterfront restaurants.
author: george o.

description: My most favorite restaurant in San Francisco!! All the ceviche dishes and also the beef heart skewers are absolutely amazing! Drinks and service is very good as well! La Mar t is a "must go to" restaurant for all couples and families!
author: Candice B.

description:
Love love love this place.

1. Complimentary chips: amazing! Love the 3 dips that come with it. There are different types of chips, I believe some are sweet potato, regular potato, and plantains.
2. Cebiche tasting: my favorite thing to get at the restaurant. Very fresh seafood and great flavor.
3. Empanadas tasting: really crisp and light and full of flavor
4. Key lime pie desser: was fantastic! Very light and tasty without the lime taste being too powerful.
5. Rice pudding: really wasn't a fan on of this one. Pretty tasteless and the texture wasn't smooth.
6. Chocolate bread balls (I don't know the actual name): were pretty good, it's dark chocolate with a sorbet.
7. Dungeness crab potato: this was probably not worth the $14, it was 3 very small pototo bites with crab on top. The taste was pretty bland, and the quantity was too little as well.

The place also has great decor and overlooks the bay. Make sure to make a reservation for this place. Thought it's pretty big, the tables fill up fast.
author: Linda J.

description: Nice location in SF by the Ferry buiding on a pier. There is a parking lot on a pier next door $10 for two hours. We didn't have reservations, walked in on a Friday night, it was packed. The  hostess told us 30 minutes for a table. There is a decent sized bar as you walk in so we sat there and ordered a drink while we waited. Once seated in the main restaurant my friend ordered the halibut ceviche starter which was very tasty. For main course I ordered the catch of the day which was a Halibut, cost $18. I had originally had my eye set on a catch of the day on another part of the menu and the price on that dish was $30, but the waiter indicated it was cod. I asked the waiter if the $18 one was a main course he said yes without any further info. When the dish arrived it was only ONE SMALL skewer with a few pieces of fish on it .. I was starving and rather perturbed that he hadn't mentioned the portion sizing and there was no indication on the menu. Food was tasty and ambiance was nice so I may return, but frankly there should have been some idea from the waiter/menu how small the main course dish was ..
author: Alex W.

description: I've been here a couple times for a birthday party and this past Valentine's weekend.  There were 11 of us.  We ordered a bunch of appetizers to share and then each had our own entrees.  The food is very fresh with a great presentation.  Eating here is like a party in your mouth.  It's likely you'll try something new here.  They keep your water glasses full, the wine and champagne flowing.  The server is very attentive to opening the wine when the entrees arrive for food pairing.  This place also has great ambiance- a cool blue lighting scheme.  It's also full of energy.  -just a fun place to go with a big group or with your friend
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Love this place. Went there for lunch with my boyfriend. Enjoyed the environment and food. The natural lighting and bright colors contrasted by dark wood made the place feel authentic to Peruvian culture. The service was good and the food even better. While eating the empanadas, I felt that I was actually eating in Peru. I've been to Peru once and La Mar is dead on with the taste and texture of the dish. Would definitely go back on another day in the city.
author: Sarah F.

description: Exceptional look... festive and beautiful and on the water!  Terrific, tasty, satisfying and not too heavy food...I love all the ceviches and plalntain chips and salads....a fave!  Great service here, and fun to surprise friends from the other coast with such an elegant yet cool place.
author: beatrice b.

description:
Oh my!  Delicious Peruvian food in the States!  I've been to Peru and also to the La Mar in Miraflores, Lima.  This didn't disappoint.  The pisco sour's are awesome, I had like 4 of them.  The bartender I talked with at the beginning knew nothing about the different types of pisco they offered and didn't understand me when I ordered a Pisco sour with a special type of Pisco, and gave it to me in a shot glass.  Once I explained it to him, he made it with the special type of pisco, but it came out to $14!  Wow.. a little bit overpriced so I stuck to the well pisco after which isn't as smooth but still good.  Next time, train your bartenders better if you are trying to open a Peruvian restaurant.  I also only met 1-2 peruvian people working there.  My waiter was from Venezuela and the bartender was American.  Not as traditional but they still do a good job.
  
The Ceviche did not disappoint.  I got the Mixto.  It was tender and the sauce was perfect, but very spicy.  I loved the plantains they give you with the sauces at the beginning as well.  We also had the causa tasting which was really good but I didn't know if wouldn't be hot.  I told the waiter that my friend didn't like spicy foods and some of it was spicy as well.  Other than that the tuna one really shined!  DO NOT go to Limon or Fresca anymore, there is NO COMPARISON to the ceviche here.  Last time I went to those places, the ceviche was so chewy I couldn't even swallow it.  Here it is tender and cut perfectly.  The Octopus was some of the best I've ever had.  So juicy, tender and marinated to perfection.  I will be back.  Save me a table!
author: Mitch A.

description: This restaurant is a great place if you want a different dining experience.  Great ambience and vibe, restaurant is airy and hip, but not too loud.  They take reservations; see if you can coax the host/hostess into outside seating.  The cebiche classico was good, and so was the causa limena, but the lomo saltado entree took the cake -- it was a simple, yet flavorful traditional Peruvian dish that is guaranteed to satisfy.  Our waiter was Tobias, and he did a fabulous job explaining the unusual menu, as well as giving us suggestions on things to do while we were in San Francisco.  If you get a good waiter or waitress, you should have a great dining experience here.
author: Rob K.

description: If you are a foody and looking for a change of pace, this is a barely OK choice.  We did the samplers of cebiche, empanadas, and causa.  While the cebiches (sp?) were good, the 4 choices seemed like 2 in terms of flavors (way too much use of calimari?).  The empanadas and causas were totally boring and uninspired.  My wife loved the pisco punch and the pisco sour was just OK.  So, 2 drinks each and the 3 samplers with tip came to $150...a bit pricey in my view, but we did enjoy ourselves and the change of pace.  Worth it...not so much!
author: Howard B.

description:
This place is HUGE!!!  I run by this restaurant all the time and finally got to try it.  The fish is so fresh and the dining area is so spacious and bright.  

I tried the cebiche clasico and the leche de tigre is soooooo yummy!  I bet it would do well in any of their cebiches.  I swear I could have had the leche de tigre by itself as a cold soup.  Just be careful of the little slice of habanero that's just hanging out in it.  Husband ate it on a dare and it almost numbed him for the rest of the meal.

The causa limeno was a party in my mouth with so many different flavors that mingled and danced so well together.  The next item was the empanadas de aji de gallina - basically chicken empanadas.  It was flavorful and not too greasy.  

Our final plate was cau cau, which was scallops seared so perfectly and seated in a light broth.  It was satisfying and a nice end to our peruvian adventure.  Yum Yum!

I'll be sure to return since I have so many other items to try.  Can't wait!
author: Nina L.

description:
liked the cebiche, causas, empanada and picarones.

didn't like the anticucho beef and passion fruit cocktail. 

a tad overpriced but worth a visit.

full review w/gorgeous pix on my site.
author: N J.

description:
I would like to preface this review with the fact that my dinner at La Mar was on the company dollar. Translation: free food and booze always warm my heart. That being said...

This place rocked. We sat outside on the enclosed patio near the water. I thought it might get too cold, but it was quite the opposite (due to the scorching heat lamps that only have two settings - on and off). 

Overall:
- Warning. Plantain chips are super good, but so is the rest of the food... so don't over do it on the chips. -OR- Overdo it on the chips, but wear pants with a draw string. Your choice.
- Food was flavorful and interesting (try the cebiche clásico)
- The cocktails were imaginative and pretty (try the chicha tu ma!)
- Vibe and decor was calming, but hip and made me want to go to Peru real bad
author: Stefanie L.

description:
FABULOUS!

The location is great, and I really want to come back so I can enjoy the patio!

We ate in the main dining room, which was LOUD and active. Tables were really close together, which is great when you are sitting next to fun and interesting people - but not so great when you're sitting next to some A-Hole who had to shout over everyone...including his date *bleh* BUT I digress...

The food was so amazing. We had to try the sampler cebiche, and it did not disappoint. It was really hard to pick one of the four that I liked the most because they were all so good. The BF especially liked the fried "chips" and sauces that they serve before the meal. I was a big fan of the octopus skewers - they were delicious and not the least bit chewy.

They also pour a good strong drink - automatic +1 star in my book!
author: Christy L.

description:
Yes please!!!

After an impromptu stop for some cebiche this afternoon before the Giants game I became enamored with La Mar.  It's sits there  unassuming, next to the ferry building (in all its glory) with an inauspicious exterior.  The interior was quite chic with palette of teals and ocean blues. Textured against mango greens and Caribbean yellow hues.  

The restaurant is quite large for a restaurant in "the city" with a trendy bar which is next to a nicely open waiting area.  The ambiance was nice, unpretentious while remaining upscale and authentic.

 The food was great, I mean surprisingly good.  We had three kinds of cebiche; One was with Ahi Tuna and had Thai flavorings that had fantastic in flavor, another one was a cebiche classico, which was, normal, it was a classic cebiche.  It reminded me of going back to basics and executing something light, clean and delicious, then the third was by far the best tasting cebiche I have ever had.  It was made with halibut (considering the season just started, it was quite a beautiful quality).  This cebiche had flavors of grapefruit and lime, habanero chilis and sweet yam.  It was incredibly fresh and left me with a feeling of wanting more.  As if this wasn't enough they brought us fresh fried chips and plantains with three dipping sauces and some peruvian nuts that when paired with the liquid left over from the cebiche was texturally interesting while still emphasizing flavor.

  Service was funny, kinda clumsy (wasn't sure if it was because they didn't speak English).  Perhaps its funny, because this place is eerily authentic.  I was completely satisfied with my experience and will be here again.

5 stars!
author: Shaun C.

description:
We had our first taste of Peruvia food at Al Mar last Saturday. That was an awsome dinner.
the waiters were so friendly and helpful that it was really easy for us to order something that would suit all of us: picky, hungry and baby !
and no regrets, our taste buds got all excited with a wonderful ceviche and then we dug in our salads, tuna, skewers and I had a great tenderloin in veggies and special sauce.
we shared a big table with another family and that was also very friendly.
we also tried the sorbets and it was a great conclusion to our fiest.
not so kid friendly, but our little one enjoyed her chicken and my rice.
and there is a parking lot just across the street, so it is very easy to get there.
author: stephanie m.

description: We were there for brunch in the afternoon. The food and the view of the ocean are so amazing. It was 81 degree, so prefect to sit at patio and enjoy summer in San Francisco
author: Patti J.

description:
La Mar is NOT a place to eat if you are in a budget. And if you are Peruvian (like me) you should calm your nerves a little before going there and paying 10 times more for the smaller version of the same food you pay back in Peru. Now, with that said, La Mar is one of my favorite restaurant experiences in San Francisco. 

I have been there several times and even celebrated my birthday there with first time Peruvian eaters. The food tastes like your mom's food (at least like my Mama), the service is excellent (Pamela is always The Best) drinks are... well, after trying them all I still have to find one that I do not like. But the main reason for me to go back to this restaurant, is the variation and uniqueness of their menu. You can find the same dishes we (Peruvians) eat at special occasions as well as the corner food you eat after a night of drinks with friends. 

Excellent setting and on a sunny day I highly recommend eating on the waterfront part.  

The only reason why I gave them 4 stars instead of 5 is because the size of their portions are too small for the price of their food.
author: Luis G.

description: Great news: another restaurant I can cross off the list of ever having to go to again. My favorite: the snotty dirty-blonde hostess who wouldn't seat us at one of the 5 empty tables in the shade because they were all reserved for a banquet. Of course, by the time we finished, none of those tables had been used. It probably would have taken almost a minute for a busboy to clean our table if they so desperately needed it for the banquet that had yet to appear. So thank you: my list of SF restaurants is one shorter now! I will say that the waiter was attentive, but the food itself was not remarkable enough to wipe out the bad taste left in my mouth by the tight-bunned hostess.
author: Fred L.

description:
Down to business:  La Mar is in a gorgeous space overlooking the water on the Embarcadero, and they serve pretty amazing food.  It's hipster, without the pretension.  

Not being a fan or cerbiche, I skipped the appetizers and went straight for the lomito saltado, which was sweet, rich and flavorful.  It was hard to share it with my husband.  (Ok, I didn't share it with my husband.)

Service was friendly, welcoming and warm, albeit slow.  But with the crowd of people we had at our table, I'm surprised we were served within an hour.  It was controlled chaos on a Friday night.

The downside to  La Mar is the price tag.  It's prohibitively high for me to eat here, and therefore, I probably won't be back any time soon.  But seeing how they filled their humongous space by 8:00 p.m., I don't think they'll miss my business.
author: Kristina R.

description:
My favorite restaurant du jour.  Creative, diverse menu.  Been 4 times in the past 2 months and haven't had a bad meal yet.  One waitress was a little lacking in the knowledge of the menu and ingredients or at least wasn't interested in sharing them with us but the food was still great.  Very good pisco sours (a touch sweet but I still order every time).  The 'chips' are out of this world.  

Highly recommend; ambience, view, interesting menu, fresh ingredients, very good staff.  Go go go!
author: T B.

description:
Stellar.

I have never been one to find myself with a hankering for ceviche. Sushi, yes? Red Lobster, duh. But ceviche school of fish prep is a type that I am not all that familiar with... until I came here for dinner last week. Wow! Talk about cevichetastic!

We tried the ceviche taste and there were so many different palate pleasing combos that it was near impossible to pick one that I liked over the other. So fresh n so clean, clean, these creations were awesome! 

We also explored the land animal offerings in the form of the lamb shank. All I can say about that dish is holy christ! Falling off the bone, totally delectable and insanely good. Seriously, come for the ceviche, stay for the lamb and thank me later, because yes, it is that spectacular!

Also, bonus points for the old Ferry building bathroom. Loved the little red stall and the super cute old school toilet. Adorable. Yeah, i like bathrooms, what of it!
author: Stephy S.

description: The drinks and the cebiche were awesome! I would definitely come back again.
author: H. A.

description:
When I first arrived at La Mar on the Embarcadero, for a moment I thought I had stepped into the restaurant of an exotic hotel in Los Angeles or Las Vegas. Surely we weren't in San Francisco anymore? Tall ceilings, palm fronds and a low-lit lounge beckoned. But first, I took a sharp turn into the bar, rowdy with beautiful people having a rollicking good time.

I stepped into the chaos and ordered the Pisco Punch while I waited for the birthday girl and her entourage to arrive. Ummm... dangerous. Sweeter than a margarita and more drinkable, by the time our full dinner party had arrived, I was two sheets to the wind. Did that stop me from ordering a second drink? No. I tottered over to our table for 20, balancing my Cholo-politan carefully.

An intoxicating blend of pisco and passionfruit guava, it was the perfect palate prep for the smorgasbord of yellowtail, halibut, tuna and calamari ceviche. The octopus appetizer looked dubious, but it ended up being the stand-out dish of the night! Tender and breaded, it's the fried chicken of the sea. My ahi tuna entree was a worthy follow-up, too beautiful to eat, served on a bed of sweet potato and drizzled in a plate-licking-good sauce.

I still can't decide whether I liked the cocktails or the food better. Hmmm... luckily, I'll never have to choose between the two.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I was blown away by my meal here.

I didn't realize I was a fan of peruvian food, but the preparations at La Mar are made to perfection and simply delicious.

We ordered a bunch of dishes to share, my favorite being the cebiche nekei (tuna & avocado in a japanese miso broth) and the causas limena (dungeness crab salad and avocado in a potato-thingy).  The menu is a bit confusing and intimidating, so take your time and ask lots of questions.

Their drink menu is also impressive, so take a cab.
author: Zuzzi E.

description: Food was great.  What brought this down to a 3 was the horrible service.  Waited 15 minutes for dessert menu then another 15 minutes to say no to dessert and that we wanted the check.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Great location, big fun space, but mediocre food and service.

We were there on  Tuesday at 8pm and it was quite crowded. Got seated right away but took about 15 minutes for our drinks to arrive after we ordered them. We ordered the ceviche sampler, which was good, and the causas tasting menu, which looked beautiful but was surprisingly bland in taste--I wish we hadn't ordered it. We should have noticed when the server was less than enthusiastic when we ordered the causas but was very happy when we ordered the ceviche.

The ceviche and causas took so long that by the time we were done with them it was about 9:15. We had ordered entrees, and by the time it got to 9:50 we told our server to cancel our order and bring us the check unless we got them immediately. I mean, seriously, almost 2 hours to get to the entrees? Every stage of our dinner was slooooowwww, and when we suggested that the kitchen was off in their timing, our server seemed relieved that we realized it wasn't his fault and hinted that this wasn't an unusual occurrence.

Frustratingly long service (really, 15 minutes for a cocktail? Almost 2 hours to get to the entree??) and just average food for a high-profile restaurant means that I will never return nor recommend this restaurant to anyone. I doubt it will be around in 2 years unless it can survive solely on non-repeat customers like tourists.

I'm very disappointed because I have a business colleague who travels to Peru a lot, loves the food/drink there, and I was looking forward to taking him to La Mar. Now I won't. Very disappointing.
author: Brent E.

description:
Came here on a whim one Sat night. There were no seats available in the restaurant but luckily they had seating at the bar with full menu service. 

As soon as we sat down, our server greeted us with a complimentary pisco sour shot. Apparently the night we dined there was a holiday in Peru, thus they were celebrating with us! What a nice start to a pleasant and delicious evening! 

So we started with the Cebiche Tasting which I highly recommend as a great way to try all the different cebiches! This included MahiMahi, Ahi Tuna, Halibut and MahiMahi with calamari & octopus. All of it was extremely fresh and tasty! If I had to choose one to get again, I would get the Ahi Tuna. We also tried the Tiradito Tres Ajies, which is the sea bass sashimi. This was also incredibly fresh. However, I thought the Cebiche Tasting was a better "starter". 

As for our meal, I got the Arroz Jugoso (seafood in juicy arborio rice) and my date had the Cordero (braised lamb shank). The Arroz Jugoso reminded me of a seafood paella but more soupy. The seafood again was fresh and really good. The arborio rice was cooked to perfection! My date seemed to really enjoy his lamb as well. By the time dessert rolled around, we were too stuffed! But I'll definitely be back and hopefully have room to eat the desserts since, based on the food, I'm sure it'll be divine!
author: Kitty L.

description:
Ugh, this place is not nearly as good as I had hoped. The food was taken down several notches on the flavor scale - maybe to cater to a bland american palate?

I was super disappointed with the aji amarillo sauces and the causas.  

The ceviche was great and so was the lomo salado but I left with my (high) expectations dashed.

-------------------
Before eating there: 

Imagine my true happiness when, while dining at my favorite restaurant in Santiago de Chile, I find they have a branch in San Francisco!! 

I could barely contain myself, so i ordered another pisco sour and dug into my ceviche.

Peruvian food is my new favorite and La Mar does an excellent job, no matter what country you're in.
author: Krissy M.

description: We went back 2 days later for drinks an appetizers. This time we tried the causal which were delicious but the Aji de Gallina Empanadas were a disappointment - the chicken was dark meat, not shredded but in pieces and didn't taste close to what an Aji de Gallina is supposed to taste like. That is the only dish we had not liked. Still refused to pay $32 for Lomo Saltado so I haven't tried it yet.
author: Daniella C.

description:
Care for some ceviche? Or as this place calls it...cebiche. YES yes and YES.

Was lucky enough to be taken here for lunch with a wonderful vendor on a quarterly visit. It was Friday at noon and it was crowded, yet we had no issues with service or our table, thankfully!

The place is cooooool As in oceanic cool... lots of blues and simplistic whites, the flowers are minimalist as well, our group of ladies loved their wonderful arrangements strewn about.

But the food was where it was at. Tried three different types of cebiche's (causa, clasico and another one I can't recall!) and I am in LOVE. The portions were not huge on anything, but we did not leave hungry. I am more than happy to have a smaller portion of a flavorful dish than a large portion of a bland one.

Tried empanadas and what looked like a monstrous crab wonton which were both good but not fabulous. Split two amazing cebiche's with a pal, and still had room for dessert.

Now I've got a sweet tooth... and it was torn on what it wanted to finish off the meal. I ended up with the bunelos aka beignets (who knew they meant the same thing?!)...and at first glance they were underwhelming. Soft donuty round puffs with cinnamon sugar...and some ice cream. That's it...okay, well I press down on them with the fork to cut them and out squirts CHOCOLATE...in all it's dark bittersweety glory. Score! These things were amazing. 

Also the pumpkin and maple dessert is quite tasty, kind of like little fried doughnuts with what looks like chocolate sauce but is really a thick honey syrup. 

Say YES when they ask you if you want dessert. Try the varieties of cebiches. Can't wait to return for dinner.
author: Mara T.

description:
I've been eagerly awaiting the opening of La Mar for some time - I love cebiche (or ceviche, or sashimi, or crudo...hell, whatever you want to call it) and the location can't be beat. Clearly I'm not the only one because the place was packed on Thursday evening, despite being one of the biggest restaurants that I've been to. So packed in fact that we waited over an hour past our 8pm reservation time. I really hate waiting that long with a reservation but understand that a new restaurant might need some time to find their timing so I can't be all that upset. Plus it gave us a chance to try some of the fantastic Pisco based cocktails (try the Cholopolitan and thank me later)

When our table was finally ready we were led past the beautiful cebiche bar to a large table with a nice view of the bay. The patio wasn't open yet but should be a fantastic spot for a bite to eat on a nice evening. On to the food...I thought everything was pretty good but a bit over priced considering the portion size. I have no problem paying for fresh ingredients (especially seafood) but don't enjoy laughably small portions.
The cebiche sampler was good but careful, a few were really spicy! The grilled octopus skewers were fantastic as was my entree, the chorrillana (pan fried Alaskan halibut) I also had a bite of the lomo saltado which was great.

It's a sexy space with views for days and a lot of interesting dishes on the menu. I wouldn't hesitate to return to La Mar, although I probably wouldn't go back starving unless I'm with a rich uncle or sugar mama. BTW I'm accepting applications for both.
author: phil h.

description: We took my dad here for his birthday - it was his first experience with Peruvian food and everything was very fresh and really tasty!! We had a great time. My mom, who is vegetarian, found a lot of thing to eat as well. The cebiche nikei was really good, as was the classico. We got the empanadas (chicken and tamalito verde), both were yummy. I can't remember what else we got but my main dish was a traditional peruvian rice dish and it was really great!
author: Ruchi M.

description:
This was my first time with Peruvian food..first thought..Very Different..and Different Good :) Went here for dinner on a Friday evening with my husband's cuz and her bf..As they said and I quote..They were the drinkers we were the drivers ;)
To start with:
Loved the decor..totally loved the blues..I like such little details, the place mats were a nice blue, the chairs matched them..very nice!
Our server was friendly umm but not flexible at all, if I may say. I was a veg that day...yeah I have days when I eat non-veg and veg :P..So well I asked the server, if I could have one of their rice dishes Veg instead of the meat..Come on this is SF..what do you if Vegans walk in the door..I am not even vegan and I am a little flexible on the food too...I asked him if he could throw in a bunch of mushrooms..but all he said was a stern NO :|
Well OK..so I went ahead and got 1 of their cous cous appetizer and their mushroom Espenada..both were YUM!

The complimentary plantain and potato chips are good..but the sauces it comes with are AWESOME...Loved the one with peppers...fell in love with those sauces..and I am going to attempt making them soon at home!

My husband's cousin ordered the purple potatoes which she liked...but the couple loved their drinks..So I know this place is good for drinks..maybe try their happy hour, like everyone else suggests.

All in all a good way to get introduced to Peruvian food...The food is good, of course it is expensive..but I would give it a second try on one of my Non-veg days ;)

Food wise it does get 4 stars, but I am taking 1 star off because they don't even want to try accommodating Veggies..umm not cool :)
author: Jyoti C.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here a couple weeks ago, we were just walking by, and stopped in around 10:30 or 11:00am. We were asked if we had a reservation... mind you the place was 90% empty... the hostess said she'd see what she could do?? We were asked if we wanted indoor or outside, it was a nice day so we went for an outside table, big mistake, we both got sun burnt. 

The food was good, but very small portions, and a bit pricey. Had we know a coffee was $4.00 we would have never ordered it!   I call that gouging. 

When we left, I notice more people had come in, so now it's a few minutes before noon and they have about 40% of the tables filled... go figure! 

I doubt we'll be going back...
author: C J.

description:
Given the fact my dining companion Katie C. got ROTD for her review of La Mar, I don't really think I will even try to top her assessment.

I loved everything about this place. Food, location, decor, presentation, service and drinks. I give it all an A without a single complaint.

GO.
author: Derek B.

description:
Private party with 15 girls on the patio on a Sat night. Here's the verdict:

Great if you like
-large fancy restaurants and bars
-to drink
-seafood
-to spend a lot of money
-like good service
-single
-like to be "seen"

Bad if you are
-pregnant (you can't eat a lot of this raw seafood and such)
-vegetarian only 3 dishes for vegetarians
-are frugal during a recession
-a large group -- service is slow and the event coordinator screwed up my meal. 
Being vegetarian and pregnant, I ended up eating just salad and still paid $20 for this. 

I don't think I would come back. However if I were single and loved seafood this might be a good place to hang out.
author: Christine P.

description:
Walking into this spacious warehouse turned gorgeously decorated Miami vice vibing white walls, club atmosphere blue ambiant lighting, you knew you were in for a treat! The decor was simplistic, but impactful, the blue chairs & lights bouncing off the white and glass surroundings.  We were promptly seated by the window facing the water and the view was pretty fantastic of the boats/yachts bobbing on the water. 

We started with some pisco sours (as pisco is THE drink of Peru) & though they came out a bit more sour than to our liking the 1st round, they were totally gracious and willing to work with us on making the perfect pisco sour by the 2nd round =) Our waiter Jesse was a complete sweetheart, very attentive, answering all our questions and patiently waiting by to explain our dishes to us and bringing us extras of whatever we needed/wanted.  

We started out with the Cebiche Clasico: California Halibut and red onions in habanero pepper leche de tigre with Peruvian corn and yam ..the taste is just explosive.  Every mouth watering bite is filled with different textures and spices, the halibut melts in your mouth.  The broth it swims in is so deliciously tasty that you just want to pick up the bowl and slurp up the rest. 

Next we had the Causa Tasting: a beautifully prepared 4-some of:

*Dungeness Crab w/avocado purée, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo Huancaína sauce with basil cilantro oil

*Sautéed Mahi Mahi, Limeñan escabeche with quail egg, avocado puree, ají amarillo Huancaína sauce and crispy parsley, 

*Purple potato causa, Ahi Tuna, Nikei sauce, avocado puree, and rocoto Huancaína sauce, and finally the 

*Purple potato causa, artichokes, asparagus, avocado and tomato confit with basil cilantro oil.  

I can't even begin to pick my favorite because they were all SO delicious in their own right. Each one has a distinct flavor that separates it from the rest, just the right portion so that you get a taste, but doesn't fill you up as you want to save room for more!

our next dish was the Atun: Peruvian spiced and seared Ahi Tuna, purple corn sesame sauce, yams, pineapple Chalaca 

The Ahi came perfectly seared with just the right amount of pepper crusting, the ahi itself soft, melty and fresh.  The yams were soft, sweet and went perfectly with the chalaca sauce.  

Next we finished up with the trio of homemade peruvian fruit sorbet, and these tiny little bites of heaven that come with your espresso. I have no idea what they are called, but get the espresso just so you can try these little babies.  I think i nearly orgasmed as it touched my mouth. WHOA NELLY! 

Fabulous dinner all around, service was attentive, waiters are eye candy, grab good company, some pisco sours &  plan to give your senses a treat!
author: Lulu C.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE their hip Miami chic atmosphere!  Food was just okay.  Tired the cebiche sampler, had a bite of the octopus skewers and the dish that was called something Nikei (2nd generation in Japanese).  I think it yellowtail in sesame oil and sugar/soy sauce then placed atop purple potatoes.  I had the Aji de Gallina which wasn't at all what I expected.  Had a better version of this in Denver (no joke), just chicken and potatoes in a cream sauce served with rice.  

BUT the cocktail menu makes up for the lack of oomph in their food.  Between our little group we definitely tried most of the cocktail list.
author: Shiho F.

description:
My boyfriend and i went to la mar for his birthday on May 8, 2012 and boy was it an experience. We had been wanting to go here for a long time and since it was his birthday we decided to go. (you can check my other reviews if you think i dont know what im talking about)
we arrived around 3:40 and we sat at the bar for happy hour since the restaurant was not open and had a couple of drinks. There was only one bartender at that time. He was very nice and made us some good cocktails. We ordered a few appetizers as well since we were a little bit hungry. After a few minutes all the waiters and bartenders started arriving and the guy who was making our drinks i guess became the bus boy because two new guys took over. 
 Everything started to go downhill from there. Our new bartender decided to give us the bill when we didnt even ask for it. I thought that the first guy who attended us was going to leave so we paid but kept drinking. I had ordered a pisco sour to our new bartender which he completely forgot about and i had to ask for it again. Then we ordered some calamari which by the time we got it was cold. Then we ordered  chicharrones.  They were taking a pretty long time to get to us so i made a comment to my boyfriend about it and the bartender overheard me and ran to get them. i guess he forgot them too. By the time they got to us they were very very cold and we sent them back. Sadly they never came back!
 Since the dining room was open we  paid the bill (including the chicharrones we didnt have) and moved to the dining area. I have to say that our experience was much better service wise. Our waiter was very nice and didnt forget our order or drinks. The food was NOT that great. It was good but not as good as people have made it seem and also very expensive for the portions. 
 To top it all off on our way out my boyfriend was looking for the restroom and i believe the manager (who was wearing a suit and a pink shirt) didnt even acknowledge him and damn near just passed by him like nothing untill my boyfriend asked him where the restroom was and he just pointed. 
Overall not pleased, not impressed. Stuck up bartenders and managers, forgeting my orders and just not friendly. Not going back.
author: J O.

description:
Great experience.
I have a taste for Peruvian and will be on the lookout from now on.
i am getting hungry just thinking about the meal.

this place is a must for SF!
author: Lino B.

description: Best pork belly sandwich I've ever tasted. Of come here just for that. The ceviches are bonus and equally delish. The bartenders are fun to watch and they engage in small talks if you sit in front of them.
author: G T.

description:
Delightful experience after just 1 pisco sour! The dash of egg white was a nice touch. Frothy but not overwhelming.

We munched on the Peruvian salted corn innocently thinking that it was safe - until later finding out that it was deep fried... we slowed down a bit :) 

The cebiche mixo was ai yai yai caliente but had a nice twist of flavors and once I tasted the perihuela - their fisherman style soup - it def calmed and comforted my taste buds. 

I'll be back!
author: Charlene A.

description:
Dined here again last night and it was even better than I remembered.

The bump up to 5 is solely due to the cebiche crudo. I would come JUST to eat that...good god, it was awesome.
author: Adrienne C.

description: My favorite Peruvian restaurant in the city. I love taking guests from out of town here, it has a very cool interior and setting right on the water.
author: Clay M.

description: Gorgeous location right on the Embarcadero and you really feel like you're on vacation since the restaurant has such an open tropical feeling. Loved the orange/blue/white color scheme and everything on the menu looked tasty. I got the ceviche clasico. Leche de tigre! Good refreshing heat and the halibut was really fresh and springy. I also got the lamb shank spring rolls with three different dippy sauces. Really well seasoned. The plaintain and potato chips that came at the beginning were also a nice treat. Would have loved to try a dessert, but next time!
author: Kevin L.

description:
Truly the taste of Peru.  What makes this a five-star place is the menu's finesse between tradition and sophistication.  The service was attentive and professional, the space was bright and inviting and well . . . the cocktails alone could have pushed this one to five-stars for me.

We stepped into the restaurant around the end of happy hour - right before the dinner rush on a Saturday.  We were seated right away at the cebiche bar.  Even with the rush of diners during our quick meal, the atmosphere and service did not suffer.

I enjoyed the pisco sours in South America while I visited there a year or so ago, but the mixologists here were even better than the real thing.

We had the cebiche clasico and lomo saltado.  The balance of flavors and textures in the clasico made my day and the lomo sautee was just perfect, brought me right back to the Southern Hemisphere.  The fried plantains and sweet potatoes were ridiculously addictive and perfectly complimented by the sauces.  Portions were fair and the food in its quality is really quite a value.

We basically had to eat and run, and only realized it halfway through our meal.  The server and captain were very understanding and ran our check right away - always a plus when a restaurant's staff can deal with its patrons' stupidity with such courtesy :)
author: Brian S.

description:
A few days after La Mar Cebicheria opened last year in SF, I went and was amazed at the quality of the food. 

I've been to the La Mar in Lima, as well as Astrid y Gaston, which is owned by the same people. Both restaurants in Lima served extremely good food, much better than the La Mar in SF.

Yesterday I went back to La Mar (the 3rd time) and I noticed that the food was not as good. The cebiches were ok, not great. I feel that the standard of cooking has gone down dramatically -- as if the kitchen is cutting corners rather severely. I think the original chef whom La Mar started with is gone? Is this correct? When they first opened, I would have given La Mar five stars. Now, only 3.

The prices are too high given what they are now serving so unfortunately I have to give this only 3 stars (the decor is superb and the pisco sour is still the best in SF). 

The dining room is extremely noisy so if there are only two of you, better to sit at the cebicheria counter (which is like a sushi bar).
author: Esme V.

description:
Establishing an upscale Latin restaurant (of any region) is a difficult task in and of itself. For the most part, you can get great Latin food (pupusas, tacos, ceviche, etc.) at many local hole in the wall places in SF at great bargain prices. To get people to pay a premium for items that they are not accustomed to paying is going to be difficult for customers to swallow (as evident in some of the reviews of people referencing portions and prices). On top of that, given the location (view along the water), you are going to pay another premium for the real estate lease (you should come to know this by now, if not, you have lots to learn).

Secondly, the concept of tapa-style restraurants is still relatively new or hard to come by for many. For one, tapas bars/restaurants are pretty lively and noisy - it's all about the ambiance and the people you're with.  If you don't like noisy places and you used that in your justification of a low rating here, then it's you're fault for not conducting your proper due diligence. Portion sizes (by definition) are small - if you haven't grasped that by now, well your fault again. 

All above mentioned info I just summed up for you should be common knowledge; if not, you'll sorely be disappointed all because of your lack of realistic expectations.

Now on to my review. The place itself is huge - bar area in the front on the right is great for drinks and appetizers; ceviche bar (like a sushi bar) on the left past the bar is great for light meals and small groups; formal dining area in the back is great for a nice sit down style meal with that special someone or small group wishing for a little less noise and slightly more privacy; and lastly the outdoor deck on the water is perfect for those nice, warm days/evenings.
