It was pricey, but I still loved it!  I read in my travel book that Gaston Acurio (chef of both this place and the restaurant I mentioned) would be opening a restaurant in San Francisco!  I hope it lives up to the hype!  I hear it opens mid-September :)
author: Alice M.

description: I've been wanting to try La Mar ever since a girl friend proclaimed it was one of her favorite restaurants in the city. Once I finally did, the stars could not have aligned better! Kevin H. had some Peruvian clients in town and as a thank you they took us out to dinner -- and wanted to come to La Mar. I was skeptical...Peruvians want to eat Peruvian food in San Francisco?! But it's a well regarded restaurant around the world. We started with Pisco sours. We moved on to albarino, ceviche and causas. I died. Then we had empanadas, fish, lamb shank, and lomo. I loved the slight asian influence in the dishes. The Peruvians then moved on to straight pisco after dinner. Yeah, that's when I could no longer hang. It's ok though, I had passion fruit beignets to keep me busy. Divine.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Meh. I had been twice to the La Mar in Lima, Peru and in comparison .... this one's rather disappointing. I had high expectations after my amazing meals in Lima.

My waiter also messed up my order and only responded with "Oh I'm sorry". I still didn't get what I wanted though ...

The ceviche that they did serve me was good but not mind-blowing. My arroz dish was also not that flavorful, rather dry. 

The only saving grace? The tender and flavorful anticucho.
author: Fiona C.

description:
Food - delicious. I tried the halibut and tuna cebiches and the arroz limeno...all three are highly recommended.

Drinks - had my first pisco sour...yum!

Only reason the place doesn't get five stars - the appetizers are a bit overpriced (or they could just give you more cebiche).
author: Katie Y.

description:
What a TOTAL disappointment.  My wife and I did enjoy the Cevice (we had the tasting option with 4 varities all of which were good).  However, everything else was below sub-par.

The service was non-existent which doesn't necessarily justify 2 stars but when you have to wait an eternity for underwhelming food at a premium price then that all adds up to a bad experience.  To sum it up, service was so bad I didn't even look at the dessert menu (and I rarely, if ever, miss dessert).

There are many better alternatives at more reasonable prices (Try Fresca).
author: Joshua J.

description: This place will always hold a special place in my heart. I fell in love with my darling here. The food had a lot to do with it. :) Everytime we revisit this place we order the same thing. Cebiche sampler, empanadas, causa tasting, and carne. It's an explosion off flavor. I love how fresh and creative all the dishes are. Even the decor in the place is very modern but inviting. The view is also a plus.
author: Ruth K.

description:
You can't find a better location than La Mar .. great place for drinks that overlooks the Bay. After going here for happy hour a couple times, I really wanted to try the food out so the fiance and I went here.

Best known for the leche de tigre - that ish is really good. Like a drug. However, everything is drenched in that so you lose the taste or freshness of the fish. We ordered your traditional peruvian dishes - cebiche, lomo saltado, etc. It wasn't too memorable. I think Limon is much more flavorful. La Mar is more about the drinks and ambiance - perfect for a group setting, not for foodies in seek of the next best thing.
author: buggy b.

description:
I give the Food  - 4.5 Stars
Service - No good

I'm giving this a lower star rating because even though the food was yummy, the experience was tarnished due to bad waiter service. I went there with a group of 6 and we ordered a lot of dishes to share and sample. The server was always MIA and we waited to extended periods with no dishes on the table.
author: Insi L.

description:
Mister B and I have dined at La Mar twice, and while we enjoyed the atmosphere and food, the service is bad enough to cause us to think again before next time.  

This place is big, spacious, very Caribbean-themed decor.  There is even a patio where you can soak up the sun on those rare days on the bay, but be sure to have a reservation (we tried w/out one and were denied).

Staff is a little awkward.  On our first trip we gave up trying to order a pre-dinner drink at the bar after about 10 minutes; there was also a very long wait between our order and the arrival of our ceviches, which was recognized by our server who comped us a delicious dessert.  Second time around, it seemed pretty dead at lunchtime on Saturday, but we were kept waiting for a while.  Our friends received not one but two wrong orders, and the server wasn't what I would call apologetic, he took the first dish back grudgingly, then told us to keep the second one for free.  

As for food, there are some hits and misses.  The grilled octopus is heavenly, most of the ceviche are good but the special ceviche a la chipotle is too saucy, which turned me off, though the taste was good.  Unfortunately the scallops were overcooked or undercooked but not right, somehow chewy.

Desserts are good and worth trying.  The wine list is also affordable and interesting, as are the cocktails.

I agree with many other reviewers in that they need to up their staff in terms of quantity and quality.
author: Aimee B.

description:
What a beautiful restaurant and a great addition to the SF waterfront!

Highlights of the meal were:
*sweet potato chips with 3 different dipping sauces!
*grilled squid - I eat a LOT of squid, and this was the most perfectly grilled squid I have ever had.  It was just soft enough to bite into on the first try, but chewy enough to retain that oh so lovely squid texture.
*the parihuela was tasty, and not a drop of soup went unfinished!  

We tried the ceviche sampler and the causa sampler of course, and they were both fairly good.  Drinks were too sweet for my taste, but they seem to be a hit to everyone else. The one complaint I have is the picarones--where was the sweet potato?  I know these weren't traditional picarones, but it would have been nice if the deep fried dough to potato ratio wasn't 9:1.

With such an extensive menu, I will definitely be returning to try more!
author: Jade H.

description:
Gorgeous views.  Decent food.  But horribly inefficient service.

Ordering drinks took 30 minutes.  Getting the wine list took 30 minutes.  Ordering our main course took 30 minutes.  Getting the picture?  

Food was A-OK -- solid ceviche, decent shaken beef, excellent chicken-thigh skewers (but VERY so-so braised lamb main course).  

But the wait staff  killed us.  Friendly, yes.  Responsive, no.  We had to ask for the heater to be turned on outside -- twice.  We never received the extra tartar sauce that we requested.  We had to ask for the wine list -- thrice.  

By the end, and with our new babysitter waiting at home, we ordered dessert and simultaneously paid the bill.

All in all, a 3+ hour meal that should have taken 2 hours.

Will I be back?  Methinks not . . . .  Fresca on West Portal is comparable food-wise, but not nearly as slow.  Yes, Fresca lacks the view, but also the frustration.
author: Rich H.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this place!

The food is so light and fresh and with every bite there's a party of flavours in your mouth. I recommend spoiling yourself and trying the samplers because you do not want to miss on all the variety of flavours and textures they have to offer like the empanadas, cebiches, and causas. 

The service is great and the atmosphere makes you feel so relaxed and mellow. It's right on the water and has great views. The music is light and refreshing like the food and the decor has beautiful colors of wood, blue, and white. 

One of my top new SF foodie faves! Yum yum peruvian food!
author: Geneva X.

description:
A new spot, walking distance from work,  serving up an extensive ceviche menu? yes please!

La Mar certainly did not disappoint and surpassed expectations in atmosphere, food and service. The Ceviche Nikei was my favorite dish of the night - it was well seasoned, very fresh and excellently balanced. 

The causa sampler was also delicious, as was the ahi tuna and grilled prawn entrees. The portions were generous, especially the appetizers (i'd say they were almost equivalent in size to the main entrees).

I can't leave out the dessert though. We ordered the creme brulee and the fritters- I eat a lot of dessert and these two dishes really topped the list. Both were lighter then expected, with just the right amount of sweetness.

I didn't get a chance to try any, but there were a nice selection of vegetarian items, and though I didn't confirm, there were what seemed to be one or two vegan options too.

I most definitely will be coming back.
author: Melissa G.

description:
We had a lovely lunch in the patio this weekend ... the view of the boats were nice (limited view of the Bay Bridge) and the beachy-decor was bright and fun.  I loved the complementary chips and plantains that they give with 3 different dipping sauces.  We also ordered the cebiches mixto and chiba, which were very fresh and tasty.  The arroz norteno was also very good (similar to a paella) and the chicken empanadas were really great.  

Most importantly, the service was great (unlike what many of the reviews here have said) and so I'll be coming back for more!
author: Grace M.

description: I went to this restaurant twice during a business trip.  It is right on the water and has a clean, modern look to it, very spacious but still inviting.  Both times the seafood was fabulous and some of the best cervices I've ever had.  The catch of the day over mushrooms with smoked broth is an excellent second course.  However, if you are particularly hungry get their version of paella.  The other shining jewel is instead of bread they serve plantain, sweet potato and regular chips with two dipping sauces.  It is pricey so be prepared for that when you go.   The second time I went it was with a group of 19.  We were served rather quickly and efficiently.  Just make sure you call in advance for large groups.
author: Brenda M.

description:
Best ceviche ever, the fish was so fresh. If you can't decide I highly recommend the sampler. With four people everyone gets a piece of each.

Also, the beef hearts were so juicy and delicious. My mother is half-Peruvian and she said they were just as good as the ones you get on the streets of Peru. I've personally never been there, but they were tasty.

Pisco sours were good and strong... I had never had one before and I really just tried it out of the novelty of them being a traditional Peruvian drink. I prefer martinis and wine but it was definitely worth it. Plus it was $5 happy hour! 

I ordered the Arroz something... the one that doesn't have the arborio rice. Jugoso or Norteno. Either way it was sooo good. Little calamaris, octopuses, shrimp in a really tasty savory rice. Highly recommend it. My sister had the other arroz dish and it did not compare. Plus she didn't like it because it was risotto-like and risotto is definitely not her thing.

Last we had the sorbet dessert. It said it came with three scoops.... i would call that maybe three large cherry-sized scoops. They were really good because they were homemade but 9$ for that amount of delicious sorbet was just cruel. 

All-in-all loved it.
Make reservations, because even then you might have to wait. 
Worth it.
author: Shanley M.

description:
We came here for a work happy hour. I'm so glad my boss made the effort to find a new location to add to the mix. She recommended the pisco sours and we dutifully complied and were all glad we did. They taste similar to margaritas and were equally sneaky. We were all laughing in no time. We also ordered appetizers which were all amazing - ceviches, empanadas, etc. We pretty much sampled everything that they had on the bar menu. Anything with potatoes in it are deeeeelish! The only thing I wouldn't order again would be the grilled octopus dish - I didn't like it and couldn't finish it. Everything else though was completely crave-able.

We stayed in the bar area, we were too early for the lounge and by the time the lounge opened we decided to stay where we were.

Service was fine. In all I would go here again, I'd like to try the dinner menu - they've got me curious now.
author: Sherrie D.

description: Food is amazing but it def is overpriced. If you go try to go during happy hr which is 3-6. The food tastes amazing.
author: Jimmy S.

description: The food here is fantastic - so tasty.  They serve a chips basket with three delicious creamy dips.  Then we had the ensalada limena which was very fresh, the ceviche mista, the chupe de camarones, and the ahi tuna.  Everything was delicious and the service was very good.  A little less intimate than Mochica, but given service issues at Mochica I'd probably rate this one higher.
author: Vivian W.

description:
I had dinner here last night and let me tell you, I LOVED it!

The place is huge (seats maybe 300 people in three different rooms) and it was hopping.  You need a reservation during the weekend. We were lucky and on a Friday night,  managed to grab two seats at the "cebiches" bar.

The service was impeccable.  I liked the gorgeous, tall Peruvian waiters who explained every dish in detail (in charming accents)  while I nodded and pretended to understand what they were saying.

We started out with the cebiches tasting platter for $28 - highly recommended!!

I eyed these fantastic cupcakes from across the bar, only to realize they were not for dessert. I went over to the chef for a closer look.   I got so excited about them the chef made me one for a treat.  They are causas, and look like darling little cupcakes.   The base is made with mashed potato  and instead of frosting, the tops are made form Dungeness crab, ahi tuna or vegetables.  

For dessert we had chocolate filled beignets with banana ice-cream. Delicious! 

On the downside, we found the chicken empanados were only so-so and the salad was so salty it was inedible.

I reluctantly give La Mar 4 stars instead of 5 as there was some inconsistency with the food.  This is a new restaurant, so I assume they will work out the kinks.  I plan to go back, often, and will update this review at some point soon. 

Great for a large group or celebration!
author: Jill D.

description:
Solid place to grab a post work drink, and munch a little ceviche.  They have happy hour deals on Pisco Sours (which go down entirely too easy) and their selection of ceviche is top notch.  To date I have yet to dislike any of them.  Service can be a little touch and go, but the energetic atmosphere and fantastic drinks/food more than make up for it....

So 4 stars for food/drink quality, 3 stars for service. Stick to the bar and it's a sure bet.
author: Barrett F.

description: We waited so long to visit this place and we are very disappointed . They claim to be a Peruvian cevicheria and their ceviche tastes nothing like Peruvian .their service is horrible the waiter was rude and short .they brought us the dessert menu and never came back to ask if we wanted to order something or not after waiting for about 15 minutes we asked to get our check we paid and left . I don't recommend this restaurant at all it is expensive their food is not good and their service is horrible
author: Erika F.

description: I have been here a few times now and the food never fails to disappoint - it is fantastic. The flank steak and the short ribs are delicious, and the tuna cebiche is wonderful. Great atmosphere, perfect for a relaxed date place. My only complaint is that the service could be better. If you are not in a larger group the wait staff can tend to forget about you. Overall however, I highly recommend.
author: Ian C.

description:
Love the atmosphere of this place. Very light, and airy without being too noisy. 

The food & drinks were quite tasty...
ceviche misto - very fresh mix of mahi mahi, squid, corn, in a yummy "sauce"

causas sampler - hmm...not TOO big of a fan, but these were definitely interesting. the tuna version tasted a little bit like a spicy tuna roll =p

side of yucca - so light and crispy. delicious!

lomo saltado - the best by worlds to what i've ever had. the steak was very tender and the potatoes were quite crispy even though there was a lot of 'sauce'. The rice had choclo in it as well and made it ever so tasty

piccarones - probably my fav 'dish' from the whole meal. i don't think i can ever eat american donuts again... Pumpkin/sweet potato fritters with honey are so much better. they were even good the next day! (i'm SO glad i got these even though i was comatosely full)

chicha tu mal - drink. i probably should skip this next time to make more room for food, but was definitely good

pisco sour - almost like a bitter margarita. good, but i liked the chicha better.

All in all - great place to dine, even though the service was slow. Not a good place if you're in a hurry, but a good place if you want to relax and eat slowly=) If the service was better, i would have rated this a 5.
author: Fuzzysaurus L.

description:
Loved it.  It works for almost any occasion, from stopping in the bar for a quick bite and a drink to a full meal in the beautiful main room.   We tried the cebiche sampler, and I thought two of the four were outstanding.  The nisei (?) was too sweet/soy sauced for me.  Also tried the causa sampler, and I've never seen more beautiful whipped potatoes.   Another  main course, I forget the name, was stir fried beef with an addictive sauce and was very good. 
Service was solid and friendly too.   The patio was not open, but once the heaters are in place that will def. be a panty dropping place to take a date, male or female.   Beautiful on the water tables with bay bridge views and boats coming right up to you.  

Negatives--desserts were not great, the Pumpkin/Sweet Potato Fritters were just fried dough.  I got no pumpkin or sweet potato at all, so if you are happy with a fairly large plate full of fried, this is what you want.  And, a big negative, $4.50 for a single espresso?  WTF is that?  Did they confuse SF with Paris?  I didn't feel screwed by any of the other prices, including the wine list, but that stuck in my craw a bit.   I'll def. be back here, next time I'll just bring a chocolate covered espresso bean for the dessert/coffee course and should be all good.
author: Kean S.

description:
We had a wonderful dining experience at La Mar. 

Our order:

1. cebiche chifa-yum
2. causa nikei-we really enjoyed this
3. anticuchos de pulpo-very, very good; hands down our favorite item ordered.
4. empanadas de lomo saltado-tasty

The potato and plantain chips with the three dipping sauces were a nice treat.  Definitely would like to go back and try more items. It's fairly loud inside, although we loved the view from the windows and the tropical feel on the inside.  Our server was attentive and together with the other staff anticipated our needs (quickly brought drinks, fresh plates, silverware, etc).
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Reservation are highly recommended.Great place to go for dinner. Expect to spend aprox 80.00 dollars p/p or more  But, it's all worth it. It has wonderful cocktails Pisco sour -Purple corn), and exquisite sea food .If you go with 3 other .You can always choose 4 plates tapa style to share. I recommend the Ceviche sampler and  Crab causa. You can always order a bottle of wine and save money on cocktails. Also , if you just go to the bar and order the appetizers ,you can also enjoy the food and save some money. Great place and the ambience is just perfect !
author: Corali C.

description: La Mar Cebicheria Peruana is a great place to go. Its interior design is outstanding. This is really a safe place. Its customer service is so attractive that any body could love it. Here some people are great they are George, Elizabeth, Christine, Rachel, David and Michale. I am so happy to visit this place.
author: Russel S.

description:
I keep going back to this place, 'cause I love sitting in their light and airy dining room. The blue.  the white. The light. The place just make me happy.  And when the weather is nice, sitting outside with an out-of-town guest makes this San Franciscan very proud.

But...the service is less than great.  And the food is very attractive and fine but not the reason I return again and again.
author: Barbara M.

description:
I'm with most of the others on this page.

was part of one of the last soft opening lunches today, and it was absolutely fantastic.  I don't often rave about restaurants (see some of my "love notes" to other restaurateurs in my other reviews...), but I am going to about La Mar--this is another SF bay area restaurant that I'm adding to my canon: Chez Panisse Cafe, Range, La Folie, etc.  

First, let's start with the decor--spectacular location, and the decor has gorgeous colors.  the bar is destined to be a hip hot spot--both for after work happy hour, but also a cool nightspot (i suspect).  

the food was fantastic:

cebiche crudo--melt in your mouth, sushi-grade sea urchin, delicious scallop. i have not historically been a fan of ceviche.  it's usually a little too acidic and tart for me. Well, call me a convert now.  

lomo saltado--as others have said--just spectacular.  so tender and melt in your mouth.   Found out the beef is from Niman Ranch and it's grass-fed.  

Macho--grouper with a tomato based sauce.  delicious sauce, but i have to admit the grouper is not my favorite fish--it's a simple, clean white fish but a little bland for me.  

had great cocktails (another reason why i think it's going to be a great spot for happy hour and a night spot).  try the pisco sours, cholopolitan, and the chica tu mia

service was great.  We had a waiter named Franco, and he was warm, friendly, knowledgeable, and pointed us in the right direction.  He did not hesitate one bit in making suggestions.  

Can't wait to go back!
author: Howard T.

description:
Loved this place!   Great atmosphere, decor, food and service.

Food:

My favorite was the causa -  nice presentation and very tasty.
Ceviche was good as well - nice big pieces of fish
Empanadas were solid but I think I've had better
A surprise favorite of mine was the vegetarian risotta with mushrooms and tomatoes.   It was quite tasty and came out piping hot/fresh.

Love how they give you banana chips at the table too.   

I would definitely come back for happy hour or dinner!
author: T M.

description: This place had me at the plantain chips they serve in the beginning. Went here for the dine about town deal. The civiche and causa limena were fantastic and I'll be ordering both again next time I come. The Lomo saltado was one of their weaker dishes, but good enough for the promotion. Overall a great place, great drinks, and great ambiance; I highly recommend to those thinking of trying it.
author: Erik V.

description: I had been wanting to try La Mar some time and was not disappointed. The cebiches were fabulous; I recommend the sampler.  I had the tuna special that evening and the flavor swerve amazing.  The space is large but the noise is not overwhelming.  The staff was knowledgable and eager to provide recommendations and explanations.
author: bill l.

description:
I tried this back in November.  The traditional ceviche was really incredible.  The food is tasty and interesting, and the location is top notch.  

Service was very slow, but they have gotten this worked out by now.

Tons of options for pescatarians.
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
The best part about this place is the cebiche - man is it tasty. I highly recommend the cebiche tasting or the nikei. The una was overly heavy and dense, but everything else I've had on the menu, including the ensalada nikei and the arroz dishes are excellent.

A big missing star for service. Every time I've gone they've taken plates away before I was done (while I was literally mid-bite so I couldn't shout NO!), drinks take a long time to receive, and the last time our waitress took my boyfriend's drink order and then walked away without even acknowledging me. What's that about?

Ideally I'd go to La Mar when I'm kind of but not super hungry and gorge on cebiche and pisco sours. Ah, the good life.
author: Allison S.

description:
Perhaps I was a little harsh.  I think I was reeling from my disappointment, but actually, La Mar is good for a booty call every once in awhile.  
Sometimes a girl just wants a little ceviche and pisco with no strings attached - and La Mar will certainly deliver on that.
author: Cindy W.

description: I love any place that makes a good ceviche and La Mar creates some of the best in town. Try any / all of them, you can't go wrong. The bar scene is pretty fun - the cocktails are small, but well made. The restaurant is located in a cool historic building as well - which I always like. We will be back!
author: Brooke S.

description: The food and the atmosphere was pretty good, but unfortunately the service made my wife and I leave not knowing if we would come back. We had a reservation and had a to wait about five minutes before we could be seated, once we were seated we looked at the menu and decided on the drink and starters we would get. We waited, we waited and waited some more. After fifteen minutes the waiter finally came and seemed really bored, but oh well, lets order and not worry about him. Finally our drinks came which were ok. I had the pisco sour, which cost $13 and half of the drink was egg white foam which was annoying. Later in the meal we ordered another drink but when they came to us the drinks were the wrong ones. From that point on we really didn't see the waiter much. When he did come he grabbed my drink, which was still a quarter full and walked away. My wife and I looked at each thinking, wtf, did he really just do that. Overall the food was good but for the price you pay the service should really be on point.
author: Ryan G.

description:
First I have to say the location is pretty amazing, love the atmosphere!
Delicious food, not to crazy about the ceviche, but other than that, love it... and the service is always very good
author: Veronica M.

description:
I thought the food here was excellent - I was here with a large group for lunch, and we shared several different appetizers, and also enjoyed the plantain chips and their dipping sauces.  We were almost too full for our meals!  Still, our lunches were so good that we managed to eat all of our entrees.  Most of us went with lomo saltado, which was just phenomenal!  

The service was very good, but I'm dinging a star for a very complicated menu - I realize that people aren't all that familiar with Peruvian food, but the menu was quite overwhelming at first.  It comes with a separate glossary page which is helpful, but also somewhat over the top.
author: Megan K.

description:
When you cross over the threshold, you're transported away to another place. The atmosphere is fresh, almost tropical, and inviting. In the very open space, it's as if La Mar created their own indoor super gentle breeze. 

The space: There were several areas to choose from...
Bar ~ Roomy, good seating, big windows look out onto Embarc. Prolly really great at happy hour. Or, would be great to host a happy hour. Mixed cocktails were fruity. I wasn't a fan of the bar "corn nuts" though.

Lounge ~ Great teak cushioned furniture line an open space that lines the wall. It's perfect for a private, cozy dining, or for a casual bite. I would sit there for apps and drinks and/or dessert. 

Sushi Bar ~ Parallel to the lounge is sushi bar-type seating. It seemed just fine, but the least interesting of all the seating options. 

Restaurant ~ The wide open dining space is New England meets Tropical, with its clean painted white and wood finishes, and bright aqua, lime, lemon, and fuschia accents. The views of the Bay anchor the setting.

Outdoor ~ I didn't get a chance to go out there, but it seemed cool. You sit right out there on the pier.  

The food: We ordered several ceviches, sashimis, a vegetarian risotto, and the lamb shoulder. Overall everything was fresh and on par. No particular complaints. The food wasn't phenomenal, but just good, solid, and fresh. Must note - that the tiny alfajores (sandwich cookie with dulce de leche) that accompanies the coffee was perfect.

Definitely make reservations for din. I think this is a great working lunch spot!

Overall, it's a solid dining experience. However, it has just a very tiny tendency to feel a little too contrived and almost commercial. I'll definitely visit back though.
author: Sharon C.

description: I loved their lomo saltado! very tender and grilled to perfection!! Chicken linguini is so so. Lamb was so so. Would wanna try their cau cau scallop next time.
author: Wendy T.

description:
Great cocktails.  Order the purple one with passion fruit.  The pisco sour is good, too, but I liked the passion fruit cocktail best.  The presentation was beautiful and everything we ordered was delicious.  I really liked the empanadas and the risotto.  The ceviche and other raw salads were great, too.  Oh, and unlimited plaintain, potato and taro fries with delicious salsas.  Mmmm so good.

Can't go wrong with anything you order here!
author: Linh N.

description: Food very good.  Service a little slow.  Prices on the high side, but fair. I would go back.
author: Clark H.

description:
I've been recovering from a minor surgery so my usual spinning class is off limits to me.  Since the weather has been so great, I've been walking along the Embarcadero everyday.  When I passed my La Mar, I immediately thought that someone finally named a place after my fabulous black gay alter-ego.   

After a few days of walking, I got very curious about trying La Mar out.  So, when my friends wanted to take me out for a belated birthday, it was the perfect excuse to try this place out.  

On a Friday we ventured into the Lions' Den without a reservation.  The hostess coldly told us that the wait was an hour for a seat at a counter.   Hey, I didn't blame them since they knew they were holding keys to the hottest place in town.  Since some of us had not eaten all day, my ingenious friend had plan.  She asked politely for the manager.  She was told that Rodrigo was tending bar cause they were being slammed.  She marched right over and greeted him like they were BFFs.  Before you know it, the hostess says, "I'm sorry.  I didn't know you were friends with Rodrigo."  and we were lead to a primo window seat.  Sweet.  See what a little moxie gets you?  No need to slip anyone some cash, just go in with confidence.

I ordered a pisco sour which I discovered is really sweet.  I even ordered it light on the simple syrup!  

The service was a bit uneven.  They are really nice and accomodating but not very adroit when it is busy.  We had to ask a couple of times for the complimentary chips.  When they arrived, they became our favorite thing on the table.  I especially loved the plantain chips.  But since everyone is talking about dipping sauces, we didn't get any.  

We ordered the cebiche sampler.  I would have liked to see a bit more fish in the order.  I think each little plate had about two pieces of fish.  For $23, I could have gotten an entire fish.   

The empanada and tamalito were forgettable.  The Lomo Saltado was nice but reminded me a bit of Shaking Beef.  I'd take shaking beef any day.  

The desserts were odd.  We settled on the chocolate beignets because who doesn't like chocolate doughnuts?  They were okay which is strange because I've never met a deep-fried food I didn't love.  

The upside of this place is that it is gorgeous.  I like the original woodwork and the high ceilings.  

I would go back with someone who doesn't have a lot of experience with Peruvian food and likes posh interiors.  

Ooops, I think that comment resembles me.
author: Monica L.

description:
i've had this place bookmarked for soooo long and have been wanting to try it ever since i've found it on yelp.

i've always been a really big fan of seafood and esp. cerviche. so of course, i was finally able to make a reservation one day for three and went on a beautiful day where we were actually seated outside. the view was perfect! the weather was a little hot but it was alright. 

of course, for starters i ordered the CERVICHE NEKEI (i love ahi tuna!!!) and for my entree, the CAUSA NEKEI. my friend wanted to sample the goods so he ordered the ALMUERCITO CHALACO that came with a cerviche, a steak skirt skewer, and an empanada. He also ordered a pisco sour that he raved about! My sister ordered the ARROZ CRIOLLO which is a seafood fried rice entree.

My cerviche came out first and honestly... i was a little disappointed with it. =[ i looooove ahi tuna cerviche but i expected it to be a lot better! maybe i just put LA MAR on too high of a pedestal. eh! BUUUUTTTTT!!! my causa was really REALLY good. so i guess it evened out. the ALMUERCITO CHALACO my friend ordered looked really good as well but i dont know if he thought so. As for my sister's fried rice... she said it was pretty good but wasn't mind blowing. it did fill her up though, so she said that was a plus, esp since it came out looking like a smaller portion of food. 

the experience was great. the service was so-so... along with some of our food. but i would def. love to come back to give it another chance, or at least get more causa and enjoy the view!!!
author: amelia g.

description:
going here and having dinner is kind of like going out for the night - the music is thumping, everyone's practically yelling, and for the most part everyone is having a good time.

i thought the food was fabulous and my roommate and i really enjoyed our visit.  i should probably have knocked another star off for the service, though - after our waitress initially greeted us she went off somewhere and didn't return for probably about forty minutes.  that was a little upsetting because we were starving (we hadn't been able to get a reservation until 9:00).  at some point someone else brought us our drinks - maybe about a half hour after we'd ordered them?  from that point on service was fine, and like i said food was great so we left happy.  but for about forty minutes there i was not so happy.  for now though i'm giving them the benefit of the doubt and going with 4 stars.
author: KT R.

description:
Best for:  Great location overlooking the Bay.   
Worst:  Fish went bad in the habenaro ceviche (tasted delicious until my husband bit into a piece that had gone off - that ammonia-y funk.  Yuck.) 

I did like the octopus though- it was under the "grilled" section but it was very tender - more like braised - and served in three pieces on little beds of mashed yucca.  

As far as bevvies, my friends who had gone the weekend before recommended the pisco sour, which is apparently their signature drink, but I wasn't enamored.  It was too sour and I didn't really think there was a whole lot of alcohol in it.  Bummer.  Maybe I'm just partial to Piqueo's sangria.  In fact, Piqueo's (Cortland St in Bernal Heights) has stellar Peruvian food overall, and would hands down be my top pick if I was seeking Peruvian.

So overall, the bad fish thing put me off, but if it's nice out and I had guests in from out of town, I'd maybe sit on the outdoor patio for a drink.
author: Heather F.

description:
OMG! OMG! OMG! What can I say? La Mar is probably the best restaurant in the city!

The lounge area is nice and cozy. Perfect for pre-dinner Pisco cocktails. The restaurant is pretty big, very cozy and chic.

We started off with a cebiche sampler. I really liked the Nikei (Japanese) and the Chifa (Chinese). We had a lot of drinks (Pisco!) through the course of dinner and before; the goal being to sample everything on the menu. All of them were fantastic, but my favorites have to be the Pisco Sour and the Sirenita. The Sirenita is amazingly refreshing.

Everyone at the table ordered different entrees, so we could sample each. One of us ordered the pasta, which was extremely creamy and yum. I ordered the lamb shanks, which were tender and delicious. But the most awesome entree was the beef dish -- the Lomo Saltado. Oh. My. God. Heavenly.

Now you absolutely must make room for desserts. MUST. Again, we ordered different things: a creme brulle; something with fresh fruits and pisco froth (yum!); and the Buñuelos de Chocolate Caliente which is downright ridiculously chocolatey rich. Must have. Yummmm!

Definitely definitely definitely going again.

Go very thirsty and very hungry.
author: Premshree P.

description: Staff is friendly.  Limon salad was definitely worth ordering.
author: Frank G.

description:
OK the food deserves 4 starts, but the overall experience has not met my expectations.

So now I have been here 3 times.

1.  With the parents.... my dad could not hear a word I was saying because it is sooo loud in there.   But we all enjoyed the food.  We had the sampler of ceviches which was delicious!  And the plantains with dipping sauce to starts is grand.  

2.  Went with two co-workers.  They did not think the food was as great as me, but they loved the Pisco Sours.  Great cocktail menu.

3.  Third time... went to the bar area in the front... they don't serve the plantains there!  I was so sad!  I had talked them up too.  We were eating too, but they only serve those in the dining room.  I offered to pay for them and still they would not walk their butt to the kitchen to get us some.  

Overall great once... but not up to par.

There is valet for $10.. must have cash.
author: Blair K.

description:
Somehow, I kept thinking La Mar was going to be a french experience and the address 'Pier 1 1/2' was in the heart of tourist district.   So when we arrived and realized it was in the nicest part of the waterfront, just a tad north of the Ferry Building and the front of the restaurant was hip with glass doors, I was relieved.

First, you walk into an expansive area with the full bar to the right and then as you walk into the dining room with super high ceilings, you past a very serious counter/bar with all of the Peruvian seafood delicacies on full display, ala sushi bar style but with a Peruvian flare.

Drinks are must and at $10 a pop you might as well go for the stylized drinks like the pisco sour.  We decided family style for our party of 6 would the best way to sample and our waiter was extremely helpful in his recommendations.  

A must is the cebiche tasting which is four different fish from octopus, ahi,  yellow tail, it was all very tasty and fresh!

For the entres, we ordered a rice/paella dish, seco del cordero which is a stewed lamb shank on mashed rice with a cilantro sauce and a couple of other dishes that I can't remember.  Everything was very tasty and fresh.

La Mar is truly an international restaurant with locations in Lima, Costa Rica, Mexico City and Santiago.  You are getting the real deal at La Mar.

They are 4 months new as of this review and are probably working out some kinks based on other reviewers, but our dinner was very good.
author: Randall F.

description:
"Gaston Acurio is the most famous chef you've never heard of." -- San Francisco Magazine


I'd been fascinated with the opening of La Mar, the first U.S. foothold in the formidable culinary empire of Peru's Gaston Acurio, ever since I first read about it a couple of years ago, primarily as a fun place to tie up a sailboat on the SF waterfront and enjoy a drink and food...something you generally have only been able to do in Sausalito or Tiburon.

But recently, since the opening, there's been a fair amount of rave reviews about the food, the vibe, the décor, the whole experience. It's become so popular that I didn't think we'd have any luck with a table but evidently the crowds are a dinner hour thing because when we walked in on Sunday at 1PM, there were only a few tables that had guests seated. Cool!

The colors in this place are the first wave of stimulation and seduction: brilliant, almost electric blues and yellow greens, contrasted with dark wood accents and bright white paint. The banquettes are a dusty blue and accented with muted orange pillows. The visual vibe is fun and has a way of creating a sense of anticipation for the food.

We had come to the waterfront for a cocktail, so now we had to figure out what said libation would be. I looked over the cocktail menu - all of the drinks sounded interesting, many if not all of the signature drinks feature Pisco, a Peruvian brandy - and had settled on "Pisco Punch."  But our waitress Michelle made such a convincing case for the restaurant's signature Pisco Sour that I went for it instead. This was a decidedly good call. This drink is amazing...or as San Francisco Magazine put it, it's a "zesty cocktail that's everything the margarita can only hope to be." Richard and I both agreed that the flavors in this drink matched the flavors in the food in a way that we've NEVER experienced outside of wine/food or beer/food pairing. You're going to have to taste it to know what I mean.

The Pisco Sour is the second act of seduction.

For the third, and your doorway to Pleasurable Delirium, start ordering ceviche. Oh, God.

Order at least two of them, maybe three. If you don't, you're crazy. If you don't want to spend a lot, go with the half-orders like we did. In addition to the great flavors, the ceviches are also the best showcase of the Asian-Peruvian fusion that is the hallmark of Acurio's food here.

We ordered two, the Clasico and the Chifa.

Both had moan-inducing, incredibly bright flavors. 

The Clasico had more heat from habaneros. It features generous pieces of California halibut and red onions in habanero pepper "leche de tigre" marinade, with Peruvian corn and a cute chunk of marinated yam.

The Chifa has a decidedly Asian taste profile, with tender, sashimi-like yellowfin tuna, peanuts, scallions, ginger, pickled carrots and daikon, habanero pepper, wonton strips and cilantro in leche de tigre marinade.

We scarfed down the fish meat and vegetables with giddy abandon, leaving two dishes half-full of marinade that we loved so much that when Mario the wait assistant asked if he could get them out of our way we both whimpered, "No!!!"  When Michelle heard this she matter-of-factly offered to dispense the marinade into a couple of ...*shot glasses* for us. And she was actually serious. How freaking nice is that?

Incidentally, here's something else remarkable about La Mar: the wait staff has obviously been extremely thoroughly coached to understand - and explain - the ins and outs of Peruvian cuisine. Michelle started out by asking us if we were familiar with Peruvian cuisine; take my advice and let the waiter walk you through the entire menu, it's incredibly helpful and interesting. And do go with their recommendations - the ones that she gave us proved to be unimpeachable.

Next we shared the seafood empanadas: light, flaky pies stuffed with shrimp, vegetables and even a bit of hard-cooked quail egg. They were delightful.

Mario walked by as we were contemplating dessert, and we asked what he thought we should order. He didn't think twice before suggesting the picarones (God I hope I have -that name right...), light, deep-fried donuts of sweet potato batter served with a sweet molasses sauce. They were melt-in-your-mouth wonderful, to the point that I plated a bite size piece and passed it to our neighbors. They in turn offered a taste of their tiramisu with sorbet.

Oh, meanwhile, while I was at the other table, a staff member casually re-folded my cloth napkin for me into a tidy triangle. This could either be interpreted as obsessive-compulsive behavior, or extraordinary attentiveness. I'm going with the latter.

Whenever Richard and I try a new restaurant, and it's a hit, one of us will invariably say "I think we'll put this on the List." 

But we both looked at each other at lunch today and realized, "We gotta get a different list." This place is CRAZY good.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I loved La Mar. The service was pretty good, the food was amazing and the view from the outside patio of the bay is magical! We had the cebiche caretillero, the causa nikei (possibly my favorite dish! Try it!) the empanadas de tamalito verde and for dessert.. the bunuelos that were so delicate and when bitten into oozed a yummy chocolate sauce!! The portions are just the right amount, you'll leave satisfied, but not stuffed. I agree with others that La Mar on a pretty day is a special occasion and I recommend it to all! Every dish looks like art, but the food is not just pretty the flavors are impressive too!
author: Fabiola M.

description: Great food, had the lamb and the pico soar drink is a must have. Great company great for birthday events.
author: Louis S.

description: The bar inside Cebicheria Peruana serves as a cafe during lunch hours and offers best quality food that is reasonably priced.  It is separate form La Mar lunch menu.  The menu selection is not that big but everything on the menu is delicious.  Tuna sandwich was my favorite with seared tuna slices with some greens and dressing on the home made bread.   Very tasty. The empanadas and alfajores are delicious too.   I am coming back there soon.
author: Irina T.

description:
A very good choice for Peruvian in the City. The space is nice and spacious. Service is a bit slow and the restaurant is very noisy so it's a bit difficult to have a conversation with someone who's not next to you. Place is a bit pricey...

Food is very good. Just stick to the seafood options.  There's a sampler plate for appetizers that is a must if you've never had peruvian food. Pretty much all of the seafood entrees I tasted were quite good.  Some of the non-seafood options were only ok. Staff here is pretty knowledgeable so feel comfortable in having them just order for you.
author: TT T.

description:
I liked La Mar even before I had a chance to visit.  The initial vibes were so positive that I didn't hesitate to recommend it to visitors.  The beautiful Bayside location combined with flavorful Peruvian seafood-inspired combinations just signaled success.

About six weeks ago, my office hosted an interview candidate for lunch at La Mar.  First of all, mad props to the team for executing a flawless business lunch at the same time a 100 person holiday party was being held.  Never mind if the entrees were the same, the fact that the service remained top notch was mucho appreciated.

There were a variety of dishes served family style.  The portions were generous and while I left feeling very full, the food is generally light, which makes for scrumptious sampling!  I loved the house-made chips in paper cones with a trio of dipping sauces that were waiting for us at the table when we arrived.  Here's the rest of what we tried:

Cebiche Clasico - red onion, habanero, peruvian corn, yam, and halibut.  Great with the potato chips.

Ensalada Limena - arugula and spinach blend with cherry tomatoes, hearts of palm, queso fresco and aji amarillo vinaigrette.  A fresh and crunchy salad - I had two helpings!

Causa Limena - whipped potato with dungeness crab, avocado puree, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, and a basil sauce.  Gorgeous presentation and my favorite dish.  Dungeness is December is impossible to beat!

Lomo Saltado - beef stir fry with onion, tomato, cilantro, soy, garlic, and fried potatoes.  A unique and balanced combination (and not too salty, a common problem with beer and garlic/soy based stir fry).  Loved that what were essentially french fries were featured prominently in this dish!

Arrox Noreno - mussels, shrimp, octopus, calamari, and fried rice with clinatro and salsa criolla.  Similar to a paella.  

Mango, Lemon and Strawberry Sorbet for dessert.  A palate cleansing finish with sugary wedges artistically placed of hard candy.  Just the sugar buzz I needed for the afternoon!

Can't wait to return.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
I have been a long time fan of La Mar because it's scrumdelicious.

I typically start off at the bar with whatever cocktail entices me.  (I really start at the bar because at the bar only, you get there homemade cornuts...yep, 90's high school graduates, just like the ones we used to eat in grade school but all grown up!)  
The ceviche at La Mar is the best in town!  For dinner I usually get the ceviche tasting platter which is perfect as an entree paired with a side of there buttery rice w/maiz.  My husband, sisters, mom, and kids always get the lomo saltado.  The tender filet mignon strips are uber flavorful and mouthwatering delicious.  I have been to a lot of Peruvian restaurants in S.F. and none of there ceviches or lomo compare to La Mar.
I highly recommend this place and 6 months ago I would have given it 5 stars.  It lost a star because prices have gone up:(  My ceviche tasting has more than doubled in price from $16 to $36...sad, sad, day!  It costs more then the filet mignon!  That's just not right!!!
That being said, I don't go there as often as I used to:( Oh well.  The good thing is, when I do, I know what to expect...super delicious food every time!
author: ada l.

description:
The best ceviche ever, and a fine atmosphere to boot.

I would have gone 4.5 stars, but we were only there at the bar for a quick repast.  beautiful spot, very pleasant staff, and the ceviche was just outstanding.  We've been trying various ceviche for years, including in Peru.  I can't say that La Mar's is authentic (and I wouldn't really want to), but the fusion of ingredients and flavors -- including some Asian -- is really exciting and inspired.  We had the tasting plate of four, and there's not one I wouldn't have made a night out of.  I used my spoon to get at the juice once all the exquisite chucks were gone.

As we lingered in our sea-citric glow, we watched other plates being delivered.  Everything looked beautiful and elicited oohs, aahs, and wows from the lucky diners.

Can't wait for a full-on experience.
author: Doug B.

description:
La Mar is in a breathtaking space overlooking the Pacific Ocean, just a block from the Ferry Building.  Perfect spot for a romantic dinner, a business lunch, or happy hour.  I was here for the latter and treated myself to the ceviche and a few pisco cocktails. 

Total fiesta for your tastebuds and your senses, ya'll.
author: Sid D.

description: Came here with my friend and his wife.  This was my second trip here and I enjoyed the food both times. On the most recent trip we walked in after munching away at the ferry building. We shared the Ceviche sampler, and the empanada sampler. They were both delicious. Next time I go I'll try the lomo saltado there which is a meat and potato lovers dream. The decor and service were outstanding. I especially love the long open bar facing embarcadero. This would be a fun place to go to with a larger group too
author: Mike K.

description: I LOVE this joint. It's right next to my office and a perfect place for happy hour so long as you can get off early enough to battle the massive crowds for a table. I've had their takeout sandwiches for lunch and they're fantastic. Also went out for a seated lunch there and had the ceviche sampler that was to die for.  So for me- unusual, authenic peruvian cuisine, amazing pisco drinks, beautiful decor and location, and good service= 5 stars baby!
author: Carly T.

description:
This review is for individuals thinking of going to La Mar when hosting a large party or group event.  The experience we had with Mayra (La Mar's event planner) was so mediocre, non-engaging, and cold, I cancelled our reservation despite liking the food and venue.  The same day, we moved our business to Farina whose event coordinator Michael took care of us in no time flat!!   At Farina, Michael sat with us for 30 mins and we selected the set menu, wine, desert, decorations, got the private room for our event in 2 days time.  Simple, pleasant, and made my life easier!  

Bottom line with La Mar is that my fiance and I were looking to host a reception for family and friends after our city hall wedding.  After sending an email to Mayra explaining what we were looking for, I was sent a canned email from Mayra with the details and menu.  I was a little surprised since most other restaurants called me back to talk live (I had left her a message, but no call back), but hey, I guess if your restaurant is highly rated on Yelp, maybe you just think you can rely on the reputation of the restaurant versus providing good customer service?  Over the next few interactions, one word answers of "yes" or "no" were the norm in her emails.  No explanations of what the restaurant could offer, no suggestions to meet in person, just short and curt to the point I felt as though I was inconveniencing her.  If I'm about to drop $2K on a dinner, I'd expect a little more.  My fiance thought things did seem a little distant with her, but also thought maybe I was overreacting, but after he took over finalizing our details with her directly, he admitted he thought I was right and commented how she gave off the vibe she just wanted him off the phone.  (He actually thinks she's just in the wrong line of work and maybe just hates her job and takes it out on potential clients?  That's his life coach background speaking...)

Anyhow, my sales job requires me host dinner parties for large groups constantly...I'd really think twice about ever suggesting La Mar as the venue just knowing we'd have to go thru La Mar's event planner.  In this economy, there are too many other good restaurants in SF that will work to earn your business.  The experience at La Mar just didn't cut it. 

(Now if you're walking in off the street and don't have any large or special events you're arranging, I think La Mar would be decent.  Again, this review is just for those of you planning an event there!)
author: Melodie Y.

description: Glad to have tried this Peruvian place at Pier 1.5. The atmosphere was lovely, with the views by the water and outdoor seating. All the seating seemed good. The food was unique and worth trying. Tried the cause sampler which was good. Reminded me of eating sushi or Spanish tapas. Loved the other dishes too. Was a bit pricey, but it was expected, since the location and atmosphere was excellent.
author: Felecia W.

description:
we were an hour late for our reservation. not my fault. if you know me, you know i am punctual to a fault. yet somehow we still got a table. nice because we didnt have a backup plan!

cebiche? it was just ok. i actually like the one i make a LOT better

causa nikei? very good. great presentation, great taste. its made with a purple potato. delicious. love most anything with ahi tuna

empanadas de picante de mariscos? excellent. order came with 2 of them, which we split into 4 to share within our group

anticuchos de carne? good. i wanted the anticuchos de corazon, but i was vetoed. i'll be back though

pescado nikei? the rice was great. the fish was good too, though i'm not a huge 'whole fish' fan

lomo saltado? delicious. kind of salty, but i didnt mind. the juice the lomo came in was great. does "saltado" mean salty in 'peruvian'?

pisco sour? not as good as the one i once had at cheesecake factory once

i love the decorations. very classy. not crazy expensive. a great choice for friends or a date. go with friends though so you can share and try more dishes.
author: Norman P.

description:
Stumbled upon this place because the Slanted Door was packed for the night. Walked into a great space with tables, lounge areas and a cebiche bar. We didnt have a rez, so we sat at the cebiche bar. A lot of great seafood along with great empanadas. 

This would be a great place for a group dinner.
author: Howard C.

description:
Pretty darn good food.

They serve fried plaintain & other chips with three dipping sauces, which are creamy so can fill you up...so save room for your meal!

Ordered the cebiche tasting, and although they were tasty, I wish we had picked one that sounded good & gone with that. With four to taste from you're sort of mixing flavors.

Also made the rookie mistake of ordering the empanada sampler, and they started to taste the same due to the same crispy exterior. Wish we had selected one & gone with that. The mushroom & the tamalito verde were probably the best. 

We ordered the lomo saltado to share since it was a classic Peruvian dish as per the waiter. The steak was yummy/tender although I didn't 'get' the french fries that were mixed into the dish. Didn't like that aspect of the dish.

Desserts were excellent -- ordered the key lime one & also the passion fruit/chocolate mousse one. 

My soda(s) were flat, even after asking for a replacement. They showed up with an opened bottle but who knows how long it was open? And the waiter seemed annoyed that I asked for a replacement and was not apologetic. 

All in all a mostly positive experience and would come again, being more selective about my appy choices.

Dinner companion's red wine was very good, so he said. Place was a little loud as my companion had trouble hearing me from across the table or the waiter.
author: D L.

description: This place was AMAZING.  Loved the atmosphere.  Staff was attentive.  Food was so fresh & drinks were on hit.  This place has a lot of seafood and most of our dishes had seafood food in them and it was fresh and flavorful.  Some of the dishes we had were the Cebiche tasting, Empanada sampler, and carne skewers.  I had the Pisco Punch which was tasty.....and the buzz was nice.  Let's just say everyone at the table was happy.
author: Natacha M.

description: I really like La Mar and highly recommend it. However, after talking two friends into going there on Saturday night, we were driven away by the attitude of the hostess. She was in her late 20's or early 30's and presented like a sullen adolescent mixed with a "I'm far too cool for this job" vibe. So, we went down to the Water Bar and spent $400 there.
author: Harland K.

description:
Okay, so I'll admit that I am being a little harsh on my review but I went for my birthday and so my expectations were high. 

The day was absolutely beautiful and we decided to sit outside. There was a good amount of people but by no means crowded. The decor is nice and we were looking out to the bay. 

I enjoyed the food. We had the sampler empanadas, skewers and ceviche. It was enough for us all to share and gave us the opportunity to try them all. We enjoyed the drinks as well. 

I know you must be thinking why two stars if everything seemed to be so good. The service really let me down. While they were all nice I felt completely neglected. We ordered all of our food at the same time and told our server we were going to share. We first got the ceviche then it seems like 30mins until we saw him again. Once we asked about the food he brought out the skewers and then about 35mins later he brought the empanadas. Towards the end I was going to just to cancel the order because we had to get back to work but just when I finally track down another servers comes with the food. 

What's tragic is he didn't offer the dessert menu, not like I had the time to wait to get it, no birthday sweet for me :(.
author: Nikki L.

description: Delicious food but the service was horrible!!  It took over 30 minutes to be waited on so we ordered our food and drinks at the same time.  The food came quickly withing 15-20 min but the drinks came about half way through our meal and the spoon that was supposed to come with our dishes arrived when we were almost done.  The waiter never checked on us yet he knew we weren't happy because when we ordered our meals he offered a free dessert to compensate us.  Well after the meal we waited another 45 min for him to come back to our table and when he did he asked if we had seen the dessert menu yet.  We said really, did you bring us the menu or even check on us to see if we wanted to order another drink?!!  Needless to say, two hours later and late the event we were attending we finally left that place.  I would recommend this place if they have "to-go" options otherwise I wouldn't go back because there are other just as delicious Peruvian restaurants to visit with better service.
author: Leala O.

description: I came here for a girlfriends birthday on a weeknight and ended up sitting in the bar area for food and drinks. While the decor and atomsphere was amazing the service was not up to par. I understand places get busy, but not having enough staff on board to service diners in an adequate timeframe is not acceptable for a place with such prestige and well talked about. Every drink we ordered had around a 20 minute delay and a couple times was forgotten to be honest. The food was good, the drinks were OK, but once again for a enjoyable experience with the money you are spending, service becomes key as well. I will come back as I liked the place, but hope for better next time. The view is wonderful as La Mar is on the water and maybe next time we will sit in the back.
author: Megan G.

description:
Great, fun place for dinner and/or drinks.

Went for happy hour with a few coworkers and ended up staying for dinner.  Nice atmosphere, good crowd filled with a mix of fidi and other upwardly mobile folks.

The tuna cebiche was outstanding, specialty drinks were really good.  Our meat dishes didn't really stand out as much, but were decent.  

Needed to flag our server down a couple of times for water.  But other than that the service was ok.

Would definitely come back for drinks and to sample some more cebiche!
author: kristi j.

description:
I took my husband here for lunch on a Saturday.  I had made reservations a few days in advance to make sure we got a table since it had only been open for 3 weeks at that time.  We were seated immediately.  We wanted to try everything on the menu, but decided to try an item from each "section" instead.  The Cebiche Mixto was delicious, not to sour, not too spicy.  The beef in the lomo saltado was soooo tender, you can cut it w/ a spoon!  The empanadas were good as well, I think they are made to order (tasted like homemade dough), but it would be even better if they put more filling.  They were a little stingy w/ the filling, but it might be because it was shrimp?  I had the tiramisu for dessert and my husband ordered the beignets and they both did NOT disappoint.  

We'll definitely be back!  It's a little pricey, but if you're willing to spend money on good food, don't knock it til you try it. =)
author: Patricia B.

description: First off the food is good, the seafood is fresh, but the portions of food for the cost of the dishes are ridiculous.  You need your binoculars to see the ceviche on the plate, and other dishes as well.  You should be ashamed of yourself for what you are charging.  It takes forever to get drinks from the bar, 20 minutes for a pisco sour, you have to be kidding.   The table service is very slow!!!!   This restaurant is nothing compared to what it was when it first opened.  It went down hill a long time ago.
author: Adriana V.

description:
Overall I'm a fan of my experience at La Mar :)

We sat at the bar while we waited for a table, my boyfriend got a Pisco Sour and I got a Pisco Punch (Red Sangria).  I liked the Pisco Sour but I felt myself making a pucker face which I knew looked funny so I stuck with my Pisco Punch, which I loved!  After about a 10 minute wait we got seated outside in the sun and it would have been okay if we had some sunglasses but it was way to bright, we couldn't even read the menu. Luckily we got switched over to a table in the shade but still looking out to the water so we got to keep our beautiful view =)

We ordered the Papa La Huancaina , Lomo Saltado and Anticuchos De Corazó.  After we ordered they bought out yukon chips, plantains and sweet potato chips with 3 dipping sauces instead of your ordinary bread and butter.  My favorite was the fried plantains but by themselves, no sauce.  The Anticuchos De Corazó came out first and it was actually really good, the thought of eating beef heart is a little out of the ordinary but it was really good.  Just like really tender steak, I just wish they cooked it a little more so that it would have had a little crispiness to it.  The Papa La Huancaina was very good, I have never seen the purple potatoes before though and I thought the purple potatoes were a little harder than the other potatoes served in the dish.  And the Lomo Saltado was delicious but I really expected it to be.  If something was wrong with that dish I would be giving Lar Mar 1 star because the Lomo Saltado was what I was craving right when I walked in the door.  We were both very satisfied and both very full after our meal but when the waiter asked if we wanted to see the dessert menu of course I said, "Yes!"  And then I ordered the Picarones which were a really great ending to our meal.  Now we were both satisfied but overly full :)

So the service at first was a little slow, I think because they had seated everyone around the same time, but after we ordered it started to pick up.

I think Lar Mar was one of the places I felt I had to try at least once.  I'll be sticking with Estampas Peruanas Restaurant in Redwood City, it's where I left my Peruvian Foodie Heart at :D
author: Katie J.

description:
"Oh! Who are you and since when are you located here?"

I was happy to stumble upon La Mar last Friday. It's a very mucho muy BIG space with a couple of different seating areas -- this time we sat at the bar. It looked packed though so I recommend reserving in advance.

If you haven't had ceviche before, try the 'cebiche sampler'... it's 4 different ceviches, 2 classic ones and 2 with a more asian taste. The platter is meant to be a starter, but it may well be a nice dish to share if you prefer to focus on the wine and the plantain chips (my favorite); both wine and plantain anything :)

The Chilean wine we ordered was excellent and reasonably priced compared to it's Californian counterparts.


Our waitress was attentive and helpful. We also had the chance to meet Rodrigo, the Manager, he's the go-to man for sure.

I'll definitely go back, as soon as I can get a table overlooking the water.
author: Diana R.

description: Top of the line Peruvian food but very pricey.  Great location on the waterfront.  Hard parking unless you pay big time.  Drinks are also great.  Sit outside on a nice day.  You will not be disappointed here.  Great food, drinks, location and service.
author: David B.

description: LaMar-velous! Pricey, yes, but well worth the fresh ingredients and immaculate preparation. I love Peruvian food and have been fortunate enough to visit Peru multiple times. I have enjoyed many restaurants in Lima, Cuzco, Trujillo and others, as well as home-cooked meals. Los Angeles is also home to many good Peruvian restaurants, some "mom & pop" and some a little more upscale. Having said that, La Mar has taken Peruvian food to a new level without losing it's "soul"  If we had been in San Francisco longer, I would have gone back to La Mar again. We had 2 cebiches, the clasico and the norteno. Both were great! The cilantro infused norteno rice dish with mussels was also spectacular. We washed it all down with a few Peruvian beers, Crystal and Cusquena...oh yeah and some Pisco Sours!...Back to the $$$ issue...Pricey-Shmicey, you don't get a chance to eat like this all the time (I can't afford it!) :) ...can you get bigger helpings for less at some other Peruvian restaurant? Of course you can, but you can say that about almost any "high-end" place. It's the food, the service, the atmosphere (and the great group of friends that joined me! SHOUT-OUT to my peeps!!, Sarah, Paul and my Peruanos, Carlos and Franco!)...it's the total experience that made La Mar the memorable event that it was!  VIVA PERU CARACHO!
author: Steve T.

description: Long waits for waiter. After flagging him down 3 times with eye contact a manager type person asked what we would like and he got it for us. Waited forever for my wine while my fellow diner had theirs. Then another manager type came and asked us how we were doing...never our waiter. Our finished dishes were sitting forever on the table. Waited forever for dessert menus when the waiter took our place mats off the table and served our dessert  on the bare table. Our waiter finally came  and had the audacity to say he was glad we enjoyed our dinner when we never said we did. Major attitude and poor service!
author: Joan M.

description: Excellent food, well seasoned. Small portion sizes for price, but great presentation and service.
author: Bryan S.

description: The food was ok but we both ordered Pisco Sour cocktails and they tasted rotten.  We were in a hurry to catch the ferry so didn't send them back; we should have.  After two drinks we just left them sitting there - terrible.  The service was mediocre as well.
author: Chris H.

description: Some times a photo is worth a thousand words.  Just view the photos and you will see the great presentation and amazing flavors. The Pisco Sous were delicious and going down very easy - Service was a little slow, but not too painful.  Great location and views of the bay
author: Louisa P.

description:
Inattentive service and not great value.  Food was hit or miss.  The tasting ceviche on the menu ($24) was 50/50.  Two of the items were great -- 2 were REALLY boring.  And that's based on the opinions of 4 people at our table.  Good Bloody Mary's.

Fresca is MUCH better
author: SF Y.

description:
I had the great fortune of watching the chefs from La Mar refine their dishes in my Emeryville kitchen, a month or so before the restaurant's kitchen was finished. Testing and sourcing the best ingredients,  intensive practice sessions before opening--repeated and refined when the kitchen was finished on site. Last evening we went to a soft opening dinner, and every single dish sang to us. Four of us tried cebiches, causas, sopas, entrees and desserts (oh, the pumpkin fritters with fig syrup, you would not believe!)--and reveled in the clean flavors, outstanding quality and generosity. The space is beautiful, our server was top-notch, friendly, informed and eloquently enthusiastic about the food. Did I mention unpretentious?  No wine until Monday's opening, but the Pisco based cocktails were strong and excellent. 

Watching the crew in my kitchen, I know that the cebiches start with such lovely things as freshly made lobster stock and fish stock, and indeed you can get shooters of the Leche de Tigre bases for the ceviches, which are each distinctive, delicate and appropriate to the fish they are paired with. When you are first seated, you get a basket of fresh, greaseless crisp fried plantain, yam and potato chips and three dips--based on the special chilies imported from Peru.

This is going to be one of the most popular restaurants in SF, with good reason. Honest food, lovingly prepared by skilled chefs who want you to love what they are so proud to serve. How can you go wrong? Congratulations Gaston, and Jose Luis and the whole crew! Bravo!!!
author: Terry P.

description:
Very good quality, flavorful and innovative ceviches.
I highly recommend it for people who like sashimi. 

The 4-in-1 ceviche is probably the best, as you get to taste them all and it's a good deal. 

There's a paste dish called Picante or so, you should totally avoid it. It tastes like Macaroni and Cheese gone bad. 

The 4-in-1 flan for desert also was great. 

Overall, highly recommend the place, it's great quality, fun and interesting.
author: Honor G.

description: I have traveled through Peru and tasted Pisco Sour's in many Latin American countries. La Mar's piscos are the best I have ever had! I am going to rate the food as good, not great. I think the ceviche should have been served with some bread to dip in the yummy marinades. They could only offer us chips for dipping (that didn't work).  I had the Lomo Saltado as my entre. The meat was tender and the french fries were tasty.
author: Karen W.

description: Disappointment....yep, that's what I felt since the moment I sat down. The restaurant was half empty on a Thursday afternoon around 2pm. We sat down with my in laws, my baby and my toddler, anxiously waiting for my husband to find a parking spot close to the restaurant. I asked the waiter right away recommendations for my toddler's meal. She suggested a green tomatillo empanadas with rice, which promptly came before my toddler start asking for food. The rice was just white rise ( 5 bucks for a side of white rice?,!!!) she kept rushing so I ordered our food. The waiter had a slight ironic personality and annoying at the same time. I asked her if she had any salsa to go with the rice, who would want to eat just plain white rice after all?  She gave me a look like if I asked the weirdest question. My husband finally arrived and sat down, she came right away few seconds later. He didn't have a chance to look at the menu' and asked him to order right away because the kitchen was closing. Seriously? They should have warned us before,  would have chosen another restaurant . All our 5 entrees arrived at different time. So my husband and I finished eating our empanadas while my in laws were staring at us. The margaritas ordered ( 10 $ each for a tequila shot size ) arrived well after our food. The calamari came out half an hour after everything else. The bus boy was in hurry and kept akin away our plates, silverware and table clothes even though we were stilly ring to finish our meal. I didn't send much it e commenting on the food because everything we ordered was very ordinary and very well overpriced. This messy experience came out to be 169$ for 5 people excluding tips. I would give it another try maybe at a different time of the day but this time I would only order a glass of wine ( they can't cheat on that) and try their ceviche instead
author: Biemme B.

description: Amazing ceviche and other South American favorites, I love how energetic & bright this restaurant is. Is is a delicious change of pace from the American, local comfort-food restaurants that have been stealing the spotlight. If you want a change from red wine, dim lights and fancy mac & cheese, La Mar is the perfect fix.
author: Barndi K.

description:
When I walked past La Mar and looked in the window the place looked like it could sit maybe like 40 people comfortably. Then I realized I was just looking at their bar. 

I had a bet with a friend from LA that SF had better ceviche (in Peruvian Spanish it is spelled with a B) and La Mar helped me put my money where my mouth is. She left dumbfounded after eating 3 servings of various ceviche. We had the Nikei, which has tuna as the main fish, the daily chef's special with bonito and sea urchin and lastly we had the ceviche chifa--with mahi mahi.

To gulp it all down we used a nice light and crisp Argentine wine Torrontes Crio which was surprisingly delightful (it is a screw top wine and had I known I probably would have never ordered it).

Service was good and the restaurant is very ample. Making a reservation for weekend lunch and Friday/Saturday dinner is highly recommended as they are a restaurant in high demand.
author: Carlos V.

description:
im breaking my biggest yelp rule and giving this place 3 stars (everything is either a 1-2 or 4-5 in my book).

so this place was just blah. ok. boo-di-doo. overpriced. food was "good". the ceviche was not as amazing as i had expected. neither was the whole experience i guess. i was expecting a huge boom out of La Mar and all i got was a pop-crackle
author: Carolina S.

description: I'm giving this restaurant one star because the service is so incredibly bad and literally no one in this place (including the manager), gives a damn.  I have eaten here many times in the past and was willing to put up with the horrible service because the food and drinks are actually good.  However, after eating there yesterday and noticing that they raised all their prices and now charge $12 for a pisco sour and serve it in a glass comparable to a shot glass,  I will not be dining here again.  The bar was completely empty and I watched as five employees chatted and never helped me until I finally said something.  Note to La Mar: If you are going to raise your prices then you better make sure you have the service to match and keep your portion sizes the same or increase them, don't make them smaller.  I really just find this place a joke as it just seems like a gathering place for employees to goof off and act annoyed that they have to serve you.
author: Athena P.

description: Second visit...the popularity of the place has gone to the staffs heads...and what is supposed to be genuine Peruvian which I have had in Peru is now a San Francisco snob spot....I did have a nice cebiche tasting platter with 4 variations...and a Sangria Blanca, which is my new summer drink....had to buck the Pisco Sour trend of the SF transplants....worth a visit still but its over priced...
author: Gomerio G.

description:
Best meal I have had in a longgggg time!
I had never had "fancy" Peruvian food, I'm used to going to hole in the wall cevicherias, so I was skeptical going in but the food blew me away. 
The portions are quite big, so you can definitively share. We tried the ceviche sampler, causa sampler, jalea and fried rice.  The jalea...not too crazy about, it consisted of mainly fried calamari, but the rest of the dishes were outstanding, especially the fried rice. 
The restaurant is nice but not over the top or stuffy.  When you make reservations it might be a good idea to request a window with a view. I didn't and was a bit disappointed considering we waited 3 weeks for our reservation.
Not a fan of the desserts, but I would DEFINITIVELY go back for the food. We all left with big smiles plastered across our faces.
author: Mrs. G.

description: Very good place. Excellent cebiche, excellent pisco sour, good dishes, nice decor. I went several times and always had very good experiences.
author: Luca R.

description: HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE!!!!   TERRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE.  The waitress forgot the rice with my second course and she never brought my third course.  I spoke with the manager and while she was apologetic, she didn't offer to take anything off of the bill.  It was the worst customer service that I have ever received at an upscale establishment.  We also waited nearly an hour before we were served appetizers.  Avoid this tourist trap at all costs.
author: B A.

description:
3.5 STARS

This is a very pretty restaurant near the water. We had a lovely table outside on the patio during lunch but the interior is actually prettier to look at since there is not much to see outside.

We've been here a couple of times and have tried a variety of menu items, including all of the cebiches on the menu, and our favorite is the cebiche nikei--the fresh tuna marinating in the leche de tigre is delicious. It's citrusy and sweet and savory all at once with an asian flavor. I like it on top of the fried plantains. The grilled meats and the rice dish were fine but not dazzling. I was very pleased that our waiter got our son's order to the kitchen correctly and they executed a deconstructed fish sandwich to perfection.
