The service was decent. The prices were about what I would expect for the place. Sorta expensive for the portions, but comparable for the area and not exorbitant.

I did not drink. However, I did try an Inca Kola. It's the Coke of Peru! You will only like it if you are a kid because it tastes like bubble gum. However, they have an exhaustive wine list and an impressive drink menu. I shall return "off the wagon" and try accordingly. Shortly after my drink arrived, I also got complimentary chips and dip. The chips were good, and I tried the dips. I really just ate the chips though; I kinda hate condiments.

I had the iradito nikei which is translated as "Ahi tuna that is better than the best %$#@ maguro sashimi that you have ever had....EVER. Despite the fact that you are very well aware of the fact that tuna is totally high in mercury and that mercury poisoning is what made the Mad Hatter mad http://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/mad-as-a-hatter.html, you will totally continue to eat gobs and gobs of it so long as you can afford it because you will totally risk going postal and living out your final days by talking to yourself while doing the Thorazine Shuffle http://everything2.com/title/Thorazine%2520Shuffle and wearing a straight jacket because the awesome tuna is totally worth the risk of going crazy." And the hot guy working behind the "sushi bar" will ask you how you like it and you will say "amazing" and you really want to say "I think you're hot" and you don't because you have not eaten enough mercury that has made you crazy enough to do so. (Or maybe too much that has made you crazy enough NOT to....).

When the dessert menu showed up, hot guy behind counter suggested that I get the bignets with the oozing chocolate in them served with a carameley sauce and banana passion fruit ice cream (as in two flavors combined in the same ice cream...not two different ice creams) because it was his favorite. I was torn between that and the sweet potato fritters...but I figured hot guy may have good taste. I totally know why freakos love those deep-fried Snickers at the fair! Have you ever had hot, soft, fried dough encapsulating a hot, gooey, chocolately surprise of a center?!?!?!? No???? It's amazing! The coolness of the ice cream totally compliments the hot surprise of the chocolate. I recommend breaking the bignets in half, putting a scoop of ice cream inside, and then taking a bit. ZOMG. Amazing. Also, because hot guy felt like he had too much influence on my choice, he showed up to my seat with a sample of the sweet potato fritter. That too was amazing. 

I will be back. I will drink. I will have a different dessert. I will try another fish. Hopefully hot guy working behind counter will be there. And if he reads this, I'm in another "it's complicated" situation...but it's negotiable. ;)
author: Zulu Q.

description: La Mar serves Peruvian-style seafood with a definite tilt towards the Asian influence in Peruvian cuisine. We were very early for our reservation and had time to enjoy some of the very Peruvian cocktails on the menu. For appetizers we had their ceviche mixto, which is a pretty true representation of the original, and empanadas, which were more on the Asian dumpling side of things (Peruvians don't serve them deep fried). I had the Chorrillana for entree, and it was tasty but in the small side of things. I would classify it as more of a Peruvian-inspired fusion dish than traditional Peruvian. The picarones for dessert were perfectly true to tradition and delicious.
author: Carlos C.

description: Lovely, fresh ceviche!  There are plenty of reviews already so I'll just quickly say that everything tasted so fresh and the seasonings were just enough to add flavor without overpowering the seafood.  The decor and view completed the experience.
author: KL S.

description: We really enjoyed our dinner at this place.  The staff is friendly and the food is great.  Presentation is amazing.  I recommend this place to anyone visiting San Francisco.  This place introduced a Mexican and an American to Peruvian food and we love it!  We need a place like this in CHICAGO!
author: chely p.

description: had the whipped potato topped with crabmeat, lomo saltado (beef tenderloin), crema volteada for dessert.  The potato had good flavor to it but was very heavy.  The beef was overall good and tasty but nothing peruvian about it.  The dessert was the best of the three.  The chocolate creme was dense and heavy in flavor but made perfect contrast with the foam and there was a hint of spice in the dessert which made it so unique.  The food was overpriced and the restaurant was very loud.  Not a good spot to take a date and I really can't find anything peruvian about this place.
author: Heidi F.

description: i went to this rest 2 times like 2 to 3 years ago and the food was terrible i went back one month ago and i was so amazed with the food that couldn't believe everything is good the anticuchos was really juicy the picarones the syrup was perfect the causas looks and tasted delicious the ceviche was really good i took my cousin from LA to this place and he loved it the drinks and the desert was perfect the service is good it was a really busy night but i didn't have to wait that much.. we had a good time we will back
author: Aaron M.

description: good staff, and yes you can get there by boat ! Public restrooms, and they cater to people getting off a boat walking up the public ramp at pier one and a half. Really good food, prices are standard for SF.  This is where we tell friends to meet us at have a drink and hop on the boat, for an afternoon cruise of the bay. Hopefully the city fixes the other docks that are now in slumber, disconnected from the main dock. That means limited space, when it  is open it is open.
author: Joseph H.

description: My husband and I celebrated our 40th anniversary with dinner at La Mar, compliments of our children.  What a treat!  The food was delicious and brought back memories of our recent trip to Peru.  Can't wait to return.
author: Phyllis H.

description:
To say we are very disappointed is an understatement, We are not food critics, just regular folks who like good food, really good ambiance, and great customer service. Arrived just after 8 pm on a Sunday it took over ten minutes before anyone knew we were alive. The anticucho we ordered was cold (obviously it sat) and the place wasn't busy at all (can you imagine how bad service would get when they are busy?) The ceviche while tasty had a creamy texture about it (this is the first for me) the "lomo saltado" was prepared with the wrong onions (they used white & green onions, should be red onions), the meat was tender but had no flavor and the sauce had to much soy sauce (can't understand why soy sauce), the white beans were a bit undercooked, again the short rib was tender but again no taste and then came the dessert, we ordered the "picarones" only 3 small thin rings that obviously were probably cooked in very hot oil and came undercooked inside and overcooked outside, it was a sad site to look at, the plate was half empty. Beware of the drinks, they fill the small glasses with ice and there are no refills, not even for their "Chicha morada" which is a VERY inexpensive to make and it is made in large quantities. 
Seemed that their staff is not in sync, we had a busboy, and three other people delivering our food at different times, asking if we ordered something else, our waiter could have been present during the delivery of the food. On top of it we were sat outside in their patio, (even though there were plenty of empty tables inside) and before we were done the space heaters were turned off leaving us cold and making us feel unwelcome. 
Overall not a good choice, money not well spent. VERY DISSAPOINTED & EMBARRASED! as a Peruvian national I wanted to treat my husband to what based on the reviews lead me to believe it was a great restaurant. Remember not to judge a book by its cover.
author: Carli P.

description: La Mar was definitely a treat.  Even though the portions didn't appear large enough, there was so much variety and flavor in abslutely everything we ate.  By the time the main course came, we were stuffed.  The only thing I didn't like was that we had a 2 person table so close to our neighbors that we could hear everyone's conversations LOL.  I would ask for a table by the windows.  Also, our bill for 2 people, was about $170.  Of course we did sample some things, and had a drink each, but I thought that was still pretty high, for 2 people.  I would definitely go back there for a special occassion.
author: Anna D.

description: So, since my last comment we have had lunch a few times in this restaurant. The food is good but being Peruvian I was expecting a real Peruvian flavor on each dish. I guess they are trying to accommodate all tastes not only Peruvian ones. If this is considered a fusion style then I would have given it 4 stars. I like it but sure I am not a fan. Besides it is way to expensive for the food you get here. I suppose the price has to do with its location and patrons they want to have.
author: Renato E.

description: We have been to Lar 20-30 times since opening. Over the last several months the service and attitude of the staff seems to have declined. A couple weeks ago we had poor (i.e. no) service in the bar area and went to Oola instead. Then last Saturday night we arrived at 9pm and were told the restaurant was closed, but that we could eat in the bar. No problem, except we watched from the bar and several parties after us entered into the restaurant. So I called the front desk and asked if I could have a table and was told yes. Then when we went to the front desk I was told no. What gives? Then we went back to the bar and lost our table and thus we left without getting dinner. We went out for dinner again tongiht and thought about going to La Mar. In stead we considered going to to La Brasa (another Peruvian joint in Berkeley) and ended up at Skate's where we had a very nice evening.
author: Michael L.

description:
3.5 stars: The food is delicious. The cebiche is a must although I agree with other reviewers that Limon serves bigger portions. They serve the cebiche in four different flavors. The grouper is amazing (and a huge serving.)  

Mainly the service still needs ironing out.  The flow of service was strange. We didn't receive the opening "chips" with various flavored dips, which they serve instead of bread, until we asked another waiter. Sometimes the busboy took our order, or we saw the waiters talking amongst themselves about who was going to take the dessert order. However, all the waitstaff is friendly and informed about the dishes - a major plus. Lots of potential, and the service should become smoother with time.
author: GS M.

description: Yum!  The food was incredible.  I wish I could eat here everyday.
author: Tahir P.

description: First time here. The cebiche sampler and pisco sours were awesome. Our favorite cebiches were the classico and the chifa. Our server was perfect--I wish I could remember his name.
author: m t.

description: I had a good experience here except for the maitre d seating people too close to us when there was more than enough space to seat people elsewhere....amazing salad with hearts of palm....  Fantastic wine recommendation from the rarely seen waiter.  Amazing meal overall!
author: Melissa B.

description: delicious beef empanadas! the lomo saltado was good, not the best i've ever had, but good nonetheless.  the rice was undercooked, but eating enough platano fritos and lomo is filling enough!
author: Yolanda S.

description:
After travelling around the world (we live in China) and getting recommendations from San Franciscans here to try this place we were very excited about having our dinner there on the last night of our holiday. 
We walked by several days earlier and popped in to make a reservation and thought that everything was settled. Until I called in on the day we were supposed to have our dinner to say we were running a bit late and somehow they managed to lose our reservation. 
What do you mean "lose" a reservation? How does one lose a reservation? We were physically there when she put it in the computer and told us the date, time and name. 
How can the reservation then be lost several days later remains a mystery to me. 

The girl on the phone was not helpful at all so NO we decided we didn't want to come anyways and wait for a table. We went to have a nice steak instead and I'm not sure if I want to give this place another chance if we're in the neighbourhood. 
I wish we could have tried it
author: Michelle C.

description:
This is a 4.5 stars on my list. Beautiful food presentation in a beautiful setting. Great location on the pier and very friendly staff. This is definitely a higher level dining experience than I'm used to for Peruvian food. There's nothing bad I can say about this place,except the prices. Its a great place to go with a large group so you can order different things on the menu and be able to sample everything. 
I came here with  a group of people for lunch, we had the ceviche sampler, causa sampler and the empanada sampler to start. The ceviche was extremely fresh, there was a lot of variety of different fishes, scallops, octopus. Really was the best ceviche I've ever had anywhere. It just melts in your mouth. The causas were also really good, bite sized rolls in different flavors and colors. The empanadas were really flavorful, are a good change in texture, fried and warm versus the melt in your mouth, cool refreshing ceviche. The next thing I had were the skewered pulpo - grilled octopus. the octopus was sweet and fresh and cooked just enough that it was not chewy. very well flavored.
I would love to come back for happy hour and just have the ceviche and chips. Lunch or dinner would be good if you're looking to impress someone. Otherwise this is really going to break your bank account.
author: Lai T.

description: My husband and I come to La Mar about once a month.  Not only is the food delicious, but the space is gorgeous, and the staff is accommodating.  This is our definite "go-to" place before a night out since the Pisco sours and the extensive Sake list can really help get the weekend started.   Our regular favorites:  1. Cerbiche tasting, 2.  Chupe, and 3. the Lomo Saltado.   The desserts are yummy too!
author: Love P.

description:
It is difficult to imagine a setting more appropriate for a Bret Easton Ellis novel: big-city yupsters sipping pisco and sampling Chef Gaston Acurio's ceviche while the Dow slides to its lowest levels in a decade and the Pacific spray peals ominously onto the restaurant's back patio.  I would say that the only thing missing from this picture is a budding young sociopath, but the menu here is as manically superficial as Patrick Bateman and the service is one grade north of the American Psycho's gruesomest fantasies.

Tourists and local idiots can experience an abundance of Peruvian flavor here, as long as they are willing to pay a hefty fee for an array of minuscule amuse-bouche that will leave you anything but amused, let alone satisfied.  All this packaged in a frigid décor done up in the same cold, institutional style as the mental ward at SF General.

This is precisely where our waitstaff must have stumbled out of.  To begin, our courses were presented completely differently than how were they described on the menu.  By magic, Huancaína sauce with basil cilantro oil became "a kind of mayonnaise with aioli."  Our table would have loved to pair this with a dry Riesling, only our water and wine glasses remained unattended by the staff the entire evening.  No worries, we sipped on the rain water that was splashing onto our table and drank from the torrent that was flowing over our lady friends' toe-less shoes underneath.

Half an hour separated our third and fourth courses, in the meantime we collectively shifted our fifteen person table three feet with not even a suggestion of help from the utterly and inexcusably inattentive staff.  The manager who appeared (once one of us decided that even in this moment of celebration it was appropriate to complain) looked like a hobo who had just been hit in the face with a frying pan.  He was just as helpful.  When asked to describe the concept of La Mar he replied "It's Peruvian," and when we wondered aloud why half an hour had elapsed in between courses he answered "it's real busy in there."

An hour later and after a promise of a free round of cocktails that was never satisfied he re-emerged with a half-witted smirk and tried to present us with his business card so that we would come back.  I've met Asberger's sufferers who can better attend to social cues; the sound my jaw made when it smacked the table in response to this restaurant's total ineptitude in the areas of food service and management was quickly echoed by my fourteen companions' shrieks at the bill.

After being rained on, presented with measly portions that wouldn't have fed Kate Moss, waiting thirty minutes between said "courses," having empty glasses on the table at all times, and never being asked if we wanted coffee or digestifs, we were expected to cough up more than $1700.  Apparently, the management didn't see fit to offer so much as a single free dessert.

The bottom line is in this economy service like this will sink a restaurant, regardless of its chef's star power.  By the end of a three-hour dinner, we left hungry, broke, and resolved to never return.
author: Kevin B.

description: Took my parents here for their wedding anniversary and we had a good time overall. We ordered a ceviche, arroz norteno, pollo skewer, and a beef dish whose name I can't remember. The food portions were smaller than other Peruvian places I've been to, but each dish was delicious. We ordered the mahi mahi ceviche and there was literally only one piece of mahi mahi in it. I was disappointed with this dish. The Arroz Norteno matched very well with the beef dish. We complemented it all with a nice bottle of merlot and we had a nice time overall. Our server was kind enough to throw in a complementary dessert for my parents, which I thought was a nice touch. Price was reasonable and the ingredients were very fresh.
author: Joe B.

description: A fabulous lunch. Fantastic food, attentive service, and pure pleasure.
author: Ann A.

description: Amazing ceviche (sp?), delicious pupusas (sp?), tasty drinks and fairly mediocre paiella (sp?).  The service was great - our waitress was really helpful and gave us some great tips.  Ended up spending WAY more than intended but it was worth it.
author: Caleb R.

description: This place was fantastic.  Fresh, diverse Peruvian seafood dishes are the name of the game.  Can't go wrong with the Cebiche Mixto, which is a cebiche featuring tuna, clams, and mussels.  The Causa Sexy was a fantastic special item I experienced as well.  I split these two dishes with my wife, then we both did our own entrees, which might have been too much food, especially with the complimentary banana chips. The drinks and service are fantastic.  Our server, Oscar, even picked up on the fact that it was my wife's birthday and brought us a free desert.  I'd go back again and again.
author: Andrew K.

description: ABSOLUTELY GREAT!!!  Pisco Sours are the best, Causas, Empanadas,  Ceviche, and just about every plate I've had are all great.   The Restaurant has it all.
author: Joe L.

description: What a lovely place this is! And the food, THE FOOD.  Make sure to try the ceviche mixto, the ceviche classico, the arroz jugoso, and my absolute favorite: the cordero, which is a braised lamb shank and is utterly to die for!  The pisco sours are delicious too, so don't forget to have a couple of those.   And I've noticed that all the employees are attractive...that sure doesn't hurt either.  I can't wait for my next experience here!
author: Dawn L.

description:
Still awesome. Lomo Saltada and beef empanada so tender and juicy. The special seafood rice was incredible.
Unfortunately today the service was a little slow getting started but the food did not disappoint. 
Always a favourite.
author: Faisal M.

description: I enjoyed La Mar for the first time last week and boy was I blown away!  I loved the cebiche mixto, the cebiche clásico, and the empanadas de choclo.  The flavors were phenomenal!  For an entree (I know, if you share the plates, you too can taste the menu) I enjoyed the arroz jugoso, a traditional prawn soup.  It was amazing as well, but it did need a bit of salt which after adding, woke up all the wonderful flavors.  The service was exceptional.  Oh, one last thing, do not, I repeat, do not leave without having a couple of pisco sours.  You will be blown away.  The bloody lorcho cocktail is pretty darn good too.  Had to down grade by a star due to the fact that I arrived one night before closing and they had closed early...I even called first before leaving my home.  Was not happy.
author: Keith B.

description: Nice place.  Drinks were pretty good and the food is appetizing.  Not sure on the price as I was there for a company holiday party, but I'm sure it's reasonable!  The people there offer great service and the atmosphere is entrancing.
author: Joseph C.

description: This place is beautifully appointed, I love the decor! Beautiful restaurant right on the water. My experience up to now with Peruvian food has mainly been lomo saltado (steak stir fried with french fries) so this seafood centric restaurant was a nice change. I came here as part of a group of four and we shared everything. I really enjoyed the causas platter the best, Peruvian whipped potatoes topped with various seafood mixtures. The ceviches were good but I didn't enjoy them as much as the causas. I also really enjoyed the octopus skewers we ordered which were substantial and meaty. All the plates were presented beautifully and good for sharing. I highly recommend this place for groups.
author: Cathy T.

description:
We made a reservation for 8:45pm and they didn't sit us until 10pm.
They patched it up with free appetizers once we finally git our table. 
The food was good but they don't honor your reservations. big bummer.
author: Bia R.

description: Came here for my friends 30th bday on Saturday night.  This is a peruvian/chinese fusion restaurant.  I had never heard of that fusion before so it was an interesting exxperience for me.  We had a really late reservation.. and still had to wait about 20 minutes before we were seated.  I did enjoy the ambience-- very modern and chic feeling.  I also liked that they gave us a round table in the corner of the restaurant so we could all see each other.   I wasn't lucky enough to try the ceviche, however, from what I heard they were pretty delicious.  We did family style for the food as suggested by the waiter.  We were all hungry and the complimentary sweetpotato,plantain and potato chips were an excellent substitute to bread.. I wish there were more plantains though.. there were plenty of potato chips and the dipping sauces were very creamy and flavorful.  We tried the fritters as well.  I liked the lomo saltado ones but the chicken ones were too dry.  It was also quite pricy for 2 spring rolls and 2 little fried fritters.. ($16?).. For the entrees (in the $20+ range) we tried the lomo saltado, arroz jugoso (paella/rissoto) and tallarin saltado (chow mein noodles with seafood).  The entrees were all OK.  The lomo saltado flavor was good.. but really just reminded me of chinese stirfry.  THe filet in the lomo saltado saved it.. but the rice with corn was not tasty.  I liked the paella more-- it was creamy and more latin flavors.  Had a good amount of seafood in it as well.. but again portion was tiny.   The tallarin saltado was the most interesting dish of th enight.. chow mein with fried calamari, fish and mussels.. it was all tossed with a soy sauce.  I think a little spice may have kicked it up a notch.. This dish was tasty but a little on the greasy side.. but what chinese food isn't greasy?  Didn't get to try drinks or desserts.. next time !  All in all, food is decent however prices steep for amount of food given.  Nice location though.
author: Margie C.

description: I was a part of a party of 7 (two joined later) and we are all in the hospitality industry and pretty much can influence any of our clients, ranging from meeting planner, city employee to hotel and restaurant folks so we are one hard group to please.  Good for them and good for us, we all agreed that the meal was just fantastic. We ordered at least five plates of different ceviches, short ribs, sea bass, beef, drinks (pisco punch was delicious) and a plate of dessert to share. We left very satisfied and i have since told many of my friends and clients about this restaurant. Unfortunately, the service was just a tad better than average so I like to see the service go up a notch. I will definitely go back to make sure the food is as delicious as the first time and the service hopefully improved.
author: Bren L.

description: Love La Mar. It's our favourite place to dine in the city, and they do a great happy hour Monday through Thursday. Great cocktails too!
author: Michael C.

description: Fancy, way too expensive and the food not memorable at all. Servings the size too small to enjoy, but perhaps rent in this place is very steep for the location is seriously impressive. We all know San Francisco is way to expensive and this place is no exception. Certainly not the best ceviche, nor the best peruvian restaurant by a long shot. Food has changed from traditionally delicious to this fancy international flare type serving. Don't mind paying the extra cash but not for this place. Lunch for a party of 3 around $150 before tips, hungry almost immediately after. I guess the joke was on us!
author: Luis P.

description: I have been to several of Gaston Acurio's restaurants in Lima. He is the most renowned chef in Peru. His restaurants are amazing! The location of La Mar in San Francisco is stunning. It is on the Embarcadero overlooking the Bay. The bar is worth a visit as well. Try the pisco sour. It's the national cocktail of Peru. There cocktails are creative and very yummy. The restaurant is expensive but definitely worth it, especially for a special occasion or a romantic meal.
author: Denali M.

description: Top 20, unreal good! This is a great place next to the water on the Pier, the food was fantastic, reminded me of the Slanted Door, slightly better all things considered.
author: Troy S.

description: Some seriously delicious Peruvian food and excellent service at this place. We had the cebiche tasting, anticuchos de corazón (grilled beef heart skewers), lomo saltado and arroz norteño (seafood rice)--all were very tasty. The dipping sauces for the cebiche were really good. We finished everything. I've never had beef heart before, but a friend highly recommended it, and it was really yummy.
author: Susan P.

description:
This place was definitely worth it. It has been on my "to-try" list for-ever, or since it opened I suppose, as I love seafood and any food thats "non-american" food.

We made reservations for the same day for the lounge. We were seated along the seafood bar area which leads into the main dining room, which i guess is considered the lounge? There was also an area with couches...Anyways, this area was fine and we had a great view of the giant octopus in the glass case, as well as food coming out from the kitchen. 

I decided even before we got there that I had to order a pisco sour, which was delicious. Our waiter was helpful and let us order a few items at a time, since we weren't quite sure how much food we'd need and just wanted to share everything. We started with cebiche sampler and the causas limena. The cebiche clasico was my favorite from the sampler, the halibut was very tender. The ahi tuna was second favorite. I would just get an order of the cebiche clasico next time and skip the others. Causas we also very good. Next up for our food order, and another pisco sour later, we asked the waiter about the octopus skewers. He was very helpful and told us how the octopus was cooked and that it was very good. This helped me to convince the fiancé to order it, since he was a little skeptical about ordering octopus at first. I was so glad we ended up ordereing the octopus because it was so delicious, I totally loved it and so did the fiancé! We also ordered the empanadas del mar, which came with a spicy dipping sauce, yum! This was the perfect amount of food for us. 

I regret not trying the desserts, as they sounded awesome, but we'll have to try one next time. The price was a little steep, especially at $10 a cocktail, but totally worth it since the food was so good. Great atmosphere and location.  I can't wait to come back and try more of the menu!
author: Carolyn K.

description: Great atmosphere....   Ceviche was some of the best I have ever had...   A bit pricey but worth it on special occasions
author: Matthew S.

description: Loved it! Had dinner there tonight with a friend. She's eaten here several times, but it was my first time. I had the Cebiche Mixto (YUMMY!) and for my entree, I had the Lomo Saltado. Enjoyed saying it as much as eating it. The steak was cooked to perfection. My friend had the Arroz Norteno. I was stuffed (we both were) that there was no room for dessert and the dessert menu looked delish! My Cholopolitan was yummy and so was my friend's Santa Maria cocktail. The different chips (plantains, sweet potatoes, etc.) was a great starter with the different dipping sauces (hot to mild). We were stuffed.  Was a great dinner and wonderful ambiance. Will definitely go back for girls' night out again to try the other cebiches and entrees...and hopefully dessert too =).
author: Neni E.

description: This was my first time coming to La Mar but my co-worker highly recommended it. So I decided to throw a surprise shindig for my mother here. When I arrived yesterday we were promptly shown to our table. Prior to arriving I had checked their menu online but I ended up bringing a small fruit tart since I didn't see a dessert menu. When it was time for dessert our waitress had the pastry chef warm up the tart I brought prior to serving it. The food was delicious. I myself am not a fan of ceviche but this ceviche was amazing. Honestly, I cannot stress enough on how phenomenal the staff is here. Our waitress went above and beyond. I will definitely be coming back.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Let me start off by saying the food is 4-5 stars-easy. Halibut ceviche, lomo and crab causas were delicious. Additionally, we enjoyed our variety of pisco cocktails too. Ambiance and setting are also nice/great/cool. Patio looks intriguing on a nice night out.

The service on the other hand was inconsistent and borderline awful, so much so that la Mar only gets 3 stars. We start with waiting for a hostess to appear for several minutes. We're early-have a drink in the bar. Splendid idea! Piscos are ordered. Several minutes later, our table is ready. Hostess then checks with the waitress and to then tell us she'll bring to us. At the bar. Huh? several more minutes elapse, and upon seeing our waitress opening a bottle of wine for a group of 6, we head to the hostess table. Several more minutes go by before she returns and we are seated. (the bartender also seemed to no hable ingles as I was leaving a tip for the waitress). Our ne wwaitrees is awesome: nice, knowledgable, attentive but overzealous. The servers are just as efficient. But whats this? Someone sweeping up crumbs, etc with a dustbin on the dining floor? Are we now at the Greyhound station? WTF, La Mar?!...No "have a nice night" from the hostess on the way out after eye contact either. So weird.

Considering it was their 2nd year anniversary its very surprising, and annoying, to have such lame and hot&cold service. We'll be back for round two though.
author: Tripp S.

description:
Pluses:  yummy plantain and potato chips with spicy dipping sauce, pretty good food.

Minuses: It's kind of a strange space and feels a bit like an airport or hotel restauarant - pretty impersonal.  The service is HORRENDOUS.  I think I can say with relative safety the worst service I have ever received.

Our waitress, Debi (named and shamed), was extremely attentive at the beginning of our meal.  She was a bit over the top with her cheeriness and slightly condescending (was dining with my boyfriend and we were both in jeans - but so were most of the other patrons since, despite being expensive, this place is not fancy) but she was prompt with our waters and drink orders, and explained the menu to us.

The turning point was when she came to check on us as we were eating our entree.  We assured her that everything was great and she responded with "It's yummy isn't it? Mmmmm!"  in much the same tone one would use with a picky two year old.  As she walked away I asked bf in disbelief, "did that just happen?" and we both laughed.

Perhaps she heard us?  Service completely ended from that point on.  A busboy gave us dessert menus when he took our plates away and after making eye contact with our initial server and others several times to no avail, we eventually flagged down a busboy to ask him to tell Debi we wanted to order dessert.  During this time she had gone to every single table around us and it seemed to be a deliberate slight.  After speaking to the busboy, she eventually came over to where we were sitting at the ceviche bar and STILL did not acknowledge us.  Instead, she asked the couple beside us, who had already received their check and were taking care of it, if she could get them anything else.  Then she finally turned to us and served us in the same over-cheerful, condescending manner, ignoring our obvious irritation.  We practically had to beg for the check and had the credit card ready so she couldn't leave us sitting there for another 20 minutes.  She referred to us as "kids" - a bit of a stretch and certainly rude.

We complained to the hostess on the way out but after reading other Yelp reviews for this place it doesn't seem to be an isolated incident. We will not go back to La Mar.
author: Jane F.

description:
yay for happy hour! yay ya-ya. 

so la mar finally got it's act together and realized people are losing their jobs left and right and don't want to pay $9 for a cocktail anymore and finally put together a decent a happy hour menu. (of course they're not entirely fooling me--i noticed the cocktail glasses got smaller, so you are actually getting a bit less than the $9 drink, but for $5 it's still substantial enuf and a much better deal.) plus they have a red and a white for $5 and beers for $3 i think. 

the pisco sours are super-fino here. if you don't already know--pisco is peru's national liquor and it's basically unaged bourbon. this drink is light and refreshing, but be careful not to drink too many cause it's a lil sweet and probably would give you a nasty hangover. 

we shared a couple empanadas, the chicken and the corn--both were delicious--tho still a lil pricey at $4 each, i think in buenos aires they're like $2 each and three times as big, but hey, this is SF. and we also had a ceviche with very asian influences that was awesome. i want to try a few other things on this menu and i think HH is the way to go. 

fyi--i love the decor here. a palette of crisp clean white, brown wood and vibrant teal feels sleek, fresh and sexy. but the dining room is a lil too mega restaurant for me. i like to sit in the bar towards the front.
author: rachel p.

description: I would give this place a 5 star if the hostess was nice.  She was incredibly rude and non-emotional like a robot.  We went here to celebrate my friend's birthday today and everything was perfect.  The food, the ambiance, the decor, our server (Giovani), our wine.  But the first thing you do as you arrive at any restaurant is see and interact with the hostess.  Either she was in a super bad mood or this is how she is.  I would suggest that you change your career.  Unfortunately, I didn't ask for her name b/c there were several hostesses (a gentleman who was super nice, another young lady who was also very bubbly and nice, and then this other person with black her but that's all I remember of her b/c I tried to forget about her as quickly as possible and honestly I did. LOL).  Other than that we had a very amazing and memorable time here.  The view was also very nice.
author: Parastoo E.

description: Oh La Mar...I do love you. Never disappointed whether it be lunch or dinner. A fan of all the ceviches. Empanadas are delish except the corn one. Not for me! Ambiance is just gorgeous as can be. Nice to stop in for drinks as well. If you're new to this place, try the sampler...won't be disappointed.
author: Lola D.

description:
Four of us had a very unpleasant experience at La Mar.  First, while two of us waited for the 2 parking, they took away one place setting, even though they confirmed there were 4 on our reservation. Then, they failed to bring a fourth menu. When we couldn't get anyone's attention, our guest got up and found a waiter that gave him one, but it turned out to be an old menu. Eventually the waiter realized it was old, and replaced it.  Then they brought us appetizers and one was not what we ordered.  They eventually brought the correct one.

Worst of all, they failed to bring one entrée and told us they thought our male guest was sharing it with my husband!!  I still haven't figured out why they thought he would share with someone other than his wife, if he intended to share with anyone!!  So my husband and I, and his wife almost finished our dinners before his entrée came. The waiter said it was the kitchen's mistake, but we heard another waiter tell him he only ordered 3 entrees.

Nothing was provided complimentary to make up for all of this and no manager came to our table to address the many mistakes.  So, embarrassed and frustrated, my husband sought out the manager on duty.  She never came to the table to apologize to our guest.  She did follow up with an email to me, but after I explained all this to her again, she didn't bother to respond!  I wish someone - anyone - had made an effort to make it right.  It was a big disappointment. There are hundreds of very good restaurants in SF, so we won't go back to La Mar.
author: Von H.

description: Everything here was amazing! The empanada tasting plate featured four distinctly different flavors and mahi ceviche was the best I've tasted. The ambiance is South Beach sleek and the wait staff was attentive and helpful. Highly recommended for visitors and locals alike.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Ive gonne to a Cebicheria in Lima and I must say La Mar sits side by side with that place.

Very well prepared stuff, with great attention to the details, flavor!

Definitely will recommend to any friends visiting San Francisco.
author: Jose C.

description: I went for happy hour and it was perfect. Wel,l the cebiche classico wasn't the best i had (perhaps the mahi mahi is not as good in ceviche as halibut or other kinds of white fish?), I just got back from Peru about a week ago and the best is at Sonia, but it wasn't bad. The empanada was perfect as good as you can get in South America and even better. . And the pisco sours were not bad, neither were the peruvian beers at $3 a piece. Looking forward to many more happy hours to try more food and more cocktails.
author: Chris D.

description: We had a glorious meal at La Mar.  The food was incredible... colorful, and artfully presented,  The Causas are delicious. The ceviches are wonderful.... melt in your mouth and so tasty.  Try the yummy empanadas, lomo saltado and exquisite trumpet mushrooms and, last but certainly not least... the scrumptious desserts!  Beautiful setting.  Pisco sours are the best I've ever had.
author: Gail W.

description: Decent appetizers, and drinks in the bar. It's a really good value during happy hour.
author: Robert D.

description: Ceviches wonderful. 5 stars if we hadn't gone on to the causas, good, but come on, potatoes are, well, potatoes. Solid staff and no rush.
author: Roy F.

description:
As a Peruvian- born and raced;
I think this is -by far- the best peruvian place in the bay area. I have had better peruvian food ofcourse in Lima and even in NY but ever since I live here I have tried every single one of the peruvian places they have opened and let me tell you La Mar is the best.
Yes, its over priced but come on... the places is beautiful... and the fact of it being expensive makes it sort of attractive... I cant afford to go there every weekend but I'd go for special occasions.
Try the Leche de tigre shots. its the ceviche sauce.
and the Arroz norteno. But you know what- EVERYTHING is pretty close to perfection. 
LOVE IT THERE!
author: Fabiola C.

description:
cebiche or ceviche...whatever you want to call it, la mar has become one of my favorite dining spots in the city.

located on pier 1 1/2 and along the bay, the ambiance of the restaurant is great for any occasion.

they also can accommodate large parties with pre-fixed menus.  some of my favorite dishes consisted of:

cebiche chipotle (ask for extra habanero if you like it extra spicy)
mushroom risotto (large portion)
seared ahi tuna with a passion fruit sauce
purple potato causa with ahi tuna
author: Carli F.

description: Went to Le Mar for dinner on a Sunday night; I thought this place was excellent, although my least favorite dish was actually the Ceviche Clasico. Thought the food was very tasty, did not sample the bar menu.
author: Eric O.

description: Fantastically complex and fresh cebiche! First time eating Peruvian and this was absolutely wonderful...will tell everyone I know!
author: Kevin B.

description: We love this place.  It's a bit pricy, but that's to be expected anywhere near the Ferry Building.  We usually get an assortment of ceviche, causas (whipped potato cakes), empanadas, and anticuchos.  The corazon (beef heart) is great, really rich flavor.  The classic ceviche is also fantastic, as is the causa nikkei.  It's essentially a spicy tuna run on top of a tasty potato base.  The desserts are good too; we particularly like the ice cream with the rice foam on top and the pumpkin fritters.  The service is excellent.  Our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive without being smothering.  Expensive, but well worth it.
author: Jordan W.

description:
The beef empanadas are calling my name! I can hear them...

I know cebiche is supposed to be the star in this place, and their cebiche chifa was certainly good and perfectly tart, but what really stood out for me were the beef empanadas (I hear you calling...I'll be right there...), and the steak skewers.  Oh, and their sweet potato chips.  Oh, and their causa limena and causa casera.  And before you ask, I was with 3 other people, so I was not alone in eating all this food!  Not that I would have minded, because they were all delicious!  The portions are similar to what you would find at a tapas place, so you definitely want to come with a bunch of gluttons just like yourself who will eat up everything in sight.  And maybe a sugar daddy/mommy or two to pick up what will sure amount to a substantial tab.  Luckily for me, I was being wined and dined by a vendor who would like to get more business from me, and as they learned that day, I ain't no cheap date.
author: Meg P.

description:
Came here for dinner on a friday, party of 2   Reservations essential for dining room!  Good food (highlights: free plaintain chips w/dip and the chocolate donut ball dessert), but kind of pricey.  Service is spotty but not horrendous.

There are several seating areas:
-Bar at the front.  Loud, crowded at happy hour.  Convivial. 
-Hallway-ish lounge area between the bar and dining room.  A bit more mellow.  Has coffee table-type seating.  
-Bar counter in the dining room.  Good option if you don't have rezzies for dining room, but you may be staring at octopus or fish heads as you eat.
-Dining room.  Airy, spacious!  Based on some reviews, I thought it would be much noisier than it was.  Didn't feel like I needed to shout or speak louder than normal.
-Outdoor patio. Not sure how the seating here works.  It looked like only half the patio was open for seating.

Food: 
-Everyone here is right to rave about the free plaintain chips they serve.  And the three dipping sauces, yum!  I could eat those all day.
-We spit 4 appetizers and 2 desserts:
1. Cebiche classico-- delicious.  The other ones seemed a bit funky.  We wanted the straight up good stuff.  Plus, we tasted this at the SF Street Food festival.  The sauce that the fish is marinated in is perfectly sour/spicy.  The fish could have used a bit more time sitting in the marinade.
2. Grilled Octopus skewers-- Tender, delicious.  Like some sort of a rub on it, so good. So flavorful.  Got this b/c of the yelp reviews and it did not dissappoint.  Dining companion likened this to something that would come out of Bobby Flay's kitchen.  Three skewers to an order.
3. Causa - crab.  This was just ok. Basically it's like a golf ball of crab mix (a bit creamy for my taste) on top of a cylyndrical mashed potatos.  The dish is very mushy--could have used some textural variation.  Also, with all the potato, it's on the heavier side.  Three to an order.  This was probably the least favorite thing I ate.
4. Chicken Empanadas.  Delicious.  Seemed lightly fried, not too heavy on the carb wrapper like some places.  Two empahanadas to an order.
5. Chocolate donuts balls.  If you love chocolate, you must get this!  Four little dough balls filled with warm gooey chocolate.  Like a chocolate explosion in your mouth.  
6. Lucuma Tiramisu w/lucuma ice cream - Not too sweet.  An interesting take on tiramisu.  balanced out the sweetness of the chocolate donuts.  Seemed lighter, but I am sure it was not.

Overall, food was delicious.  I want to try other things on the menu.

Service: spotty, as reviewers have noted.  We had to ask the server to bring out the plaintains/dips, and it arrived after the cebiche.  We also had to ask a couple times for water.

If you get a chance, go outside and walk around the place-- you can walk right by the kitchen which has an open window and watch the chefs at work.
author: Caroline I.

description: Everything I have tried here is delicious. The fish is so fresh and flavorful. The portions are substantial. The drinks are delicious. The staff is friendly. The decor and location are pleasant and relaxing. The clientele is not what I usually aim for -- business types, tourists. But, once you are seated you don't notice the other patrons. It is an expensive place to dine, but worth it if you are in the mood.
author: sadie r.

description: If you would like to experience the flavors of Peru, this is the place! from your first step into the restaurant the customer service was welcoming and our waitress was most accommodating, professional and with good personality, which helped to make our visit pleasurable. The food was bursting with flavor, smooth, not overwhelming, delish in my point of view. Ambiance is very San Francisco with Peruvian flair. Great place to eat. We'll be back.
author: Linda Y.

description: um, yea.  this place was super tasty.  My man and I were having a foodie vacation and we were originally headed for the slanted door based on a recommendation, but when they were closed on labor day (with no indication on their phone recording) we stumbled upon La Mar and sat at the bar. The great bartender helped us choose some super tasty plates (about 3) and some awesome drinks to pair.  Sadly I cant remember everything we had, but I do remember that I savored every bit of it.  I will definitely be back the next time I'm in San Fran.
author: Cindy M.

description: Love the staff!  Love the food! Love the professionalism of the staff in always accomodating my requests to have dinner in a particular location in the restaurant.  The staff is ALWAYS positive, friendly, and so informative about the menu and the ability to have a conversation with a personal touch!  Have celebrated my anniversary, my sister's babyshower and dinner with grilfriends.  Excellent place for any event!
author: P A.

description:
Close your eyes and imagine paradise... that is what La Mar Cebicheria looks like inside. The restaurant reminds me of the Caribbean with bright blue pillows and a wide open space much like you would find on a tropical island, yeah, well...in paradise. The only difference is instead of the pale turquoise Atlantic its the beautiful bay! 
They have fabulous outdoor seating...(Which is where you will find me with a pisco sour in my hand!) The Classic Pisco Sour is Peru's version of a Margarita and Oh my goodness it tastes so refreshingly delicious! I haven't had a drink that I liked so much in a looong time. As soon as you sit down they place plantain chips and three sauces (Peru's version of salsa) on the table...My waitress was Michelle and she was not only attentive and polite but very informative...I left feeling like I had just attended a class on Peru's food and culture! Five stars all the way for Michelle, what a sweety! She helped guide my mom and I through the menu so that we ordered the perfect amount of food meanwhile trying a nice variety of the menu... we ordered a variety of ceviches and causas (Peruvian whipped potatoes w/seafood) that to my surprise resembled sushi! The food was all delicious, the ambiance is killer (seriously on vaca in that place) and the pisco sours are fantastic... since I can't afford a vacation during these tough times, chances are, your going to find me sitting outside la Mar with a Pisco sour in hand....go ahead call me Norm Peterson and this is my Cheers!   
See you soon Michelle!!
author: Michele K.

description: You cannot have a decent conversation in here because the place is bustling w/ noise. The food is quite overrated where everything starts tasting the same because they use the same sauce on all of the food. We ordered about 5 different dishes (tapa style) so I will have to say that I didn't just order the wrong item. Also, I haven't tried their main dishes but I don't think I'll be back to try it.
author: Randy L.

description:
The first time I went to La Mar it was mouth watering, the food was outstanding. However with time (I have gone 3 additional time within a 2 year period) the quality of the food decreased in a way that I wouldn't recommend this place for a full meal anymore. 
The happy hour (ask for a pisco sour!) however is REALLY good, and the appetizers are nice. I would for sure recommend this place for happy hour, but that's about it. 
It saddens me to write this review, because I am peruvian and I was really excited that a peruvian restaurant with such a high reputation had open in San Francisco.
author: Maria Fe L.

description: Great cerviche!  Stick to the classic version!  Great service and beautiful location. What's not to like?
author: Yenyi F.

description: First off, it was a beautiful November day. Sun was shinning, good friends, a couple of nice cocktails with a very good lunch. The free public pier  behind this place was great pulled right in. Not even a meter. lol. Overall a good experience
author: Jeff K.

description: Off the hook fabulous! Great vib, pow explosion of flavor, nice staff, with every pricy sheckle the charge!
author: David O.

description:
Wow I had no idea this place was so large. We ate on the enclosed patio along the water, on a warm night, and the restaurant and two bars were really buzzing. 

The servers were really careful to help with the menu, and we really loved the pisco sours while we waited for the cebiche to arrive in all kinds of formats (we loved the sampler plate)

I'd recommend this place for sure.
author: Rick R.

description:
awwww dang, that was a nice meal!

ceviche classico....it had a nice flavor to it...i'm not huge into raw fish, so no real point in me giving you my assessment of this....

we got the empanada sampler...nice, flaky bundles of loveliness...need i say more?

the highlight for sure was the una, which is this croquette of crab, prawns, chicken....it's served over bok choy, and this crazy good sauce....definitely has some asian influence in this one...wait, excuse my while i wipe some of my drool of this keyboard here....

lomo saltado...the fillet was nice and tender....although the garlic fried rice was probably my favorite part of that dish...wonder if you can just order that by itself?

the peruvian chips....if you knew me you'd know that i don't say "no" to fried starch....

dessert was good...the sweet potato fritters and the tiramisu with lucuma ice cream...both were tasty.... 

the service was attentive and good.  the atmosphere was pretty cool...we sat in the patio....overlooking the bay....it's somewhat enclosed and there are heating lamps, so unless you have Reynaud's syndrome, you'll probably do fine.  it wasn't cheap, but it wasn't outrageous either....we kinda over-ordered anyway...i could seriously just order the una and empanadas and i'd pretty stoked.....next stop: Peru....
author: Miss P.

description: This was some of the best food I've had in a long time. Luckily, I've spent time in Lima, where I fell in love with Peruvian food and La Mar did not dissapoint. We ordered empanadas to start with, and all were very good- and in an odd twist the two veggie options were the standouts. The mushroom empanada was the table favorite (we had to carefully divide it among three) and the corn was a close second. I had the halibut/chorillana and it was amazing, my colleagues had the tallarin saltado and scallops respectively and there was not talking while eating. We had a picky eater with us so we skipped the ceviche but on my next trip out I'll make a special trip to experience that section of the menu. God bless chile aji!
author: Jeff L.

description: It was my wife's birthday so this was like our third time having dinner  at La Mar. The food is and has always been excellent. Honestly, everything on the menu is good or better! The short ribs melts in your mouth, it's that tender!  You have to go and see their website to see the complete dinner menu. A great selection of red and white wines. My favorite is the Martin Alfaro - Pinot Noir. This is a medium body wine with a very smooth finish! Oh, and most importantly, was our waitress Tilde(say it with an spanish accent, her grandmother does) whose professionalism and recommendations was right on the money. The place is kinda pricey for dinner, but then, there's always the bar where you can order a drink and apps on the cheap side.
author: George F.

description: The food was pretty tasty but the service in the bar was really slow and the waiter forgot an item. I'll give this place another try but will definitely make a reservation and dine in the dining room.
author: Juan F.

description: Beautiful spacious interior and setting by the bay.  Recent lunch was excellent: ceviche (prawns, squid, lobster),  and "Peruvian" pork belly sandwich.  Service was professional and friendly.
author: Eugene P.

description: Stopped in on a Sunday afternoon and caught the happy hour.  Tried a bunch of things as the prices were inviting.. Pisco Sours, white ceviche, mussels, fried yucca, fried banana chips.  Our Server was helpful and friendly,Even providing a few things to do on a Saturday night for us tourists.  At the end of the meal, they provided toasted corn, too.  Having been to Lima and eaten at Cevicherias there, we can say this gets a thumbs up.  Yummy...Delicioso!
author: Maria S.

description: On 1/5/11 went with T and Nena.   All tried specialty cocktails.  My Peruvian mule was strong, not too sweet, different tasting (good use of lime) and worth doing again.  Tried 4 ceviches.  The ahi one was sublime.  Other 3 were very good.  Skewered grilled scallops very good.  Empanadas ok except the vegetarian one which was exceptional.  Two main courses.  First was a risotto with scallops that was killer.  Second was a seafood mix in a spicier sauce atop a mound of pressed risotto like goo that was very worth doing again.
author: Matt S.

description:
Went there for lunch today. Awsome, awsome, awsome. Gaston Acurio is the MAN!

Everything was great. We got the jalea and papas rellena for an appetizer. The jalea was huge and maybe we could have called the appetizers lunch for the three of us, but we also got ceviches. I got the classico and just like everything else, it was really good.

I think that the place (based on what I had and saw) really captures all of the different flavors of Peru. The Cechuan, African, Chinese and Japanese are all there. I also thought that compared to other places, the value was really good (take note Limon fans).   

Just too bad they don't have cuy and chicha de jora and I'd be all set, but I won't let that color my review.
author: Nacho R.

description:
La Mar is great - the atmosphere, service, and food!  

Two of us went, tapas style, and got:
Cocktails - 
  Pisco Sour - really tasty
  Pisco Punch - good, but the Pisco Sour was better

Tapas (starting from the favorite):
causa limeña - AWESOME!!  Crab mix on top of whipped potatoes.  You should try this
cebiche nikei - great quality tuna (and I don't really like sashimi or ceviche), the marinade was amazing 
empanadas de ají de gallina - yummy chicken empanadas
salmon skewers - cooked and seasoned very well

Desserts:
We got the picarones, which are basically little fried tasty donuts with honey for dipping.  Mmmmm....

Everything we had was good and I would love to try more!
author: L L.

description:
My boyfriend and I had a lovely meal here on New Year's Day.  I had been to Peru in 2007 and I had eaten at Astrid y Gaston when I was there and was blown away by the meal.  The meal we had at La Mar was a 4.  Ambiance and decor were lovely, although the music was slightly louder than I would have liked.  

To start, I had two lovely although slightly strong pisco sours, which totally reminded me of Peru. We had the causa tasting and empanada tasting samplers for appetizers, sharing both between the two of us.  I am a huge fan of causa and all but the vegetarian one were amazingly good (I wish there had been more!).  Of the empanadas, the lomo saltado and sweet corn one were the two standouts.  

For the main course, my boyfriend had the lomo saltado, which was excellent.  And for myself, I had the gnocchi arequipenos.  The purple potatoes seem to be harder to form into gnocchi, but it was delicious, with different types of seafood and fava beans. 

Dessert was my main disappointment of the evening.  We ordered queso helado (him) and picarones (me).  I am sorry to report the picarones were not the heavenly experience I had when I went to Astrid y Gaston in Lima .. I was so disappointed that I stole my boyfriend's dessert because it was far yummier than my own.  

After 3 hours, we left very satisfied with the meal .. we'll be back again soon!
author: Beth L.

description: Great pisco cocktails. We enjoyed the civiche sampler, my favorite was the yellow-tail. Empanadas where good, my favorite was the cheese and corn.  Dessert was great. Our server was a sweat woman from Lima.  The busser was a bit obtrusive trying to take our plates before we were done, but overall it was the best Latin restaurant experience I have had in years. It is located right on the water and I was told they do a great happy hour.
author: fred j.

description: 5 stars for the dipping sauces alone.  La Mar generally rules.
author: Gina K.

description: My overall impression-everything is a little overpriced.Potatoes as an ingredient are CHEAP.Next time I should try Happy Hour-and I would be happier.
author: sue n.

description: Great happy hour place!  I loved the signature pisco sour everyone was drinking.  Who knew that lemon/lime and egg whites could make such a yummy drink!  The happy hour appetizers were tasty and well priced.  I plan to come for dinner next time.
author: Kara H.

description: I had dinner here on Tuesday night. The food is just plain amazing. I was with a certified seeafood snob and everything passed her test with flying colors. A great place for a wonderful lunch or dinner. Beautiful wine list as well. Had a 2004 tempranillo which was a great value at under $40 a bottle.
author: Bradley H.

description:
I was looking forward to eating here and I finally got to try it today but was a little disappointed with the food but everything else was GREAT. 
The restaurant was beautiful with a lot of colors and very spacious. I felt like I was on vacation. The server was sweet but spoke way too fast and it was hard to understand her but she helped me pick my appetizers and entrees. 
We ordered the Ceviche classic, Lomo Saltado (steak dish) & Tacu Tacu Norte (special of the day, fish and shrimp over rice). The total was $75 for just lunch and we had no alcohol or dessert. 
If the food was excellent I wouldn't complain about spending the money but it was just OK. I had to ask for hot sauce to put on everything which made it taste 100% better. The best part of the meal was the FREE basket of chips (yucca, plaintain, potato). 
I don't think I'll go back for lunch or dinner but I'll probably go back for drinks on a beautiful sunny day. It brings back memories of when I was in Miami..
author: Deb C.

description:
La Mar is one of my favorite places for lunch.  The place is big, comfortable and in a great location on the bay.  Sitting outside on a nice day is great fun.  I don't know how they do it, but there are no issues with sea gulls as is the case at the ferry building just a couple blocks away.  The cebiche is excellent - always refreshing.  Another "I don't know how they do it"... the calamari in the cebiche is always extremely tender.  They used to include a slice of habanero on the cebiche, but no longer.  I enjoy that heat with the acid of the cebiche and they are happy to bring some habanero on request. Yum!  Only 4 stars vs 5 as the service is sometimes uneven.  Don't try to press lunch into an hour - although there have been times when the service was excellent.  The best service I have had at lunch was by a new server.  There was also excellent service one day when Gaston Acurio was there.  Some of the menu changes over the past year or so are odd.  They used to do two sizes of cebiche and the larger size was excellent for a full lunch.  Now its only one size offered and its more of an app size.  The chip basket is now served with only two sauces - the third, spiciest, is gone.  (is this a theme...is it whimpy SF gringos and 'tourists in tennis shoes' complaining about the spice of the habanero and the now missing sauce?...could be, but its unfortunate.)    Also, the arrzo noteno is no longer on the lunch menu.  :( it was my favorite.  I hope La Mar reads this and considers bringing it back.  
Bottom line,  amazing, fresh seafood.  You won't be disappointed in the food and don't be in a hurry - enjoy the beautiful surroundings inside or out.  And, I don't find lunch to be expensive. Considering the quality of the ingredients in all La Mar's dishes, I think its an amazing value.
author: R Y.

description:
overall? delightful.

:) had a fabulous lunch to be....THANKFULLY ON A NON RAINY DAY.. boo rain, go away, i hatechoo... leaves me with nothing to spare and sip wine in front of a fireplace... anyhow, its unfortunate we weren't able to make ressies for dinner that we decided to opt for lunch ... 

la mar ... 

super fresh and super yummy...

thee ONE restaurant everyone in peru seem to line up to get in -- no reservations are accepted, (BUT thank god sf has opentable and has made its debut, off the embarcadero, off pier 1...

i took 4 pictures for your eyes ... first off, the interior... the colors are brilliant! mix of ocean blue, orange, green, you just feel extremely calm ... funky yet a fun blend of colors.

for starters, they give you complimentary chips/plantanos with 3 diff types of sauce.  we then ordered their cebiche tasting for $28 which gives you a variety of diff types of cebiche, and it was super fresh and yummy.  

then, we went for another tasting of causa which is some potato type thingie which came out in purple and yellow. the presentation was beautiful. super bright and super fun. this was a good choice, but for $17, i think they could put another one in:) each causa had a diff topping on top from mahi mahi to guacamole... good but not orgasmic.

then, for our entree, we shared their cilantro rice which was quite good. it comes with this yellow habenero type sauce which was super good with the rice. they were slightly cheap with their mussels, but overall, i was happy. we were debating to get another entree but we had planned another seafoody venture for dinner that we stopped ourselves because we didn't wanna do a seafood overdose. ;) not that it'd really happen.

youre looking about droppin a $100 for a decent lunch...your call... portions are relatively appropriate... kinda...mebe cuz i eat a lot... *oink!*

oh, if anything, you should order their inca cola which is their signature drink (non alcohol)... looks like mt dew but tastes like bubble gum. well, i know, youre prolly thinking, "sick!" or " yummy!" but honestly, for me, the initial response was, "mmmm, sweet!" then, a sec later,  "eeeeeekk..." then you see me 5 minutes later, drinking it as if it was mt dew... so yea, itll grow on ya.. :)

service: gal was hella sweet, very attentive and extremely helpful in giving us suggestions in what to get.

oh, another fun perk? the restroom is a historical place, so make sure you don't taint it by "TOOTIN" :)

PS.
make sure to get a view of the oceanfront:)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
A stunningly rude experience.  

You should know that apparently there is no such thing as Cafe La Mar anymore.  We showed up, said we were here to dine in the cafe, and were informed that, well, "the cafe guy is in Seattle," or something like that, and that the cafe, per se, was no longer open.  The hostess, who seemed confused at best, then waved us into the front bar and suggested we order off the "cafe" menu.  We sat at a table in the bar and it went downhill quickly.  The hostess curtly delivered the menus and told us we'd have to order at the bar.   Ok, odd, but fine, we said.  Then, incredibly, she made a point of removing--rudely--each PAPER place mat on the table--from beneath our elbows--and every napkin and piece of silverware and plate.  I laughed and asked, "Will we be able to eat off of plates?"  She said something on the order of, "This is how we keep our costs down."  Really, I'm not making this up.  Little did I know how serious she was...

I ordered a sandwich and a salad and two chicha moradas and some chips.  We waited, expecting at least our drinks to arrive.  Eventually, the bartender showed up at the table with our drinks in to-go cups and a bag containing our boxed food.  We were surprised, expecting the food to be served on plates.  I proceeded to take the food from the bag, but the bartender approached again, discontented, and said the tables were only for food ordered off "the menu," meaning, I suppose, the full restaurant menu.  I could not believe this was happening.  Need I point out that there were only 2 other customers in the bar so it wasn't like they needed the table.  

Fed up, we left and ate at tables nearer the Ferry Building.

It seems, in retrospect, that while the hostess led us to believe we were ordering from the "cafe" menu, apparently we were ordering from the to-go menu.  For some reason, it appears to be restaurant policy that staff is to spare no effort to prevent customers from eating to-go orders on-site, in a practically empty restaurant, even when they were led to believe they were ordering from the "cafe" menu (and even if it means abusing them).

In the spirit of full disclosure:  (1) The food was good, once we pried it out of the plastic to go containers (I've always liked the food there)(and it was good despite the bitter taste the experience left in our mouths); (2) the restaurant apologized, after the fact, by email, but never explained how a restaurant of its caliber could treat paying customers so poorly.
author: Keith J.

description:
No complaints regarding this restaurant, but overall wasn't impressed.  

Location/decor:  Just down the street from the Ferry Building, the location is a good as it gets.  The restaurant has a great view of the bay if you sit in the back.  I also liked the decor & set up of the restaurant.

Food/Drinks:  Although i have no major complaints, I just wasn't excited.  There wasn't anything particularly original or novel in any of the dishes, even though the menu promises more.  For the prices at La Mar i expect to be wowed and that just didn't happen.  My drink, desayano peruana, was good, but a bit too sweet.  Civiche mixto was good, but a bit chewy and the sauce was a bit overpowering.  

Bottom line:  I would go here again if i needed a place to go in the area, or if a friend really wanted to go, but I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Amelia B.

description: There is not much I don't like about La Mar except they could improve their service but everything else is out of this world. I had a lunch there for my 55 birthday and loved it. The place was packed on June 26th and the service slow, in fact our order came before we got our drinks. We ordered the cebiche taster with four ceviches, tuna, squid and octopus, mahi mahi and halibut, all were wonderful, light and flavorful including the wonderful Amarillo peppers they are using. Each one had a unique sauce and they all were very very good. We also had the causa sampler with three different toppings, again wonderful. What I really like about this place is the environment and the colors match the foods very uniquely. Drinks are great including the Pisco punch which we really liked and the location is great.
author: Peter A.

description: The most exciting food that I've had in San Francisco on two recent trips.  Fresh, different, innovative and fun.
author: Disco B.

description:
The fish was very fresh & the "Causa Sampler" was my highlight of the evening.  The flavors were fresh- although some of their sauces were quite spicey.  I tried the chocolate puffs for dessert- the only disapointment of the evening.  The only thing you tasted was the chocolate.  
We were there on a fairly busy Saturday night- the food came quite quickly after ordering- but it took a while to place our order- as the waiter was quite slow.
Overall, I would reccommend this place.
author: Melly B.

description: Good food, Lomos Saltado and Cebiche but a little overpriced.
author: Ben T.

description: The food is awesome and the crowd is also good at this place. If you're a newbie to Peruvian food, this is a great place to get broken in. When on the menu, you must try their lamb shank. It's to die for.
author: Jay S.

description: Food was creative and tasty creations. Atmosphere was fun and lively and packed late into the evening.  Prices were not cheap so bring the extra $$ for this night out
author: Annette M.

description:
When looking for a place to host my friend's bridal shower, I never would have thought of La Mar.  I never really think of places on the Embarcadero for events and usually don't head down that way when I'm looking for a more dressy spot, but after being steered here, we were definitely steered in the right direction.

We booked La Mar about 2 months in advance for a May afternoon.  We knew with the weather it might be tricky but we decided to go for the patio area.   Which was perfect since it became sunny at mid-60's! The area was set up with beautiful colors and multiple tables.  It was perfect for what we were looking for.  Overlooking the bay, very relaxed.  

We had two great servers who walked around with trays of red and white wine that we had chosen for our guests.  It was the perfect touch for our event and really classed it up for a nice afternoon party.

The food was amazing and everyone seemed to love it.  The event planner there was helpful in setting up the menu so that it was something for everyone and featured dishes that would suite all tastes and eating styles (vegetarians, vegans, meat eaters...).

I only have two real complaints about La Mar.  The first is when we got there we were told the room would be ready for us to set up at 11am and they weren't set up for us until nearly 11:45am.  It was aggrivating since we had favors, a slide show, cake, gifts, etc...and we needed to do it before the bride arrived.  When I spoke with the event manager she was really rather blaise about it and it didn't seem like she really cared.  The second complaint is that the white wine we contracted for was not available and the white they substituted ended up costing us more money.  We were frustrated that they didn't tell us this ahead of time and charged us for the bottles.  When we asked about the price the event manager reminded us that we were getting other items "on the house" (also in the contract).  Essentially, I felt like they were trying to make up for the money they were losing on the complimentary items they had given us for free.  

Overall, The things I liked FAR outweighed the annoyances.  I would just caution anyone who is planning an event there to really watch the event planning and double check the contract to ensure you get what you agreed too!!
author: Jennifer C.

description: You HAVE to get the Tuna Cebiche. Just thinking of the sauce and onions on this dish makes my mouth water. It is to die for! I got the Santa Maria cocktail and it was... ehh. Overall, great service and ambiance. But you pay for what you get. This restaurant is definitely on the higher end.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
When you bring someone a sauce with the hottest chile in all of latin america you should WARN THEM. I had to drink Milk with my meal after that.

Before taht we had a bunch of tasteless ceviche and some really nice potatoe stuff.   its a beautiful room but the staff is terrible and the food is marginal.

we made it very clear that my husband is dangerously allergic to peanuts - so they brought us a dish served with a peanut sauce (let us order it, didn't say a word about the sauce when they brought it)

terrible.
author: patricia d.

description: they have settled in..this large chain is now what it is and will always be....solid good pisco drinks, fun bar scene, great outside sunny patio, solid yummy food bites... I bail out to this place more than I should...
author: Ricote F.

description: We came here with some friends and had a great experience.  The waiter took his time to explain the menu and how to order.  The Mojito was great!  The food was excellent.  The service was great!  The ambience was excellent as well.
author: Salaish S.

description:
After working late downtown on a Friday night, the bf and I decided we needed a special dinner to get say "goodbye" to a hell-acious week and hello to two days of freedom and sanity. La Mar fit the bill. A high energy sprawling environment on the waterfront in Pier 1 1/2, with high ceilings and giant windows (excellent views during the day...) we were immediately invigorated upon entry with smells, sounds and visuals of a happening popular restaurant. For drinks we started with a FINE glass of Malbec and a FAIR pisco sour. (Destino on Market does better. Less eggy froth and tart-er citrus.) We decided on a meal of small plates though their entrees looked good too. We thought "Why waste time on a single set of flavors when we can travel a long list of multiple flavors?" After noshing on the ADDICTIVE free basket of fried plantain, potato and yam chips with a trio of dipping sauces (DELISH), all three!) and consulting with our pleasant waitperson (delivering decent, competent service throughout,) we began with a traditional cebiche the Cebiche Nikle, an ahi tuna based dish that was more like Hawaiian poke but it was the only one not containing habenero in the marinade. EXCELLENT. The others cebiches looked good too, so will have to wait when I come back with someone who likes hot...) Then a list of mind blowing empanadas. Where to start? Got the phenomenal empanadas sampler of veggie, chicken, steak and seafood. Delivered hot from the fryer, each mixture was encased in a perfectly crispy fried pocket. SAVORY PERFECTION. Next up, street food style skewers. We got the beef. Three large chunks tender (skirt?) beef, perfectly flavored by the grill and marinade, a touch salty sweet. CARNIVORE DELIGHT! The only disappointment: STEER CLEAR of their house salad which have a tamarind based dressing that was so sweet it was like eating a candy salad. Uuugh. We skipped dessert after the run in with the aforementioned sweet salad. Thought the other tables ordered some fried dough option with dipping sauces I believe. Too much. We headed home. Satiated and successfully transitioning from our hell week to an indulgent and promising weekend. We'll be back to La Mar. 

(Kevin, you asked for it, so here it is...a positive review.)
author: Alexander G.

description: Terrible and overpriced. Cocktails were yummy. My sea bass was about this size of two postage stamps and cost $28. After we spent $450 on dinner for nine, our family went out for pizza. We were hungry! Big disappointment.
author: Jeannette S.

description:
I love Peruvian cuisine and was excited to hear about this well regarded La Mar Cebicheria. The restaurant decor and setting are superb. The waiter was very professional.

However, I was disappointed with the food. I ordered their "Chorillana" which is a grilled fresh fish of the day, at $29 for the entree alone. It happened to be white bass that day.

The dish came with what seemed like 3 generous portions of fish meat. Unfortunately, each portion of fish turned out to be approximately 1-3/4 inches square by 1/2 inch thick, sitting on top of a big dollop of mashed potato. The fish was cooked perfectly and I rate the taste above average. However, I have had just as good or better fish in much more generous portions.

So altough I liked the fish per se, overall I was disappointed with what I got for $29. I would not mind going back if someone else is paying.
author: Kuo Liang Y.

description:
Tried La Mar last night as had a friend visiting from London.  I was able to get a reservation the day of.  We had a lovely table outside.

The food was really good, so highly recommend this for something a bit different.  The atmosphere and setting was also great.

The host (at the door) was less than friendly.  Not sure why she had such an attitude, but acted too busy to help out the customers coming to get seated.

The waiter was really nice, but a bit less attentive than needed.  There were long periods between when he came to check on us or bring our orders.  Maybe they were a bit understaffed.

Other than that - I would highly recommend.
author: D K.

description:
Again, i would give La Mar a 4.5 star if i can. 
I first heard about La Mar when I was traveling in South America.  I was told this is the best place for the best ceviche in the world.  I was very disappointed for not going to the original La Mar in Peru.  But, a year later, i went to La Mar twice right at home, San Francisco.  i think i tried more than enough items to say this, if La Mar is well known for their ceviches, that's what you should order, at least during your first visit.
