You should order the ceviche tasting, so you can have a little bit of everything, and they are good portion too.  I ordered an Tiraditos (sashimi), i don't think that was flavorful enough for me.   i also had Cau cau, Arroz Norteno, Risotto, and atun.  i mean, they are very fresh and well prepared, but i think i would stick with my exceptional ceviches next time.  when you are there, be sure to try couple drinks, they are unique and tasty.  i had purple corn drink, several cocktails i dont' remember their names, but i liked them!
author: Sophia L.

description:
I just went to La Mar for my 2nd time which was my birthday. My experience was so much fun both times!  I sat at the bar and tried 3 different Pisco drinks. One was the special of the week and it was fantastic - passion fruit juice, mint, with Pisco was perfect. The bartender was friendly and kept me entertained while I waited for my husband to arrive. 

We started with the Cebiche Chifa. So fresh and tasty. I love the bit of crunch with the peanuts and won ton strips. 

Then we shared the Causa Tasting. The presentation is fun and each of the causa were equally wonderful

Then a Peruvian skewer with salmon that was pretty yummy too

The entrees were Atun and I had a special salad with white fish. I think every bite that my husband made was followed with a "wow, this is really good". 

We asked to be seated outside since it was an unusually warm night in the city (no wind). It was after the last World Series game in the city and the place was pretty crowded but the hostess was kind enough to make space for us outside. It was so nice to be by the water  and boats without freezing. The waiter was really nice and offered suggestions on how much to order etc. 

They knew it was my birthday and brought me a free dessert with a candle. You know, most places ask if you want dessert first, then when you don't order they bring you a cookie with a candle... know what I mean. La Mar didn't ask at all which I was impressed with for some reason. Just seemed like they weren't trying to squeeze ever nickel out of us. 

LOVE it and will be going back!
author: Stacey B.

description: This is our favorite restaurant in the city. The happy hour gets 5 stars for sure. Best in the city. Pisco sours for $5?! I could drink 'em all day long. Only drink worth ordering on the happy hour menu. The ceviche is incredible. Last time we were there we ordered one of everything on the happy hour menu and couldn't have been happier. Only thing that's not worth ordering is the calamari. We even sent it back. We always order the octopus skewers off the regular menu (which is a bit pricey) but they are worth it. My dad now insists on coming here every time he is in town. Best dining patio in the city hands down. Writing this is making me crave La Mar!
author: Lindsay S.

description: Drinks were yummy. But service during happy hour sucks!!! They never give u eye contact, u have to gets someone's attention "if" they even bother to acknowledge u. They forgot our appetizer n order it n it still never came. Paid for our drinks n cancelled our order. Don't think I will return!!
author: Evelyn L.

description:
We LOVED our dining experience at La Mar.  We started off in the bar for cocktails (pisco sours) and then moved on to dinner.
Our server was friendly and very knowledgeable, making great suggestions for the four of us and sharing what some of his favorite dishes were (he was spot on.)  He made a very good wine recommendation as well.
This restaurant is most definitely a repeater.....can't wait to go back!!!!
author: Robin L.

description:
It takes a lot to get me out of the house on a cold, rainy, Monday evening. Promises of pisco sours, the company of two very adored girlfriends, and of course, much coveted reservations at a restaurant which I've been dying to try. So I bundled up, put on my boots, and grabbed an umbrella. 

The spacious waterfront building has been done up in lively bold colors. White beams and accents are a sharp contrast and make you feel as if you're in a beachfront restaurant rather than the foggy city. Even on a Monday night, the dining room was full and there were still quite a few groups at the bar area in front. Amongst all this, within five minutes of walking in, I felt much warmer and almost forgot about the rain and gloom outside.

Our server was friendly and quite helpful. She was able to make some recommendations as to which dishes were must-try's and which ones we could have passed on. We decided on two main dishes, the lomo saltado, and a chicken stew, one ceviche, and the causas sampler. The loma saltado was well flavored, similar to a stir fry of beef strips, french fries, green onions, and more. Nancy rightly assesed that I would prefer the chicken stew over the chicken w/cilantro rice, noting my affinity for creamy sauces and such dishes as butter chicken, alfredo sauce, and so on. She was right. The stew was prepared with white meat only, laddled on top of tender slices of potatoes, topped with a few olives and a quail egg. For dessert, the beignets were just too irresistable to pass up. Fried balls filled with a warm gooey chocolate center, glazed with orange sauce, and served with a scoop of passionfruit-banana ice cream. It was good, but would have been better had they served it with another scoop of ice cream.

The food is on the heavier side, and like the restaurant, a little bit showy, but thats pretty much expected for a prime waterfront property. For the most part, I enjoyed my dinner and will probably return once I work off the five extra pounds gained.
author: helen l.

description: This place sucks! I am Peruvian and was expecting great things about this restaurant because La Mar in Lima Peru is great but in reality it was a BIG disappointment, the server was super rude and was rushing us out, she was also racist, i went with 2 of my good friends from Mexico and they were super excited about it, one of my friends ordered "ceviche tradicional" and it was gross, the fish had skin and it was hard to chew, my friend couldn't even eat it because the fish was hard to eat,we told the server that it wasn't very good and the fish had skin and she got pissed off and said "well, people from Central America" don't really know how "peruvian ceviche" is! I was like WTF! Im peruvian and was born in Peru, i know exactly how a ceviche should taste, then she got quite and gave us attitude saying "do you want another ceviche" we were so insulted by her that we said "no thank you" anyway, racist and rude, the portions are small and its expensive for food that its not even good, my mom makes waayy better peruvian ceviche at home! Thats for sure!  DONT Go there, they are rude, racist, expensive and the food not even worth what they charge, i rather go somewhere else, will never EVER go back to this restaurant ever again!!
author: J B.

description: La Mar is an all around 5 star restaurant.  Went here for my birthday this past weekend and had a great time.  For appetizers we ordered the causa tasting and empanada tasting- both were fantastic.  For my entree I ordered the seared ahi tuna- delish!  Our server was great and very attentative.  I also had the Pisco Sour, which if you've never had before you should def try.  The food is pricey, but worth it for special occassions.  Definitely want to try this place for lunch too. Great place!!
author: christina c.

description: Fantastic food! I took my mother there for her birthday and the food, service, and drinks were spectacular. Try the cebiche sampler!
author: Joveth G.

description: Going to La Mar was the perfect ending to very intense week. This place is great for groups, tapas style!  Relaxing enviornment mixed with a great festive energy. The food is unique, my first time having Latin cusine and might I add, we really need a few more good ones like this.  My favorite in particular was the ceviche. I think it's one of the most popular dishes on the menu and it's for good reason. Once you have a piece of the fish, omygod!!  Fresh, juicy, flavorful in every bite!  Plus, they have big corn kernels with rice that were soo yummm..... Sweet. Mmmmm.  The mix drinks were good.  Good blend of alcohol and flavor.  I Highly recommend for a fun night out! :)
author: elle c.

description:
Upon returning from a 6 week holiday in Europe I christened my pallet on u.s turf at La Mar, a restaurant t i had ironically heard about from a fellow san franciscan i met in PROGUE! I had been informed it was Peruvian cuisine with a sexy san francisco flare.. I came in jet lagged and battered and sat at the bar to be entertained with company and pisco by Jared, hands down one of the quickest, wittiest, most talented bar tenders I've encountered, maybe ever? 5 drinks deep i was contemplating why i had taken a vacation in the first place- the best drinks and service was right under my nose this whole time! 
after the pisco sours were flowing through my veins  i started craving tobacco when JARED informed me that out back lies a patio where i can smoke what i want?! ??! i stumble out back to find a water front terrace- i felt like swimming but refrained, sf is chilly a sobering reminder I'm not in turkey anymore :(
As I left that evening i couldn't help but wonder whether the pisco sours and my arroz norteño (a dish filled with mussels, shrimp, octopus, and fried rice which puts world class spanish paellas to shame!) were what I was high on or the idea of my new friendship/ bromance with Jared? With the most adorable little martini tattooed on his forearm i started becoming worried that there was more in the pisco sours than i was prepared to handle, emotionally and physically- talk about an aphrodisiac.. 
I recommend checking this place out on Sundays for the mere fact that Jared is guaranteed to be there, a little eye candle with your ceviche never hurt anyone
author: michael L.

description: Every time I go to San Francisco, La Mar is a MUST GO TO spot for me!  The food is wonderful and well prepared!  I particularly love their Ceviches they offer, probably the best I've had! They also have a great drink menu with plenty of options (especially Sake!).  Service has always been efficient and very pleasant.  They also have a great Ceviche/appetizer & drinks happy hour that's fairly priced.  I highly recommend going if you haven't!
author: Jonathan E.

description:
I admit, I follow Yelp's hot list religiously and had been dying to try La Mar.....also because the quarter Peruvian girl I am was very excited about enjoying my heritage in the new trendy hot spot.
The boy and I had 730 reservations, strolled in and were immediately seated in the packed dinning room. Deafening would be an understatement.....it is VERY VERY noisy, and if I were to come back I'd sit at the cebiche bar which seems far more intimate and electrically blue.
Our waiter was perfectly nice, although when I asked him for  suggestions for an entree he just suggested the most expensive (which would have been fine if it was really the best in his opinion.....don't think it was).
Our food runner decided I spoke spanish...must be the quarter peruvian.....well, I do speak spanish, but the boy didin't.....so having all our food explained in spanish, was in my opinion rude-especially when I repeatedly answered him in English.
We had:
Cebiche tasting -Mixto,Nikel,Chifa and Classico
Anticuchos-octopus salad
Lomo saltado-stir fry
...and my scallop dish special
The cebiche tasting was good, and the perfect amount of each. The octopus salad stole the show in my opinion, although the boy found the octopus a little chewy.The lomo saltado was good, but nothing special. MY special dish was, well, EH...The rice was perfectly seasoned and creamy, but the scallops were sauteed and placed on top of the rice...they had NO flavor whatsoever, and could have been a completely different dish. 
I had an amazing pisco sour, and will probably be back to La Mar eventually. I'll sit at the bar, nibble on appetizers and enjoy the drinks.....but will remain loyal to Fina Estampa for a full Peruvian meal.
author: Bianca L.

description:
la mar great drinks!
and ceviche!
author: Bing S.

description: There's really one word to describe this place ... WOW! From the ambience to the food, wow. I've been to a ton of Peruvian restaurants in my life - mostly because I'm married to a woman whose step father is Peruvian - so I think I know good food when I come across it. Admittedly, I did stick with the easy stuff but I did so for a reason. Screw up lomo saltado adnd you don't cut it. Well, the lomo was the most fabulous I have ever eaten in my entire life. The meat was high quality and then broth/sauce was spot on. The causa was dope (we ordered two different kinds). My only complaint was that they don't have papas a la huancaina, which is a staple of most places. Other than that tiny infraction, this place was amazing. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for something different or anyone tired of the routine family-run Peruvian place.  Congrats to San Fran for hosting such an amazing place.
author: Richard N.

description: MUCH better service at the bar.  They took and served our drink and food orders quickly.  The room is energetic, too bad there is no water view.
author: brewgirl b.

description: I always pass by this restaurant and wondered what it would be like to dine here.  Finally had an opportunity and was very much pleased with the food.  I had the ceviche mixto and it was wonderful.  The calamari was very tender and the hamachi was so good.  My main dish consisted of their version of paella and it too was wonderful.  We had the dessert, and of course that really ended the meal with a bang!  The server was very good and informative.  It was our first time, so he guided us through the menu and made great suggestions.  I definitely would go back again.
author: Ruth L.

description:
Had my outing with the gfs fixed with the following:
Pisco sour - strong & beautiful cocktail, it's to die for
appetizers:
Cebiche tasting - 4 awesome seafood tastings with a touch of freshness and lingering memory of the taste
tequenos de aji de gallina - the best chicken spring rolls
choroillna - nice sea bass fillet dish
entrees:
arroz nortenos - thick sauce mixed with rice and seafood combo dish with mussles, shrimp, octupus..yum!
atun - grilled ahi tuna, seasame sauce, purple mash potatoes...!

sinfully delicious food, beautiful presentation and the vibrant feel of the place sooth a nice fun evening must-have in the heart the city!
author: Phuong T.

description:
We went there for a friends birthday.. Awesome food and service. everything that we had was tasty.. 
did not like their sangria..
author: nit p.

description: Good food but small portions and also very expensive. Dont use the lounge area on a cold day/night , there is no heater.... Nice atmosphere and very nice decor.
author: nancy n.

description:
I dined here yesterday with my mom, older brother, and younger sister as an early celebration of my birthday, which happens to be today. I had read the Yelp reviews and was very excited to eat here- neither I nor my family has had the pleasure of enjoying much Peruvian food, so it was nice to try something new.

We started out with a round of Pisco sours (naturally), the cebicha chifa, the anticuchos de pollo (grilled chicken skewers), and the empanadas de aji de gallina, which were filled with creamy chicken in a delicately spiced aji sauce.

This first course was all very satisfying- from the complimentary fried plantain and homemade potato chips, served with three different aiolis (going from mild to medium in spiciness, but not quite reaching hot), to the last bite of the wonderfully-seasoned and fresh cebicha (indeed, the chifa did remind me of a Chinese chicken salad minus the chicken, as one reviewer noted). The grilled chicken skewers (anticuchos de pollo) had a nice kick, having been marinated in aji panca (Peruvian red pepper, and were served with a nicely spiced rocoto salsa and the largest variety of corn I have ever witnessed. Seriously, these Peruvian corn kernels are huge, and kind of starchy- and like all good starches, were very addicting. As for the empanadas, our order came with two, so we split them four-ways and enjoyed the extra-fried crispiness of the outer shells and the perfectly savory creaminess of the filling. Very nice.

We then moved on to our salad course, in which the four of us split the two different dinner salads offered that evening per our kind* waiter's recommendation (both vegetarian- the Ensalada Nikei with green papaya, jícama, soybeans, pickled carrots and daikon, crunchy quinoa, Peruvian purple corn and rocoto dressing was my favorite, but the other one on spinach with fresh white corn and a light vinaigrette was very crisp and refreshing as well). I appreciated the fact that our waiter helped us not order too much salad, and suggested we split the two different varieties. The salad portions are huge, so it was perfect.

For our main course, I ordered the chupa andino (creamy chicken soup with a delicious soft quail egg and potatoes), my mom ordered the lomo saltado (beef tenderloin strips in rich dark sauce served with fries, onions, and corn rice), my brother ordered the arroz norteno (a mixture of seafood on top of seasoned rice), and my sister ordered an entree of some sort of fish fillet served in a rich broth with vegetables and corn rice (the name escapes me now!). Everything looked and smelled amazing, and we all devoured as much of our plates as we could. Contrary to other reviews, I must say, I found the portion sizes to be generous and sizable. Nothing excessive, a la Cheesecake Factory, but nothing tiny, as well.

We were full and content and would have ordered dessert, except that the restaurant got a little busier by the time we finished our meal, and our waiter was distracted by another table that had just filled up. Despite this, he was still very pleasant and quick to serve us through the whole meal; we did not lack for anything, and felt better leaving without dessert anyhow (I know, I know it was my birthday celebration, but I'm more into savory than sweet, anyhow!)

I loved coming here; beautiful view of the water on a lovely day (Sunday, June 21, 2009 = beautiful, awesome sunny weather), good cocktails, yummy food, friendly service, and laid-back environment. What was not to love?

*handsome, too :)
author: Anna S.

description:
My boyfriend and I have become frequent diners at La Mar and never get tired of our favorite dishes and cocktails. This is by far my favorite restaurant in this city. The atmosphere is trendy, yet relaxed, the food is delish and the cocktails are dangerously good. The bartender Sal is very knowledgable and friendly. We love to eat at the bar (for which seating is first come, first serve) and enjoy the wonderful drinks! The chicha tu sour and pisco sour are two of the best cocktails around! 

This is also a great place for large parties!
author: Alyssa B.

description:
i relized that i never reviewed this place.
i was there 4 opening nite, fun!
i also just got back from peru when they first opened and my friends down there told me that their most famous chef was opening a place in my city.
yum. everything was delic! drinks, cebiche app., entrees.
its pricy but the portions r pretty good, i couldn't fit dessert.
but i came back and the dessert is great. i 4 get what i had but it was awsome. 
i had subpar service once, she couldn't answer any of my questions and seemed kinda lost. or inexpearienced anyway.
but whatever. its on the water. the food/fish is great. i like it. and one not-so-great waitress isn't gonna stop me.
just go ppl.
author: Renee S.

description: Ok, I've gone back and forth on this for two days, I'm going with 3*'s.  Here is my break down: 5* location, ambiance, outdoor seating, any cebiche(sp), 4* staff, presentation, 3*, the rest of the menu, 2* bathrooms.  The Cebiche was wonderful, had 4 different little plates, all very, very fresh, great presentation, wonderful mix of flavors and sauces.  Staff was great, good attention to detail, hustling all the time, well done.  Rest of menu, we all had something different, Chalaco, sandwiches, yellow-fin kabob.  All were.... ok. No house rocking.  Bathrooms, wow that surprised me, trashed at 2:30 in the afternoon.  Also, it was strange when we walked in that at 1:15 on a beautiful Saturday, next to the Farmers Market, tons of foot traffic, they were not very busy.  Overall, would I go back again, no, that is why I went with 3*'s.
author: John A.

description: A great dining experience made even better when someone else is paying for it. I went here for my fiances Christmas party and they lined up nearly 8 courses all served family style. I was surprised that there weren't more meat dishes since there was plenty of seafood. Everything was excellent including the salads and I am not a salad person. Too many good dishes to mention but you can't go wrong with the Cebiche Classico (Halibut) and don't forget to try the Pisco Sour cocktail. This is a large restaurant with large bars so I'll be going back for happy hour.
author: Kiran G.

description:
This restaurant had a great atmosphere! We had a really nice waitress.

I loved the ceviche and the empanadas. 

Don't miss the sangria I dont even like sangria but it was a happy hour special so I tried it... wow!
author: Alexandra M.

description: Expensive, yet the quality of the actual food didn't reflect that.  Tough tough meat, for example.  And the drinks were just ho-hum.
author: Mason G.

description:
I went to La Mar last Sunday with high expectations because I love seafood and it's supposed to be a good seafood restaurant. Well, the cebiche was really just OK, not great. The dessert was amazing though. We got the chocolate crepe and it was great. 

Might go back for drinks and desserts, but probably not a full meal...
author: Tracy C.

description:
this is a nice place, but the food doesn't match. 

Great for tourists, terrible for foodies
author: Stephen E.

description: I love the design of this place--beautiful colors, a fun--vacation like vibe.  Unfortunately for  vegetarians there just isn't much on the menu and I feel it is really over priced for the portion size and for the type of food.
author: Jana H.

description: Went there with no reservations on a beautiful sunny day, told them it was my birthday (it actually was) granted we didn't get great outdoor seating - it was all booked up.  We kind of dropped the birthday thing there-but the team there didn't.  The mix of Japanese and Peruvian cuisine is awesome.  Go for the tuna tartars on top of potatoes-delicious!  When it came time for dessert they brought a comp dessert with a candle.  The waiter just smiled and said 'it's a bit cheesy, but try it' he was right-it was delicious.  A very nice gesture that topped off a great meal.
author: Dean F.

description: Elected the tasting menu. Over-priced, stingy portions, and marginal execution. Spend your $$$ elsewhere.
author: Jsq J.

description: I went to La Mar for a friend's birthday - and had drinks and food at the bar.  The location was great - I even found street parking across the street.  The special that day was Pisco Sours for $5.  I enjoyed two very well made pisco sours.  I had the una as my main dish - and found it was a tad spicy for my taste, and I hadn't been expecting that from the description.  The server recommended the Bunuelos with Chocolate for the dessert and it did not disspoint.  Chocolate came oozing out of a perfect little donut, and the ice cream was a perfect compliment.  Do be prepared to spend some quality money at the location but the food is fabulous.
author: Erica R.

description: While I cannot complain about the food itself, nor the decor or location, the portions and service were disappointing. Although overcoming the high expectations of my peruvian counterpart, the cebiche (why "v" here and "b" there, I do not know) portions were rather small and not just compared to portions I have eaten in Peru. Limon has a similar price tag but about twice the fish. The entree was a better sized portion, but then again, I guess rice is cheaper. Unless I am eating at somewhere like Coi, I find it unacceptable to leave a $100 lunch hungry. For my cebiche, ceviche, etc. I will not be returning to La Mar. When will a non-fusion Peruvian joint come to SF??
author: Hallie A.

description:
Went here for my 5th anniversary. Service is excellent. Food is 3.5/5 stars. We had the cerbiche tasting and the chulos (spelling?) tasting. The yellowtail cerviche is the best, second is the tuna, third is the halibut.

Octopus was a bit on the overcooked and chewy side. We shared short ribs for entree. Dessert is excellent with the chocolate fills balls and rice pudding.
author: Chanh N.

description: I can't say enough good things about la mar. The cocktails, the food, the wine, the service, the ambiance - all was phenomenal. And it was reasonably priced. I wish I lived closer and I would go there all the time.
author: L L.

description: How did I end up here? I had a Spanish professor one semester who was from Peru and I was talking to somebody the semester before I took this professor and this person was telling me how this professor like to talk about a Peruvian restaurant, I actually do not recall him doing so, but my Spanish isn't that good and half the time I didn't really catch what he was saying, so he might have after all, but anyway, one day after class towards the end of the semester I decided to talk to him and ask him what peruvian restaurant it was, and he suggested this one La Mar. So when I finally went to was Wednesday night the second till last full day I was in San Francisco, and I needed to go out to eat anyways am I remember what my Spanish professor had told me about, my final exams were done, I had a couple papers left but again I needed somewhere to eat, the bus trip took a long time but I finally made out there, and I finally found the place and I kind of knew what was going on that it would be somewhat expensive when I stepped foot into the place, but by that time it was getting late and I had taken a long time to get there so I just decided all well whatever I'll stay fortunately, I still had some money in the bank and enough to eat there the food seem pretty good if it was the food alone this place would probably get a four stars from me, but despite the good food price was a little steep for it, I really enjoyed that interesting taste and I never received bad service mentioned by some other reviews, and so I cannot complain about that, the food seemed fresh enough and well-made and well, I guess it is pretty hard to mess up deep fried fish, I had the calamari the ceviche I had seemed tiny but really good at the same time, the vegetable or fruit juice I had seemed quite decent and the rice paper ice cream I had also seemed really good would I come back here? Maybe? But I would have to have tons and tons of money to blow that I probably don't want to spend at a record store or somewhere else, but I guess this was alright for a one time thing the point is I certainly wouldn't rush back here tomorrow, mostly because of the price.
author: Rachel N.

description:
We went last night, with a reservation for 2 at 8pm on a Wednesday.

The cebiche nikel was yummy, as was the dulce de leche with a port wine meringue desert.

Unfortunately, our waiter was a bit off all evening.  We waited quite awhile for our order to be taken after he took our drink order.  I asked him to leave the wine menu so I could order a glass with dinner, but he left the dinner menu.  He brought my dinner partner the wrong entree.  The worst grievance, though, was that the waiter never came to get the check from us so that he could run our credit card.  We eventually got up from the table and searched the (by then) near empty restaurant.  We finally found him when he came out of a back room, carrying his jacket, and talking to another employee.  That is just totally unacceptable service!
author: stacy c.

description:
naturally, when i think of peruvian food, i think of your typical latin american "beans and rice" food. so when i first heard of this place, i thought, "sweet, a new afterparty hot spot. no more dennys!!"

then it started to get big. not only did i read a review on thrillist, but people were actually talking about it. i was thrilled that people are finally learning about what cebiche is. cause they should.

the place is very contemporary: wide and spacious white walls and just a splash of color from the exotic flowers and saturated blue chairs. the crew are dressed in all black and in what looks like old navy fleece sweater vests, perhaps a friendly reminder that the check might not be TOO high (thanks gaston).

okay, first things first... upon seating, they will drop off their "bread basket" of fried plantains, regular and sweet potatoes and three creamy dips ranging from mild to spicy. it is in my "food science" nature to play with my taste palette, so i had a blast eating these bad boys. i'd try each dip with different chips, then i'd do different combos with the dip! trust me, it's delicious. and since it's complimentary, i recommend refilling throughout the night just until dessert arrives (your wallet will thank you).

the first time i came here, we ordered the cebiche tasting, a sampling of four cebiches. the nikel (ahi tuna) is THE BOMB. seriously, i'd eat a whole bowl of it and call it a day. stay clear from the chifa, i swear, it tasted like a chinese chicken salad wtf. and for dinner i had a classic peruvian seafood stew, i felt like the ocean was literally in my mouth.

the second time around, we ordered the cebiche tasting again and for some reason, the halibut tasted really fishy... we also shared the causa tasting, talk about some fancy ass mashed potatoes! basically, a causa consists of fish and garnish sitting on top of a mini tower of whipped mashed potatoes with it's own mini grotto of sauce. they look cute as shit. and they're tasty too! the causas are so strategically thought out, you have to give them credit. they know exactly what their doing.

the drinks are fabulous~ the bloody mary is very spicy and the molasses cosmo is very sweet. and don't hesistate to ask about their wines. when you look at the wine menu, you will have questions... ;p

after both visits, i've had all of their desserts. everything is great except the tiramisu, they can leave that with the italians.

conclusion: i can't help but feel that most fusion restaurants try to cater their ethnic flavor to white people. but this place moves far from it. this guy obviously loves food and you can feel his sense of exploration in his dishes. his taste and creativity is showcased in every aspect of the restaurant. overall, la mar is fucking awesome.
author: krys s.

description:
dont get me wrong. this place is GREAT!
location is PRIME. atmosphere is LIVELY! the food is AMAZING! waiters are attentive and plentiful.
BUT last night....ohhh last niiiight, after two pisco sours, seafood empanadas and handfuls of the potato, sweet potato & plantain chips, i was about to continue on my new shellfish journey: a second attempt with oysters. ive been told to chew about two to three times and then swallow {i have issues with swallowing things w/o chewing see: pills, jello shots, clams etc} so i suck it up and just go for it. these were pretty big, piled high with tomatoes, cucumber, onion, cilantro and fresh lime juice...down the hatch and BOOM! first bite is down on a hard piece of the shell and i chip my molar! WTF!! i freak out {why meee? was it bc it was Fri the 13th? bad karma?}, try to make the most of it, decide to chew on the left side of my mouth and drown my sorrows in cusqueña beer & cebiche. i move on with the sampler. DELICIOUS! the Nikei with ahi is a top ten dish for sure!!

anyways, the general manager came over to 'check on me' and he barely looked me in the face for more than ten seconds. sort of doubted or was confused by the situation, said he would take the appetizer off the bill & tell the kitchen to check the oysters more carefully going out, apologized and vanished. 
if i owned a restaurant that prides itself on serving fresh authentic Peruvian cuisine {mainly seafood} and someone chipped their tooth on a poorly shucked oyster {3 out of the 6 oysters had pieces of shell in them}, i would be extremely apologetic, comp the entire meal and offer to pay the dental bills!!!!...hmmm
having pieces of shell inside an oyster is the type of mistake that would get you kicked out of Top Chef in an instant! Unacceptable!!

besides my situation and the soft repsonse, this place is really great! a must-try if you like seafood and hot peruvian men! ;) i will definitely be back! but will NOT be eating the oysters! no way! 
'Eek! Methinks not' is RIGHT YELP!!!
author: Kaylan S.

description:
We had dinner there on Saturday 9/1 after much anticipation.  Unfortunately our experience was not good.  The service we received was poor .  Our waiter was nice but it seemed like the whole service organization at the restaurant was hectic.  We had stuff come to our table that  we did not order from other waiters.  We waited a long while for our food to come.  Our first drinks came after the first appetizers.  Looking at the other waiters in the place - everyone seemed crazed and mixed up.  One waiter went around for quite some time trying to figure out who ordered a certain drink he had on his tray.  It was a mess and looking at the people who worked there - it was clear the service was badly disorganized.  Not fun to experience at all.   Our waiter never asked if we wanted a second drink.  It was bad.  I can understand that there was an event happening that day there too - but we are still paying guests so why should our service be so bad.  The food was delicious - the ceviche and the causas were great. However, our main entrée - the Lomo Saltado - was not good.  It was overly salty and we would not have known it was a Peruvian dish - as it seemed like some sort of Chinese fusion with an overpowering soy sauce.  So I would not go back to La Mar as much as I wanted to really like this place as I love latin food.

Sorry.
author: yasir f.

description: This was the second time we came here.  We ordered Cebiche tasting and Causas Trio.  Their Cebiche was delicious.  It had the same taste and presentation as a year ago.  I ate Causas this time.  Our waiter said this dish was the one of their speciality.  It was 3 types of sea foods topped on naturally colored mushed potatoes.  The sauces came with Causas were yummy.  I couldn't tell what is in it but colorful delightful goodness.  Also, it was sophisticated plate.  I like this place's high opened air feeling with ocean view which normally lacks in San Francisco area restaurant.
author: Amanda C.

description: Last night we had dinner at La Mar.  First, the hostess was slow to seat us at our table even though there appeared to be plenty of tables available.  The portions are extremely small for the price.  We paid over $120 without wine and we barely got full.  While the food was good, the price tag puts the restaurant on par with the very expensive restaurants in SF - and on that level, La Mar does not compare.  In this economy, the owners should consider scaling down the prices or scaling up the portions.
author: Anna S.

description: Some of the tables are too cramped and food is WAAAY overpriced! But, the ambiance is nice and those Pisco cocktails are delish!
author: Ali C.

description:
The meal started like an episode of Chopped. In the basket for the first course the mystery ingredients would have been Mint, Peanuts, Potatoes, and Animal Crackers.  The result: a fantastic basket of chips from many potato varietals with three dipping sauces, my favorite one (the green one) was a blend of Mint, Animal Crakers and Peanuts. Fantastic! I couldn't get enough of it.
The Pisco Sour is the perfect cocktail to wash it down. And I am not a cocktail person. I loved the fluffiness of the beaten egg whites in the cocktail. We share one and that was enough though. They were kind enough to bring us two half glasses. Classy.
Seating on the terrace on a sunny lunch made it extra special and earns the place the 5th star because the food was very good, but a bit uneven in terms of creativity.
Not to be missed: the dessert balls filled with chocolate. Can't remember the name...
This is a special place I would go back to but reserve it for a special occasion.
author: Elsa T.

description: This was the second time I've been here and will not be racing to return.  We were seated by a snarly hostess to a table under the glare of the skylight.  When we requested to sit outside, she said everything was reserved (it was half empty at 1pm).  We had to wait to place our order, and after we did, the waiter returned 15 minutes later to say they were out of the kind of fish we ordered.  It took 45 minutes to get our order, and the waiter forgot to bring the salad, which we eventually told him to forget it.  Our water glasses were never refilled, and the waiter only returned when I requested the check.  The restaurant was not crowded. As far as the food, the first time I thought things were great; now extremely medicore, compounded by the rotten service.
author: WK C.

description:
Don't even know where to begin this disgruntled review. Was considering just one star, but my pisco sour was very good, and I suspect the bar experience might be fun on its own. 
But if you're looking for a happy customer, this isn't me. You may be surprised - the restaurant is beautiful, the location by the water is stunning, and we did sit on the patio after all. And if the aforementioned pisco sour was indeed awesome, why am I complaining? 
Because of dinner, that's why. Our reservation was for 8, yet for some inexplicable reason, our party of 10 was made to wait until 8:45, as our hostess said, "over there by the tree." The tree she was referring to was a large potted something or other by the door. I felt like an errant child sent to bed without chocolate milk. 
The manager finally seated us, but without an apology for the wait. I decided to give the place a second chance, but had to quickly revise that opinion while biting into a completely tasteless causa. The ceviche looked pretty good, but the empanadas were not a hit. The best things on the table were really the free chips and dips. 
And I had to get plenty familiar with the chips, cos my main course never arrived. Nope, never. Not with the rest of the table, not 10 minutes later, not when everyone was done. Our server offered many variations on his apology, but that still didn't put food on the table. Finally, we decided to move on to dessert and ordered three to share. The tiramisu and beignets were fine. But when the bill arrived, I was shocked to see that the only reimbursement we had been offered for my not getting an entree was one free dessert. I think these guys may need a lesson (or two) in good sense.
author: Purnima M.

description: The bar has a lovely decor and a great bartender who prepared us a delicious Pisco sour...we later moved to the outside patio where the view is gorgeous! Our waitress was very lovely and patient! All we were there for was drinks and appetizers and we had a great time! I'm a huge ceviche fan and had tried lots of versions of it, but never peruvian! Try their ceviche sampler, its delicious! And their empanadas are great too, many styles of sauces to add on! Lovely place, look forward to my next visit ;)
author: Claudia G.

description: Great restaurant gave us that South Florida feel! The location & view is very nice! I even like the restaurant layout inside & outside. The food was very very good! Their ceviches are great! The only "no-no" is their restroom situation. For a restaurant that size & location....the restrooms is that of a "hole in the wall" place. Outside of that meal & view is great!
author: Reggie A.

description:
spacious, bright, and boisterous.  

order a signature pisco sour at the bar while you wait for your table.

this is definitely a fun new hot spot to try out delicious peruvian food.

the ceviches were outstanding.

1. nikei: the cuts of tuna were top notch and drenched in tamarind
2. criollo: yellowtail, scallops, mussels, calamari and celery hearts were complete with a spicy habanero marinade. 

the anticuchos: grilled octopus was fantastic and a must order to share

for entrees:
1. the lamb shank was tender and tasty
2. criollo rice dish which had calamari, prawns, mussels and clams was a bit of a disappointment
3. regretfully didn't get to order the lomo saltado that the server recommended.
4. the stews also looked amazing - bookmarked for a future order

we were seated so late after our late night reservations that we opted for no dessert but another round of cocktails.

overall, not quite the first date spot but definitely one for a casual date or a group where you can share many dishes.
author: Anh V.

description: If you want the ultimate SF scene experience, La Mar is the place to be! The bar was buzzing with beautiful people and the decor was very cool. We started off with one of the Pisco cocktails and I WISH I could remember which one because it was delicious! It was like a margarita but even more refreshing (plus, the waiter verified it was 46% alcohol! Now that's worth your $$). Usually in places like these, you get small portions for big prices, but I think the portions and quality were well worth the prices. First, they serve you free plantain and potato chips with 3 types of dipping sauce. We then ordered the sampler empanada plate - delicious! We also ordered the mahi mahi skewer: the sauce was delectable and the portion was huge! We probably should have stopped there, but we wanted to try more so we ordered the lamb shank entree. It was falling off the bone and very savory. I wanted dessert but unfortunately, no room in my belly! The service was great and overall an almost perfect experience. I would say perfect except for the fact that I ordered the unfiltered sake and for $12, I got it in a glass that was MAYBE 2 ozs at the most. That wasn't worth the money - stick with the Pisco drinks! I can't wait to go back.
author: LuLu M.

description:
Being that I am half Peruvian and I have a grandmother and mother that are great cooks, I am difficult to please when it comes to Peruvian food. This is the best Peruvian restaurant I have been too. Not only is the food great, but the location is unbeatable. It has great views of the Bay! 

My order is always comprised of ceviche, anticuchos (I no longer eat this though b/c it is the cow's heart), cau cau, or lomo saltado. All the fish dishes are great though, including ahi tuna and red snapper. For starters, they give you plantain and sweet potato chips with three diff sauces, which are all very flavorful.

For drinks, the pisco sour is an authentic drink from Peru...It is very sweet though, so I usually have to share.  This place has become my mother's (100% peruvian) fav restaurant in SF...We always go back to try new things :)


The ambiance is great too, pretty loud, but so fun for groups!
author: Stephanie F.

description: We just had an office Bday lunch here (4 of us), The service was efficient i don't understand why people are complaining about the service. They where efficient and accommodating we asked if we could move to a sunny patio table as the servers where standing with our main courses and they where happy to move us across the whole patio. The waitress was very articulate and clear when explaining  ingredients we did not know. The food was excellent,  i highly recommend the Ceviche Tasting, Empanadas de aji de gallina and the Arroz Norteno.  We also asked for advice on what wine would be a good pair for our food and the waitress suggested an Albarino from spain, we had two bottles. Great place for lunch will try dinner soon.
author: Eric G.

description:
this place is a cebiche paradise! very hard to make decisions with such a large menu. went on the server's recommendation to try a dish from various sections of the menu:

cebiche: clasico (halibut)
causas: limena (dungeness crab)
anticuchos: de corazon (beef hearts)
tiraditos: tres ajies (sea bass sashimi)
platos de fondo: cau cau (scallops & clams rissoto)

the beef hearts wow'd us. flavorful and with a surprisingly nice texture. everything else was good but not outstanding. the sauce trio they serve each table is very tasty though!

love the industrial set up, high ceilings. creates a very cool vibe.

la mar was my first stop after flying into sf, and i was way underdressed in my comfy airplane clothes. so not only did i look like a hobo, my party of 2 was one of the last to leave the restaurant. yet no one made us feel bad about it. what a nice change from the LA scene.
author: Thy N.

description: Food was great however services was poor. Took 35mins before we got our drinks then 20mins after the appetizer arrived. We had a reservation so didn't wait at all for a table; however, we couldn't even get attention from our server until 20 mins later.....food quality was phenomenal but Friday night is not the best time to go....
author: Geetika P.

description:
I liked the octopus skewers and was impressed with the professionalism of the waiter.  I also noted that this place has a huge staff.  

From there, it goes downhill unfortunately.  There was a distinct note of sweetness in nearly all of the dishes and certainly in the cocktails as well.  The cebiche crudo was OK, but trying to eat the large slices of raw onions was simply impossilbe without the (sweet) cebiche liquid flying everywhere.  Like some other places I can think of (Anchor & Hope and Slanted Door as examples), the space here is big, bright and very Spartan (and there is nothing good about that).  When subjected to tables so cramped that I fear my buttocks may swipe the plates from the next table when I get up, then there simply is not enough space!

So, altogether not a terrible experience, but simply one I would not wish to repeat.  Also, I have to question the economics of their business model since the customer traffic required to support the service staff they have means that every night probably has to be a blow out.  My guess is that they don't have what it takes to produce that sort of customer traffic on a consistent basis.
author: Richard P.

description: Awesome ceviche or um cebiche...as this place calls it. Nice place for a group dinner as there's lots of space. There's a separate bar in the front and outdoor dining space right on the water. Definitely a place for seafood lovers...not so much vegan-friendly. Not sure if it's the most authentic Peruvian place but given it's proximity to Slanted Door (it's right next door), I think it's more like an upscale Peruvian fusion place. Upscale [insert ethnic cuisine] fusion is a very San Franciscan treat. When done well, this kind of food is a spendy but worthy treat and when done poorly it's a big waste of money and you might as well go to the authentic hole-in-the wall corner joint, but  I'd say that La Mar does a good job... and I'll definitely come back  here when I am craving some cebiche.
author: Kimi W.

description: Loved the decor.  It was bright, clean and fun.  A friday place for lunch or somewhere you go with a large group of friends.  The food was okay.  Fish in ceviche was fresh, but lacking flavors.  Had the cod special and it was just okay.  Sauce was a bit too sweet for me.  In the end, decor pushed it to four stars.
author: Jim B.

description:
I have gone twice to La Mar, and I love everything of it:  the atmosphere, the food, the drinks, the view, the service... It's a solid place to go and enjoy a date or a meeting with friends.  

I loved the causas (i tried the one with crab and the one with raw tuna, both excellent), the cebiche (we got the sampler, fantastic), the complimentary chips and salsa,  and all the fish dishes.  I personally would stay away from the fried stuff, but someone at my party, who doesn't like raw fish, did love their empanadas, tequenos, and everything else.  I have taken 6 friends there and they all loved it as well.  I think it's well worth a try.
author: Ana V.

description: The cebiche rocks, the small plates are great and the wine list was also very good and the waiter was able to pair some nice wines with our food. I have also eaten at the bar and the bar tender took us through a pisco tasting on the house. Very cool dude. I would highly recommend this place for anyone that is looking for some good cebiche, nice atmosphere and a cool ambiance.
author: Nick J.

description: I came here for an office lunch about two months ago. We went with a group of 10 people, 4 of whom were vegetarian. It happened to fall on good Friday so I didn't eat any meat either. It's the first time I had to deal with that issue at a restaurant. We had ensalada limena (vegetarian), *quinoa soltera (vegetarian) and arroz crioll. It was all amazing. I have to say I have never been so full without having meat. This place was amazing, and they have really good drinks too. Their drinks are typical perubian drinks, but that was that first time I've had them and they were amazing. I highly recommend to anyone whether you do or don't eat meat, there was one meat dish that I did not have but was popular amongst the rest of the group. They said their meat was great.
author: CarpeDiem C.

description: The food was good. Service was good, our waiter was very friendly and helpful.  We had already read the reviews on yelp and had a idea what to order so that was helpful.  Everything was pricey, but that is the price for eating in the city and on the bay.  It was enjoyable but I wouldn't do it again.  We had the cebiche ,& empanada samplers, a bottle of wine (45.00) one main course for each of us, plenty of food for us, and we were hungry! Total bill $200.00.  Plan on spending ..
author: Vikki W.

description: Have been very excited to eat here since the grand opening a couple of months. I have been to Peru twice and traveled all over the country eating my through at in-laws homes and well respected restaurants. And I have to say the food matches what you find in Peru.
author: Edwin C.

description: Great location, ambiance and service...(except for some girl at the front named Stephanie). We ordered the empanda sampler, the ceviche nikki (?), the anticuchos de corazon and an amazing dessert of chocolate mousse/passion fruit.  My favorite was handsdown the ceviche! The drinks were great too with my favorite being a cocktail of pisco and chicha morada...delicious and strong. Overall I enjoyed this spot and will probably return to try more of what they have on their menu (so much). Again the only issue I had was that within the first few minutes of arriving my friend and I had to deal with the rudeness of the hostess (Stephanie) who didn't seem particularly concerned with providing a welcoming experience at a top restaurant.
author: Gina D.

description: It's a very nice place, specially because of its location. But it's extremely overpriced and they food is not all that great. I think it's good to go there for their happy hour because of their pisco sours. But other than that, if I'm in the mood for Peruvian food, I rather go to another restaurant.  Very disappointed with their ceviche, and I should know cause I'm Peruvian.  The service is not that great either, specially at the bar.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I heard great things about this new place...it looks really cool, but the food wasn't all that! the bar area is nice, love the turquoise theme they have going on. my husband and I had the vegetarian food, it was ok. I like the purple corn with avocado on top appetizer, but the other stuff was just alright. our friends ordered non-vegetarian food and they were not impressed either! we thought they would at least enjoy it since it was a ceviche joint. anyways, we probably won't be going back :( bummer, because we had high hopes for this place!

one other thing - when we walked by, the people that seat you told us about so many different veggie options. when we had dinner, the waiter was hesitating to even ask the chef about creating some veggie dishes.
author: bhavna p.

description:
Went today with my hubby to celebrate a bday and thought the food was awesome but the maitre d was awful.

We got to the restaurant for lunch at 1230 today and the maitre d named Tanya was on the computer never looked up to acknowledge we were there (we were the only ones there and we stood right in front of her) continued typing on the keyboard for about 5 minutes ignoring us, when I tried to get her attention,she then said " I will be with you in a minute"  She continued to type some more and then after about 3more mins asked if we had reservations,never apologizing for her rudeness and never smiled. We told her yes and instead of seating us right away told us to wait some more (the restaurant was almost empty since they just opened) while she goes to the couple who just literally walked in. VERY  RUDE!!  If the restaurant mgmt is reading this, please demote this woman to the back of the kitchen (maybe doing supplies with no human contact) since she lacks good basic customer service skills and acts as if she is doing customers a favor.  We almost walked out of the restaurant if it were not for our wonderful server Djovanni--please promote him, he is great with people, had good recomendations and very pleasant.

Would have given this restaurant 4 stars but because of Tanya--NO.

To recap:
Food--AWESOME
DJOVANNI--Great
TANYA (seating hostess)--SHE NEEDS TO GO
author: arlene c.

description: If you understand that this restaurant is new and very crowded, you will know what to expect and will enjoy your food even more.  The only bad thing I can say about this place was that we had a reservation at 8:30 and we did not get seated till 9pm because they were really busy.  I was expecting a little delay, so I was not overly mad.  It helped that the hostess comped us a round of pisco sours due to our wait.  We had the ceviche combo which was excellent, I can't remeber what I had for the main course (too much booze), but all 6 of us trully enjoyed our entrees as well as the desert.  If I can sift thru the fog of that night, I will edit my review with our selections.  Very nice/huge restaurant and we had a great waitress.
author: Dave U.

description: Just OK.  Been there 3 times and won't go back again; even if the setting is very cool.  The noise level was a bit much where conversation was difficult with the person across the table.  All in all, overpriced and overrated.  One plus, presentation of the dishes was well above average.
author: Monica D.

description: Went for lunch on opening day, great location and atmosphere.  Tried a couple ceviches, a tiradito, and a causa.  All were very good, as were the plantain/potato/yam chips with dipping sauces they brought when we first sat down.  The pisco sours were very good too, if a bit sweet.  Definitely want to come back for dinner.
author: Ron W.

description:
Went on tuesday night with high hopes and see whats the difference between this La Mar and La Mar in Lima, Peru. Flavor is awesome, great creations, and of course pricy.  This is a great place to bring first timers and taste the different Peruvian flavors in a supposedly luxurious, high class atmosphere. The decor is plain simple, the dark wood bar section is awesome, the group section is chic w/sofas.  What you are gonna eat, or i should say "taste" is great refine food by the spoon. Very, very small portions. Remember the ceviche sampler at Limon(4small plates w/small ceviche portions) well, take half from each plate, thats what u will get.  Same for the main dishes ($20-25) worth about 4 big table spoons of food (Lomo Saltado: 4oz of rice, 3-4 strips of beef & sauce). Need to remember you are going for the " taste" not to get full.  And the menu tells u, it reads: the sampler dishes are for sharing(2people); the rest: appetizers and main dishes are NOT!. Cause it's funny seeing couples who order a main dish ($25) w/ an extra plate for sharing and realize the main dish is sooo diminutive, you cannot share it, and if u do, people are gonna stare at u and ....you know :)
*If you believe in the force like I do, Obi Wan Kenobi would definitely remind u: "Do NOT ask for an extra plate!" Concentrate & remember that.

Don't get me wrong, had a blast flavoring 3 dishes, the ceviche sampler ($25), jalea ($15) and pisco sour! ($9), and dessert ($10).  People you will enconter next to u, metrosexualmen from across the embarcadero center/enterpreneurs/venture capitalists and the innocent ones who are in for a portion surprise.

Oh, La Mar in Lima, Peru is way different, pretty much the same prices, but because of el Nino, Peru is so abundant with fish and variety that the dishes over there are 10 times bigger.  Yes, lots of people in Peru are monetarily incapacitated, poor, but they dont worry about food, the basic need.  Now if u still hungry and notice that the bill it's easily and quickly hittin $100, u can always ask for a refill of the Peruvian chips w/ the 3 dipping sauces(huancaina(yellow), rocoto(red), and mani(peanut based)  that are complementary served when you first sit down.  Remember where u are, don't eat the chips as fast as u do at Chevys, have some class damn it :)  It's hard, i had to stop and freeze with my mouth open and realize what I was doing.  They are so delicious that immediatly u realize what an experience this is going to be.

My ranking for Peruvian restaurants in SF:

1) La Mar (very special ocassions, or last dinner before jumpin the GGB)
2) Mochica (amazing fresh seafood, Jalea!, top class)
3)Fresca (anyday stop for the prices, ceviche and Pollo a la Brasa)
4)Toro Loco in Pacifica ( only for the Anticuchos-heartbeef, just like Lima)
5)El Perol inside Mission Market(only for Papa a la Huancaina, authentic)
6)and Lemon (closed due to fire, now on S.VanNess and 22nd) Lemon for...dunno what for, rather go to Mochica. 

I cant wait to go back to La Mar and try the rest of the desserts, Peruvian cocktails, and the rest of the appetizers.  Full strike at the appetizers where most of the flavors are. Bye.
author: Tony A.

description: Will definitely return for the food, drinks and atmosphere.  I suggest to the manager to lighten up on the reservation policy (15 minute window for seating).  Also, I know your busboys are super efficient and that you want to fill your tables in a timely manner and maximize your income, but having your bus boys removing dishes just milli-seconds after setting my cutlery down on the dish or wiping my mouth just makes your customers feel rushed.  May even make customers decide against making the return visit to La Mar.  Hopefully, a middle-ground can be reached with the pacing of the serving and removal of the dishes.
author: Lark A.

description:
This restaurant is a disaster!!!!!

From the service to the bathroom placement this place should be avoided at all costs.  My family and some old family friends went for dinner, received very little help understanding the menu.  The service was horrible, we had mistakes at ever step of service, a wine flight was forgotten with the drinks, and appetizer was forgotten then delivered twice, and the desserts were forgotten and then arrived before our coffee and after the digestives.  Then ontop 20% gratuity was added automatically which we protested but were told that it was policy over 6 people.  Do not go to this restaurant if you expect a pleasant dinning experience.
author: Brendan S.

description:
i was very impressed with this restaurant.  first off, there was a great energy in the place.  loads of people at the bar, the HUGE dining area was packed, and the patio held a wedding party.  the kitchen was off to the left of the restaurant, in plain view, and seriously clean.  i liked the colors in the kitchen...very aquatic.

the food was delicious. the different pisco were tasty and original.   the samples of empanadas and ceviches provided a nice way to taste the different varieties.  they were very attentive to our bachelorette party of 10.  we even had our own secluded space near the windows.

to me, la mar is one of the new breeds of the modern classic san francisco restaurants.  it's all the buzz now, and will be remembered and still popular in it's years to come.

can i recommend the tres leches for dessert?  please try it.  it's divine.
author: Sheri N.

description: Was there a few months back.  Great venue.  Comfortable seating, great food and walkable location.  Took some clients there and they were thoroughly impressed.  Me thinks their specialty is Ceviche (citrus marinated seafood) so if you like sushi, you'll get a huge hit of flavour beyond soy and wasabi.  +ives: solid food, good for groups -ives: can be tough to get a table unless you know the right people.
author: Rich T.

description:
The service deserves 1 star. The food deserves 4.
They started out by sitting our table of 5 at a 4-top, so someone got the crack. The super duper tall waiter did nothing to help me avoid a neck ache while I ordered for the table - he just stood right behind me making me turn and look straight up. Very awkward.
A server dropped a dirty (saucy) fork on my skirt and napkin after kicking my purse on the ground and was barely apologetic about either incident. 
After asking about (not ordering) the ceviche sampler, we were brought out an order. Interesting. And it came 15 mins before our drink order. Ceviche is not very fun without the pisco sour. Flagging down anybody was a nightmare. It seems that there are too many servers who are not in sync.  I ordered a bunch of food for sharing and they brought it all out at one time. It didn't fit in our little 4 top, to say the least. The waiter should have figured out that the plates should come out in batches.
They forgot my diet coke. I waited and waited. I reminded the waiter eventually and then told him to forget about it. After we paid the bill and were getting ready to leave, a diet coke suddenly appeared.
Really bad service, overall.
author: SG G.

description:
Im shocked to see all the negative reviews bashing this new establishment on everything from service, to prices, to portion size.  I mean this is San Francisco one of the foodie capitals of the world and clearly its not gonna come cheap.  The location is also on the embarcadero which of course will have one of the highest rents in the city.  If you expect to pay under 50 a piece, then this is not the place for you.  I personally loved this place and would recommend it to anyone looking for a new unique place to eat.  The buildout is fantastic, eye catching, spacious and totally trendy.  I called for a reservation on Monday, went to dinner on Wednesday and were greated in a friendly and professional matter.  I had my motorcycle helmet with me and the staff were kind enough to hold onto it for me behind the hostess stand so it woudlnt be in our way during dinner.  We were seated instantly and the service was top notch.  We had the ceviche clasico and lomo saltado, both of which were exceptional.  I loved the banana & sweet potato chips with cheese dipping sauces too.  It was about 80 for two people without alcohol.   

I left extremely full and very happy that I got to try this type of cuisine.  Cant wait to go back!!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Damn this place is good. The food is fresh, tasty and pleasing to the eye. Who knew Peruvian-Japanese fusion would be such a dynamic duo?! 

All you need to know is that if it's served with the Nikkei sauce, it's delicious. I also recommend the Bloody Mary. It has octopus, mussels, and all sorts of sea-dwelling critters marinating in it's pisco-laden tomato goodness.

I haven't dined outside yet, but I'd imagine it's enough to make me lobby for a sixth star addendum to the yelp rating scale.
author: Nick G.

description:
A good friend of mine recommended this place and later on invited me.
Reservations are a must if you want to seat comfortably. We had dinner at the bar instead to avoid the long wait. 

My friend and I decided to split everything since we just wanted to sample the food. We had the Cebiche mixto which in my opinion, was the best, Parihuela soup which was just ok, and the norteno as a rice dish which wasn't too bad but not great. 

I think I ordered a Sauvignon blanc to pair with the seafood dishes. The wine selection seemed limited. I forgot the dessert we had but we ordered two of them and they topped the meal!

The only reason I would hesitate to go back to La Mar Cebicheria is because there aren't enough water closets and they were not clean at all. 

Overall, this place gets 2.5 stars!
author: JL V.

description: I'm dreaming of going here again when the sun shines. It's like an instant vacation to a high-luxe resort on the Pacific coast of Mexico. We took the Chihuahua with us to sit outside on the banquets and snarf down the fabulous ceviche. Sip sipping on a Pisco sour turned me completely sweet. Oh, yeah.
author: Lynka A.

description:
Everything was perfect basically. 

The food was suprising and delicious. I got the Parmesean scallops and purple mashed potatos with artichoke.

The scene was popping and lively without being obnoxious.

It couldnt be more beautiful on the water and everything. 

But most of all the service was warm and thoughtful. Our waiter did such a great job and the manager even came over and spoke to us. When he found out about it being my boyfriend and brother and law's birthday celebration he even sent over delicous pumpkin fritters with candles. 

It was such a special night and I for one really want one of these in NYC!
author: Summer C.

description:
I would have ordered everything on the menu. I love Peruvian food and this restaurant did a very good job at providing it.
I went here for lunch, and instead of ordering an appetizer and an entrée, we ordered several smaller dishes which was great because I got to try a lot of different things. 
To start, they give you this chips with different sauces which are amazing, we had to ask if they could bring us more. We ordered the ceviche mixto, crab causa, anticucho de pulpo, all really good, and the empanadas de mar, which I didn't like very much.  
The service was very good, extremely friendly.
I had the impression that this place was really expensive, but I was wrong. We ate a lot and it wasn't pricey at all for the quality of the food.
I'm definitely going back.
author: carla f.

description: Food is good; if you like fish dishes, this is the place to go.  The non-fish fare was only OK.  The ambiance is very energetic, with appealing music, nice view of the water, and very trendy.  The place is a lot of fun; a bit expensive for what it is, service is pretty good if sometimes slow, but otherwise a very fun evening out.
author: Michal T.

description:
Sad to say it, but we were disappointed.
I'll start with the pisco sour, which is what we all started with.  My folks thought they were too heavy on the egg-white (which there was indeed a lot of), and I thought the white should have been a creamier foam.  I think they're better at Pisco lounge.
Then we'll get to the service.  Actually, I think the servers are doing as good a job as they can, but I think they're way under staffed (or someone called in sick last minute).  There was one waiter for our entire (large) section, so we saw very little of him.  To make up for that, though, damn do things show up fast after you order them!  That was really impressive.
While trying to flag down our waiter to order some wine, we got to spend a fair amount of time looking at the space.  It's white.  And remarkably bland.  There's a big open kitchen in the back (you can tell when there's a big flare-up every few minutes) but most of the seating is organized such that you can't really see it well.  Honestly, it's a pretty boring space.  Maybe they were going for the simplicity of a Peruvian cebicheria, but that just makes the $20 entrees seem ridiculous, so maybe it's better if they just weren't creative?
Finally, the food.  It was good.  That's about it.  I've had better ceviche multiple places in the city - Destino most recently.  The chunks of mahi mahi in it, aside from being a poor choice environmentally, were tough and slightly fishy.  The 3 chile sauces with the house-made plantain chips were tasty, and the empanadas were also quite tasty (though again, I think Destino's are better).  Neither of the 2 rice dishes my folks got were great - one had so much more rice than seafood it felt like an excavation to find the fish.  The other was much more balanced, and had an interesting sort of smoky flavor, but certainly wasn't a standout.  I think I got the best of the 3, a roasted corvina over beans.  The fish was excellent, and the beans (while very filling) were a good match with it.

So yes, the physical location on the water is great, but the space itself is quite uninspired, the food is only average, and the price is high.  Unless I hear they've improved, I doubt I'll bother returning.
author: Don H.

description: Excellent happy hour! Just show up before the masses at 5, grab a seat at the bar and indulge in super fresh, flavorful, thoughtfully prepared ceviches and assorted root chips with three dipping sauces. Wash it down with a tangy and refreshing $5 pisco punch and you're good to go.
author: Jen S.

description:
Saturday was date night with my husband and we had 9 o'clock dinner reservations at La Mar Cebicheria, Gastón Acurio's first San Francisco project at Pier 1 1/2 next to the Ferry Building.  I had read about Acurio, he is a heavy hitter in Peruvian cuisine.  He owns many restaurants, has published cookbooks and is a celebrity TV chef.   Beyond that, I didn't know what to expect. 

We took a cab to the Embarcadero and were immediately drawn into the spacious, vibrant space, accented in blue, green and burnt orange hues.  We were a tad early so hubby and I sidled up to the bar and grabbed a Cristal Peruvian beer ($5) and pisco sour ($10), respectively.  My cocktail, made from distilled grapes with lime juice, simple syrup, egg whites and bitters was so refreshing.  It was a perfect combo of tart, sweet, bitter and creamy.  We decided to share the empanadas de ají de gallina ($10) while we waited. Two big, savory pockets filled with tender hen arrived with a small salad tossed in a sweet vinaigrette.  It was delish!  We were really excited about the rest of the meal.

As soon as we were done, the hostess led us past the bustling lounge and raw bar showcasing beautiful, fresh octopus, and into the main dining room where my seat offered a good view of the open kitchen.  We shared a bunch of things, starting with the cebiche sampler.  It consisted of four plates of fish briefly marinated in different types of "leche de tigre," or chili peppers and lime juice.  The clásico featured California halibut and red onions in habanero pepper leche de tigre with Peruvian corn and yam.  In the mixto, there was Mahi Mahi, calamari, octopus and habanero pepper in ají amarillo leche de tigre, with cilantro and red onion.  In the nikei, ahi tuna was the star, with red onion and Japanese cucumber, in tamarind leche de tigre with avocado.  Finally, the chifa consisted of Mahi Mahi with peanuts, scallions, ginger, pickled carrots, daikon, habanero pepper, wonton strips and cilantro with sesame leche de tigre.  As many of you know by now, I don't do peanuts, so I had the chifa without, but it was still excellent.  We enjoyed each kind immensely, and my husband says it was the best cebiche he has ever tasted.  The fish was incredibly fresh and the flavors really popped.  Just beware of those thin slices of habanero pepper hiding beneath the cilantro leaves, unless you like setting your tongue on fire.

The anticuchos de pulpo ($13), or grilled octopus skewers with herbed mashed potato with chimichurri sauce and ají panca, is a must.  It's amazing.  You get large pieces of tender octopus boasting a nice smokey flavor with a slightly sweet hint. 

The causa limeña ($12) came out next.  It had whipped potato with Dungeness crab, avocado puree, quail egg, cherry tomatoes, ají amarillo Huancaina sauce with basil cilantro oil.  It was like a dressed up crab salad, tasty and creamy, but didn't wow us as much as the other items we sampled. 

Our server was so enthusiastic about the anticuchos de corazón ($11), or grilled beef heart skewers, which he claimed were so reminiscent of the ones he found while traveling in Peru, that we had to give them a shot.  We did this, despite our misgivings, having recently eaten duck heart elsewhere that was really tough and tasted like iron.  Well, right on, Nick, you called it!  It was surprisingly good, with a texture somewhat similar to a filet.  The red rocoto sauce packed a lot of heat, wow!  But fortunately, it was on the side so we could use as much or little as we wanted.

The complimentary basket of potato, sweet potato and plantain chips was good which is a testament to how well food is seasoned and prepared here.  My husband isn't a big fan of potatoes, but he actually liked the potato chips the best.  The chips were crispy, perfectly salted, cut on the thicker side and not all greasy.  They came with three sauces:  huancaína with ají amarillo, rocoto, and ocopa with peanuts.  To boot, my husband also enjoyed the potatoes prepared in different ways in the rest of the dishes; what a nice surprise.

We were too full for dessert, but next time, I may save room for the rollitos de arroz con leche ($10), a rice pudding spring roll topped with homemade ají amarillo and orange marmalade with passion fruit sorbet.  We'll see, because first, I want to try  other items including tiraditos, sopas, salads, rice plates and main entrees.  They also have an interesting wine list with varieties from South America, Spain and California which needs exploring.  

Our hostess and server were very friendly and attentive, and we appreciated it when the manager stopped by our table to see how we were doing.  We loved the airy space and lively atmosphere, it felt celebratory.  It would be great to return to La Mar during the day to take in the Bay view on their 80-seat patio.
author: Dina B.

description: Ceviche Clasico is wonderful.  Simply wonderful.  This place is perfect for a upscale lunch with great views and a beautifully appointed interior.  The plaintain/yucca chip/dip thing they bring out is a great start, and I recommend the pisco sours.  The hot menu is fair quality, but doesn't stand out like the ceviche does.  Service is so-so, though the waitstaff are easy on the eyes.  Go for the ceviche.
author: Joseph G.

description: The food and service here is good and refreshingly different from any others around.  It is good for business, family, dates...I especially like that the portions are generous enough to share a taste. The staff is knowledgeable too.  It is not a simple short menu so choosing can be cumbersome.  I have had to wait to be seated even with a reservation on more than one occasion, so plan for a drink first.    The bar is cozy and the restaurant is spacious and airy (can be cold at night--take a wrap).  I hope it can maintain its popularity.
author: Rita G.

description: This is an update.  Despite the paucity of money in my banking account, I wanted to go out with friends to enjoy a special Leos birthday dinner. I'm impractical and dangerous like that. Everything was fabulous as usual.  Food, drink, service...  a minor blemish having to ask for cream for our coffee a couple of times... no biggie... but what shocked and hurt me was THEY TOOK THE BUNUELOS OFF THE MENU!!!!!!!!!!!! OK... I want to put a million exclamation points after that because it's so friggin' impossible to believe.  These were UNIQUE and truly INCREDIBLE and should have won the best desserts of all time in the universe award so their foolish foolish foolish foolish foolish foolish answer to this was to "change it up"  "keep it fresh"  .... awwwww COME ON!!! CUT THE BULLSHIT!!!  I spent my last $80 on dinner at your restaurant and had to leave disappointed.  I will SERIOUSLY not go back until you put these on the menu permanently.  You have those sickly fritters with honey on the menu .... OK OK ... it's "classic" Peruvian ... I don't care... I had 'em and they suck.  GET THE BUNUELOS BACK or you've lost me and my clan forever.  Period.
author: Richard P.

description: Lots of space, excellent seafood! Sat at the island-style inner bar area on my first trip. Service and food was v good that night, but it was an unusually quiet tuesday from what we were told. Ceviche sampler was great - I would have to recommend the Japanese or Chinese style versions. You may even want to drink the "leche de tigre" - lime/fish juice marinade. Fish seemed very fresh. The assortment of chips with dips that's standard service will easily fill you up so save some room. The grilled octopus was amazing the first time, could have been a bit more charred and salted on my second visit. Entrees were pretty good - esp the gumbo-type seafood stew. There is a surprisingly large vegetarian selection. Main dining area was a bit noisy and service wasn't the greatest on the second go round. Bottom line is food and drinks were a touch pricey but well worth it.
author: Manj G.

description: Awesome food! The causas limena was amazing. The flavors are clean and go together very nicely. Modern design and nice people. Casual attire but good food.
author: Foodie Y.

description:
one of my new faborite restaurants.  

came here with a friend for a weeknight "i need a drink" dinner and wow, are these drinks ridiculous.  I'm more of a wine girl than a cocktail girl but I didn't touch the vino at all that night (or would it be bino?)!  Tried 3 of the cocktails (yes, it was that bad of a day) and can't wait to get back and try some more.

we had the 2 samplers for dinner.  the cebiche sampler was by far better than the causas, and i thought the boat presentation was a little excessive.  dessert of the beignets was a perfect ending.  

To be honest, i think i would've been perfectly happy with a drink (or 3) and that "chips and salsa" thing they've got going on.
author: Alyssa W.

description: Ok, I JUST realized that I am NOT a fan of Yucca, it's just YUCKA!!! The texture KILLS me!!!! Had a group birthday dinner there and must say, it's a good space, good service and fun! Food wise, it was good/ok, nothing really stood out and mind you we had a family style with several offerings from the menu so we had a broad sample. What DID stand out was their Tiramasu! I am NOT a fan of Tiramasu but theirs is also mixed/made with a cheesecake and OMFG it was SO good!!!! Oh and the Civiche was AWESOME too! I only gave it 3 stars, need to go back and try it again and see how it goes....
author: Rob L.

description:
Wonderful restaurant.  Had lunch there today on the sun deck.  It wasn't as busy as it deserves to be.  I love properly prepared ceviche....theirs is lovely....one caution....if you do not like celantro it is in almost everything....that said, I loved everything we had from the Tuna Cebeche to the meat & veg pies to the sampler plate...and the patio on a sunny day is a nice place to enjoy.

I am back again on another sunny day.
author: Bryce L.
