description: My friends and I decided at the spur of the moment to try La Mar. It was wonderful. We had the three sampler platters (cerbiche tasting, empanada sampler and causa tasting). These three samplers gave us a nice variety and allowed those who had never had Peruvian food to see what it's all about. I left a little hungry, but that's not a bad thing. My favorite was the tuna cerbiche, followed by the tuna causa and then then chicken empanada. We very much look forward to returning for after work cocktails and dinner sometime. The atmosphere is very relaxed and the service was wonderful. There is a back patio that over looks the bay and on a nice summer day it would the be idea place to eat. I have no problem recommending this restaurant!
author: Lisa C.

description: Free sweet potato and plantain chips with dipping sauces were great.  I liked their Solterito (Quinoa Salad) and Ceb Nikei (Japanese style). Perfect for lunch or eat outside on the water front in warm, sunny days.
author: Rita L.

description:
i had the cebiche clasico, an empanada sampler, and the their almuercito criollo (which consists of grilled fish skewers, cebiche chalaco, and an empanada).

the cebiche clasico was very good, but i've had better. they use soft peruvian corn instead of the crunchy "corn nuts" a lot of other places use (i actually prefer the corn nuts, personally). the empanadas were very good. their mushroom empanadas (de k'apchi) were empowered by the flavor of the pisco (liquor) they use. but they were still good. the cebiche chalaco was good, but i prefer their cebiche clasico.

the fish skewers were incredible. they were cooked perfectly and had a beautiful taste. sadly, i'm not even sure what kind of fish it was, but it was fresh.

la mar is definitely worth trying.
author: J L.

description: I don't try and use superlatives when describing a restaurant but this is the best ceviche I have ever tasted and a really damn good piece of steak. It was simply amazing.  We started out with 4 appetizers and the ceviche was by far the best. The tuna was so fresh that it melted in your mouth. The flavors were exploding on your tongue with each bite. For my entree, I had the beef with fried potatoes (fries) and rice. I have never had more tender piece of beef in my life. This is by far and away the best restaurant in San Francisco right now. Great value. The atmosphere is bright and the wait staff is amazing. If I could give this place 6 stars I would.
author: John S.

description: I was surprised by some of the reviews about the bar at La Mar, that the service is poor and the bartenders are rude. I went there today for a Pisco. The bartenders were busy color-chalking the blackboard. They definitely do not know what customer service means. Wont be back to the bar again. The food is great though. So 3 stars.
author: Daria G.

description: Great pisco sours, disappointing sangria, excellent empanadas, tasty ceviche, but don't forget you're paying high end restaurant prices even in the bar.  Fun when you're up for dealing with a crowd.  Also, we found service to be fine in the bar area.  They dealt with the hordes well.
author: Leo C.

description:
this is going to be a hot ticket in town as soon as more people discover it!  its the first restaurant in north america of famed peruvian chef and restaurateur Gaston Acurio http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaston_Acurio 

building - historic and nicely renovated, right next to the ferry building with the bar window facing embarcadero and the back window facing the water

alcohol bar - classy, cool amber sphere light filament fixtures, view of the embarcadero, frothy delicious pisco sours, nice bartenders, super helpful staff, food menu available

entry way - super tall ceilings, light and airy feeling, friendly host staff

cebiche bar - watch your cebiche  prepared (like a sushi bar) and dine at the 'counter', cool blue light from underneath the bar makes it glow

dining room - wow.  fabulously designed with tall windows, water view, dark wood, bright turquoise webbed chairs, open kitchen, surprisingly full for the 2nd day they were open to the public (tuesday 9/30)

food - exquisite. taste. freshness. presentation. variety. color. taste. texture. a riot of flavors.  we were lucky enough to have 2 peruvians with us -- so Cintia ordered for all of us. plate after plate of fabulous deliciousness.  halibut, tuna, scallops, octopus, shrimp and more!  i wish i knew the names of the dishes, but i don't - we had both cold and hot dishes and they were all uniformly superb.  the only thing i didn't like was the octopus skewer (but that's a personal thing, esp the texture...)  for dessert, we had the creme caramel sampler (chocolate, vanilla, a grain, and a fruit flavor) and sorbet trio (lemon mint, pink guava, and a peruvian fruit that tastes like custard) -- the desserts were the perfect ending to a wonderful dinner.

service - waitstaff was great -- esp considering it was the 2nd night! though i might suggest that the explanations should also include the "plain english" version of what it is -- after we're told the beautiful official name in spanish.  sometimes, asking what something is and being told "anticuchos" isn't helpful :)  if i had one other criticism - it'd be that we had a reservation for 10 people at 8p.  we weren't able to be seated until 8:30 and the communication between us and the hostesses wasn't the greatest.  however, i expect that to be worked out as they smooth out the operations.

total cost for 8 people (we ordered a lot of food!) was ~$500 incl tip, 1 bottle of wine, and a few cocktails from the bar.

definitely going back.  you should too.
author: Dora F.

description:
Surely the best Peruvian restaurant in California, and quite likely, in the US.  Went for lunch today, with high expectations.  The location can't be beat.  Patio dining (by the sea!) will be offered starting next week.  The indoor space is ample, airy, modern, and sophisticated.  You'll recognize the colors, furniture, and even waitstaff uniforms from the original La Mar, in Lima (this is a franchise, after all).  Don't go expecting a traditional Peruvian cevichería, "huarique"-style.  If you have ever heard of Gastón Acurio, you will know that he has worked hard at bringing Peruvian cuisine up to international standards.  Don't get me wrong.  Peruvian food, per se, is delicious.  But where, until recently, could you find such care in the presentation, such innovation in the dishes prepared, besides the most tried and true of Peruvian ceviches, rice dishes, and stews?  Enter Gastón.  But I am getting ahead of myself.  La Mar-San Francisco's menu is still limited when compared to the original's.  On to the food.

Our choice of drinks: Chicha tu ma, Pisco Punch, and Pisco Sour.  Loved the Pisco Punch!  Curiously, this drink originated in San Francisco.  It is fruity: pisco, lime and pineapple juices.  We shared a ceviche chifa, a tiradito clásico, a causa criolla, and the anticuchos, as appetizers.  I had the arroz norteño for an entree.  My husband tried the tuna special.  The two other people in our party went for the pescado a lo pobre and the arroz criollo (better known as arroz con mariscos).  The best appetizer was the anticuchos: grilled ají panca-marinated octopus (with chimichurri, chopped herbs in oil) over mashed potato with herbs.  Ají panca (on anticuchos at least) is rarely hot.  It is similar to paprika in taste.  The octopus was tender, tasty.  I can't imagine a better way to cook it than in the grill.  My arroz norteño was also delicious.  The rice itself was "atamalado," moist and plump.  Have you tried arroz con pollo or arroz con pato?  Well, I had the seafood version.  The predominant flavor (other than cilantro, of course) was the char from the wok!  It was served with huancaína sauce (I still had to ask for some ají amarillo sauce for that extra spice).  Loved it.  For dessert, we ordered picarones and lúcuma tiramisú.  Those picarones!  Just like in Peru!  The zapallo (squash) taste shone through.  They were deep-fried to perfection and served (as tradition dictates) with chancaca honey.  Wary of getting lost in translation?  A glossary is provided in the menu.  I am not a fan of lúcuma, but my husband is.  He loved the lúcuma ice cream accompanying the tiramisu.  D'onofrio fans, you may be disappointed!  This is fresh lúcuma through and through.  I hear you can also find it in Mitchell's (in San Francisco), but La Mar's is way better, gelato-like creamy and with a very concentrated flavor.  I had tea; everyone else had coffee drinks.  No, you won't find your favorite (ok, mine) mate here, but the usual selection of jasmine, green, etc.  A good choice of dessert wines too!

As for the prices, appetizers range between $8-$15 (approximately).  Do go for the half orders of ceviche (and taste more!).  The price of entrées is in the low to mid 20s.  I was a guest this time (thus, my lack of precision).  Service was attentive and friendly.  We saw quite a few Peruvian families in attendance.  I hear that weekdays tend to attract more of a business crowd.  The full menu is available at the bar between lunch and dinner hours.    

Southern Californians, rejoice!  La Mar is coming to San Diego next year.
author: Vanessa S.

description: Nothing special here... had a bad experience with Ceviche, probably ordered the wrong one. Empanadas were good tho! Plus the orange chocolate dessert was wonderful! Lamb shank tasted like plastic.. very awkward. I wouldn't go here again.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Went to a pre-opening dinner here last night.  What a beautiful space!  The bar along the Embarcadero is so classy, with big open windows and a nice staff.  The pisco sour and the pisco punch were both delicious and refreshing.  There is a breezeway in the center with a nice cebiche bar and colorful seating.  It's actually part of the public access area so it really feels inviting to both patrons and the public - like all the cool lobby/atrium areas you see in NYC.  The food was great - particularly the cebiches.  

Had the cebiche clasico and the causa tasting for appetizers.  The causas were beautifully prepared, brightly colored, and fresh with seafood toppings.  My favorite was probably the crab.  Also had the tiger prawns and the pan fried Alaskan Halibut filet - both really good, plenty of spice and flavor.  

I can't wait until this place is officially opened.  It will be a wonderful place to go after work and sit out on their patio right on the waterfront.  Delicious.
author: Ming Y.

description: I had the cibiche sampler, which was a generous amount of food for a starter.  Four different dishes, all of which were pretty tasty: a good balance between spicy, sour and "sweet" tasting sauces over a variety of raw seafood.  But the kicker was the entree of sea bass over mashed cannelloni beans -- wow -- warm and comforting, light and yet filling.  What kind of voodoo did they use to make this stuff.  Give me more.
author: Adam L.

description:
Always enjoy eating here.

Huge restaurant, so sometimes if there is less staff on (odd/non peak hours) it can be a bit slower due to the distance they need to cover to get a drink (at the bar in front of the restaurant) to the patio (a football field away, but the best place to sit).

If your cocktails are taking a long time, opt for a bottle of wine.  The bar is so popular and you can't pack more bartenders into it, if the place is packed expect to wait for cocktails.

The cebiches are amazing- and well priced (think of sushi and how much you pay for 2 piece nigiri them compare it with what you get in your cebiche bowl here!)  This is their specialty.

The octopus skewers are more like chicken in texture (and I usually am not a fan, but these are GOOD).  The sauce is flavorful.

All of the Arroz style main courses are big enough to share for two so if you are on the price conscious side, opt for one of those or the Veggie Risotto (YUM).

Very fairly priced considering the location, atmosphere and QUALITY of the food.

Highly Recommend!
author: Sasha C.

description: I went here for my last night in town and I am glad I did. The service was surprisingly on point, considering it is a fairly casual atmosphere. The staff seemed genuine, knowledgeble, and friendly. The ceviches were great and so was the cappuccino tres leches dessert. A must-try!
author: Vitor L.

description: Gorgeous restaurant right on the water.  I came for lunch and tried several ceviches (all of them are awesome) and the dungeness crab appetizer (delish!).  For my entree, I ordered the chupe de camarones at the waiter's suggestion -- the stew was very hearty and fairly heavy as well (too much so for lunch).  They have this one drink there with egg whites and brandy (don't remember the name)-- order that!
author: Mitzi C.

description: I started with a $14.00 glass of sake in the bar. This seemed way over priced. I do like the cool breezy feel to the restaurant. The service was good but we had a 5:30 reservation. I had the seared tuna. Maybe I'm not into Peruvian but it had too much salt and spice. It could have been any fish. I might stop in for a beer but I'll pass on dinner.
author: Chris N.

description:
now, I've never been to Peru or had supposed authentic Peruvian food, but this stuff was SIMPLY DELICIOSO!

here is why:
:: the open kitchen concept and calming sea green and blue colors of the restaurant put you in the right mood to indulge and excite your taste buds!
:: the cocktail menu, though a mouthful (har har), is filled with fun and fruity concoctions. my favorite was the cholopolitan! 
:: the huuuge menu of seasonal and classic peruvian appetizers and entrees satisfied any of your shellfish, meat, or fish cravings. we enjoyed the seared tuna and halibut carpaccio, as well as the deep-fried-everything appetizer called "juela".
:: ah, and the ocean view. you will be transmorgified into a south american chica with her very own waterfront plantation house. 
:: gorgeous presentation and leisure service (read: not for those of you that are in a hurry) makes it a place to settle into after a long day's work!

a fun place for groups, a festive place for couples, and a fruitful place even if you want to dine alone at the bar. 

it's not perfect yet (thus the quattro bling blings), but me want to go back!  who's in?!
author: Diana L.

description: Absolutely the best Peruvian in the city.  The ceviche is yummy, just as everyone says.  I'd actually say that you should stick to that, and maybe some other seafood dishes.  Expect to be there for hours.
author: Amme P.

description:
Food = 4-5 stars.
Service = 2 stars.

Made reservations 3 weeks in advance for Friday night and requested outside seating.  Given an 8:15 reservation and we arrived early to have drinks at there very busy bar.  This was all expected.  When seated we were given a table at the water edge at the uncovered area of the patio.  Being the usual SF night it was frigid out there and asked to be seated at any one of a number of the open tables under the heat lamps.  I was then told they were "reserved" and that if we wanted one of those we should have reserved those at the time of making the reservation.  I had never been to the place prior to this and didn't think you had to "reserve" a heat lamp table...what a friggin joke!    We said we would wait until one "opened up"  .  After about an hour (it is now 9:30 pm)  they said they could only seat us inside now.  Frustrated we we took the table but soon noted numerous open tables outside.  We were too hungry and the food looked too good to leave.  I MAY return some in the future as the food, as hundred of other reviewers have stated, is great.  I would suggest avoid busy weekend nights.
author: Damon S.

description:
Hate to do this, but 2 stars is actually generous


PROS-
*Cerviche was pretty good
*When the outdoor patio is completed, should be a nice setting for drinks and cerviche
*bar area is not bad

CONS
*paper table mats (what is this, Pizza Hut???!!)
*poor acoustic experience, very noisy (waiter said they were working on this problem with sound paneling)
*poor hostess experience. Not that the hostess wasn't pleasant enough, upon arrival with a reservation, she told us that our table was finishing desert -  no updates or explanations... 45 minutes later,  we finally inquire if our table was ready yet, to which she replied, " oh, okay, yeah your table is ready" then asked us to gather our party. Another 5 minutes lined up at the door waiting with no reception,  we had to inquire again if she was going to seat us...."oh, yeah" another few minutes....etc...not very smooth!
*fair service- wait staff spread too thinly, poor timing and service technique. Waiter recommendations of "the best menu item"  was chewy and pretty unimpressive (grilled octopus skewers). He also recommended the lomo saltado
*Lomo saltado was probably the worst I've had in the city
 
Summary of experience- 

This restaurant is VERY large, and not very well run. It looks very impressive, but is like a really pretty girl with no personality.  Overall vibe is kind of 'cheesecake factory-ish' certainly not the most pleasant experience unless you like that kind of place.  They are new and are probably trying to do the best they can, but with so many FANTASTIC restaurants in SF, why waste the meal? 

Food is average at best, (although the cerviche was a little above average). I might go here again on a nice day when the patio is ready  but I certainly would not rush back there.

Essencia, Limon or Fresca much better!!
author: Susan D.

description:
I was introduced to this place by my co-worker and was worth checking it out.  I was in a mood for good ceviche so went for the Ceviche Tasting for $24 which consisted of 4 types of ceviches:  Mixto, Chifa, Nikei and one more which I can't remember.  All of them were great and especially liked the Nikkei one.  The chips that they offer instead of bread were also very good. Unfortunately I was there by myself for lunch so I was not able to order other dishes.  

The table next to me ordered Chupe de Camarones and looked very appetizing.  I will most likely have that the next time I go there.

Service was good but the only cons is the fact that it was pretty loud.  I was by myself listening to my ipod but it will probably be too loud for a casual event or a date. 

As for price it is a little pricey and the portions are not huge but the taste is definitely top notch.
author: Marcelo N.

description: This is a place to go if you really want to impress people. Right off the pier with a gorgeous ocean view, modern design and look, with beautiful presentation. The ceviche was delightful, though not exquisite, the corn however was the most addicting corn i've ever had, and normal i'm not a big fan of corn. Any dish with a side dish of corn is sure to delight. The causas were beautiful, but not addictingly tasty. Overall, if you're a big fan of raw tuna, halibut, mahi mahi, and squid/octopus, this is the non-sushi choice you have to seem urban and trendy. Be prepared to come slightly full or with a fat wallet.
author: Tony Y.

description: Good location right next to the ferry building, nice pastel colored decor, fantastic drinks. Their happy hour is a good deal with tasty fruit-filled sangrias and cebiche mixto for $6. My new go-to drinks place near the Financial District.
author: Vikram K.

description:
I took my girlfriend here for a surprise birthday dinner. She had raved about the Lima location, so we were curious to see how SF stacked up. Overall, we were pleased (and stuffed!).

While vibrant, La Mar's expansive dining area seems more fitting for groups than intimate dates. 3.5 stars.

Service was adequate; waiters provided recommendations and refilled my water frequently. 3.5 stars. 

We began with the cebiche tasting, which is a great choice for indecisive foodies like ourselves. The clasico was our favorite, and I also liked the nikei, with ahi tuna immersed in a tart tamarind leche de tigre. 4 stars.

While cebiche kicks you in the teeth, tiradito melts in your mouth. We ordered the clasico, and the yellowtail tasted so fresh and so clean. 4 stars.

The rocoto relleno, stuffed with beef tenderloin, peanuts, raisins, gouda, and cilantro, was earthy, hearty, and a perfect foil for the opening fish. 4.5 stars.

Neither of us finished our main course because of our opening feast. My seco de cordero was expectedly tender, but the tacu tacu tasted fairly bland. My girlfriend's scallops were tasty. 4 stars.

For dessert, we ordered the tiramisu, but I was so stuffed that I only had a bite. 

Décor: 3.5 stars
Service: 3.5 stars
Openers: ~4 stars
Main: 4 stars
Desert: N/A
Overall: 3.75 stars

I'll give La Mar the benefit of an extra 1/4 star because of its "Gastronomic Dictionary." Found on La Mar's website, this handy online feature provides explanations for Peruvian foods and cooking styles. Extremely useful for any Peruvian foodie.

Also, order a pisco sour! Pisco sours are the drinks with the peruvian brandy and the egg whites...smooooth.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Went here again for dinner -- this time took my brother for his birthday. 
Not sure if it was just an off night for La Mar but I ordered the same dish as last time, the Shrimp soup --- this time, it was a-ok....
my bf ordered the seared ahi tuna dish -- portion was the size of an appetizer 
my brother ordered the duck - he loved it, so that was all that mattered that night.
In the end, I think after eating at Fresca the other night and coming back to La Mar, Fresca is much tastier and their portions are better for the price. However, La Mar is still fun to go to..but I think Fresca or another place would be my choice the next time I want Peruvian.
author: Julie M.

description: I've been to one of Gaston's restaurants in Lima (Panchita) -- once you've been to one of his restaurants in Peru, you cannot compare.  Food was decent, ambiance was nice, but there are much better restaurants in SF.
author: A B.

description: I've dined at this fine establishment two times now and have been very pleased with the presentation and the quality of the food. Each plate is a visual feast and my friends grow impatient with me as I must photograph each plate before anyone can eat. The outdoor dining with a view of the Bay is lovely too!  I highly recommend La Mar for a tasty and exotic dining experience!
author: Deirdre R.

description: I had the Lomo Saltado and it was delicious. Appetizers were delicious. Great ambiance and bar.  The service was excellent.  They did charge me a 21 dollar corking fee, But other than that it was a near perfect dinner.
author: Ara M.

description:
I had dinner on a Saturday evening at La Mar and felt compelled to join yelp and write my first review after eating here.  

Truthfully, I have been searching for a Peruvian restaurant that can do both the traditional Peruvian dishes and the more modern/fusion interpreted Peruvian dishes as well.  This combination is rare.  I am happy to say I found both at La Mar. If it is of any measure, my family is Peruvian and I have tried a number of Peruvian restaurants in the SF area (Limon, Fresca and Mi Lindo Peru) within the last year and felt that two of the three restaurants were good but not authentic enough for me.  The space of the restaurant is great (high ceilings, bright blue lights, on the water); the vibe, upscale but somewhat laid back.  The server was knowledgeable about the menu and ingredients.  

I went into the dinner somewhat skeptical about the authenticity and how overdone the food might be and came out a fan.  After dinner, I called my family to rave about having found a Peruvian restaurant that is worthy to take them to when they visit.  

To start, we had "chalaca", the ceviche starter, and "Tiradito clásico".   "Chalaca" or "choros a la chalaca"  are mussels topped with lime juice, diced fresh tomatoes and onions.  This appetizer you can eat just about anywhere in Peru but really I have memories of having them on a hot day at the beach in the middle of the afternoon.  The "choros" were as fresh as I have had them.  We tried 4 different kinds of ceviche (ceviche clásico, ceviche mixto, Japanese influenced ceviche, Chinese influenced ceviche).  The choice of fish, the cut or presentation and sauce for each version of the ceviche was interesting.   The ceviche was served in small tapas like plates with medium sized cubes halibut, Mahi-Mahi, Yellow Tail and Ahi (depending on the ceviche you ordered).   The ceviche clasico was soaked in the lime based  "leche de tigre" sauce with thinly sliced onions, and some kernels of white corn (the corn that peruvians are oh so proud of).  The Japanese ceviche had cubes of Ahi with some tiny specks of seaweed on top. The mixto had more of the yellow chili pepper lime sauce and the Chinese influenced ceviche had an air of sesame in its sauce.   The Tiradito was served in thinly sliced leaf-like cuts with a leaf of cilantro and tiny piece of "rocoto" (chili pepper) resting on top.  It was very delicate.  

As our main, we shared "Seco de Cordero", a extremely tender lamb shank dressed in a cilantro based stew with with carrots and peas, and the classic Peruvian soup "Chupe de Camarones".  The lamb in the "Seco" was extremely tender served on the bone on top of a hash brown like potato mash with light cheese in the middle.  The lamb was not too gamy.  My only complaint is that despite having the carrots and few peas, it needed a little more of the cilantro stew served with it.    

The "Chupe" I had at La Mar was as traditional as it gets and I was very pleased with it.   As usual, it had a variety of ingredients. This "Chupe" has a milky soup base with shrimp, Aji, chopped onions, garlic, rice, potatoes, peas, and a poached egg in it.  It was savory and delicious albeit a tad salty.  I left that night happy that I could taste something like my grandmother's "Chupe" here so far away from Peru.
author: M H.

description: Fried plantains with dipping sauces - tasty! Every cebiche i tried... amazing!  Cocktails, Wine, Champagne... all fantastic.  The empanadas sampler was great.  And don't be afraid to try the octopus- The antichuchos de pulpo are delicioso!
author: Kelly D.

description: My new favorite San Francisco restaurant.  Wonderful ambiance right on the Embarcadero and not far from the Ferry.  Loved the Pisco Sour, the ceviche, and everything else really.  And while expensive, not out of the park.  Lots of fun.
author: Fran M.

description: Honestly the best food I have had in a long time.    The staff was incredibly helpful on everything we ordered.  The Cevieche is to Dies for.   Go Go Go!
author: Jasara L.

description:
the cebiche was out of this world, and fortunately several of the options did not have cilantro (which i am not a fan of).  the cebiche clasico was delicious with huge chunks of halibut and tangy tigre de leche.  

i ordered the grilled cow's heart too upon recommendation.  i was a little nervous it would taste too "organ'y" but it was cooked to perfection and tasted almost like fillet mignon.  

unfortunately, the grilled octopus was not very good. it was over cooked and served on mashed potatoes that were mealy and a bit cold.  but the rest of the meal way overcompensated for it.

the pisco sours were fantastic. great ambiance and attentive service.

i absolutely recommend and will definitely go back.
author: mike j.

description: I love the pisco sour! Really excellent variety of ceviches to try. Empanadas, too. Great view of the bay on the back patio.  I love their  food presentation -- really creative mixture of colors and shapes.  Photo worthy food!
author: Avid E.

description: Awful, awful, service, bad experience, don't really know how they can call their happy hour "happy" not even to say that the place was packed, only a few tables, none of the employees had a smile, no music, not welcoming at all, our waiter was the worst!! This man was extremely rude.  One of my friends had a dry throat with an unstoppable cough, I ask for a glass of water which he brought 15 mnts later, and didn't even apologize for his delay, instead when I reach out for a glass from his tray he had the nerve to tell me not to touch the glasses!! Which just made it more uncomfortable, this place had a tired, angry, staff.  In regards to the food, the empanada was ok, Peruvian empanadas are baked, not fried, the pork sandwich was half fat half meat,  the Pisco was not good, more like lemonade.  Last time I was here I had a similar bad experience and thought I would give it another try, it seems that this place is due for new management, staff and menu.
author: Danny V.

description:
ambiance: excellent. very trendy, hopping bar scene . . . and if i weren't so happily married, it would definitely be on my list of places to grab a drink. the pisco was excellent. brought me back to some great south america trips.

appetizers: cebiche/ceviche taster was the highlight. great flavors, creative presentation, not your everyday ceviche. highly recommended. 

main courses: very very disappointing. my beef tenderloin was good, but seemed like a fairly ordinary stir fry made more ordinary by the pedestrian french fries on top. my wife had one of the white fish (can't remember which one . . . sorry) that was recommended by the waiter and once again, it was fine, but not nearly to the level of the appetizers or the decor. i did enjoy the crusted tuna that one of my friends had, but even that was not truly exceptional.

overall, the main courses left me wanting. it's worth a try, but i can't give it high kudos.
author: Christopher W.

description:
The worst customer service at a San Francisco restaurant in a long time. The manager on duty at Saturday 17th lunch was just horrible. 
The food is just okay for all the attitude. Very disappointing.
author: Tessa S.

description:
Great place. Beautiful interior design with the blue colors. Great ceviche. Had the halibut and ahi ceviches. Really nice wait staff.

Here's the problems:

*On the bill it gives recommended tip. Telling you what 15%,18%, and 20% is, so you don't have to do the math. But they include tax and SF health care. But the math for the tip should not include tax and SF health care.

* In the bar, ordered two pisco sours. (As an aside, it's a great drink, but you should know it's a double shot. I thought it was a single shot.) It was $22.45 and the bartender shorted me 55 cents, to make make the change just bills. Bartenders should never do that.

*Had "Jalea?" which was deep fried sea food in batter, and didn't feel so hot afterwards. I wasn't food poisoned, but didn't feel so hot.
author: Tom K.

description: So have been here twice and the food is spectacular - BUT the service, I'm sorry to say, is pitiful.  they take reservations as if they're Nobu in NYC and then they make you wait 30 - 45 minutes.  Happened twice and I just don't get it.  Plus we were there for one of my friend's birthday parties - so you'd think they'd seat us right away.  I'm just more into restaurants if the service is good.  But again - it's worth a try b/c the food is yum and cocktail menu is desant as well.
author: Puneeta S.

description: Went here with my girl friends two weekends ago....I wasnt that hungry so I decided to try their Ceviche Mixto and it was good, and fresh.  My friend tried the Ceviche Chipotle and it wasnt as tasty as the mixto.  The Tumi mix drink was preety good and the mix punch was way too sour for my taste. Judging by the price, ambiance, food, and location - I had to just give it an OK rating. Seriously, my brother in law's ceviche tasted just as good as the ones made here.
author: Jaylyn S.

description: we ordered a dish from the specials menu which was promised to contain "scallops, shrimp, catch of the day", a bunch of other ingriedients including lima beans. it was $27. i'm a huge scallop fan and did not see any when the dish arrived. we asked the waiter and he said something to the effect that there should have been ONE scallop (mind you the specials board said scallops in plural) and then he checked with the kitchen and informed us that they ran out of scallops and would be buying us dessert. we later realized there were also no lima beans in the dish either...the waiter was super nice and it was nice that they offered a dessert, but really? the kitchen should have told the waiter that they omitted the scallops prior to the dish getting to us in the first place. even if it had 1 scallop and lima beans, i dont think it would have been worth the $27....FAIL.
author: Yevi A.

description: Love, love, love La Mar!!! Every dish I've tried here is simply yummalicious. With a side of EXTREMELY good cocktail concoctions! They have a decent selection of wines as well. If it's nice outside, there is an amazing terrace that you can sit outside by the waterfront. Ahhh (big sigh) I think I'm in love...
author: Andrea Y.

description: Brings back memories of food we had in our recent trip to Lima.  The pisco cocktail was yummy (less strong than the ones in Lima but very good and can be dangerous if you have one after another), the mahi mahi cebiche oriental special was fresh and tasty (has a SF twist to it with the Asian flavors), the causa limena was good (but better in Lima).  I'd go back again to try a few other plates.
author: Irene C.

description: Great location but very expensive for what you get.  I am a Peruvian who truly likes traditional Peruvian food.  This place puts a nice spin on the traditional dishes, sauces, but I still believe that you pay too much for what you get..   I would have loved the original Cebiche so much more if it had been truly marinated long enough in the lime juice.  The real Cebiche is not sashimi.  It is never raw.  In this case, I think it is catering to the sashimi loving public.   How about offering the Cebiche both ways.  That way, you will satisfy both customers.  I spent $125.00 for two people. 3 appetizers, 1 entree and 2 drinks.  Tasty, but very small portions.  If you want to try real traditinal Peruvian dishes, go to Redwood City's Estampas Peruanas, or San Mateo's Machu Pichu.  You will definitely be satisfied.
author: Maggie B.

description:
This was one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  Tonight I had a reservation, but was running a few minutes late due to the rain and traffic.  I called ahead and the hostess let me know that they would hold the table for me for 20 minutes.  I arrived 17 minutes after my reservation time and they told me that they had given away my table.  The abrubt hostess told me that the other hostess had accidently told me the wrong thing, but that they had a "great" spot for us at the ceviche bar.  It was disappointing that an "agent" of the restaurant made a claim and then took it back upon arrival.  

For our inconvenience, they gave us free Pisco Sours, but I would have preferred that they would have just made good on their word.  

Lastly, the Lomo Saltado apprears to be shrinking and price increasing.  We had Arroz Con Mariscos (rice w/seafood) type dish along with it that was cheaper and 3x the amount of food.  I think they're taking advantage of the volume and popularity of the Lomo Saltado to take an unreasonable margin on the dish over other dishes that provide more value.  

Overall, I still like the restaurant, but after this past experience, I don't hold it in the same top tier regard as I have in the past...
author: Mr. S.

description: Some of the flashiest and highest-end Peruvian food I've had and I've had a lot.  The new champion of SF Peruvian food for sure and likely the best in the Bay Area.  Excellent flavors and presentation, gorgeous location decorations and bar scene.  Excellent sit down and take out.  Highly recommended.
author: Pablo G.

description:
The location is potentially excellent, though little has been done
to make the interior appealing. You're aware that you're
dining in a shipping pier.  Food, especially ceviche, is very good.  But
the noise!  We (four people) literally had to shout to hear one another.
Never again!
author: Morton D. P.

description: Who knew?!  My previous experience with Peruvian food was largely limited to ceviche and roasted chicken.  Lunch at La Mar was a real eye opener to a much greater scope of Peruvian cuisine.  Clearly based in traditional Peruvian cooking but with a modern and adventurous flare, the menu at La Mar can be a bit overwhelming at first.  Even the menu categories, let alone the choices within them, are likely to be a bit unfamiliar to the average patron.  But the exploration is absolutely worthwhile.  What struck me most about the food was the absolute freshness and flavorfulness of the ingredients.  The natural flavors of the various fishes, vegetables, fruits, oils and acids used are coaxed out into the dishes rather than slamming you in the face.  The atmosphere is pleasant.  The service is professional and competent.  I can't wait to go back again. for dinner.
author: Charlie Z.

description: Fantastic fresh food, top notch service and interesting cocktails. I have brought friends, family and business associates here on numerous occassions (lunch, dinner & cocktails) and everyone raves.  I can safely say I recommend to anyone the loves food presented in a beautiful restaurant or on the deck!!
author: Cathy C.

description:
I'm going to bump up my rating two stars for the effort that their GM, Kike has made due to my review (and my hubs) from this past Saturday.  S/he politely emailed me and apologized profusely for our experience last Saturday, and assured me that it won't happen again.  Mind you that my update is purely for the prompt attention that s/he took in regards to our experience, and the additional stars are for her/him only.

At this point, we are still a little put off by the treatment that we received from that horrid hostess, however in due time I am sure that I will cool off enough to perhaps actually give them a try.  

Thank you Kike for your prompt attention and making the amazing effort to correct a wrong.  Like I said to you in my email, I wish you all the best of luck :)
author: Shyer L.

description:
I was just in Peru about 2 months ago and ate at the La Mar in Larco mar, Lima.  I have to say, the ceviche at the one here in SF is better!  

The ceviche nikei and ... Chifa were delicious.   Service was great and the cocktails were awesome.  They only seem to serve drinks using traditional peruvian alcohols as its base.  (ie. pisco)  The Chicha tu ma (I think that's what it was called) was a drink based on the traditional Chicha tu madra in peru.  Must try!  

The space was really swanky, the waiting area, near the dining bar area where they displayed the fish looked like it had a lot of potential.  There was a lot of seats for the waiting area.  

Should be open either last week of sept. or first week of oct.
author: Kevin K.

description:
It is a pricey spot, but it is a GOOD spot! It has been a while since I've had good ceviche and since my other favorite Peruvian spot (see earlier review) changed for the worse after some good reviews, I have been on the hunt. I had the Cebiche Mixto: excellent flavors and great texture for the fish. Alongside, I had the best pisco sour I have ever had. 

I am anxious to return to try more dishes, but it will be a while and i'll tell you why. While the cebiches seem adequately priced for the product/quality/quantity, it seems the platos de fondo are overly priced... particulary for the meat dishes such as the quintessential Peruvian dish Lomo Soltado. It has no business being almost $30 unless it is big enough for two and I'm sure it is not. 

People who have read my previous reviews know that I respect only restaurants who can fairly price their menus based on quality and quantity. I would take slightly less swanky decorations for honest food. Like I said, the cebiches are well worth it, but La Mar has priced out some would-be regulars. One day, perhaps I'll be back to try a plato de fondo.
author: Maria Y.

description: Excellent ceviche, cold beers and wonderful empanadas. Definitely worth a second visit the next time I am in San Francisco.
author: daniel w.

description: Beautiful place we sat at the bar and had a great view of the city lights.  Our waitress was wonderful, really sweet and very efficient, if i remember correctly her name was Erin.  As far as the food is concerned i was disappointed, we ordered the Causas the potato totally overpowered the filling and you could not tell one from the other.  The Solterito De Quinoa was very bland, the four tartar's were OK.  Their signature drink the Pisco sour was very sour and i thought it left a unpleasant taste in my mouth.  I would maybe go back to La Mar for drinks and maybe a snack.
author: G C.

description:
I have a lot of experience with Peruvian food having been to Peru many times and having a Peruvian wife who is a big fan of La Mar in Lima.... we were there for lunch a few weeks after opening. The chips with the three sauces that they bring to your table were great. We followed that with the traditional ceviche. Also very nice: very fresh halibut and an unusual but delicious leche de tigre. The portion was so small that we asked ourselves if we had ordered the half portion by mistake instead of the full portion. We followed that with the tamale and  the jalea (octopus and tuna). The tamale was excellent (but agan - very small portion). The jalea was really nothing special... the breading was falling apart and the tuna was a little fishy.

Desert was ok and we had chicha morada to drink (a little too watery and too spicy).

Overall a decent but expensive lunch. We may have enjoyed it more if we had made better menu selections. I guess we'll have to go back and see!
author: Pablo P.

description:
the happy hour is so fabulous.  it so makes me happy.

the fresh frothy pisco sours make me happy and so do the delicioso ceviches.

happy happy happy.
author: Christine R.

description: If you're looking for some yummy peruvian food, this is the place to go!  They start you out with a basket of chips (yucca, plaintain, potato) and 3 delicious dipping sauces.  It's a little pricey, but it's well worth it.
author: Dana D.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place since it opened.  Once the sun is shining, I have a real problem eating anything but ceviche, tuna tartare or sushi.  I ate at one of Gaston's restaurants (Lima) a couple of years ago and loved it.  So I assumed La Mar would be gastronomically correct and on the higher end price-wise.  Surprise, I was right.  
You have to really know Peruvian food to understand what's going on here.  If you do, then you know that the preparation at La Mar is superb.  The food was phenomenal.  And expensive.  Normally such an over the top cost turns me off with what could be considered "simpler" food, but the plates here are prepared to perfection.  I thought about each thing I ate and looked at the check and thought..."was it worth it"?  Two for Lunch, no alcohol, two 1/2 ceviches, two entrees, shared dessert = $92 not including tip.  Yea, that's STEEP.  I hover between 3 $$$ and 4 $$$$ for this place.  Had we ordered drinks it would have been in the 4-$$$$ range for sure.  I almost choked when I saw the $27 lomo saltado on the menu.  Really?  As in for real?  I mean it's lomo saltado for God's sake.  Let's put it this way, it's the most typical (read "basic", "common" or "country") dish of Peru.  It would be like paying $27 for fried chicken or spaghetti at LUNCH.  But, that dang lomo saltado was the BEST lomo saltado I have ever had, and it might have been the best beef dish I have ever had.  Tastiest, tenderest beef ever.  Wow.  Well done.  And the ceviches are superb, as well as all the chifa-inspired dishes.  So the answer to the question "was it worth it" as I eyed the bill, is Yes.
Oh yeah, add in friendly wait-staff, a wonderful location, and a super patio.  Convenient street or lot parking along embarcadero.  This is one of those "you get what you pay for"s.  Save your pennies and go.
author: Isa L.

description: very good cebiche.   excellent service.  nice wine list.
author: Ron D.

description: Good food, ambiance and decor; but prices were a bit high for what you get.   Go there for lunch, you probably get more for your $$$.
author: P J.

description: We were seated right away even though we did not have reservations for dinner. Good ambiance. The ceviche was amazing!
author: Marlene L.

description:
What we ordered:

(1) Pisco Sours
(2) Cebiche Chifa -- The only ceviche without tons of red onions (therefore my favorite one).
(3) Cebiche Mixto
(4) Causa Tasting -- Interesting color of potatoes, thought it looked like Play-Doh, but tasted much better than Play-Doh.
(5) Empanadas del Mar
(6) Empanadas de Choclo -- Not a big fan of the cheesy/nacho-flavored dipping sauce, so I just ate the empanadas by themselves.

I would definitely recommend the Cebiche Chifa and the Empanadas de Choclo.

Service was average, the waiter even told us that he was swamped so it took a while to get drinks. Also, the hostess was cold or aloof and did not even greet us when we walked in. Even though she saw us walk in, I had to go up to her, get her attention, and ask if we could be seated. 

Also, it is not the fault of the restaurant, but there should be a rule against loud, obnoxious children. They definitely did not add to the relaxing ambiance out on the patio.

Other than that, the food was different in a good way and was light and refreshing for a Sunday lunch.
author: Jon H.

description: oh fish so fresh! boss took us here for a lunch one rainy afternoon.. and it was pretty great. the cebiche (ceviche) were all delightful as well as the tiradito clásico, definitely get the empanadas, too. the sauteed beef dish was drool worthy. service was eh. and it was loud. and it was a little pricey. But besides that, the food is worth the trip.
author: Abigail W.

description: The La Mar outfit's first installment outside of Central and South America located inside Pier 1...even before NY. I was a little nervous about the location in a heavy populated tourist area, but once we walked inside my fears subsided. This place is huge, with most likely some of the best views during the day. Peruvian food all dressed up and updated. We went to try this restaurant based on a recommendation from someone in our party. There is a full bar up in front, a raw bar just past the entrance and then the formal dining room. We chose to sit in the formal dining room and have dinner. We started the dinner off with an aperitif....a round of pisco sours which is a light drink made with egg whites. I can't remember the last time I had a pisco sour, but this one was served just right. I ordered a bottle of malbec from Mendoza for our meal. We just came from a long day of enjoying the abnormal warm weather for the city on Pier 23. Since there were 4 of us, we decided to go with the tasting of ceviches, and the tasting of empanadas. The ceviche tasting included 4 styles: Claisico, Mixto, Chalaco, and Nikei. Both appies were pleasing and the dipping sauces were a mix of savory and spicy. The tasting of empanadas included 1 of each: Lomo Saltado, Camarones, Chicken, and corn filled. I am a big fan of empanadas, historically always grabbing some in the Lower East Side. Our appies were accompanied by plantain chips and a trio of dipping sauces. For our main courses we ordered the Lomo Saltado, the Bass Nikei, Arroz Limeno, and the Pescado skewers. The real winner here was the Lomo Saltado, the beef was cooked to a perfect medium rare and melted in your mouth like butter. The Sea bass was a close second and a much lighter dish, but I think the traditional Lomo Saltado outshined the rest. Our server was informative and attentive and the food was excellent, albeit a little pricey for traditional peruvian food but you can't really beat the quality of the food. We ended the night with a dessert wine and went home satisfied. I will definitely make a repeat visit. Limon now has serious competition.
author: Anthony V.

description:
I normally HATE raw fish. However, I had the ceviche sampler and am totally a convert. The ceviche melted on my tongue with these delicious flavors all happening in my mouth. I also had the empanada sampler and they were delish too! Perfectly flavored. 

Fun and yummy fried chips, I think plantains, potatoes and sweet potatoes. Impeccable service, great location, fun and interesting decor.
author: Leslie H.

description:
yes, the food is good. the ceviche variety is pretty ridiculous, and the fish is the freshest i've had in while. although, i can't say i felt the same about the other dishes we got (the jaleo had so much seafood variety - all deep fried - that it seemed like a whale's dream come true).

the space is okay, yes, yes, it's not your typical sf restaurant, very open and hip. blah blah blah. but! it's crazy loud to the point that our server had to lean in a bit too close for us to hear him, the tables are so close together that it really feels like they're trying to squeeze as much money as possible out of every square foot.

and the most disturbing part of all is the truly terrible service. i can't even begin to describe how ridiculous it was, but let me try:
1. made a reservation, but still waited 20 min at the bar for our table
2. sat down, no menus for another 20, and it could have been longer if i literally didn't chase our server down (actually, i didn't know who our server was, i just asked the first one i saw, and it turned out to be him)
3. finally get menus, wait 20 min more 
4. order, wait some more...

total time before some food (i.e. complimentary chips that they give to everyone comes out): 1.5 hours. YES 1.5 hours, on a damn tuesday!

my prediction for this place: the food is good now because they just opened, so go without expecting much from the service, because in 3 months, it's all going to go down hill.
author: alina p.

description: Our group just had a dinner here to celebrate an award, and had a great time! The restaurant made special accommodations and printed up a menu for our pre-fixe selections. The food was spectacular, the waiters were funny and quick to clean up (there were 11 of us), and our table was ready and waiting for us when we arrived 15 minutes late! :) The drinks kept coming and I would strongly recommend the Pisco Sours! It's like a tangier margarita, and totally creeps up on you. The scallop risotto was to die for, and we had a beef dish with fries on top, that resembled a deconstructed pot-roast. The guys loved it needless to say! I would definitely rec commend this place for another group meeting. The only reason I am taking away one star, is because the picnic-table esque seating was a bit small for our group. You couldn't really eat without rubbing elbows, and 2 wine glasses broke (it wasn't just the alcohol, trust). All in all, if the group was smaller and they got new glassware, it would have been a 5 based on service and food.
author: Brandy B.

description: The bottom line on La Mar is that it isn't customer friendly. I've been here for lunch, dinner and happy hour, and I am always reluctant to go again. Others I have talked with also feel that the restaurant is never welcoming, and the managers don't seem to care if you come back. The food is mostly good, but hit or miss with the service and some selections are way overpriced compared to other restaurants with comparable quality, creativity and great food. I would recommend trying happy hour here rather than dinner. The appetizers are very good. One caveat - you have to get there early or you won't get a seat at the bar. If La Mar doesn't need it's customers and it can afford to be arrogant, then it is succeeding.
author: k w.

description:
Love the space and decor but more importantly-I loved the food.  Honestly wonderful-from the complimentary peruvian chips (a combination of sweet potatoes, regular potatoes and plantains) and the three dipping sauces....it was delicous.

The crowd is a bit upscale-but the waitstaff does not act snobby at all-which is important in these places.  

I am not from SFO and it was on my list as the only restaurant I wanted to try because it is the only one in the USA-and I am so happy I tried it.  I loved my meal-the ceviche was AMAZING.

Wonderful job-would go back in a minute...and honestly, no as expensive as I would have thought.  But to me, if the meal is good-I have no issues paying a bit more $$$!
author: Maggie O.

description:
Top notch -- especially considering the restaurant is brand new.  Does not seem to be experiencing the initial bumps that most restaurants do.  The ceviches were amazing -- we tried a sampler platter, and I could have eaten an entire meal of their ceviche.  Delicious empenadas.  All 4 of us were very happy with our main courses.  The portions are rather small, though it didn't bother me.  I'd rather have a small portion of something delectable than a large portion of less tasty food.  The menu is very long, and a lot of the dishes sounded appealing.  The room is large and has a good buzz.  I wouldn't mind if they dimmed the lights a bit more -- it seemed just a bit too bright.  Restaurant is right on the water near the Ferry Building.  Service was flawless -- everyone from the waiter, to the somelier to the bus boys were great.  Our waiter was a doll -- gave us lots of background on the restaurant, the owner, etc.  

I would go back to this place in a heartbeat.


****UPDATE. TAKING ONE STAR AWAY TO MAKE IT 4 STARS. I DID GO BACK TO THIS RESTAURANT FOR A HOLIDAY DINNER WITH 10 LADIES.  WE WERE ALL DRESSED UP AND LOOKING FOR A FESTIVE MEAL, AND INSTEAD WERE PUT AT A LONG TABLE IN THE BACK CORNER OF THE RESTAURANT WITH AIR CONDITIONING BLOWING STRAIGHT DOWN ON US.  UGH!  THE ONLY REASON I'M TAKING ONLY ONE STAR AWAY AND NOT MORE IS THAT THE HOST ATTEMPTED TO BE ACCOMMODATING AND ACTUALLY GOT GUYS UP ON A LADDER TO MOVE THE VENTS SO THEY WERE NOT BLOWING COLD AIR DIRECTLY ON US.
author: Pomelo S.

description: I love this place, been a couple times. The food is outstanding, I recommend the cebiche tasting, causa limeña, anticuchos de pulpo, and you can't go wrong with any of the empanadas or entrees.  The buñuelos de chocolate are an absolute must.  The wine list is not extensive but pairs well with the food and the service is outstanding.
author: Kevin R.

description:
We visited La Mar on a Saturday night, the place was packed, but with reservations we got seated promptly in the patio.  Thank goodness it was an unusually warm SF night since we were way outside of the heated area, right next to the outdoor lounge seating and the water.  I'm not sure if they usually have these tables here, but I can imagine it being a problem since it's not covered or heated and can be annoying with the lounge people right next to you getting drunk and yelling.  Anyhow, this place is beautiful, walking to the patio we got to see all the different seating area, the kitchen, and prep counters....and they did a  great job with the building.

After sitting down it was a good few minutes before our waitress introduced herself, she then asked what kind of water we would like and told us that chips would be arriving soon.  Fifteen minutes later no water or chips came and we had to ask for them, which was answered with a generic "it's coming" response.  Finally, after 20 minutes we had water, 5+ more minutes and chips came out accompanied with three sauces.  Note that this is more than 30 minutes after we first sat down!!!  

Thankfully the food didn't take quite as long (but water refills were few and far in between.)  We ordered the Cebiche Tasting which had the Mixto, Chifa, Nikei and Clásico Cebiches.  The Chifa was interesting because it tasted like a generic Chinese Chicken Salad, but with fish, even had the stereotypical crispy wonton strips.  Overall these were pretty good and a generous portion.  Next up was the Causa Tasting with Limeña, Criolla, Nikei, Casera varieties.  I thought the Causa Casera (vegetarian) was actually the best of these, the causa limeña (crab) was a huge fishy tasting disappointment.  We also ordered the Tiradito Nikei, aji tuna in a sweet sauce that tastes like teriyaki, not in a good way, but at least the aji was good.  For something hot we ordered the Empanadas Tasting (yeah yeah, we couldn't decide on anything so went with the all encompassing samplers when it was available).  I like most of these empanadas, with the exception of the one that was filled with what tasted like creamed corn.  

To finish the meal we had the rollitos de arroz con leche dessert.  That's rice pudding stuffed into a fried egg roll and served with the sourest ice cream ever.  (Is passion fruit ice cream a Peruvian thing??)  Delicious without the ice cream, a wake up call if with.  

Through the night I realized that the entire patio had about four wait staff, but only one busboy and two runners.  I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and assume a busboy called in sick on the night that we went in, because there is no other way so many people could have liked this place with the level of service we received at La Mar.  Even with better service there are much better Peruvian food choices in the City at Fresca and Limon.  The only thing I can see La Mar has going for it is it's lounge atmosphere and beautiful waterfront view.  It's too bad because we really wanted to like this restaurant.
author: Edgar C.

description: Good food-check. Nice view of the bay on a clear day-check. Cool enthusiastic servers-check. I skipped cocktails that day but the bartender was kind and let me sample a few whites until I chose the one for me-and I got two of the one for me. It was the Sauvignon Blanco. The yucca chips and dips were a fun treat to snack on pre-entree. I got the sampler chicken and rice/ceviche/yucca fries. Pretty filling even though it looked small.
author: MT U.

description:
From someone who is Peruvian it makes me proud to have this restaurant in San Francisco. Ceviche is a Peruvian addition to the culinary world and a part of the cuisine often overlooked. 

great service, excellent pisco sours (the only ones in SF), and the best lomo saltado i have ever eaten (peru or the states).  this place is becoming very popular so get to it before you are locked out by the long wait
author: fred b.

description: After our trip to Peru we fell in love with peruvian food, so we went  to try La Mar for lunch with "dine about town".  Frankly speaking the food, the service the atmosphere had nothing to do with our food experience in Peru.  Food: run from mediocre to bad.  Ceviche was edible, but worse than the inexpensive Soy Cholo:  a miserable two small pieces of fish served with what seemed to be mashed potatoes shaped into a nice small smokestack.  The clams were the size of a pea (where did they find them that small?) swimming in a salty broth(that was the only spice in that broth).  Sorbet was OK, but our grocery store has better.  The atmosphere:  cafeteria, but nicely located near water.  Service:  waitress grabbed a glass of beer while passing by without asking if it was finished (it was not).  Dropped the bill also passing by. The bill for 2 dine about town lunches and 1 beer was $55.  Do yourself a favor, and spend that kind of money on a lunch elsewhere.  The chef (s) would benefit from some training in Peru.
author: Julia A.

description: This is my favorite peruvian restaurant in the city.  The Causa platter is delicious and the pisco sours are very good as well.  I love the combination platters where you can get a little of everything.  The decor gives the place a nice ambiance.  I recommend this place to everyone.  I really like the ceviche's and trying the tiger's milk.  It is better than Limon in it's selection of foods.
author: C L.

description: Had lunch while on vacation based on a friend's recommendation - was not disappointed!  Had the cebiche sampler, entrees and amazing drinks.  Loved the space - very open.  Our waiter was adorable and very knowledgeable about the menu too - hoorah for good service!
author: katie c.

description: I wanted to eat Peruvian food since I heard it was a great mix of Asian and Latin culture. I was recommended this place but I didn't really like that it was in a touristy part of SF so I knew that the prices would be pretty high. The location itself is easy to find and the views are great. Catch a table outside to see the bay. I had lunch there with friends and we ordered Cebiche clásico which has California Halibut in a classic leche de tigre, red onion, habanero, Peruvian corn and yam. For lunch I ordered pan con lomo sandwich which has Peruvian style roast beef, tomato, sautéed bell peppers & onions, crispy potatoes with lomo saltado aioli on an ACME roll with a side salad. Oh wow the food was awesome. I was amazed at the kernel of Peruvian corn. It was as big as my thumbnail! My sandwich also was so delicious. I had already eaten a big breakfast earlier and was full but I scarfed down the Pan con lomo like it was my last meal on earth. So good. The place is clean, spacious with great views. The food is great!
author: Chester M.

description:
Was aaiight. We were there for their 1-year anniversary, so they had a fixed 5 course dinner. The first two (ceviche and scallops au gratin) were fantastic, but then it kinda went downhill from there. Had a traditional peruvian soup that neither of us liked that much. A meat dish with lamb, chicken and pork... honestly, couldn't really tell the meats apart... not that great. And then sorbet popsicles for dessert. Mehhh.

Reviews have called this place romantic. I didn't think so at all. Definitely a nice restaurant, but it's big and fairly lively, not romantic. 

Service was great. Overall, it was decent and I'd definitely give it another shot, but certainly wasn't blown away.
author: Nithin R.

description: Really interesting & delicious food not to mention a great location. in my favorite city. Their bar is a great place to wait while  your table comes up...even the cocktail menu was delicious.  would recommend it, especially if you're looking for something different.
author: Deidre C.

description:
I have found my new favorite restaurant! Great Flavors, Great Selection, Amazing Service, Yummy Drinks and a Beautiful Design.

   Let me start out by saying I have never been compelled to stay in a restaurant for the sheer purpose of soaking up the atmosphere. Lar Mar rocks this aspect. From the moment I walked in I was taken by the colors of the restaurant. High ceilings, Deep brown furniture with bright turquoise fabrics, and a view of the bay. Even though it was raining I felt as if I had left SF. Truly an experience.
  As soon as my Coworker and I entered the restaurant, we saw a plate of causas pass by. We were so obviously stricken by the site of them that the server stopped to tell us what he had on the plate. We immediately decided that we had to order that whether or not our client wanted them LOL. The causas are mashed potato pillows made with vibrant purple and yellow potatoes and topped with either crab and avocado, mahi mahi, tuna, or asparagus and artichoke. As they pass through the restaurant they are like purple beacons of happiness calling out to be ordered. Really it's as much art as it is food. Awesome.
  I could honestly go on and on but everything was full of flavor and on par. I will say that I got the seafood soup for my entree which featured a poached egg. At first I was apprehensive about a yoke running amok in my soup, but they masterfully cook the egg to the right consistency so that when you break the yoke it doesn't bleed throughout your soup! They definitely scored on the technical side with that one. 
  In short if you enjoy seafood and Latin flavors, you must visit La Mar. I know I'm going back ever chance I get!
author: chelsea b.

description:
Poor Front of House Customer Service! 

Despite the fact that La Mar is huge, this is not the place to take a large party. Several friends wanted to get together and try La Mar as we had all been to Astrid & Gaston in Lima and had a wonderful meal. I called 2 weeks in advance and asked for a party of 9 on a Thursday night. I was told someone would get back to me. 5 days later a woman called to say they could do the party of 9 but we had to do a set menu. She told me no exceptions and was very impatient with me. So instead of making us feel like we were special, they made us feel irritated. Since we did not want a set menu, one person agreed not to come. When I called back to make the reservation for 8 people, the next woman I spoke to was as terse as the first. Just not very customer friendly. 

So we arrive *early* for out table for 8 at 8:30. At 8:29 I reconfirm with the hostess that we are all here and ready to be seated. She tells us to keep waiting in the bar. No explanation, no further information. Not even a smile. 15 minutes later I check in again, this time a man says he will actually check on the table. He tells me the table has the check and hopefully will leave soon. At 9 pm the hostess comes over *to ask if we are all here*. For the 3rd time we say "yes"!  Finally around 9:15 they seat us. No apologies. 

The rest of the meal was fine. Our actual waiter was nice and got food out quickly. The food was over priced considering you can get something just as nice at Limon or Fresca for less. 

I am not expecting someone to roll out the red carpet, but a little customer service up front would go a long way. No need to be terse on the phone and keep us in the dark about when we will be seated. With so much other good Peruvian food in the city, I see no reason to go back.
author: Andrea B.

description:
La Merde!

What a terrible disappointment this restaurant's food was for us. I had read about the opening of this Peruvian eatery and its founding famous Peruvian chef Gaston Acurio about a year before we finally got here for lunch earlier this month on our semiannual visit to San Francisco.  We are both big ceviche fans and have located the best Los Angeles Peruvian restaurants, including El Pollo Inka (23705
Hawthorne Blvd. Torrance, CA), Mario's Peruvian & Seafood (5786 Melrose Ave., Los Angeles, CA) and right up the street from Mario's in Hollywood, Los Balcones del Peru (1360 Vine St. Hollywood, CA)--all more modest establishments which are affordable and serve up wonderfully fresh Peruvian cuisine, from ceviches to Lomo Saltado and many more authentic dishes.  Plus, at San Francisco's more upscale Fresca (2114 Fillmore St., San Francisco, CA), we have always had consistently mind-blowing ceviches, their fantastic lomo saltado and perfectly grilled rib eye steaks. 

At La Mar, we ordered the ceviche mixto ($16) and--in a moment of reckless abandon--also ordered the ceviche chipotle ($18). While we waited, the busboy delivered a bowl of thick potato and platano chips, and three kinds of dipping sauce, warning us that the red one was spicy. The chips were fine, but not only was the red sauce not spicy, it hardly had any noticeable flavor. Then we tried the green sauce.  At least the green dipping sauce had some flavor of some cilantro and onion which was at best a pale imitation of the green table aji hot sauce--a staple at most of the aforementioned LA Peruvian restaurants we frequent. We tried the yellow sauce which was the most bland and flavorless of all. Our two ceviches arrived shortly thereafter and, sadly, based on visual first impressions, we were already disappointed.  We were anticipating a pile of fresh mixed fish, shrimp, octopus, and calamari with a mound of thinly sliced purple raw onions and a small teaspoon of aji amarillo chili salsa on top to mix in, with the usual large Peruvian corn and a couple chunks of sweet and white potato on the side.  Instead, in both ceviches, the seafood itself--which should be the showcase of any ceviche--was barely visible, submerged in a thick creamy-looking sauce.  The ceviche mixto was obscured in a bright yellow sauce, which presumably had the crucial Peruvian aji pepper in it but again the distinct aji flavor was barely discernable. Plus there was no brightness from citrus as there usually is from the taste of the fresh lime and/or lemon juice the ceviche is marinated in, normally enhanced with the crunchy onions, and a little chopped celery.  The ceviche chipotle had the same creamy appearance as the mixto, except it looked and tasted not unlike like Campbell's tomato soup--before you dilute it with water. 

Even with our own additions of lemon and lime juice, which we had to flag the busboy down for as our server was nowhere to be seen, the ceviche was not salvageable whatsoever. We had ordered one other entrée from the menu, the grilled octopus with the chimichurri sauce, served with mashed potatoes, which we hoped, based on the reviews we'd read, might redeem our dining experience. Alas, it was not to be: the busboy brought us new plates and placed the entrée ($16) in front of us.  On the plate at two-inch intervals were three small brazil-nut shaped and sized rations of mashed potatoes, each with a small piece of grilled octopus draped, packing mule-style, over each potato ration.  While the octopus was cooked properly and tasted good, coming on the wake of the ceviche experience and at a tad more than $5.00 a bite, it was hard to stomach. 

It's sad that with its beautiful mod décor and prime location, this will be what many diners take away as Peruvian cuisine.  It's overpriced and it just isn't good.  San Franciscans:  Head to Fresca on Fillmore!   And if you ever deign to visit LA :) , please check out the above-mentioned restaurants for true, tasty  Peruvian fare.
author: Pamela L.

description: For Christmas, instead of exchanging gifts, my wife and I throw equal amounts of money into a stocking and go out to a nice dinner somewhere in the city.  This year we chose La Mar and it was FANTASTIC!!!  We sat in the bar drinking pisco sours soaking up the cooler-than-thou vibe, then moved on into the dining room for dinner.  Our server(s) were attentive and helpful and super cool (we laughingly joked that we wanted a straw for the left-over ceviche juice and the waiter told us he'd bring us glasses and said thats what they do in Peru - don't know if he was pulling our leg, but it sounded fun).  We dined on ceviches and assorted smaller plates and walked out quite full (be careful how many small plates you order - they will fill you up).  Next time we go, I want to sail up for lunch!!
author: Curtis H.

description: This might be my current favorite restaurant.  From the hot servers and bartender to the open design of this restaurant, you just feel happy when you walk in.  Their Cebiche is to die for, try the platter and get a taste of it all.  I've never been a huge fan of octopus, but they have a bbqed octopus app. that was melt in your mouth delicious.  I've been here a few times now and I've yet to be disappointed.
author: T V.

description: Empanadas were great. Cebiche was a bit bland compared to Limon Rotisserie.  I love the chips that they give.  Ambiance was good as well because it was right next to the water and it was just a very high ceiling space.  I liked it and will be recommending it to friends as well.
author: Paul C.

description: Best Peruvian food I've had in the US - by far! Ceviche is outstanding. Octopus anticuchos are unreal. Causa sampler is yummy. Service is great. Venue is beautiful.
author: Debbie J.

description:
This place has become a staple for me. Whenever someone wants to go out to dinner, whether for work or fun, I'm making reservations here. It's not perfect, but it has the right combination. My main complaint is the chips. They are too good and plentiful. This is not the place to come if you are on a diet.

The pisco sours are SO GOOD. And STRONG. Try to go easy on those things. That pisco liquor is potent but in a good way. It makes you happy.

Sometimes the food isn't totally on point but that is because this place demands high expectations. When they're good they are *really* good.

This is a great place for a big group. The space is massive with different areas that can be roped off. Lots of natural light. Airy. Open. Really pleasant environment.
author: Sheri E.

description: Do NOT go to La Mar for the take out lunch service. I repeat, Do NOT go to La Mar for the take out lunch service. Ordered the lomo saltado steak sandwich and it was all veggies and maybe one piece of steak. Not worth the $8 plus tax. I shouldn't have even tipped them. They must be doing poorly if they started a take out lunch service. Never will I go back here ever again.
author: AE W.

description: As good as the one in Lima without the lunchtime posers.  We had a couple of ceviches, huancaina, mixed cauza, the lomo saltado rolls and a rice dish.  More than enough for 3 for lunch!
author: Nick A.

description:
We went back with a group of 6.  Food was excellent.  Service was very good, drinks were outstanding and desserts to die for!
Everybody in our group was happy and full.
We are going back in two weeks!
Viva el PERU!
author: Margarita M.

description: I've wanted to try this place forever because it was recommended by a few friends...  Overall the food was good, but I'm not going to say it was the best.  I've had better and for cheaper, however I am still giving it four stars because the restaurant itself is so cool!  The location is fabulous, it has an extremely spacious interior with a lively ambiance and the view from both the back window and the back outside dining area are really amazing.  Overall it was a very enjoyable dining experience and I think it would probably be fun for group dinners.  I would recommend this restaurant to friends but I would let them know to be prepared to shell out about $50 per person, give or take depending on drinks.
author: Erin S.

description: My wife and I went here recently for dinner.  It is good to combine having dinner here and also visiting the nearby Ferry Building for pre-dinner snacks and shopping.   The hostess was very professional and accommodated us coming it a little early.  First we visited the bar, since we wanted to try one of their Pisco drinks on their cocktail menu.  I had the pisco punch and my wife had the pisco sour.  They were both delicious.  We were inspired to pick up some pisco at BevMo to make some drinks with it at home.  If you haven't had pisco, this is a restaurant to sample it.  We came to this restaurant primarily for the cebiches - we had the cebiche clasico and cebiche mixto.  Both were excellent.  If you like habanero, then you can add a bit of this too every bite for a spicy experience.  If you don't like it hot, be sure to pick it out.   Dinners come with fried plantain  chips with three sauces (mild, medium and hot).  The plantains are fried up crispy like a potato chip, so not oily or soggy.  One could probably just do 2 cibiches and plantains for a lite dinner, but we had the arroz criollo and the pescado nikei, both were excellent.
author: John H.

description: We had a work lunch here today and although the food was quite good, especially the cebiche tastings, the service left a lot to be desired.  I also felt the prices were a little too high given the portion sizes.  We had a very light pour on our wines, I'm guessing it was only 3oz at best even though the waiter argued with me that it was the standard 4oz (and the gentleman at the table next to us had a noticeably healthier pour in his glass).  The service was very slow and I was almost finished with my entree before they brought the second glass of wine (and I had to ask twice).  I'll give a place with great food a second shot with poor service so hopefully next time it will be better.
author: Ingrid E.

description: Was supposed to receive a call this past Friday (4/9/2010) from the head manager Andrew.  I was told he would be resolving my problem and that he was the only one with authority to do so.  No call.  Yet again an unfulfilled promise that I would be hearing from management.  This is the fourth occasion this has happened.  I'm really pretty speechless.  Can't say enough how frustrating my experience with La Mar has been.
author: Zach K.

description: I love the ambiance. Although I went on a cold evening, it felt like a vacation beach house. It's right on the water and there are green and blue accents. The place feels spacious and very modern. Service was very friendly; our waitress was funny and offered good suggestions. Food was delicious too, however, I'm not a seasoned Peruvian foodie. Most the dishes were new to me and for the most part I like what we ordered. But I did expect more of a punch from the ceviche. I liked the mashed potatoes sampler--it was so pretty and tasty too. My cocktail was delicious, I think it was the Tummi (something with pear juice and pisco).   Chocolate beignets with banana ice cream was okay--too rich and not enough ice cream to wash it down with.
author: Royce L.

description:
It's hard to believe we're in a major financial crisis and recession when it's almost impossible to get a table on a Tuesday night. We were able to get a reservation for 8:30 and showed up promptly but still had to wait about 45 minutes before being seated. We talked the bartender into comping a round of drinks which thankfully turned out to be very creative and tasty libations.

When we were finally seated, the food was delish and presentation impeccable. The ceviche sampler was perfect and as much disdain as I have for cilantro, I overlooked it that night because the fish itself was so outstanding. We did everything family style and I can't remember all the details of what we ordered, but I remember loving every bite.

The space was very hip but it was so loud, it was a bit of a strain to hear each other talk. Our bartender Sarah? was delightful. However, the only nice thing I have to say about our server, Shane, was that he had excellent posture. Seriously, if I stood up that straight, I'd probably be 2 inches taller than I am now. No matter how cute, charming and delightful I was, he couldn't crack a smile all night and was totally aloof. 

I would definitely come back again for the food, but I will probably be more prepared to wait for a table and make sure that I have a different server.
author: Cher E.

description: never had cebiche before...this was a great experience. Service was attentive but not overly.
author: Kathy S.

description: Definitely a fan of the Cebiche variations here.  I highly recommend you try the Cebiche tasting and get a good sense of the latitude of the definition of a Cebiche when fused with other genres of cuisine.  A beautiful space with great ambiance in the Patio and Bar areas.  I'll be coming back again to try more of that menu and will update my review with more info, and perhaps more stars :-)
author: Leroy R.

description:
Flipping Fantastic!

Just got back from a fabulous lunch here and I was so impressed by the place that I had to yelp about it as soon as I got back to work (because clearly, that's more important than any work that I actually have to do).  We came here because my coworker's boy toy man plaything is one of the chef's here.  And am I ever glad that we did.  

As you first walk in, you enter a wide foyer with a bar to your right and a huge open dining area with high ceilings.
