love the space and the fact that the tables aren't squeezed in wherever there's spare square footage... the airy feel to the place is soothing and refreshing.  the pisco bar is located right off the embarcadero entrance, seperate from the main dining room.  if you continue in, you will arrive at the spaceous ceviche bar with a connection to an exhibition kitchen...and even further in is the dining room itself with access to an outside dining area.
we had several ceviches to start off with and lovely seafood main courses... all with authentic peruvian flavors created on a high-end twist... if you've never heard of chef gaston acurio before, i'm sure he will soon be a name that pops up here and there in the u.s. culinary world too... this is his first u.s. restaurant with plans on opening up establishments in los angeles and new york in the very near future.
cocktails were sweet and delicious... had the pisco punch as well as the chupe tu ma.  can't remember the name of the main dishes off-hand but mine was a peruvian style chioppino with prawns and creamy seafood stew filled with cubes of cheese, potatoes, a lightly poached egg and toast... my friends had a pasta and a mussell stew as well as peruvian tamales which were delicious.  the desserts were rich and potent with decadent presentations.  tiramisu, creme brule, and truffells were the ones we sampled...
i'm surprised they had everything so well together for their 'soft opening'... i was impressed that i didn't notice any major glitches throughout our dinner.... 
welcome to san francisco, la mar!  i'm sure you will do really well here
author: charlotte s.

description: Some coworkers had given good reviews so I figured I'd try it out with some out of town friends who had yet to experience the Embarcadero area. The drinks and food were very good, but they host was a pretentious jerk. We did not have reservations and was told it would be an hour wait to sit on the patio (it was empty and a Monday). We said that was fine and told him we would sit in the bar and wait. He reminded us again that it would be an hour, apparently he thought it was not clear the first time. We asked to put our name in and he dismissed us and told us that he would find us with a dismissive tone. After more than an hour catching up with friends in the bar he came over and told us that someone was a no show and he would take us early (Hour and 15 min in). No complaints about the wait, which we expected, but when we got out to the large patio it was almost completely empty. The restaurant was maybe half full as well. Definitely good atmosphere, food and drinks, but have a reservation or you'll be made to wait while the restaurant is completely empty.
author: Sam R.

description: i went back to la mar with a group of friends and was not disappointed.  i still prefer the more authentic style peruvian cooking but still enjoy the fancied up versions too.  for starters, we ordered the cebiche nikei,  anticuchos de corazon and causa limena.  all were wonderfully delicious!  for the main course, we shared the lomo saltado, jalea and i think the arroz jugoso.  the waiter was great, although he wasn't sure which wine to suggest.  it was a busy night when we went and i had to ask for water 3x before one of the waiters/bus boys finally refilled my water.  other than that, everything was really good and i would definitely go back!
author: Vic S.

description: The food is fantastic, and the location is beautiful, so if that's what you're all about, then have at it, and you won't be disappointed.  Incredible ceviche, and a menu that has gotten even better with time.  I've eaten here at least a dozen times, so take my criticisms with a grain of salt, because I obviously keep coming back.  But still--La Mar is ridiculously loud; I took a friend from San Diego there the other day, and we couldn't hear each other talk.  And also, the complaints about service are spot on.  It doesn't matter if the restaurant is empty or packed, you're going to be waiting at every step of the meal, from getting seated and having your order taken, to getting drinks refilled and your check at the end.  The waitstaff is pleasant, and doesn't seem to be doing anything wrong per se, but the place still has some room for organizational improvement.  The prices could also use some improvement--I have no problem paying for quality, but I always find myself surprised at the size of the bill at La Mar.
author: Ty D.

description:
This place is absolutely astonishing!

I went here with my Dad shortly afer their grand opening.  I'm a self proclaimed restaurant snob, so coming from me, this means a lot.  

We were warmly welcomed by more than one hostess.  We were asked whether we would like to be seated immediately (though we were there 20 minutes early) or enjoy the bar for a drink, until our designated reservation time.  I love to experience all aspects of a restaurant, and chose to further explore the bar.  The bar is bright and tropical and seems to cater to single customers upon group wine tastings, as well.
Though it took the bar tender a few minutes to break away from what he was currently doing, he anxiously greeted us to take our drink order.  He kindly suggested a red wine for my dad, as I studied the very unusual Peruvian drink menu.  I like to custom-order drinks, so I asked the bartender for something spicy.  Although a little taken a back (as most people would be about such a request), he quickly brainstormed to make me exactly what I wanted.  
Here's what he concocted: muddled cilantro, lime juice, cachaca (I believe it was this Brazilian alcohol), agave nectar, habanero, and blue corn.  I kid you not, this drink was literally breath taking.  I took a sip and my jaw dropped!  I've never tasted something so charismatic!  It was similar to drinking (pleasantly so) liquid salsa.  It was impeccably created.  Jose, I believe his name was, told me to name it, since it was a spur of the moment creation.  I told I would return back when I'd thought of something clever.

Seated promptly at our reservation time, we walked through the vast space this restaurant encompasses towards the main dining section, overlooking the water.  Beautifully decorated and meticulously designed, there is nothing about this restaurant that wouldn't captures one's attention.
Seated at a nice two-some table near the open kitchen, we were thoroughly explained the menu by our waiter.  We were also tended to quite regularly by not only our waiter, but two very kind bussers.  The gathering of people in this large and spacious main dining area seemed to be business people mixed with couples and those who were in open and upbeat moods.  Everyone appreared to enjoy the gorgeous view and incredibly unique food.  

The food is so well thought out.  It would take far too much time to describe all that we had, but in short, it was perfectly displayed, prepared and tasting.  The fish is extremely fresh, the concept is near sushi-like with a strong Peruvian influence.  The portions are just right, not too small, not too large.  I would highly recommend sharing starters and/or entrees since there is so much to choose from! 

The staff seemed proud to be a part of this establishment and were well informed.

I rave to everyone about my recent experience here, and push for all to embark upon their own outtings .  I am very much anticipating my own return and highly recommend everyone to pop in for a drink, dinner or both.

p.s. I did go back to the bar to name the drink: Cilantro Fuego...if they are not familiar, at least you have a list of the ingredients to experience this utterly fabulous drink yourself!
author: Erika S.

description:
omg. what a gorgeous, fabulous space along the embarcadero! i have been here twice and it has quickly made its way into my  top 10 places to sip and dine in the city.. ! 
amazing architecture that is classy, trendy and sexy without being cheesy.  
amazing food!  the cebiche mixto (halibut)  was so fresh and delish...  the ahi tuna - v fresh and had an interesting flavour profile that was unique....finally! i have had ahi tuna 5000 ways from sunday and it was refreshing to have it done with a diff twist!  have also had an amazing stuffed chicken dish called Una ...  a must try!  it is in the to share section and it is divine..  what else.. oh the portobello quinnoto.  super delish! that is in the vegetarian section and it is another must try. very hearty and filling and tasty.  
for dessert, we had the sorbet trio and it was the perfect ending to the evening.... home made and so smooth and delectable on the tongue.  left me wanting more! 
and last but not least...the muy importante part!  the pisco cocktails.  sooo super yummy. i cant stop drinking them...!  my fave is the Chicha Tu Ma..  passion fruit deliciousness! but they do sneak up on you, so watch out! 
on a side bar, la mar is a bit on the pricey side, but so worth it!  be prepared to bust out your black amex or your corporate card!
author: Caroline S.

description:
A long-time friend of my wife's took us out to dinner on Tuesday 12th May 2009. We had reservations and so were seated by 6.40PM. After a few minutes we were brought water and fried potato/sweet potato/plantain slices to nibble on with three excellent sauce dips. We ordered cocktails: pisco sour and pisco punch and these were 'tasteee' (I'm a beer drinker so this was a sort of step into the dark trying 'hard' liquor so to speak). My wife ordered the non-alcoholic chiche morada. Her first glass was slightly disappointing but her refill (maybe, or simply a repeat order - we weren't paying so I didn't see the bill) was much better. My American wife is of Peruvian descent and so this was going to be a true test of everything everybody's raved about this 'new' restaurant. The three of us chose two cerbiches (they spell 'cerviche' 'cerbiche' at La Mar - I don't know why?) and one grilled mahi mahi skewer starter. The mahi mahi was cooked perfectly - melt in your mouth quality. Top marks to the grilling skills there. The cerbiche dishes were the 'mixto' from the menu (which obviously contained  various fish and a pleasantly seasoned citrus 'cooking' juice) and the other choice was one of the three daily specials: a mix of sliced octupus, fresh sea urchin (which I'd never eaten before and was divine in texture and very pleasing to the palette), scallops, thinly sliced onions, a dash of sliced habanero (which could be left to the side depending on one's tolerance for heat in cerbiche) and maybe a few extra ingredients which escape my memory at the moment, along with a yellow citrus 'cooking' juice. A wonderful start I have to honestly say.

The three entrees we chose were: leg of duck with 'green' rice (best description there is as it's identical to the excellent creation my mother-in-law cooks and I've yet to master myself), a seafood mixture with the same rice, and the lomo soltado (which every Peruvian restaurant on earth will have by the way). The duck was cooked to perfection. Quite unbelievably perfect I have to say. I have never sampled duck served in a restaurant that was so perfectly prepared. I'm still amazed with its quality two days later. The seafood dish was very generous and all the seafood items were once again individually cooked extremely well. Delicious. And a large serving as well. Surprised there a bit. For instance, entrees at First Crush on Cyril Magnon are tiny in comparison - the quality of cooking is excellent there though. Can't knock that place on those grounds. Finally the 'lomo' as it's casually known  [yes, there is pollo (chicken) soltado, and fish soltado, but, as it's known as the national dish of Peru, lomo (beef strips, made with at least sirloin cut quality) soltado is commonly abbreviated as just 'lomo']. La Mar uses a tenderloin cut served with a decent quantity of 'seasoning gravy' to accompany the excellent French fries and 'eighthed' sliced tomatoes, with cilantro garnishing and plain white rice. Extremely well made and a meritorious display of culinary expertise by the kitchen. Now, raving at what my brother-in-law says are simply 'standard' dishes may sound odd to him, but as a decent home cook myself I was honestly impressed with every dish. I wish I could create these dishes as well at home. Good seasoning balance and perfect texture to the cooked meat and fish. We were full and didn't sample a dessert so if I ever return I'll skip the starter maybe and sample one of the wonderful creations the praised pastry/desert chef makes. 

Other reviews have savaged the place on its service. We enjoyed pretty decent friendly service. It is a busy place probably every day of the week. If you are considering going I'd assume a reservation is a no-brainer, and it's possibly a place where if it does get really busy then some slight delays could occur. We didn't suffer any problems in that regard. My brother-in-law would never give anywhere 5 stars, but as I don't consider him much of a cook at all his opinion is unrealistic to me. To me this is a 5-star place. Yes he's Peruvian, but I consider my judge of properly cooked (to restaurant standard level) meat and fish to be more objective. 

This is a superb friendly restaurant and one SF should be rightly proud of. 

Finally, you're going here because it has earned a fine rating through its reviews. Yes, it comes with 3 '$"s as a price rating (definitelyy 4 if the excellent cocktails are sampled, the most expensive menu items are chosen along with dessert as well), and there's imported beer alternatives as well, but they're standard fare really. If you're bothered about the price then don't come. Eat at three ordinary places instead. Or, save up and have a real treat. The food is certainly kid-friendly if any 'hot' garnishes are ignored, and the generous entrees mean you'd have a great 'doggy-bag' to go home with!

I don't think I give many 5 star ratings out  (Colibri, Helmand Palace) so this place has something let me tell you.
author: Ian W.

description: We came here for my birthday because it was recommended by a friend of mine.  The chips, ceviche, tiraditos and empanadas were excellent.  I also liked the grilled octopus.  I did not like my main course though which was the arroz jugoso - it was too wet.  Now, I wish I tried the steak!  I also didn't like their selection of wines.  We tried several before we settled on an Argentinian chardonnay but I still was not impressed by it.  I wish I stuck it out with the cholopolitan - it was awesome!  Our waiter was very good, very chatty and knowledgeable.  However, the people who brought the food to us were not very friendly.  They dropped the food on our table and did not say anything.  They should do a better job of explaining the different dishes that they are bringing in considering that most people are not very familiar with it.  What we did was we called our waiter and he did a very good job with that.  I would like to come back and try the other dishes though!
author: Sharon C.

description: Great Fish.  Great date place.  Drinks a little small but good vide and nice out on the patio.  The Ceviche was really good...Cold and fresh on a Sunday afternoon.  Can get pricey....
author: Mark C.

description: fantastic soft launch dinner. i'm not a peruvian food expert but it was alright by me (FB connect review experiment)
author: tommy p.

description: great drinks ( pisco sours!), fun ambience, sub-standard food
author: aj s.

description: Stopped by La Mar on a Saturday afternoon to grab a glass of albariño and a  few tastings of cebiche.  Tried the classico with halibut, very refreshing, also tried the uni, scallop and prawn in a creamy sauce, which was also very good.  Decor and food presentation very clean and urban.  I've been waiting for this place to open, seeing how I live less than a mile away.  First impresssions overall-- not good.  Hostess very rude, waitress forgot the wine, bus boy over zealous about cleaning up.  I'm giving La Mar another try tomorrow for dinner, hope it changes my mind.
author: Sandra P.

description:
i'll start with the good:  the food was delicious, and the cocktails were tasty.
now the bad:  our server was so terrible, we thought it was a joke.  it took more than thirty minutes for our cocktails to arrive at the table, and as long to get our server to give us the time of day in order to place our order.  when at our table, the server looked bored and annoyed.  the only saving grace was the busboy, who was so helpful in tracking down our drinks and explaining the menu to us, he ended up with a tip all his own.
because of stories from friends raving about this place, i will probably try la mar again in the hope that this was an isolated experience.
author: Sarah L.

description: Wasn't sure what to expect as we went to this restaurant during the soft launch when they are getting the kinks out.  As it turns out there were no kinks whatsoever.  We walk in to a beautifully designed area.  There is a Pisco bar to your right, straight ahead is the ceviche bar (like a sushi bar) and continuing on is the dining room.  After we were seated the waitress brought us three dipping sauces and very unique chips made of dried potatoes, tomatoes and what had to be bananas.  This was delicious.  We ordered drinks, a Pisco Sour and a Tumi (like a cosmo but with Pisco, prickely pear).  As noted in another review the Pisco will be the new hot drink.  The specialty drink menu is very long, think Pisco twist on normal drinks and you will have a good idea.  We ordered the Cebiche Nikei (ahi tuna with avocado in a ceviche).  It was also amazing.  There is a lot of Asian influenced dishes on the menu.  For the main course we had the lomo saltado (filet mignon strips with onions and french fries) and the halibut.  Again both were delicious.  We ended with a dessert of beignets with warm chocolate centers and a bit of ice cream.  Service was great as was the decor and food.  This is definitely a place to return to once it officially opens on Sep. 29. Book your reservations early!
author: George M.

description: The place is just beautiful!!!!  We had the empanada sampler plate and the causas sampler plate - simply delicious!!!!!!  The ceviche could have been a little more tender - the cubes were sliced a bit too large.  Overall, I would definitely go back again! Would be wonderful to sit outside on the patio overlooking the water!!!  Alphonso, our waiter, was awesome!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jane S.

description: I first heard of this place from a co-worker, who happens to be a big yelper, that this place is supposedly known for it cebiches, so I was totally down for checking it out after work one day. For a Tuesday, the place was pleasantly crowded (always a good sign) so I sat at the front bar to try out some food and have a little drink. The guys at the bar were nothing but super friendly, suggesting choice dishes and making conversation. Though the menu is pretty expansive with their Peruvian specialties, I came for one reason and that being the cebiche. By recommendation of the bartender, I decided to go over the Cebiche Tasting which included four different types of marinated fish. Though the portions were small - four small bowls with about 5 pieces of fish each - the taste was terrific. The fish was melt-in-your mouth fresh and the marinades were not over-powering. My two favorites were the spicy lime marinade and a Thai-inspired one. The only downside, as mentioned before, the portions of the fish are small, so my suggestion is to order something else more hearty or several appetizers from the menu as well. Try the Anticuchos, the grill-roasted octopus on a skewer over mashed potato and Chimichurri sauce - it's tender and delicious!
author: Cynthia G.

description: The food here is amazing!!!   What incredibly fresh, tasty dishes.  I'm hooked.. Already have reservations to take another friend here.  Tried the tasting dish of cebiches.. It had the mixto, nikei, criollo, and clasico. I couldn't decide which I liked best.. They all had such a unique and mouth exciting flavor.  I could dine on those dishes every day.  Also had the ensalda nikei...  it was good, but I must say to cebiches are the best...  The cocktails were great, especially a drink called  something,  tu mama...  Plan on bringing  visitors to this place with much enthusiasm.  Looking forward to a Friday night  here in a few weeks.  Even though the waiter brought the wrong appetizer and the drinks were a bit delayed, this place has incredible food.  The location on the pier is also ideal..  It is a large space with energy.  I highly recommend this place and I'm looking forward to future  visits.
author: Stacy C.

description: i really liked La Mar.  we sat at the bar, so i cant really say anything about the main dining room.  the bar was quite pleasant.  we were having convos with the bartender there, who was very nice.  i honestly dont remember what cocktails i had, but both were very good.  we ordered small plates of food, because we wanted to try more stuff on the menu (it was my first time).  we had the causas, which is basically stuff on top of purple potato.   the veggie causa was good.  the dungeoness crab causa was my favorite -- all flavor minus the fishiness.  now, the mahi mahi causa....not good.  ours in particular tasted overwhelmingly fishy and tough.  i am not a big fish eater, but i have tried mahi mahi in hawaii, and it was flaky and tender and remarkably unfishy in taste and smell, and my more fish savvy dinner companion confirmed it was no bueno.  the sauce on the causas was fantastic on all of them regardless of the protein.  anyways, the best part of the meal was definitely the lomo saltado spring rolls....thats right, peruvian eggrolls!!  i could eat 100 of them.  they were that good.  i definitely plan to go back....when i am richer.  with so many good restaurants to go to, with so little money, this one may take a while to get back to the top of the rotation, as La Mar is quite expensive.
author: Christian C.

description: what i really love here is the chips they serve before the meal - its a bowl of banana, sweet potato, and potato chips accompanied by three different sauces by order of spiciness. i would take this over bread any day. awesome cebiches, great calamari. the presentation is awesome, the location of this restaurant is awesome as well. its gorgeous inside, with a great view of the water. for dessert, try those pumpkin donuts, and MUST get the tiramisu - its coupled with coffee beans, great touch.
author: Angie K.

description: This place had me at...well, my first bite of vegetarian cebiche. I finally understand what all the hype is about. Love the open, natural feel of the restaurant, and the views are unbeatable. Just be sure to go when you are not going to be paying - perfect place to dine with your expense account.
author: kirti p.

description: Seafood so fresh! Food so delicious! Wish I could come back again and again if it wasn't for wallet-itous! Street parking was a bit of a hassle as the meter is limited to maximum of 30 minutes even though the sign on the meter indicates a 4 hour limit in the evening. There is valet parking for $20 (versus $2 for 4-hour street parking). Hostess suggested that just think of the ~$50 parking ticket as a very expensive cocktail drink?? That was the only non-sense of the meal. Otherwise, staff was attentive and food arrived tasty and relatively quick. Peruvian drinks were also tasty and worth trying!
author: V V.

description: 2 pisco sours and two appies later, i am a fan.  pisco, where have you been all my life?!  lovely setting, delicious food and drinks.  hot chef.
author: e w.

description: Good happy hour - spot to go if you like Peruvian brews
author: N.R. G.

description: I was there last night and sat around the blue-lit fish bar in the main room.  This area was empty but the hostess constrained us to sit at one area because we'd be better served on that side...but that took away being able to look out the window onto the Bay.  This is a pretty big place, and it's just west of the Ferry Building.  First, those chips are amazing - they are freshly made daily.  The waitress gave us a good education about the ins & outs of Peruvian food.  We tried the samplers and had the steak as a main entree.  The highlight for me was the octopus on a skewer.  Wow!  All were just fine.  We also had Pisco Sours and a "madaline?" and I was happy with them.  They only disappointment was Tres Leches dessert - it was not impressive.  I had the Tres Leches at the Peruvian place on Fillmore in Pac Heights last week and it was in a whole different league.  Overall a nice dining experience, and on the expensive side, but given the location and the ambiance, it was close to worth it.
author: Robert N.

description: Went there with some friends tonight and was pleasantly surprised.  Since there were a few of us, we were able to order the sample cebiche as well as the sample empanadas.  The cebiche consisted of 4 different types of fish (halibut, ahi, bass and one other) marinated different styles and it was quite tasty.  The empanada sampler consisted of 4 small empanadas, similar to the size of a fried dumpling.  Again, very tasty, $18 is too much for the portion.  My entree was exceptionally tasty- the arroz jugoso.  The seafood was so fresh and it is cooked in the clay dish, similar to a cippino sauce.  I think I had the best dish out of the group of friends.  The friends ordered the lomo saltado which is like beef tenderloin simmered with french fries.  Although I didn't taste the dish, they seemed to enjoy it.  All in all, I would definitely go back and order the arroz jugoso again.  I hear they have happy hour where the appetizers are much cheaper so that's probably a better deal.  By the time we left ~ 8:30pm, the place was packed on a Wednesday night, and it's a large place.
author: Suzi T.

description: We (a party of 6 people) came here Saturday for dinner, and were promptly seated at 5:30 pm and immediately received by our waiter who explained the restaurant and the menu. I have to admit the menu looked amazing, there was a dictionary page to help the customer understand the different dishes which helped out tremendously. The drinks were delicious and very potent... I ordered Pisco Sour, Chucha tu Ma, and about 2 more ... I was going down the list, I was in liquor heaven. We then moved on to the appetizers, which were very small but delicious. We started off with the Cebiche Tasting platter, I have to admit it was excellent BUT SMALL... not enought for 6 people. We moved on to the Anticucho, delicious BUT SMALL. There were only 4 pieces, not enough for 6 people, so we all took a bite and passed it on. There were chips made of Yucca, banana and sweet potato with dipping sauces which were amazing. I've never had anything like it before. I ordered the Lomo Saltado as the entree (5 STARS) and great portion.  By the time we left (around 7:30 pm) the whole place was packed. The restaurant is located in a great location, it's very large with great views, there is parking located adjacent to the restaurant which made it very convenient. Of course, it's not free but it's convenient. The bar/lounge/restaurant is decorated very Miami'ish. I'll definately come back and sample other dishes and drinks!
author: Amber U.

description: Very unique and delicious.  Both atmosphere and food are fun, exciting and new.  Excellent service and attention to detail.  A great place for both a casual lunch or a night on the town.  If you like to try new tastes in a great atmosphere this is the spot.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
I searched the menu online and it looked so interesting with a large variety of seafood and exotic ingredients. When I arrived at the restaurant, it looked very hoity-toity for a young fraternity crowd. There was a flood of  sparkly tops, high heals, and button down striped shirts... which made me dubious. 
However.... hoooowwevvverrr, once we were seated we had a great view of the open kitchen, and when I looked around, it seemed as though everybody in the restaurant had a great view no matter where they were sitting. 
Then we were given complimentary sweet potato, plantain, and potato chips with three great sauces, which ranged from sweet to spicy. I am not a fan of potato chips, but the sweet potato and plantain chips were delicious. 
The waiter was very helpful in guiding us through the menu and recommending the perfect amount of food, while also getting a taste of everything. 
The best of the evening was the grilled octopus, which resemble street food. The sauce on it was amazing, and the octopus was soo sweet and so tender. 
Everything that we ordered was a complete experience - visual, taste, and even surprises that occur. There was a slight spice to everything, but nothing that would kill your palate.
We were way to full for dessert, but they all looked great. 
In the end we left very happy, and I can't wait to recommend it to more people!
author: Alexandra a.

description: went there for new years. so the location was great for seeing fireworks. our server was really nice. the appetizers were good. better than the entree. i ordered the fish of the day..seabass. but the seabass was overcooked and the sauce was not great. it was a strong sweet/tangy sauce that didn't compliment the fish. it seemed like a similiar sauce on the rib eye my bf ordered. another person in my group asked for some items on the side but it didn't come out that way. everything was on the plate. so our server tried to be accommodating but im not sure why they didnt offer to redo the dish the way it was requested. it was a bone-in rib eye but no bone. boo...
author: Master C.

description: Wow!  This restaurant blew me away!  What gorgeous and fun ambiance!  And the food is just amazing.  We sat at the bar and had a pisco sour and a pisco punch before ordering a ceviche and empanadas.  There's a lot of care that goes into making the food as well as the drinks; every dish and drink was aesthetically beautiful!  Just a great place for the senses...it's wonderful to be dining is such a beautiful spot on amazing food.
author: Samantha G.

description: Hands down one of the best meals I have ever had.  From the mahi ceviche to start, to the pepper-crusted ahi for the entree, to the chocolate crepe for dessert.  It was absolutely, mouth-wateringly delicious.  This being said from someone who's not even a huge seafood fan.  Absolutely excellent.
author: Sweet B.

description: This review is strictly for the bar and the awesome bartenders. After a day of movie watching and pupusa eating we had time to kill waiting for our ferry. We decided to look for a place near the embarcadero to have a cocktail at. I remembered that I had walked by this place at lunch on a weekday and thought, 'very pretty, must come back' so we decided to mosey up to the bar. Oh and so glad we did, we first decided to try a couple of Pisco drinks, since its the Peruvian liquor and this is a Peruvian restaurant. We had a Monje verde and a Pisco sour both were good but not great to our liking so we decided to switch to Tequila. And OMG what an extensive list of tequila do they have, they had 7 Leguas which is my recent discovery and had shots of that. The bartenders were so attentive and nice. The gave us 'leftover' pisco sours for free and let us try the chicha something other for free too, which of course they make themselves, sorry to say I didn't like it because it's infused with cloves but my cousin loved it. The bartenders simply rocked. They were so nice and chit chatted about our movie with us and were at all times anxious to get us whatever we needed. We will definitely be back to try the dinner menu because it looked awesome, somewhat pricey but fascinating to say the least.
author: La C.

description: Delicious! Went for lunch and tried most of the sampler platters. Everything was good, most of it being excellent. Great presentation, awesome space, though the waiters could be slightly more knowledgeable about the food (or Peruvian, for that matter...). The scallop entree was incredible. Can't wait to go back and try more.
author: Xander M.

description: This is a great place for happy hour! I tried several of the appetizers which were small in size but very tasty and filling. I am not a big fan of Yucca, however I will admit that the way it was cooked was DELISH! I also tried some of the cebiche mixto,  chicharrón de calamar and the platano chips! Talk about being creative with your menu!  Loved it! - Ohh as for cocktails I recommend the chicha tu ma! Taste like passion fruit but two will have you feeling warm and fuzzy inside.
author: Evangelina M.

description: Goodness gracious......YUM!!!! i love the food here. i've eaten in this restaurant twice and the one in lima, peru. the food is so fresh and tasty.............ceviche is amazing and we also had a portobello mushroom on quinoa which was soooooooooooo good!  i also love the pisco sours and the bright, lively atmosphere. it's my new favorite restaurant!!!
author: Diana S.

description: Went to LaMar on 8/10/09 service was outstanding, informative, the food was so well presented and flavors were outstanding.  The cebiche sampler was so great along with the Mahi skewer.   Waiter recommended a Spanish wine that was perfect with the seafood pallet.  Wine was reasonable as he didnt try to upsell us.  Restaurant was so colorful, tasteful decor and a beautiful water front view.  I highly recommend La Mar.  Staff did not rush us as we spent 2 hours truly dining and savoring the experience.
author: Jim H.

description:
went there yesterday for lunch, simply amazing.....
clean modern style with clean lines but not cold.

the waitress was friendly, helpful and the food was unbelievable.

so were the drinks!
author: Brad T.

description: I loved trying several different varieties of cebiche at a party I recently attended.  Even the free appetizer, potato chips with three types of ahi sauces was excellent.  The lomo saltado had such a good cut of meat.  And the chicha tu ma (a drink with purple corn and alcohol) was also wonderful.  The interior design was also very aesthetically pleasing (high ceilings, modern) and the patio in the back would be perfect to enjoy a sunny lunch downtown.
author: M R.

description: I'm sort of mixed on this one. The location is AMAZING. Great light open space that didn't feel crowded. We had reservations and were still waiting for 1 when we asked to be seated on time. The snotty hostess told us we had to order "immediately" upon sitting down. Immediately??? Really??? So anyway, bad taste in our mouths but the server was super friendly and rolled his eyes when we told him that. The food was really good although the empanadas were a bit greasy for us. Everything else was very tasty. I have to say I would definately return to try out more dishes. We filled up on the yummy dried plantains and sweet potatoes before hand so save some room!
author: LiL R.

description: Beautiful environment, so-so food, definitely not worth the exorbitant price. Worst service I've experienced in at least 2 years. Go to Limon, better ceviche, less attitude.
author: Lorinda C.

description: huge restaurant and bar, with a view of the water.  apparently they are known for their ceviche, which i thought was good.  but the rest of their food was delicious too.  we shared a few things, appetizers and entrees.  there were a lot of choices, in fact that would be one of the reasons i would go back again, to try more.  great cocktails too!
author: Carolyn B.

description: i like their piscos. good spot for drinks before a good reggae show on pier 23....mellow and good service. their ceviches are tasty
author: aldo x.

description:
Service is zero.
On Oct 3rd we had a reservation for 4 people at 9pm. My husband and I (temporary on crutches) got there at 8:55pm. Because our friends were not there yet they didn't want to seat us. They asked to be standing in a bar and wait until all the parties get there before seat us. We didn't go to the bar because there were no seats for me, instead we waited at lounge where we asked a nice couple if we would share their couch with us. My friends got there at 9:15pm and my husband went to talk to the hostess we were ready. One of their hostess looked at her watch and said, well, it's kind of late now BUT we will seat you. Finally, at 9:40pm they seated us. Waiter? Serves first the gentleman, then the women and takes forever to come back to serve us...cleaning glasses and not even aware of us while waiting for at least our drinks. My friend asked 1/2 portion and they brought 1...just one of the details.
Very disappointed. In SF people are so nice and polite, especially with me, now  on crutches, and at this place they didn't even care to find a seat for me.
Go for the food though.
author: val m.

description: I had dinner here on a Friday night. I'm unsure about parking but we parked in a meter across the street, which was difficult to determine monitored times. Whatever, it worked...Upon walking in, it seemed like the place was filled with financial district, new money snobs. We were minutes late for our reservation and told it would be a little bit of time by the seemingly cold ladies at the host stand. We went to the bar area and the host came back and was suddenly quite friendly and informing us that our table was nearly ready. Great. The dining room is large and very, VERY pretty. I loved it. Medium brown wood floors, white trim, skylights, pretty lights, GREAT views of the water, and pops of blue everywhere. Very nice! The starter plantain chips came with a trio of sauces--one seemed like psiracha, one of cilantro and another one, which I couldn't determine the main flavor. Very good. We then got the cebiche mixo consisting of white fish, calamari, octopus, habanero, giant corn, cilantro. It was fantastic and I was happy with the assistant took the bowl away bc I kept trying to find things to drink up the broth/citrus sauce. YUM. 9/10. We then had the empanada sampler which consisted of four different flavors--steak, mushroom, seafood and chicken. By looks, the chicken would be my least favorite but it ended up the opposite. 8/10. We then had the carne skewers with fried potatoes, huge corn and sauce. YUM-O. The steak and potatoes were fantastic!! 10/10. Last, we had the lomo saltado, beef tenderloin, sauced veggies and some rice/corn with butter. While very good, I think we overdid the steak dishes at that point and were quite satisfied. Good, but I'd try another of the mains next time. 7/10. For dessert we have the orange glaze beignet with a chocolate, almost melty Nutella sauce inside and subbed out the lemongrass ice cream with the mango sorbet. YUM but again over indulgence. 8/10. Coffee was very delicious. All-in-all a great meal definitely worth a return trip. Dinner for 2 plus drinks/dessert = $190 and very worthwhile!
author: Chris H.

description: La Mar is an electric gourmet experience. Try the empanada and cebiceria sampler plates along with the daily specials. The chocolate donuts are  smooth as silk and soft as satin. Although the menu is extensive and overwhelming, waiters are incredibly knowledgeable and intuitive. La Mar is the best new restaurant in San Francisco for 2009. You won't be disappointed unless you think you can get a walkin reservation on a hopping Saturday night. Call ahead and you won't be disappointed.
author: mike m.

description: Food here is great!  Ceviche plate is nicely done, super good and you get a variety of flavors, scallops are pretty amazing as well!
author: Emily H.

description: Muy bien!  The food is awesome.  Try the empenadas, they are the bomb.  I will repeat!
author: Tim J.

description: I went there the night before my birthday with friends and I had the chance to try a lot of their samplers such cebiche, empanada and another one that I don't remember the name. I had as main course the Lomo saltado and tried the Camarones  I honestly liked everything I tasted, good flavors, excellent preparation and presentation. The deserts were delicious as well, I wish I had more room to finish them all!!! The restaurant is beautiful too,good lightings and decor and it looks very clean it's a good atmosphere and vibe. I have a crush on the restaurants on Embarcadero where you can see the ocean especially at night time, it makes me feel on vacation. 4 stars because the second time the waiter brought us the sparkling rosé didn't let us know that the bottle wasn't cold enough to be served but he just opened and pour it pretended he didn't realize it...We all did by the way...But we didn't care at the end we had a great experience, but it shouldn't have happened in a Restaurant like La Mar.
author: claudia c.

description: Great Peruvian restaurant!  The food is very, very good, and the decor is very swanky and hip.  Loss of one star just based on the prices.
author: Sonia S.

description: After hearing several rave reviews about La Mar, I finally tried it for a work dinner.  Honestly, it was a total disappointment.  The food was good but far from great.  The ceviche (tuna, curry fish), dessert (donuts filled with chocolate, onion rings with molasses syrup), empanadas and malbec (luca) were pretty good.  But, the main courses and the servers were uninteresting and worthless, respectively.  From the beginning, I expected the server to charge the "standard" gratuity for more than six people...and he did not disappoint me/us.  There are many, many restaurants in San Francisco which merit a return visit but not this one.  Fine but pass.
author: Courtenay B.

description:
-1 for service and the unfortunate, poor quality of the ceviche.
The last 2 times we went, the food was good overall, but the ceviche was a disappointment.  The fish was very fresh, but unfortunately, underflavored.  A good ceviche soaks in the leche de tigre, and the fish then tastes salty, sour, just like the leche.
But the major disappointments as in the beginning is still the service.  We went with friends, and the waitress spilled a bottle full beer which she'd just served us.  It should have been replaced (no offer) or she should have left it off the check.  No.  We had to ask her to.
The last time we went, we waited 15 min. before we finally signalled someone for service.  Because the 2 or 3 servers that were walking around, hadn't "NOTICED" us.  And the service afterwards was uneven, some dishes came fairly promptly, others no.  
Good, attentive service has been an issue with La Mar since the beginning, and they've had enough time to get organized.  And now, even the food, ceviche specifically, isn't that great.
Mr. Acurio should sit up and pay attention, this La Mar is not elevating his reputation.
author: H K.

description: Lovely restaurant with lots of bright aqua everywhere.  I thought the food was overpriced.  Most entrees were about $29.  I got the risotto for $19, and although it tasted very good, it really was just a plate of rice.  For an appetizer I got some sort of mashed potato topped with avocado, dungeness crab, and quail egg.  This also tasted very good, but I wouldn't go back to the restaurant for it.  I found the potatoes to be a bit too sour for my taste.  Dessert was the best part.  We got the chocolate beignets.  I just realized that they were supposed to be coated with an orange flavor, but I didn't taste any orange.  They were chocolatey good though.  Also, I often judge a restaurant by their coffee.  I thought that for the prices La Mar was charging, the coffee was some of the worst--very sour/acidic and they gave me what seemed to be skim milk.  What is the point of putting white-colored water in my coffee?  In my opinion, a good restaurant should give you half and half.  Our waitress was very pleasant and attentive.
author: Kandi K.

description: Great ambiance, lots of fun and good for groups. Very interesting assortment of cocktails using Peruvian liqueurs. I'd recommend sticking with the tapas, especially the ceviche and seafood is very good. I also enjoyed the rice dishes. The desserts are just so-so.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Had a reservation at the restaurant Saturday evening hoping to have a nice meal and drinks with a friend. We were stuck in traffic - so tried to call to let them know that we were running a little late. However, there was only the answering machine picking up the calls. We  arrived 13 min. late. Once we got there the two front desk ladies notified us that they gave our table away and it would be 30-45 minutes to get another table.  Apparently, it's their policy to release the reservation if you don't show up within 15 minutes. I can accept that. However, I cannot accept that they released it before 15 minutes was up. I also could not accept their non-accommodating and cold customer service. We left the place disappointed and have no desire to go back anytime soon. After all, there are so many great restaurants in San Francisco.
author: The Critic A.

description: I took my wife yesterday to san francisco to celebrate our wedding anniversary and since I'm peruvian and she's not I decided to take her to " La Mar Restaurant " after reading all these reviews. We had our reservation set @ 8pm we got there at 7:50pm they sat us right away, we sat in the yard where it's headed with good lighting,very intimate and nice. Now the food was nicely decorated but " The cebiche " isn't authentic, too many extras and it kills the flavor. The dinner menu is very poor, so we order " Anticuchos, Causas, Ceviche, & Lomo Saltado " We wanted to taste a little bit of everything and of course we had 4 alcohol drinks " Pisco Sour " Our server was kind and came to check on us a couple of times. Why would I rate a star? Here it is, the use of the peruvian sauces " Huancaina " it gets used for everything almost, our bill came out to $135 I was surprise but I didn't mind since it is our wedding anniversary, and plus we had more plans after so I tip our server $7 dollars so as we walking out, I was confronted by our server about my tip, he demanded more money, he claimed that for the tip I left to him it is like he paid for us to sit at our table, I told him thats not right and offered to give a good comment if there was a comment box and he replied if there was one to dropped money in there instead. He was angry, disrespectful and ungrateful. He kept mentioning my bill of $135 he didnt have much to attend since it was just myself and my wife, I really wanted to insult the man and even talk to his manager but I wasn't going to ruin my wife's night. This restaurants, because of him reminded me of those cheap restaurants where the waiters expect big tips of $20 and up. A better peruvian restaurant in located in South Vaness where the ambient is private calm and elegant, I shouldve taken my wife out there but we wanted to try something new. Don't be fool by decorated plates, peruvian food is all about taste, criolle food that is best made at home.
author: Manuel S.

description: Ok I haven't actually tried the food here but walked past it today after eating at The Plant next door. This place looks very promising, great outdoor patio in the back and menu also looks yummy. A bit pricey so would be great to get some deals maybe from buywithme or dine about town. Will update after I get a chance to actually try it out
author: F F.

description: good food, attentive staff, great atmosphere and space. notice i mentioned food FIRST, over the space/decor-- if it was the other way around, i'd say avoid the place. but i Do remember the food first; fresh and tasty. my only regret is i didn't go with a larger party so i could have tried more dishes family style!  definitely going back for more.
author: eriin w.

description: Went for lunch in a group of four.  Tried several of the cebiches, and the octopus and salmon skewers.  Food was good, not great.  Service sucked ass - unbelievably slow, and one item never made it.  2 stars because the place is clean and on the water.  Will not be returning anytime soon.
author: Manuel A.

description: This place, while pretty with good food, has the worst service in San Francisco.  The hostess is disorganized and even when slow there's a long wait to be seated;  the waiter, while pleasant, does nothing to ensure your food is good or timely; 35 minutes for a (cold appetizer);  no one to stop by to see if your food is to your liking--which should happen at these prices--and a horrendous wait for the check until you virtually shriek for help.  Avoid it until they work out the kinks, then go back for the nice setting and the interesting menu.
author: lynne h.

description: My first experience (November 2008) was superb and I raved to all my friends. Sadly, each time I return the service and food become progressively disappointing. Last visit (June 2009) we were seated 45 minutes after our reservation time, with not much care from the hostesses. Then 2 of our 3 dishes came out wrong from the kitchen (that doesn't look like octopus). And everyone I know who's been there has experienced the same dish mix up. I love the decor, whether inside, outside or just at the bar, but I think the staff  has been unable to manage the large volume of diners. If you're looking for a wonderful ceviche experience, but without the bay view, try Fresca.
author: Tracy P.

description: Ok so the food was great but never had such rude or bad service in my many years of going to great restaurants. It starts with being told that we only had 2 hours for our reservation. It was then followed by extremely tardy service - food took extremely long to come, drinks we had to ask for 3 times. - it took over an hour to get them. The kicker was when the two hours were up and our dinner was just removed because of the poor service, our check was placed in the middle of the table without asking. We gathered telling us not-so-subtly to leave. This was before we were asked if we cared for any dessert. It was followed by the manager had asking us to leave when we requested dessert menus. While they did make good once we explained the situation, it never should have happened. On the good side the food was very good and the atmosphere was too.
author: Robin C.

description: I love this place. Pricie but good. Came here with friends last Saturday, spent $300 but the upside is that they still have the same outstanding service as they would on the weekday even if it were super busy.  Such fresh and clean seafood. Downside is it's hard to get reservations on the weekend. Must have pull for last minute reservation.
author: Sofia B.

description: Great fun place for groups or celebrations or even just lunch :) The colors and flavors of the food really add to a festive atmosphere helped no doubt by the pisco sours! Bold, bright interior with food to match - all the cebiches are delicious and the sweet potato chips with three sauces dangerously addictive! The picarones for dessert are baby doughnuts made of sweet potato and pumpkin with a chancaca sauce - like a caramel sauce made from sugar cane and orange juice. Writing this makes me want to go back - La Mar will make you happy :)
author: Barbara L.

description: Great restaurant! . Peruvian seafood that is very innovative and delicious. The food is excellent. The service was very attentive and friendly. It may be a bit pricey for some but definitely a restaurant for a special occasion. It's at the waterfront on the Embarcadero not far from the Ferry Building with a view of boats and the bay. Highly recommended!
author: Ian I.

description: I was thoroughly happy with their ceviches.  Their lomo saltado though was not what I would call traditional.  Taste was good, but I was disappointed because I was expecting a real lomo saltado.  But this is a funky fresh new place... maybe they just don't do tradition!  Service was sloooooow (took three hours before we got around to even ordering dessert, and we finished eating the meal in about 30 minutes!) but pleasant in a don't-bother-me-euro type of way.  Their pisco sour was strong!  Yum. =)  Overall, I'd come back on the company dime, or for a really special occasion (es muy caro!), and when I had plenty of time to just relax and hang out.
author: Cat M.

description: Went here for lunch after going to the Farmer's Market.  I was really fascinated with the color scheme in the restaurant.  Most of the walls were white and brown, but the table mats, plates and chairs were all bright, fluorescent colors, making everything stand out.  Liked the daily specials written on the chalkboard at the top of the ceviche bar.  We started off with some pisco drinks, which were both very tasty.  The plantain and potato chips and dipping sauces continued the "colorful" theme and were very tasty, each providing something different.  We started with the ceviche tasting.  Each had its own unique taste; I especially liked the mixto, which had the perfect blend of everything.  We also had the causa sampler, which again was very colorfully presented.  All three were very good as well, although a little salty for my taste.  Finally, we shared the arroz norteno which was out of this world!!   I could definitely have that everyday; a perfect mix of spices/herbs, seafood and rice.  We ended the meal with some very good sangria.  The setting is beautiful right on the waterfront.  My only complaint; the service was a little slow as the place got busy.  But the food is awesome.
author: Keith M.

description: I went here on a friday nite, with rsvp @ 7pm, our party was seated within 5 minutes of our rsvp, which is always nice! it was pretty crowded with ppl overflowing from the bar area, but the place is pretty big so i never   felt cramped.  the food is soooo good! but what was even better were the drinks!!! omgosh, i had 3 and wanted more! so yummy!!! would love to go back again.
author: Tricia L.

description:
food - meh
service - eh
ambiance/crowd - the bowel contents of a junior trading desk after a couple of red bull and vodkas, poured over some east bay cleavage
author: ilya a.

description: La Mar is a great place for both its ambiance and its food.  They have a great selection of ceviche's, although ic an say that they all needed a little more flavor (it seemed like salt was lacking 100%).  I felt the same way about my scallop main course.  The lamb shank is just okay.  The crusted ahi tuna is amazing, the hamachi version of sashimi was skimpy and flavorless.  The atmosphere is great and it's a great place for groups.  As far as desserts go, the sorbet is fantastic, the chocolate.  The service was terrible, our waiter spent most of the night chatting with another waiter while our water glasses remained empty and the attention between dishes was non-existent.
author: Ashley K.

description: Uh... WOW!  I say "ceviche" they say "cebiche" but it's all delicious.  All their variations are pretty amazing.  I'm a BIG fan of ceviche, both the Mexican style, chopped up with cilantro, onions, lime, etc, and the Peruvian version with the solid filet of fish and big corn.  BIG fan of both.  The stuff from La Mar is seriously in another level.  You're basically having sashimi with a Peruvian twist.  Amazing!  Nikkei is my personal favorite, but try the Cebiche Mixto on your first visit so you can pick your own reson-for-living. The grilled octopus (anticucho de pulpo) is another fenomenal dish.  Potato dishes, another winner.  The lomo saltado is just "ok" defintely not the reason to come here.   Stick with the seafood dishes, like all of the aforemetioned, or something like the  Arroz Norteño (seafood rice similar to Paella) and you will no doubt be a regular here.  ...and OH, Pisco Sours are dangerously good.  I prefer mine with no egg.  Given that I'm not training for a boxing match, I order an eggless version, which the call a "gimlet".  Uh, ok, sure.  They can call it "stanley" if they want, just get a couple in front of me.
author: Moz R.

description:
Very nice ambiance....and that's it. As for Peruvian food, if you really never taste Peruvian food, you would know that the food had nothing of Peruvian taste!!!!!!!Very disappointing. It was all looks, no real Peruvian food. It has been prepared so different than the original recipes, that it really didn't seem to me that I was tasting  Peruvian food. Besides that the waitress was very inattentive and offer very poor service. We had to remind her so many times of what we had order........... . We waited around 35 minutes to be served, I ordered a Cusquena and the server didn't even remember that i had order it. When asked she mentioned that they were out of Cusquena's.......
My overall experience was disappointing, I thought I would find better food, nicer service, for that price!!!!!! It's probably amazing for someone that never tried real Peruvian food, but for Peruvians not impressive at all.
author: MP T.

description: was there this evening with friends for the first time..yum yum..tasty cebiche..great space n location..started with the tasting cebiche mix..yum,scallops,soup n more..we  ordered a few more dishes to sample..all good,..coming back for more..great spot to bring out of towners as well..luv it..
author: lovetoeat n.

description: Being a Bolivian married to a Peruvian, I had high expectations and La Mar pretty much met them all.   The restaurant definitely has a great vibe and the close seating encourages you to chat with fellow patrons.   We started off with tiradito chifa- very refreshing and decent sized portion of yellowtail tuna, my favorite dish by far.  Followed by empanada de choclo also tasty and anticuchos served with the red "rocoto" sauce (just the right amount of heat).  This sauce was amazing and we ordered more of it for our dishes that followed.  If you don't order anticuchos or ask for it you will miss out!  We then had causa de ahi also amazing, and then split the seabass which was underwhelming after all the delicious apps.  Service was friendly, and quick.  We'll be flying from SD to SF more often just to come back to La Mar.  And don't forget to order the pisco sours, by far the best pisco sours outside of Peru.
author: Gabriela M.

description:
La Mar is the latest import from Lima, Peru offering contemporary Peruvian ceviche with local and Japanese. A very high-end take on what was historically a low-end fisherman's food, La Mar is situated on the Embaracadero waterfront in a hip, modern (and blue) space to thoroughly enjoy sipping Pisco sours while dining on fresh seafood. 

Now I could run  through all the items I've personally had, but to save time, I'll summaries it as follows: (1) This is obvious, but for first timers, order the cebiche tasting. You'll get 4 ceviches to try. I'm a fan of the nikei and mixto.  Additionally, if you want just the singles, I also like the crudo (the shellfish ceviche; (2) You may want to pass on the menu or just ask the server for his best suggestion. Generally, I wasn't too impressed with non-ceviche items. I suppose dishes like the camarones grillado or lamb shank were pretty good. I'd probably recommend you take this opportunity to down a few more pisco sours, to build up my courage, and order off the various specials they may have; Lastly, (3) Unless you have a Peruvian friend, it may be tough to figure out what's good/bad. So be adventurous. Or ask me and I'll refer you to one - they're such nice people and would love to try to convince you the food is appropriately priced. =) Oh, and be wary of the bar tab. It's rather easy to drop $200 on food while another $200 on pisco sours. 

Parking, like all restaurants on the waterfront, is a drag. Be prepared to pay for $20 parking next to the restaurant (through the causeway) or on the street followed by a brisk walk. Reservations are highly recommended if you want to get out of the bar area (although you can order food at the bar as well).

Service is such a stickler for me. As some of the other reviewers have mentioned, the staff here does not seem fully up to speed on the menu (or the drinks). My Peruvian had to correct the server a couple of times during my initial visit. On subsequent visits, I've noticed servers giving contradictory information. It's a fairly new restaurant, so I'll cut them some slack, but I think this should be solved by now, no? 

All in all, an upscale dining experience. A good "take your date and impress her" place.
author: George K.

description: Bring 2 tin cans and string... you'll have a better time trying to have a conversation.  This place is beyond loud.  Would never go back based on that alone.  But then there's the mediocre food.  This place belongs in Fisherman's Wharf... that's about the level of food they make.  Honestly, there were no highlights... well  one, my Campari and soda.
author: Marty B.

description: This wins the best new restaurant award for 2008 and best new Peruvian in the city! You can't go wrong with the any of the Ceviches or Causas, Octopus skewers, Lomo Saltado beef dish, seafood rice paella style. You'll love the comp peruvian style chips and dips, I couldn't get enough, and don't go home without trying the pisco sour or seniorita, which is like a pisco apple martini! The desserts are so authentic, I'm sure you'll never have tried them before. The place is definitely pricey, but it's worth it if you want the scene and vibe, you'll have a great time here, and the service is great. Just love it.
author: Elle L.

description: it was very good food i love  cebiche and drink pisco sour i will go next time and try some more choice
author: sunny p.

description: I was there to meet my old friend.  We sat at the bar and order 4 dishes from Menu. The food was fantastic and tasty!!! Bartenders are very friendly and helpful. recommend this place for happy hours!!!
author: Grace C.

description: La Mar's front end/service is just what you would expect of an oversized new restaurant: confused.  My party literally had to guide the bar service staff through each mini-step of the table service of six or seven small plates.  By the fourth plate and ware change the busser sort of had the hang of it.  Having visited Peru multiple times for month's on end I can say the dishes most closely resembling "tipical" were the best.  "Causas" are downright bad which is surprising considering how naturally tasty Peruvian yellow potatoes are.  Only the Ceviche clasico was rewarding and I found myself literally drinking the extra sauce which was complex, spicy and refreshing.  The crab stuffed empanadas with quail egg and leche de tigre were also great with the classic pastry shape and fried texture exactly like those experienced in Empanada-City B.A. (don't believe the weaker baked version touted by Chilenos).  Also remarkable; the Pulpo antichuchos.  Everything else was a redundancy and dissapointing.  The exterior of the restaurant, waterside, fits perfectly with the Embarcadero's brass and concret.  As the moon rose above the Pier in the purple dusk light and oily boat swells lapped the pylons I felt another Cusqueno backed by another Sour were in order.  Really, for now, La Mar is what you make of it.
author: The I.

description:
We really wanted to like this place. It's close to our condo, we've been watching the build-out of this beautiful location, and we love cebiche. However, although the cebiche is pretty good, it's just not great. I've had much better at many seafood stands and restaurants in Mexico and Costa Rica and at far less than half the price. I know my ceviche and  make a much better version myself frankly.
As far as experience, we received a call yesterday morning at 9, warning us that they were 100% booked and that if we were 15 minutes late, we'd lose our reservation. This was a pre-theatre reservation, which I related to the hostess, letting her know we'd be on time and would not linger as I thought this would be useful to their table planning on a busy night. We arrived at 5:15 and checked in before heading for the bar (we knew they wouldn't start serving until 5:30 but that the bar was open). Good pisco sours. Then another. Still no table until 5:50, so much for timing. The hostesses and bartenders, and the wait and table staff couldn't have been nicer, though the waiter was a bit verbose (to his credit though, many people may not know about Peruvian food, and he was just very thorough with his explanations and likes-and-dislikes). 
Food portions are very small for the price... and the cebiches have very few pieces of fish. Also, the beef dish is really good but again, not much steak in the portion. The braised lamb shank was a normal-sized portion, but really really mushy and not that flavorful (yes, it's braised, but nothing was done to make it savory, just a dash of broiling or glazing after the braise would have done wonders). I had starters for dinner and the octopus skewers and empanadas were the best things our party of 4 ordered. We had the creme brulee taster for dessert, it was okay.
They've got a good/reasonable wine list with some of our favorite Malbecs and Chards, some which we've only found in Argentina. 
The room is beautiful, though they could use some art on the walls. 
Bottom line, the food was good but not that great. I think food-wise, Limon is better unless all you're after is ceviche, really small portions of very watery ceviche.  This will be a go-to place for us for a drink and appetizer, especially next spring once the deck opens up, but won't be rushing there for dinner.
author: Rose A.

description: I heard good things about this space and I was excited to go check it out after work on a Thursday. I heard the food was a bit overpriced, but that it was a good place to grab a drink before dinner.  Unfortunately, I may have received some bad advice as the bar is actually just a tiny room facing the street instead of the water.  The bar room was packed at 6pm although the ceviche bar and dining area were pretty empty.  Since there was not a single place to sit, I asked the hostess if we could order a drink and sit in the ceviche bar/lounge area which was huge and empty.  She said that she could only sit us there if we were having food.  So we stood in a corner next to where they pile glasses and left as soon as we finished one pisco sour.  It seems to me like a very poor use of the space and bad businees to discourage the happy hour cocktail crowd.
author: d q.

description: My first experience at La Mar was good enough for me to plan a dinner there for some out of town colleagues.  I thought the location would be great for people to see the view and the service was great the first time (waiter was Jesse and he was wonderful).  Now I have a completely different view of La Mar and will not be back.  They make you go through their event planner and pick a set menu for parties of 8 or more.  That's expected for parties of 12, 15, 20 but since when is 8 a large party?  Think it's a tactic to mark up their prices.  In addition, their event planner, Mayra, is mean and unhelpful.  And they make you sit in their lounge, which is a table near the bar that has no view.  We could have been in an airport restaurant.  I'd think a restaurant that gets a party of 8 on a slow night would give at least good service but we actually got worse service than if we'd been a party of 3.  Wish I'd cancelled and booked this dinner some place else.
author: C S.

description: stylish, cold,and disappointing, from the surly host who wouldn't seat us until the entire party was present(expected at chez panisse,but this ain't no chez panisse) to the one-dimensional,overly chipotled ceviche, the doughy empanadas, touch beef heart.  all in all, not a success
author: otto v.

description: An interesting experience.  I was skeptical at first, although I love Peruvian food and have been to Peru where of course the food is wonderful.  We decided to stop here at the beginning of happy hour (4-6) before heading over to Ferry Plaza for a cocktail week event (best food by far there were the pork buns from Heaven's Dog).   Shortly after 4 La Mar was deserted.  I walked around outside and was amazed at how large it is, with many different seating areas, inside, outside, bar, counter, etc etc, thinking that this poor place was never going to be able to fill all those seats and stay in business in what must be a super-high rent location.  After a few delightful happy hour pisco sours (only $5!) and possibly the best ceviche I ever had, we headed over to the event, returning hours later to La Mar for a final pisco sour (as if we hadn't already had enough cocktails!).  What a change!  The place was packed (a Wed night no less), thus allaying my needless fears on their behalf.  Return visits to one of my new favorites are definitely in order!
author: David T.

description: mmmmm...it was not what i expected from gaston a. leche de tigre was bland, onions in ceviche were at least a day old, pisco sour was not good, service..... definetly dissapointed!
author: ignacio d.

description: I really didn't care for this restaurant. It has amazing ambiance with great lighting, themed decorations, and a view of the water. BUT, I really think the food is incredibly overpriced for what you get. My husband and I shared a cerviche dish (appetizer) and shared special rice seafood dish and two lemonades, and it was $75 total. There are very few restaurant where you can have one appetizer and one entree and two lemonades for that price. The food was good, but I didn't think it was anything special, and afterward (maybe due to the cerviche classico I ordered) I felt sick to my stomach the next day. We wouldn't go back, just because there are so many other good places in SF worth the money. We also found the hostesses to be rather snooty, although the wait staff was very friendly and knowledgeable. Also, the bathrooms are considered "historically significant "- which means they can paint them and keep them tiny and not so nice. Also, because of the location, the parking isn't great nearby...
author: Jennifer D.

description: delicious, fresh, beautiful food and decor. lots of seafood so not really your place if you want something else. service could have been faster but we were ok with the leisurely pace for easter lunch. recommend the tres leches dessert if it's still on the specials menu.
author: I. K.
